doc_16 |@raw_text From %3A  ray %40 unisql.UUCP (Ray Shea) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Back Breaker, Near Hit!! %0A Message-ID %3A  <5324 %40 unisql.UUCP> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 22 %3A 09 %3A 32 GMT %0A References %3A  <1r941o$3tu %40 menudo.uh.edu> %0A Organization %3A  UniSQL, Inc., Austin, Texas, USA %0A Lines %3A  34 %0A  %0A In article <1r941o$3tu %40 menudo.uh.edu> inde7wv %40 Rosie.UH.EDU writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I understand why you theoretically stop so far behind a car but can you %0A >really in actuality avoid such an incident?  Suggestions? %0A  %0A If you had been looking in your mirror, you would have seen the guy coming  %0A before you heard the screeching tires. %0A  %0A When you're stopped at a light %3A  %0A  %0A 1)  Stop so that you're got space in front of you, and a quick easy escape %0A route (between lanes, into a crosswalk, up a driveway, somewhere) if someone %0A decides they want to plow into you. %0A  %0A 2)  Keep the bike in first with the clutch in until at least a couple of cars %0A are stopped behind you, so you don't have to waste a second you don't have %0A trying to get it in gear if you need to move. %0A  %0A 3)  Watch your mirrors.  In that situation, most of the hazards you are  %0A trying to avoid are coming from behind you.  SIPDE (<-- msf-geek-speak) %0A isn't just for when you're moving.  And you're less likely to panic and stall %0A the bike if you've got time to prepare before the guy's tires lock up behind %0A you.  (You still get the bejeezus scared out of you, but it's more a feeling %0A of quickly-rising dread than a sudden jolt.) %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Ray Shea    		  %0A UniSQL, Inc.		 	 %0A unisql!ray %40 cs.utexas.edu  %0A DoD #0372  %3A  Team Twinkie  %3A  '88 Hawk GT      %0A

doc_44 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Bursters. positional stuff. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr29.010847.1 %40 vax1.mankato.msus.edu> %0A From %3A  belgarath %40 vax1.mankato.msus.edu %0A Date %3A  29 Apr 93 01 %3A 08 %3A 47 -0600 %0A References %3A  <93116.093828SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA>  %0A  <1993Apr26.141114.19777 %40 midway.uchicago.edu> <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A Organization %3A  Mankato State University %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  vax1.mankato.msus.edu %0A Lines %3A  52 %0A  %0A In article <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu>, kwp %40 wag.caltech.edu (Kevin W. Plaxco) writes %3A  %0A > In article <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> abdkw %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov (David Ward) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A >>Given that fact, and the spacecraft attitude knowledge %0A >>of approx. 2 arcmin, we might be able to figure out how well BATSE can %0A >>determine the location (rotational) of a Gamma Ray burster from knowledge %0A >>of the all-sky map's accuracy.  PR material for the other three instruments %0A >>give accuracies on the order of "fractions of a degree", if that's  %0A >>any help. %0A >  %0A > But I believe that there is a fundamental difference here.  The other x %0A > three instruments are focusing instruments, that, more or less, form %0A > an image, so positional errors are limited by craft attitude and the  %0A > resolving power of the optics.  BATSE is an altogether different %0A > beast, effectively just 8 coincidence counters, one on each corner of  %0A > the craft.  Positional information is triangulated from the  %0A > differential signal arrival times at each of the detectors. %0A > Positional error would be predominantly determined by timing errors %0A > and errors in craft attitude. Since none of the 8 BASTE detectors have %0A > any independant angular resolution whatsoever, they can not be used to %0A > determine parallax.  Indeed, parallax would just add a very small  %0A > component to the positional error.   %0A >  %0A > Demonstrating that these puppies are beyond the oort cloud would  %0A > require resolution on the order of arcseconds, since the oort  %0A > cloud is postulated to extend to about 0.5 parsec (all together  %0A > now %3A  "Parallax ARc SECond", a parsec is the distance of an object  %0A > that demonstrates one arc second of parallax with a 2 AU base line). %0A > If the 3 degree accuracy reported above is true, we're going to  %0A > have to add a BASTE to the pluto fast flyby to get enough baseline. %0A >  %0A > The beauty of BASTE is that it both gives positional information and %0A > watches the entire sky simultaneously, a realy handy combination %0A > when you have no idea where the next burst is coming from. %0A >  %0A > -Kevin %0A         Batse alone isn't always used to determine position.  WHen a %0A particularly bright burst occurs, There are a couple of other detectors that %0A catch it going off.  Pioneer 10 or 11 is the one I'm getting at here.  This %0A puppy is far enough away, that if a bright burst happens nearby, the huge %0A annulus created by it will hopefully intersect the line or general circle given %0A by BATSE, and we can get a moderately accurate position. Say oh, 2 or 3 %0A degrees. That is the closest anyone has ever gotten with it.   %0A         Actually, my advisor, another classmate of mine, and me were talking %0A the other day about putting just one detector on one of the Pluto satellites.  %0A THen we realized that the satellite alone is only carrying something like 200 %0A pounds of eq.  Well, a BATSE detector needs lead shielding to protect it, and 1 %0A alone weighs about 200 pounds itself. %0A  %0A         We decided against it. %0A                                                         -jeremy %0A  %0A

doc_51 |@raw_text From %3A  C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu (John Kelsey) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Once they get your keys.... %0A Message-ID %3A  <16BBAC7D3.C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mont.cs.missouri.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  mizzou1.missouri.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Missouri %0A References %3A  <930424031634.176183 %40 DOCKMASTER.NCSC.MIL> <strnlghtC5z0pw.BLH %40 netcom.com> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 93 14 %3A 12 %3A 10 CDT %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A  %0A >In article <930424031634.176183 %40 DOCKMASTER.NCSC.MIL> Grant %40 DOCKMASTER.NCSC.MIL (Lynn R Grant) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >About 50 people so far have asked, "Once the FBI gets your Clipper keys, %0A >won't they be able to read all your future and past traffic?" %0A > %0A >There has been no response from NIST, NSA, Ms. Denning, Mr. Hellman, or %0A >anyone else who might be able to give us an authoritative answer. %0A >This is troubling. %0A   %0A    It was implied in the first technical posting by Dorothy Denning that the %0A FBI would do the decryption *for* the law enforcement agencies.  It wasn't %0A clear to me from the post whether this would be done in realtime or not, or %0A whether the FBI would just decrypt the session keys for the locals, or would %0A do the whole message. %0A   %0A    One thing I'm a bit puzzled by %3A   Why aren't they doing this with a public %0A key scheme of some sort?  You could generate two uniqe public/private pairsor %0A for each chip.  Then, escrow the private keys with the escrow agencies.  Set %0A the protocol up to encrypt the session key with both public keys.  To decrypt %0A a message, both escrow agencies (in the right order, for most PK schemes) %0A have to decrypt with the escrowed private key.  This way, there wouldn't be %0A thecconcern that, once the police had asked fo  a warrant/wiretap, they %0A would have your key forver. %0A   %0A    --John Kelsey %0A

doc_99 |@raw_text From %3A  neal %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org (Neal Howard) %0A Subject %3A  Do Splitfires Help Spagthorpe Diesels ? %0A Keywords %3A  Using Splitfire plugs for performance. %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5LGsG.K9w %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org> %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 93 20 %3A 55 %3A 27 GMT %0A Sender %3A  neal %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org %0A Distribution %3A  rec.motorcycles %0A Organization %3A  CompuTrac Inc., Richardson TX %0A Lines %3A  34 %0A  %0A In article <C5JF22.DJr %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> wcd82671 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (daniel warren c) writes %3A  %0A >Earlier, I was reading on the net about using Splitfire plugs.  One %0A >guy was thinking about it and almost everybody shot him to hell.  Well, %0A >I saw one think that someone said about "Show me a team that used Split- %0A >fires...."  Well, here's some additional insight and some theories %0A >about splitfire plugs and how they boost us as oppossed to cages. %0A > %0A >Splitfires were originally made to burn fuel more efficiently and %0A >increased power for the 4x4 cages.  Well, for these guys, splitfires %0A > %0A >Now I don't know about all of this (and I'm trying to catch up with %0A >somebody about it now), but Splitfires should help twins more than %0A  %0A Splitfires work mainly by providing a more-or-less unshrouded spark to the %0A combustion chamber. If an engine's cylinder head design can benefit from this, %0A then the splitfires will yield a slight performance increase, most noticeably %0A in lower rpm range torque. Splitfires didn't do diddly-squat for my 1992 GMC %0A pickup (4.3l V6) but do give a noticeable performance boost in my 1991 Harley %0A Sportster 1200 and my best friend's 1986 Sportster 883. Folks I know who've %0A tried them in 1340 Evo motors can't tell any performance boost over plain %0A plugs (which is interesting since the XLH and big twin EVO combustion chambers %0A are pretty much the same shape, just different sizes). Two of my friends who %0A have shovelhead Harleys swear by the splitfires but if I had a shovelhead, %0A I'd dual-plug it instead since they respond well enough to dual plugs to make %0A the machine work and extra ignition system worth the expense (plus they look %0A really cool with a spark plug on each side of each head) %0A --  %0A ============================================================================= %0A Neal Howard   '91 XLH-1200      DoD #686      CompuTrac, Inc (Richardson, TX) %0A 	      doh #0000001200   %7C355o33%7C      neal %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org %0A 	      Std disclaimer %3A  My opinions are mine, not CompuTrac's. %0A          "Let us learn to dream, gentlemen, and then perhaps %0A           we shall learn the truth." -- August Kekule' (1890) %0A ============================================================================= %0A

The condition of them vary quite a bit,  %0A so I've come up with my own condition system.  Some dragons may be missing  %0A items like the inserts.  If you have any questions, feel free to ask. %0A * %0A Condition ratings - Usually this is just an evaluation of the cover, as %0A most of the material inside is in great shape. %0A Excellent - IE-"As you find them in the store" %0A Very Good - Still in great condition, but can tell it's been boughten %0A Good      - On down the line %0A Very Fair/fair - indicates lots of use (But still "decent") %0A Poor      -  Indicates the material inside may be damaged (usually by %0A scissors).   %0A A * by the condition indicates that something from the magazine is  %0A missing (usually the insert) %0A I'll post another public update sometime this weekend (which will be the %0A final public posting, after which the auction will be by e-mail until %0A the bidding stops) %0A * %0A Again if you have any questions, ask away. %0A * %0A arrow      $2.50 056 - doc_124 |@raw_text From %3A  mpaul %40 unl.edu (marxhausen paul) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Passive Mixer %0A Date %3A  29 Apr 1993 12 %3A 42 %3A 39 GMT %0A Organization %3A  University of Nebraska--Lincoln	 %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1roifvINNd9n %40 crcnis1.unl.edu> %0A References %3A  <C665M4.4u1 %40 acsu.buffalo.edu> <C678o5.ED0 %40 unx.sas.com> <1rmk8t$8l0 %40 cat.cis.Brown.EDU> <1rmsbuINN59f %40 MINERVA.CIS.YALE.EDU> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  unlinfo.unl.edu %0A  %0A shaffer-wendy %40 yale.edu (Wendy Shaffer) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >I'm trying to build a mixer for a friend of mine to run several things into %0A >a single boom box.  I have a circuit that uses an op-amp powered by either a %0A >couple of 9V batteries or using some kind of power supply.  But in a catalog %0A >I was looking at recently, a "passive mixer" for guitar was advertised taht %0A >doesn't appear to use any power at all.  Does anyone know what the circuit for %0A >this would be, because then I could just adapt it for RCA jacks, and save my %0A >friend and I alot of messing with batteries and plugs.  Thanks. %0A  %0A Well, the fastest, crudest mixer (aside from just physically connecting %0A all your inputs together directly) is to run each signal through a  %0A resistor to a common output.  The resistors give some isolation so the %0A signal sources aren't driving directly into each other.  %0A  %0A Taking a wild, seat-of-the-pants guess, I'd say that if you are mixing %0A high-impedance sources like some dynamic mikes, electric guitar pickups, %0A etc., your resistors ought to be maybe 5K - 10K or so.  If you are mixing %0A line-level stuff or the outputs of a Walkman, or such, I'd go with 1K. %0A  %0A input 1 --/\/\/\/ -------------+--- output %0A                                %7C %0A input 2 --/\/\/\/\-------------+ %0A                                %7C %0A input 3 --/\/\/\/\-------------+ %0A  %0A  %0A -- %0A paul marxhausen .... ....... ............. ............ ............ ..........  %0A  .. . .  . . . university of nebraska - lincoln .  . . .. . .  .. . . . . . . . %0A  .     .    .  .   .     .   .  .    .   .  .   .    .   .  grace .   .    .  .  %0A    .         .       .      .        .        .      .        .   happens .      %0A

doc_129 |@raw_text From %3A  scst83 %40 csc.liv.ac.uk (Mr. C.D. Smith) %0A Subject %3A  Voltage Multiplier Problem. %0A Message-ID %3A  <C52HE5.8s4 %40 compsci.liverpool.ac.uk> %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 93 14 %3A 54 %3A 05 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 compsci.liverpool.ac.uk (News Eater) %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science, Liverpool University %0A Lines %3A  53 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  goyt.csc.liv.ac.uk %0A  %0A Hi, %0A  %0A    I've just built a valve preamp and use a diode/capacitor %0A voltage multiplier to step the 12vAC supply voltage up to approx  %0A 260vDV. As the load resistance increases, the RC constant decreases %0A and hence the output voltage drops. I need as high an output %0A voltage as possible. (about 260v). %0A   The circuit consists of seven voltage multiplier stages %0A (ie 14 diodes and 14 capacitors) each capacitor develops about 38v %0A across them, and I take the output from across seven capacitors=260v. %0A   Each capacitor is 100mfd at 68v. %0A  If I increase each of the capacitors rating (220-470mfd), that will %0A increase the RC constant, and hence alleviate some of the problem. %0A These capacitors are going to be a little expensive as I need 14 of %0A them, So %3A  %0A  %0A 1. What would happen if I connected a 470mfd at 400v capacitor in parallel  %0A with the output (and hence in parallel with the seven 100mfd capacitors)? %0A   Will it, as I assume, increase the C in circuit and hence increase %0A the RC time constant? If it does, and my output voltage becomes more %0A stable by doing this, then I will have killed two birds with one stone... %0A as I am experiencing some 50Hz ripple (and hence amp hum), and this new %0A capacitor will 'smooth' this out. %0A  %0A and %0A 2. Can anyone recomend a suitable value for an inductor (choke) to %0A be placed in the output line of the power supply to filter out %0A the 50Hz mains hum. Lowest resistance possible ! %0A  %0A   I've not got my preamp with me at the moment because it is TOO MUCH %0A of a distraction.... (I'm at university and I've got to get my  %0A dissertation finished in two weeks !!!!!!!) hence I'm mailing not %0A playing with my solderoing iron (it'll be cheaper too in the long %0A run... especially if 14 new large capacitors don't work as planned!) %0A  %0A Email please.... Can't always read the net..... %0A  %0A Thanks in advance.. %0A  %0A  %0A Chris ;-) %0A  %0A   +====================================================================+ %0A   %7CName  %3A  Mr Chris Smith       %7C     Twang on that 'ole guitar !       %7C %0A   %7CAddrs %3A  scst83 %40 uk.ac.liv.csc %7C                                       %7C %0A   %7CUni   %3A  Liverpool University %7CQuest %3A  To build more and more hardware %7C %0A   %7CDgree %3A  Computer Science     %7C                                       %7C %0A   +====================================================================+ %0A  %0A  "What ever the sun may be, it is certainly not a ball of flaming gas!" %0A   -- D.H. Lawrence. %0A  %0A  * All views expressed are my own, and reflect that of private thought. * %0A

Our branch guy who's helping %0A out says that things have gone smoothly with the iso-valve preps and the %0A burns will take place in mid-June. %0A  %0A Anyway, I'm off to find out more. doc_144 |@raw_text From %3A  smk5 %40 quads.uchicago.edu (Steve Kramarsky) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Keeping Your Mouth Shut (was %3A  Hard drive security) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.023319.13965 %40 midway.uchicago.edu> %0A Keywords %3A  cooperation %0A Sender %3A  news %40 uchinews.uchicago.edu (News System) %0A Reply-To %3A  smk5 %40 midway.uchicago.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Chicago %0A References %3A  <1993Apr13.143712.15338 %40 cadkey.com> <1993Apr13.214520.2075 %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu> <1993Apr14.055903.5358 %40 qualcomm.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 02 %3A 33 %3A 19 GMT %0A Lines %3A  43 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr14.055903.5358 %40 qualcomm.com> karn %40 servo.qualcomm.com (Phil Karn) writes %3A  %0A > %0A > %0A >I say "in theory" because in another case, a woman was held in %0A >contempt for refusing to reveal the location of her child even after %0A >taking the 5th. In this case, the woman was suspected of having %0A >murdered the kid, so taking the 5th wasn't surprising. Sure, so she %0A >was probably guilty, but that's not good enough. In our system you're %0A >not supposed to be able to force a suspect to confess to a crime, no %0A >matter how strongly you think they're guilty.  You have to develop %0A >your evidence independently. Doing otherwise might catch a few more %0A >crooks, but only at the cost of turning the clock back to the middle %0A >ages, when confessions were routinely tortured out of suspects both %0A >guilty and innocent. %0A > %0A  OK, I should have read the thread before posting my own $0.02.  I would %0A just add to Phil's very infomative discussion the following caveat %3A  the %0A fifth amendment applies ONLY in crinial cases.  ("...nor shall any person . %0A . . be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself..."). %0A Thus if the father sued for custody of the children, the case would be %0A civil and the defendant mother would not have fifth amendment protection. %0A Oddly enough, her refusal to give information in a civil case can lead to %0A criminal contempt charges (thus landing her in jail.)  The interesting part %0A of all this is that in a murder trial, the woman CAN plead the fifth as  %0A to the location of the child--this is routine.  A "computer crime"  %0A prosecution thus would seem to be fertile ground for this kind of defense,  %0A where a suit by a party injured by "hackers" would not.  If I am accused,  %0A for example, of sending encrypted kiddie porn over the nets the fifth should  %0A protect my key.  If I am accused of sending copyrighted material, however, %0A it proabably will not (copyright infringement not being a "crime" in the %0A technical sense.)  The REALLY tricky question is, say I do both (naughty %0A boy that I am) can the government use the information gained in the civil %0A trial (ie. my key) to gain access to my files for use in the criminal %0A prosecution.  The answer should certainly be no, but lord only knows how %0A this would work out. %0A  %0A Steve. %0A   %0A  %0A --  %0A             Steve Kramarsky, University of Chicago Law School %0A            steve %40 faerie.chi.il.us -or- smk5 %40 quads.uchicago.edu  %0A      "All I did was kiss a girl." - Jake, the night before his hanging. %0A

doc_184 |@raw_text From %3A  Dave Banisar <Banisar %40 washofc.cpsr.org> %0A Subject %3A  CPSR Statement on White House Crypto Plan %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.214751.28995 %40 eff.org> %0A X-Xxmessage-Id %3A  <A7F4A1214F01AC81 %40 coolidge.eff.org> %0A X-Xxdate %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 93 17 %3A 45 %3A 05 GMT %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 eff.org (NNTP News Poster) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  coolidge.eff.org %0A Organization %3A  CPSR, Civil Liberties and Computing Project %0A X-Useragent %3A  Nuntius v1.1.1d17 %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 21 %3A 47 %3A 51 GMT %0A Lines %3A  60 %0A  %0A ----------------------------------------------------------- %0A April 16, 1993									 %0A Washington, DC %0A  %0A                COMPUTER PROFESSIONALS CALL FOR PUBLIC  %0A            DEBATE ON NEW GOVERNMENT ENCRYPTION INITIATIVE %0A  %0A 	Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility (CPSR)  %0A today called for the public disclosure of technical data  %0A underlying the government's newly-announced "Public Encryption  %0A Management" initiative.  The new cryptography scheme was  %0A announced today by the White House and the National Institute  %0A for Standards and Technology (NIST), which will implement the  %0A technical specifications of the plan.  A NIST spokesman  %0A acknowledged that the National Security Agency (NSA), the super- %0A secret military intelligence agency, had actually developed the  %0A encryption technology around which the new initiative is built. %0A  %0A 	According to NIST, the technical specifications and the  %0A Presidential directive establishing the plan are classified.  To  %0A open the initiative to public review and debate, CPSR today  %0A filed a series of Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests  %0A with key agencies, including NSA, NIST, the National Security  %0A Council and the FBI for information relating to the encryption  %0A plan.  The CPSR requests are in keeping with the spirit of the  %0A Computer Security Act, which Congress passed in 1987 in order to  %0A open the development of non-military computer security standards  %0A to public scrutiny and to limit NSA's role in the creation of  %0A such standards. %0A  %0A 	CPSR previously has questioned the role of NSA in  %0A developing the so-called "digital signature standard" (DSS), a  %0A communications authentication technology that NIST proposed for  %0A government-wide use in 1991.  After CPSR sued NIST in a FOIA  %0A lawsuit last year, the civilian agency disclosed for the first  %0A time that NSA had, in fact, developed that security standard.   %0A NSA is due to file papers in federal court next week justifying  %0A the classification of records concerning its creation of the  %0A DSS. %0A  %0A 	David Sobel, CPSR Legal Counsel, called the  %0A administration's apparent commitment to the privacy of  %0A electronic communications, as reflected in today's official  %0A statement,  "a step in the right direction."  But he questioned  %0A the propriety of NSA's role in the process and the apparent  %0A secrecy that has thus far shielded the development process from  %0A public scrutiny.  "At a time when we are moving towards the  %0A development of a new information infrastructure, it is vital  %0A that standards designed to protect personal privacy be  %0A established openly and with full public participation.  It is  %0A not appropriate for NSA -- an agency with a long tradition of  %0A secrecy and opposition to effective civilian cryptography -- to  %0A play a leading role in the development process."  %0A  %0A 	CPSR is a national public-interest alliance of computer  %0A industry professionals dedicated to examining the impact of  %0A technology on society.   CPSR has 21 chapters in the U.S. and  %0A maintains offices in Palo Alto, California, Cambridge,  %0A Massachusetts and Washington, DC.  For additional information on  %0A CPSR, call (415) 322-3778 or e-mail <cpsr %40 csli.stanford.edu>. %0A  
doc_185 |@raw_text From %3A  idh %40 nessie.mcc.ac.uk (Ian Hawkins) %0A Subject %3A  Making up odd resistor values required by filters %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.134348.2663 %40 nessie.mcc.ac.uk> %0A Organization %3A  Manchester Computing Centre %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 13 %3A 43 %3A 48 GMT %0A Lines %3A  14 %0A  %0A When constructing active filters,  odd values of resistor are often required  %0A (i.e. something like a 3.14 K Ohm resistor).(It seems best to choose common  %0A capacitor values and cope with the strange resistances then demanded). %0A  %0A Is there a PD program out there that will work out how best to make up such %0A a resistance, given fixed resistors of the standard 12 values per decade?.(1, %0A 1.2,1.5,1.8,2.2,3.3 etc ). doc_229 |@raw_text From %3A  mcnally %40 quip.eecs.umich.edu (Mike McNally) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  I have seen the lobby, and it is us %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr27.221327.14483 %40 zip.eecs.umich.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 zip.eecs.umich.edu (Mr. News) %0A Organization %3A  University of Michigan EECS Dept., Ann Arbor, MI %0A References %3A  <1993Apr22.043233.8855 %40 uc.msc.edu> <Apr22.185314.14420 %40 yuma.ACNS.ColoState.EDU> <C5xxGA.GAv %40 ms.uky.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  usa %0A Date %3A  Tue, 27 Apr 1993 22 %3A 13 %3A 27 GMT %0A Lines %3A  51 %0A  %0A In article <C5xxGA.GAv %40 ms.uky.edu> morgan %40 engr.uky.edu (Wes Morgan) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >You should realize that form letters are the *worst* way to influence %0A >your congresscritters; exact copies are routinely placed on the lowest %0A >rung of the opinion ladder. %0A > %0A >If you want to write (and I think you should!), take the time to really %0A >*write* a letter.  Things to emphasize %3A  %0A  %0A   [excellent and helpful list deleted]  %0A  %0A >	- Be concise; don't ramble.  Rants are *definitely* out of place. %0A >	  Cite references, if necessary, but only use "accepted" references %0A >	  like academic journals.  "My neighbor Jim" is *not* a real refer- %0A >	  ence.  8) %0A  %0A   Wes's list is of "do"s and "don't"s for writing your Congressional %0A representatives is a fine one but I'd like to encourage people to pay %0A extra attention to the point above.  As cliched as the saying may be %0A it's nevertheless true that you can catch more flies with honey than %0A with vinegar. %0A  %0A   While the writing styles prevalent on the net possess a certain charm %0A please remember that the person reading your letter is likely to be %0A uninfluenced or negatively influenced if you express your concerns in %0A a way that makes you sound like a flake or a paranoid crackpot.  Wild %0A and unsupported accusations about the menace from the NSA will not %0A carry much weight, nor are overblown conclusions about the inevitable %0A consequences of the proposal likely to convince (especially not ones %0A that attempt strained analogies to the rise of the Nazi party.  Please %0A save the Niemoller quote for another letter..) %0A  %0A   If you want your opinions to be taken seriously it is *very* important %0A that you state those opinions in a manner that is understandable and  %0A seems reasonable to a layman.  Don't overburden your reader with technical %0A details or expect them to know the history of various encryption  %0A technologies.  Before you mail it, hand your letter to a non-technical %0A friend and ask them to sanity-check it. %0A  %0A   Above all, realize that legislators are often motivated as much by %0A self-interest as by anything else.  Try to point out risks in terms that %0A will be meaningful and motivating to them such as the loss of individual %0A privacy rights or the damage restrictive export regulations do to American %0A businesses' ability to compete in the global marketplace.  Pull the  %0A strings that you think will work with your legislator -- if your %0A legislator is unlikely to be swayed by civil-rights concerns then point out %0A how a government-granted monopoly for Mycotronx damages the competitiveness %0A of businesses in your district that manufacture or market phone or crypto %0A technology. %0A  %0A                                                                  -mcnally. %0A  
doc_230 |@raw_text From %3A  C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu (John Kelsey) %0A Subject %3A  Competing standard %0A Message-ID %3A  <16BB51C9E.C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mont.cs.missouri.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  mizzou1.missouri.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Missouri %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 93 02 %3A 02 %3A 06 CDT %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A    Perhaps one way of getting away from this cripple chip that the U.S. %0A government seems to be pushing would be to come up with a good alternative. %0A For example, how about a scheme using RSA, and some hybrid of DES-CFB and %0A another strong stream cipher (Maybe IDEA-CFB)?  This could be substantially %0A the same as the cripple chip, except that instead of key-registration, the %0A police could demand that you give up your secret key to them (with a court- %0A issued warrant).  Then, they could read the last few months of wiretapped %0A messages you've sent, and assuming you've committed no crimes, you could %0A generate a new key pair and go about your business.  I find that I'd be %0A willing to pay RSA for the right to use such a system, especially given the %0A alternative.  If you were unwilling to give up your secret key, then you'd %0A probably stay in jail (has anyone got a real legal precedent for this?). %0A    This would allow court-issued warrants to be used to gather information %0A on suspected criminals, but it couldn't be done in secrecy, and there %0A would be enormously less likelihood of corruption or theft of escrowed keys. %0A (Maybe someone from the law-enforcement or intelligent community will correct %0A me, but this doesn't *seem* like such a big loss in terms of law-enforcement %0A capabilities.) %0A   %0A    Any comments? %0A   %0A    --John Kelsey %0A

doc_259 |@raw_text From %3A  baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) %0A Subject %3A  Magellan Update - 04/16/93 %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 1993 20 %3A 26 UT %0A Organization %3A  Jet Propulsion Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <19APR199320262420 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A Keywords %3A  Magellan, JPL %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A Forwarded from Doug Griffith, Magellan Project Manager %0A  %0A                         MAGELLAN STATUS REPORT %0A                             April 16, 1993 %0A  %0A 1.  The Magellan mission at Venus continues normally, gathering gravity %0A data which provides measurement of density variations in the upper %0A mantle which can be correlated to surface topography.  Spacecraft %0A performance is nominal. %0A  %0A 2.  Magellan has completed 7225 orbits of Venus and is now 39 days from %0A the end of Cycle-4 and the start of the Transition Experiment. %0A  %0A 3.  No significant activities are expected next week, as preparations %0A for aerobraking continue on schedule. %0A  %0A 4.  On Monday morning, April 19, the moon will occult Venus and %0A interrupt the tracking of Magellan for about 68 minutes. %0A      ___    _____     ___ %0A     /_ /%7C  /____/ \  /_ /%7C     Ron Baalke         %7C baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C  __ \ /%7C %7C %7C %7C     Jet Propulsion Lab %7C %0A  ___%7C %7C %7C %7C %7C__) %7C/  %7C %7C %7C__   M/S 525-3684 Telos %7C The aweto from New Zealand %0A /___%7C %7C %7C %7C  ___/    %7C %7C/__ /%7C Pasadena, CA 91109 %7C is part caterpillar and %0A %7C_____%7C/  %7C_%7C/       %7C_____%7C/                     %7C part vegetable. %0A  %0A

doc_275 |@raw_text From %3A  gerald.belton %40 ozonehole.com (Gerald Belton)  %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  A question about 120V %0A Message-ID %3A  <5860.442.uupcb %40 ozonehole.com> %0A Date %3A  15 Apr 93 08 %3A 30 %3A 00 GMT %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  Ozone Online Operations, Inc., DBA The Ozone Hole BBS %0A Reply-To %3A  gerald.belton %40 ozonehole.com (Gerald Belton)  %0A Lines %3A  38 %0A  %0A >>SO..  Here's my question.  It seems to me that I'd have the %0A >>same electrical circuit if I hooked the neutral jumper from the %0A >>neutral over to the ground screw on new 'three prong' grounding %0A >>outlets. What's wrong with my reasoning here? %0A  %0A >First, go to the local hardware store and pick up a copy of "Wiring %0A >Simplified" by H.L. Richter.  Now if your house is wired with metal %0A >conduit, you don't need a seperate ground wire (assuming the house %0A >is wired correctly and the pipes are connected to a cold water %0A >pipe in your basement).  The outlets that have a neutral hooked to %0A >the ground screw seem wrong.  Anyone else think so? %0A  %0A Back in the 70's I was a service technician for a cash register company. %0A The cash registers used microprocessor circuits and back then they were %0A VERY susceptible to electrostatic discharge and line noise.  The biggest %0A problems came from outlets that were not properly grounded. %0A  %0A In almost every place we went to do an installation, we found outlets %0A with the ground connected to the neutral.  For 99.9% of the things you %0A can plug into one of these, they work fine.  For our cash registers they %0A were a nightmare -- line noise tended to scramble the memory %0A periodically. %0A  %0A With modern electronics using switching power supplies this should be %0A less of a problem.  Even the company I used to work for is no longer %0A recommending a dedicated line with a seperate ground for their %0A equipment.  I imagine if you check MOST household wiring you will find %0A that the ground and neutral are connected.  Although not ideal, it %0A should be o.k. for most applications. %0A  %0A --- %0A  . SLMR 2.1 . My reality check just bounced. %0A                                  %0A ---- %0A The Ozone Hole BBS * A Private Bulletin Board Service * (504)891-3142 %0A 3 Full Service Nodes * USRobotics 16.8K bps * 10 Gigs * 100,000 Files %0A SKYDIVE New Orleans! * RIME Network Mail HUB * 500+ Usenet Newsgroups %0A Please route all questions or inquiries to %3A   postmaster %40 ozonehole.com %0A  
doc_277 |@raw_text From %3A  squish %40 endor.uucp (Shishin Yamada) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  ATARI 2600 Processors %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.072040.13014 %40 das.harvard.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 das.harvard.edu (Network News) %0A Organization %3A  Aiken Computation Lab, Harvard University %0A References %3A  <93110.125951PCA103 %40 psuvm.psu.edu> <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> <1r7e14$l2c %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 07 %3A 20 %3A 40 GMT %0A Lines %3A  71 %0A  %0A In article <1r7e14$l2c %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> ifarqhar %40 laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au (Ian Farquhar) writes %3A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> squish %40 endor.uucp (Shishin Yamada) writes %3A  %0A >>The Atari 2600 used a 6502 CPU, just like their entire 8-bit line %0A >>(400, 800,1200,1400, 1440, 130xe, 65xe computers, as well as the 5200 %0A >>game machine).  %0A > %0A >Wrong, it has a 6507. %0A  %0A Sorry Ian, I haven't toyed with it in several years. I haven't seen %0A the insides in quite a few years. I just saw the post lagging for %0A quite a few days, and thought I'd toss in my $0.02. I assume the 6507 %0A was functionally similar to the 6502 (was it also made by MOS %0A Technologies?). I really am more versed in the (6502 based) Atari %0A computers. The 2600 came later on. %0A  %0A > %0A >>The 2600 had some extra ASIC chips that were basically %0A >>modified graphics chips and PIA's for the joysticks.  %0A > %0A >It had one custome chip (not an ASIC in the sense that word is now understood) %3A  %0A >the TIA (sometimes known as the 6526, although most other manufacturers list %0A >that as the CIA complex interface adapter.)  TIA stands for Television %0A >Interface Adapter, and it handles sound, paddles and the minimal video hardware %0A >the 2600 possessed. %0A  %0A In the Atari computers, the "CIA" chip you refer to sounds an awful %0A lot like the CTIA (Color Television Interface Adapter) chip used in %0A the early models. Later Atari upgraded this to the GTIA (Graphics %0A ...). Other colorful literature stated that the GTIA might have stood %0A for "George," the developer of the chip. %0A  %0A > %0A >There was also a standard 6532 RAM, I/O, Timer (RIOT), plus a voltage %0A >regulator and (if memory serves) a 555 timer.  That's all. %0A > %0A >>Later model 2600 %0A >>might have incorporated many of the chips into one ASCI, as the weight %0A >>of the machines and part count decreased a lot over the years. %0A > %0A >Not according to the servicing documentation I have here.  The 2600 did not %0A >change intenally very much at all. %0A  %0A Funny, I had an old and new model. The old one was SIGNIFICANTLY heavier. %0A  %0A >>Additionally, I think the 2600 used 2K, 4K, and up to 8K of ROM for %0A >>their games.  %0A > %0A >ROMS were mapped into the upper 4K of the 6507's address space.  2K and 4K %0A >games were fine, but later 8K and 16K games needed bank switching.  Atari %0A >(and others) made much of these "huge" cartridges. %0A > %0A >>I have no idea how much RAM it had to work with, but I %0A >>would hazard a guess of 2 or 4K RAM.  %0A  %0A Sorry, I am way out of line here. My first microcontroller I built was %0A a MC68701 based chipset with 128 bytes onboard. That was not easy to %0A work with (in addtion to a small 2K on-board EPROM). %0A  %0A >Wrong, it had 128 bytes of RAM from the RIOT.  This was multiply mapped into %0A >both page 0 (pseudo-registers) and page 1 (stack), and also throughout the %0A >bottom 4K of memory.  TIA registers also sat in this address space. %0A > %0A >As 128 bytes of RAM was somewhat limiting, some later cartridges also carried %0A >RAM themselves, which was interesting as Atari had provided no write line %0A >to the cart.  This was managed by mapping the reads from RAM into one address %0A >range, and the writes into another, but all the time this scheme ate into %0A >the *very* scarce ROM address space. %0A > %0A >							Ian. %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_296 |@raw_text From %3A  "UTADNX %3A  %3A UTDSSA %3A  %3A GREER" %40 utspan.span.nasa.gov %0A Subject %3A  Vandalizing the sky %0A Message-ID %3A  <C65J1D.9yt.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A X-Added %3A  Forwarded by Space Digest %0A Sender %3A  news+ %40 cs.cmu.edu %0A Organization %3A  [via International Space University] %0A Original-Sender %3A  isu %40 VACATION.VENARI.CS.CMU.EDU %0A Distribution %3A  sci %0A Date %3A  Tue, 27 Apr 1993 16 %3A 52 %3A 59 GMT %0A Approved %3A  bboard-news_gateway %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A In Space Digest V16 #487, %0A hathaway %40 stsci.edu writes %3A  %0A  %0A ...about the protests over proposals to put a giant billboard into orbit, %0A  %0A >I'd like to add that some of the "protests" do not come from a strictly %0A >practical consideration of what pollution levels are acceptable for research %0A >activities by professional astronomers.  Some of what I would complain about %0A >is rooted in aesthetics.  %0A  %0A >Regards,  %0A >Wm. Hathaway  %0A >Baltimore MD  %0A  %0A Mr. Hathaway's post is right on the money, if a little lengthy.  In short, %0A an orbiting billboard would be trash, in the same way that a billboard on %0A the Earth is trash.  Billboards make a place look trashy.  That is why there %0A are laws in many places prohibiting their use.  The light pollution %0A complaints are mainly an attempt to find some tangible reason to be against %0A orbiting billboards because people don't feel morally justified to complain %0A on the grounds that these things would defile the beauty of the sky. %0A  %0A Regular orbiting spacecraft are not the same in this respect, since they are %0A more like abstract entities, but a billboard in space would be like a beer %0A can somebody had thrown on the side of the road %3A  just trash. %0A  %0A _____________ %0A Dale M. Greer, whose opinions are not to be confused with those of %0A   The Center for Space Sciences, University of Texas at Dallas %0A    UTSPAN %3A  %3A UTADNX %3A  %3A UTDSSA %3A  %3A GREER or greer %40 utdcss.utdallas.edu %0A "Let machines multiply, doing the work of many, %0A                But let the people have no use for them." - Lao Tzu %0A

doc_305 |@raw_text From %3A  nlu %40 Xenon.Stanford.EDU (Nelson Lu) %0A Subject %3A  SHARKS REVIEW Part 5 %3A  Left Wings %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.021058.2615 %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Department, Stanford University. %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 02 %3A 10 %3A 58 GMT %0A Lines %3A  161 %0A  %0A Apparently, Part 2 (defensemen numbered 2 through 19) was lost when I posted %0A it; to make things worse, I lost my own copy.  I have asked on the Sharks %0A mailing list, on which it did get out, to see if someone can mail me a copy %0A back.  If someone responds, I will repost it when I get it; otherwise, I will %0A re-write it in a day or two and post it.  Sorry about that. %0A  %0A #8	LARRY DEPALMA		Season %3A 	3rd %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, free agent from Minnesota %0A Grade %3A 		I (C-/D+) %0A  %0A No netter/fan watching the Sharks, including me, knows where DePalma was at %0A the end of the season; the Sharks appeared to still have his rights, but he %0A wasn't in San Jose, he wasn't in Kansas City, and his name hasn't appeared on %0A the waiver wire.  And that kind of invisibility was prevalent for the most part %0A for DePalma.  After being called up October 30 against the Tampa Bay Lightning, %0A DePalma had an excellent week, scoring 5 points in 3 games while playing good %0A defense.  Unfortunately, the 27-year-old DePalma then disappeared the rest of %0A the way, getting just 3 more points in 15 more games, and generally looked %0A lethargic and uninterested on both ends of the ice.  He then was sent down to %0A Kansas City, walked out from there, and was suspended and later reinstated %0A when it was revealed that he was injured; he then promptly disappeared from %0A the watching eyes of Shark Bytes (as the mailing list is now known to Sharks %0A officials) faithful, and neither the Sharks nor we miss him. %0A  %0A #10	JOHAN GARPENLOV		Season %3A  3rd %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, trade with Detroit for D Bob McGill and 8th round %0A 		pick in '92 entry draft from Vancouver %0A Grade %3A 		A/A- %0A  %0A After an early slump, Garpenlov was nothing short of inspirational the rest %0A of the way, finishing with 66 points in 79 games, second highest total on the %0A team, as he clicked well with team MVP Kelly Kisio and right wing Rob %0A Gaudreau.  Kisio got most of the credit, but Garpenlov, finishing second in %0A the MVP voting, clearly demonstrated his playmaking and scoring skills, as he %0A was seen making excellent centering passes as well as finishing passes to him %0A by putting the puck past opposing goaltenders, getting a club-high 14 power- %0A play goals.  Contrary to his previous rep, Garpenlov also showed that despite %0A his small size (5' 11", 183 lbs.), he was willing to throw himself around %0A when necessary, albeit not very successful yet.  He also still needs to work %0A on his defense, although he improved tremendously throughout the season, and %0A was actually quite a good penalty killer by the end of the season.  He will %0A be a major key to the offense next year. %0A  %0A #15	DAVID BRUCE		Season %3A  5th %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from St. Louis in expansion draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (?) %0A  %0A After a banner '91-92, when he led the team in power-play goals (10) and %0A was third in total scoring (38 points in 60 games), Bruce was bothered %0A virtually all of this season with a groin injury, which kept him out of the %0A lineup for all by 17 games this season.  Of course, it is difficult to %0A speculate how well he would have done this season had he not been affected by %0A the injury, but the 28-year-old Bruce was effective with a man up or a man %0A short in the Sharks' first season, and was expected to be a strong offensive %0A leader this season as well.  The injury appears serious, which is a shame, %0A because otherwise he may have a much brighter future for now; instead, his %0A future with the Sharks next season appears clouded. %0A  %0A #18	MARK PEDERSON		Season %3A 	3rd %0A Acquired %3A 	'92-93, trade with Philadelphia for C/LW Dave Snuggerud %0A Grade %3A 		I (B) %0A  %0A It is difficult for me to understand the Flyers' decision to unload Pederson, %0A after a very good offensive season last season (40 points in 58 games), but %0A after riding the pine early in the season, Pederson was summarily sent to the %0A Sharks in exchange of the defensive-minded Snuggerud, and he finished with %0A 41 games combined with the Flyers and the Sharks.  He was also limited by %0A injuries this season, and this limited his production (17 points).  But when %0A healthy, Pederson appears impressive, with a good scoring touch, good size %0A (and the willingness to throw it around, although he's not considered a %0A physical forward), and good speed.  He also does not appear to be a liability %0A on defense, but the Sharks probably have to wait until next season to see how %0A much, exactly, Pederson can do. %0A  %0A #20	JOHN CARTER		Season %3A  4th %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, free agent from Boston %0A Grade %3A 		I (B+/B) %0A  %0A Carter was definitely one of the hardest workers on the team, and the hard %0A work worked wonders, as at times he looked great on ice.  However, although he %0A did look great at times, the fact that he received just 16 points (in 55 %0A games) for his efforts is a sign that there is only so much his hard work can %0A do, and the Sharks confirmed that by sending him to Kansas City with about %0A 20 games left in the season.  Carter, who will turn 30 on May 6, always %0A hussled, but as a result, was sometimes trapped too deep within the offensive %0A zone while forechecking, but he was generally a credit on the defensive end, %0A but he is probably of limited utility in that capacity, and he did not impress %0A offensively, although he was one of the best Sharks at drawing penalties.  He %0A is very unlikely to be back next season. %0A  %0A #28	JEAN-FRANCOIS QUINTIN	Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (B+/B) %0A  %0A I don't understand why the Sharks didn't let Quintin play any more than the %0A 14 games he played this season.  He was generally hard-working and creating %0A opportunities offensively, and appeared, at age 23, ready for regular NHL %0A duty, at least for a team like the Sharks, finishing with 7 points in those %0A 14 games while not being a defensive liability.  Shoulder injury in training %0A camp before the '91-92 season limited Quintin, the team's leading scorer in %0A exhibition games despite sitting out the final two, to just 29 games with the %0A Sharks and the Blades that season, but he looked impressive.  He should be a %0A solid contender for regular duty next season. %0A  %0A #41	MARK BEAUFAIT		Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	2nd round pick in 1991 supplemental draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (?) %0A  %0A After a all-star season at Kansas City, Beaufait got a cup of coffey with the %0A Sharks late in the season when the Blades knocked down a playoff spot and the %0A Sharks decimated with injuries, playing 5 games and scoring a goal for his only %0A NHL point thus far.  Despite small size (5' 9", 165 lbs.), Beaufait was not shy %0A to throw himself around when necessary, and looked pretty good at times, %0A although it's too early to judge him based on 5 NHL games, in which he played %0A mostly left wing, away from his center position at Northern Michigan and %0A Kansas City. %0A  %0A #42	JAROSLAV OTEVREL	Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	8th round pick in 1991 entry draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (?) %0A  %0A Like Beaufait, Otevrel also played away from his normal position when he was %0A up for his cup of tea (7 games) midway through the season.  He was generally %0A very much of a defensive liability, and did not show much offensively either, %0A although that may be more indicative of the lack of ice time he got in those %0A 7 games.  He may need another season to work on his defense, but once his %0A defense is acceptable, he should be ready. %0A  %0A #44	MICHEL PICARD		Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	'92-93, trade with Hartford for LW Yvon Corriveau %0A Grade %3A 		I (B-/C+) %0A  %0A The 23-year-old Picard, although he perennially tore up the minors, seems to %0A be close to being out of chances, for some reason, after being acquired by the %0A Sharks but failing to impress the management in 25 games, scoring 4 goals for %0A his only points, and he spent most of the rest of the way in Kansas City. %0A He was not particularly strong defensively, and despite his offensive %0A brilliance in the minors, he has failed thus far to score in the NHL, although %0A he has been given limited opportunities.  He may be the Sharks' bait in the %0A expansion draft. %0A  %0A #45	DODY WOOD		Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	3rd round pick in 1991 entry draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (D+/D, although perhaps I shouldn't give a grade at all) %0A  %0A I have been accused of knocking on Wood too much.  %3A -)  Then, it is probably %0A no surprise to you that I am thoroughly unimpressed by Wood thus far, although %0A 13 games is a small example.  He was generally a nonfactor on offense, was %0A not particularly good defensively, and took too many silly penalties, losing %0A many fights in the process and gathering 69 penalty minutes in those 13 games, %0A projecting to to 446(!) in an 84-game season.  He's not ready, and needs at %0A least another season at KC, where he can work on his fighting skills, if %0A nothing else.  His relatively small size (5' 11", 181 lbs.) does not give much %0A possibility that he can survive, at this stage, as an enforcer. %0A  %0A =============================================================================== %0A GO CALGARY FLAMES! Even if we assume that these "trusted agents" are really entering %0A a wide range of S1 and S2 seeds (rather than using the same one all the %0A time to reduce the key search space to 30 bits), I assume they are not %0A doing so by picking up an iron filing and poking it into the circuitry %0A at carefully selected points to encode data. Hence, %0A digitally compressed TV is supposed to be less susceptible to interference %0A than amplitude modulated TV. %0A  %0A --  %0A Bill McFadden    Tektronix, Inc.  P.O. I upgraded my motherboard last fall.  I %0A would have been quite pissed at any software that would have forced me to %0A reinstall simply because I changed motherboards. %0A  %0A 	Any info in the BIOS is too volatile to use as a checksum.  Are you %0A going to require that a user re-install all their software if they add 4Mb %0A of RAM to their computer?  I did that a couple of weeks ago.  It's in the %0A BIOS, and if software had told me "this isn't the machine you installed me %0A on" I would never have used that software again.  Really bad idea. %0A  %0A > I did not say that the originals would allow only one install.  The user's  %0A > conscience should do that. %0A  %0A 	This is silly.  It's much easier to loan disks to a friend and let %0A them do an install than to backup your copy already on disk, and then give %0A them that.  Your scheme isn't going to stop anyone. %0A  %0A > You know how many bytes you need to change in X-wing to disable %0A > the quiz?  TWO!  Yes, TWO!  (And don't ask me which ones they are.) %0A  %0A 	Do you know any assembly language at all?  All anyone needs to do if %0A find the part of the code that does the quiz, and insert a JMP instruction %0A to just completely skip it.  Not that difficult, really!  And there is very %0A little that commpanies can do to stop this type of thing.  Using PKLITE or %0A some similar utility would help, but only if the resulting compressed .EXE %0A were tagged as uncompressable. %0A  %0A > What I believe the companies should do is implement the above plus %0A > a special patch once the user registers that loudly exclaims upon bootup %0A > "REGISTERED TO XXXXX -- address, city, state zip" and disables the above. %0A  %0A 	This is by far the best idea you presented in your post.  Making it %0A plainly obvious who registered is going to stop casual pirates. But, the %0A determined ones are just going to answer "Joe Blow" to the question of %0A "what's your name" so this won't stop them in the long run. %0A  %0A 	Pirates are always going to win this fight.  They simply have more %0A time to work on the software and figure out the protection scheme. %0A  %0A -- %0A Steve Madsen %0A sjmadsen %40 nextsrv.cas.muohio.edu %0A  %0A Ask me about Linux, the free 386 unix! %0A

Krumins) writes %3A  %0A >[deleted] %0A >>To say that "visible light astronomy is already a dying field" is  %0A >>pure hokum.  To use the "logic" that things are already bad, so it doesn't %0A >>matter if it gets worse is absurd.  Maybe common sense and logic %0A >>are the dying fields. %0A >>--  %0A >[deleted] %0A >Ok, so those scientists can get around the atmosphere with fancy %0A >computer algorythims, but have you looked ad the Hubble results, the %0A >defects of the mirror are partially correctable with software (see %0A >those jupiter pictures for results), but is the effects are completely %0A >reversable, why is there going to be a shuttle mission to fix it? %0A >[deleted] %0A  %0A The main effect of the spherical aberration problems with the %0A primary mirror was to drive the computer engineers to develop the image %0A processing software that much faster. When they use the _same_ deconvolution  %0A software on the images from the fixed Hubble, be ready for some  %0A incredible results!  There is every reason to believe that the results will  %0A _exceed_ the original specs by a fair margin.   %0A  %0A Adaptive optics is a combination of hardware and software.  It works  %0A realtime, not after the fact, as is the case with Hubble.  You might be %0A interested to know this technology has made it to the amateur market, in %0A the form of the AO-2 Adaptive Optics System.  Starting on page 52 of the  %0A April, 1993 Sky & Telescope is a three page review of this new product. %0A It lists for $1,290.  The article states %3A  "The AO-2 Adaptive Optics System  %0A comes in a handy soft-plastic case that a three-year-old could carry  %0A around."  Even though this device is really only good for the brightest %0A objects, "it could cope with image movements of up to 0.8 millimeter %0A in the telescope's focal plane."  Now just imagine how well this infant  %0A technology will do in a few years, especially in a dedicated system that  %0A has hundreds of thousands of dollars, and many man-hours invested in its %0A development. %0A  %0A George Krumins %0A --  %0A Pufferfish Observatory         %7C^^^^^\^^^^%7C     The Universe had its origin %0A gfk39017 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu       ^^^/\ \^^^      in two hockeysticks colliding  %0A                                   / /\ \  %0A        "Home of the Hockeystick  /_/  \_\  Memorial Telescope" %0A

doc_446 |@raw_text From %3A  willis %40 oracle.SCG.HAC.COM (Stan Willis) %0A Subject %3A  Kings playoff notes %3A  Stauber, TV ratings, etc. %0A Message-ID %3A  <31521 %40 hacgate.SCG.HAC.COM> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 23 %3A 12 %3A 59 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 hacgate.SCG.HAC.COM %0A Reply-To %3A  willis %40 empire.dnet.hac.com (Stan Willis) %0A Organization %3A  none %0A Lines %3A  112 %0A  %0A 1992-93 Los Angeles Kings notes. %0A -------------------------------- %0A Playoffs %3A  %0A --------- %0A *Stauber disturbed by third-man theme %0A by Rick Sadowski, Daily News %0A  %0A Barry Melrose's decision to stick Robb Stauber in the stands rather than in the %0A crease or even on the bench for the Stanley Cup playoffs does not sit well with %0A the rookie goaltender. %0A  %0A "I want to be a part of the team at the most crucial time of the year, the most %0A fun time of the year, and I'm not,"  Stauber said with some emotion Monday.  "I %0A think I have worked hard enough for that." %0A  %0A Stauber said he accepts Melrose's choice of Kelly Hrudey as the teams top goalie %0A in their playoff series with the Calgary Flames. Hrudey made 21 saves in Sundays %0A 6-3 opening victory. %0A  %0A But Stauber clearly is upset with his sudden status as the No. 3 man behind Rick %0A Knickle.  Stauber had a 4-1-2 record and 2.98 goals-against average down the %0A stretch in the regular season and nearly wrestled the No. 1 job from Hrudey. %0A  %0A Knickle?  He won 2 of 3 decisions but had a bloated 5.26 average, twice was  %0A yanked from games (once for stomach cramps) and hasn't played since March 29. %0A  %0A Yet, when the series resumes Wednesday, Knickle will serve as Hrudey's backup %0A again and Stauber will have to satisfy his playoff hunger by munching on Olympic %0A Saddledome popcorn. %0A  %0A "If I'm supposedly close to being the starter or could have been the starter...I %0A dropped too. 3.  What happened to No. 2?"  Stauber wondered.  "Not that I'd be %0A happy with No. 2, but I feel I should at least be a part of this team in the %0A playoffs." %0A  %0A Perhaps Stauber eventually will get his chance, but Melrose apparently is not %0A convinced the 25-year old is capable of handling playoff pressure. %0A  %0A While insisting he is the Kings' "goalie of the future," Melrose said Stauber %0A flubbed all four of the big games he was asked to win this season.  They were, %0A according to Melrose %3A  a 7-2 loss to San Jose on Dec. 26; An 8-3 loss to the New %0A York Rangers on Jan. 23; a 6-6 tie with Detroit on Feb. 11; an 8-6 loss to  %0A Vancouver on Thursday. %0A  %0A "Four times this season Robb could have emerged as the elite goalie, he could %0A have taken it away from Kelly Hrudey, and he didn't do it," Melrose said.  "An %0A elite goaltender has to carry the ball when you give it to him.  The mark of a %0A great goalie is that he isn't satisfied to be a backup." %0A  %0A "I'm not blaming Robb for the losses, but if you're going to be No. 1, you've %0A got to be able to walk your talk.  You've got to be able to play when everything %0A is on the line.  Robb Stauber has a great deal of ability, but maybe I expect %0A more from him than he does." %0A  %0A Ouch.  That remark stung Stauber.  He began the season 9-0-1, struggled when the %0A team hit a mid-season slump, didn't play for a month after Knickle was signed %0A off the San Diego Gulls roster, then came on at the end. %0A  %0A "I expect more from myself than anybody, including Barry Melrose," said Stauber, %0A a three-year star at the University of Minnesota who left school in 1989, only  %0A to have his development hampered by a string of serious injuries. %0A  %0A "What I've been through the last four years - two knee operations, a herniated %0A disk in my back, shoulder surgery - what more can I go through?  I obviously do %0A expect a lot from myself, otherwise I wouldn't be here." %0A  %0A "Anybody who would disagree with that doesn't know me.  I'm not saying Barry  %0A doesn't know me, but don't say I've been without expectations.  If anything, I'm %0A a perfectionist." %0A  %0A Stauber acknowledged he played poorly in the four games Melrose mentioned. "But  %0A even though I didn't play well, I get knocked down from maybe on to three? It's  %0A a bit of a jump," he said.  "You're almost No. 1, or if you play a good game  %0A you're No. 1 and if you don't you're No. 3?  Why does Jack Nicklaus shoot a 67  %0A and then a 75?  Can you explain that?  That's what barry wanted me to explain  %0A to him, why I didn't come through when he counted on me.  I don't know. What I  %0A do know is, it's a sport.  I'll be there." %0A  %0A Melrose's "goalie of the future" statement doesn't mean much to Stauber. "Before %0A you know it, I'll be 30 and there will be no future," he said. %0A  %0A ------ %0A  %0A *Game 1 of the Kings  %40  Flames playoff series drew a 4.2 Nielsen rating on ABC  %0A Channel 7 here in LA.  The Kings averaged a 2.1 Nielsen rating in the 10 regular %0A season games aired on Channel 5. %0A  %0A Around the NHL %3A  %0A --------------- %0A *San Jose fired Coach George Kingston, who lead the team to a 11-71-2 mark in  %0A their 2nd NHL season.  Kingston was 28-129-7 over the past 2 years with the %0A Sharks. %0A  %0A ------ %0A  %0A *Former Islander executive Bill Torrey was named as President of the expansion %0A Florida Panthers.  Bobby Clarke was named as the clubs General Manager. %0A  %0A *Last nights games %3A  %0A ------------------- %0A WIN  2  %40  VAN  4 (VAN leads 1-0) %0A TOR  3  %40  DET  6 (DET leads 1-0) %0A  %0A =============================================================================== %0A Stan Willis (willis %40 empire.dnet.hac.com) %0A net contact %3A  L.A. Kings %0A  %0A  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> %0A       talk with the L.A. Kings Mailing List ...... kings %40 cs.stanford.edu %0A       to subscribe or unsubscribe %3A  ....... kings-request %40 cs.stanford.edu %0A  <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< %0A =============================================================================== %0A

The receivers  %0A look much like what you describe, but they include a UHF whip antenna (less %0A than a foot tall) and a light which flashes on and off to let traffic know that  %0A an emergency vehicle has taken control and is approaching.  Local folklore  %0A says this system was invented here; I don't know if this company has any  %0A other installations.  It has been in operation for at least 30 years, going  %0A only by my memory. %0A  %0A Bob Sciamanda %0A Edinboro Univ of PA %0A

doc_502 |@raw_text From %3A  kolstad %40 cae.wisc.edu (Joel Kolstad) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Organization %3A  U of Wisconsin-Madison College of Engineering %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 93 00 %3A 15 %3A 36 CDT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.001536.8068 %40 doug.cae.wisc.edu> %0A References %3A  <sehari.735331566 %40 marge.ecss.iastate.edu> <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu> <sehari.735357542 %40 du139-213.cc.iastate.edu> %0A Lines %3A  38 %0A  %0A In article <sehari.735357542 %40 du139-213.cc.iastate.edu> sehari %40 iastate.edu (Babak Sehari) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I have written a program and I want to market it.  I would like certain degree %0A >of protection, since my main custmers are individuals and not the  %0A >cooperations.   I know laser hole burning method, and hardware key method, %0A >however, my  software is going to cost only $15.00, so I can not afford that. %0A >Also, at this low price I can not afford people make too many copy of my %0A >software. Well, I guess say upto %20 illigal copying is ok by me. %0A > %0A >However, I do not want someone to get a copy of PCTools and copy my software.   %0A >Off course, I never meant to forbid the true hackers from copying, since they %0A >can develope a better program anyway. %0A  %0A I wouldn't bother with the copy protection, if I were you.  If you program %0A is any good, the pirates will have stripped the protection and will be %0A distributing the stripped version is well under a week. %0A  %0A Hardware methods prevent J. Random Loser from using his Copy II PC to pirate  %0A your software, but doesn't stop anyone who knows a few people with enough  %0A connections to "real" pirates who _will_ be able to defeat your "check for the  %0A hole" code. %0A  %0A You may want to price your software (depending on what it is) a tad %0A higher... a price change from $15 to $25 probably would turn off very few %0A potentials buyers, and that way you could tolerate more pirates (whose %0A numbers don't change with the price). %0A  %0A As for the 20% pirating figure... ha, ha.  Of course, a lot of pirates just %0A have this "thing" about having pirated software, even if they never use it, %0A so perhaps that really wouldn't count towards 20%.  Even so, 20% is awfully %0A low. %0A  %0A  %0A 					---Joel Kolstad %0A  %0A P.S. -- I assume you're talking PC software.  If you're talking UNIX, %0A HP-48, or something else somewhat obscure, copy protection might be a %0A slightly more viable alternative. %0A

I'm assuming that the V-Pilot, in addition to its handy %0A >storage facilities, is a pretty decent fit. Is there any company that %0A >makes a reasonable line of women's motorcycling stuff? More importantly, %0A >does anyone in Boulder or Denver know of a shop that bothers carrying any? %0A  %0A I was very lucky I found a jacket I liked that actually _fits_. %0A HG makes the v-pilot jackets, mine is a very similar style made %0A by Just Leather in San Jose. I bought one of the last two they %0A ever made. %0A  %0A Finding decent womens motorcycling gear is not easy.  There is a lot %0A of stuff out there that's fringed everywhere, made of fashion leather, %0A made to fit men, etc.  I don't know of a shop in your area.  There %0A are some women rider friendly places in the San Francisco/San Jose %0A area, but I don't recommend buying clothing mail order.  Too hard %0A to tell if it'll fit.  Bates custom makes leathers.  You might want %0A to call them (they're in L.A.) and get a cost estimate for the type %0A of jacket your wife is interested in.  Large manufacturers like %0A BMW and H.G. sell women's lines of clothing of decent quality, but %0A fit is iffy. %0A  %0A A while ago, Noemi and Lisa Sieverts were talking about starting %0A a business doing just this sort of thing. doc_519 |@raw_text From %3A  keller %40 hubble.ifa.hawaii.edu (Tim Keller) %0A Subject %3A  airhorns on an FJ1100 review             %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5nGwx.vq %40 news.Hawaii.Edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 news.Hawaii.Edu %0A Organization %3A  Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii %0A References %3A  <3604 %40 contex.contex.com> <9901217 %40 hpfcso.FC.HP.COM> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 17 Apr 1993 22 %3A 53 %3A 21 GMT %0A Lines %3A  44 %0A  %0A For those of you who are thinking about fiamms, you might also want to think %0A about airhorns. I just installed a set of Bosch air horns ordered from  %0A Dennis Kirk (pg. 282 of the latest catalog) on my '85 FJ1100. They are rated %0A at 93db at 7 meters. I installed them using 10 gage wire from the battery to %0A the relay to the compressor to ground. My stock horn connectors fit the relay %0A pins just fine. I soldered the connections to the relay and compressor, and used %0A a crimp type battery connector and an inline 10amp fuse/connector from NAPA. %0A 	I installed the compressor just forward of the fuse box in the front %0A fairing by tie wrapping between the steering head frame and the black steel tube %0A frame used to support the front fairing. You have to remove the front fairing to %0A do this, but it fits outside of the frame but inside the fairing on the two %0A vertical supports just in front of the fuses. Depending how tight your fairing %0A follows the frame, you should be able to fit it somewhere in the fairing. %0A The compressor is about 2" in diameter and about 5" long. %0A 	The relay mounted on the front of the steering head frame (it is small %0A so there should be plenty of good places for it. %0A 	I found a perfect place for the horns that required only tie wraps to %0A mount. The horns fit inside the front fairing/frame and stick out on either side %0A just in front of the air scoops, but behind the turn signals. The back of the %0A horns point back towards the center of the bike and come real close to where %0A the gas tank connects to the front part of the frame. There is just enough %0A room to the outside to allow full lock to lock clearance, and there are nice %0A cut outs in the frame for the back of the horn to go into. %0A 	The short horn is even with the fairing, and the long one sticks out %0A about an inch or so, but it is really not that noticable unless you look %0A closely. They end up pointing down slightly and maybe 30 degrees from straight %0A ahead (perfect for those cagers trying to change lanes into you). %0A 	If you have any other questions about the mounting, email, and I can try %0A to explain better. If your bike is not red, then you may want to paint them %0A first. %0A 	How do they work you ask? They are very, very, very *LOUD*. They sound %0A more like a european sports car than a truck, but a vast improvement over stock. %0A I have used them at least daily since installing them, and the 10 amp fuse has %0A not blown yet (although, the duration of the horn blasts have been short). %0A 	I've repeatedly scared the shit out of my friends with them, even though %0A they know that I have the horns, they still jump. They are perfect for keeping %0A the pedestrians on the sidewalk. %0A The bottom line is they work, are loud enough to cause pain and suffering to %0A those stupid lane changing cages (as well as take a few years off their lives) %0A and are relatively easy to install on the FJ. YMMV. %0A  %0A -TJK %0A '85 FJ1100 with "GET OUT OF MY WAY" horns. %0A "That looks like a suit you'd fight a fire in" -comment about the Aerostich %0A

doc_574 |@raw_text From %3A  kpa %40 rchland.vnet.ibm.com (Karl Anderson) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  A WRENCH in the works? %0A Sender %3A  news %40 rchland.ibm.com %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.182414.19319 %40 rchland.ibm.com> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 18 %3A 24 %3A 14 GMT %0A Disclaimer %3A  This posting represents the poster's views, not necessarily those of IBM %0A References %3A   <1993Apr15.190725.16117 %40 ncsu.edu> %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  oslo.rchland.ibm.com %0A Organization %3A  IBM Rochester %0A Lines %3A  42 %0A  %0A From another space forum %0A >  NOW WHERE DID I LEAVE THOSE PLIERS? %0A     When workers at the Kennedy Space Center disassembled the STS-56 %0A  solid rocket boosters they were surprised to find a pair of pliers %0A  lodged into the outside base of the right hand SRB.  The tool survived %0A  the trip from the launch pad up to approximately a 250,000 foot %0A  altitude, then down to splashdown and towing back to KSC. %0A  %0A     NASA spokesperson Lisa Malone told the media, %0A  %0A     "It's been a long time since something like this happened.  We've %0A  lost washers and bolts (before) but never a tool like this." %0A  %0A     The initial investigation into the incident has shown that a %0A  Thiokol Corp. technician noticed and reported his pliers as missing on %0A  April 2nd.  Unfortunately, the worker's supervisor did not act on the %0A  report and Discovery was launched with its "extra payload".  NASA %0A  officials were never told of the missing tool before the April 8th %0A  launch date. %0A  %0A     The free-flying pliers were supposed to be tethered to the SRB %0A  technician.  When the tool was found in an aft section of the booster, %0A  its 18-inch long rope was still attached.  The pliers were found in a %0A  part of the booster which is not easily visible from the launch pad. %0A %7C(Ron's ed. note %3A   naaahhh,  just too easy) %0A  %0A     A spokesperson for the Lockheed Space Operations Company said that %0A  the Shuttle processor will take "appropriate action".  Thiokol is a %0A  subcontractor to LSOC for work to prepare Shuttle hardware for launch. %0A  %0A _________________________________________________________ %0A  %0A Karl Anderson	 %0A DEV/2000 %3A  Configuration Management/Version Control %0A  %0A Dept 53K/006-2		Rochester, Minnesota 55901 %0A 253-8044		Tie 8-453-8044 %0A INTERNET %3A  karl %40 vnet.ibm.com %0A PRODIGY %3A  CMMG96A %0A  %0A "To seek, to strive, to find, and not to yield." %0A 			Alfred Lord Tennyson %0A

Shaver, when asked by his son (who was doing the broadcast with him), %0A "What will you do now?" responded, "First I'm going to get me a new pair of %0A slippers.  Then I'm going to sit in my easy chair and watch the world go by." %0A  %0A Thank you North Stars, and thank you Al Shaver, for 26 years of Minnesota %0A memories. %0A  %0A Joel Alvstad %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_608 |@raw_text From %3A  kennejs %40 a.cs.okstate.edu (KENNEDY JAMES SCOT) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  RE %3A  RE %3A  Clipper Chip %0A References %3A  <67 %40 cyberia.win.net> %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr29.003732.2184 %40 a.cs.okstate.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  talk.politics.guns %0A Organization %3A  Oklahoma State University %0A Date %3A  Thu, 29 Apr 93 00 %3A 37 %3A 32 GMT %0A Lines %3A  44 %0A  %0A From article <67 %40 cyberia.win.net>, by johnston %40 cyberia.win.net (Robert Johnston) %3A  %0A > Encryption technologies are currently reguarded as arms by the %0A > Feds, hence the export ban.  While the Second is under enough %0A > attack for guarrentteing our rights to fire arms, perhaps we %0A > should reflect on this as well.  (Perhaps fire arms are not the %0A > only weapons covered under the Second Amendment) %0A  %0A Hmmm... I wouldn't consider encryption to be a weapon.  How would the %0A government classify encryption?  Seems to me that encryption ought to %0A be covered by the first amendment.   Using this line of reasoning, the %0A government shouldn't be able to restrict what data people encrypt and %0A what encryption algorithms they use because this would be restricting %0A one's freedom of speech.  In other words, encrypted data---text, %0A graphics, or other information---is just another form of free speech. %0A For this reason the government shouldn't be able to regulate the use %0A of encryption algorithms and encrypted data.  The only time the %0A government should be able to 'force' someone to reveal his or her %0A encryption keys for some encrypted data is when the encrypted data %0A in question may be something that isn't protected by the first %0A amendment such as kiddy porn.  Even in a case like this the %0A government should be required to get a search warrant before coercing %0A someone into revealing the keys. %0A  %0A BTW, what encryption methods are considered to be state-of-the-art %0A nowdays.  Have the feds relaxed export restrictions on DES yet? %0A Also, is DES still regarded as a good form of encryption? %0A  %0A > Robert Johnston %0A > johonston %40 cyberia.win.net %0A  %0A  %0A Scott Kennedy,  Brewer and Patriot %0A  %0A Before %3A   "David Koresh is a cheap thug who interprets %0A           the Bible through the barrel of a gun..."  --ATF spokesman %0A After %3A    "[The ATF] is a cheap thug who interprets %0A           [the Constitution] through the barrel of a gun..."  --Me %0A  %0A          ******************************************* %0A          * BATF = Cigarette Cops                   * %0A          * FBI  = Fuehrer's Bureau of Incineration * %0A          ******************************************* %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_615 |@raw_text From %3A  mkapor %40 eff.org (Mitch Kapor) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Jerry Berman on pseudonymous privacy %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr24.171628.22449 %40 eff.org> %0A Originator %3A  mkapor %40 eff.org %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 eff.org (NNTP News Poster) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  eff.org %0A Organization %3A  The Electronic Frontier Foundation %0A References %3A  <9304241538.AA10342 %40 alumni.cco.caltech.edu> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 17 %3A 16 %3A 28 GMT %0A Lines %3A  21 %0A  %0A nobody %40 alumni.cco.caltech.edu correctly states Jerry Berman's 1985 view on %0A privacy, but he mistakenly assumes that this represents Berman's 1993 view as %0A EFF Executive Director. %0A  %0A As one of the people who convinced Jerry that legal protections for privacy %0A are insufficient, and that technical measures, especially public key %0A cryptography, are also vitally necessary, I can tell you that Jerry and EFF %0A are fully committed to this position. %0A  %0A The previous poster is apparently unaware of a long series of EFF positions in %0A support of this view.  I suggest those interested read EFF's position on %0A Clipper or our other work in digital privacy.  Check ftp.eff.org for more %0A details. %0A  %0A One of the great things about human beings is that they are capable of change %0A and evolution in their thinking.  The idea that crypto is critical to privacy %0A is one which is no longer limited to certain net afficianados, but is  %0A spreading to parts of the public policy community in Washington. %0A  %0A Mitch Kapor %0A co-Founder, EFF  %0A

doc_633 |@raw_text From %3A  fennell %40 well.sf.ca.us (Michael Daniel Fennell) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Why circuit boards are green? %0A Message-ID %3A  <fennell.735855525 %40 well.sf.ca.us> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 well.sf.ca.us %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  well.sf.ca.us %0A Organization %3A  The Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link, Sausalito, CA %0A References %3A  <1993Apr23.105152.20155 %40 news.cs.tut.fi> <ulan.735839488 %40 ee.ualberta.ca> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 20 %3A 18 %3A 45 GMT %0A Lines %3A  13 %0A  %0A  %0A Why are circuit boards green?  The material used to make them goes by two %0A names.  If it is used to make circuit boards it is called FR-4.  The same %0A material is used in the cryogenics industrya and marine industries as a %0A structural material and is called G-10.  FR-4 and G-10 are both green.  They %0A are not green because of a solder masking agent.  The basic ingredients are %0A a clear epoxy resin and glass fibers.  I am not sure what the specs are on %0A the resin, but if you are really curious you can call NEMA (National %0A Electronics Manufacturing Association) or Ciba Geigy (a major manufacturer %0A of epoxy resins) to find out.  As an aside, I occasionally mix clear epoxy %0A and glass microsphres to cast small structures for cryogenics experiments. %0A The proportions of glass to epoxy are about the same as in G-10.  They are %0A the same green color. %0A

doc_665 |@raw_text From %3A  pvr %40 wang.com () %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  2% silver solder %0A Organization %3A  Wang Labs, Lowell MA, USA %0A Date %3A  Tue, 27 Apr 1993 13 %3A 20 %3A 59 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <C6592z.Dw6 %40 wang.com> %0A References %3A  <199304251131.AA08572 %40 dec3100a> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 wang.com %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  preilley.wiis.wang.com %0A Lines %3A  20 %0A  %0A shiekh %40 ictp.trieste.it (Andy Shiekh) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >  I have seen the existance of electronics solder with a 2% silver %0A >content that seems to have good wetting and fatique reatings. %0A >  Can anyone tell me why it is not used? (silver is not such an expensive %0A >metal). %0A  %0A    This is called silver bearing solder.   It is used to solder to %0A devices that have silvered contacts.   One application is soldering %0A to the ceramic terminal strips used in the old Tektronix scopes.   These %0A were notched ceramic strips that were silver plated in the notches. %0A If you used ordinary solder the molten metal would disolve the silver %0A off of the ceramic.   The silver was quite thin.   The 2% is a saturated %0A solution of silver in tin and lead.    Thus, no more silver can be %0A disolved in the solder solution.   Other devices that use silver contacts %0A are quartz crystals and ultrasonic transducers. %0A -- %0A -->>>>>>>>>> Peter Reilley ..... pvr %40 wiis.wang.com ..... KA1LAT <<<<<<<<<<<-- %0A      For info on BEAV (Binary Editor And Viewer) finger pvr %40 das.wang.com %0A                      Well, that about says it. %0A
