doc_668 |@raw_text From %3A  higgins %40 fnalf.fnal.gov (Bill Higgins-- Beam Jockey) %0A Subject %3A  *Doppelganger* (was Re %3A  Vulcan? It may have been their first production using live %0A actors-- they were better known for their technophilic puppet shows, %0A such as *Supercar*, *Stingray*, and *Thunderbirds*.  Later, they went %0A on to do more live-action SF series %3A  *UFO* and *Space %3A  1999*. %0A  %0A The astronomy was lousy, but the lifting-body spacecraft, VTOL %0A airliners, and mighty Portugese launch complex were *wonderful* to %0A look at. %0A  %0A Bill Higgins, Beam Jockey              %7C In a churchyard in the valley %0A Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory  %7C Where the myrtle doth entwine %0A Bitnet %3A            HIGGINS %40 FNAL.BITNET  %7C There grow roses and other posies %0A Internet %3A        HIGGINS %40 FNAL.FNAL.GOV  %7C Fertilized by Clementine. %0A SPAN/Hepnet %3A            43011 %3A  %3A HIGGINS  %7C %0A

It's  wet %0A    kippers at ten paces if there's any repeat of this sort of thing! %0A  %0A    Now, in keeping with the  grand tradition of wreck.moto, let's  mutate! %0A    Take your partners by the hand... %0A  %0A    On Tuesday morning I spent a couple of hours (when I -should- have been %0A    working) with a  torch, brazing bits  of scrap metal  over the  biggest %0A    holes in  Yamadog's exhaust  pipes (s'mazin'  what you  can do  with  a %0A    couple of AA  cells and a  three-volt bulb!). So, I stuff in a bit %0A    of baked-beanz can and a bit more of Mr Holts' very best "gun-gum"  and %0A    come to work (late again!) so that I  can ask of the oracle... Anybody tried it? %0A  %0A    Oh, and if anybody can tell me  what the differences are between a  205 %0A    and a  207  brazing  rod (made  by  "Gaz"  [Yup!   the  camping  folks. %0A    Surprised the marmalade outa' me, too!] in that place just off the Isle %0A    of Wight) I'd be eternally  grateful (twenty-sodding-quid for two  rods %0A    and I don't even know what I'm buying. Soon %0A    >companies will be doing larger, and more permanant, billboards in the %0A    >sky.  I wouldn't want a world a few decades from now when the sky %0A    >looks like Las Vegas.  That would _really_ make me sad. %0A  %0A    Think for a moment about the technology required to do that.  By  %0A    the time they could make the Earth's sky look like Las Vegas,  %0A    the people could afford to go backpacking on the Moon. Round %0A    trip costs for 500 kg to the Moon would be about the same as %0A    5000 kg in a Low Earth "advertising" orbit %3A  Very roughly the %0A    same cost as a smallish billboard, therefore. If such ads were %0A    to become common place, that would have to be a very low price... %0A  %0A This is nonsense.  Its like saying that by the time commercials %0A on television become commonplace every citizen will have their own %0A hour long nationally broadcast TV program. %0A  %0A    There's always been a problem of having to get  %0A    away from civilization before you can really find "natural" %0A    scenery. 100 years ago, this usually didn't take a trip %0A    of over 5 miles. Today, most people would have to go 100 miles %0A    or more. If we ever get to the point where we have billboards %0A    on orbit, that essentially means that no place on Earth is still %0A    "wild." While that may or may not be a good thing, the orbital %0A    billboards aren't the problem %3A  They are just a symptom of  %0A    growing, densely-populated civilization. Banning such ads will %0A    not save your view of the night sky, because by the time  %0A    such ads could become widespread you will probably have trouble %0A    finding a place without street lights, where you can _see_ %0A    the stars... %0A  %0A The rest of your post is strange mishmash of "its already really bad" %0A and "it doesn't really matter if it gets worse."  You should try to %0A figure out what you are really arguing for.  (Kneejerk anti-environ- %0A mentalism?) %0A  %0A -david %0A  %0A P.S.  A passing sattelite does not have the same effect on visible %0A light astronomy as an object as bright as the full moon. %0A

doc_711 |@raw_text From %3A  boyd %40 acsu.buffalo.edu (Daniel F Boyd) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Off the shelf cheap DES keyseach machine (Was %3A  Re %3A  Corporate acceptance of the wiretap chip) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5wFqH.98o %40 acsu.buffalo.edu> %0A Date %3A  22 Apr 93 19 %3A 06 %3A 16 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.192105.11751 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr21.001230.26384 %40 lokkur.dexter.mi.us> <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> <strnlghtC5wCMo.Fx5 %40 netcom.com> %0A Sender %3A  nntp %40 acsu.buffalo.edu %0A Organization %3A  UB %0A Lines %3A  40 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  autarch.acsu.buffalo.edu %0A  %0A In article <strnlghtC5wCMo.Fx5 %40 netcom.com> strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A > In article <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> arussell %40 austin.ibm.com (AG Russell) %0A > writes %3A  %0A > >At the company I worked for previously, I received a file that was %0A > >des encryped and the person that had sent it, went on vaction. %0A > >Rather than wait two weeks I set up a straight frontal attack with %0A > >one key at a time.  It only took two(2) days to crack the file. %0A  %0A > Taking this at face value (though it seems quite dissonant with much else %0A > that has been published here about brute force DES cracking, unless Russell %0A > was lucky with respect to the key), I'd be very interested in whether the %0A > program Russell used is available? In whether he used a cleartext %0A > recognition algorithm in the program or whether he had to examine each %0A > decryption by hand? In whether he used a known plaintext attack? %0A  %0A  %0A This has to be a dictionary attack.  No other attack makes sense. %0A  %0A  %0A This means that whoever encrypted the file just typed some password %0A which was a single dictionary word, and then Russell tried all the %0A words in the dictionary.  This isn't too implausible, especially if he %0A was smart and clipped the first plaintext block off the ciphertext (if %0A the first block doesn't decrypt then obviously the others won't %0A either). %0A  %0A Assuming one attempt a second, it takes seven hours to try all the %0A words in /usr/dict/words.   Not real tough. %0A  %0A If you want DES to be secure, you have to use RANDOM KEYS.  You can't %0A just type your wife's name and think "aha they'll never guess that %0A one!" %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Daniel F. Boyd -- boyd %40 cs.buffalo.edu  %0A  %0A "Welcome to the First Church of Appliantology.  The white zone is for %0A loading and unloading only." %0A

doc_728 |@raw_text From %3A  djb %40 silverton.berkeley.edu (D. J. Bernstein) %0A Subject %3A  Does any organization fight encryption-is-harmful statements? %0A Message-ID %3A  <2877.Apr1918.29.0993 %40 silverton.berkeley.edu> %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 93 18 %3A 29 %3A 09 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5L1D2.GMw %40 dove.nist.gov> %0A Followup-To %3A  comp.org.eff.talk,alt.privacy.clipper %0A Organization %3A  IR %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A Here are two quotes from the White House. %0A  %0A ``The Administration is not saying, "since encryption threatens the %0A public safety and effective law enforcement, we will prohibit it %0A outright" (as some countries have effectively done); nor is the U.S. %0A saying that "every American, as a matter of right, is entitled to an %0A unbreakable commercial encryption product."'' %0A  %0A ``In making this decision, I do not intend to prevent the private %0A sector from developing, or the government from approving, other %0A microcircuits or algorithms that are equally effective in assuring %0A both privacy and a secure key-escrow system.'' %0A  %0A These quotes bother me in three ways. (1) Many people will read and %0A remember that ``encryption threatens the public safety and effective %0A law enforcement.'' (2) The Administration is explicitly failing to %0A acknowledge that every American is entitled to use strong encryption %0A to ensure his own privacy. (3) The President, by implication, may %0A intend to outlaw any cryptographic devices which ensure privacy but %0A do not have a key-escrow system. %0A  %0A I want to see an organization which will combat such statements. %0A Encryption does _not_ threaten the public safety, any more than ski %0A masks do. Every American _is_ entitled to use strong encryption which %0A ensures his own privacy and is _not_ crippled by a key-escrow system. %0A I guess I'm looking for a ``League for Cryptographic Freedom.'' Or a %0A ``National Cryptography Association.'' %0A  %0A To what extent does the EFF serve this purpose? Is a new organization %0A necessary? Does it already exist? %0A  %0A ---Dan %0A

Carpenter) writes %3A  %0A >I'm wondering if it's possible to use radio waves to measure the %0A >distance between a transmitter(s) and receiver? %0A  %0A Yes, you could. %0A  %0A >Seems to me that you should be able to measure the signal strength %0A >and determine distance. This would be for short distances (2000 ft), %0A >and I would need to have accuracy of 6 inches, or so. %0A  %0A Well, letsee (whipping out HP-48SX, soon to be GX) %3A  6 inches/3*10^8 m/s=.5 %0A nanoseconds resolution.  Hmm.  That'll be rather difficult! %0A  %0A The more standard (read %3A  better) method is to use ultrasound, generally %0A somewhere around 40kHz.  Sound travels a heck of a lot slower than light %0A (radio waves), and is therefore much easier to deal with. %0A  %0A >What frequencies would be best for this? Or does matter? %0A  %0A It might be easiest to visit a hardware store and look at the numerous %0A "sonic estimator" type devices that do what you want here.  Many are pretty  %0A cheap too -- <$30.  (In fact, for awhile the Stanley Estimator was selling %0A for something like $8.  That's the one I bought!  %3A -) ) %0A  %0A 					---Joel Kolstad %0A

It can pitch-shift it (change the %0A notes you sing).  It can add harmonies to your singing (up to 5 parts at one %0A time).  It can change your voice into a synthesizer's voice but leave what %0A you say alone and intelligible.  This works well for a "computerized" sounding %0A singer, or robot voice.  For those of you who just thought about that, yes - %0A you can do the voices from Robo-Cop, and the old ELO lead-ins with it, and yes - %0A I'm a little red-faced to say that I tried those specifically.  For an input, %0A it takes both %3A  XLR (3-prong mic) and 1/4" cables.  For output, you can have %0A a combination of the original-input-only, and your choice of mix between the %0A original signal and the effect (can be effect only if desired).  It has preset %0A setups, which you can edit and save for your own preferences.  It has a couple %0A of light scratches, but does not look bad, and works flawlessly.  Even when we %0A don't use it in my music, it's been good for after-hours fun in the studio. %0A The manual is included.  I never got around to getting rack-ears for it, but %0A it has only gotten studio use from me - no roading, so it's not beaten. %0A --  %0A       oooooooo       o     o                      Steve Hitch %0A      oo      o     oo    oo       My opinions are my own. doc_746 |@raw_text From %3A  fleice_mike %40 tandem.com (Mike Fleice) %0A Subject %3A  Last call %3A  S/W wizard position at Tandem (Cupertino CA) %0A Message-ID %3A  <fleice_mike-190493170435 %40 130.252.132.77> %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.space %0A Sender %3A  news %40 tandem.com %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  130.252.132.77 %0A Organization %3A  Tandem Computers Incorporated, Cupertino, CA %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 23 %3A 58 %3A 04 GMT %0A Lines %3A  28 %0A  %0A Well, we got some responses and are doing some interviews with interesting %0A responders. However, just in case the other posting was overlooked by an %0A incredibly talented person ... Mea Culpa for posting this here for Mike, %0A but we're looking for someone special %3A  %0A  %0A    Tandem Computers is currently looking for a software wizard to help %0A  us architect & implement a fault-tolerant generalized instrumentation %0A  subsystem as part of our proprietary operating system kernel (TNS %0A  Kernel). The TNS Kernel is a proprietary, loosely-coupled parallel, %0A  message-based operating system. The TNS Kernel has wide connectivity %0A  to open standards. %0A    In this key individual contributor role, you will work with other %0A  developers working on various components of the Transaction Management %0A  Facility. %0A    Your background needs to encompass some of the following 4 categories %0A  (3 of 4 would be excellent) %3A  %0A    Category 1. Math %3A  Working knowledge of statistics, real analysis, as %0A  used in experimental physics or chemistry, or in engineering. %0A    Category 2. Working knowledge of telemetry issues-- i.e. time series, %0A  autocorrelation, and statistical correlation of data streams. %0A    Category 3. Integration & Test -- Instrumentation of systems under test, %0A  i.e. payloads, flight modules, etc. %0A    Category 4 %3A  Software Engineering %3A  programming skills, algorithms, and %0A  systems software techniques. %0A  %0A    Please send your resume to Mike Fleice, Tandem Computers 10555 %0A  Ridgeview Ct., LOC 100-27, Cupertino, CA 95014-0789; Fax (408) 285-0813; %0A  or e-mail fleice_mike %40 tandem.com %0A

doc_831 |@raw_text From %3A  elliott %40 optilink.COM (Paul Elliott) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Analog switches/Balanced Demodulators %0A Message-ID %3A  <15485 %40 optilink.COM> %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 93 00 %3A 37 %3A 22 GMT %0A References %3A  <msf.734832494 %40 skaro> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  DSC/Optilink Access Products %0A Lines %3A  53 %0A  %0A In article <msf.734832494 %40 skaro> msf %40 skaro.as.arizona.edu (Michael Fulbright) writes %3A  %0A >I am trying to build a synchronous demodulator and I've hit a snag. %0A >In my application I want to be able to change the gain of an %0A >op amp amplifier from 1 to -1, controlable via a digital input. %0A >The most obvious way I've come up with is to use analog switches %0A >to adjust the gain of the op amp. The only analog switch I have %0A >experience with it the 4066. Unfortunately I want to switch an %0A >AC signal which goes from about -5V to 5V, and the 4066 is only %0A >for positive signals. %0A >[...] %0A > I have a carrier signal which varies between 0V and +5V. I want %0A >to demodulate an input signal by feeding the input signal thru a %0A >amp with a gain of 1 when the carrier is at +5V, and thru a amp %0A >with a gain of -1 when the carrier is 0V. The output is then %0A >low pass filtered. I believe this is called lock in detection as well %0A >as synchronous demodulation. %0A  %0A Look at the 4053.  This is a triple 2-to-1 transmission-gate analog %0A multiplexer, with positive and negative power supplies (can be run %0A from a single-ended supply as well).  With dual supplies, the logic %0A inputs still range from ground (0 Volts) to VDD. %0A  %0A This is a neat (well, I think so) design for a switchable-polarity %0A amplifier %3A  %0A  %0A                  +-----/\/\/\-------+ %0A                  %7C                  %7C %0A                  %7C    /--------\    %7C %0A INPUT -+-/\/\/\--+----%7C -      %7C    %7C %0A        %7C              %7C  opamp %7C----+------- OUTPUT %0A        +-/\/\/\--+----%7C +      %7C %0A                  %7C    \--------/ %0A                  %7C %0A CONTROL	---------X (analog switch) %0A                  %7C %0A                  %7C %0A                 --- %0A                 GND %0A  %0A All resistors are equal-value.  When the analog switch is closed, %0A the amp is inverting-gain-of-one.  With the switch open, it is %0A non-inverting-gain-of-one.  You can clean up the circuit to trim %0A out input offset current if this hurts the balance (this would show %0A up as carrier feed-through). %0A  %0A For high frequencies, the slew-rate of the opamp might cause problems, %0A especially if it isn't symmetrical (and it usually isn't). %0A  %0A --  %0A --------     Paul Elliott - DSC Optilink - Petaluma, CA USA      ---------- %0A     {uunet,pyramid,tekbspa}!optilink!elliott -or- elliott %40 optilink.com %0A        "I used to think I was indecisive, but now I'm not so sure." %0A  %0A  
doc_833 |@raw_text From %3A  games %40 max.u.washington.edu %0A Subject %3A  Words from the Chairman of Boeing on SSTO type stuff %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr27.124850.1 %40 max.u.washington.edu> %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 93 20 %3A 48 %3A 50 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  max.1993Apr27.124850.1 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Lines %3A  57 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  max.u.washington.edu %0A  %0A  %0A   Yesterday, I went to the Boeing shareholders meeting.  It was a bit shorter %0A than I expected.  Last year (when the stock was first down), they made a big %0A presentation on the 777, and other programs.  This year, it was much more %0A bare-bones. %0A  %0A In any case, I wanted to ask a question that the board of directors would %0A hear, and so I got there early, and figured that If I didn't get to the mike, %0A maybe they would read mine off of a card, and so I wrote it down, and handed it %0A in. %0A  %0A After the meeting started, Mr. Shrontz said that he would only answer written %0A questions, in order to be fair to the people in the overflow room that only %0A had monitors downstairs.  Naturally, I was crushed. %0A  %0A So, when question and answer time came, I was suprised to find my question %0A being read and answered.  Admittedly near the end of the ones that he took. %0A Presumably getting there early, and getting the question in early made all %0A the difference. %0A  %0A So, on to the substance. The question was  %0A  %0A Is Boeing looking at anything BEYOND the high speed Civil Transport, such %0A as a commercial space launch system, and if not, how will Boeing compete %0A with the reusable single stage to orbit technology presently being developed %0A by Mcdonnell Douglass? %0A  %0A Well, he read it without a hitch, and without editing, with impressed me, %0A then he answered it very quickly treating it as a two part question, last %0A part first. %0A  %0A This is to the best of my recollection what he said. %0A  %0A As far as single stage to orbit technology, we think that we have a better %0A answer in a two stage approach, and we are talking to some of our customers  %0A about that.  As far as commercialization, that is a long ways off.  The High %0A speed Civil Transport is about as far out as our commercial planning goes at %0A this point. %0A  %0A So, this tells me that Boeing still considers space to be a non-commercial %0A arena, and for the most part this is true, however it also tells me that  %0A they consider there to be enough money in building space launchers for them %0A to persue work on their own. %0A  %0A Now, I do have a friend on the spacelifter program at boeing.  Actually, %0A this is a mis-nomer, as there is no spacelifter contract for the work that this %0A guy is doing, however, he is doing work in preparation of a proposal for space %0A lifter contracts.  He won't tell me what he is doing, but maybe this is where %0A the TSTO action is taking place at boeing.  At the very minimum, the chairman %0A of the board of boeing said that they have an approach in mind, and they are %0A trying to do something with it.   %0A  %0A Anybody know anything further? %0A Is this really news? %0A Does this threaten further work on DC-? ? %0A  %0A                     John. %0A  
doc_834 |@raw_text From %3A  whughes %40 lonestar.utsa.edu (William W. Hughes) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Tempest %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.132638.19448 %40 ringer.cs.utsa.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 ringer.cs.utsa.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  lonestar.utsa.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Texas at San Antonio %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.034724.3748 %40 colnet.cmhnet.org> <1993Apr21.172614.10185 %40 lehman.com> <1993Apr22.105915.5584 %40 infodev.cam.ac.uk> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 13 %3A 26 %3A 38 GMT %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr22.105915.5584 %40 infodev.cam.ac.uk> rja14 %40 cl.cam.ac.uk %0A (Ross Anderson) writes %3A  %0A >res %40 colnet.cmhnet.org (Rob Stampfli) writes %3A  %0A >> Wouldn't a a second monitor of similar type scrolling gibberish and adjacent %0A >> to the one being used provide reasonable resistance to tempest attacks? %0A >We've got a tempest receiver in the lab here, and there's no difficulty in %0A >picking up individual monitors. Their engineering tolerances are slack enough %0A >that they tend to radiate on different frequencies. Even where they overlap, you %0A >can discriminate because they have different line synch frequencies - you can %0A >lock in on one and average the others out. %0A > %0A >The signals are weird in any case, with varying polarisations and all sorts %0A >of interactions with the building. Just moving a folded dipole around is also %0A >highly effective as a (randomised) means of switching from one monitor to %0A >another, %0A > %0A Hell, just set up a spark jammer, or some other _very_ electrically-noisy %0A device. Or build an active Farrady cage around the room, with a "noise" %0A signal piped into it. While these measures will not totally mask the %0A emissions of your equipment, they will provide sufficient interference to %0A make remote monitoring a chancy proposition, at best. There is, of course, %0A the consideration that these measures may (and almost cretainly will) %0A cause a certain amount of interference in your own systems. It's a matter %0A of balancing security versus convenience. %0A  %0A BTW, I'm an ex-Air Force Telecommunications Systems Control Supervisor and %0A Telecommunications/Cryptographic Equipment Technician. %0A  %0A --  %0A                             REMEMBER WACO! %0A      Who will the government decide to murder next? Maybe you? %0A [Opinions are mine; I don't care if you blame the University or the State.] %0A

doc_868 |@raw_text From %3A  strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Off the shelf cheap DES keyseach machine (Was %3A  Re %3A  Corporate acceptance of the wiretap chip) %0A Message-ID %3A  <strnlghtC5wCMo.Fx5 %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  DSI/USCRPAC %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.192105.11751 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr21.001230.26384 %40 lokkur.dexter.mi.us> <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 17 %3A 59 %3A 12 GMT %0A Lines %3A  34 %0A  %0A In article <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> arussell %40 austin.ibm.com (AG Russell) %0A writes %3A  %0A  %0A > %0A >At the company I worked for previously, I received a file that was des encryped %0A >and the person that had sent it, went on vaction.  Rather than wait two weeks %0A >I set up a straight frontal attack with one key at a time.  It only took two(2) %0A >days to crack the file.  No, I don't have any faith in DES. %0A > %0A  %0A Taking this at face value (though it seems quite dissonant with much else %0A that has been published here about brute force DES cracking, unless Russell %0A was lucky with respect to the key), I'd be very interested in whether the %0A program Russell used is available? In whether he used a cleartext %0A recognition algorithm in the program or whether he had to examine each %0A decryption by hand? In whether he used a known plaintext attack? %0A  %0A He probably should also tell us, given his address, what machine he used--a %0A desktop, workstation, or super-computer. %0A  %0A Depending on his answer, this could be an appalling development calling into %0A question both DES and RSA/DES. Dunno about RSA/IDEA. %0A  %0A If any bright programmer with a little idle machine time can crack a single %0A DES message in a couple of days (assuming no tricks that are %0A message-specific), then here's my Clipper key, NSA; give me the chip at %0A once.   %3A -) %0A  %0A David %0A --  %0A David Sternlight         Great care has been taken to ensure the accuracy of %0A                          our information, errors and omissions excepted.   %0A  %0A  %0A

Otherwise it's %0A better to simply launch the probes independently. Don't judge interplanetary trajectories in general %0A by what the Voyagers did %3A   they exploited a lineup that occurs only %0A every couple of centuries, and even so Voyager 2 took a rather indirect %0A route to Neptune. %0A  %0A >Also the mother ship would be powered (if not the Mars Mission) by a normal %0A >propulsion, but also a solar sail ... %0A  %0A Solar sails are pretty useless in the outer solar system. doc_891 |@raw_text From %3A  mock %40 abell.mit.edu (Patrick C. Mock) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Bursters. Where are they? %0A Date %3A  28 Apr 1993 23 %3A 16 %3A 42 GMT %0A Organization %3A  MIT Center for Space Research %0A Lines %3A  24 %0A Sender %3A  mock %40 abell (Patrick C. Mock) %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1rn38qINNdv %40 senator-bedfellow.MIT.EDU> %0A References %3A  <93116.093828SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> <1993Apr26.141114.19777 %40 midway.uchicago.edu> <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  abell.mit.edu %0A Originator %3A  mock %40 abell %0A  %0A  %0A In article <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu>, kwp %40 wag.caltech.edu (Kevin W. Plaxco) writes %3A  %0A > In article <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> abdkw %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov (David Ward) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A > But I believe that there is a fundamental difference here.  The other x %0A > three instruments are focusing instruments, that, more or less, form %0A > an image, so positional errors are limited by craft attitude and the  %0A > resolving power of the optics.  BATSE is an altogether different %0A > beast, effectively just 8 coincidence counters, one on each corner of  %0A > the craft.  Positional information is triangulated from the  %0A > differential signal arrival times at each of the detectors. %0A  %0A This is not quite right.  The differential arrival time techinique %0A requires interplanetary baselines to get good positions.  The %0A differential arrival at the eight detectors differ by 10's of nanoseconds. %0A This is smaller than BATSE's microsecond timing capabilities. %0A BATSE, Ulysses, and Mars Obsverver are used for this technique. %0A  %0A Each BATSE detector does not have a full sky field of view. %0A The sensitivity of each detector decreases with increasing  %0A angle of incidence.  The burst position on the sky is determined by %0A comparing the count rates in different detectors. %0A  %0A Pat %0A

doc_895 |@raw_text From %3A  Carr-C10973 %40 email.comm.mot.com (Eric Carr) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  help with phone wire %3A  which ones are "tip" & "ring"? %0A Message-ID %3A  <Carr-C10973-230493125059 %40 145.1.160.178> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 18 %3A 04 %3A 52 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr22.103922.23177 %40 husc3.harvard.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 lmpsbbs.comm.mot.com (Net News) %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.electronics %0A Distribution %3A  usa %0A Organization %3A  SmartNet Trunked Systems %0A Lines %3A  38 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  145.1.160.178 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr22.103922.23177 %40 husc3.harvard.edu>, %0A mlevin %40 husc8.harvard.edu (Michael Levin) wrote %3A  %0A >  %0A >  %0A > I just bought a little gizmo that is supposed to be installed "in %0A > series with the tip or ring lines" of the phone wire. Which ones are %0A > those? Suppose I am holding a regular phone wire, such that the little %0A > plastic tooth (on the little plastic square thing with the naked lead %0A > ends that you plug into the phone) is facing down, and away from me. %0A > Which of the 4 wires that I see is the "tip" and which is the "ring"? %0A > Please reply to mlevin %40 husc8.harvard.edu. %0A >  %0A > Mike Levin %0A  %0A Assuming you are refering to standard POTS or ground start lines %3A  %0A  %0A If you are looking at loop start lines under idle conditions, the RING %0A conductor is the one with approximately -48 to -52 vDC with respect to %0A ground while the TIP conductor is at or very near ground potential (be sure %0A to reference the telco ground when taking your measurements).   %0A  %0A If you are dealing with ground start lines under idle conditions, the RING %0A conductor will be the one with approximately -48 to -52 vDC while the TIP %0A conductor would look like it's floating (you may see some potential from %0A line capacitance it will bleed off over time).  Remember to use the telco %0A ground as your reference when making measurements.  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A                                    _________ %0A                             ______/        /_______ %0A                            /     '67 Caprice      / %0A                           /_____ Sport Coupe_____/ %0A                                 /_________/ %0A  %0A  %0A                                %0A                                            %0A  
doc_898 |@raw_text From %3A  rogue %40 ccs.northeastern.edu (Free Radical) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper considered harmful [Restated and amplified] %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr25.025459.12837 %40 random.ccs.northeastern.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 random.ccs.northeastern.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  damon.ccs.northeastern.edu %0A Organization %3A  College of CS, Northeastern U %0A References %3A  <15583 %40 optilink.COM> <strnlghtC602KA.IFD %40 netcom.com> <1rcboi$j4a %40 access.digex.net> %0A Distribution %3A  inet %0A Date %3A  Sun, 25 Apr 1993 02 %3A 54 %3A 59 GMT %0A Lines %3A  43 %0A  %0A In article <1rcboi$j4a %40 access.digex.net> steve-b %40 access.digex.com %0A (Steve Brinich) writes %3A   %0A [...] %0A >  FEDS %3A  We need the keys to Joe Blow's phone. %0A > %0A >  ESCROW AGENT %3A  Joe Blow?  You have a warrant to tap his line? %0A > %0A >  FEDS %3A  Well, no, but we have a warrant to tap Carlos "Slime-Devil" Gonzales' %0A >     line, and our tap shows that Mr. Gonzales is using Mr. Blow's phone. %0A > %0A >  ESCROW AGENT %3A  Well, OK.... %0A  %0A No no no no no no no. %0A  %0A It will go like this %3A  %0A  %0A FEDS %3A  We need the key to phone 334RE67D99. %0A  %0A ESCROW %3A  You have a warrant to tap the line phone 334RE67D99 is on? %0A  %0A FEDS %3A  Yes. %0A  %0A ESCROW %3A  Fine, here is our key. %0A  %0A What happens is, Feds tap a line; find Clipper is being used; extract %0A serial number; get key; decipher convo.  The serial number is never %0A registered to a specific owner, it is _sent_ as part of the %0A conversation.  If I give you my Clipper phone, you do not need to %0A re-register it (mainly because it was never 'registered' to me in the %0A first place). %0A  %0A There are a lot of things that bother me about Clipper, but this is %0A not one of them.  Let's get our facts straight and not waste effort %0A demolishing straw men. %0A  %0A 	RA %0A  %0A rogue %40 cs.neu.edu (Rogue Agent/SoD!) %0A ----------------------------------- %0A The NSA is now funding research not only in cryptography, but in all areas %0A of advanced mathematics. If you'd like a circular describing these new %0A research opportunities, just pick up your phone, call your mother, and %0A ask for one. %0A

doc_914 |@raw_text From %3A  caronni %40 nessie.cs.id.ethz.ch (Germano Caronni) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  More technical details %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.184944.12092 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 bernina.ethz.ch (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, CH %0A References %3A  <1993Apr19.134346.2620 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr19.162936.7517 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 18 %3A 49 %3A 44 GMT %0A Lines %3A  120 %0A  %0A Hmm, followup on my own posting... Well, who cares. %0A  %0A First let me try to work out the facts that we get to know about the %0A Clipper-Chip, from what Hellman and Denning were able to tell us %3A  %0A  %0A The chip itself is not confined to (digital) telephony, but performs %0A general encryption in a symmetric manner.  The chip supports CFB OFB %0A ECB (and whatever the fourth mode of operation for DES is), the algorithm %0A consists of 32 rounds of *whatever*, and takes 80-Bit keys. Input data %0A seems to be 64 Bit? Yes. %0A So if two people want secure communication (whatever that means when  %0A Clipper is involved) they have first to agree on ONE secret key.  %0A (Or is it one key per direction ?) %0A They can exchange this key via DH-schemes or however. %0A Somehow the two feed their so won secret key into the Clipper-chip %0A which is now ready to work. %0A The clipper chip carries an unique Serial-Number (30 Bit's), and 160 Key-Bits. %0A These 160 key-bits seem to have been gained by encrypting the serial-number %0A with 160 seed-bits. (The seed-bits seem not to be stored in the chip) %0A At beginning of communication (and perhaps at certain invtervals whithin??) %0A before sending the fist real 64-bit output of the first encryption the Clipper %0A chip put's out packets (I guess 3) which represent the serial number, %0A and the session key. This might look like %0A X{ E[K; chipkeyK1+K2], serial number} %0A where X is a transformation of these 3? Packets involving a family-key. %0A This family(sp?)-key is equal for ALL chips. (X might be a simple XOR ???) %0A After that, the (digital?) phone-call can be done as usual, every packet %0A being encrypted and decrypted by Clipper. %0A  %0A Denning describes how K1 and K2 shall be generated, using a seed of 160 %0A Bit's. %0A  %0A Now, leaving alone politics, which does not concern me as much as you, not %0A being an American Citicien(tm) [  %3A -) ] , there are some weak points in this %0A scheme, which might be exploited by several parties. %0A  %0A As far as I know about the generation of K1,K2 ; S1 and S2 look like the  %0A obvious backdoor. They could be used to generate the chip-keys by knowing %0A the serial-number (and also the family-key) of the chip. I really can't %0A imagine why these seeds would be needed otherwise, as true random-sources %0A for the generation of the K1,K2 can be bought for not to much money. %0A  %0A Then, the escrows. Each of them will get 80 bit of a 160-Bit key. Security %0A could (as little as existant) be maximized by giving them 160-bits %0A each, which have to be xored together to give the K1,K2. Now let's simply %0A assume the escrows are trustworthy, and can't be fooled by criminals or %0A law enforchemnt agencies. (And there will be no quarrel between escrows %0A and l.e.a which would hinder the l.e.a in doing their duties, and so on %0A and so on) Once the keys are surrendered, the corresponding %0A chip is compromised forever. Not very clever, IMHO [  %3A -)) ]. %0A How about sending in the encrypted session-keys for each phone-call that %0A the police (or whoever) want's to listen to? Escrows could then simply decode %0A this session-key and send it back to police. (And would naturally not do this %0A after the warrant has expired...) This would be a better technical solution, %0A but I guess politics will not work that way. %0A  %0A Apparently (as Miss Dennings stated) the only one performing actually decodes %0A of intercepted messages shall be the FBI. Great. So local guys can not inter- %0A cept (understand) your traffic anymore. Does this mean that the FBI monopolizes %0A the right to do legal wiretaps ? (How is law over there, I have no idea who %0A is allowed to tap, and who not) This certainly means that watched communi- %0A cations will be routed automatically from the service-providing company %0A to the FBI, if the communicaiton is a watched one. And this means as far %0A as I understand it that the family-key has to be known by each switching- %0A company, and those providing cellular-phone servies etcetc. So the family-key %0A will not be very secret, and thus serial-numbers of calls will be readable %0A by anybody who cares. I _like_ traffic-analysis! %0A  %0A What do you guess, what happens, if you use the chip in ECB mode, and the %0A first few packets of the chip are somehow lost or garbled? So the session %0A key would not be actually broadcasted over the line? Hmmm. Shouldn't be so %0A difficult to do *that*  %3A ^) %0A  %0A And now a last point, for the other side. After all I have read and heard about %0A Clipper (not the programming language for dBase, is it ? [ %3A -)]) it seems %0A to have many advantages, which shold not be overseen! %0A  %0A  %0A Now an afterthought to your rights. Please note that I have no idea what I am %0A talking about!!! %0A  %0A From %3A  grady %40 netcom.com (1016/2EF221) %0A >    Amendment 1                                                            %0A >                                                                           %0A >    Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or %0A >prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, %0A >or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to  %0A >petition the Government for a redress of grievances. %0A  %0A If this text is actually in your Bill of Rights, who can overrule this ? %0A But %3A  'Freedom of speech' is not 'Secrecy of speech' %0A  %0A Maybe you need to extend your Amendment #4  to cover information and %0A communication too ? %0A  %0A I am not very sure in what position your government actually is *legally* %0A when it tries to ban cryptography (and arms) Amendment say you may have them, %0A but not under what conditions. Hmm, tricky situation  %3A -( %0A  %0A Actually it will make not much sense to discuss that topic in sci.crypt... %0A Discussion of technical details and vulnerabilites of the system are highly %0A suggested and appreciated  %3A -) %0A  %0A Friendly greetings, %0A  %0A 	Germano Caronni %0A  %0A  %0A DISCLAIMER %3A  Everything in here is derived from things I heard and read from %0A other persons, so everything could be wrong. All opinions and thoughts in here %0A are mine, and subject to change without further notification. No warranty, %0A neither implicit not explicit etc. etc. etc. ad nauseam. %0A  %0A p.s. Please don't ask me about political opinions, as I might not bother to re- %0A      ply. (For further information read the last line of P. Metzgers signature) %0A --  %0A Instruments register only through things they're designed to register. %0A Space still contains infinite unknowns. %0A                                                               PGP-Key-ID %3A 341027 %0A Germano Caronni caronni %40 nessie.cs.id.ethz.ch   FD560CCF586F3DA747EA3C94DD01720F %0A

A  %0A second on-orbit replacement was also considered, with the FUSE telescope. %0A  %0A >--  %0A >		David M. doc_983 |@raw_text From %3A  smb %40 research.att.com (Steven Bellovin) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper considered harmful %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.014337.18108 %40 ulysses.att.com> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 01 %3A 43 %3A 37 GMT %0A Distribution %3A  inet %0A References %3A  <15469 %40 optilink.COM> <1r24us$oeh %40 agate.berkeley.edu> %0A Organization %3A  AT&T Bell Laboratories %0A Lines %3A  19 %0A  %0A In article <1r24us$oeh %40 agate.berkeley.edu>, shirriff %40 sprite.berkeley.edu (Ken Shirriff) writes %3A  %0A > Imagine archiving all pay-phone conversations, so if someone turns out %0A > to be a drug dealer, you can listen to all their past drug deals.  And %0A > archive calls to/from suspected Mafia members, potential terrorists, %0A > radicals, etc.  Imagine the convenience for the police of being able to %0A > get a warrant now and listening to all the calls the World Trade Center %0A > bombers made in the past year. %0A >  %0A > Since archiving would be such a powerful tool and so easy to do, why %0A > wouldn't it happen? %0A  %0A Apart from the storage and search requirements, because the evidence %0A is inadmissible %3A   wiretaps require a warrant.  And as soon as one %0A such case comes to light, all previous cases are likely to be discovered, %0A and thrown out.  There was an article in the NY Times a few months ago %0A about how many convictions in the state might be invalidated because %0A they relied on pen registers -- and the Court of Appeals ruled that %0A pen registers were equivalent to wiretaps, and hence required warrants %0A under New York law. %0A

I %0A do not believe that RSA would consent to such.   %0A  %0A However, there are other limitation in the concept of RSAREF in which %0A NSA has an interest.  It has an interest in a limited number of %0A implementations, i.e., targets.  It has an interest in fixed key or %0A maximum modulus size.   %0A  %0A It has a legitimate (literally) right to pursue such interests.  Within %0A bounds, it probably has a right to pursue those interests by covert %0A means.  At least it has the same right as the rest of us not to disclose %0A all of its motives and intentions.  (Institutions are not self-aware; %0A they do not know their intentions in any meaningful sense.) %0A  %0A William Hugh Murray, Executive Consultant, Information System Security %0A 49 Locust Avenue, Suite 104; New Canaan, Connecticut 06840                 %0A 1-0-ATT-0-700-WMURRAY; WHMurray at DOCKMASTER.NCSC.MIL %0A

That means if the Isles %0A beat the Devils on Friday, the will meet the Caps in the playoffs. %0A  %0A 	However, I have some more comments on the Islanders and hockey in %0A general that I need to get off my chest  %3A ).  First of all, with the Islanders  %0A back-to-back lackluster performances against the Whalers, one may think that  %0A the Islanders are out of shape.  These guys always suck wind in the 2nd period, %0A come on a little in the 3rd and run out of gas too soon.  It is unbelieveable %0A how many one goal games these guys have lost.  Anyway, the games was pretty  %0A wide open.  The Isles still have tons of trouble scoring.  The Whalers played  %0A a golie in is 1st NHL start, I think his name was Lenarduzzi (sp?). Has anyone else noticed this? %0A  %0A 	Also, I think it is really a shame for hockey when I guy like Mick %0A Vukota gets as much ice time as he does.  This guy has about as much hockey %0A talent as Jiggs MacDonald (who did play hockey, I think).  Anytime he gets the %0A puck it gets stolen, and he always starts fights and gets needless penalties.  %0A Richard Pilon is another guy who is on the ice to stir up crap.  And he's a %0A defenseman.  He's got to be approaching negative infinity for his plus/minus.  %0A This guy gets beaten all the time.  Why the need for such "enforcers"?  Not %0A only do fights slow the game down ALOT, but it takes away from the guys who are %0A really trying to play the game.  I'll be one of the few to admit, I do enjoy a  %0A good fight once in a while, but only when it's "called for".  You know, when a %0A guy checks the goalie too hard.  In other words, a violation of "hockey ethics" %0A might cause you to get puched.  But there is no need to start crap when you are %0A losing or becuase you can get away with it!! Does anyone agree that referees %0A need to be a little less lenient in the 3rd and OT?  I mean COME ON already.  %0A I'm sick of seeing teams pulling guys down, holding guys etc. just becuase the %0A referee doesn't call it.  OT and late in the 3rd should be a time for strategy, %0A not physical prowess.  Trying to set up a goal should be first and foremost.  %0A If you are so afraid that the other team is going to score that you have to %0A pull a guy down to prevent it, you don't deserve to win in the first place. %0A  %0A Just My Honest Opinion, %0A  %0A Gary at Hofstra %0A ACCGSG %40 VAXB.HOFSTRA.EDU %0A ACCGSG %40 HOFSTRA.BITNET %0A

doc_1038 |@raw_text From %3A  grady %40 netcom.com (1016/2EF221) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Subliminal Channels in DSS %0A Message-ID %3A  <gradyC68AJE.HLF %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  capriccioso %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL6] %0A References %3A  <1rni9i$r4q %40 msuinfo.cl.msu.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 29 Apr 1993 04 %3A 45 %3A 13 GMT %0A Lines %3A  59 %0A  %0A May I suggest that any any proposed cipher system %0A having less entropy than the user's key and message can have %0A an embedded subliminal channel as big as the %0A difference in entropies between the entropy of the user %0A input (message) and the entropy of the output? %0A  %0A For example, take plain DES.  The unsuspecting %0A user inputs a string "PLAINTEXT" to be enciphered. %0A  %0A He cranks the algorithm which has been hacked %0A by George Quisling and comes out with j*3H4902d. %0A  %0A Nine char in and nine chars out.  Right? %0A  %0A The unsepecting user ships the ciphertext %0A to be decrpyted and the message "PLAINTEXT" %0A is produced.  Everything fine, right?  Nope. %0A  %0A  %0A Imagine the algorithm did a LZ compression %0A on PLAINTEXT before DESing. (Compressing is %0A down to four characters with more entropy %3A  %0A  %0A 9#wj %0A  %0A The opponent now pads the message with his %0A own message, also compressed %0A  %0A *3dk %40  %0A  %0A before applying DES to the concatenated %0A compressed pairs.  When decrpyted, the %0A first compressed message is stripped off %0A and declared sent.  Unbeknowst to the %0A receiver, the opponents accomplice collects %0A the remaining message in the bit bucket and %0A uncompresses to KILL NOW. %0A  %0A And to prevent all such subliminal or covert %0A storage channels you would need to have  %0A maximal entropy all the time -- which is %0A a priori impossible because (for example) %0A a stereotypical message might be %0A replaced by one bit in the output reserving %0A the rest of the output bits for the long %0A covert message. %0A  %0A In other words, if you opponent get to muck %0A with the algorithm -- you either have got to %0A muck with it LAST or concede his possible  %0A embedding of covert channels. %0A  %0A In other words, if you present a message %0A to an opponet with less than maximal entropy %0A then you have given him free bits of storage. %0A  %0A --  %0A grady %40 netcom.com  2EF221 / 15 E2 AD D3 D1 C6 F3 FC  58 AC F7 3D 4F 01 1E 2F %0A  %0A

doc_1076 |@raw_text From %3A  drunen %40 nucleus.ps.uci.edu (Eric Van Drunen) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Big amateur rockets %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  nucleus.ps.uci.edu %0A Message-ID %3A  <2BCEDFE2.18001 %40 news.service.uci.edu> %0A Organization %3A  University of California, Irvine %0A Lines %3A  30 %0A References %3A  <C5Ky9y.MKK %40 raistlin.udev.cdc.com> %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 93 16 %3A 33 %3A 38 GMT %0A  %0A Actually, they are legal! I not familiar with the ad you are speaking of %0A but knowing Popular Science it is probably on the fringe.  However, you %0A may be speaking of "Public Missle, Inc.", which is a legitimate company %0A that has been around for a while. %0A  %0A Due to advances in composite fuels, engines are now available for model %0A rockets using similar composites to SRB fuel, roughly 3 times more  %0A powerful than black powder motors.  They are even available in a reloadable %0A form, i.e. aluminum casing, end casings, o-rings (!).  The engines range %0A from D all the way to M in common manufacture, N and O I've heard of %0A used at special occasions. %0A  %0A To be a model rocket, however, the rocket can't contain any metal  %0A structural parts, amongst other requirements.  I've never heard of a %0A model rocket doing 50,000.  I have heard of > 20,000 foot flights. %0A These require FAA waivers (of course!).  There are a few large national %0A launches (LDRS, FireBALLS), at which you can see many > K sized engine %0A flights.  Actually, using a > G engine constitutes the area of "High %0A Power Rocketry", which is seperate from normal model rocketry.  Purchase %0A of engines like I have been describing require membership in the National %0A Association of Rocketry, the Tripoli Rocketry Assoc., or you have to %0A be part of an educational institute or company involved in rocketry. %0A  %0A Amatuer rocketry is another area.  I'm not really familiar with this, %0A but it is an area where metal parts are allowed, along with liquid fuels %0A and what not.  I don't know what kind of regulations are involved, but %0A I'm sure they are numerous. %0A  %0A High power rocketry is very exciting!  If you are interested or have  %0A more questions, there is a newsgroup rec.model.rockets. %0A

doc_1099 |@raw_text From %3A  wagner %40 mala.bc.ca (TOM WAGNER, Wizzard of old Audio/Visual Equipment........Nanaimo Campus) %0A Subject %3A  correction of last followup re relays %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.103012.1710 %40 mala.bc.ca> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 10 %3A 30 %3A 12 -0700 %0A References %3A  <C5qsBF.IEK %40 ms.uky.edu> <C5r60r.4ID %40 megatest.com> <1993Apr20.102756.1709 %40 mala.bc.ca> %0A Organization %3A  Malaspina College %0A Lines %3A  73 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.102756.1709 %40 mala.bc.ca>, wagner %40 mala.bc.ca (TOM WAGNER, Wizzard of old Audio/Visual Equipment........Nanaimo Campus) writes %3A  %0A > In article <C5r60r.4ID %40 megatest.com>, alung %40 megatest.com (Aaron Lung) writes %3A  %0A >> In article <C5qsBF.IEK %40 ms.uky.edu> billq %40 ms.uky.edu (Billy Quinn) writes %3A  %0A >>>I built a little project using the radio shack 5vdc relays to switch %0A >>>audio.  I got pretty bad 'clicks' when the thing switched.  I was doing %0A >>>most of the common things one is supposed to do when using relays and %0A >>>nothing seemed to get rid of the clicks. %0A >>> %0A >>> %0A >>>My question is %3A  %0A >>> %0A >>>	Is there a good relay/relay circuit that I can use for switching %0A >>>audio, so that there will be *NO* noise of any kind on the audio lines. %0A >>> %0A >>> %0A >>>I will appreciate any advice or references to advice.  Also, exact part %0A >>>numbers/company names etc. for the relays will help! %0A >>  %0A >> Are you switching high level signals or low level signals like pre-amp %0A >> out level signals?  Also, are the clicks you mentioning the big %0A >> clack that happens when it switches or are you refering to contact %0A >> bounce?  How are you driving the relays?  TTL gate output?  Switching %0A >> transistor?  How are the relays connected to what you are driving? %0A >>  %0A >> Need more specifics to answer your question!!  %3A -) %0A >  %0A > As a general rule, no relay will cleanly switch audio if you try to tranfer %0A > the circuit with the contacts.  The noise you hear is due to the momentary %0A > opening and closing of the path. %0A >  %0A > The noiseless way of transfering audio is to ground the circuit.  In high %0A > impedance audio circuits a resistive "T" is constructed close to characteristic %0A > impedance of the circuit.  Grounding the imputs (connected to the T) transfers %0A > the audio. %0A >  %0A > In low impedance circuits transformers are usually used, and the inputs are %0A > shorted out or grounded.  Secondaries are paralleled at the characteristic %0A > impedance. %0A >  %0A > Sometimes if it is necessary to actually switch audio, a second contact is used %0A > to momentarily short the circuit output for the duration of the switching time. %0A >  %0A > Telephone relays are handy, because contacts can be adjusted to "Make before %0A > break and Vica Versa" but I haven't seen any of these for years. %0A >  %0A > Nowadys switching is done electronically with OP amps, etc. %0A >  %0A > A novel circuit I used to build was a primitive "optical isolator".. It consists %0A > of a resistive photocell and a lamp, all packaged in a tube.  When the lamp is %0A > off the cell is high resistance.  Turn the lamp on and the resistance lowers %0A > passing the audio.  Once again this device in a "T" switches the audio.  Varying %0A > the lamp resistance give a remote volume control.  Use 2 variable resisters and %0A > you have a mixer! %0A >  %0A > Lots of luck! %0A > --  %0A > 73, Tom %0A > ================================================================================ %0A > Tom Wagner, Audio Visual Technician.  Malaspina College Nanaimo British Columbia %0A > (604)753-3245, Loc 2230  Fax %3A 755-8742  Callsign %3A VE7GDA Weapon %3A .45 Kentucky Rifle %0A > Snail mail to %3A   Site Q4, C2.   RR#4, Nanaimo, British Columbia, Canada, V9R 5X9   %0A >  %0A > I do not recyle.....   I keep everything!       (All standard disclaimers apply) %0A > ================================================================================ %0A --  %0A 73, Tom %0A ================================================================================ %0A Tom Wagner, Audio Visual Technician.  Malaspina College Nanaimo British Columbia %0A (604)753-3245, Loc 2230  Fax %3A 755-8742  Callsign %3A VE7GDA Weapon %3A .45 Kentucky Rifle %0A Snail mail to %3A   Site Q4, C2.   RR#4, Nanaimo, British Columbia, Canada, V9R 5X9   %0A  %0A I do not recyle.....   I keep everything!       (All standard disclaimers apply) %0A ================================================================================ %0A

Then others will get interested %0A in the idea, that maybe one should settle something bigger. The ultimate  %0A goal, as you want it, would be European Division in NHL. doc_1143 |@raw_text From %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu (T. Joseph Lazio) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Burst Mystery %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 93 10 %3A 23 %3A 43 %0A Organization %3A  Department of Astronomy, Cornell University %0A Lines %3A  45 %0A Message-ID %3A  <LAZIO.93Apr27102343 %40 seti.astrosun.tn.cornell.edu> %0A References %3A  <sarfattiC649tL.3It %40 netcom.com> %0A Reply-To %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  seti.tn.cornell.edu %0A Summary %3A  Gamma Ray Bursts are still a mystery. %0A Keywords %3A  GRBs - cyclotron lines - cosmological bursts %0A In-reply-to %3A  sarfatti %40 netcom.com's message of Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT %0A  %0A >>>>> On Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT, sarfatti %40 netcom.com (Jack Sarfatti) said %3A  %0A  %0A js> Question %3A  what is the power spectrum of the bursts. Are their sharp lines? %0A js> If so, can they be interpreted as blue-shifted atomic or molecular lines? %0A  %0A  Don't remember the spectra, but have seen some autocorrelation functions %0A  recently.  The ACFs show correlation times of milliseconds to 10s of  %0A  seconds; interestingly, the higher energies show a shorter correlation  %0A  time. %0A  %0A js> Can electron-positron annihilation gammas be seen in the bursts? Are they %0A js> red shifted or blue shifted? %0A  %0A  I believe there were claims from an earlier satellite (Ginga?) of  %0A  detection of cyclotron absorption lines.  These lines were taken as  %0A  strong evidence for neutron stars being the objects responsible for  %0A  GRBs since the magnetic field indicated was 1.0E12, fairly typical  %0A  for a neutron star.  However, Compton GRO has not seen any of these  %0A  lines and I get the impression that many are beginning to doubt whether %0A  these lines were ever real. %0A  %0A js> Since the bursts are isotropic and maybe in the galactic halo they may %0A js> be saying something about dark matter in the halo. %0A  %0A  *If* the bursts are in the halo, they most certainly are saying something  %0A  about dark matter there.  However, if they are in the halo, in order  %0A  that they appear isotropic, the "core radius" of the halo (i.e. the  %0A  innermost region of the halo) has to be greater than about 50 kpc. %0A  The halo itself would stretch much further than this.  Since the  %0A  Andromeda Galaxy is only 700 kpc away, we should be seeing bursts %0A  from that galaxy's halo, which we aren't. %0A  %0A js> If the bursts are something like the cosmic black body radiation from %0A js> way back then where are the red shifts - I mean cosmological red shifts? %0A  %0A  Remember to get a redshift, one needs some type of emission or  %0A  absorption line so one can compare the observed line frequency  %0A  to the rest line frequency.  Since no lines are seen in GRB spectra,  %0A  that comparison cannot be made. %0A  %0A -- %0A                          %7C e-mail %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A    T. Joseph Lazio       %7C phone %3A   (607) 255-6420 %0A                          %7C ICBM %3A    42 deg. 20' 08" N  76 deg. 28' 48" W %0A Cornell knows I exist?!? %7C       STOP RAPE %0A

doc_1170 |@raw_text From %3A  thomsonal %40 cpva.saic.com %0A Subject %3A  What counntries do space surveillance? %0A Message-ID %3A  <15657.2bd7de55 %40 cpva.saic.com> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 12 %3A 17 %3A 25 PST %0A Organization %3A  Science Applications Int'l Corp./San Diego %0A Lines %3A  111 %0A  %0A       Ethnocentric USian that I am, I've assumed that we and the %0A xUSSR were the only countries with significant capabilities to track %0A non-cooperative objects in low Earth orbit. Grazing in a couple of  %0A databases recently,  I found that Japan has some optical capabilities %0A along this line, and also uses a radar designed for other purposes %0A for orbital debris surveys (it isn't clear whether the radar can  %0A determine orbital elements for the objects it detects). Abstracts of  %0A the articles are appended.  %0A  %0A  %0A     This leads to the more general question %3A  do yet other people than  %0A the US, Russia, and Japan do space surveillance, and if so, how and  %0A why?  %0A  %0A Allen Thomson              SAIC                        McLean, VA, USA %0A ----------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A                          ABSTRACTS %0A  %0A Optical tracking of the experimental geodetic satellite (EGS) %0A TAKABE, MASAO; ITABE, TOSHIKAZU; ARUGA, TADASHI %0A Radio Research Laboratory, Review (ISSN 0033-801X), vol. 34, %0A March 1988, p. 23-34. In Japanese, with abstract in English. %0A      This paper reports the optical tracking results of EGS %0A (experimental geodetic satellite) which was launched on August 13, %0A 1986, by NASDA. The EGS optical tracking experiment process and an %0A outline of the Radio Research Laboratory (RRL) optical ground       <---- %0A station are discussed. A star tracking technique for optical %0A equipment calibration and satellite tracking technique for orbit %0A prediction improvement are also described. The accuracy of EGS %0A tracking data obtained by RRL at the request of NASDA is also %0A discussed. In addition, it is briefly demonstrated that the %0A position of the Japanese amateur satellite (JAS-1) which was %0A launched with the EGS, was accurately determined by means of a      <---- %0A satellite tracking video. It is clear from this experiment that     <---- %0A optical observation data (i.e., satellite direction data) are very  <---- %0A useful for satellite orbit determination during initial launch      <---- %0A stages. Furthermore, the results confirm the effectivenes of these  <---- %0A two satellite optical tracking techniques.                          <---- %0A  %0A  %0A MU radar measurements of orbital debris %0A SATO, TORU; KAYAMA, HIDETOSHI; FURUSAWA, AKIRA; KIMURA, IWANE %0A (Kyoto University, Japan) %0A AIAA, NASA, and DOD, Orbital Debris Conference %3A  Technical Issues and  %0A Future Directions, Baltimore, MD, Apr. 16-19, 1990. 10 p.  %0A RPN %3A  AIAA PAPER 90-1343 %0A      Distributions of orbital debris versus height and scattering cross  %0A section are determined from a series of observations made with a high- %0A power VHF Doppler radar (MU radar) of Japan. An automated data  %0A processing algorithm has been developed to discriminate echoes of  %0A orbiting objects from those of undesired signals such as meteor trail  %0A echoes or lightning atmospherics. Although the results are preliminary,  %0A they showed good agreement with those from NORAD tracking radar      <---- %0A observations using a much higher frequency. It is found that the     <---- %0A collision frequency of a Space Station of 1 km x 1 km size at an  %0A altitude of 500 km with orbiting debris is expected to be as high as  %0A once per two years.  %0A  %0A  %0A Monitoring of the MU radar antenna pattern by Satellite Ohzora (EXOS-C) %0A SATO, T.; INOOKA, Y.; FUKAO, S. (Kyoto Univ., Japan); KATO, S. %0A Kyoto Univ., Uji (Japan). Radio Atmospheric Science Center. %0A In International Council of Scientific Unions, Middle Atmosphere Program. %0A Handbook for MAP, Vol. 20 5 p %0A Publication Date %3A  Jun. 1986 %0A       As the first attempt among MST (mesosphere stratosphere  %0A troposphere) type radars, the MU (middle and upper atmosphere) radar  %0A features an active phased array system. Unlike the conventional large  %0A VHF radars, in which output power of a large vacuum tube is distributed  %0A to individual antenna elements, each of 475 solid state power amplifier  %0A feeds each antenna element. This system configuration enables very fast  %0A beam steering as well as various flexible operations by dividing the  %0A antenna into independent subarrays, because phase shift and signal  %0A division/combination are performed at a low signal level using  %0A electronic devices under control of a computer network. The antenna  %0A beam can be switched within 10 microsec to any direction within the  %0A zenith angle of 30 deg. Since a precise phase alignment of each element  %0A is crucial to realize the excellent performance of this system, careful  %0A calibration of the output phase of each power amplifier and antenna  %0A element was carried out. Among various aircraft which may be used for  %0A this purpose artificial satellites have an advantage of being able to  %0A make a long term monitoring with the same system. An antenna pattern  %0A monitoring system for the MU radar was developed using the scientific  %0A satellite OHZORA (EXOS-C). A receiver named MUM (MU radar antenna  %0A Monitor) on board the satellite measures a CW signal of 100 to 400  %0A watts transmitted from the MU radar. The principle of the measurement  %0A and results are discussed. %0A  %0A  %0A Equatorial radar system %0A FUKAO, SHOICHIRO;  TSUDA, TOSHITAKA; SATO, TORU; KATO, SUSUMU %0A (Kyoto University, Uji, Japan) %0A (COSPAR, IAGA, SCOSTEP, et al., Plenary Meeting, 27th, %0A Workshops and Symposium on the Earth's Middle Atmosphere, %0A Espoo, Finland, July 18-29, 1988) Advances in Space Research %0A (ISSN 0273-1177), vol. 10, no. 10, 1990, p. 151-154. %0A      A large clear air radar with the sensitivity of an incoherent  %0A scatter radar for observing the whole equatorial atmosphere up to 1000  %0A km altitude is now being designed in Japan. The radar will be built in  %0A Pontianak, West Kalimantan, Indonesia (0.03 deg N, 109.29 deg E). The  %0A system is a 47-MHz monostatic Doppler radar with an active phased array  %0A configuration similar to that of the MU radar in Japan, which has been  %0A in successful operation since 1983. It will have a PA product of about  %0A 3 x 10 to the 9th W sq m (P = average transmitter power, A = effective  %0A antenna aperture) with a sensitivity of approximately 10 times that of  %0A the MU radar. This system configuration enables pulse-to-pulse beam  %0A steering within 20 deg from the zenith. As is the case of the MU radar,  %0A a variety of operations will be made feasible under the supervision of  %0A the radar controller. A brief description of the system configuration  %0A is presented.  %0A  %0A

doc_1209 |@raw_text From %3A  schaerer %40 isi.ethz.ch (Thomas Schaerer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Voltage regulation and current limiting %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.062118.16775 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 bernina.ethz.ch (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, CH %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL9] %0A References %3A  <1r4qul$jgc %40 agate.berkeley.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 06 %3A 21 %3A 18 GMT %0A Lines %3A  21 %0A  %0A Andy Collins (acollins %40 uclink.berkeley.edu) wrote %3A  %0A  %3A  One not-so-quick question to throw out there for you guys... %0A  %0A  %3A  For our class project, we need to design and build a power supply %0A  %3A  to the following specs %3A  %0A  %0A  %3A  Voltatge %3A   adjustable from 1-12V %0A  %3A  Current %3A    *limited* at 1A %0A  %0A  %3A  Voltage must stay within 2% of designated value for I from 0-1A %0A  %3A  AC ripple less than 5 mV (rms) %0A  %0A To decide which kind of circuit you must know the initialprecission of %0A the limiter-current and the allowed temp-drift. %0A  %0A In the first case, you can use a Ube of a transistor as a voltage-reference %0A of about 0.7 VDC with a temp-drift of 2mV/K. In the second case its better %0A you use a bandgap-ref and a opamp-circuit to detect the maximum-current. %0A The output of this opamp controlls the outputstage to limit the current. %0A  %0A Bye Thomas %0A

doc_1268 |@raw_text From %3A  gtoal %40 gtoal.com (Graham Toal) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Automatic online encryption of data %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 11 %3A 03 %3A 52 +0000 %0A Message-ID %3A  <9304181103.AA12613 %40 pizzabox.demon.co.uk> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 demon.co.uk %0A Lines %3A  46 %0A  %0A 	From %3A  andersom %40 spot.Colorado.EDU (Marc Anderson) %0A  %0A 	>Also.. how about a box that you plug your phone into, which would allow %0A 	>encrypted voice communications with someone who has a similar box?   %0A 	>(digitizing input speech, transmitting, and decrypting on the other end).  I  %0A 	>don't know how a public-key system could work in this regard, but it might  %0A 	[...] %0A  %0A 	heh heh... I posted this just before reading all the Clinton Chip messages.. %0A 	I guess they beat me to it..  Anyway, I think it would be a great idea to %0A 	develop such a product, perhaps in the underground, as it would otherwise %0A 	probably become illegal pretty quickly here... %0A  %0A It's really very feasible and shouldn't be too expensive - all that's needed %0A is a box with a phone jack on one side, a DSP in the middle to do codec %0A functions of speech->compressed bytestream, and an RS232 on the other side. %0A  %0A You'd plug your phone into it, plug the RS232 into your computer, and have %0A a good old fashioned normal modem on your other RS232 port.  The CPU in the %0A middle would do the encryption with a version of pgp modified to work on %0A a byte stream. %0A  %0A With v32bis or better modems to carry the bytestream, it should work.  %0A Quality would only be marginally lower than a normal telephone. %0A  %0A At the very highest price, you could use one of those voice-mail compatible %0A modems to do the digitisation - that puts an upper bound of about $500 on %0A the cost of such a box.  In practice, you really ought to be able to get %0A the price well below $100 - I could do it now in software on my cheap&nasty %0A home RISC box (Acorn Archimedes) with the digitising microphone I bought %0A for 25 pounds, if I knew how to write good speech compression software %0A (which I don't). %0A  %0A The reason it won't work of course is that hardly anyone will have one - %0A the only consumer equipment to have encryption will use the wiretap chip. %0A Economics, I'm afraid. %0A  %0A However... we can get about 2Kcps throughput on the internet even with %0A the bottleneck of a v32bis modem.  When we get ISDN for all (ha ha ha) %0A and the new NREN, it might then be trivial to run compressed speech %0A over a tcp/ip connection on the Internet.  Perhaps we should start %0A thinking now of a standard to keep voice on the internet compatible %0A for everyone, and side-step the clipper stuff and use internet for %0A all our phone calls in future  %3A -)  [1/2 joking] %0A  %0A G %0A

Should we %0A >get into how many feet a bike going 55mph goes in .30 seconds; or %0A >how long it would take me to push my horn button?? %0A  %0A If we do, I think you'd loose.  Sure, you're hand's already on the %0A throttle.  And your thumb is already near the horn button.  Pushing the %0A horn button is one simple move.  Revving the throttle requires either %0A engaging the clutch, or accelerating.  The first is a more complex %0A manuver than a simple horn button push, and the second ain't too bright %0A when there is a potential hazard ahead.  Besides, the unique sound of a %0A horn is more effective in attracting the attention of BDI cagers than %0A is the sound of an engine, which is what they expect to hear (you are %0A on the road!). %0A  %0A As is usually the case, a single anecdote hardly constitutes sound %0A safety procedure. %0A  %0A The answer is 161.33 feet. %0A  %0A --- %0A Ed Green, former Ninjaite %7CI was drinking last night with a biker, %0A   Ed.Green %40 East.Sun.COM   %7Cand I showed him a picture of you. doc_1288 |@raw_text From %3A  warlord %40 MIT.EDU (Derek Atkins) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Screw the people, crypto is for hard-core hackers & spooks only %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 1993 21 %3A 55 %3A 48 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Massachusetts Institute of Technology %0A Lines %3A  42 %0A Message-ID %3A  <WARLORD.93Apr20175546 %40 deathtongue.mit.edu> %0A References %3A  <C5qy3M.DE3 %40 agora.rain.com <C5rrtD.1Gz %40 agora.rain.com> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  deathtongue.mit.edu %0A In-reply-to %3A  jhart %40 agora.rain.com's message of Tue, 20 Apr 1993 06 %3A 39 %3A 11 GMT %0A  %0A -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE----- %0A  %0A > Why do we hackers care about the Clipper chip?  Do we give a shit %0A > about anybody's privacy accept our own?  And perhaps not even our %0A > own; are we so smart that we always know when we're talking to %0A > somebody who has a wiretap on their phone? %0A  %0A I find this a very disturbing view!  Yes, we DO care about EVERYONE's %0A privacy... Even if "they" don't know it. What happens if the gov't %0A starts creating legislation such that the Clipper and such %0A technologies become the only "legal" encryption forms?  What happens %0A when the Clipper is the *ONLY* type of encryption chips available to %0A the masses? %0A  %0A Sure, you might have your own method of encryption, but if you don't %0A have anyone else to talk to, what use is it?  You can't assume that %0A EVERYONE will be as open as you appear to be about encryption. %0A  %0A The point here is not the specific instance of the Wiretap Chip. %0A Rather, it is like having the government telling you that they want a %0A copy of your house key, safe-deposit box keys, etc., and telling you %0A that "they wont use them unless its totally neccessary."  I sure %0A wouldn't want that.  Why should encryption be any different? %0A  %0A - -derek %0A  %0A PGP 2 key available upon request on the key-server %3A  %0A 	pgp-public-keys %40 toxicwaste.mit.edu %0A  %0A -----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE----- %0A Version %3A  2.2 %0A  %0A iQBuAgUBK9RxVjh0K1zBsGrxAQHd8ALEDi3Ear7rEmr1UHuxqv2YIblH6px6VXnb %0A +sJLcUGzZxTCfxbRqIf7msLp98p0EvYYnLZbbORyVhfSzyyHYHeQqQILHEK3LPQE %0A aP29+od6YZrCCHarNRS024E= %0A =Ftek %0A -----END PGP SIGNATURE----- %0A -- %0A   Derek Atkins, MIT '93, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science %0A      Secretary, MIT Student Information Processing Board (SIPB) %0A            MIT Media Laboratory, Speech Research Group %0A            warlord %40 MIT.EDU       PP-ASEL        N1NWH %0A

doc_1311 |@raw_text From %3A  lemay %40 netcom.com (Laura Lemay) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Need advice for riding with someone on pillion %0A Message-ID %3A  <lemayC5uEoB.IA4 %40 netcom.com> %0A Keywords %3A  advice, pillion, help! %0A Organization %3A  Netcom Online Communications Services (408-241-9760 login %3A  guest) %0A References %3A  <C5t759.DsC %40 well.sf.ca.us> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 16 %3A 48 %3A 10 GMT %0A Lines %3A  65 %0A  %0A In article <C5t759.DsC %40 well.sf.ca.us> rwert %40 well.sf.ca.us (Bob Wert) writes %3A  %0A > I need some advice on having someone ride pillion with me on my 750 Ninja. %0A > This will be the the first time I've taken anyone for an extended ride %0A > (read %3A  farther than around the block   %3A -).  We'll be riding some twisty,  %0A > fairly bumpy roads (the Mines Road-Mt.Hamilton Loop for you SF Bay Areans). %0A >  %0A  %0A  %0A An extended ride as a passenger on a 750 ninja. %0A  %0A Owww. %0A  %0A Well, I hate to be a wet sock, but, well... %0A  %0A I was a passenger on many bikes for the longest time before I started %0A riding myelf, and I grew to hate long rides on sport bikes.  The passenger %0A seats are not designed for long rides.  The passenger positions aren't %0A even usually designed for short rides.  I ended up torturing my knees and my %0A back by taking long rides as a passenger on sport bikes.  One of the %0A reasons I originally liked my current guythingy so much was becase he had %0A a BMW.  %3A ) %0A  %0A I'd suggest a shorter extended ride at first -- a short turn in the mountains %0A or some such.  Then see how much pain she's in, and proceed from there. %0A  %0A The best advice I'd give a beginning passenger %3A  %0A  %0A - Don't get on the bike until the rider says its OK, and work out some sort %0A   signal for the rider to tell you when its OK to get off.  After I get on  %0A   the bike I squeeze my riders hips to tell that I'm ready, and at the stop %0A   he nods his head to show its OK for me to get off. %0A  %0A - Keep your feet on the pegs at all times.  Don't wiggle (unless your rider %0A   asks you to  %3A ) %0A  %0A - The best passengers are those which are unobtrusive.  Echo the movements %0A   and lean of your rider.  Look over the shoulder thats most comfortable, %0A   but during turns look over the shoulder on the inside of the turn. %0A  %0A - Get used to your rider's shifting style (Riders %3A   use a reasonably %0A   consistent shifting style).  Avoid "helmet bonk."  Helmet bonk is  %0A   when your rider revs the bike up and then shifts and the sudden change %0A   in foreward acceleration causes your helmet to bonk his/hers.  It %0A   gets old real fast. %0A  %0A - When pulling to a stop, put a hand or both hands on the tank to keep %0A   your weight from pushing your rider up onto the tank.  Putting your hands %0A   on the tank is also a good way to stretch your back if you're in pain, %0A   but I'm told it gets harder to steer in turns if you leave them there. %0A  %0A - Switch your hands to the guardrail to stretch your shoulders, but be  %0A   sure and squeeze your thighs while you're doing it so your rider knows you're %0A   still there.  %3A )  The guard rail isn't as safe as holding onto your rider. %0A  %0A - Don't be afraid to ask for frequent stops if you're in pain or %0A   losing feeling in your feet.  Passenger seats are not generally designed  %0A   for comfort.  Work out some sort of pull over signal beforehand. %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A ********************************************************* %0A Laura Lemay                              lemay %40 netcom.com %0A writer of trifles in shadows and blood %0A ********************************************************* %0A  %0A

doc_1323 |@raw_text From %3A  pmetzger %40 snark.shearson.com (Perry E. Metzger) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Do we need the clipper for cheap security? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr24.230744.26542 %40 lehman.com> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 lehman.com (News) %0A Organization %3A  Partnership for an America Free Drug %0A References %3A  <9304191013.AA10506 %40 pizzabox.demon.co.uk> <1993Apr21.012011.27470 %40 shearson.com> <C5upHy.GH7 %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 23 %3A 07 %3A 44 GMT %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A  %0A pdc %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk (Paul Crowley) writes %3A  %0A >How fast do the fastest modems go? %0A  %0A The Shannon limit for voice lines is likely somewhere around 25kbps. %0A We are rapidly approaching it. The fastest affordable full-duplex %0A modems currently on the market are V32bis, which is 14400bps. %0A  %0A >How far can voice be compressed? %0A  %0A CELP manages to sound decent at 4800 bps. %0A  %0A In theory, if you built a speech recognition system that turned voice %0A into ASCII, and a perfect synthesis system on the other end that %0A sounded just like the person you were speaking to, you could get it %0A down to the information content of the speech. %0A  %0A With various kinds of LPC, you can get it down to 2400 bps or prehaps %0A even less, at which point it sounds horrible. %0A  %0A 4800 bps is more than adequite for our purposes. %0A  %0A -- %0A Perry Metzger		pmetzger %40 shearson.com %0A -- %0A Laissez faire, laissez passer. Le monde va de lui meme. %0A  
doc_1324 |@raw_text From %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu (T. Joseph Lazio) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Burst Mystery %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 93 09 %3A 21 %3A 57 %0A Organization %3A  Department of Astronomy, Cornell University %0A Lines %3A  45 %0A Message-ID %3A  <LAZIO.93Apr27092157 %40 seti.astrosun.tn.cornell.edu> %0A References %3A  <sarfattiC649tL.3It %40 netcom.com> %0A Reply-To %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  seti.tn.cornell.edu %0A Summary %3A  Gamma Ray Bursts are still a mystery. %0A Keywords %3A  GRBs - cyclotron lines - cosmological bursts %0A In-reply-to %3A  sarfatti %40 netcom.com's message of Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT %0A  %0A >>>>> On Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT, sarfatti %40 netcom.com (Jack Sarfatti) said %3A  %0A  %0A js> Question %3A  what is the power spectrum of the bursts. Are their sharp lines? %0A js> If so, can they be interpreted as blue-shifted atomic or molecular lines? %0A  %0A  Don't remember the spectra, but have seen some autocorrelation functions %0A  recently.  The ACFs show correlation times of milliseconds to 10s of  %0A  seconds; interestingly, the higher energies show a shorter correlation  %0A  time. %0A  %0A js> Can electron-positron annihilation gammas be seen in the bursts? Are they %0A js> red shifted or blue shifted? %0A  %0A  I believe there were claims from an earlier satellite (Ginga?) of  %0A  detection of cyclotron absorption lines.  These lines were taken as  %0A  strong evidence for neutron stars being the objects responsible for  %0A  GRBs since the magnetic field indicated was 1.0E12, fairly typical  %0A  for a neutron star.  However, Compton GRO has not seen any of these  %0A  lines and I get the impression that many are beginning to doubt whether %0A  these lines were ever real. %0A  %0A js> Since the bursts are isotropic and maybe in the galactic halo they may %0A js> be saying something about dark matter in the halo. %0A  %0A  *If* the bursts are in the halo, they most certainly are saying something  %0A  about dark matter there.  However, if they are in the halo, in order  %0A  that they appear isotropic, the "core radius" of the halo (i.e. the  %0A  innermost region of the halo) has to be greater than about 50 kpc. %0A  The halo itself would stretch much further than this.  Since the  %0A  Andromeda Galaxy is only 700 kpc away, we should be seeing bursts %0A  from that galaxy's halo, which we aren't. %0A  %0A js> If the bursts are something like the cosmic black body radiation from %0A js> way back then where are the red shifts - I mean cosmological red shifts? %0A  %0A  Remember to get a redshift, one needs some type of emission or  %0A  absorption line so one can compare the observed line frequency  %0A  to the rest line frequency.  Since no lines are seen in GRB spectra,  %0A  that comparison cannot be made. %0A  %0A -- %0A                          %7C e-mail %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A    T. Joseph Lazio       %7C phone %3A   (607) 255-6420 %0A                          %7C ICBM %3A    42 deg. 20' 08" N  76 deg. 28' 48" W %0A Cornell knows I exist?!? %7C       STOP RAPE %0A
