Now the shuttle is a heavy %0A  %3A  thing.  THe HST isn't light either.  THe amount of OMS fuel %0A  %3A  needed to fly both up is substantial.   a small booster %0A  %3A  carried up and used to boost HST on it's own will weigh significantly %0A  %3A  less then the OMS fuel required to Boost  both HST and SHUttle, %0A  %3A  for a given orbital change.   %0A  %0A  %3A  From what i understand,  the mass margins on the HST missions are %0A  %3A  tight enough they can't even carry extra Suits or MMU's. %0A  %0A  %3A  pat %0A  %0A I haven't seen any specifics on the HST repair mission, but I can't see why %0A the mass margins are tight.  What are they carrying up?  Replacement components %0A (WFPC II, COSTAR, gyros, solar panels, and probably a few others), all sorts of %0A tools, EVA equipment, and as much OMS fuel and consumables as they can.  This %0A should be lighter than the original HST deployment mission, which achieved the %0A highest altitude for a shuttle mission to date.  And HST is now in a lower  %0A orbit.   %0A  %0A Seems like the limiting factors would be crew fatigue and mission complexity. %0A  %0A -- %0A Steve Derry %0A <s.d.derry %40 larc.nasa.gov> %0A  
doc_1348 |@raw_text From %3A  robinson %40 cogsci.Berkeley.EDU (Michael Robinson) %0A Subject %3A  Passenger helmet sizing %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 1993 20 %3A 38 %3A 52 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Institute of Cognitive Studies, U.C. Berkeley %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qn5gs$s65 %40 agate.berkeley.edu> %0A References %3A  <211353 %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com> <1qk5oi$d0i %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  cogsci.berkeley.edu %0A  %0A In article <1qk5oi$d0i %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> egreen %40 east.sun.com writes %3A  %0A >In article 211353 %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com, maven %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com (Norman Hamer) writes %3A  %0A >>  %0A >> The question for the day is re %3A  passenger helmets, if you don't know for  %0A >>certain who's gonna ride with you (like say you meet them at a .... church  %0A >>meeting, yeah, that's the ticket)... What are some guidelines? Should I just  %0A >>pick up another shoei in my size to have a backup helmet (XL), or should I  %0A >>maybe get an inexpensive one of a smaller size to accomodate my likely  %0A >>passenger?  %0A > %0A >If your primary concern is protecting the passenger in the event of a %0A >crash, have him or her fitted for a helmet that is their size.  If your %0A >primary concern is complying with stupid helmet laws, carry a real big %0A >spare (you can put a big or small head in a big helmet, but not in a %0A >small one). %0A  %0A While shopping for a passenger helmet, I noticed that in many cases the %0A external dimensions of the helmets were the same from S through XL.  The %0A difference was the amount of inside padding. %0A  %0A My solution was to buy a large helmet, and construct a removable liner  %0A from a sheet of .5" closed-cell foam and some satin (glued to the inside %0A surface).  The result is a reasonably snug fit on my smallest-headed pillion %0A with the liner in, and a comfortable fit on my largest-headed pillion with %0A the liner out.  Everyone else gets linered or not by best fit. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A   ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A   Michael Robinson                          UUCP %3A    ucbvax!cogsci!robinson %0A                                         INTERNET %3A  robinson %40 cogsci.berkeley.edu %0A

And what about costs?  And does it %0A >have to be transparent as in totally transparent?  Or just transparent enough %0A >to allow light from the other side to shine through? %0A  %0A Yes it has to be very clear (like it wasn't there).  And of course, cost is  %0A always a factor.  I am trying to get an idea of the feasability of such an  %0A idea.  But I don't want to give too much away. %0A  %0A -Mark %0A  
doc_1355 |@raw_text From %3A  zwork %40 starfighter.den.mmc.com (Michael Corvin) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  HST Servicing Mission Scheduled for 11 Days %0A Keywords %3A  HST %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr29.201036.11256 %40 den.mmc.com> %0A Date %3A  29 Apr 93 20 %3A 10 %3A 36 GMT %0A References %3A  <23APR199316425663 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> <1rd1g0$ckb %40 access.digex.net> <3t75nhg %40 rpi.edu> %0A Sender %3A  zwork %40 starfighter (Michael Corvin) %0A Organization %3A  Martin Marietta Astronautics Group %0A Lines %3A  24 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  starfighter.den.mmc.com %0A  %0A Regarding the feasability of retrieving the HST for repair and %0A relaunching it %3A  %0A  %0A (Caution %3A  speculation mode engaged) %0A There is another consideration that hasn't been mentioned yet. %0A I expect that retrieving HST would involve 'damaging' it considerably in %0A order to return it to its cradle in the cargo bay.  Most of the deployed %0A items (antennas and, especially, the solar arays) probably are not %0A retractable into their fully stowed position, even by hand.  They would %0A have to be removed by the astronauts.  (The only advantage that this %0A might yield is that we could put new panels on that don't 'ring' due %0A to thermal cycle stresses...) %0A  %0A I also expect that, as has been discussed, the landing loads on the %0A HST optics structure is a big issue (but that the reentry loads are %0A much less so.)  Can the moveable optical components even be re-caged %0A (I assume that they were caged for launch)? %0A  %0A ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A Michael Corvin 	      				zwork %40 starfighter.den.mmc.com %0A GN&C R&D					Martin Marietta Astronautics %0A ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A ===============    My views, not Martin Marietta's   ======================== %0A ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  
doc_1357 |@raw_text From %3A  zellner %40 stsci.edu %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  temperature of the dark sky %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr28.125208.1 %40 stsci.edu> %0A Lines %3A  36 %0A Sender %3A  news %40 stsci.edu %0A Organization %3A  Space Telescope Science Institute %0A References %3A  <C65o4t.A7o %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1993Apr28.002214.16544 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Wed, 28 Apr 1993 17 %3A 52 %3A 08 GMT %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr28.002214.16544 %40 Princeton.EDU>, richmond %40 spiff.Princeton.EDU %0A (Stupendous Man) writes %3A   %0A  %0A >  (Henry Spencer) writes %3A  %0A >> Does anyone have a reference (something I can look up, not just your own %0A >> recollections -- I have a few of those myself) on the temperature of the %0A >> (night) sky as seen from space? %0A >> %0A >  %0A >    Henry, if I read you correctly, you may be asking "If I put a blackbody %0A > in interstellar space ('disregarding the Sun and nearby large warm objects'), %0A > what termperature will it reach in thermal equilibrium with the ambient %0A > radiation field?" %0A >  %0A >    If that's the case, let me point out that interstellar dust and  %0A > molecules provide many instances of things that are, well, not-too-far %0A > from being blackbodies.  Many different observations, including IRAS %0A > and COBE, have determined that interstellar dust grain temperatures %0A > can range from 40K to 150K.   %0A  %0A Yes, but that's because interstellar grains are very poor radiators, not %0A remotely black bodies.  As a consequence they are a lot warmer than the %0A "ambient". %0A   %0A >    Inside the disk of the galaxy, the temperature varies quite a bit %0A > from place to place (how close are you to the nearest OB association, %0A > I would guess).  Outside the galaxy, of course, things aren't so  %0A > varied. %0A >  %0A  %0A When I was in graduate school, a long time ago, we used 10,000 deg K with %0A a DILUTION FACTOR of 10+4 for representative values of the radiant energy %0A background in the galaxy due to starlight.   %0A  %0A Ben %0A  %0A

doc_1414 |@raw_text From %3A  arussell %40 austin.ibm.com (AG Russell) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Off the shelf cheap DES keyseach machine (Was %3A  Re %3A  Corporate acceptance of the wiretap chip) %0A Originator %3A  arussell %40 pal500.austin.ibm.com %0A Sender %3A  news %40 austin.ibm.com (News id) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5wsA5.2qDz %40 austin.ibm.com> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 23 %3A 37 %3A 16 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.192105.11751 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr21.001230.26384 %40 lokkur.dexter.mi.us> <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> <strnlghtC5wCMo.Fx5 %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  IBM Austin %0A Lines %3A  54 %0A  %0A  %0A In article <strnlghtC5wCMo.Fx5 %40 netcom.com>, strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A > In article <C5uvn4.MF7 %40 austin.ibm.com> arussell %40 austin.ibm.com (AG Russell) %0A > writes %3A  %0A >  %0A > > %0A > >At the company I worked for previously, I received a file that was des encryped %0A > >and the person that had sent it, went on vaction.  Rather than wait two weeks %0A > >I set up a straight frontal attack with one key at a time.  It only took two(2) %0A > >days to crack the file.  No, I don't have any faith in DES. %0A > > %0A >  %0A > Taking this at face value (though it seems quite dissonant with much else %0A > that has been published here about brute force DES cracking, unless Russell %0A > was lucky with respect to the key), I'd be very interested in whether the %0A > program Russell used is available? In whether he used a cleartext %0A > recognition algorithm in the program or whether he had to examine each %0A > decryption by hand? In whether he used a known plaintext attack? %0A  %0A Given that certain archival methods have certain key(cleartext) in a file I %0A used a programatic dictionary attack.  I used the DES library provided with the %0A system that I was using.  What is to keep anyone from being lucky with a key? %0A   %0A > He probably should also tell us, given his address, what machine he used--a %0A > desktop, workstation, or super-computer. %0A  %0A My previous employment has nothing to do with my current address, other than %0A the fact that the fastest machine in the office was an IBM RISC System/6000  %0A model 530, with 16 meg of memory.(not a super-computer) %0A   %0A > Depending on his answer, this could be an appalling development calling into %0A > question both DES and RSA/DES. Dunno about RSA/IDEA. %0A  %0A I really think this more of a statement of the limitations placed on the key %0A by the interface(ascii char/no padding), and most programs don't bother to %0A clear off the archival front and backend ID's. %0A  %0A > If any bright programmer with a little idle machine time can crack a single %0A > DES message in a couple of days (assuming no tricks that are %0A > message-specific), then here's my Clipper key, NSA; give me the chip at %0A > once.   %3A -) %0A  %0A Yes any moderatly bright programmer with a little idle machine time, can %0A crack most of todays real world encryption.  I sure that you or I could %0A select a key, and prepare the data inorder that the decryption will become a  %0A worst case.  but that is not the real world, and I'm sure that is how any  %0A agency would start an attack on a message, as you pointed out, there are some  %0A very good recognition algorithms availible, I'm just not familiar with them. %0A  %0A A.G. %0A --  %0A A.G. Russell   Dept A06S  OLTP section of PALS Group   VM ID  SC39093 at AUSVM1 %0A Email  arussell %40 austin.ibm.com       Phone 512-838-7953        TieLine 678-7953 %0A These are my views, on anyone else they would look silly. It would have %0A       to involve new physics as far as I can tell. Closest to %0A       "conventional" Oort sources is a model of B-field pinching %0A       by comets, it's got too many holes in it to count, but at %0A       least it was a good try... %0A  %0A    So you have a plausible model for GRB's at astronomical distances? %0A  %0A I don't have any plausible models for GRBs at any distances ;-) %0A  %0A    Recent observations have just about ruled out the merging neutron star %0A    hypothesis, which had a lot of problems, anyhow.  We have to look for %0A    implausible models and what is fundamentally allowed independent of %0A    models. %0A  %0A Hmm, the "superbowl" burst has been claimed in press releases %0A to cast doubt on the merging NS hypothesis, from what I've read %0A (and I haven't seen the papers, only the press) I'd say it is %0A consistent with some of the merging NS models %0A  %0A    A paper on the possibility of GRB's in the Oort cloud just came %0A    through the astrophysics abstract service.  To get a copy of this %0A  %0A    Here is the abstract of that paper. %0A  %0A  ... %0A       indicator to these events all possible sources which are %0A       isotropically distributed should remain under consideration. This is %0A       why the Oort cloud of comets is kept on the list, %0A       although there is no known mechanism for generating \GRBs %0A       from cometary nuclei. Unlikely as it may seem, the possibility that \GRBs %0A       originate in the solar cometary cloud %0A       cannot be excluded until it is disproved. %0A  %0A This does not propose a _mechanism_ for GRBs in the Oort (and, no, %0A anti-matter annihilation does not fit the spectra at least as far %0A as I understand annihilation spectra...). Big difference. %0A That's ignoring the question of how you fit a distribution %0A to the Oort distribution when the Oort distribution is not well %0A known - in particular comet aphelia (which are not well known) %0A are not a good measure of the Oort cloud distribution... %0A  %0A  %0A *  Steinn Sigurdsson   			Lick Observatory      	* %0A *  steinly %40 lick.ucsc.edu		"standard disclaimer"  	* %0A *  The laws of gravity are very,very strict			* %0A *  And you're just bending them for your own benefit - B.B. 1988* %0A

A shining example is %0A if you look at the Penguins individual +/-, you will find very few minuses. %0A That only makes common sense, since they didn't lose many games. %0A  %0A  %3A    Until the NHL publishes a more useful quantifiable statistic including ice %0A  %3A    time per game and some measure of its "quality" (i.e., is the player put out %0A  %3A    in key situations like protecting a lead late in the game; is he matched up %0A  %3A    against the other team's top one or two lines; short-handed, etc), I would %0A  %3A    much rather see the +/- disappear altogether instead of having its dubious %0A  %3A    merits trumpeted by those with little understanding of its implications. %0A  %0A Unfortunately, you will need to keep a ridiculous number of stats to %0A really come up with a statistic which really shows a player's value. %0A Let's just enjoy the game and not overanalyze it. doc_1520 |@raw_text From %3A  caryd %40 a.cs.okstate.edu (CARY DAVID ALLEN) %0A Subject %3A   Self-modifying hardware %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr6.005629.25237 %40 a.cs.okstate.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Organization %3A  Oklahoma State University, Computer Science, Stillwater %0A Date %3A  Tue, 6 Apr 93 00 %3A 56 %3A 29 GMT %0A Lines %3A  70 %0A  %0A Permit me to quote fragments of  %0A praetzel %40 sunee.uwaterloo.ca's article %0A out of context. %0A  %0A -Newsgroups %3A  sci.electronics,comp.lsi.cad %0A -From %3A  praetzel %40 sunee.uwaterloo.ca (Eric Praetzel) %0A -Date %3A  10 Feb 93 15 %3A 46 %3A 41 GMT %0A  %0A -  Currently the XNF format is propierty and I know of at least on person at %0A -a university who was able to get it after signing a non-disclosure agreement. %0A -The Xilinx-bit map format is pretty well top secret.  I would love to know it %0A -because then you could make self_modifying_hardware  ;-)  As it is I had to %0A -reverse eng. the Xilinx tools to dump the bit map to the FPGA because it only %0A -runs on the computer with the hardware key. %0A  %0A self-modifying hardware could be *very* interesting -- %0A  computers that could write thier own programs (assemblers, compilers) %0A were an immense breakthrough from calculators that couldn't. %0A  %0A -  I eagerly await a programmable gate array which uses a PD format and does %0A -not cost your first born to program.  Till then we will keep on reverse %0A -engineering whatever we can.  As it is one company that I worked at has gone %0A -under.  FPGAs are what they needed to make their product competitive.  They %0A -could not afford them.  In the end you could say that they could not afford %0A -to not use them but the management discovered that too late.  %0A -   - Eric  %0A  %0A my condolences. %0A  %0A i can't even imagine what i could do with self-modifing hardware. %0A i *can* imagine self-modifying software, %0A and even though *all* my teachers say that's BAD, even Worse than GOTO, %0A check out what the experts *used* to say about self-modifying code %3A  %0A (he uses "orders" rather than "opcodes") %0A  %0A  %0A "On the Principles of Large Scale Computing Machines" %0A by Goldstine and von Neumann, %0A collected in  %0A _John von Neumann %3A  Collected Works, Vol. V_ %0A reprinted here with absolutely no permission from anyone. %0A "We plan... to have a full size (40 binary digit) word hold %0A either contain %0A 1 full size number (... equivalent to 12 decimal digits, %0A but we will use the first binary digit to denote the sign) %0A or two (20 binary digit) orders. %0A .... %0A 	It should be added that this technique of %0A automatic substitutions into orders, %0A i.e. the machine's ability to modify its own orders %0A (under the control of other ones among its orders) %0A is absolutely necessary for a flexible code. Thus, if %0A part of the memory is used as a "function table", then %0A "looking up" a value of that function for a value of the  %0A variable which is obtained in the course of the computation %0A requires that the machine itself should modify, or %0A rather make up, the reference to the memory in the order which %0A controls this "looking up", and the machine can only make this %0A modification after it has already calculated the value of the  %0A variable in question. %0A 	On the other hand, this ability of the machine to modify its %0A own orders is one of the things which makes coding %0A the non-trivial operation which we have to view it as." %0A  %0A david cary, tenor, e- and comp. engineering (finger caryd %40 a.cs.okstate.edu). %0A 227 S. 163 E. Ave, Tulsa, OK  74108-3310, USA, Sol 3, Universe v. 1.2 %0A  %0A --  %0A david cary, tenor, e- and comp. engineering (finger caryd %40 a.cs.okstate.edu). %0A 227 S. 163 E. Ave, Tulsa, OK  74108-3310, USA, Sol 3, Universe v. 1.2 %0A

Why on the Earth split the %0A 80-bit key in 40-bit parts to keep them in escrow separately %0A (having 40 bit and large volumes of data voice links produce %0A it should be relatively easy to break it) when they simply %0A could keep 80-bit sequences in N (N>=2) independent places %0A and then XOR all the partial keys to get the actual key (N-1 %0A sequences should obviously be selected randomly and Nth is the %0A actual key XOR-ed with the random sequences). %0A  %0A (Or is it a conspiracy? 1/2  %3A -) %0A  %0A --vadim %0A

Were it not for the  %0A > NSA and company, cheap encryption systems would be everywhere. As it  %0A > is, they try every trick in the book to stop it. Had it not been for  %0A > them, I'm sure cheap secure phones would be out right now.  %0A  %0A You can build them right now as long as you don't want to export (a  %0A restriction I firmly oppose).  The only thing stopping people from making  %0A cheap encryption is greed %3A  they want a lock on the market. %0A  %0A > They aren't the ones making cheap crypto available. They are the ones  %0A > keeping cheap crypto out of people's hands. When they hand you a  %0A > clipper chip, what you are getting is a mess of pottage -- your prize  %0A > for having traded in your birthright.  %0A  %0A Oh, come on.  Only if you trust it farther than it deserves.  A Clipper phone  %0A *IS NOT* a substitute for a Cylink phone, or a STU-III.  It's a substitute  %0A for the "voice scramblers" advertised in the back of Radio Electronics. %0A  %0A > Are we getting cheaper crypto  %0A > for ourselves? No, because the market would have provided that on its  %0A > own had they not deliberately sabotaged it. %0A  %0A I disagree.  Modulo ITAR, it's not the government that has sabotaged the  %0A market. %0A  %0A > Someone please tell me what exactly we get in our social contract in  %0A > exchange for giving up our right to strong cryptography?  %0A  %0A Can you tell me where exactly we have given up that right? %0A  %0A  %0A Amanda Walker %0A InterCon Systems Corporation %0A  %0A  %0A

Everest without oxygen assistance... %0A >>... This is quite a feat of physiological endurance... %0A > %0A >Indeed so; it's at the extreme limit of what is humanly possible.  It is %0A >possible only because Mount Everest is at a fairly low latitude %3A   there %0A >is a slight equatorial bulge in the atmosphere -- beyond what is induced %0A >by the Earth's rotation -- thanks to the overall circulation pattern of %0A >the atmosphere (air cools at poles and descends, flowing back to equator %0A >where it is warmed and rises), and this helps just enough to make Everest- %0A >without-oxygen feasible.  Only just feasible, mind you %3A   the guys who did %0A >it reported hallucinations and other indications of oxygen starvation, %0A >and probably incurred some permanent brain damage. %0A  %0A Climbers regard 8000 metres and up as "The Death Zone".  Even on 100% Oxygen, %0A you are slowly dying.  At 8848m (Everest), most climbers spend only a short %0A period of time before descending.  I've been above 8000 once.  Descending as %0A little as 300m feels like walking into a jungle, the air is so thick.  Everest %0A in winter without oxygen, no support party (Alpine style).  That is the %0A "ultimate challenge" (or is it solo?) %0A -- %0A Dillon Pyron                      %7C The opinions expressed are those of the %0A TI/DSEG Lewisville VAX Support    %7C sender unless otherwise stated. %0A (214)462-3556 (when I'm here)     %7C %0A (214)492-4656 (when I'm home)     %7CTexans %3A  Vote NO on Robin Hood.  We need %0A pyron %40 skndiv.dseg.ti.com          %7Csolutions, not gestures. %0A PADI DM-54909                     %7C %0A  %0A

Also the DeskJet can do downloadable fonts ONLY if you buy a softfont %0A memory cart for it.  OH!  You said the LaserJet can rotate a graphic image! %0A Hmmmmm!  The DeskJet can only rotate text.  Nevermind! %0A   %0A

If anything, the clearances seem to be getting a little smaller which %0A >makes no sense to me with the pad system - the pads should wear until the %0A >clearances are too great right?  I know that threaded adjusters can tighten  %0A >up, but I didn't think these kind could. %0A  %0A >Bottom lines is that I haven't touched my valves for 30K on this bike and %0A >they are still nice and quiet and if anything, the clearances are tighter... %0A >What's the deal? The valve seats tend to wear  %0A very slowly, and anything that might get taken off the pad (which shouldn't %0A really wear) will tend to compensate - so it's a sort of self-compensating %0A system. %0A

doc_1613 |@raw_text From %3A  behnke %40 FNALF.FNAL.GOV (M.L. 'Broomen' Behnke) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Peltier Effect Heat Pumps %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 1993 21 %3A 04 %3A 29 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Fermi National Accelerator Lab %0A Lines %3A  66 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1psr8t$6cb %40 fnnews.fnal.gov> %0A References %3A  <2745 %40 snap> %0A Reply-To %3A  behnke %40 FNALF.FNAL.GOV %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  fnalf.fnal.gov %0A  %0A In article <2745 %40 snap>, paj %40 uk.co.gec-mrc (Paul Johnson) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I was having a look through a couple of components catalogues when I %0A >came across a range of Peltier Effect heat pumps intended for cooling %0A >components.  For those who have not heard of this effect, you put a %0A >current through one of these devices, and it pumps heat from one side %0A >to the other.  Reverse the current and you reverse the effect.  I %0A >think a temperature difference can give you an EMF as well. %0A > %0A >Anyway, it struck me that you could make a nice cool/hot box for %0A >picnics with one of these, a power regulator, a thermostat and a %0A >couple of heat sinks.  The biggest device can shift 60W with an %0A >efficiency of 80-90%, which ain't bad (although it would flatten my %0A >car battery in about half an hour). %0A > %0A  So-Called Cool-Hot boxes have been advetised for several years.  I recall %0A Damark advertising them in a recent catalog.  Problem with the units is they do %0A a sh***y job of keeping food cold/warm.  The peliter devices used just don't %0A seem to have enough punch to keep up.  If you want something hot, you need to %0A heat it up before you put it in the box, and end up hours later with food thats %0A only moderately warm.  Same goes for cold items. %0A  %0A >Unfortunately the catalogue didn't list anything more than the basic %0A >specs as a heat pump.  I imagine that you would get a back-EMF as the %0A >temperature gradient across the device increases.  If so, presumably %0A >its power decreases as the back-EMF increases, until eventually we %0A >have a steady state with no current being consumed (assuming no %0A >leakage).  If so, then the final temperature difference between the %0A >two sides could be set by the supply voltage and nothing more %0A >(although that would be a lousy way to control it). %0A > %0A >What I would like to know is %3A  %0A > %0A >1 %3A  Are the above guesses correct? %0A > %0A >2 %3A  What is the open-circuit thermal resistance of a typical device? %0A >   (I just want to be sure that my coolbox is not going to get warm %0A >   too fast when I unplug it) %0A  %0A  You'de probably be better off getting a good Coleman(tm) cooler and stocking %0A up on "blue ice" blocks. %0A  %0A > %0A >3 %3A  How does a Peltier Effect heat pump actually work?  It looks like %0A >   magic! %0A > %0A >4 %3A  Why don't they use these things in domestic fridges/freezers? %0A > %0A  Same as above.  Not enough "punch" in them to keep/get things cold/hot. %0A > %0A >Thanks in advance, %0A > %0A >Paul. %0A > %0A >Paul Johnson (paj %40 gec-mrc.co.uk).	    %7C Tel %3A  +44 245 73331 ext 3245 %0A >--------------------------------------------+---------------------------------- %0A >These ideas and others like them can be had %7C GEC-Marconi Research is not %0A >for $0.02 each from any reputable idealist. %7C responsible for my opinions %0A Mike Behnke             %7C Senior Tech/Advisor %7C Quid est illuidin aqua?? %0A Fermi Nat Accel Lab     %7C Equipment Suuport   %7C %0A Batavia, Il.            %7C Computing Div       %7C PISTRIX!! doc_1632 |@raw_text From %3A  mbeckman %40 mbeckman.mbeckman.com (Mel Beckman) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  An Open Letter to Mr. Clinton %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 93 23 %3A 11 %3A 07 PST %0A Organization %3A  Beckman Software Engineering %0A Message-ID %3A  <01050810.vkcsbl %40 mbeckman.mbeckman.com> %0A Reply-To %3A  mbeckman %40 mbeckman.com %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A X-Mailer %3A  uAccess LITE - Macintosh Release %3A  1.5v5 %0A Lines %3A  38 %0A  %0A  %0A In article <strnlghtC5M2Cv.8Hx %40 netcom.com> (sci.crypt), strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A > Here's a simple way to convert the Clipper proposal to an unexceptionable %0A > one %3A  Make it voluntary. %0A >  %0A > That is--you get high quality secure NSA classified technology if you agree %0A > to escrow your key. Otherwise you are on your own. %0A >  %0A  %0A David, %0A  %0A   As an economist, I'm sure you can see the flaws in this logic. If the (naive) %0A market is flooded with proprietary, but weak, encryption, then truly strong  %0A encryption will be unable to compete. Suppose the govt had a secret TV broadcast %0A standard, and then sold TVs below cost. Private industry has a better standard, %0A but it's not as widespread due to the govt early flooding of the market %0A with cheap proprietary sets. Even though the industry's technology is better, %0A the programming is being broadcast to the govt's unduplicatable standard. %0A Who could compete? %0A  %0A   The other flaw, of course, is that making something voluntary today ensures %0A that it will be voluntary in the future. I went to renew my CA drivers license %0A last week and was required not only to give my SSN, but to PRODUCE AN SSN %0A CARD to veryify the number!  Note that a federal law once said that no state %0A or local govt could ever require the use of SSNs for drivers license registration %0A (specifically!). %0A  %0A    I do not trust the govt that says "trust me on this even though we could %0A have an arrangement that doesn't require your trust."  Something is big %0A time fishy. If you look more carefully, you'll see it. %0A  %0A   -mel %0A  %0A ________________________________________________________________________ %0A %7C Mel beckman                  %7C   Internet %3A  mbeckman %40 mbeckman.com     %7C %0A %7C Beckman Software Engineering %7C Compuserve %3A  75226,2257                %7C %0A %7C Ventura, CA 93003            %7C  Voice/fax %3A  805/647-1641 805/647-3125 %7C %0A %7C______________________________%7C_______________________________________%7C %0A  "You can observe a lot just by watching."  -Yogi Bera %0A

doc_1650 |@raw_text From %3A  victor %40 inqmind.bison.mb.ca (Victor Laking) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  making copy of a Video tape %0A Keywords %3A  video %0A Message-ID %3A  <3Xw62B1w165w %40 inqmind.bison.mb.ca> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 17 Apr 93 12 %3A 54 %3A 49 CDT %0A References %3A  <hooperw.734990126 %40 spot.Colorado.EDU> %0A Organization %3A  The Inquiring Mind BBS  1 204 488-1607 %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A hooperw %40 spot.Colorado.EDU (Wayne Hooper) writes %3A  %0A  %0A > victor %40 inqmind.bison.mb.ca (Victor Laking) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A > >You are experiencing what is called Macrovision.  It is the protection  %0A > >that they use on the video tapes.  There are two ways around this that I  %0A > >know of.  First of all, you can try using a different VCR to copy onto. %0A > >It is the input of the VCR that reacts to the protection so sometimes  %0A > >just switching the two VCRs around will take care of it.  Some models  %0A > >just don't react to it. %0A >  %0A > Does this also affect the viewing of tapes ? I have had problems with %0A > a couple of rented tapes; they were virtually unviewable. I fiddled  %0A > with the tuning, tracking and vertical hold but it was no good. %0A >  %0A  %0A  %0A It sounds like your TV is one of the ones that also reacts to the video  %0A protection.  (Poor you!) %0A  %0A The Macroscrubber from Radio Electronics removes the protection so you  %0A souldn't have any more problems.  However, if you use the method of  %0A copying it from one VCR to another where the second VCR doesn't react to  %0A the protection, you will end up with a duplicate tape, including the  %0A protection. %0A  %0A One thought comes to mind about your problem...  When playing the tape  %0A for viewing, are you feeding the signal from the source VCR through an  %0A extra device before going to the TV?  If you feed it through a second VCR  %0A first, that is your problem.  As to other devices such as converters, I  %0A don't know if they would react or not.  Just to be safe, you might want  %0A to make sure that you have NOTHING between the VCR and TV. %0A  %0A victor %40 inqmind.bison.mb.ca %0A The Inquiring Mind BBS, Winnipeg, Manitoba  204 488-1607 %0A

The other day I was feeling a tad nostalgic and thought %0A about constructing an old-time crytal radio set.  I figured on %0A substituting a modern germanium diode for the crystal, and winding the %0A antenna coil, etc., myself. %0A  %0A The only problem I seem to have is in locating a source for a tuning %0A capacitor -- you know, the old meshed-plate variable condensers which %0A used to be the mainstay for tuning circuits. doc_1691 |@raw_text From %3A  craigv %40 rad.verbex.com %0A Subject %3A  Ensoniq SQ-80 Cross-Wave Synthesizer for sale %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.193507.27156 %40 msc.cornell.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  sender %0A Originator %3A  rob %40 snoopy.msc.cornell.edu %0A Sender %3A  craigv %40 rad.verbex.com %0A Organization %3A  cluttered-but-in-order %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 19 %3A 35 %3A 07 GMT %0A Lines %3A  71 %0A  %0A  %0A Ensoniq SQ-80 Cross-Wave Synthesizer %3A  %0A I have an SQ-80 for sale.  The SQ-80 is a powerful performance %0A oriented synth with a limited on-board sequencer.  I bought it because %0A it has a very large timbral repertoire;  it seems to do meaty analog %0A synth sounds as well as sounds that are considerably more "digital". %0A Below are a list of features extracted from the owner's manual %3A  %0A   o Eight-voice polyphonic poly-timbral synthesizer, capable of %0A     playing eight different sounds at once, with dynamic stereo %0A     panning for each voice %0A   o Voice section employing Cross-Wave synthesis;  combine different %0A     attack and sustain wave segments to create complex, dynamic sounds %0A   o 75 sampled waves (includes a drumset) serve as the sound source %0A   o Dynamic voice allocation %3A   each sequencer track/MIDI channel has %0A     access to all eight voices %0A   o A full-featured MIDI controller keyboard capable of sending eight %0A     MIDI program and volume changes at once.  Keyboard is velocity %0A     sensitive, and transmits/receives velocity and polyphonic aftertouch. %0A   o Powerful matrix modulation scheme allows a very wide range of  %0A     modulation sources and routings. %0A   o A 3.5" floppy disk drive which writes/reads ordinary DS/DD disks %0A     allows fast and reliable storage of up to 600 sequences and up to %0A     1728 sound patches on a single floppy disk.  Also has a RAM-cart slot %0A     for patches that is compatible with ESQ-1 RAM-carts. %0A   o Does sysex dumps to its floppy disk for any sysex capable MIDI device %0A   o 80 character fluorescent display and user-friendly "page-driven" %0A     programming scheme provides a fairly humane user interface %0A   o Stereo line-outs, and stereo headphone jack for private listening %0A   o Sound programs and sequences are upwardly compatible with the ESQ-1 %0A     so that sounds and sequences created for the ESQ-1 can be played on %0A     the SQ-80. %0A  %0A This SQ-80 has been the main MIDI controller in my studio for quite a while %0A now.  It has performed ably in that role, and has also been a heavily %0A used sound source at the same time.  The SQ-80 seems to have been designed %0A with this role in mind, and it works very well with my software sequencer %0A (WinCake) in its multitimbral mode. %0A  %0A >From a synthesis point of view, this machine is a hybrid.  It uses looped %0A short samples (there are 75 of them) as sources, then these waves %0A are processed with a sophisticated DCF-DCA arrangement.  The SQ-80 %0A is capable of great things because of its 4-pole analog lowpass filter. %0A Simply put, it makes fabulous analog synth sounds.  But unlike most %0A good analog synths, it has a very thorough MIDI implementation so that it %0A works very well with a MIDI sequencer.  What I really like most about this %0A thing is that it is capable of making a very wide range of sounds. %0A This SQ-80 is about 5 years old (mfg. date 1/21/88).  It does have %0A an 8-track sequencer, but like most on-board sequencers, it is a pain %0A to use so I have avoided it. %0A  %0A REASON FOR SALE %3A  %0A I am selling my SQ-80 because I recently joined forces with another individual %0A here in Boston, and we have more keyboards than space to put them.  I %0A recommend it for someone who is getting started in sequencing and needs a %0A powerful but economical master keyboard. %0A  %0A PRICING AND TERMS %3A  %0A I paid $1300.00 for this synth a few years ago.  I am willing to accept %0A $650.00 (average r.m.m.s asking price is $733.00).  I will include a bunch of  %0A patches on SQ-80 floppy disks for the buyer of this synth, as well as the  %0A original Ensoniq SQ-80 owner's manual. %0A  %0A Price %3A     Asking $650.00 (everything) %0A Shipping %3A  split shipping (UPS Surface COD) anywhere in the lower 48 states %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A Craig Vanderborgh                                         Verbex Voice Systems %0A e-mail %3A   craigv %40 rad.verbex.com                            119 Russell Street %0A phone %3A  (508) 486-8886                                     Littleton, MA 01460 %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_1721 |@raw_text From %3A  pdc %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk (Paul Crowley) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Hard drive security for FBI targets %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5uppn.GKM %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk> %0A Sender %3A  cnews %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk (UseNet News Admin) %0A Reply-To %3A  pdc %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk (Paul Crowley) %0A Organization %3A  Edinburgh University %0A References %3A  <C4uKKz.1G6 %40 telebit.com> <114800 %40 bu.edu> <Apr13.011855.69422 %40 yuma.ACNS.ColoState.EDU> <1993Apr21.021837.13289 %40 midway.uchicago.edu> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 20 %3A 46 %3A 34 GMT %0A Lines %3A  14 %0A  %0A If "I forgot" doesn't have as much credibility as you'd like, consider %0A this alternative.  Somewhere on the hard disk, duplicated a few times, %0A keep a 128-bit random number.  When the 128-bit digest of your %0A passphrase is computed, it is XORred with the random number before being %0A used as the key for your hard disk.  Writing random junk over the random %0A numbers makes the hard disk unreadable by anyone. %0A  %0A Now, if you were merely to *claim* that you have written random junk %0A over the XOR key, no-one would be able to tell whether or not you were %0A telling the truth.  This is (a) perjury, and (b) vunerable to %0A rubber-hose cryptography, but otherwise effective. %0A   __                                  _____ %0A \/ o\ Paul Crowley   pdc %40 dcs.ed.ac.uk \\ // %0A /\__/ Trust me. I know what I'm doing. \X/  Fold a fish for Jesus! %0A

She has some sort of grudge, now.) %0A  %0A I was riding downhill at ~60mph on a local backroad when a brown dobie came  %0A flashing through the brush at well over 30mph, on an intercept course with  %0A my front wheel. The dog had started out at the top of the hill when it heard  %0A me and still had a lead when it hit the road. Rover was looking back at me to calculate the  %0A final trajectory. Too bad it didn't notice the car approaching at 50+mph  %0A from the other direction. %0A  %0A I got a closeup view of the our poor canine friend's noggin careening off  %0A the front bumper, smacking the asphalt, and getting runover by the front  %0A tire. It managed a pretty good yelp, just before impact. (peripheral  %0A imminent doom?) I guess the driver didn't see me or they probably would have  %0A swerved into my lane. The squeegeed pup actually got up and headed back  %0A home, but I haven't seen it since.  %0A  %0A Sniff.  %0A  %0A Sometimes Fate sees you and smiles. %0A  %0A -Rick %0A

Not a crypto %0A device, simply an RS232<->voice converter. Make it capable of recording %0A speech and playing it back simultaneously. That was certainly partially the case with Apollo, %0A    but real Lunar colonies will probably require a continuing %0A    military, scientific, or commercial reason for being rather than %0A    just a "we have the money, why not?" approach. %0A  %0A Ah, but the whole point is that money spent on a lunar base is not %0A wasted on the moon. It's not like they'd be using $1000 (1000R?) bills %0A to fuel their moon-dozers. The money to fund a lunar base would be %0A spent in the country to which the base belonged. It's a way of funding %0A high-tech research, just like DARPA was a good excuse to fund various %0A fields of research, under the pretense that it was crucial to the %0A defense of the country, or like ESPRIT is a good excuse for the EC to %0A fund research, under the pretense that it's good for pan-European %0A cooperation. %0A  %0A Now maybe you think that government-funded research is a waste of %0A money (in fact, I'm pretty sure you do), but it does count as %0A investment spending, which does boost the economy (and just look at %0A the size of that multiplier  %3A ->). %0A  %0A Nick Haines nickh %40 cmu.edu %0A  
doc_1793 |@raw_text From %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu (T. Joseph Lazio) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Burst Mystery %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 93 10 %3A 23 %3A 43 %0A Organization %3A  Department of Astronomy, Cornell University %0A Lines %3A  45 %0A Message-ID %3A  <LAZIO.93Apr27102343 %40 seti.astrosun.tn.cornell.edu> %0A References %3A  <sarfattiC649tL.3It %40 netcom.com> %0A Reply-To %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  seti.tn.cornell.edu %0A Summary %3A  Gamma Ray Bursts are still a mystery. %0A Keywords %3A  GRBs - cyclotron lines - cosmological bursts %0A In-reply-to %3A  sarfatti %40 netcom.com's message of Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT %0A  %0A >>>>> On Tue, 27 Apr 1993 00 %3A 39 %3A 20 GMT, sarfatti %40 netcom.com (Jack Sarfatti) said %3A  %0A  %0A js> Question %3A  what is the power spectrum of the bursts. Are their sharp lines? %0A js> If so, can they be interpreted as blue-shifted atomic or molecular lines? %0A  %0A  Don't remember the spectra, but have seen some autocorrelation functions %0A  recently.  The ACFs show correlation times of milliseconds to 10s of  %0A  seconds; interestingly, the higher energies show a shorter correlation  %0A  time. %0A  %0A js> Can electron-positron annihilation gammas be seen in the bursts? Are they %0A js> red shifted or blue shifted? %0A  %0A  I believe there were claims from an earlier satellite (Ginga?) of  %0A  detection of cyclotron absorption lines.  These lines were taken as  %0A  strong evidence for neutron stars being the objects responsible for  %0A  GRBs since the magnetic field indicated was 1.0E12, fairly typical  %0A  for a neutron star.  However, Compton GRO has not seen any of these  %0A  lines and I get the impression that many are beginning to doubt whether %0A  these lines were ever real. %0A  %0A js> Since the bursts are isotropic and maybe in the galactic halo they may %0A js> be saying something about dark matter in the halo. %0A  %0A  *If* the bursts are in the halo, they most certainly are saying something  %0A  about dark matter there.  However, if they are in the halo, in order  %0A  that they appear isotropic, the "core radius" of the halo (i.e. the  %0A  innermost region of the halo) has to be greater than about 50 kpc. %0A  The halo itself would stretch much further than this.  Since the  %0A  Andromeda Galaxy is only 700 kpc away, we should be seeing bursts %0A  from that galaxy's halo, which we aren't. %0A  %0A js> If the bursts are something like the cosmic black body radiation from %0A js> way back then where are the red shifts - I mean cosmological red shifts? %0A  %0A  Remember to get a redshift, one needs some type of emission or  %0A  absorption line so one can compare the observed line frequency  %0A  to the rest line frequency.  Since no lines are seen in GRB spectra,  %0A  that comparison cannot be made. %0A  %0A -- %0A                          %7C e-mail %3A  lazio %40 astrosun.tn.cornell.edu %0A    T. Joseph Lazio       %7C phone %3A   (607) 255-6420 %0A                          %7C ICBM %3A    42 deg. 20' 08" N  76 deg. 28' 48" W %0A Cornell knows I exist?!? %7C       STOP RAPE %0A

doc_1801 |@raw_text From %3A  babb %40 sciences.sdsu.edu (J. Babb) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Getting rid of screen wiggles? %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.electronics %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 1993 18 %3A 00 %3A 23 GMT %0A Organization %3A  SDSU - LARC %0A Lines %3A  42 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <babb-190493103409 %40 larc.sdsu.edu> %0A References %3A  <1qphfnINN59b %40 life.ai.mit.edu> <1qpj5t$itg %40 vela.acs.oakland.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  larc.sdsu.edu %0A  %0A In article <1qpj5t$itg %40 vela.acs.oakland.edu>, eabyrnes %40 vela.acs.oakland.edu %0A (Ed Byrnes) wrote %3A  %0A >  %0A > My monitor display has a bad case of the wigglies. I have a good ground. I %0A > live in an old house and I have replaced much of the wiring. I have two %0A > EMI filters on the computer, the monitor plugs into the computer. When %0A > fluorescent lights are on upstairs, the display jiggles, when motors run %0A > in the house, the display jiggles, when incandescent lights are on in the %0A > kitchen the display jiggles.  I could bring a separate line from the %0A > breaker box, and use it only for the computer, would this do it? EMI %0A > doesn't only travel the 110 volt line though. Should I shield the back of %0A > the monitor? Ground a grid or plate?  %0A > Your expertise is appreciated. Thanks very much!  Ed Byrnes %0A  %0A  %0A Aaahh... a problem very near and dear to my heart. In our case, other %0A monitors cause this problem - the deflection coil of other monitors to be %0A specific. Have also seen a monitor backed up to a fuse panel exhibit this %0A problem. This sounds like your problem since flourescent lites, motors, etc %0A several 10s of feet away seem to me to be too far to cause it, but the %0A juice running to them must pass nearby your monitor. Fusebox on other side %0A of wall maybe? %0A We started spec'ing Panasonic CT-1331Y video monitors (3 switchable input %0A lines(vid & aud) S-VHS on one) <$400. This stopped the wavy interference %0A effect on the computer monitor next to it.  %0A Now on to your problem. You need what is known as mu shielding (very %0A common, in fact almost mandatory on electrostatic deflection type %0A O'scopes). %0A I talked to a EE prof. He said get a coffee can, cut both ends off, mount %0A around deflection coil of interfering monitor.  %0A BE CAREFUL TO AVOID ALL HIGH VOLTAGE CIRCUITRY. ESPECIALLY THE THICKER HIGH %0A VOLTAGE ANODE LEAD USUALLY COLORED RED. IF YOU KILL YOURSELF, DON'T %0A BLAME/SUE ME!!! USE PLASTIC OR OTHER NON-CONDUCTING STAND-OFFS AND SUCH TO %0A MOUNT CAN. %0A Now, I would assume that what is good for keeping mag fields in is also %0A good at keeping them out, so hopefully this'll work by mounting shield on %0A monitor being interfered with as well. If not, start shielding those other %0A sources. %0A  %0A Jeff Babb %0A babb %40 sciences.sdsu.edu   babb %40 ucssun1.sdsu.edu %0A Programmer, SDSU - LARC %0A  
doc_1810 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Re %3A  The [secret] source of that announcement %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr23.110149.29470 %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz> %0A From %3A  pgut1 %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz (Peter Gutmann) %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 11 %3A 01 %3A 49 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr21.133445.3930 %40 leland.Stanford.EDU> <gradyC5uAMw.BnG %40 netcom.com> <1r3vjhINN5iq %40 dns1.NMSU.Edu> <C5x2xs.EF0 %40 lerami.lerctr.org> %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Dept. University of Auckland %0A Lines %3A  56 %0A  %0A In <C5x2xs.EF0 %40 lerami.lerctr.org> merlin %40 lerami.lerctr.org (David Hayes) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >OK, Andrew, I'll provide some evidence. A friend of mine worked for an %0A >electronics manufacturer on with a west-coast office. They routinely sold %0A >equipment to the Japanese. One day, the Japanese started showing up with %0A >discount demands that were amazingly close to the cost to manufacture the %0A >products. %0A  %0A >This company routinely sent most of the manufacturing data to the field  %0A >offices. The Japanese had simply intercepted it. So my friend, the computer %0A >systems admin, came up with a solution. He started sending the data out %0A >double-block-encrypted with DES.  %0A  %0A >Two days after this new distribution plan was implemented, the president of %0A >the company got a visit from a pair of government agents. They told him to %0A >"knock it off". The president gave in, since his company did a considerable %0A >business with the federal government. %0A  %0A >Now, if the government wasn't monitoring the communications, how would they %0A >even know that the encryption system was installed? Further, since encryp- %0A >tion isn't illegal, and DES certainly isn't, what is the basis of the %0A >government's cease-and-desist demand? %0A  %0A Something similar has happened to me - ages ago when we were working on PGP %0A we used to send short messages about development issues or simply to test  %0A new features around.  Now at this time PGP (and certainly the newer version) %0A was unknown over here.  Suddenly the admin at the site I was using received %0A a request that I stop sending encrypted email.  Now there is almost no way %0A that some automatic scanner could have found this, since they wouldn't have %0A known about PGP - they *must* have checked for unknown data types in the %0A message, tried to unscramble it, found they couldn't get past the PEM %0A armour part, and then contacted the sysadmin and asked me to stop.  Luckily %0A the current email carriers are less picky about what goes over their %0A networks  %3A -). %0A  %0A In case people think email scanning doesn't take place, I can assure you %0A that it is done regularly by many sites - usually not by government %0A agencies (or at least not that I know of), but by local administrators who, %0A for reasons of their own, have decided to monitor all communications %0A (I'm sure you can all think of a whole mess of reasons - stop hackers/ %0A terrorists/child pornographers/drug dealers/evil commies/whatever).  There %0A have been several occasions when I've got people into trouble simply by %0A including the traditional NSA bait in a message (I don't try it any more %0A now  %3A -).  A friend of mine was once picked up for mentioning the name of %0A the UK town of Scunthorpe (hint %3A  look for words embedded in it).  I'm sure %0A there are many more examples of this happening (in fact if anyone has any %0A examples I'd appreciate hearing from them - I could use them as %0A ammunition during talks on privacy issues). %0A  %0A Peter. %0A -- %0A  pgut1 %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz%7C%7Cp_gutmann %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz%7C%7Cgutmann_p %40 kosmos.wcc.govt.nz %0A peterg %40 kcbbs.gen.nz%7C%7Cpeter %40 nacjack.gen.nz%7C%7Cpeter %40 phlarnschlorpht.nacjack.gen.nz %0A              (In order of preference - one of 'em's bound to work) %0A                -- Don't vote.  You'll only encourage them -- %0A  %0A

If you reverse engineer it and %0A >tell people, you are likely to go to jail. %0A  %0A Well, I'm not a lawyer, but from what I can tell this is completely %0A and utterly untrue. %0A  %0A You see, this country has this thing called a "constitution". %0A  %0A If you legitimately aquire the device, and you yourself are %0A not a government employee or otherwise encumbered, I don't think they %0A can stop you from revealing anything about the device you can %0A determine. Remember the Pentagon Papers precedent? The First Amendment %0A applies here. %0A  %0A The U.S. does NOT have an official secrets act. We do have laws that %0A will punish you for revealing what classified information you learned %0A in your capacity as a government official, contractor, etc, and we %0A have laws that prohibit stealing such information. However, if they %0A sell you the chip, I can't see that they can make reverse engineering %0A it and revealing the details illegal. %0A  %0A -- %0A Perry Metzger		pmetzger %40 shearson.com %0A -- %0A Laissez faire, laissez passer. First calculate a teams +/-.  (Goals Scored - PP Goals Scored) - %0A >> (Goals allowed - PP Goals Allowed (when they were penalty killing)). %0A >>  %0A >> 2.  Divide this number by 5 to take into account of the fact that there %0A >> are 5 players on the ice and each is 1/5 responsible for the team +/-. %0A >>  %0A >> 3.  A players adjusted +/- is (His raw +/-) - (Team Adjustment). %0A >>  %0A >> BTW  If anyone could calculate and post adjusted +/- ratings it would be %0A >> greatly appreciated.  I might find the time to do so- but don't count on %0A >> it. %0A > %0A >I have a database filter set up for the player stats.  When it is posted for %0A >the end of season I'll repost the team averages.  You don't need to go through %0A >the complicated team adjustment you are using - all you need is the team %0A >average by summing all the individual players' +\- and divide by the total %0A >number of players on the team.  This will be a little distorted because the %0A >players who have been traded recently will have come with +\- scores based %0A >on their original teams.  This shouldn't distort it too bad though.  If you %0A >want to look at individual players from this perspective then go ahead - %0A >you'll require the original player stats though. %0A  %0A Question %3A  %0A If a team uses 40 players in a season do you merely divide the total +/- %0A by 40?  If so, a player who plays in only 1 game is considered equally %0A valuable as a player who plays in all of them. %0A  %0A >Another way of looking at the same thing is to compare the deviation from %0A >the mean for the team of the player to the standard deviation for the team. %0A >I'll post both. %0A  %0A Since the standard deviation for each team is different, I am unsure how  %0A "transferable" between teams that these stats are.  Shouldn't the average %0A standard deviation in the league be used? %0A  %0A I am interested in seeing each method. %0A But I still think that mine is the best. If for no other reason than familiarity. %0A  %0A Gregmeister %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  
doc_1845 |@raw_text From %3A  steve-b %40 access.digex.com (Steve Brinich) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper considered harmful %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 1993 19 %3A 41 %3A 22 -0400 %0A Organization %3A  Express Access Online Communications, Greenbelt, MD USA %0A Lines %3A  42 %0A Distribution %3A  inet %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r21n2$4cb %40 access.digex.net> %0A References %3A  <15469 %40 optilink.COM> <bontchev.735336144 %40 fbihh> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  access.digex.net %0A  %0A  > > Criminals who very badly want inscrutable tactical communications %0A  > >(specifically the terrorists and drug dealers who proponents of key escrow %0A  > >cite as threats) will be highly motivated to steal the cipher phone of %0A  > >a legitimate user, and to kill this person or hold them hostage so %0A  > >discovery of compromise of the device will be delayed. %0A  %0A  >Why doing it in such a rough manner? It is much more professional to %0A  >steal the chip from the phone and even to replace it with a %0A  >pin-compatible do-nothing chip that does not encrypt at all. Chances %0A  >are that the victim will not notice anything, especially if it is done %0A  >professionally. %0A  %0A   Assuming that the bad guys can easily obtain substitute chips which don't %0A cause any noticeable effect to either the user or the person at the other end %0A of the line (if there is any significant difficulty to obtaining such chips, %0A some of the criminals will decide to fall back on the murder/kidnap method). %0A  %0A  > > Once a suitable collection of devices is stolen, criminals can communicate %0A  > >with impunity (assuming the cipher system carries no trapdoors apart from %0A  > >key escrow) until and unless the compromise is discovered by some other %0A  > >means. %0A  %0A  > No, because the Feds will still be able to decrypt the conversations. %0A  >True, they'll blame the wrong guys, but nevertheless one cannot say %0A  >something like "The drugs arrive tommorrow on the ship 'Terminus'" %0A  >when the Feds are listening, even if they cannot identify who the %0A  >speaker is. %0A  %0A  This assumes that the Feds are tapping Clipper phones belonging to ordinary %0A citizens (getting such a phone is the whole point of the crime under %0A discussion).  To be sure, I wouldn't put it past them -- but raising the %0A possibility of such crime has the benefit of forcing the Feds to either %0A 'fess up about such intentions in advance or state that using Clipper %0A exposes the user to an additional criminal threat. <g> %0A  %0A  > No, the criminals will just use some secure encryption. The new %0A  >proposal does not stop criminals; it ensures that the government will %0A  >be able to wiretap the average citizen and stops the casual snooper. %0A  >To me, it also clearly looks as a step towards outlawing any other %0A  >strong encryption devices. %0A  %0A   Agreed. %0A

Tens of thousands?  Do some arithmetic, please...  Skipjack %0A >has 2^80 possible keys.  Let's assume a brute-force engine like that %0A >hypothesized for DES %3A   1 microsecond per trial, 1 million chips.  That's %0A >10^12 trials per second, or about 38,000 years for 2^80 trials.  Well, %0A >maybe they can get chips running at one trial per nanosecond, and build %0A >a machine with 10 million chips. I mean, if we can imagine the %0A machine that does 1 trial/nanosecond, we can imagine the storage medium %0A that could index and archive it. %0A --  %0A  "Shadwell hated all southerners and, by inference, was standing at the %0A   North Pole." %0A 	-- "Good Omens", by Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett %0A

THe government does lots of multi year %0A >contracts with Penalty for cancellation clauses.  They just like to be %0A >damn sure they know what they are doing before they sign a multi year %0A >contract.   THe reason they aren't cutting defense spending as much %0A >as they would like is the Reagan administration signed enough %0A >Multi year contracts,  that it's now cheaper to just finish them out. %0A  %0A I don't have to "try reading a bit", Pat.  I *work* as a government %0A contractor and know what the rules are like.  Yes, they sign some %0A (damned few -- which is why everyone is always having to go to %0A Washington to see about next week's funding) multi-year contracts; %0A they also aren't willing to include sufficient cancellation penalties %0A when they *do* decide to cut the multi-year contract and not pay on it %0A (which can happen arbitrarily at any time, no matter what previous %0A plans were) to make the risk acceptable of something like putting up a %0A private space station with the government as the expected prime %0A occupant. %0A  %0A I'd like a source for that statement about "the reason they aren't %0A cutting defense spending as much as they would like"; I just don't buy %0A it. The other thing I find a bit 'funny' about your posting, Pat, is %0A that several other people answered the question pretty much the same %0A way I did; mine is the one you comment (and incorrectly, I think) on. %0A I think that says a lot.  You and Tommy should move in together. %0A  %0A --  %0A "Insisting on perfect safety is for people who don't have the balls to live %0A  in the real world."   -- Mary Shafer, NASA Ames Dryden %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ %0A Fred.McCall %40 dseg.ti.com - I don't speak for others and they don't speak for me. %0A

doc_1924 |@raw_text From %3A  fmg %40 alpha.smi.med.pitt.edu (Filip Gieszczykiewicz) %0A Subject %3A  Switching PS questions %0A Summary %3A  I know basics, !commercial models, 3Qs %0A Message-ID %3A  <9824 %40 blue.cis.pitt.edu> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 15 %3A 13 %3A 22 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news+ %40 pitt.edu %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Organization %3A  Medical Informatics, Pittsburgh, PA USA %0A Lines %3A  43 %0A  %0A  %0A 	Greetings. I've recently decided to chuck the linear regulators %0A 	and learn the "black magic" art of switching power supplies... %0A 	(before anyone flames me, I KNOW, both have their place  %3A -) %0A  %0A 	Anyways, I've built the basic up & down converters with pretty %0A 	good results (>80% efficiency) but I'm running into problems %0A 	when I try to design & build anything that puts out serious %0A 	amps... I know it can be done (I have some 5V %40 200A guts on my %0A 	bench) but something puzzles me %3A  I'm using a simple choke as  %0A 	the storage element (basicly a toroid with a single winding) %0A 	but ALL commercial models use transformers with MANY windings. %0A 	I traced a few and they seem to use some of the winding for %0A 	the usual error/feedback but some of the others seem to loose %0A 	me... What are they for? Better than that, anyone have a full %0A 	schematic for one of these that I could get a copy of? I'd %0A 	love to see how they manage to squeeze out so much from such %0A 	low volume  %3A -) %0A  %0A 	My other problems (in getting high amps & good efficiency) are %0A 	1) Lack of sources of ideal components (calculated) and 2) %0A 	Limited knowledge of the whole topic... I'm doing this on my %0A 	own (not school) mind you (in fact, I have yet to take any %0A 	course that covers transistors ;-) %0A  %0A 	So, is the answer to #1 the accumulation of dead commercial %0A 	models and truning into a scavanger (not that it's not what %0A 	I'm doing now...) and #2 getting & understanding schematics %0A 	and a bit more of the [mind-boggling] theory?  %0A  %0A 	Take care. %0A  %0A 	P.S. My goal is 12V  %40  ~25A in (car battery) -> 250VAC out and %0A 	(on the other end) 250V -> +5VDC  %40  5A, -5V  %40  1A, +12VDC  %40 8A %0A 	and -12VDC  %40 1A... the distance between the two will be %0A 	more than 100 feet (of 14-16 gauge) but less than 300 feet. %0A 	Would like to have a working model in a year or so...  %3A -)  %0A 	(Do I have a chance to make it?) %0A --  %0A / Filip "I'll buy a vowel" Gieszczykiewicz. %7C Best e-mail "fmgst+ %40 pitt.edu"  \ %0A %7C All ideas are mine but they can be yours for only $0.99 so respond NOW!!!! %7C  %0A %7C I live for my EE major, winsurfing, programming, SCA, and assorted dreams. %7C %0A \ 200MB Drive - Linux has 100MB and MS-DOS has 100MB. MS-DOS is worried ;-)  / %0A

doc_1930 |@raw_text From %3A  john %40 gu.uwa.edu.au (John West) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  ATARI 2600 Processors %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 1993 07 %3A 01 %3A 03 GMT %0A Organization %3A  The University of Western Australia %0A Lines %3A  54 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r847f$kp7 %40 uniwa.uwa.edu.au> %0A References %3A  <93110.125951PCA103 %40 psuvm.psu.edu> <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> <1r7e14$l2c %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mackerel.gu.uwa.edu.au %0A  %0A ifarqhar %40 laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au (Ian Farquhar) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> squish %40 endor.uucp (Shishin Yamada) writes %3A  %0A >>The Atari 2600 used a 6502 CPU, just like their entire 8-bit line %0A >>(400, 800,1200,1400, 1440, 130xe, 65xe computers, as well as the 5200 %0A >>game machine).  %0A  %0A >Wrong, it has a 6507. %0A  %0A For those who would like to know, the 6507 was a 6502 without IRQ or NMI, %0A and with only 13 address lines (giving 8K memory space). %0A  %0A >It had one custome chip (not an ASIC in the sense that word is now understood) %3A  %0A >the TIA (sometimes known as the 6526, although most other manufacturers list %0A >that as the CIA complex interface adapter.)  TIA stands for Television %0A >Interface Adapter, and it handles sound, paddles and the minimal video hardware %0A >the 2600 possessed. %0A  %0A Didn't know about it being called the 6526 - thats the CIA found in the %0A Commodore 64 (I don't believe this chip existed when the 2600 was around). %0A The TIA was mapped into the bottom 128 bytes of page 0, and shadowed in the %0A bottom 128 bytes of page 1. To get an image on the screen, you had to wait %0A until the raster line your picture started at, load bitmaps for this line %0A into the 'sprite' registers, tell them what x positions to take, how many %0A duplicates you wanted, etc, then do it all again for the next line. This %0A took all of the processor's time during the visible portion of the %0A display. %0A  %0A >There was also a standard 6532 RAM, I/O, Timer (RIOT), plus a voltage %0A >regulator and (if memory serves) a 555 timer.  That's all. %0A  %0A The RAM was mapped into the top 128 bytes of page 0, and shadowed in page %0A 1. The 6502 has a zero-page addressing mode on most instructions that is %0A both shorter and faster than the normal ones, so it is important on a %0A machine like this to have the scratchpad RAM in page 0. Unfortunately, it %0A also wants its stack to be in page 1 (the stack pointer is 8 bits, and the %0A high byte of the address is hardwired to 1). %0A  %0A The IOT section was mapped into page 2 somewhere. 2 8 bit I/O registers %0A (can't remember if each bit could be independantly set to I or O like the %0A 6522 and 6526), and 1(?) 8(?) bit timer with a programmable prescaler (I %0A think this was some power of 2). There were no interrupts in the system, so %0A many games would set up the timer at some known time, go away and do %0A something else for a while, then sit and wait for the timer to run down. %0A  %0A There was no logic in the box to do address decoding - the RIOT had at %0A least 2 chip select pins (probably one active high, one active low), and I %0A imagine the TIA was much the same. Various address lines were fed directly %0A to chip selects. The 6507 likes to have ROM right at the top of memory, so %0A the 2600 had to use ROMs with active high chip selects - not exactly %0A normal, so some cartriges had a 7404 in them to convert this to the more %0A usual active low chip select. %0A  %0A John West %0A

Thus Distribution %3A  world. %0A  %0A ygoland %40 wright.seas.ucla.edu (The Jester) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >However assuming that I can still encrypt things as I please, who %0A >cares about the clipper chip?  %0A  %0A Why do we hackers care about the Clipper chip?  Do we give a shit %0A about anybody's privacy accept our own?  And perhaps not even our %0A own; are we so smart that we always know when we're talking to %0A somebody who has a wiretap on their phone? %0A  %0A I find the "call thru your computer" ideas may reflect this attitude. %0A Ideas that are of, by, and for hackers, and don't help anybody in the %0A real world, aren't going to do anybody much good, including ourselves %0A where voice phones are concerned. %0A  %0A We *do* need an alternative to NSA-bugged telephones, but %0A we're talking inexpensive *telephones* here, including hand-sized %0A cellulars, that need strong crypto, real privacy.  Make-shift %0A computer hacker rigs that require living by your computer to %0A talk privately over the phone are just a dumb stunt that doesn't  %0A do anything for anybody's privacy in the real world.   %0A  %0A What we need is a true *privacy chip*.  For example, a real-time  %0A voice-encryption RSA, silicon compile it and spit out ASIC.   %0A Put this chip on the market as a de facto standard for international  %0A business, diplomats, and private communications.  If the U.S. bans  %0A it, we make it somewhere else and import it.  The Japanese, German, %0A Dutch, Taiwanese, Korean, etc. electronics companies don't want the  %0A NSA spying on them.  U.S. workers lose more jobs to government fascist %0A stupidity. %0A  %0A jhart %40 agora.rain.com %0A

doc_1983 |@raw_text From %3A  dannyb %40 panix.com (Daniel Burstein) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  What do Nuclear Site's Cooling Towers do? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5nJqL.42F %40 panix.com> %0A Organization %3A  PANIX Public Access Unix, NYC %0A References %3A  <Yfnutuy00WB=02e1hU %40 andrew.cmu.edu> <nagleC5n17r.3Fn %40 netcom.com> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 17 Apr 1993 23 %3A 54 %3A 21 GMT %0A Lines %3A  27 %0A  %0A <lots of pretty good stuff about how the huge towers near most nuclear %0A power plants are there to cool the used steam back into near ambient %0A temperature water deleted> %0A  %0A >>water.  As I recall the water isn't as hot (thermodynamically) in many %0A >>fossil fuel plants, and of course there is less danger of radioactive %0A >>contamination. %0A  %0A >       Actually, fossil fuel plants run hotter than the usual  %0A >boiling-water reactor nuclear plants.  (There's a gripe in the industry %0A >that nuclear power uses 1900 vintage steam technology).  So it's %0A >more important in nuclear plants to get the cold end of the system %0A >as cold as possible.  Hence big cooling towers.   %0A  %0A     as a point of info, some of the early nuclear power plants in this %0A country used the fission pile as a first stage to get the water hot, and %0A then had a second stage -fossil fuel- step to get the water (actually %0A steam) VERY HOT. %0A  %0A    I remember seeing this at Con Edison's Indian Point #1 power plant, %0A which is about 30 miles north of NYC, and built more or less 1958. %0A  %0A  %0A dannyb %40 panix.com %0A  %0A (all the usual disclaimers apply, whatever they may be) %0A  %0A

doc_2001 |@raw_text From %3A  amanda %40 intercon.com (Amanda Walker) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Secret algorithm [Re %3A  Clipper Chip and crypto key-escrow] %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 23 %3A 50 %3A 03 -0500 %0A Organization %3A  InterCon Systems Corporation - Herndon, VA  USA %0A Lines %3A  30 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qnupd$jpm %40 news.intercon.com> %0A References %3A  <jhesseC5LuMC.2Ex %40 netcom.com> %0A Reply-To %3A  amanda %40 intercon.com (Amanda Walker) %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  chaos.intercon.com %0A Keywords %3A  encryption, wiretap, clipper, key-escrow, Mykotronx %0A X-Newsreader %3A  InterCon TCP/Connect II 1.1 %0A  %0A jhesse %40 netcom.com (John Hesse) writes %3A  %0A > Oh great. Wonderful news. Nobody can listen in--except the feds.  %0A  %0A Hey, it's better than the status quo. %0A  %0A I am far less worried about "the feds" tapping my phone than high school  %0A scanner surfers who get their kicks out of eavesdropping on cellular and  %0A cordless phone calls. %0A  %0A It would be stupid to rely on even a "Clipperized" channel for truly  %0A sensitive material, but it *does* seem to finally offer a reasonable way to  %0A guard against casual eavesdropping.  For example, even with my strong "right  %0A to bear arms" view of the private right to possess and use strong  %0A cryptosystems, the system as described provides enough security that I would  %0A actually buy a cordless phone, and would be much less wary of using cellular  %0A phones, walkie-talkies, and so on.  As long as it's only used for mass-market  %0A voice scrambling, I actually don't see a problem with it. %0A  %0A If you want more security than it offers, use something different.  Use PKCS  %0A for electronic mail, CELP over DES or triple DES with Diffie-Hellman key  %0A exchange for your voice traffic, or whatever. %0A  %0A And yes, I'd rather just see all crypto restrictions lifted, but this is at  %0A least an incrememental improvement for certain applications... %0A  %0A  %0A Amanda Walker %0A InterCon Systems Corporation %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_2024 |@raw_text From %3A  svoboda %40 rtsg.mot.com (David Svoboda) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering sans Hands %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr23.231213.29910 %40 rtsg.mot.com> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 rtsg.mot.com %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  corolla18 %0A Organization %3A  Motorola Inc., Cellular Infrastructure Group %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.203344.8417 %40 cs.cornell.edu> <gbnvgw %40 quantum.qnx.com> <1993Apr22.005308.11779 %40 cs.cornell.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 23 %3A 12 %3A 13 GMT %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr22.005308.11779 %40 cs.cornell.edu> karr %40 cs.cornell.edu (David Karr) writes %3A  %0A %7CIn article <gbnvgw %40 quantum.qnx.com> dagibbs %40 quantum.qnx.com (David Gibbs) writes %3A  %0A %7C> %0A %7C>Yes, even when steering no hands you do something quite similar %0A %7C>to countersteering.  Basically to turn left, you to a quick wiggle %0A %7C>of the bike to the right first, causing a counteracting lean to %0A %7C>occur to the left. %0A %7C %0A %7CThis sounds suspiciously like black magic to me.  If by "quick wiggle %0A %7Cto the right" you mean that the handlebars turn toward the right %0A %7Cbefore turning to the left, what is the input to the steering %0A %7Cmechanism that makes this happen in the absence of the old %0A %7C"shove-shove"? %0A  %0A Well, as many a bored bike tourer can tell you, the way to steer %0A sans hans is to push your body off to the side you want to lean. %0A Say you want to turn left.  You push your body off to the left. %0A To do this, you have to push against something, and the only %0A thing to push against is the ground (through the bike).  Well, %0A the apple guy (Wozniak? or was that Churchill?) says that the  %0A ground will push you right back.  So, you pushed yourself off to  %0A the left by pushing on the ground to the right, and the ground  %0A pushed back toward the left.  Well, that push is on both wheels.   %0A The rear wheel doesn't care (unless you have serious bearing  %0A problems) (except of course on the Spagthorpe Dragonfly, which %0A had the revolutionary countersteering-contra-shaft-drive rear end),  %0A but the front wheel has trail.  If the ground pushes the front wheel  %0A toward the left at the contact patch, the trail will cause the  %0A wheel to turn to the right.  Hey, there we are.  No-hands counter- %0A steering. %0A  %0A Dave Svoboda (svoboda %40 void.rtsg.mot.com)    %7C "I'm getting tired of %0A 90 Concours 1000 (Mmmmmmmmmm!)              %7C  beating you up, Dave. %0A 84 RZ 350 (Ring Ding) (Woops!)              %7C  You never learn." %0A AMA 583905  DoD #0330  COG 939  (Chicago)   %7C  -- Beth "Bruiser" Dixon %0A

doc_2026 |@raw_text From %3A  aj %40 sage.cc.purdue.edu (John Dormer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  text of White House announcement and Q&As on clipper chip encryption %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5qJs9.FwF %40 mentor.cc.purdue.edu> %0A Summary %3A  Misinterretation got us here today %0A Keywords %3A  constitution, misinterpretation, law %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mentor.cc.purdue.edu (USENET News) %0A Organization %3A  Purdue Daemons %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> <bontchev.734981805 %40 fbihh> <1993Apr19.130132.12650 %40 afterlife.ncsc.mil> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 14 %3A 48 %3A 08 GMT %0A Lines %3A  26 %0A  %0A   Misinterpretation, though it should be a crime in itself, is what %0A United States lawyers use to make their bread and butter. %0A  %0A   In Manchester, CT a few years ago, a small company wanted to run a %0A game system galled "LaserGames," similar in many aspects to Photon %0A (tm). Three lawyers and about a hundred citizens found an ancient law %0A in Manchester's books which clearly from context was designed to %0A prohibit travelling carnivals by enumerating the features of a carnival %0A which they felt at the time made the prohibition obvious. Among these %0A things was "shooting galleries," which is what the lawyers for the %0A opposition to LaserGames wanted to harp upon. The judge took the two %0A words from this law, completely out of context, and ruled that %0A LaserGames could not operate in Manchester. %0A  %0A   Keep in mind that most travelling carnivals use projectile weapons in %0A their shooting galleries, and not light beams. Clearly from context, %0A LaserGames got shafted, but if the two words are applied, their denial %0A of operating permission was justified. %0A  %0A   If I had the text of the law I'd post it, but I'm afraid I don't %0A remember it all well enough to even try. That little bit with the two %0A words stuck well, though. %0A  %0A  %3A 	John Dormer %0A  %3A 	jad %40 expert.cc.purdue.edu %0A  %0A

doc_2037 |@raw_text From %3A  jlevine %40 rd.hydro.on.ca (Jody Levine) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering_FAQ please post %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.144330.2608 %40 rd.hydro.on.ca> %0A Organization %3A  Ontario Hydro - Research Division %0A References %3A  <66652 %40 mimsy.umd.edu> <mjs.735230272 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk> <1993Apr19.155551.227 %40 cs.cornell.edu> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 93 14 %3A 43 %3A 30 GMT %0A Lines %3A  37 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr19.155551.227 %40 cs.cornell.edu> karr %40 cs.cornell.edu (David Karr) writes %3A  %0A >In article <mjs.735230272 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk> mjs %40 sys.uea.ac.uk (Mike Sixsmith) writes %3A  %0A >> %0A >>No No No No!! All I am saying is that you don't even need to tell people the  %0A >>technique of countersteering, cos they will do it intuitively the first %0A >>time they try to go round a corner. %0A  %0A Some will, and others will steer with their tuchuses. I don't know how much %0A the teaching of countersteering in the beginner course really helps the %0A tuchus steerers. I was one, I guess that I always steered a bicycle that way, %0A and I only got the hang of countersteering in normal riding *after* the course. %0A I could do the countersteering swerves in the course no problem, but I only %0A started using it in my normal riding when I decided that my turning at speed %0A (off-ramps and the like) was a lot more difficult that it should have been. %0A I knew how it works (although that's currently up for debate) definitely knew %0A *that* it works, as I could do it in swerves, but only figured it out later %0A in my normal riding. Just a data point. I think that it's not a bad idea to %0A bring the idea up, but it's best to let everyone tuchus-steer for the first %0A lesson or two, so they can learn to shift gears before they have to worry %0A about proper handlebar technique. %0A  %0A >countersteering.  In fact, my Experienced Rider Course instructors %0A >claimed that they could get on behind a new rider and make the bike %0A >turn to whichever side they wanted just by shifting their weight %0A >around, even when the operator was trying to turn in the opposite %0A >direction.  (I admit I've never actually seen this.) %0A  %0A I have. In our beginner course we had passenger training. Sometime during %0A the lesson the instructor would hop on the back of the bike, and the student %0A would take him for a ride. If the student did not give the instructor the %0A "you are a sack of potatoes" passenger speech, the instructor would steer %0A the bike and make a general nuisance of himself. It was amusing to watch, %0A I'm just happy that it didn't happen to me. %0A  %0A I've        bike                      like       %7C Jody Levine  DoD #275 kV %0A      got a       you can        if you      -PF  %7C Jody.P.Levine %40 hydro.on.ca %0A                          ride it                 %7C Toronto, Ontario, Canada %0A
