doc_2061 |@raw_text From %3A  et %40 teal.csn.org (Eric H. Taylor) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  HELP_WITH_TRACKING_DEVICE %0A Message-ID %3A  <C4ruoI.B2z %40 csn.org> %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.electronics %0A Summary %3A  underground and underwater wireless methods %0A Keywords %3A  Rogers, Tesla, Hertz, underground, underwater, wireless, radio %0A Sender %3A  Eric H. Taylor %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  teal.csn.org %0A Organization %3A  4-L Laboratories %0A References %3A  <00969FBA.E640FF10 %40 AESOP.RUTGERS.EDU> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 31 Mar 1993 21 %3A 07 %3A 28 GMT %0A Expires %3A  Fri, 30 Apr 1993 06 %3A 00 %3A 00 GMT %0A Lines %3A  36 %0A  %0A In article <00969FBA.E640FF10 %40 AESOP.RUTGERS.EDU> mcdonald %40 AESOP.RUTGERS.EDU writes %3A  %0A >[...] %0A >There are a variety of water-proof housings I could use but the real meat %0A >of the problem is the electronics...hence this posting.  What kind of %0A >transmission would be reliable underwater, in murky or even night-time %0A >conditions?  I'm not sure if sound is feasible given the distortion under- %0A >water...obviously direction would have to be accurate but range could be %0A >relatively short (I imagine 2 or 3  hundred yards would be more than enough) %0A > %0A >Jim McDonald %0A  %0A Refer to patents by JAMES HARRIS ROGERS %3A  %0A 958,829; 1,220,005; 1,322,622; 1,349,103; 1,315,862; 1,349,104; %0A 1,303,729; 1,303,730; 1,316,188 %0A  %0A He details methods of underground and underwater wireless communications. %0A For a review, refer to _Electrical_Experimenter_, March 1919 and June 1919. %0A  %0A Rogers' methods were used extensively during the World War, and was %0A unclassified after the war. Supposedly, the government rethought this %0A soon after, and Rogers was convieniently forgotten. %0A  %0A The bottom line is that all antennas that are grounded send HALF of %0A their signal THRU the ground. The half that travels thru space is %0A quickly dissapated (by the square of the distance), but that which %0A travels thru the ground does not disapate at all. Furthermore, %0A the published data showed that when noise drowned out regular %0A reception, the underground antennas would recieve virtually noise-free. %0A  %0A IF you find this hard to believe, then refer to the work of the %0A man who INVENTED wireless %3A  Tesla. Tesla confirmed that Rogers' methods %0A were correct, while Hertzian wave theory was completely "abberant". %0A  %0A ---- %0A  ET   "Tesla was 100 years ahead of his time. Perhaps now his time comes." %0A ---- %0A

doc_2107 |@raw_text From %3A  brad %40 clarinet.com (Brad Templeton) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  text of White House announcement and Q&As on clipper chip encryption %0A Organization %3A  ClariNet Communications Corp. %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Sat, 17 Apr 1993 00 %3A 18 %3A 05 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr17.001805.11432 %40 clarinet.com> %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> <1qmugcINNpu9 %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A Lines %3A  37 %0A  %0A The stragegy of the government is interesting.  The real fear comes from %0A them doing more than this. %0A  %0A This is a voluntary program, and thus harder for us to object to on %0A the surface. %0A  %0A Their strategy is a business one rather than legal one.  They are %0A pushing to get a standard in place, a secret standard, and if they %0A get it as a standard then they will drive competitors out of the market. %0A It will be legal to sell better, untapable encryption that doesn't have %0A registered keys, but it will be difficult, and thus not a plan for %0A most phone companies. %0A  %0A You see, with clipper chip phones you'll be able to talk to any %0A cellular company, or other phones or ports because they will follow %0A the standard.  AT&T has already announced a clipper chip encryption %0A product.  The government has marketed hard to get major vendors to %0A use these chips.   If they get enough market share, they will rule. %0A  %0A And thus there will be very little market for systems that can't be %0A tapped by the police.  The public isn't that concerned about it now, %0A after all.  They freely do calls that anybody with an old TV can listen %0A to today!  They won't pay big extra bucks for proprietary phones that secure %0A them only from the police. %0A  %0A Well, some people will buy these phones, but they will only work with %0A other proprietary phones, so the market will be small and the phones %0A expensive.  Unless they are made in numbers large enough to sell them %0A cheap, only the Mob will buy them. %0A  %0A And this means that the FBI will want to track the customer lists of %0A better encryption phones, because "the only reason a person would want %0A one is to evade the police." %0A  %0A Interesting. %0A --  %0A Brad Templeton, ClariNet Communications Corp. -- Sunnyvale, CA 408/296-0366 %0A  
doc_2117 |@raw_text From %3A  kschang %40 sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu (Kuo-Sheng (Kasey) Chang) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.163605.24784 %40 csus.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 csus.edu %0A Organization %3A  San Francisco State University %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu> <1993Apr21.085848.12704W %40 lumina.edb.tih.no> <1993Apr21.141137.863 %40 imag.fr> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 16 %3A 36 %3A 05 GMT %0A Lines %3A  75 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr21.141137.863 %40 imag.fr> schaefer %40 imag.imag.fr (Arno Schaefer) writes %3A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.085848.12704W %40 lumina.edb.tih.no>, ketil %40 edb.tih.no (Ketil Albertsen,TIH) writes %3A  %0A >%7C> In article <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu>, mblock %40 reed.edu (Matt Block) writes %3A  %0A >>>	I guess what I am saying is that your question is difficult, if not %0A >>>impossible, to answer. What exactly do you want to know?  Do you need a good %0A >>>one for a project you are working on? How secure must it be?  Are you trying %0A >>>to crack one that someone else has used?  I can probably make suggestions, %0A >>>assuming the activity is strictly legal.  (In general, it is a BAD idea, %0A >>>legally, to tamper with copy protection.  It can also lead to corruption of %0A >>>files which you necessarily do not have back ups of (being as they are copy %0A >>>protected,) which can be devestating.)  Do you have absolutely no ideas for %0A >>>practical applications, and are merely curious? %0A >>>	Please clear up those questions, and I'll try to help as much as I %0A >>>can. %0A >>  %0A >> May we interpret this as an offer to volunteer as editor for a %0A >> "Copy protection FAQ" ? I am quite sure that I am not alone welcoming such %0A >> an initiative! *I* will volunteer to ask some of the questions, if you will %0A >> provide the answers  %3A -) %0A >>  %0A >Hey, now will you stop encouraging him? Copy protection only serves one pur- %0A >pose %3A  to keep the honest buyer from making (legal) backup copies. It will %0A >definitely not stop any pirates. If you want to protect you soft, supply a %0A >good documentation and support. This is IMHO the *only* way of effectively  %0A >protecting software. %0A  %0A There are several types of copy protection, and the point is to make sure the %0A user is using a legitimate copy.  The simplest and virtually fool-proof way is %0A for the program to somehow fixate itself to the machine it was installed on %0A (some sort of checksum, serial number, whatever) so a copy put on a different %0A machine (NOT installed from original disks) will not work.   %0A  %0A The program is definitely backupable, if restored to the same machine (depends %0A on the programmer...  don't use a disk drive characteristic!)  If the user  %0A did an upgrade to the machine, he/she should reinstall all programs any way. %0A No document look-up, no disk wear-and-tear! %0A  %0A I did not say that the originals would allow only one install.  The user's  %0A conscience should do that. %0A  %0A I know, I'll get flamed for this...  But with the increasing number of "casual" %0A users who either unknowingly or don't care about the software copyrights %0A (It's the truth.  I have "friends" who ask me for copies of my latest games %0A all the time, and when I refused, they went after somebody else.), casual %0A pirating is becoming more of a problem.  Some sort of copy protection will %0A discourage the casual copying.  I've seen what some of my "friends" dug up %0A somewhere...  Latest and the greatest games, all cracked, WITHIN days of actual %0A release!  You know how many bytes you need to change in X-wing to disable %0A the quiz?  TWO!  Yes, TWO!  (And don't ask me which ones they are.)  Determined %0A pirates are unstoppable, given enough time, but their results do not spread  %0A that far, since pirate boards are not that well-known, and easily tracked once %0A found by authorities.  It is the "casual" pirates that the copy protection is %0A determined to discourage. %0A  %0A What I believe the companies should do is implement the above plus %0A a special patch once the user registers that loudly exclaims upon bootup %0A "REGISTERED TO XXXXX -- address, city, state zip" and disables the above. %0A Two benefits %3A  1) encourages registration, 2) cuts down on pirating and %0A makes it more traceable, because if the patch's registration message is %0A encrypted, it will be quite hard to change, and therefore provides a %0A stable trail of who allowed their copy out of their hands, and thus %0A violated their license agreement. %0A  %0A This way, the legitimate users who does not register will experience minimal  %0A discomfort (who does major upgrades to their computer frequently?) as only %0A problem they have is they won't be able to restore to another computer. %0A  %0A The registered users would have proven they are legitmate users and therefore %0A gains full rights, and can restore to different machines.  On the other hand, %0A the software company now have a record of where THIS particular copy is  %0A supposed to be.  If this user's copy was found to be somewhere it was not  %0A supposed to be, we know who has broken their license agreement.  Of course, %0A a hacker can break that eventually, but that's not the point, is it? %0A  %0A --Kasey Chang %0A

doc_2157 |@raw_text From %3A  strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) %0A Subject %3A  Wiretapping reality today %0A Message-ID %3A  <strnlghtC5wKH0.62x %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  DSI/USCRPAC %0A References %3A  <GUMBY.93Apr20073629 %40 tweedledumb.cygnus.com> <1993Apr22.022324.17172 %40 news.clarkson.edu> <strnlghtC5wJn3.4t1 %40 netcom.com> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 20 %3A 48 %3A 36 GMT %0A Lines %3A  24 %0A  %0A  %0A Some of the messages here seem to reflect the view that the government is %0A listening in on everything and one will have to hide one's clipper messages %0A somehow if non-escrowed crypto goes away. %0A  %0A A little perspective might be in order. %0A  %0A The number of court ordered wire taps is pretty low. Law enforcement has to %0A present pretty good evidence to get even that limited number of %0A authorizations. %0A  %0A Thus the overwhelming majority of conversations are neither tapped nor %0A recorded by the government, and for that to happen they have to %3A  %0A a) Have a pretty good reason, with evidence; %0A b) Use this sparingly on highest priority "pretty good reasons." %0A  %0A Though the system may be imperfect, it is a long way from the horror stories %0A some here seem to believe or anticipate. %0A  %0A --  %0A David Sternlight         Great care has been taken to ensure the accuracy of %0A                          our information, errors and omissions excepted.   %0A  %0A  %0A

My understanding of the current process %0A that mail takes is it gets downloaded on floppy disk and is processed %0A by retiree volunteers, who match the message against message profiles %0A and check the message count. (I.e. %3A  "yeah, that's a for gays in the %0A military. what's this clipper stuff? must be against gays in the %0A military...") %0A  %0A 	The higher-volume white-house email stuff is in the works, %0A I know for a fact, but won't be online for probably another month %0A or two at the soonest. My understanding is that the link speed will %0A increase (direct internet instead of Compu$erve to floppy) but the %0A message processing will remain the same. %0A  %0A >Unless the people at the White House print and distribute this mail %0A >every day, you may have better luck printing out a letter (on paper, %0A >that flat white stuff all over my desk) and Snail-Mailing it to the %0A >White House. I agree that printing it %0A and sending Cc %3A  to everyone you can think of is probably better because %0A it is more visible, but the message processing (fitting messages against %0A a template) is the same in either case. %0A  %0A mjr. %0A

American manufacturers peddling Cripple Chips with a secret untested %0A      algorithm whose keys are held by people with a history of untrustworthy %0A      behavoir, or %0A  %0A  2. Japanese (to pick the obvious example) manufacturers peddling encryption %0A      chips with an algorithm that has faced public scrutiny and keys under %0A      the control of the user, %0A  %0A which would you choose?  At most, the American government can deny this %0A choice to American citizens (and probably not that, if the glorious success %0A of the War on Drugs is any example); it can't do much about the global market. %0A  
doc_2177 |@raw_text From %3A  baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) %0A Subject %3A  Mars Observer Update - 04/23/93 %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 1993 20 %3A 36 UT %0A Organization %3A  Jet Propulsion Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  48 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <23APR199320361315 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A Keywords %3A  Mars Observer, JPL %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A Forwarded from the Mars Observer Project %0A  %0A                        MARS OBSERVER STATUS REPORT %0A                              April 23, 1993 %0A                               10 %3A 00 AM PDT %0A  %0A Flight Sequence C8 is active, the Spacecraft subsystems and instrument %0A payload performing well in Array Normal Spin and outer cruise %0A configuration, with uplink and downlink via the High Gain Antenna; uplink %0A at 125 bps, downlink at the 2 K Engineering data rate. %0A  %0A As a result of the spacecraft entering Contingency Mode on April 9, all %0A payload instruments were automatically powered off by on-board fault %0A protection software.  Gamma Ray Spectrometer Random Access Memory %0A was successfully reloaded on Monday, April 19.  To prepare for %0A Magnetometer Calibrations which were rescheduled for execution in Flight %0A Sequence C9 on Tuesday and Wednesday of next week, a reload of Payload %0A Data System Random Access Memory will take place this morning %0A beginning at 10 %3A 30 AM. %0A  %0A Over this weekend, the Flight Team will send real-time commands to %0A perform Differential One-Way Ranging to obtain additional data for %0A analysis by the Navigation Team.  Radio Science Ultra Stable Oscillator %0A testing will take place on Monday . %0A  %0A The Flight Sequence C9 uplink will occur on Sunday, April 25, with %0A activation at Midnight, Monday evening April 26.  C9 has been modified to %0A include Magnetometer Calibrations which could not be performed in C8 due %0A to Contingency Mode entry on April 9.  These Magnetometer instrument %0A calibrations will allow the instrument team to better characterize the %0A spacecraft-generated magnetic field and its effect on their instrument. %0A This information is critical to Martian magnetic field measurements %0A which occur during approach and mapping phases. MAG Cals will require %0A the sequence to command the spacecraft out of Array Normal Spin state %0A and perform slew and roll maneuvers to provide the MAG team data points %0A in varying spacecraft attitudes and orientations. %0A  %0A Today, the spacecraft is 22,971,250 km (14,273,673 mi.) from Mars %0A travelling at a velocity of 2.09 kilometers/second (4,677 mph) with %0A respect to Mars.  One-way light time is approximately 10 minutes, 38 %0A seconds. %0A      ___    _____     ___ %0A     /_ /%7C  /____/ \  /_ /%7C     Ron Baalke         %7C baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C  __ \ /%7C %7C %7C %7C     Jet Propulsion Lab %7C %0A  ___%7C %7C %7C %7C %7C__) %7C/  %7C %7C %7C__   M/S 525-3684 Telos %7C The aweto from New Zealand %0A /___%7C %7C %7C %7C  ___/    %7C %7C/__ /%7C Pasadena, CA 91109 %7C is part caterpillar and %0A %7C_____%7C/  %7C_%7C/       %7C_____%7C/                     %7C part vegetable. %0A  %0A

Thank you for your support. %0A  %0A Spring break, I went through the four corners area and back.  The most %0A beautiful stop I made was in Utah at the Needles Overlook.  Though this %0A is a bit further east than where you appear to be going, I highly %0A recommend it.  IMHO it is far more beautiful than the Grand Canyon.  It %0A was not well marked, but was one of few paved roads off of US191 (I was %0A heading north from Monticello).  In order to get to the right place, I %0A should clarify that it is the Needles OVERLOOK, and not the recreation %0A area.  Heading north from Monticello, it is the second turnoff, and may %0A have been marked as the Anticline Overlook.  Anticline overlook is %0A about 20 (dirt, if this matters to you) miles past the Needles %0A overlook.  The road out to the overlook is paved and reasonably %0A maintained (I ran it about 70mph). %0A  %0A Looking out from the overlook was like being God and looking down on  %0A the world.  If it isn't too far out of your way, you should see it. %0A  %0A  %0A Dan Martin         %7C     "I can't stand this proliferation of paperwork. %0A martind %40 spot       %7C      Its useless to fight the forms. %0A                    %7C %0A                    %7C      You've got to kill the people producing them." %0A .colorado.edu      %7C           -Vladimir P. Kabaidze, Soviet Plant manager %0A  %0A

( I hope that this is the %0A >proper place to post this subject) %0A  %0A Oh, yeah.  This is a fine place.  We haven't had the "why does concrete %0A kill lead-acid batteries" thread in at least six months. %0A  %0A >  Why does a lead acid battery discharge and become dead (totally unuseable) %0A >when stored on a concrete floor?   %0A  %0A The concrete simply sucks all the electrons out of the battery and drains %0A them into the ground. %0A  %0A Another explanation, implausible as it is,  is that the lead-acid battery %0A needs to be periodically charged (topped-off), otherwise the battery %0A self-discharges and then undergoes irreversible chemical reaction. %0A  %0A Naawwwww.... the concrete sucks the life out. %0A  %0A --  %0A  * Dana H. Olson; CMSC (G)) %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r20f7INNji2 %40 umbc7.umbc.edu> %0A References %3A  <1993Apr18.034352.19470 %40 news.clarkson.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  umbc7.umbc.edu %0A X-Auth-User %3A  olson %0A  %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr18.034352.19470 %40 news.clarkson.edu>, tuinstra %40 sunspot.ece.clarkson.edu.soe (Dwight Tuinstra) writes %3A  %0A %7C> It might pay to start looking at what this proposal might mean to a %0A %7C> police agency.  It just might be a bad idea for them, too. %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> OK, suppose the NY State Police want to tap a suspect's phone.  They %0A %7C> need a warrant, just like the old days.  But unlike the old days, they %0A %7C> now need to  %0A %7C>  %0A %7C>    (a) get two federal agencies to give them the two parts of %0A %7C>        the key. %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> Now, what happens if there's a tiff between the two escrow houses? %0A %7C> Posession/release of keys becomes a political bargaining chit. %0A  %0A 	While I think it is unrealistic to suppose that the federal %0A agencies will fail to promptly comply with a court order, there is  %0A still a good point here.  Local law enforcement will be unable to perform %0A a wiretap without bringing in federal agencies.   Based on the (possibly %0A incomplete) understanding of the system quoted from D. Denning, only the %0A FBI will be able to decrypt the system key encryption layer, which seems %0A to be needed even to identify what escrowed keys to request.  This moves %0A a great deal of law enforcement power to the federal level. %0A 	The reason I like this point is that it may sway or even persuade %0A people who don't generally line up with the civil liberties crowd.  A %0A national police force is opposed by people from a broad range of political  %0A viewpoints. %0A  %0A  %0A olson %40 umbc.edu %0A

There is also the 683xx, I think %0A  DU> one of those has the DRAM controller built in. This one is for the 6664 %0A  DU> DRAM, however, the 41256 has only one more address line, adding only %0A  DU> another component or so. The 256k SIMMs are basically 8 or 9 41256 %0A  DU> DRAM chips (or their equivalent in fewer packages). %0A  %0A     Be careful.  The 41256 is organized as 4 64k sections and %0A     needs only 8 bits to refresh.  Whereas the 44256 has 4 256k %0A     (IE is a 1M dram) and requires 9 bits to refresh. %0A  %0A  DU> It *can* be done, just takes a bit of logic design. I'm actually %0A  DU> about to do it using a 65C02P3 chip... I've got 8 256k simms... that's %0A  DU> 2 megabytes on my Apple //e... (used to be in my '386). %0A  %0A     How to you plan to use it? I mean, if we can imagine the %0A >machine that does 1 trial/nanosecond, we can imagine the storage medium %0A >that could index and archive it. %0A   %0A    Hmmmm.  I think, with really large keyspaces like this, you need to %0A alter the strategy discussed for DES.  Attempt decryption of several %0A blocks, and check the disctribution of the contents.  I don't think it's %0A at all feasible to keep 2**80 encryptions of a known plaintext block on %0A *any* amount of tape or CD-ROM.  And certainly not 2**128 such encrypted %0A blocks.  (Anyone know a cheap way of converting every atom in the solar %0A system into a one bit storage device?) %0A   %0A    Actually, a keysearch of this kind shouldn't be much worse than the %0A simpler kind in terms of speed.  It's just that you have to do it over %0A for *every* encrypted message. %0A   %0A    Dumb question %3A   Has anyone ever done any serious research on how many %0A legitimate ASCII-encoded 8-byte blocks there are that could be part of %0A an english sentence?  For attacking DES in ECB mode, it seems like a %0A dictionary of this kind might be pretty valuable.... %0A   %0A    --John Kelsey %0A

Or you can %0A do what I did one soggy summer %3A  open the fuel line, drain some onto a  %0A piece of rough or rotten wood, stick that into the middle of the soon-to- %0A be inferno and CAREFULLY strike a match... As Kurt Vonnegut titled one %0A of the latter chapters in Cat's Cradle, "Ah-Whoom!" %0A  %0A Works like a charm every time  %3A -) %0A  %0A  %0A /-----b-o-d-y---i-s---t-h-e---b-i-k-e----------------------------\ %0A %7C                                                                %7C %0A %7C     DoD# 88888           asphaug %40 hindmost.lpl.arizona.edu      %7C %0A %7C  '90 Kawi Zephyr                  (Erik Asphaug)               %7C %0A %7C   '86 BMW R80GS                                                %7C %0A \-----------------------s-o-u-l---i-s---t-h-e---r-i-d-e-r--------/ %0A

doc_2267 |@raw_text From %3A  wcd82671 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (daniel warren c) %0A Subject %3A  Splitfire Plugs...  Kinda Offical... %0A Date %3A  Thu, 15 Apr 1993 18 %3A 22 %3A 49 GMT %0A Summary %3A  Supposed "Higher power output". %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5JF22.DJr %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  rec.motorcycles %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu (Net Noise owner) %0A Keywords %3A  Using Splitfire plugs for performance. %0A Organization %3A  University of Illinois at Urbana %0A Lines %3A  54 %0A  %0A  %0A Yo, Whaz up!!! %0A  %0A Earlier, I was reading on the net about using Splitfire plugs.  One %0A guy was thinking about it and almost everybody shot him to hell.  Well, %0A I saw one think that someone said about "Show me a team that used Split- %0A fires...."  Well, here's some additional insight and some theories %0A about splitfire plugs and how they boost us as oppossed to cages. %0A  %0A Splitfires were originally made to burn fuel more efficiently and %0A increased power for the 4x4 cages.  Well, for these guys, splitfires %0A increased performance by increasing TORQUE.  They weren't focusing %0A on horsepower numbers. %0A  %0A Now how does this related to us high performance pilots?  Well, that %0A depends.  Do you pilot a high performance 2- or 4-cylinder machine? %0A In the case of 4-cylinders, splitfires would increase overall torque, %0A but 4's make more top end horsepower with its torque packed down low. %0A So for 4's, splitfires would not significantly increase power. %0A  %0A But what about twins?...  Many of you 4 guys laugh at some of us twins, %0A but many times we carry less weight which sometimes can make up for %0A the hp loss (see Doug Polen vs. Scott Russell, Daytona 1992).  However, %0A twins make more torque thoughout their powerbands.   So how does this %0A translate?  Increased torque should "theoretically" help twins make %0A more power.  Splitfire claims that there should be not extra mods %0A or anything made, just stick 'em in. %0A  %0A Now I don't know about all of this (and I'm trying to catch up with %0A somebody about it now), but Splitfires should help twins more than %0A 4's.         %0A  %0A As far as racing teams....  Ducati team "Fast by Ferraci" used %0A splitfires in the 1989 season (this is when they had Jamie James %0A running for em), but I don't know why they stopped since then. %0A Also, somebody check to see if they had them in 88..... %0A  %0A Peace. %0A  %0A Warren %0A wcd82671 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu %0A "Have Suzuki, will travel..." %0A  %0A At a local "fix-er-up-er" shop, the bike repairest looked at a %0A dumped ZX-7.  Then he asked the guy... %0A  %0A "What happened..."   "I dumped the clutch..." %0A "How fast..."        "Pretty fast..." %0A "Insurance..."       "Nope." %0A  %0A The fixer smiled..... %0A  %0A "What do you know about bikes?"   "Not much....." %0A   %0A

Lets write a DOCUMENT which includes all the reasons %0A we oppose Clipper, in clear, concise, non-techincal manner. I urge  %0A everyone of you to take the (very simple) "start" below and repost it %0A with changes. Let the text evolve until we reach something most of us %0A like. Then, all of you should send a copy (with a personnel letter) %0A to your congress critter, local reporter on sci/tech, etc. %0A  %0A Please, to make this a success, try to post only an "agreed" version, %0A not flames. To respond to a flame to this, please change the subject %0A to, e.g, "clipper scope - discussion". %0A  %0A -- Michael Golan %0A    mg %40 cs.princeton.edu %0A  %0A [all of these are points - which should be made into paragraphs] %0A  %0A What is wrong with the clipper chip - By usenet users %0A ----------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A 1) It is secret.  %0A 2) How can we trust the escrow agencies? %0A 3) It is not cost-effective %0A 4) We want other encryption systems, the government seems to want to %0A    disallow it in the future %0A 5) Anyone can build a non-key system %0A 6) We are worried about a back door %0A 7) Once everyone uses a clipper chip, the mechanism for a Big-Brother %0A    government is in place, a change of government can lead to it.  %0A    Especially since the escrow agencies operation is not governed by %0A    law (so the president can change the rules to allow free access to %0A    the keys at any time, e.g., during war) %0A 8) Few criminals are caught by wiretaps, the cost [and risks] are unjustified %0A 9) Once the FBI get hold of a key, it can decrypt past and future conversations %0A  %0A ... %0A  %0A     %0A

doc_2290 |@raw_text From %3A  mg %40 cs.princeton.edu (Michael Golan) %0A Subject %3A  how can 0.022 uF be different from two 0.047 in series?! %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.185326.9830 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Originator %3A  news %40 nimaster %0A Sender %3A  news %40 Princeton.EDU (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  elan.princeton.edu %0A Organization %3A  Princeton University %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 18 %3A 53 %3A 26 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A I was looking at the amps diagram for Sony 1090/2090 receivers, and I %0A was amazed to find a difference between the US and Canadian model %0A on the capacitor(s) that hangs off the output to the speakers %3A  %0A  %0A                          ------\/\/\----- to speaker (identical both models %0A from amp ---------------%7C %0A (idnetical both models) > %0A                         <  10  %0A                         > %0A                         %7C %0A                        -----                         %0A                       %7C     %7C                         %0A         0.022        ---   ---        Canadian model only! %0A      US model        ---   --- 0.047  %0A      and world-wide   %7C     %7C %0A      model only.      %7C    ---        Candian model only! %0A                       %7C    ---  0.047 %0A                       %7C     %7C %0A                        ----------- gound %0A  %0A The board itself is also identical, with room for all three caps. The %0A US/Can versions is clearly indicated in both places. %0A  %0A How does that make sense? 0.047/2 is 0.0235, essentially 0.022 for caps %0A (there are just standard caps, no special W/type/precision).  %0A  %0A Please explain this %0A  Michael Golan %0A  mg %40 cs.princeton.edu %0A

doc_2293 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Moonbase race %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5x9Hr.92F %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 05 %3A 49 %3A 01 GMT %0A References %3A  <1r6rn3INNn96 %40 mojo.eng.umd.edu> <3HgF3B3w165w %40 shakala.com> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A  %0A In article <3HgF3B3w165w %40 shakala.com> dante %40 shakala.com (Charlie Prael) writes %3A  %0A >Doug-- Actually, if memory serves, the Atlas is an outgrowth of the old  %0A >Titan ICBM... %0A  %0A Nope, you're confusing separate programs.  Atlas was the first-generation %0A US ICBM; Titan I was the second-generation one; Titan II, which all the %0A Titan launchers are based on, was the third-generation heavy ICBM.  There %0A was essentially nothing in common between these three programs. %0A  %0A (Yes, *three* programs.  Despite the similarity of names, Titan I and %0A Titan II were completely different missiles.  They didn't even use the %0A same fuels, never mind the same launch facilities.) %0A  %0A >If so, there's probably quite a few old pads, albeit in need  %0A >of some serious reconditioning.  Still, Being able to buy the turf and  %0A >pad (and bunkers, including prep facility) at Midwest farmland prices  %0A >strikes me as pretty damned cheap. %0A  %0A Sorry, the Titan silos (a) can't handle the Titan launchers with their %0A large SRBs, (b) can't handle *any* sort of launcher without massive %0A violations of normal range-safety rules (nobody cares about such things %0A in the event of a nuclear war, but in peacetime they matter), and (c) were %0A scrapped years ago. %0A

doc_2297 |@raw_text From %3A  wagner %40 mala.bc.ca (TOM WAGNER, Wizzard of old Audio/Visual Equipment........Nanaimo Campus) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Suggestions  on Audio relays ??? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.102756.1709 %40 mala.bc.ca> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 10 %3A 27 %3A 55 -0700 %0A References %3A  <C5qsBF.IEK %40 ms.uky.edu> <C5r60r.4ID %40 megatest.com> %0A Organization %3A  Malaspina College %0A Lines %3A  63 %0A  %0A In article <C5r60r.4ID %40 megatest.com>, alung %40 megatest.com (Aaron Lung) writes %3A  %0A > In article <C5qsBF.IEK %40 ms.uky.edu> billq %40 ms.uky.edu (Billy Quinn) writes %3A  %0A >>I built a little project using the radio shack 5vdc relays to switch %0A >>audio.  I got pretty bad 'clicks' when the thing switched.  I was doing %0A >>most of the common things one is supposed to do when using relays and %0A >>nothing seemed to get rid of the clicks. %0A >> %0A >> %0A >>My question is %3A  %0A >> %0A >>	Is there a good relay/relay circuit that I can use for switching %0A >>audio, so that there will be *NO* noise of any kind on the audio lines. %0A >> %0A >> %0A >>I will appreciate any advice or references to advice.  Also, exact part %0A >>numbers/company names etc. for the relays will help! %0A >  %0A > Are you switching high level signals or low level signals like pre-amp %0A > out level signals?  Also, are the clicks you mentioning the big %0A > clack that happens when it switches or are you refering to contact %0A > bounce?  How are you driving the relays?  TTL gate output?  Switching %0A > transistor?  How are the relays connected to what you are driving? %0A >  %0A > Need more specifics to answer your question!!  %3A -) %0A  %0A As a general rule, no relay will cleanly switch audio if you try to tranfer %0A the circuit with the contacts.  The noise you hear is due to the momentary %0A opening and closing of the path. %0A  %0A The noiseless way of transfering audio is to ground the circuit.  In high %0A impedance audio circuits a resistive "T" is constructed close to characteristic %0A impedance of the circuit.  Grounding the imputs (connected to the T) transfers %0A the audio. %0A  %0A In low impedance circuits transformers are usually used, and the inputs are %0A shorted out or grounded.  Secondaries are paralleled at the characteristic %0A impedance. %0A  %0A Sometimes if it is necessary to actually switch audio, a second contact is used %0A to momentarily short the circuit output for the duration of the switching time. %0A  %0A Telephone relays are handy, because contacts can be adjusted to "Make before %0A break and Vica Versa" but I haven't seen any of these for years. %0A  %0A Nowadys switching is done electronically with OP amps, etc. %0A  %0A A novel circuit I used to build was a primitive "optical isolator".. It consists %0A of a resistive photocell and a lamp, all packaged in a tube.  When the lamp is %0A off the cell is high resistance.  Turn the lamp on and the resistance lowers %0A passing the audio.  Once again this device in a "T" switches the audio.  Varying %0A the lamp resistance give a remote volume control.  Use 2 variable resisters and %0A you have a mixer! %0A  %0A Lots of luck! %0A --  %0A 73, Tom %0A ================================================================================ %0A Tom Wagner, Audio Visual Technician.  Malaspina College Nanaimo British Columbia %0A (604)753-3245, Loc 2230  Fax %3A 755-8742  Callsign %3A VE7GDA Weapon %3A .45 Kentucky Rifle %0A Snail mail to %3A   Site Q4, C2.   RR#4, Nanaimo, British Columbia, Canada, V9R 5X9   %0A  %0A I do not recyle.....   I keep everything!       (All standard disclaimers apply) %0A ================================================================================ %0A

doc_2305 |@raw_text From %3A  sasrer %40 unx.sas.com (Rodney Radford) %0A Subject %3A  WD-40 as moisture repellant (was Lead Acid batteries & Concrete?) %0A Sender %3A  news %40 unx.sas.com (Noter of Newsworthy Events) %0A Message-ID %3A  <sasrer.735576383 %40 cinnamon> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 14 %3A 46 %3A 23 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr21.204556.21262 %40 cronkite.ocis.temple.edu> <1993Apr22.220549.26828 %40 dmu.ac.uk> <1993Apr23.115031.6151 %40 titan.inmos.co.uk> %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  cinnamon.unx.sas.com %0A Organization %3A  SAS Institute Inc. %0A Lines %3A  31 %0A  %0A stephen %40 dogmatix.inmos.co.uk (Stephen Collyer) writes %3A  %0A >%7C> The same thing happens to my car (Citroen 2CV) -- damp gets under the %0A >%7C> bonnet (US %3A  "hood") and shorts the spark-plugs to earth so it won't start. %0A >%7C>  %0A >%7C> The solution (for the car) is to clean the plug leads and spray with %0A >%7C> WD-40 (moisture repellant).  If damp *is* the problem, then storing the  %0A  %0A >Well, this is off-topic, but back in the days when I used to drive bangers %0A >I never found WD-40 to do anything that wiping with a dry cloth did'nt do. %0A >I think the effectiveness of WD-40 is a myth invented by the guy who owns %0A >the company. %0A  %0A Back in high school I used to work for a detailing company, and one of the %0A services we offered was an engine cleaning (remove all that oil BEFORE you %0A sell the car...  ;-}). Unfortunately, we did not have a high pressure %0A washer so we would use one several miles from the shop. On more than one %0A occasion after washing the engine, it would not start as water would have %0A gotten under the distributor (I would put a plastic bag around it to try and %0A minimize this), around the spark plug wires, etc and it would be nearly %0A IMPOSSIBLE to try and wipe all these areas down with a dry rag. The usual %0A solution was to carry a can of WD-40, and when the car wouldn't start to spray %0A all the likely areas and it would then start on the very first time. %0A  %0A It may be a myth, but it certainly kept me from being stranded at a car wash... %0A  %0A -- %0A --- %0A Rodney Radford          %7C%7C Computer Graphics/Imaging %0A sasrer %40 unx.sas.com      %7C%7C SAS Institute, Inc. %0A (919) 677-8000 x7703    %7C%7C Cary, NC  27513 %0A  %0A  
doc_2306 |@raw_text From %3A  ryan_cousineau %40 compdyn.questor.org (Ryan Cousineau)  %0A Subject %3A  Spagthorpe Viking %0A Message-ID %3A  <10499.97.uupcb %40 compdyn.questor.org> %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 93 19 %3A 04 %3A 00 GMT %0A Reply-To %3A  ryan_cousineau %40 compdyn.questor.org (Ryan Cousineau)  %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  Computer Dynamics-Vancouver B.C.-(604)986-9937 (604)255-9937 %0A Lines %3A  103 %0A  %0A DS>From %3A  viking %40 iastate.edu (Dan Sorenson) %0A  %0A DS>ryan_cousineau %40 compdyn.questor.org (Ryan Cousineau)  writes %3A  %0A  %0A DS>>Riding up the hill leading to my %0A DS>>house, I encountered a liver-and-white Springer Spaniel (no relation to %0A DS>>the Springer Softail, or the Springer Spagthorpe, a close relation to %0A DS>>the Spagthorpe Viking). %0A  %0A DS>        I must have missed the article on the Spagthorpe Viking.  Was %0A DS>that the one with the little illuminated Dragon's Head on the front %0A DS>fender, a style later copied by Indian, and the round side covers? %0A  %0A No. Not at all. The Viking was a trick little unit made way back when %0A (forties? fifties?) when Spag was trying to make a go of it in racing. %0A The first iteration (the Springer) was a boxer twin, very similar to Max %0A Friz's famous design, but with an overhead "point cam" (see below for %0A more on the valvetrain). The problem was that the thing had no ground %0A clearance whatsoever. The solution was to curve the cylinder bores, so %0A that the ground clearance was substantially increased %3A  %0A  %0A  %0A       == %40 ==   <-Springer motor (front) %0A                  Viking motor (front) ->   \= %40 =/ %0A  %0A This is roughly the idea, except that the bores were gradually curved %0A around a radius, as the pistons were loath to make a sharp-angled turn %0A in the middle of their stroke. The engine also had curved connecting %0A rods to accomodate the stroke. %0A  %0A The engine stuck out so far because of its revolutionary (and still %0A unique) overhead cam system. Through the use of clever valve timing and %0A and extrordinarily trick valve linkage, only a single cam lobe was %0A required to drive both overhead valves. %0A  %0A Just as revolutionary was the hydraulic valve actuation, which used a %0A pressurized stream of oil to power the "waterwheel" which kept the lobe %0A spinning over. One side effect that required some rather brutal %0A engineering fixes was that until the engine's oil pressure came up to %0A normal, the engine's valve timing would be more or less random, %0A resulting in some impressive start-up valve damage. The solution was a %0A little hand crank that pressurized the cases before you started the %0A beast, remarkably similar to the system used in new Porsches to %0A pressurize the oil system before the car is started (the cage, however, %0A uses an electric oil pump. Wimps). %0A  %0A Despite this fix, the engine had a nasty propensity for explosively %0A firing its valves into the pistons when a cylinder would temporarily %0A lose a bit of oil pressure in a corner. The solution was to run even %0A higher oil pressures and change the gaskets and seals regularly. This %0A was feasible because it was a racing engine. %0A  %0A With just a single overhead lobe, and no pushrod/shaft/chain towers %0A because of the hydraulic system, the head of the engine came to an %0A almost perfect point %3A  %0A  %0A                     /\ %0A                    /()\   <-lobe %0A                   / XX \  <-complex linkage (not shown due to %0A  valvestems ->   / \  / \    complexity) %0A                 %7C  %7C   %7C %7C %0A                 %7C  %7C===%7C %7C %0A                     =0=  <---piston %0A                      %7C %0A                              Note that the tip was not truly vertical %0A                              (it was at about a 70 degree angle to the %0A                              ground, and this drawing doesn't show the %0A                              curvature because there was none in the %0A                              head itself. The bore curve would start %0A                              about where the cylinder bore disappears in %0A                              this diagram %0A  %0A  %0A The effect of the pointy heads on top of a pair of gently (pundits of %0A the day even said sensuously) curved cylinders was much like a pair of %0A finned Viking horns poking out from beneath the gas tank. Thus, the %0A name. %0A  %0A The Vik was a moderately successful racer, lightning fast when it %0A worked, but plagued by problems relating to its revolutionary %0A technology. Eventually, it was dumped when Spag finally realized that %0A racing was not where the Spagthorpe name would be made. The machines %0A were raced for another year or two by privateers, and their fate %0A (approximately six Vikings were made, plus one or possibly two %0A Springers. Confusing the issue is one old Spag staffer who swears up and %0A down that this machine was tooled for production, and that as many as %0A twenty or thirty machines may have come off the line. However, no modern %0A record of a production Viking has survived, and most motorcycle %0A historians discount this story. %0A  %0A Ryan Cousinetc.%7C1982 Yamaha Vision XZ550 -Black Pig of Inverness%7CLive to Ride %0A KotRB          %7C1958 AJS 500 C/S -King Rat                      %7Cto Work to %0A DoD# 0863      %7CI'd be a squid if I could afford the bike...    %7CFlame to %0A ryan.cousineau %40 compdyn.questor.org  %7C   Vancouver, BC, Canada   %7CLive . . . %0A  %0A  %0A  * SLMR 2.1a * If you aren't sliding, you aren't riding. %0A                                                                                                            %0A ---- %0A +===============================================================+ %0A %7CCOMPUTER DYNAMICS BBS    604-255-9937(HST)    604-986-9937(V32)%7C %0A %7CVancouver, BC, Canada -  Easy Access, Low Rates, Friendly Sysop%7C %0A +===============================================================+ %0A  
doc_2314 |@raw_text From %3A  rmugele %40 oracle.com (Robert Mugele) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to act in front of traffic jerks %0A Message-ID %3A  <RMUGELE.93Apr15135857 %40 oasun1.oracle.com> %0A Date %3A  15 Apr 93 21 %3A 58 %3A 57 GMT %0A References %3A  <nielsmm-150493114522 %40 nanna.imv.aau.dk> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 oracle.us.oracle.com (Oracle News Poster) %0A Followup-To %3A  rec.motorcycles %0A Organization %3A  Oracle Corporation, Belmont, CA %0A Lines %3A  21 %0A In-Reply-To %3A  nielsmm %40 imv.aau.dk's message of 15 Apr 93 08 %3A 54 %3A 34 GMT %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  oasun1.us.oracle.com %0A X-Disclaimer %3A  This message was written by an unauthenticated user %0A               at Oracle Corporation.  The opinions expressed are those %0A               of the user and not necessarily those of Oracle. %0A  %0A In article <nielsmm-150493114522 %40 nanna.imv.aau.dk> nielsmm %40 imv.aau.dk (Niels Mikkel Michelsen) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >   The other day, it was raining cats and dogs, therefor I was going only to %0A >   the speed limit, on nothing more, on my bike. This guy in his BMW was %0A >   driving 1-2 meters behind me for 7-800 meters and at the next red light I %0A >   calmly put the bike on its leg, walked back to this car, he rolled down the %0A >   window, and I told him he was a total idiot (and the reason why). %0A > %0A >   Did I do the right thing? %0A  %0A Absolutely, unless you are in the U.S.  Then the cager will pull a gun %0A and blow you away. %0A  %0A ================================================================== %0A %7C Bob Mugele  (Jungle Bob)      %7C Email %3A  rmugele %40 oracle.com      %7C %0A %7C Senior Computational Linguist %7C Phone %3A  214-401-5875            %7C %0A %7C Oracle Corp.                  %7C Moto %3A  '81 GS450ES '87 Concours %7C %0A %7C Irving, Texas                 %7C DoD# %3A  283                      %7C %0A %7C    If vegetarians eat vegetables, beware of the humanitarians  %7C %0A %7C          --Dr. Bob                                             %7C %0A ================================================================== %0A  
doc_2318 |@raw_text From %3A  johnh %40 macadam.mpce.mq.edu.au (John Haddy) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Help with ultra-long timing %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 1993 00 %3A 52 %3A 59 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Macquarie University %0A Lines %3A  60 %0A Sender %3A  johnh %40 macadam (John Haddy) %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1pqk9b$ib4 %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A References %3A  <1993Apr5.083324.48826 %40 kuhub.cc.ukans.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  macadam.mpce.mq.edu.au %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr5.083324.48826 %40 kuhub.cc.ukans.edu>, wellison %40 kuhub.cc.ukans.edu writes %3A  %0A %7C> I have a project that was drooped in my lap that is somewhat a pain to design. %0A %7C> What I am looking for is a stable ultra-long solid state timer. What they want %0A %7C> to do is to place this thing on the Antartic ice shelf and measure the amount %0A %7C> of snow fall over a period of six weeks. Every two weeks, they want to trip a %0A %7C> selonoid to discharge different colored pellets by gas pressure out across the %0A %7C> snow. Then by digging down into the snow, the snow fall amount can be measured %0A %7C> as they come to the different color pellets. %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> The problem is trying to build a timer that would stand the cold (-40 degrees) %0A %7C> and a power source that wouldn't drain. I have looked at the XR-2204 timers and %0A %7C> the standard NE556 dual timers, but thier temp specs won't go that low. Also, %0A %7C> two weeks equates to 1,209,600 seconds per firing, which means one big timing %0A %7C> cap ! I have found 2.2 farad (yes, Farad !) caps that have a working voltage of %0A %7C> 5 volts and are small in size. But again, the time of discharge at -40 or lower %0A %7C> degrees isn't linear. I was thinking of using several timers chained together  %0A %7C> to fire the selonid at the end of the timing period, but that blasted cold and %0A %7C> the drain on a battery over six weeks is the pain. One possibility would be to %0A %7C> use solar panels, but this is during the six month twilight. Anyone have any %0A %7C> good ideas ? %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> Thanks in advance... %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> -=-= Wes =-=- %0A  %0A Firstly, I would never consider trying to make a one-shot timer. Your 2F2 cap %0A will have been designed as a RAM battery substitute, rather than for use in %0A applications where you wish to drain the cap with a constant current. Their %0A performance, in some respects, is more akin to batteries than to a normal cap. %0A The other point is that big electro's are usually rated with -5%+20% tolerances, %0A so calculating exactly what capacitance you have (particularly when considering %0A the cold). %0A  %0A You should be looking at designing a micropower oscillator and divider chain, %0A that "rolls over" (from zero to maximum count, or vice-versa) once every %0A 1,209,600 seconds. If you were to use something like a 110Hz clock, you would %0A need a divider chain of 2^27, to give an error of less than one percent in the %0A firing times over the six week period. Of course, you could trim the 110Hz %0A oscillator to give you exact time, but the likelyhood of the oscillator %0A remaining exactly constant at -40 is low anyway. %0A  %0A I would suspect that there would be far more battrey drain in firing the %0A solenoid than there would be in the timer circuit. %0A  %0A Caveat - I'm not experienced in low temperature electronics, so I can't %0A guarantee that this (or any other) approach is the best for inhospitable %0A conditions. %0A  %0A JohnH %0A  %0A ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A       %7C  _  %7C_   _   %7C_%7C  _   _%7C  _%7C              Electronics Department %0A     %7C_%7C (_) %7C %7C %7C %7C  %7C %7C (_%7C (_%7C (_%7C \/           School of MPCE %0A     ---------------------------------/-           Macquarie University %0A                                                   Sydney, AUSTRALIA 2109 %0A  %0A     Email %3A  johnh %40 mpce.mq.edu.au, Ph %3A  +61 2 805 8959, Fax %3A  +61 2 805 8983 %0A  %0A ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  
doc_2321 |@raw_text From %3A  maven %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com (Norman Hamer) %0A Sender %3A  gateway %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com %0A Subject %3A  Good Reasons to Wave at each other %0A Message-ID %3A  <222834 %40 mavenry.altcit.eskimo.com> %0A X-AltNet-ID %3A  222834 %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 93 15 %3A 36 %3A 34 GMT %0A Lines %3A  11 %0A  %0A   %0A  One of those "morning, just getting the coffee in me" thoughts %3A  %0A   %0A  Waving at other bikers makes more sense than just "Hey, how's it going,  %0A nice to meet you on the road, have a good ride" %0A   %0A  1) If you're watching for other bikes to wave to, it means your attention  %0A is on the road, where it should be, and you're more likely to see cages. %0A   %0A  2) It keeps you in the habit of watching really carefully for bikes when  %0A you're IN a cage. This is a Good Thing.  %0A

Let me trt to explain again... %0A  %0A Look for information about 567 tone decoder chip. It is an easy to use %0A chip for detecting sound of certain frequency. You need only one %0A 567 and some other componets for each led you want to control. %0A The chip can take the voltage levels, which the casette gives. %0A Radio Shack Archer Semiconductor Reference Guide gives good information %0A how to use that chip. It should be simplest way to go. The chip costs %0A something like 1-2 $. %0A -- %0A Tomi.Engdahl %40 hut.fi  !  LOWERY'S LAW %3A  %0A then %40 niksula.hut.fi  !  "If it jams - force it. doc_2353 |@raw_text From %3A  leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech) %0A Subject %3A  Space FAQ 06/15 - Constants and Equations %0A Keywords %3A  Frequently Asked Questions %0A Message-ID %3A  <constants_733694246 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Date %3A  1 Apr 93 09 %3A 57 %3A 28 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  cs.constants_733694246 %0A Expires %3A  6 May 1993 19 %3A 57 %3A 26 GMT %0A References %3A  <diffs_733693816 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill %0A Lines %3A  189 %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Supersedes %3A  <constants_730956482 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mahler.cs.unc.edu %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  space/constants %0A Last-modified %3A  $Date %3A  93/04/01 14 %3A 39 %3A 04 $ %0A  %0A CONSTANTS AND EQUATIONS FOR CALCULATIONS %0A  %0A     This list was originally compiled by Dale Greer. Additions would be %0A     appreciated. %0A  %0A     Numbers in parentheses are approximations that will serve for most %0A     blue-skying purposes. %0A  %0A     Unix systems provide the 'units' program, useful in converting %0A     between different systems (metric/English, etc.) %0A  %0A     NUMBERS %0A  %0A 	7726 m/s	 (8000)  -- Earth orbital velocity at 300 km altitude %0A 	3075 m/s	 (3000)  -- Earth orbital velocity at 35786 km (geosync) %0A 	6371 km		 (6400)  -- Mean radius of Earth %0A 	6378 km		 (6400)  -- Equatorial radius of Earth %0A 	1738 km		 (1700)  -- Mean radius of Moon %0A 	5.974e24 kg	 (6e24)  -- Mass of Earth %0A 	7.348e22 kg	 (7e22)  -- Mass of Moon %0A 	1.989e30 kg	 (2e30)  -- Mass of Sun %0A 	3.986e14 m^3/s^2 (4e14)  -- Gravitational constant times mass of Earth %0A 	4.903e12 m^3/s^2 (5e12)  -- Gravitational constant times mass of Moon %0A 	1.327e20 m^3/s^2 (13e19) -- Gravitational constant times mass of Sun %0A 	384401 km	 ( 4e5)  -- Mean Earth-Moon distance %0A 	1.496e11 m	 (15e10) -- Mean Earth-Sun distance (Astronomical Unit) %0A  %0A 	1 megaton (MT) TNT = about 4.2e15 J or the energy equivalent of %0A 	about .05 kg (50 gm) of matter. Ref %3A  J.R Williams, "The Energy Level %0A 	of Things", Air Force Special Weapons Center (ARDC), Kirtland Air %0A 	Force Base, New Mexico, 1963. Also see "The Effects of Nuclear %0A 	Weapons", compiled by S. Glasstone and P.J. Dolan, published by the %0A 	US Department of Defense (obtain from the GPO). %0A  %0A     EQUATIONS %0A  %0A 	Where d is distance, v is velocity, a is acceleration, t is time. %0A 	Additional more specialized equations are available from %3A  %0A  %0A 	    ames.arc.nasa.gov %3A pub/SPACE/FAQ/MoreEquations %0A  %0A  %0A 	For constant acceleration %0A 	    d = d0 + vt + .5at^2 %0A 	    v = v0 + at %0A 	  v^2 = 2ad %0A  %0A 	Acceleration on a cylinder (space colony, etc.) of radius r and %0A 	    rotation period t %3A  %0A  %0A 	    a = 4 pi**2 r / t^2 %0A  %0A 	For circular Keplerian orbits where %3A  %0A 	    Vc	 = velocity of a circular orbit %0A 	    Vesc = escape velocity %0A 	    M	 = Total mass of orbiting and orbited bodies %0A 	    G	 = Gravitational constant (defined below) %0A 	    u	 = G * M (can be measured much more accurately than G or M) %0A 	    K	 = -G * M / 2 / a %0A 	    r	 = radius of orbit (measured from center of mass of system) %0A 	    V	 = orbital velocity %0A 	    P	 = orbital period %0A 	    a	 = semimajor axis of orbit %0A  %0A 	    Vc	 = sqrt(M * G / r) %0A 	    Vesc = sqrt(2 * M * G / r) = sqrt(2) * Vc %0A 	    V^2  = u/a %0A 	    P	 = 2 pi/(Sqrt(u/a^3)) %0A 	    K	 = 1/2 V**2 - G * M / r (conservation of energy) %0A  %0A 	    The period of an eccentric orbit is the same as the period %0A 	       of a circular orbit with the same semi-major axis. %0A  %0A 	Change in velocity required for a plane change of angle phi in a %0A 	circular orbit %3A  %0A  %0A 	    delta V = 2 sqrt(GM/r) sin (phi/2) %0A  %0A 	Energy to put mass m into a circular orbit (ignores rotational %0A 	velocity, which reduces the energy a bit). %0A  %0A 	    GMm (1/Re - 1/2Rcirc) %0A 	    Re = radius of the earth %0A 	    Rcirc = radius of the circular orbit. %0A  %0A 	Classical rocket equation, where %0A 	    dv	= change in velocity %0A 	    Isp = specific impulse of engine %0A 	    Ve	= exhaust velocity %0A 	    x	= reaction mass %0A 	    m1	= rocket mass excluding reaction mass %0A 	    g	= 9.80665 m / s^2 %0A  %0A 	    Ve	= Isp * g %0A 	    dv	= Ve * ln((m1 + x) / m1) %0A 		= Ve * ln((final mass) / (initial mass)) %0A  %0A 	Relativistic rocket equation (constant acceleration) %0A  %0A 	    t (unaccelerated) = c/a * sinh(a*t/c) %0A 	    d = c**2/a * (cosh(a*t/c) - 1) %0A 	    v = c * tanh(a*t/c) %0A  %0A 	Relativistic rocket with exhaust velocity Ve and mass ratio MR %3A  %0A  %0A 	    at/c = Ve/c * ln(MR), or %0A  %0A 	    t (unaccelerated) = c/a * sinh(Ve/c * ln(MR)) %0A 	    d = c**2/a * (cosh(Ve/C * ln(MR)) - 1) %0A 	    v = c * tanh(Ve/C * ln(MR)) %0A  %0A 	Converting from parallax to distance %3A  %0A  %0A 	    d (in parsecs) = 1 / p (in arc seconds) %0A 	    d (in astronomical units) = 206265 / p %0A  %0A 	Miscellaneous %0A 	    f=ma    -- Force is mass times acceleration %0A 	    w=fd    -- Work (energy) is force times distance %0A  %0A 	Atmospheric density varies as exp(-mgz/kT) where z is altitude, m is %0A 	molecular weight in kg of air, g is local acceleration of gravity, T %0A 	is temperature, k is Bolztmann's constant. On Earth up to 100 km, %0A  %0A 	    d = d0*exp(-z*1.42e-4) %0A  %0A 	where d is density, d0 is density at 0km, is approximately true, so %0A  %0A 	    d %40 12km (40000 ft) = d0*.18 %0A 	    d %40 9 km (30000 ft) = d0*.27 %0A 	    d %40 6 km (20000 ft) = d0*.43 %0A 	    d %40 3 km (10000 ft) = d0*.65 %0A  %0A 		    Atmospheric scale height	Dry lapse rate %0A 		    (in km at emission level)	 (K/km) %0A 		    -------------------------	-------------- %0A 	    Earth	    7.5			    9.8 %0A 	    Mars	    11			    4.4 %0A 	    Venus	    4.9			    10.5 %0A 	    Titan	    18			    1.3 %0A 	    Jupiter	    19			    2.0 %0A 	    Saturn	    37			    0.7 %0A 	    Uranus	    24			    0.7 %0A 	    Neptune	    21			    0.8 %0A 	    Triton	    8			    1 %0A  %0A 	Titius-Bode Law for approximating planetary distances %3A  %0A  %0A 	    R(n) = 0.4 + 0.3 * 2^N Astronomical Units (N = -infinity for %0A 	    Mercury, 0 for Venus, 1 for Earth, etc.) %0A  %0A 	    This fits fairly well except for Neptune. %0A  %0A     CONSTANTS %0A  %0A 	6.62618e-34 J-s  (7e-34) -- Planck's Constant "h" %0A 	1.054589e-34 J-s (1e-34) -- Planck's Constant / (2 * PI), "h bar" %0A 	1.3807e-23 J/K	(1.4e-23) - Boltzmann's Constant "k" %0A 	5.6697e-8 W/m^2/K (6e-8) -- Stephan-Boltzmann Constant "sigma" %0A     6.673e-11 N m^2/kg^2 (7e-11) -- Newton's Gravitational Constant "G" %0A 	0.0029 m K	 (3e-3)  -- Wien's Constant "sigma(W)" %0A 	3.827e26 W	 (4e26)  -- Luminosity of Sun %0A 	1370 W / m^2	 (1400)  -- Solar Constant (intensity at 1 AU) %0A 	6.96e8 m	 (7e8)	 -- radius of Sun %0A 	1738 km		 (2e3)	 -- radius of Moon %0A 	299792458 m/s	  (3e8)  -- speed of light in vacuum "c" %0A 	9.46053e15 m	  (1e16) -- light year %0A 	206264.806 AU	  (2e5)  -- \ %0A 	3.2616 light years (3)	 --  --> parsec %0A 	3.0856e16 m	 (3e16)  -- / %0A  %0A  %0A Black Hole radius (also called Schwarzschild Radius) %3A  %0A  %0A 	2GM/c^2, where G is Newton's Grav Constant, M is mass of BH, %0A 		c is speed of light %0A  %0A     Things to add (somebody look them up!) %0A 	Basic rocketry numbers & equations %0A 	Aerodynamical stuff %0A 	Energy to put a pound into orbit or accelerate to interstellar %0A 	    velocities. %0A 	Non-circular cases? %0A  %0A  %0A NEXT %3A  FAQ #7/15 - Astronomical Mnemonics %0A

doc_2357 |@raw_text From %3A  wa2ise %40 cbnewsb.cb.att.com (robert.f.casey) %0A Subject %3A  2 level brightness Xmas light set (for Easter? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr6.023827.6628 %40 cbfsb.cb.att.com> %0A Keywords %3A  xmas %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cbfsb.cb.att.com %0A Organization %3A  AT&T %0A Date %3A  Tue, 6 Apr 1993 02 %3A 38 %3A 27 GMT %0A Lines %3A  54 %0A  %0A  %0A Yes, I know it's nowhere near Christmas time, but I'm gonna loose %0A Net access in a few days (maybe a week or 2 if I'm lucky), and wanted %0A to post this for interested people to save 'till Xmas.    %3A -( %0A Note %3A  Bell Labs is a good place IF you have a PhD and a good boss, I %0A have neither. %0A -------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A Subject %3A  Xmas light set with 2 levels of brightness %0A  %0A Another version of a variable brightness Xmas light set %3A  %0A This set starts with a 2 blinker 35 bulb string.   %0A  %0A DIAGRAM %3A   orginal 2 way set %0A  %0A 120v---+--b-*-*-*-*-*-*-*--! %0A        !---b-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-! %0A                            ! %0A 120rtn_____________________! %0A  %0A modified set for 2 level brightness %3A  %0A  %0A                 string 1 %0A 120v---------*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*--! %0A   \_10K_______*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-! %0A     5w    !      string 2     ! %0A           b   ________________! %0A 120v rtn__!___! %0A  %0A              ^ Note %3A  no mods to wiring to the right of this point. %0A  %0A Only one blinker is used. %0A  %0A Note that the blinker would not have as much current thru it as the %0A string 1 bulbs, because of the second string of bulbs in %0A parallel with it.  That's why the use of the 10K 5W resistor %0A here to add extra current thru the blinker to make up for the %0A current shunted thru the second string while the blinker is glowing %0A and the second string is not glowing.  When the blinker goes open, %0A this resistor has only a slight effect on the brightness of the %0A strings, s1 slightly dimmer, s2 slightly brighter.   %0A Or use a 3W 120v bulb in place of the 10K resistor if you can get %0A one.  Caution, do not replace with a standard C9 bulb, as these %0A draw too much current and burn out the blinker.  C9 = approx 7W. %0A  %0A What you'll see when it's working %3A   powerup, string 1 will light  %0A at full brightness, and b will be lit, bypassing most of the current  %0A from the second string, making them not light.  b will open, placing  %0A both strings in series, making the string that was out to glow at a  %0A low brightness, and the other string that was on before to glow  %0A at reduced brightness.  %0A  %0A Be sure to wire and insulate the splices, resistor leads, and cut wires  %0A in a safe manner! %0A

I always worry more when %0A I'm in the lane, at the front of the line, and no one in behind me. Then you %0A have to keep an eye on your mirrors. doc_2364 |@raw_text From %3A  hrubin %40 pop.stat.purdue.edu (Herman Rubin) %0A Subject %3A  U.S. Government and Science and Technolgy Investment %0A Message-ID %3A  <C6Exsu.59K %40 mentor.cc.purdue.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mentor.cc.purdue.edu (USENET News) %0A Organization %3A  Purdue University Statistics Department %0A References %3A  <1993Apr30.151033.13776 %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 2 May 1993 18 %3A 53 %3A 18 GMT %0A Lines %3A  75 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr30.151033.13776 %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov> kjenks %40 gothamcity.jsc.nasa.gov writes %3A  %0A >People who criticize "big Government" and its projects rarely seem to %0A >have a consistent view of the role of Government in science and %0A >technology.  Basically, the U.S. Government has gotten into the role of %0A >supporting research which private industry finds too expensive or too %0A >long-term.   %0A  %0A >(Historically, this role for the U.S. Gov't was forced upon it because %0A >of socialism in other countries.  In order for U.S.  industries to %0A >compete with government-subsidized foreign competitors, the U.S. Gov't %0A >has taken on the role of subisizing big-ticket or long-lead R&D.) %0A  %0A This definitely had nothing to do with the entry of the government into %0A the support of science; some of it is relevant in technology.  There %0A was little involvement of federal funds, or except through support of %0A state universities, of state funds, for scientific research before WWII. %0A The US research position had been growing steadily, and the funding was %0A mainly from university and private foundation funds.  There were not that %0A many research universities, but they all provided their researchers with %0A low teaching loads, laboratories, assistants, and equipment, and funds for %0A travel to scientific meetings.  Not that much, but it was provided, and a %0A university wishing to get a scholar had to consider research funding as well %0A as salary. %0A  %0A During WWII, the military and the defense departments found that pure %0A scientists could do quite well with their problems, even though they  %0A were not exactly in the areas of the scientists' expertise.  This is %0A probably because of the "research mind" approach, which is not to try %0A to find a solution, but to understand the problem and see if a solution %0A emerges.  This works in stages, and as research scientists were used to %0A discussion about their problems, the job got done. %0A  %0A The military realized the importance of maintaining scientists for the %0A future, and started funding pure research after WWII.  But Congress was %0A unwilling to have military funds diverted into this investment into the %0A future supply of scientists, and set up other organizations, such as  %0A NSF, to do the job.  It also set up an elaborate procedure to supposedly %0A keep politics out.  Also, the government did a job on private foundations, %0A making it more difficult for them to act to support research. %0A  %0A The worst part of the federal involvement is that in those areas in which %0A the government supports research the university will not provide funding, %0A and in fact expects its scholars to bring in net government money.  Suppose, %0A as has been the case, I have a project which could use the assistance of %0A a graduate student for a few months.  What do you think happens if I ask %0A for one?  The answer I will get is, "Get the money from NSF."  Now the %0A money at the university level is a few thousand, but at the NSF level it %0A comes to about 20 thousand, and is likely to keep a faculty member from %0A getting supported.  So the government is, in effect, deciding which projects %0A get supported, and how much.   %0A  %0A Also, the government decided that the "wealth" should be spread.  So instead %0A of having a moderate number of universities which were primarily research %0A institutions, the idea that more schools should get into the act came into %0A being.  And instead of evaluating scholars, they had to go to evaluating %0A reseach proposals.  As a researcher, I can tell you that any research proposal %0A has to be mainly wishful thinking, or as now happens, the investigator conceals %0A already done work to release it as the results of the research.  What I am %0A proposing today I may solve before the funding is granted, I may find  %0A impossible, or I may find that it is too difficult.  In addition, tomorrow %0A I may get unexpected research results.  Possibly I may bet a bright idea %0A which solves yesterday's too difficult problem, or a whole new approach to %0A something I had not considered can develop.  This is the nature of the beast,  %0A and except for really vague statements, if something can be predicted, it %0A is not major research, but development or routine activity not requiring  %0A more than minimal attention of a good researcher.   %0A  %0A I believe that at this time less quality research is being done than would %0A have happened if the government had never gotten into it, and the government %0A is trying to divert researchers from thinkers to plodders. %0A --  %0A Herman Rubin, Dept. of Statistics, Purdue Univ., West Lafayette IN47907-1399 %0A Phone %3A  (317)494-6054 %0A hrubin %40 snap.stat.purdue.edu (Internet, bitnet)   %0A {purdue,pur-ee}!snap.stat!hrubin(UUCP) %0A  
doc_2367 |@raw_text From %3A  amanda %40 intercon.com (Amanda Walker) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Once tapped, your code is no good any more. %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 11 %3A 18 %3A 47 -0500 %0A Organization %3A  InterCon Systems Corporation - Herndon, VA  USA %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qufsg$edt %40 news.intercon.com> %0A References %3A  <115863 %40 bu.edu> %0A Reply-To %3A  amanda %40 intercon.com (Amanda Walker) %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  chaos.intercon.com %0A X-Newsreader %3A  InterCon TCP/Connect II 1.1 %0A  %0A uni %40 acs.bu.edu (Shaen Bernhardt) writes %3A  %0A > I wish I could agree with you.  Ask yourself this.  Why would any  %0A > private sector entity wish to buy a crypto system that was KNOWN to be  %0A > at least partially compromised? %0A  %0A (a) To use for sensitive but not strategically important traffic, %0A (b) if the system was cheap. %0A  %0A For example, I don't own a cordless phone.  With Clipper, I would.  If the  %0A local men in blue really want to listen to me talk to my friends or order  %0A pizza, I'm no worse off than I am now, and I don't have to worry about %0A local kids or nosy neighbors. %0A  %0A That is to say, Clipper "raises the bar" on insecure channels.  It doesn't  %0A make them secure, by any means, but a wall, even if the FBI can get a master  %0A key by court order, is still better than a "keep off the grass" sign. %0A  %0A > The answer seems obvious to me, they wouldn't.  There is other hardware  %0A > out there not compromised.  DES as an example (triple DES as a better  %0A > one.)  %0A  %0A So, where can I buy a DES-encrypted cellular phone?  How much does it cost? %0A Personally, Cylink stuff is out of my budget for personal use  %3A )... %0A  %0A > How can you reconcile the administrations self proclaimed purpose of  %0A > providing law enforcement with access to encrypted data without making  %0A > the clipper system the only crypto available in the U.S... ? %0A  %0A The Second and Fourth Amendments do come to mind.   %0A  %0A  %0A Amanda Walker %0A InterCon Systems Corporation %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_2427 |@raw_text From %3A  brad %40 clarinet.com (Brad Templeton) %0A Subject %3A  Once tapped, your code is no good any more. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr17.032828.14262 %40 clarinet.com> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 03 %3A 28 %3A 28 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> <1qmugcINNpu9 %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  ClariNet Communications Corp. %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A It occurs to me that if they get a wiretap order on you, and the escrow %0A houses release your code to the cops, your code is now no longer secure. %0A  %0A It's in the hands of cops, and while I am sure most of the time they are %0A good, their security will not be as good as the escrow houses. %0A  %0A  %0A What this effectively means is that if they perform a wiretap on you, %0A at the end of the wiretap, they should be obligated to inform you that %0A a tap was performed, and replace (for free) the clipper chip in your %0A cellular phone so that it is once again a code known only to the %0A escrow houses. %0A  %0A Do the police normally reveal every tap they do even if no charges are %0A laid?   In many ways, it would be a positive step if they had to. %0A Judges set time limits on warrants, I assume.  At the end of the time %0A limit they should have to renew or replace your chip. %0A  %0A  %0A That's if we go with this scheme, which I am not sure I agree with. %0A --  %0A Brad Templeton, ClariNet Communications Corp. -- Sunnyvale, CA 408/296-0366 %0A

doc_2446 |@raw_text From %3A  vanderby %40 mprgate.mpr.ca (David Vanderbyl) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  mysterious TV problem -- source? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr15.204430.9793 %40 mprgate.mpr.ca> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mprgate.mpr.ca %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  chip %0A Reply-To %3A  vanderby %40 mprgate.mpr.ca (David Vanderbyl) %0A Organization %3A  MPR Teltech Ltd. %0A References %3A   <9304151511.AA06281 %40 deepthought.cs.utexas.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 15 Apr 1993 20 %3A 44 %3A 30 GMT %0A Lines %3A  30 %0A  %0A LLBGB %40 utxdp.dp.utexas.edu writes %3A  %0A >Initial symptoms %3A  %0A >-no picture or sound %0A >-CRT filament does NOT glow %0A >-flyback ticking as described abovew %0A  %0A >Discovered when hooked up the scope %3A  %0A >-IF strip is not putting out audio or video signals %0A >-everything is making simple 20-30 Hz pulses %0A >-horiz out transistor collector (case of the TO-3) is a 20-30 Hz downgoing %0A >  sawtooth with ca. 15kHz ring at front end %0A  %0A >guys, WHAT"S GOING ON HERE?  Anyone seen this before? %0A  %0A What is happening is this %3A  %0A 1) You turn the TV on. %0A 2) The horizontal output begins normal operation.  This powers up the %0A    high voltage and most of the rest of the circuitry. %0A 3) A problem is sensed and the horizontal oscillator shuts down. %0A 4) After it powers down the cycle repeats. %0A  %0A Things to check %3A  %0A First check for a shorted high power component.  Your best bet is the vertical %0A output transistor(s) or, if there is one, the voltage regulator.  The most %0A common cause of this type of failure is too much current being drawn %0A somewhere. %0A Also look for shutdown circuits (which your TV may or may not have), %0A if you can find one that is shutting down the horizontal oscillator %0A then it shouldn't be too hard to find the problem from there. %0A  %0A

doc_2459 |@raw_text From %3A  whit %40 carson.u.washington.edu (John Whitmore) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  A question about 120VAC outlet wiring.. %0A Keywords %3A  outlet %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qkm8iINN92t %40 shelley.u.washington.edu> %0A Date %3A  15 Apr 93 22 %3A 06 %3A 10 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  shelley.1qkm8iINN92t %0A References %3A  <1993Apr14.172145.27458 %40 ecsvax.uncecs.edu> <1993Apr14.193122.20818 %40 mprgate.mpr.ca> <1qids1INNebl %40 chnews.intel.com> %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  University of Washington, Seattle %0A Lines %3A  34 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  carson.u.washington.edu %0A  %0A In article <1qids1INNebl %40 chnews.intel.com> crichmon %40 sedona.intel.com (Chris Richmond) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >In article <1993Apr14.193122.20818 %40 mprgate.mpr.ca>, vanderby %40 mprgate.mpr.ca (David Vanderbyl) writes %3A  %0A >> In article <1993Apr14.172145.27458 %40 ecsvax.uncecs.edu>, crisp %40 ecsvax.uncecs.edu (Russ Crisp) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >> %7C> I'm considering modernizing some old wiring in my home, and %0A >> %7C> I need a little advice on outlet wiring.  Several outlets %0A >> %7C> are the old 'two prong' type, without the ground.  Naturally, %0A >> %7C> the wire feeding these outlets is 12/2, WITHOUT the ground %0A >> %7C> wire.  I noticed at the fusebox that some circuits have the %0A >> %7C> 12/2 with ground, and that on these circuits, the ground %0A >> %7C> wire was tied to the same bus as the neutral (white) wire. %0A  %0A >> This is contrary to the electrical code and should be fixed. %0A  %0A >Well, my house was built just last year, and the breaker box is wired the %0A >same way.   %0A  %0A 	There SHOULD be a connection of the GROUND wire to a ground %0A in the breaker box.  There also should be a connection of the NEUTRAL %0A wire to a ground in the breaker box.  There should be no other  %0A place in the building where such a connection occurs (i.e. not in %0A any of the outlet boxes). %0A  %0A 	The NEUTRAL (white) wire is a 'grounding conductor' for %0A the plug, and is NOT safe to touch, while the GROUND (green) %0A wire is a 'protective ground' and carries no current unless %0A some kind of electrical fault has occurred.  It's safe %0A to touch the protective ground, but not to touch the  %0A grounding conductor (because there is current in the grounding %0A conductor, its outlet-box end will not be at the same ground %0A potential as its breaker-box end). %0A  %0A 	John Whitmore %0A

Also, as implied by other posters, why  %0A >do you need to boost the orbit on this mission anyway? ... %0A  %0A You don't *need* to, but it's desirable.  HST, like all satellites in %0A low Earth orbit, is gradually losing altitude due to air drag.  It was %0A deployed in the highest orbit the shuttle could reach, for that reason. %0A It needs occasional reboosting or it will eventually reenter.  (It has %0A no propulsion system of its own.)  This is an excellent opportunity, %0A given that there may not be another visit for several years. %0A --  %0A SVR4 resembles a high-speed collision   %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A between SVR3 and SunOS.    - Dick Dunn  %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A
