doc_2498 |@raw_text From %3A  farenebt %40 craft.camp.clarkson.edu (Droopy) %0A Subject %3A  AHL Season in review (off ice stuff) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.001323.10308 %40 news.clarkson.edu> %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 93 00 %3A 13 %3A 23 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 news.clarkson.edu %0A Organization %3A  Clarkson University %0A Lines %3A  114 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  craft.clarkson.edu %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL8] %0A  %0A Here is a review of some of the off-ice things that have %0A affected the AHL this year. %0A  %0A  %0A ST JOHN'S MAPLE LEAFS PROBLEMS %0A The St John's Maple Leafs sophomore season has been plagued by %0A problems. On-ice, the Leafs won the Atlantic Division title but %0A off ice was less happy. A strike by public workers has forced the %0A leafs out of the Newfoundland city for much of the last half of %0A the seaosn (since mid-Jan). They have played "home" games in places %0A like Montreal, Cornwall and Charlottetown. Their playoff "home" %0A games will be played in the Metro Center in Halifax, NS. One %0A demostration got violent. Workers attacked a Leafs' bus and %0A rocked it and broke windows in the St John's Memorial Stadium. %0A Despite the problems, Toronto officials insist that the Leafs %0A will return to St John's once the strike ends. %0A =================================================== %0A SENATORS SOLD %0A The New Haven Senators have been sold by Peter Shipman to %0A the Ottawa Senators NHL organization. They are the only Canadian %0A NHL team with an American AHL affiliate, and have made it clear %0A they intend to move the team to somewhere in the Canadian Atlantic %0A Provinces. This sale and move has yet to be approved by the AHL %0A head office, but is expected to pass easily at the general meeting %0A in May. The quote in the story from Jack Butterfield made it  %0A clear the league was more interested in the stability of the  %0A AHL franchise accompanied by NHL ownership, rather than maintaining %0A the 56-year history of the AHL in New Haven.  %0A  %0A The Senators are currently in serious negotiations with Charlottetown %0A New Brunswick and are expected to move there. %0A ================================================== %0A DALLAS HELPS HAWKS STAY IN MONCTON %0A After announcing that they would pull their affiliation out %0A of Moncton, the Winnipeg Jets changed their mind.  %0A  %0A The Jets announced the move when they said that they would be slashing %0A their minor league roster from 20-something to around a dozen; and they %0A wanted to share with an existing AHL or IHL franchise. %0A  %0A Enter the Dallas Lone Stars. Dallas agreed to supply the remaining %0A 6 or 8 players to the Moncton franchise. Thus keeping the Hawks %0A in the New Brunswick city. %0A  %0A The deal is for one year and will be extended to three years if %0A the season ticket base increases to over 3000. The Hawks only sold %0A 1400 for this year. %0A ============================================================ %0A SAINT JOHN FLAMES OFFICIAL %0A The Calgary Flames have officially signed a deal with the city of %0A Saint John, NB. The Saint John Blue Flames will play in the 6200 %0A Exhibition Center. The Flames still have to apply for an expansion %0A frnachise from the AHL but are expected to have no trouble. %0A ========================================================= %0A CAPS FOLLOW JACKS TO MAINE %0A Despite rumors to the contrary, the Capitals will follow the Baltimore %0A Skipjacks to Maine. The Caps' current farm team, the Baltimore Skipjacks, %0A announced that they would move to Maine and become the Portland Pirates. %0A There was much doubt as to if the Caps would follow but they announced %0A a limited deal with Portland. They would supply a dozen or so players %0A including 2 goalies. They become the third team to announce a limited %0A farm team along with Moncton and the Capital District Islanders. %0A ====================================================== %0A AHL GAME OF THE WEEK %0A In early January, the AHL started a game of the week. The game, produced %0A by, I believe, Pyman Productions, was televised across the Canadian %0A Maritimes and northeastern US. The first few weeks saw two games of %0A the week, one in Canada and another in the US but since then, there %0A has been only one. Sunday afternoon and night games were covered and %0A shown on Sportschannel NY and NE in the US and, I believe, Atlantic %0A Sports Network in Canada (but I'm not sure about that). I am not %0A sure if playoff games will be covered. %0A ===================================================== %0A UTICA GONE? SYRACUSE ADDED? %0A There were heavy rumors that the Utica Devils will not be around next %0A season. There were rumors that they might be headed to a midwestern %0A city and that the city of Syracuse is trying to lure them. %0A ===================================================== %0A WHAT THE AHL MIGHT LOOK LIKE NEXT YEAR %0A  %0A ONE OPTION				ANOTHER OPTION %0A 			 %0A Northern Division			Southern Division %0A ADIRONDACK RED WINGS			ADIRONDACK %0A SPRINGFIELD INDIANS			SPRINGFIELD %0A PROVIDENCE BRUINS			PROVIDENCE %0A CD ISLANDERS				CDI %0A PORTLAND PIRATES			HERSHEY %0A 					BINGHAMTON %0A Southern Division			ROCHESTER %0A HERSHEY BEARS				HAMILTON %0A BINGHAMTON RANGERS			UTICA %0A ROCHESTER AMERICANS %0A HAMILTON CANUCKS			Atlantic Division %0A UTICA (?) DEVILS			PORTLAND  %0A 					ST JOHN'S %0A Atlantic Division			SAINT JOHN %0A ST JOHN'S MAPLE LEAFS			MONCTON %0A MONCTON HAWKS				HALIFAX %0A HALIFAX CITADELS			FREDERICTON %0A CAPE BRETON OILERS			CAPE BRETON %0A FREDERICTON CANADIENS			CHARLOTTETOWN %0A SAINT JOHN BLUE FLAMES %0A CHARLOTTETOWN SENATORS (move is unofficial as yet) %0A  %0A     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ %0A     + Bri Farenell			farenebt %40 craft.camp.clarkson.edu + %0A     + AHL and ECAC contact for rec.sport.hockey		Go USA Hockey!	 +	 %0A     + Adirondack Red Wings, Calder Cup Champs %3A  '81  '86  '89  '92	 + %0A     + Clarkson Hockey, ECAC Tournament Champ %3A  '66  '91  '93		 + %0A     + Glens Falls High School, Division II NY State Champs %3A  '90  '91 	 + %0A     + Join the AHL mailing list %3A  ahl-news-request %40 andrew.cmu.edu    	 + %0A     + CONGRATS TO CLARKSON GOLDEN KNIGHTS HOCKEY %3A  1993 ECAC CHAMPIONS!!! + %0A     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ %0A

doc_2524 |@raw_text From %3A  frankb %40 sad.hp.com (Frank Ball) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Type spesifications (CB, VFR, GT, etc.) %0A Sender %3A  news %40 srgenprp.sr.hp.com (News Administrator) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5sK1D.C1p %40 srgenprp.sr.hp.com> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 16 %3A 48 %3A 49 GMT %0A References %3A  <vidaros.152.735310732 %40 dhhalden.no> %0A Organization %3A  HewlettPackardSantaRosaSystmsDiv,RohnertParkCA %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1.4 PL6] %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A VIDAR OLAF SOLBERG (vidaros %40 dhhalden.no) wrote %3A  %0A & Can somebody tell me what all the letter spesifications on motorcycle models  %0A & really mean.  %0A & Example %3A  What means the C, the B and the R in Honda CBR. - Or the V, S, G, L  %0A & and P in Suzuki VS750GLP %0A  %0A Honda %3A   a "V" designates a V engine street bike. "VF" for V-4, "VT" for V-twin. %0A "CB" is a street bike with an parallel twin or inline 4-cylinder engine. %0A "R" used to mean race bike, but is now also used to mean sport bike. %0A "CL" was for the old steet scramblers-street bikes with high pipes %0A "CM" was a "custom" street bike %0A "CR" is dirt only two strokes %0A "XL" is dual purpose bike %0A "XR" was dirt only four stroke, but now can be a dual purpose bike if it has %0A an "L" as a suffix. %0A "GL" is a touring bike %0A  %0A -- %0A Frank Ball   1UR-M          frankb %40 sad.hp.com    (707) 794-4168 work, %0A Hewlett Packard             (707) 794-3844 fax,  (707) 538-3693 home %0A 1212 Valley House Drive     IT175, XT350, Seca 750, '62 F-100, PL510 %0A Rohnert Park CA 94928-4999  KC6WUG, LAW, AMA, Dod #7566, I'm the NRA. %0A  
doc_2528 |@raw_text From %3A  kolstad %40 cae.wisc.edu (Joel Kolstad) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Organization %3A  U of Wisconsin-Madison College of Engineering %0A Date %3A  26 Apr 93 02 %3A 39 %3A 13 CDT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.023913.504 %40 doug.cae.wisc.edu> %0A References %3A  <1rc4dbINNp44 %40 phage.cshl.org> <C60DvH.FAn %40 ucdavis.edu> <rcstage1.132.735807672 %40 urc.tue.nl> %0A Lines %3A  21 %0A  %0A In article <rcstage1.132.735807672 %40 urc.tue.nl> rcstage1 %40 urc.tue.nl (Guido Klemans) writes %3A  %0A  %0A [stuff about hardware keys] %0A  %0A >If you put another computer on the port instead of the key, you can hack  %0A >them by reading what happens. So I've been told, I've never seen this done  %0A >but I think it's possible. You'd need some hardware knowledge and some  %0A >software to read the port! %0A  %0A True, which is why many of the newer keys ship out, oh, maybe 32 bits or %0A so, have the key encrypt them, and return them to the PC.  Making a bunch %0A of these 32 bits part of your program code is a good way to make sure %0A things won't run without the key.  %3A -)  Anyway, then, this scheme at least %0A defeats your approach.  It's a little costly, though. %0A  %0A Personally, I don't believe in copy protection, and agree with the thought %0A that the mass inconvenience that it causes all legal users far outweighs %0A the gains from what few pirates won't be able to copy the program. %0A  %0A 					---Joel Kolstad %0A  %0A

doc_2561 |@raw_text From %3A  nickh %40 CS.CMU.EDU (Nick Haines) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Level 5? %0A In-Reply-To %3A  18084TM %40 msu.edu's message of Tue, 20 Apr 1993 21 %3A 37 %3A 55 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5u8xI.5Mo.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A Originator %3A  nickh %40 SNOW.FOX.CS.CMU.EDU %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cs.cmu.edu (Usenet News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  snow.fox.cs.cmu.edu %0A Organization %3A  School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University %0A References %3A  <C5sy4s.4x2.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  sci %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 14 %3A 43 %3A 59 GMT %0A Lines %3A  50 %0A  %0A In article <C5sy4s.4x2.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> 18084TM %40 msu.edu (Tom) writes %3A  %0A  %0A    Nick Haines sez; %0A    >(given that I've heard the Shuttle software rated as Level 5 in %0A    >maturity, I strongly doubt that this [having lots of bugs] is the case). %0A  %0A    Level 5?  Out of how many?  What are the different levels?  I've never %0A    heard of this rating system.  Anyone care to clue me in? %0A  %0A This is a rating system used by ARPA and other organisations to %0A measure the maturity of a `software process' i.e. the entire process %0A by which software gets designed, written, tested, delivered, supported %0A etc. %0A  %0A See `Managing the Software Process', by Watts S. Humphrey, Addison %0A Wesley 1989. An excellent software engineering text. The 5 levels of %0A software process maturity are %3A  %0A  %0A 1. Initial %0A 2. Repeatable %0A 3. Defined %0A 4. Managed %0A 5. Optimizing %0A  %0A The levels are approximately characterized as follows %3A  %0A  %0A 1. no statistically software process control. Have no statistical %0A    basis for estimating how large software will be, how long it will %0A    take to produce, how expensive it will be, or how reliable it will %0A    be.  Most software production is at this level. %0A  %0A 2. stable process with statistical controls, rigorous project %0A    management; having done something once, can do it again. Projects %0A    are planned in detail, and there is software configuration %0A    management and quality assurance. %0A  %0A 3. The process is defined and understood, implementation is %0A    consistent. This includes things like software inspection, a %0A    rigorous software testing framework, more configuration management, %0A    and typically a `software engineering process group' within the %0A    project. %0A  %0A 4. Statistical information on the software is systematically gathered %0A    and analysed, and the process is controlled on the basis of this %0A    information. Software quality is measured and has goals. %0A  %0A 5. Defects are prevented, the process is automated, software contracts %0A    are effective and certified. %0A  %0A Nick Haines nickh %40 cmu.edu %0A

Perhaps we should boycott %0A those games?  If DC-X and company get finished, and there is a market %0A for it, those "abominable" space will probably be much more cost %0A effective for the companies, and those starving children.  More people %0A buy products, the company hires more workers, end result fewer %0A children die of starvation. %0A  %0A --  %0A  %0A ---------=======================================================--------- %0A                   ->POLAR CAPS<- or tfv0 %40 lehigh.edu %0A Student Konsultant Making the world safe for computing! %0A "Never before have we owed so little to so many..."- R.T.Folk %0A "One must not confuse John Dunne's famous quote `No man is an Island' with %0A  New York Telephone's `We're all connected'" - Dad %0A

doc_2647 |@raw_text From %3A  ifarqhar %40 laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au (Ian Farquhar) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  ATARI 2600 Processors %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 1993 00 %3A 42 %3A 12 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Macquarie University, Sydney Australia %0A Lines %3A  47 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r7e14$l2c %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A References %3A  <93110.125951PCA103 %40 psuvm.psu.edu> <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> squish %40 endor.uucp (Shishin Yamada) writes %3A  %0A >The Atari 2600 used a 6502 CPU, just like their entire 8-bit line %0A >(400, 800,1200,1400, 1440, 130xe, 65xe computers, as well as the 5200 %0A >game machine).  %0A  %0A Wrong, it has a 6507. %0A  %0A >The 2600 had some extra ASIC chips that were basically %0A >modified graphics chips and PIA's for the joysticks.  %0A  %0A It had one custome chip (not an ASIC in the sense that word is now understood) %3A  %0A the TIA (sometimes known as the 6526, although most other manufacturers list %0A that as the CIA complex interface adapter.)  TIA stands for Television %0A Interface Adapter, and it handles sound, paddles and the minimal video hardware %0A the 2600 possessed. %0A  %0A There was also a standard 6532 RAM, I/O, Timer (RIOT), plus a voltage %0A regulator and (if memory serves) a 555 timer.  That's all. %0A  %0A >Later model 2600 %0A >might have incorporated many of the chips into one ASCI, as the weight %0A >of the machines and part count decreased a lot over the years. %0A  %0A Not according to the servicing documentation I have here.  The 2600 did not %0A change intenally very much at all. %0A  %0A >Additionally, I think the 2600 used 2K, 4K, and up to 8K of ROM for %0A >their games.  %0A  %0A ROMS were mapped into the upper 4K of the 6507's address space.  2K and 4K %0A games were fine, but later 8K and 16K games needed bank switching.  Atari %0A (and others) made much of these "huge" cartridges. %0A  %0A >I have no idea how much RAM it had to work with, but I %0A >would hazard a guess of 2 or 4K RAM.  %0A  %0A Wrong, it had 128 bytes of RAM from the RIOT.  This was multiply mapped into %0A both page 0 (pseudo-registers) and page 1 (stack), and also throughout the %0A bottom 4K of memory.  TIA registers also sat in this address space. %0A  %0A As 128 bytes of RAM was somewhat limiting, some later cartridges also carried %0A RAM themselves, which was interesting as Atari had provided no write line %0A to the cart.  This was managed by mapping the reads from RAM into one address %0A range, and the writes into another, but all the time this scheme ate into %0A the *very* scarce ROM address space. %0A  %0A 							Ian. %0A

L. Ranck (ranck %40 joesbar.cc.vt.edu) wrote %3A  %0A  %3A     I hate to admit this, and I'm still mentally kicking myself for it. %0A  %3A  I rode the brand new K75RT home last Friday night.  100 miles in rain %0A  %3A  and darkness.  No problems.  Got it home and put it on the center stand. %0A  %3A     The next day I pushed it off the center stand in preparation for going %0A  %3A  over to a friend's house to pose.  You guessed it.  It got away from me %0A  %3A  and landed on its right side.   %0A  %3A     Scratched the lower fairing, cracked the right mirror, and cracked the %0A  %3A  upper fairing.   %0A  %3A     *DAMN* am I stupid!  It's going to cost me ~$200 to get the local %0A  %3A  body shop to fix it.  And that is after I take the fairing off for them. %0A  %3A  Still, that's probably cheaper than the mirror alone if I bought a  %0A  %3A  replacement from BMW. %0A  %0A You got off cheap.  My sister's ex-boyfriend was such an incessant pain %0A in the ass about wanting to ride my bikes (no way, Jose) that I %0A finally took him to Lindner's BMW in New Canaan, CT last fall where %0A I had seen a nice, used K100RS in perfect condition.  After telling %0A everyone in the shop his Norton war stories from fifteen years ago, %0A signing the liability waiver, and getting his pre-flight, off he went... %0A  %0A Well, not quite.  I walked out of a pizza shop up the street, %0A feeling good about myself (made my sister's boyfriend happy and got %0A the persistent wanker off my ass for good), heard the horrendous %0A racket of an engine tortured to its red line and then a crash.  I %0A saw people running towards the obvious source of the disturbance... %0A Jeff laying under the BMW with the rear wheel spinning wildly and %0A someone groping for the kill switch.  I stared in disbelief with %0A a slice hanging out of my mouth as Matty, the shop manager, slid %0A up beside me and asked, "Friend of yours, Steve?".  "Shit, Matty, %0A it could have been worse.  That could been my FLHS!" %0A  %0A Jeff hadn't made it 10 inches.  Witnesses said he lifted his feet %0A before letting out the clutch and gravity got the best of him. %0A Jeff claimed that the clutch didn't engage.  Matty was quick. %0A While Jeff was still stuttering in embarrassed shock he managed %0A to snatch Jeff's credit card for a quick imprint and signature.  Twenty %0A minutes later, when Jeff's color had paled to a flush, Matty %0A presented him with an estimate of $580 for a busted right mirror %0A and a hairline crack in the fairing.  That was for fixing the crack %0A and masking the damaged area, not a new fairing.  Or he could buy the %0A bike. %0A  %0A I'm not sure what happened later as my sister split up with Jeff shortly %0A afterwards (to hook up with another piece of work) except that Matty %0A told me he ran the charge through in December and that it went %0A uncontested. %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Stephen Manes					   manes %40 magpie.linknet.com %0A Manes and Associates				   New York, NY, USA  =o&>o %0A  %0A

Rand) writes %3A  %0A >>In article <randall.735251839 %40 woof> randall %40 informix.com (Randall Rhea) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >>   Hams can legally run up to 1500 watts.  It is very unlikely, however, %0A >>   that a ham would be running that kind of power from a car.  Ham rigs %0A  %0A >>Not possible either.  You'd need about a 300 amp alternator for %0A >>just the amplifier.  I can just see it.  You need to slow %0A >>down on a downgrade,  so you hit the push to talk button. %0A  %0A >Now, that indeed is possible.  A good friend of mine is running about 1 KW %0A >PeP from his car.  Yes, he does have a second alternator.  Yes, he calls %0A >the rig an "electronic brake" since the engine noticeably slows when the %0A >key is down. %0A  %0A It has been a while since I knew the electronics of ham radio, but I seem %0A to remember that PeP is actually 4x the "real" power.  Which makes 1KW PeP %0A actually around 250W.  Or was it 2x?  I disremember. %0A  %0A "Effective transmitted power" is also "odd", in that it takes into account %0A antenna height and geometry.  Which is why a TV station with a 50KW Klystron %0A might advertise a megawatt (if their antenna is on the top of the %0A CN tower ;-). %0A  %0A This is like Sears HP ;-) %0A  %0A Though, 1500 real watts still isn't impossible.  About 125-150A with %0A a 12V alternator, less if the alternator produces higher voltages. %0A  %0A It's only three horsepower (taking into account inefficiencies).  You'll %0A feel it when you hit the key.  But not too much. %0A --  %0A Chris Lewis; clewis %40 ferret.ocunix.on.ca; Phone %3A  Canada 613 832-0541 %0A Psroff 3.0 info %3A  psroff-request %40 ferret.ocunix.on.ca %0A Ferret list %3A  ferret-request %40 ferret.ocunix.on.ca %0A

Mckissock) writes %3A  %0A  %0A ...text of options "A" and "B" deleted... %0A  %0A >Option C - Single Core Launch Station. %0A >This is the JSC lead option. Basically, you take a 23 ft diameter %0A >cylinder that's 92 ft long, slap 3 Space Shuttle Main Engines on %0A >the backside, put a nose cone on the top, attached it to a  %0A >regular shuttle external tank and a regular set of solid rocket %0A >motors, and launch the can. Some key features are %3A  %0A >  - Complete end-to-end ground integration and checkout %0A >  - 4 tangentially mounted fixed solar panels %0A >  - body mounted radiators (which adds protection against %0A >    micrometeroid & orbital debris) %0A >  - 2 centerline docking ports (one on each end) %0A >  - 7 berthing ports %0A >  - a single pressurized volume, approximately 26,000 cubic feet %0A >    (twice the volume of skylab). %0A >  - 7 floors, center passageway between floors %0A >  - 10 kW of housekeeping power %0A  %0A Only 10KW? %0A  %0A >  - graceful degradation with failures (8 power channels, 4 thermal %0A >    loops, dual environmental control & life support system) %0A >  - increased crew time for utilization %0A >  - 1 micro-g thru out the core module %0A  %0A Ha!  "North America Modular SPACE STATION construction"  %3A -) %0A Same apprach, same reasoning %3A  "construction occurs under assembly %0A line conditions, no random weather problems interupting site-work %0A on your home - better quality control" -- sounds like first "-" %0A point above  %3A -) %0A  %0A Somehow I have a strange attraction for this idea (living in %0A a modular home maybe has altered my mind).  The only thing %0A that scares me is the part about simply strapping 3 SSME's and %0A a nosecone on it and "just launching it."  I have this vision %0A of something going terribly wrong with the launch resulting in the %0A complete loss of the new modular space station (not just a peice of %0A it as would be the case with staged in-orbit construction). %0A  %0A -- %0A -+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ %0A Michael F. doc_2704 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Combo Propulsion System!? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C6DEMz.Bo9 %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 1 May 1993 23 %3A 01 %3A 44 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993May1.043916.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  20 %0A  %0A In article <1993May1.043916.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> nsmca %40 aurora.alaska.edu writes %3A  %0A >How hard or easy would it be to have a combo mission such as a solar sail on %0A >the way out to the outer planets, but once in near to orbit to use more normal %0A >means.. %0A  %0A If you've got a good propulsion system that's not useful for deceleration, %0A sure you can use chemical rockets for that part... but even just doing the %0A deceleration chemically is a major headache.  We're talking seriously high %0A cruising velocities; taking the velocity down nearly to zero for a Pluto %0A orbit isn't easy with chemical fuels. %0A  %0A Incidentally, solar sails are not going to be suitable as the acceleration %0A system for something like this.  They don't go anywhere quickly.  (I speak %0A as head of mission planning for the Canadian Solar Sail Project, although %0A that is more or less an honorary title right now because CSSP is dormant.) %0A They can't fly a mission like this unless you start talking about very %0A advanced systems that drop in very close to the Sun first. %0A --  %0A SVR4 resembles a high-speed collision   %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A between SVR3 and SunOS.    - Dick Dunn  %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_2733 |@raw_text From %3A  globus %40 nas.nasa.gov (Al Globus) %0A Subject %3A  Space Colony Size Preferences Summary %0A Sender %3A  news %40 nas.nasa.gov (News Administrator) %0A Organization %3A  Applied Research Office, NASA Ames Research Center %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 93 10 %3A 26 %3A 12 %0A Message-ID %3A  <GLOBUS.93Apr21102612 %40 wk208.nas.nasa.gov> %0A Reply-To %3A  globus %40 nas.nasa.gov %0A Distribution %3A  sci.space %0A Lines %3A  92 %0A  %0A  %0A Some time ago I sent the following message %3A  %0A    Every once in a while I design an orbital space colony.  I'm gearing up to %0A    do another one.  I'd some info from you. If you were to move %0A    onto a space colony to live permanently, how big would the colony have %0A    to be for you to view a permanent move as desirable?  Specifically, %0A  %0A    How many people do you want to share the colony with? %0A   %0A  %0A    What physical dimensions does the living are need to have?   %0A  %0A  %0A    Assume 1g living (the colony will rotate).  Assume that you can leave %0A    from time to time for vacations and business trips.  If you're young %0A    enough, assume that you'll raise your children there. %0A  %0A I didn't get a lot of responses, and they were all over the block. %0A Thanx muchly to all those who responded, it is good food for thought. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Here's the (edited) responses I got %3A  %0A  %0A  %0A    How many people do you want to share the colony with? %0A   %0A 100 %0A  %0A    What physical dimensions does the living are need to have?   %0A  %0A Cylinder 200m diameter x 1 km long %0A  %0A Rui Sousa %0A ruca %40 saber-si.pt %0A  %0A ============================================================================= %0A  %0A >   How many people do you want to share the colony with? %0A  %0A 100,000 - 250,000 %0A  %0A >   What physical dimensions does the living are need to have?   %0A  %0A 100 square kms surface, divided into city, towns, villages and %0A countryside.  Must have lakes, rivers amd mountains. %0A  %0A ============================================================================= %0A  %0A > How many %0A 1000.  1000 people really isn't that large a number; %0A everyone will know everyone else within the space of a year, and will probably %0A be sick of everyone else within another year. %0A  %0A >What physical dimensions does the living are need to have?   %0A  %0A Hm.  I am not all that great at figuring it out.  But I would maximize the %0A percentage of colony-space that is accessible to humans.  Esecially if there %0A were to be children, since they will figure out how to go everywhere anyways. %0A And everyone, especially me, likes to "go exploring"...I would want to be able %0A to go for a walk and see something different each time... %0A  %0A ============================================================================= %0A  %0A For population, I think I would want a substantial town -- big enough %0A to have strangers in it.  This helps get away from the small-town %0A "everybody knows everything" syndrome, which some people like but %0A I don't.  Call it several thousand people. %0A  %0A For physical dimensions, a somewhat similar criterion %3A   big enough %0A to contain surprises, at least until you spent considerable time %0A getting to know it.  As a more specific rule of thumb, big enough %0A for there to be places at least an hour away on foot.  Call that %0A 5km, which means a 10km circumference if we're talking a sphere. %0A  %0A                                          Henry Spencer at U of Toronto Zoology %0A                                           henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu   utzoo!henry %0A  %0A ============================================================================= %0A My desires, for permanent move to a space colony, assuming easy communication %0A and travel %3A  %0A  %0A Size %3A   About a small-town size, say 9 sq. km.  'Course, bigger is better  %3A -) %0A Population %3A   about 100/sq km or less.  So, ~1000 for 9sqkm.  Less is %0A better for elbow room, more for interest and sanity, so say max 3000, min 300. %0A  %0A -Tommy Mac %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A Tom McWilliams %7C 517-355-2178 (work) \\     Inhale to the Chief! %0A 18084tm %40 ibm.cl.msu.edu  %7C 336-9591 (hm)\\  Zonker Harris in 1996! %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A

A reseacher will first of all try  %0A to publish a worthy paper in a credible, professional magazine and not in a  %0A community like USENET which is infamous for lots (not all) of junk  %0A information. The papers that will be "published" here will, in general, be  %0A of low quality. Also, it is improbable that any credit will be given to a  %0A researcher who publish here - and sadly, that is nowadays a main reason for  %0A publishing. %0A  %0A USENET is great for informal discussions and free exchange of ideas - keep  %0A it like that. A new, specialist group is just not worth it. %0A  %0A - gerrit %0A

doc_2823 |@raw_text From %3A  wcs %40 anchor.ho.att.com (Bill Stewart +1-908-949-0705) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Fifth Amendment and Passwords %0A Organization %3A  Brought to you by the numbers 2, 3, and 7 %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 16 %3A 52 %3A 39 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <WCS.93Apr20115239 %40 rainier.ATT.COM> %0A In-Reply-To %3A  pmetzger %40 snark.shearson.com's message of Tue, 20 Apr 1993 11 %3A 21 %3A 34 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr18.233112.24107 %40 colnet.cmhnet.org> %0A 	<1993Apr19.180049.20572 %40 qualcomm.com> %0A 	<1qv83m$5i2 %40 geraldo.cc.utexas.edu> %0A 	<1993Apr20.000359.20098 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> %0A 	<PMETZGER.93Apr20062134 %40 snark.shearson.com> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cbnewsh.cb.att.com (NetNews Administrator) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  rainier.ho.att.com %0A Lines %3A  42 %0A  %0A    In article <1993Apr20.000359.20098 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> caronni %40 nessie.cs.id.ethz.ch (Germano Caronni) writes %3A  %0A       Just a question.  %0A       As a provider of a public BBS service - aren't you bound by law to gurantee %0A       intelligble access to the data of the users on the BBS, if police comes %0A       with sufficent authorisation ? I guessed this would be  a basic condition %0A       for such systems. (I did run a bbs some time ago, but that was in Switzerland) %0A  %0A The US doesn't yet have many laws covering BBSs - they're not common carriers, %0A they're not phone companies, they're just private machines or services %0A operated by businesses.  There's no obligation to keep records. %0A As Perry Metzger points out, if the police come with a search warrant, %0A you have to let them see what the warrant demands, if it exists, %0A and they generally can confiscate the equipment as "evidence" %0A (which is not Constitutionally valid, but we're only beginning to %0A develop court cases supporting us).  A court MAY be able to compel %0A you to tell them information you know, such as the encryption password %0A for the disk - there aren't any definitive cases yet, since it's a new %0A situation, and there probably aren't laws specifically covering it. %0A But the court can't force you to *know* the keys, and there are no %0A laws preventing you from allowing your users to have their own keys %0A for their own files without giving them to you. %0A  %0A Even in areas that do have established law, there is uncertainty. %0A There was a guy in Idaho a few years ago who had his business records %0A subpoenaed as evidence for taxes or some other business-restriction law, %0A so he gave the court the records.  Which were in Hebrew. %0A The US doesn't have laws forcing you to keep your records in English, %0A and these were the originals of the records.  HE didn't speak Hebrew, %0A and neither did anybody in the court organization.  Don't think they %0A were able to do much about it. %0A  %0A It might be illegal for your BBS to deny access to potential customers %0A based on race, religion, national origin, gender, or sexual preference; %0A it probably hasn't been tested in court, but it seems like a plausible %0A extension of anti-discrimination laws affecting other businesses. %0A  %0A  %0A -- %0A #				Pray for peace;      Bill %0A # Bill Stewart 1-908-949-0705 wcs %40 anchor.att.com AT&T Bell Labs 4M312 Holmdel NJ %0A #	              No, I'm *from* New Jersey, I only *work* in cyberspace.... %0A # White House Commect Line 1-202-456-1111  fax 1-202-456-2461 %0A

doc_2838 |@raw_text From %3A  Rick Miller - former spook <rick %40 ee.uwm.edu> %0A Subject %3A  Alternate *legal* wiretaps. %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 1993 13 %3A 47 %3A 11 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Just me. %0A Lines %3A  43 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r3j8vINNdlp %40 uwm.edu> %0A References %3A  <bontchev.735230663 %40 fbihh> <1993Apr21.041033.16550 %40 news.clarkson.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  129.89.2.33 %0A Summary %3A  Nothing spooky, it's an Executive Order. %0A  %0A tuinstra %40 signal.ece.clarkson.edu.soe writes %3A  %0A [...] %0A >  It would be a strong incentive, as Vesselin points out, for more %0A >police agencies to "go rogue" and try to get keys through more efficient %0A >(but less Constitutional) means.  Notice what the release said %3A  %0A > %0A >   Q %3A    Suppose a law enforcement agency is conducting a wiretap on %0A >        a drug smuggling ring and intercepts a conversation %0A >        encrypted using the device.  What would they have to do to %0A >        decipher the message? %0A > %0A >   A %3A    They would have to obtain legal authorization, normally a %0A >                                                       ^^^^^^^^^^ %0A >        court order, to do the wiretap in the first place. %0A >        ^^^^^^^^^^^ %0A  %0A >The clear implication is that there are "legal" authorizations other %0A >than a court order.  Just how leaky are these?  (And who  %0A >knows what's in those 7 pages that authorized the NSA?).  There %0A [...] %0A  %0A I was a cryptologic tech in the US Navy (CTRSN, nothing big).  All 'spooks' %0A in the Navy are required to know the "gist" of "USSID 18", the Navy-way of %0A naming a particular Presidential "Executive Order".  It outlines what spooks %0A can and can't do with respect to the privacy of US nationals. %0A  %0A The following information is (of course) UNCLASSIFIED. %0A  %0A The whole issue hangs about what you mean by "wiretap".  If the signal can %0A be detected by "non-intrusive" means (like radio listening), then it may be %0A recorded and it may be "analyzed".  "Analyzed" means that it may be either %0A deciphered and/or radio-location may be used to locate the transmitter. %0A  %0A The catch is this %3A   Any and all record of the signal and its derivatives %0A may only be kept for a maximum of 90 days, after which they are destroyed %0A unless permission is obtained from the US Attorney General to keep them. %0A  %0A Didn't you ever wonder how Coast Guard cutters *find* those drug-runners %0A in all those tens of thousands of square miles of sea, even in the dark?!? %0A  %0A Rick Miller  <rick %40 ee.uwm.edu> %7C <ricxjo %40 discus.mil.wi.us>   Ricxjo Muelisto %0A Send a postcard, get one back! %7C Enposxtigu bildkarton kaj vi ricevos alion! %0A           RICK MILLER // 16203 WOODS // MUSKEGO, WIS. 53150 // USA %0A

doc_2883 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  japanese moon landing? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5LFDM.35p %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 20 %3A 24 %3A 56 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5Kys1.C6r %40 panix.com> <C5L2xt.IqD %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <C5LDoD.7pC %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A In article <C5LDoD.7pC %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> rls %40 uihepa.hep.uiuc.edu writes %3A  %0A >allow it to go into lunar orbit without large expenditures of fuel to slow %0A >down. The idea is that 'natural objects sometimes get captured without %0A >expending fuel, we'll just find the trajectory that makes it possible". The %0A >originator of the technique said that NASA wasn't interested, but that Japan %0A >was because their probe was small and couldn't hold a lot of fuel for %0A >deceleration. %0A  %0A Actually, Hiten wasn't originally intended to go into lunar orbit at all, %0A so it indeed didn't have much fuel on hand.  The lunar-orbit mission was %0A an afterthought, after Hagoromo (a tiny subsatellite deployed by Hiten %0A during a lunar flyby) had a transmitter failure and its proper insertion %0A into lunar orbit couldn't be positively confirmed. %0A  %0A It should be noted that the technique does have disadvantages.  It takes %0A a long time, and you end up with a relatively inconvenient lunar orbit. %0A If you want something useful like a low circular polar orbit, you do have %0A to plan to expend a certain amount of fuel, although it is reduced from %0A what you'd need for the brute-force approach. %0A --  %0A All work is one man's work.             %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A                     - Kipling           %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_2900 |@raw_text From %3A  tenney %40 netcom.com (Glenn S. Tenney) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  HELP! Some nut is threatening to sue! %0A Message-ID %3A  <tenneyC6E4LD.LG5 %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  Netcom - Online Communication Services (408 241-9760 guest) %0A References %3A  <9304292001.AA20252 %40 memexis.memex.com> <a_rubin.736125803 %40 dsg4.dse.beckman.com> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 2 May 1993 08 %3A 22 %3A 25 GMT %0A Lines %3A  44 %0A  %0A I don't wish to rehash the PGP patent issue at all, but I do feel %0A that some potential misconceptions in interpretting intellectual property %0A laws need to be raised. %0A  %0A In article <a_rubin.736125803 %40 dsg4.dse.beckman.com> a_rubin %40 dsg4.dse.beckman.com (Arthur Rubin) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >If PGP violates RSAs patents, then only executing PGP could be a violation. %0A >Distributing PGP could be contributory infringement, but the PGP %0A >documentation seemed sufficient to me to protect distributors (before I %0A >deleted it -- using PGP might be a patent violation in the US, so I have no %0A >need to keep it.) %0A  %0A You are correct that executing PGP would be a violation (unless the patent %0A were declared invalid by the courts), but...  there is a question as %0A to when, how, or if distributing PGP would be a violation.  If the person %0A or company distributing PGP receives money for doing so, then it is %0A clearly a sale (for example, if it were on Compuserve, they charge you %0A for access so they would be selling PGP).  When there is no charge for %0A PGP things get less clear, but there would still be a reasonable view %0A that it is inducing an infringement. %0A  %0A > ... [nb re %3A  Jim Bidzos] %0A >You have no legal action you can take, unless you believe you can prove %0A >someone is using PGP in the US, for a purpose other than that specifically %0A >allowed by patent laws.  (Not entirely correct, anyone can sue for any %0A >reason, but, you cannot prevail unless you can prove that by a prepoderance %0A >of evidence).  Under patent laws, PGP does have legitimate uses, as a means %0A >to study your algorithm, in order to produce improvements (which would %0A >still require your approval to execute, until the patent runs out around %0A >2000). %0A  %0A This is a common misconception.  The patent laws do not mention any valid %0A purpose for infringing a patent.  Although it is clear that in order to %0A create a new invention either based on a prior patent or to avoid infringing %0A a prior patent, one must perform research on an existing patent.  To %0A just say that you infringed a patent (assume we're not talking the RSA %0A patent) only for research purposes (wink wink, nudge nudge) and then never %0A develop any related invention (ie. only use it), would be a clear %0A infringement. %0A  %0A --  %0A Glenn Tenney %0A voice %3A  (415) 574-3420      fax %3A  (415) 574-0546 %0A tenney %40 netcom.com          Ham radio %3A  AA6ER %0A  
doc_2903 |@raw_text From %3A  msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu (Mark  Underwood) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  help - how to construct home-built battery for 3rd grade sci report %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5r7E7.IGL %40 ms.uky.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 ms.uky.edu (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  nx26.mik.uky.edu %0A Reply-To %3A  msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu %0A Organization %3A  University Of Kentucky, Dept. of Math Sciences %0A References %3A  <C5quI4.4CF %40 spk.hp.com> %0A Distribution %3A  usa %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 23 %3A 18 %3A 06 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A In article <C5quI4.4CF %40 spk.hp.com> borowski %40 spk.hp.com (Don T. Borowski)   %0A writes %3A  %0A > Dean Anneser (anneser %40 pwa-b.uucp) wrote %3A  %0A >  %3A  My 9 yr old son has signed up to do a science report on batteries.  I   %0A was %0A >  %3A  wondering if anyone could provide me with some information as to how   %0A to %0A >  %3A  construct a home-built battery.  In my grade school days, I remember  %0A  %0A (snip!) %0A  %0A I haven't been following this, so I'm sorry if somebody already mentioned   %0A this, but you could grab a lemon (I think potatoes work too, but I'm not   %0A sure), a strip of copper, and a strip of zinc (I think you can get the   %0A metal in a hardware store or hobby shop, maybe??).  Stick the strips in   %0A the lemon (so they don't touch!) and you'll get a measurable voltage (not   %0A a lot, but, hey, it's a lemon  %3A -)  ).  As I recall we had to hook   %0A something like ten of these things to get an appreciable amount of   %0A current, because of the mondo internal resistance, but if you just need a   %0A demo you might get it to run a tiny fan or something!  %3A -) %0A  %0A  %0A Mark S. Underwood %0A EE Student, University of Kentucky %0A Lab Assistant, Boyd Hall Microlab  %0A 	(a tiny little division of UK Library Microlabs) %0A E-Mail %3A   msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_2940 |@raw_text From %3A  karn %40 servo.qualcomm.com (Phil Karn) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Keeping Your Mouth Shut (was %3A  Hard drive security) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.211925.25309 %40 qualcomm.com> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 qualcomm.com %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  servo.qualcomm.com %0A Reply-To %3A  karn %40 chicago.qualcomm.com %0A Organization %3A  Qualcomm, Inc %0A References %3A  <C4uKKz.1G6 %40 telebit.com> <114800 %40 bu.edu> <Apr13.011855.69422 %40 yuma.ACNS.ColoState.EDU>,<1993Apr13.143712.15338 %40 cadkey.com> <C5K1CE.51A %40 sunfish.usd.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 21 %3A 19 %3A 25 GMT %0A Lines %3A  37 %0A  %0A In article <C5K1CE.51A %40 sunfish.usd.edu>, vkub %40 charlie.usd.edu (Vince Kub) writes %3A  %0A %7C> Now, %0A %7C> the original scheme as suggested here would be to have the key disappear if %0A %7C> certain threatening conditions are met. Once the key is gone there is no %0A %7C> question of Contempt of Court as there is nothing to compell, the key is no %0A %7C> longer there to be produced. %0A  %0A Getting rid of the keys is actually pretty easy to do automatically on %0A a communications link, as opposed to storage where the keys have to be %0A retained somehow as long as the owner wants to be able to retrieve the %0A data. %0A  %0A The right way to do communications security is to generate a random %0A session key with Diffie Hellman, use it for a while and then destroy %0A it. Once it's gone, there's no getting it back, and no way to decrypt %0A recordings of the conversation. %0A  %0A To make sure you aren't being attacked by a man in the middle, you %0A have to authenticate your DH exchanges. The AT&T secure phone does %0A this by displaying the DH key so you can compare them verbally over %0A the phone. This is nice and simple, but it relies on user awareness %0A plus the inability of the man in the middle to duplicate the users' %0A voices. %0A  %0A A better way is to authenticate the exchanges with RSA. Since you'd %0A never use RSA for actual encryption, compromising your RSA secret key %0A would only allow someone to impersonate you in a future conversation, %0A and even that only until you revoke your public key.  They would still %0A not be able to decrypt recordings of prior conversations for which the %0A session keys have been destroyed. %0A  %0A I'm convinced that this is how the government's own secure phones %0A (the STU-III) must work. Neat, eh? %0A  %0A Phil %0A  %0A  %0A

Both the ACLU and the NRA are resistent to government pressure %0A  %3A  by the simple expedient fact that they are not supported, funded, or %0A  %3A  overtly controlled by the government. %0A  %3A  -------------------------- %0A Thats one problem that has so far been overlooked. These two escrow %0A agencies will have to create a secure database and service the %0A input and output of Keys. Who pays for this? If they refuse an %0A illegal request from some congressman to deliver a key can their %0A budget by cut to punish them? Will congress be forced to fund %0A them forever? %0A  %0A The problem is that laws can change. Congress may pass a law setting %0A up an escrow agency with instructions that keys are private. Some %0A future congress may change that law. Suppose pre-nazi Germany had %0A a clipper system. Do you think the escrow agencies would have %0A told Hitler that he could not have the keys without a valid  %0A court order? %0A  %0A In effect you must set up escrow agencies as a fourth branch of %0A the goverment and isolate them from any outside interferance.  %0A They will be able to directly tap into Federal funds with no %0A accountability to anyone except through a court challenge. %0A  %0A John Eaton %0A !hp-vcd!johne %0A  %0A  %0A

I don't know about %0A >launch loads, etc.. but since the Centaur survives Titan launches which %0A >are probably worse than the Proton (those Titan SRB's probably shake things %0A >up pretty good) it seems feasible. EXCEPT, the Centaur is a very fragile %0A >thing and may require integration on the pad which is not available now. %0A >Protons are assembled and transported horizontially. Does anyone know  %0A >how much stress in the way of a payload a Centaur could support while %0A >bolted to a Proton horizontally and then taken down the rail road track %0A >and erected on the pad?   %0A  %0A >They would also need LOX and LH facilities added to the Proton pads  %0A >(unless the new Proton second stage is actually built), and of course %0A >any Centaur support systems and facilities, no doubt imported from the %0A >US at great cost. doc_3019 |@raw_text From %3A  bakalis %40 apollo.HP.COM (Steven Bakalis) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Speeding ticket from CHP %0A Message-ID %3A  <C52JGB.K99 %40 apollo.hp.com> %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 93 15 %3A 38 %3A 34 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  apollo.C52JGB.K99 %0A References %3A  <65930405053856/0005111312NA1EM %40 mcimail.com> <1pqarb$fnq %40 gaia.ucs.orst.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 apollo.hp.com (Usenet News) %0A Organization %3A  Hewlett-Packard Company, Chelmsford, MA %0A Lines %3A  18 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  fantail.ch.apollo.hp.com %0A  %0A In article <1pqarb$fnq %40 gaia.ucs.orst.edu>, crucej %40 osshe.edu (Jerry Cruce) writes %3A  %0A %7C> Peter Nesbitt (0005111312 %40 mcimail.com) wrote %3A  %0A %7C>  %3A  Riding to work last week via Hwy 12 from Suisun, to I-80, I was pulled over by %0A %7C>  %3A  a CHP black and white by the 76 Gas station by Jameson Canyon Road.  The %0A %7C>  %3A  officer stated "...it <looked> like you were going kinda fast coming down %0A %7C>  %3A  highway 12.  You <must have> been going at least 70 or 75."  I just said okay, %0A %7C>  %3A  and did not agree or disagree to anything he said.  %0A %7C>  %0A  %0A 1) The next time you get stoped by a cop, never never never admit to anything. %0A  %0A 2) Don't volunteer any information. %0A  %0A 3) When a retoracle question is ask by the cop, like "...it <looked> like you were going kinda fast coming down highway 12.  You <must have> been going at least 70 or 75?" -- the correct reponse is to deny it. This technique is employed by police to help establish guilt, especially when (9 times out of 10) he/she is not sure who was doing the speeding. If the cop is unsure this may be the difference of him letting you off the hook or getting the tissue. %0A  %0A Hope this helps for next time. %0A  %0A Steven Bakalis %0A

doc_3030 |@raw_text From %3A  bontchev %40 fbihh.informatik.uni-hamburg.de (Vesselin Bontchev) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  text of White House announcement and Q&As on clipper chip encryption %0A Message-ID %3A  <bontchev.734981805 %40 fbihh> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 informatik.uni-hamburg.de (Mr. News) %0A Reply-To %3A  bontchev %40 fbihh.informatik.uni-hamburg.de %0A Organization %3A  Virus Test Center, University of Hamburg %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 17 %3A 36 %3A 45 GMT %0A Lines %3A  268 %0A  %0A clipper %40 csrc.ncsl.nist.gov (Clipper Chip Announcement) writes %3A  %0A  %0A > The President today announced a new initiative that will bring %0A > the Federal Government together with industry in a voluntary %0A > program to improve the security and privacy of telephone %0A > communications while meeting the legitimate needs of law %0A > enforcement. %0A  %0A A nice formulation for the introduction of the first encryption %0A devices with built-in trapdoors - just like the Feds wanted... %0A  %0A > For too long there has been little or no dialogue between our %0A > private sector and the law enforcement community to resolve the %0A > tension between economic vitality and the real challenges of %0A > protecting Americans.  Rather than use technology to accommodate %0A > the sometimes competing interests of economic growth, privacy and %0A > law enforcement, previous policies have pitted government against %0A > industry and the rights of privacy against law enforcement. %0A  %0A Bla-bla. %0A  %0A > protect electronic mail and computer files.  While encryption %0A > technology can help Americans protect business secrets and the %0A > unauthorized release of personal information, it also can be used %0A > by terrorists, drug dealers, and other criminals. %0A  %0A Indeed, and the current proposal does nothing to prevent the latter. %0A  %0A > an ordinary telephone.  It scrambles telephone communications %0A > using an encryption algorithm that is more powerful than many in %0A > commercial use today. %0A  %0A This doesn't say much. There are many incredibly weak encryption %0A algorithms in commercial use today... %0A  %0A > This new technology will help companies protect proprietary %0A > information, protect the privacy of personal phone conversations %0A > and prevent unauthorized release of data transmitted %0A > electronically. %0A  %0A Except from the government. %0A  %0A >  At the same time this technology preserves the %0A > ability of federal, state and local law enforcement agencies to %0A > intercept lawfully the phone conversations of criminals.  %0A  %0A Nope. The criminals won't be stupid enough to use the new chip, %0A they'll use something secure. This technology provides only means to %0A intercept the phone conversations of people who are stupid enough to %0A use it. %0A  %0A > agencies to decode messages encoded by the device.  When the %0A > device is manufactured, the two keys will be deposited separately %0A > in two "key-escrow" data bases that will be established by the %0A > Attorney General.  Access to these keys will be limited to %0A > government officials with legal authorization to conduct a %0A > wiretap. %0A  %0A That is, the government has the keys. It doesn't matter much if they %0A are in one or in two of its hands... %0A  %0A > The "Clipper Chip" technology provides law enforcement with no %0A > new authorities to access the content of the private %0A > conversations of Americans. %0A  %0A Correct. It does, however, provide those Americans with the false %0A sense of privacy. %0A  %0A > devices.  In addition, respected experts from outside the %0A > government will be offered access to the confidential details of %0A > the algorithm to assess its capabilities and publicly report %0A > their findings. %0A  %0A If the screening is not public, it cannot be trusted. Some people do %0A not trust DES even today, after all the examinations - only because %0A some parts of its design were kept secret. %0A  %0A > The chip is an important step in addressing the problem of %0A > encryption's dual-edge sword %3A   encryption helps to protect the %0A > privacy of individuals and industry, but it also can shield %0A > criminals and terrorists.  We need the "Clipper Chip" and other %0A > approaches that can both provide law-abiding citizens with access %0A > to the encryption they need and prevent criminals from using it %0A > to hide their illegal activities.  In order to assess technology %0A  %0A So they'll use a different technology to hide their illegal %0A activities. So will those law-abiding citizens, who do not trust their %0A government not to misuse its abilities to decrypt their conversations. %0A  %0A >      --   the privacy of our citizens, including the need to %0A >           employ voice or data encryption for business purposes; %0A  %0A Except from the government. %0A  %0A >      --   the need of U.S. companies to manufacture and export %0A >           high technology products. %0A  %0A Huh? Later it says that the new technology will be export restricted. %0A  %0A > Since encryption technology will play an increasingly important %0A > role in that infrastructure, the Federal Government must act %0A > quickly to develop consistent, comprehensive policies regarding %0A > its use.  The Administration is committed to policies that %0A > protect all Americans' right to privacy while also protecting %0A > them from those who break the law. %0A  %0A In short, the new technology can %3A  %0A  %0A 1) Protect the law abiding citizen's privacy from the casual snooper. %0A  %0A It cannot %3A  %0A  %0A 1) Protect him from the government, if it decides to misuse its %0A ability to decrypt the conversations. %0A  %0A 2) Protect him from the criminals who succeed to break the new %0A encryption scheme or to steal the keys, or to bribe the people who %0A handle them, etc. %0A  %0A 3) Prevent the criminals from using secure encryption for %0A communication. %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Does this approach expand the authority of government %0A >      agencies to listen in on phone conversations? %0A  %0A > A %3A    No.  "Clipper Chip" technology provides law enforcement with %0A >      no new authorities to access the content of the private %0A >      conversations of Americans. %0A  %0A Correct. However, it does not provide them that much privacy as it %0A claims. %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Who will run the key-escrow data banks? %0A  %0A > A %3A    The two key-escrow data banks will be run by two independent %0A >      entities.  At this point, the Department of Justice and the %0A >      Administration have yet to determine which agencies will %0A >      oversee the key-escrow data banks. %0A  %0A Two candidates %3A  the NSA and the Mafia. %0A  %0A > Q %3A    How strong is the security in the device?  How can I be sure %0A >      how strong the security is?   %0A  %0A > A %3A    This system is more secure than many other voice encryption %0A >      systems readily available today.  %0A  %0A That is, "trust us". %0A  %0A > While the algorithm will %0A >      remain classified to protect the security of the key escrow %0A  %0A "Security through obscurity". %0A  %0A >      system, we are willing to invite an independent panel of %0A >      cryptography experts to evaluate the algorithm to assure all %0A >      potential users that there are no unrecognized %0A >      vulnerabilities. %0A  %0A If it's not entirely open to public examination, it cannot be %0A trusted. Besides, who can prove that the devices used for examination %0A and the ones built into your phones will be the same? %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Whose decision was it to propose this product? %0A  %0A > A %3A    The National Security Council, the Justice Department, the %0A  %0A The NSA and the FBI? %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Who was consulted?  The Congress?  Industry? %0A  %0A > A %3A    We have on-going discussions with Congress and industry on %0A >      encryption issues, and expect those discussions to intensify %0A >      as we carry out our review of encryption policy.  We have %0A >      briefed members of Congress and industry leaders on the %0A >      decisions related to this initiative. %0A  %0A Why did they "forget" the Academia? %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Will the government provide the hardware to manufacturers? %0A  %0A > A %3A    The government designed and developed the key access %0A >      encryption microcircuits, but it is not providing the %0A >      microcircuits to product manufacturers.  Product %0A >      manufacturers can acquire the microcircuits from the chip %0A >      manufacturer that produces them. %0A  %0A Doesn't this smell to monopolism? %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Who provides the "Clipper Chip"? %0A  %0A > A %3A    Mykotronx programs it at their facility in Torrance, %0A >      California, and will sell the chip to encryption device %0A >      manufacturers.  The programming function could be licensed %0A >      to other vendors in the future. %0A  %0A Like the Mafia? %0A  %0A > Q %3A    If the Administration were unable to find a technological %0A >      solution like the one proposed, would the Administration be %0A >      willing to use legal remedies to restrict access to more %0A >      powerful encryption devices? %0A  %0A This is the main question, why was it buried at the end? %0A  %0A > A %3A    This is a fundamental policy question which will be %0A >      considered during the broad policy review.  The key escrow %0A  %0A "We'll see". %0A  %0A >      mechanism will provide Americans with an encryption product %0A >      that is more secure, more convenient, and less expensive %0A >      than others readily available today, but it is just one %0A  %0A "Trust us". %0A  %0A >      The Administration is not saying, "since encryption %0A >      threatens the public safety and effective law enforcement, %0A >      we will prohibit it outright" (as some countries have %0A  %0A In short, "If we decide to outlaw strong crypto, we'll tell you". %0A  %0A >      effectively done); nor is the U.S. saying that "every %0A >      American, as a matter of right, is entitled to an %0A >      unbreakable commercial encryption product."  There is a %0A  %0A Since the US government seems to consider strong crypto as munitions %0A and since the US constitutions guarantees the right to every American %0A to bear arms, why is not every American entitled, as a matter of %0A right, to an unbreakable commercial encryption product? %0A  %0A > A %3A    It indicates that we understand the importance of encryption %0A >      technology in telecommunications and computing and are %0A >      committed to working with industry and public-interest %0A >      groups to find innovative ways to protect Americans' %0A >      privacy, help businesses to compete, and ensure that law %0A >      enforcement agencies have the tools they need to fight crime %0A >      and terrorism. %0A  %0A Bullshit. The proposed technology provides a false sense of security, %0A encryption devices with built-in capabilities for breaking the %0A encryption, does not prevent the criminals to use strong crypto, and %0A is a step to outlaw strong crypto. %0A  %0A > Q %3A    Will the devices be exportable?  Will other devices that use %0A >      the government hardware? %0A  %0A > A %3A    Voice encryption devices are subject to export control %0A >      requirements.  Case-by-case review for each export is %0A >      required to ensure appropriate use of these devices.  The %0A  %0A Who was the optimist who believed that the new administration will %0A leave the export controls on strong crypto devices? %0A  %0A OK, I'm not American, it's not my business, but I just couldn't resist %0A to comment... The whole plot looks so totalitaristic... It's up to %0A you, Americans, to fight for your rights. %0A  %0A Regards, %0A Vesselin %0A  %0A P.S. Now is the time for David Sternlight to pop up and claim that the %0A new system is great. %0A --  %0A Vesselin Vladimirov Bontchev          Virus Test Center, University of Hamburg %0A Tel. %3A +49-40-54715-224, Fax %3A  +49-40-54715-226      Fachbereich Informatik - AGN %0A < PGP 2.2 public key available on request. > Vogt-Koelln-Strasse 30, rm. 107 C %0A e-mail %3A  bontchev %40 fbihh.informatik.uni-hamburg.de    D-2000 Hamburg 54, Germany %0A

doc_3040 |@raw_text From %3A  irwin %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org (Irwin Arnstein) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Cultural Enquiries %0A Message-ID %3A  <C50uGG.9As %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 5 Apr 1993 17 %3A 41 %3A 04 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Mar17.115603.28712 %40 aber.ac.uk> <1phuse$5u1 %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> %0A Organization %3A  CompuTrac Inc., Richardson TX %0A Lines %3A  24 %0A  %0A In article <1phuse$5u1 %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> egreen %40 east.sun.com writes %3A  %0A >In article 28712 %40 aber.ac.uk, azw %40 aber.ac.uk (Andy Woodward) writes %3A  %0A >>Two questions that fascinate me %3A - %0A > %0A >Check you local blue light special for a sale on lives... %0A > %0A >>1) Why are rednecks called rednecks? %0A > %0A >The origin of the slang is probably a reference to a sunburned neck, %0A >often obtained while performing honest work outdoors.  The neck is %0A >specified to distinguish these people, whose shirt-protected chest and %0A >back are pale, from the elitist wealthy, who, in their idiotic quest %0A >for darker skin pigmentation as a badge of leisure time, overdo it and %0A >get full-body sunburns. %0A > %0A  %0A More like those who use their backs instead of their minds to make %0A their living who are usually ignorant and intolerant of anything outside %0A of their group or level of understanding. %0A --  %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A "Tuba" (Irwin)      "I honk therefore I am"       CompuTrac-Richardson,Tx %0A irwin %40 cmptrc.lonestar.org    DoD #0826            (R75/6) %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  
doc_3041 |@raw_text From %3A  jca2 %40 cec1.wustl.edu (Joseph Charles Achkar) %0A Subject %3A  Blues into playoffs, beat TB 6-5 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.141217.4890 %40 wuecl.wustl.edu> %0A Keywords %3A  Blues, Shanahan, Joseph, Hull, Minnesota, TB %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 wuecl.wustl.edu (News Administrator) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  cec1 %0A Organization %3A  Washington University, St. Louis MO %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 14 %3A 12 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  127 %0A  %0A By Dave Luecking Of The Post-Dispatch Staff %0A  %0A At 9 %3A 11 Thursday night, the scoreboard watchers at The Arena began to cheer. %0A Their cheer quickly turned into a roar, and finally, the sellout crowd of %0A 17,816 rose as one to rock the old barn at 5700 Oakland Avenue in a salute to %0A the playoff-bound Blues. %0A  %0A The scoreboard had just flashed the news from Detroit -- Red Wings 5, Stars 3. %0A With the North Stars' loss, the Blues officially clinched fourth place and the %0A final playoff spot in the Norris Division. Good thing, because the Blues quit %0A playing. %0A  %0A They held a 5-1 lead over Tampa Bay when the Detroit-Minnesota final appeared %0A with 3 minutes 52 remaining in the second period. They promptly went to sleep %0A and barely held on for a 6-5 victory that nearly slipped away at the buzzer. %0A Tampa's Bob Beers tipped in a pass from Shawn Chambers, but officiating %0A supervisor John D'Amico and video goal judge Rich Schweigler ruled that the %0A shot had gone into the net after time had expired. %0A  %0A ``I'm glad I didn't see it go in at the end," Blues coach Bob Berry said. %0A  %0A If the goal had counted, he'd have been more upset than he was by the Blues' %0A disappearance in the final 24 minutes. Holding on for the victory and making %0A the playoffs tempered Berry's anger. %0A  %0A ``It wasn't pretty at the end," he said. ``We played 36, 37 great minutes, as %0A good as we played all year. It slipped away at the end. It shouldn't have, but %0A it did." %0A  %0A Still, the Blues won, prompting another ovation from the crowd at game's end. %0A Despite their shoddy effort in the third period and all the turmoil this %0A season, the Blues still made the playoffs. They'll meet the Chicago Blackhawks %0A in a best-of-seven Norris Division semifinal, beginning at noon Sunday at %0A Chicago Stadium. %0A  %0A The Blues finished the regular-season with a record of 37-36-11 for 85 points, %0A their fourth consecutive plus-.500 season. Minnesota finished three points %0A behind in fifth place, with a record of 36-38- 10 for 82 points. Tampa Bay, %0A which played spoiler last week by tying the Blues 2-2 at Tampa, ended its %0A first season with a record of 23-54-7 for 53 points. %0A  %0A The poor finish cast an unnecessary shadow over what should have been a joyous %0A Blues locker room. Instead, the mood was one of relief and some disappointment. %0A  %0A ``It's a shame we let down," said Kevin Miller, one of three Blues to score %0A two goals. Brendan Shanahan and Bob Bassen were the others. %0A ``There was no need for a letdown. If we'd have kept working, it would have %0A ended 6-2 and everyone would be happy." %0A  %0A Instead, a lot of players were happy just to make the playoffs. %0A ``We won, and that's all that matters," said Brett Hull, scoreless and minus-3 %0A for the night. ``Once we got up 4-0, it was really tough to play." %0A  %0A Some players didn't have a problem. %0A  %0A ``Just because the score was announced, our line didn't quit," said Rich %0A Sutter, who played with Bassen and Miller. ``We still had a game to play. You %0A can't allow five goals like we did, that's not right. %0A  %0A ``It was disappointing to see what was going on." %0A  %0A Bassen was almost frantic on the bench because of the Blues' effort. Somehow, %0A he missed the announcement of Minnesota's loss. %0A  %0A ``I didn't know it was final," he said. ``I was kind of looking around on the %0A bench. I didn't realize it was a final for some reason. We're in the playoffs, %0A and that's great, but it's a little disappointing to play like we did at the %0A end." %0A  %0A The letdown was precisely the reason that Berry had instructed the scoreboard %0A operators to keep the Minnesota-Detroit score off of the board. The score %0A showed 0-0 until it first popped up with Detroit leading 4-2 in the third %0A period. The Blues already led 4-0 at the time. %0A  %0A ``I told them I didn't want to see the score, I didn't want to know the score," %0A Berry said. ``I felt we had to win the game, and that's the approach we took." %0A  %0A If Minnesota took a lead, Berry feared, the pressure of having to win might %0A bother the Blues. If Detroit led, he worried, the Blues might quit. %0A  %0A Until the announcement, the Blues played splendidly. Shanahan got the crowd %0A going at 10 %3A 44 of the first period, scoring his 50th of the season. Then, %0A Miller and Bassen took charge late in the period. %0A  %0A With the teams playing four on four, Miller broke in on left wing, deked %0A defenseman Roman Hamrlik and beat former Blues goalie Pat Jablonski with the %0A rebound of his own shot with 21.6 seconds remaining in the period. %0A  %0A Then, just 10.5 seconds later, Bassen rifled a long slap shot past Jablonski %0A after defenseman Rick Zombo intercepted a Tampa pass in the neutral zone. %0A  %0A Bassen made it 4-0 just 14 seconds into the second period, scoring on the  %0A rebound of Bret Hedican's shot. The goal gave him his first two-goal game of %0A the season and reminded him of a special friend. %0A  %0A Last year, Bassen befriended young Oliver Mulvihill, who died of a rare form %0A of cancer at age 6 on Feb. 23. %0A  %0A ``I was thinking of my buddy Oliver," Bassen said. ``He's in heaven now, and %0A I know he was watching. I know he's happy." %0A  %0A Miller increased the Blues lead to 5-0 on a break-away goal set up by Zombo %0A at 11 %3A 09. Then, Steve Maltais broke Curtis Joseph's shutout just 18 seconds %0A later, making it 5-1. %0A  %0A Less than a minute after the North Stars' final was announced, Tim Bergland %0A scored and cut the lead to 5-2. But Shanahan scored his 51st, converting a pass %0A from Nelson Emerson with 21.3 seconds remaining in the  second period. %0A  %0A Then, it was all Lightning. Adam Creighton scored 40 seconds into the third %0A period, prompting Berry to rest the overworked Joseph. Guy Hebert allowed goals %0A to Shawn Chambers and Danton Cole in a span of 1 %3A 21 midway through the third %0A period. %0A  %0A The goals by Chambers and Cole made Shanahan's second goal stand up as the %0A winner. ``We were in there," Shanahan said. ``The game was over. We were in." %0A  %0A   %*%*%*%**%*%%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%* %0A   *   __  ______________         ____________________________________    %  %0A   %   \ \_)____________/         A L L E Z   L E S   B L U E S  ! ! !    *  %0A   *    \    __________/          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~    %  %0A   %     \    ________/                                                   * %0A   *      \   _______/                  Joe Ashkar                        %  %0A   %       \  \                         Contact for the Blues             * %0A   *        \  \  SAINT LOUIS           jca2 %40 cec1.wustl.edu               %  %0A   %        (___)             BLUES                                       *  %0A   *%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%*%  %0A

NASA would provide contractual launch services. However, %0A >since NASA bases its charge on seriously flawed cost estimates %0A >(WN 26 Mar 93) the taxpayers would bear most of the expense. This %0A >may look like environmental vandalism, but Mike Lawson, CEO of %0A >Space Marketing, told us yesterday that the real purpose of the %0A >project is to help the environment! The platform will carry ozone %0A >monitors he explained--advertising is just to help defray costs. %0A  %0A How could this possibly be "environmental vandalism" when there is no %0A "environment" to vandalize up there? %0A  %0A Since the advertising "is just to help defray costs", it's certainly no %0A surprise that "the taxpayers would bear most of the expense".  Sounds %0A like a good idea to me, since the taxpayers would bear _all_ of the %0A expense if they didn't do the advertising. %0A  %0A >What do you think of this revolting and hideous attempt to vandalize %0A >the night sky? %0A  %0A Great idea, they should have done it long ago. %0A  %0A >What about light pollution in observations? (I read somewhere else that %0A >it might even be visible during the day, leave alone at night). %0A  %0A I can't believe that a mile-long billboard would have any significant %0A effect on the overall sky brightness.  Venus is visible during the day, %0A but nobody complains about that.  Besides, it's in LEO, so it would only %0A be visible during twilight when the sky is already bright, and even if %0A it would have some miniscule impact, it would be only for a short time %0A as it goes zipping across the sky. %0A  %0A >Are protesting groups being organized in the States? %0A  %0A No doubt.  People are always looking for something to protest about, so %0A it would be no surprise. %0A  %0A >Really, really depressed. %0A  %0A Well, look on the, er, bright side.  Imagine the looks on the faces of %0A people in primitive tribes out in the middle of nowhere as they look up %0A and see a can of Budweiser flying across the sky...  %3A -D %0A  %0A -- %0A  %0A Jeff Cook                                  Jeff.Cook %40 FtCollinsCO.NCR.com %0A  %0A  
doc_3091 |@raw_text From %3A  dchhabra %40 stpl.ists.ca (Deepak Chhabra) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Leaf slump over %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr13.190225.29001 %40 newshub.ists.ca> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 newshub.ists.ca (News Subsystem) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  stpl.ists.ca %0A Organization %3A  Solar Terresterial Physics Laboratory, ISTS %0A References %3A  <1993Apr12.013939.23016 %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 13 Apr 1993 19 %3A 02 %3A 25 GMT %0A Lines %3A  39 %0A  %0A  %0A On March 21, 1993 Roger Maynard wrote (in reply to an article by Graham %0A Hudson) %3A  %0A  %0A >> will still have the Jennings Trophy at the end of the year. Have you even thought about what  you %0A >mean  by pressure, or are your thoughts, like most of the rest of %0A >this drivel, simply half-baked? %0A  %0A This was <1993Mar21.223936.6192 %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca>, for anybody who %0A would like to check. %0A  %0A He went on (in another article) to say [paraphrased] %0A  %0A >"Playoff hockey" is just an expression used by announcers to convince %0A >simple-minded folks like yourself that what you are seeing is a better %0A >product than a regular-season game. %0A  %0A *NOW*, however, in article <1993Apr12.013939.23016 %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca>  %0A (Roger Maynard) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >With a 4-2 win over a tough Whaler squad the Leafs showed all doubters %0A >what playoff hockey is all about.   %0A  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ %0A  %0A So, Roger, what exactly *is* playoff hockey all about? But if you look in the amp and see what components %0A  %3A  >  they use and how it was designed, you can easily see why the %0A  %3A  >  amplifiers sound so brilliant. %0A  %0A  %3A  Good point...also, I wouldn't be surprised that the components %0A  %3A  they use off-shore are of inferior quality.  As long as it was %0A  %3A  properly designed and robust, premium components are used, it %0A  %3A  shouldn't matter where it is assembled. %0A  %0A Definately, I agree wholeheartedly.  If they can build the amp where %0A   the labour is not so expensive, they can afford to put decent %0A   components in and go to more effort to improve the design of the %0A   amplifier - as Adcom has done. %0A  %0A  %3A  >I cannot see why people say the amplifier won't last - not with %0A  %3A  >  those quality components inside.  Sure the amp runs very fairly %0A  %3A  >  hot - but that's how you get an amp to sound incredibly good. %0A  %0A  %3A  An amp that runs hot has no bearing on how it's gonna sound. %0A  %3A  The amp you have probably is running Class-A the whole day. %0A  %0A  %3A  Actually, I'd be wary of excessively hot amps, 'cauz even though %0A  %3A  the components inside may be rated to run that way, excessive  %0A  %3A  heat will dramatically shorten the life of *any* electronic component %0A  %3A  regardless of quality.  In fact, an amp that does run hot to the touch is %0A  %3A  because either the engineer or manufacturer of that amp wanted %0A  %3A  to skimp on heatsinking or cooling to save costs!  Hmmmmm.... %0A  %0A Sure, I didn't mean to imply that because of the heat generated, the %0A   amp sounds good.  My Adcom GFP 535II runs fairly warm - not hot to %0A   the touch - but enough to satisfy me that the amp is running nicely. %0A I don't like it when an amp runs dead-cold.  It makes one think that %0A   the amp is doing nothing  %3A ) %0A The heatsinks that Adcom uses in their amps are certainly far for %0A   skimpy - they're massive things with heating vents both below %0A   and above.  More than enough to carry away excessive heat. %0A  %0A My opinions once again. %0A  %0A -- %0A *********************************************************************** %0A **    Alan Webber                                                    ** %0A **                      webb %40 itu1.sun.ac.za                          ** %0A **                      webb %40 itu2.sun.ac.za                          ** %0A **                                                                   ** %0A ** The path you tread is narrow and the drop is sheer and very high  ** %0A ** The ravens all are watching from a vantage point near by          ** %0A ** Apprehension creeping like a choo-train up your spine             ** %0A ** Will the tightrope reach the end; will the final couplet rhyme    ** %0A *********************************************************************** %0A
