doc_3097 |@raw_text From %3A  billn %40 hpcvaac.cv.hp.com (bill nelson) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Power, signal surges in home... %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.050806.5757 %40 hpcvaac.cv.hp.com> %0A Organization %3A  Hewlett-Packard Company, Corvallis, Oregon USA %0A References %3A  <1993Apr14.022159.5377 %40 ntg.com> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 05 %3A 08 %3A 06 GMT %0A Lines %3A  55 %0A  %0A dplatt %40 ntg.com (Dave Platt) writes %3A  %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  >What kind of power must he be putting out to cause the effects? %0A  %3A  >The affected equipment is about 100 feet from the road... %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  Might be a couple of hundred watts, from the sound of it.  Kicking sound %0A  %3A  out of the TV and stereo speakers by direct RF rectification requires a %0A  %3A  mighty strong carrier!  [I've heard of linears so powerful that %0A  %3A  triggering them while the car was idling, would stall the engine by %0A  %3A  pulling down the battery voltage.] %0A  %0A It would take a lot more than that. It sounds like the radio equipment is %0A actually not shut completely off - but just goes to a standby situation. %0A  %0A I suspect that the stories are just that, stories.  The voltage can only %0A be sucked down so far instantaneously. When you try to jumpstart someones  %0A car, when your vehicle is at idle, does your car stall? No, the other car %0A just does not crank well.  Now, the engine might stall because the idle %0A was too low to start with. When the extra current is drawn, the idle speed %0A will drop - as the alternator loads down the engine to compensate for the %0A increased amperage requirement. %0A  %0A  %3A  >Is resolution of this problem a matter for the power company, the fcc, or both? %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  Ultimately it's likely to be your problem to resolve, I'm afraid.  The %0A  %3A  FCC is so understaffed that they don't pay much attention to citizen %0A  %3A  complains about RFI (or so I've heard)... they'll just send you a %0A  %3A  pamphlet describing how you can apply corrective measures. %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  Talking to the power company might help - they might be able to install %0A  %3A  filtering devices at your service panel (or recommend a type which you %0A  %3A  could have installed by a licensed electrician). %0A  %0A A transmitter is not going to be affecting house power. If surges are %0A occurring there, it is due to another cause - not a transmitter. %0A  %0A  %3A  Unfortunately, there's a fair chance that enough signal is being picked %0A  %3A  up by your house wiring that a simple service-panel filter won't %0A  %3A  suffice.  You may need to install heavy-duty RFI filters at the power %0A  %3A  connections of your affected equipment. %0A  %0A It is probably not that much of a problem. Often - toroid coils on the %0A power leads will solve that part of the interference problem. It will %0A not solve internal equipment deficiencies. %0A  %0A  %3A  If the problem occurs regularly, you may need to "stake out" the street %0A  %3A  in question, and watch for trucks or cars with big antennae driving by %0A  %3A  at the time interference occurs.  If you can identify the vehicle which %0A  %3A  is transmitting, you may be able to contact its owner and complain. %0A  %0A It is probably not the transmitter that is at fault. If the person is an %0A amateur, then he/she will probably be willing to help - if you explain %0A that the person is causing interference. %0A  %0A Bill %0A

Books have been written on that! But in regard to %0A AeroStich it really depends on your particular size, shape and needs. %0A If you upper and lower body are not proportional (according to aero %0A dimensions) then it probably is going to be better mixing and matching %0A the 2 piece suit. I have the 2 piece suit and I am very happy with it. %0A Having my life quota of scars from crashing off road, I am very %0A concerned with good protection and I believe that the difference in %0A protection between the 1 and 2 piece suits is almost negligible. I %0A think the optional hip pads and back protector make much more of a %0A difference. One thing that is nice about the 2 piece is if you go %0A somewhere and then want to walk around for a while (still with jacket) %0A you can just detach and stow the pants.  %0A  %0A One thing to note is that Goldfine has problems getting a good fit for %0A many women (with standard suits). Supposedly for smaller women (and %0A petite men for that matter) the 1 piece will fit better.  %0A  %0A Another recommendation is to pay for mods if you need them. I wish I %0A got 2-3 inches added to my pant legs. I find the Long suits are not %0A really that long (I can't imagine how short the standard suits must %0A be).  %0A  %0A -- %0A Jonathan E. Polito 		    Internet %3A  jpolito %40 encore.com %0A Encore Computer Corp, 901 Kildaire Farm Rd, Cary, NC  27511  USA %0A 919-481-3730/voice  				919-481-3868/FAX %0A

The government told them "don't do encryption %0A if you ever hope to export this technology".  The reason that CDMA doesn't %0A have encryption is NOT because the G-men came a'knocking at Qualcomm's door. %0A It's because Qualcomm doesn't think that the US market for digital cellular %0A is big enough for them.  This is just the International Traffic in Arms %0A Regulations all over again. %0A  %0A If you don't believe me, call Qualcomm and ASK THEM.  Don't just throw %0A out conspicracy theories. Better yet, %0A >prehaps someone will produce a package that turns any 486 box with a %0A >sound card into a secure phone. %0A  %0A "Someone" this and "someone" that.  If you think it's so easy, why are %0A you whining on the net instead of getting your butt in gear and writing %0A it?  Your name would become known and loved by dozens!  But no, that would %0A require actual EFFORT. %0A  %0A 					-= Servalan =- %0A

doc_3207 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Satellite around Pluto Mission?  %0A Message-ID %3A  <C6B05B.168 %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 30 Apr 1993 15 %3A 53 %3A 29 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr30.004311.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr30.004311.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> nsmca %40 aurora.alaska.edu writes %3A  %0A >Is there a plan to put a satellite around each planet in the solar system to %0A >keep watch? ... %0A  %0A There would be some point to doing long-term monitoring of things like %0A particles and fields, not to mention atmospheric phenomena.  However, %0A there is no particular plan to establish any sort of monitoring network. %0A To be precise, there is no particular plan, period.  This is a large %0A part of the problem.  In this context, it's not surprising that unexciting %0A but useful missions like this get short shrift at budget time.  The closest %0A approach to any sort of long-term planetary monitoring mission is the %0A occasional chance to piggyback something like this on top of a flashier %0A mission like Galileo or Cassini. %0A  %0A >How about a mission (unmanned) to Pluto to stay in orbit and record things %0A >around and near and on Pluto... %0A  %0A It is most unlikely that there is much happening on Pluto that would be %0A worth monitoring, and it is a prohibitively difficult mission to fly %0A without new propulsion technology (something the planetary community %0A has firmly resisted being the guinea pigs for).  The combined need to %0A arrive at Pluto within a reasonable amount of time, and then kill nearly %0A all of the cruise velocity to settle into an orbit, is beyond what can %0A reasonably be done with current (that is, 1950s-vintage) propulsion. %0A  %0A >It could do some scanning of not only Pluto, but also of the solar system, %0A >objects near and aaroundpluto, as well as SETI and looking at the galaxy %0A >without having much of the solar system to worry about.. %0A  %0A Most of this can be done just about as well from Earth.  The few things %0A that can't be, can be done better from a Voyager-like spacecraft that is %0A *not* constrained by the need to enter orbit around a planet. %0A --  %0A SVR4 resembles a high-speed collision   %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A between SVR3 and SunOS.    - Dick Dunn  %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_3213 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  HST Servicing Mission Scheduled for 11 Days %0A Message-ID %3A  <C60zJp.85F %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  25 Apr 93 06 %3A 04 %3A 36 GMT %0A References %3A  <23APR199316425663 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> <1rd1g0$ckb %40 access.digex.net> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A In article <1rd1g0$ckb %40 access.digex.net> prb %40 access.digex.com (Pat) writes %3A  %0A >How will said re-boost be done? %0A >Grapple, HST,  stow it in Cargo bay,  do OMS burn to high altitude,   %0A >unstow  HST,   repair  gyros,  costar install,  fix solar arrays, %0A >then return to earth? %0A  %0A Actually, the reboost will probably be done last, so that there is a fuel %0A reserve during the EVAs (in case they have to chase down an adrift %0A astronaut or something like that).  But yes, you've got the idea -- the %0A reboost is done by taking the whole shuttle up. %0A  %0A >My guess is  why  bother with  usingthe shuttle to reboost? %0A >why not  grapple,  do all said fixes,   bolt a small  liquid  fueled %0A >thruster module  to  HST,   then let it make the re-boost... %0A  %0A Somebody has to build that thruster module; it's not an off-the-shelf %0A item.  Nor is it a trivial piece of hardware, since it has to include %0A attitude control (HST's own is not strong enough to compensate for things %0A like thruster imbalance), guidance (there is no provision to feed gyro %0A data from HST's own gyros to an external device), and separation (you %0A don't want it left attached afterward, if only to avoid possible %0A contamination after the telescope lid is opened again).  You also get %0A to worry about whether the lid is going to open after the reboost is %0A done and HST is inaccessible to the shuttle (the lid stays closed for %0A the duration of all of this to prevent mirror contamination from %0A thrusters and the like). %0A  %0A The original plan was to use the Orbital Maneuvering Vehicle to do the %0A reboost.  The OMV was planned to be a sort of small space tug, well %0A suited to precisely this sort of job.  Unfortunately, it was costing %0A a lot to develop and the list of definitely-known applications was %0A relatively short, so it got cancelled. %0A --  %0A SVR4 resembles a high-speed collision   %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A between SVR3 and SunOS.    - Dick Dunn  %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

Since we apparently %0A don't have the sensor base you folks have, they're installing %0A cameras at strategic points along the freeways (initial tests %0A are going to be in the Santa Clara area I'm told), with the %0A video being piped into a command center they're building %0A somewhere in the East Bay.  I'm not sure if frame grabbers or %0A cheap labor will be used to interpret the data, but large %0A multi-colored status displays will show the various routes %0A using different colors to represent the various average speeds %0A for each stretch of highway.  An announcer will sit in front %0A of the status 'wall', and will relay continuous verbal traffic %0A status to those who want to receive it.  They're apparently also %0A looking into licensing a low-AM frequency to be dedicated to %0A providing continuous audio from this system. %0A  %0A In the mean time, they'll set up large incandescent display %0A boards along the test stretch to provide commuters with data %0A on traffic conditions up ahead.  My understanding is that the %0A system is subsidized as a pilot program, and information from it %0A will be available free of charge.  Perhaps the LA system is %0A similarly free or provided at an obviously subsidized rate (read %0A "cheap"). %0A  %0A We also have the traffic reports that are broadcast on the SAP %0A audio channel of television channels 2 and 36.  These are verbal %0A reports, qualified with a identification tone to tell in-vehicle %0A receivers like the 'Auto Talk' that the information coming next is %0A applicable to a given area.  In LA, they're probably using some %0A other TV channels, but the concept is the same.  Try setting your %0A stereo TV or VCR to receive the SAP audio channel, and go station %0A jumping to find out which one is broadcasting this information. %0A I believe this program is also subsidized, making the in-vehicle %0A receivers cheap to purchase (and without having to incur monthly %0A fees to use it).  Since the makers of these in-vehicle receivers %0A don't have to pay for the broadcast (this may not be completely %0A true), they likely have no investment in keeping the system %0A up and running when the Cal Trans stuff hits the airwaves.  You %0A may have a nifty little TV audio receiver in your car, nothing %0A more, when this happens.  Perhaps a word to the wise...?  ;) %0A  %0A I think we'd all be interested in a summary post if you get more %0A info on how the LA system is networked and paid for. %0A  %0A Cheers, %0A Alan %0A <acooney %40 netcom.com> %0A  %0A

doc_3264 |@raw_text From %3A  webb %40 itu1 (90-29265  Webber  AH) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Adcom cheap products? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.105738.20864 %40 hippo.ru.ac.za> %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 93 10 %3A 57 %3A 38 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  hippo.1993Apr16.105738.20864 %0A References %3A  <mdonahue.15x9 %40 amiganet.chi.il.us> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 hippo.ru.ac.za (Usenet News Admin) %0A Followup-To %3A  rec.audio,rec.audio.car,sci.electronics %0A Organization %3A  Rhodes University, Grahamstown, South Africa %0A Lines %3A  44 %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL8] %0A  %0A  %3A  >I want to upgrade my system and was thinking of buying Adcom seperates. %0A  %3A  >I have heard from alot of people, though, that Adcom sounds great but %0A  %3A  >that the components are made cheaply and therefore won't last very long. %0A  %3A  >The time estimates I've heard are like only 3 or 4 years.  Is this true? %0A  %0A I own the Adcom 60W power amp.  As far as I'm concerned, there's no %0A   amp which can touch it at the price range. %0A The build quality is very impressive and is far superior to other  %0A   amps in the price range.  The whole amplifier is extremely solid %0A   with massive heat sinks and very solid casing. %0A If you open the amp up, there are only very good quality components  %0A   in and the amp seems to be designed extremely well.  Perfect %0A   symmetry for both channels and TWO transformers - one for each %0A   channel.  The binding posts on the back of the amplifier are %0A   virtually the same as those on the Classe model 70 ie. very good. %0A  %0A I was also sceptical about the amps being built in the far-east %0A   or where-ever.  But if you look in the amp and see what components %0A   they use and how it was designed, you can easily see why the %0A   amplifiers sound so brilliant. %0A I cannot see why people say the amplifier won't last - not with %0A   those quality components inside.  Sure the amp runs very fairly %0A   hot - but that's how you get an amp to sound incredibly good. %0A  %0A My last point, I recently auditioned the Adcom preamp something like %0A   the 545 or something.  It was two years old and it still sounded %0A   like new. %0A  %0A If you build an amplifier decently, like the Adcom's, they will %0A   sound brilliant and last a long time - period. %0A  %0A Just my thoughts, but then - I do own one of Adcom's amps. %0A  %0A -- %0A *********************************************************************** %0A **    Alan Webber                                                    ** %0A **                      webb %40 itu1.sun.ac.za                          ** %0A **                      webb %40 itu2.sun.ac.za                          ** %0A **                                                                   ** %0A ** The path you tread is narrow and the drop is sheer and very high  ** %0A ** The ravens all are watching from a vantage point near by          ** %0A ** Apprehension creeping like a choo-train up your spine             ** %0A ** Will the tightrope reach the end; will the final couplet rhyme    ** %0A *********************************************************************** %0A

doc_3277 |@raw_text From %3A  hanson %40 kronos.arc.nasa.gov (Robin Hanson) %0A Subject %3A  Estimating Wiretap Costs/Benefits %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.202629.20783 %40 kronos.arc.nasa.gov> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 kronos.arc.nasa.gov (Will Edgington, wedgingt %40 ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  jabberwock.arc.nasa.gov %0A Organization %3A  NASA/ARC Information Sciences Division %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 20 %3A 26 %3A 29 GMT %0A Lines %3A  166 %0A  %0A               WOULD WIRETAP CHIP BE COST-EFFECTIVE? %0A  %0A                         by Robin Hanson %0A                      Draft, April 21, 1993 %0A  %0A   SUMMARY %3A  Compared to an average monthly phone bill of sixty dollars, %0A   wiretaps are only worth two cents a month to police.  So the %0A   proposed wiretap chip must raise phone costs by less than one part  %0A   in three thousand to be cost-effective.  %0A  %0A BACKGROUND %0A  %0A Until now, phones have happened to allow the existence of "wiretaps", %0A detectors which could pick up conversations on a phone line.  And over %0A time, law enforcement agencies have come to rely on this capability to %0A aid in criminal investigations.  However, powerful new encryption %0A technologies threaten this status quo, by making possible truly %0A private communication.  A small chip in each phone could soon make it %0A literally impossible to overhear a conversation without physical %0A microphones at either end. %0A  %0A In order to preserve the ability of law enforcement agencies to tap %0A phone conversations, the U.S. government announced on April 16, 1993 %0A that it had developed and begun manufacturing a special "wiretap" chip %0A to be placed in future phones, instead of the total privacy chips %0A which have been under private development.  The same day, AT&T %0A announced it would use these chips "in all its secure telephone %0A products". %0A  %0A Each chip would be created under government supervision, when it would %0A be given a fixed indentifier and encryption key.  Periodically during %0A each conversation, the chip would broadcast its identifier and other %0A info in a special "law enforcement block".  Law enforcement officers %0A with a court order could then obtain the key corresponding to the %0A indentifier from special trust agencies, and could thereby listen in %0A on any future or previously recorded conversations on that phone. %0A  %0A To date, most concerns voiced about this plan have been about its %0A security.  The government won't disclose the encryption algorithm, and %0A many suspect the government will not limit its access in the way it %0A has claimed.  The track record of previous governments does not %0A inspire confidence on this point [1]. %0A  %0A However, this paper will neglect these concerns, and ask instead %0A whether this new wiretap chip is a cost-effective tool for police %0A investigation.  That is, which is a cheaper way for society to %0A investigate crime %3A  force phone communications to support wiretaps, or %0A give police agencies more money to investigate crimes in other ways? %0A Or to put it another way, would police agencies be willing to pay for %0A each wiretap, if they had to pay their share of the full social cost %0A of forcing phones to support wiretaps? %0A  %0A To start to answer this question, we might compare the current %0A benefits wiretaps provide to law enforcement agencies with projected %0A costs of implementing the new wiretap chip plan.  And since current %0A benefits are easier to estimate, we begin there. %0A  %0A WIRETAP BENEFITS %0A  %0A 1990 is the latest year for which wiretap statistics are available %0A [2].  In that year, 872 wiretap installations were requested, and no %0A requests were denied.  (This figure does not include wiretaps obtained %0A with the consent of a party to the conversation.)  2057 arrests %0A resulted from wiretaps started the same year, 1486 arrests came from %0A wiretaps in previous years, and 55% of arrests led to convictions. %0A 76% of the wiretaps were for phones (vs pagers, email, etc.), 60% were %0A regarding drug offenses, and 40% were requested by federal %0A authorities.  Each wiretap installation heard an average of 1487 %0A calls, 22% of them incriminating, among 131 people, and cost an %0A average of $45,125 (extrapolating from the 794 installations %0A reporting costs), mostly for labor. %0A  %0A Thus a total of about $40 Million was spent on wiretaps, to obtain %0A about 4000 arrests, at $10,000 per arrest.  Thus these arrests are at %0A least four times more expensive than the $2500 per arrest figure one %0A gets by dividing the $28 Billion spent by all police nationally by the %0A total 11 Million non-traffic arrests [3].  Thus the $30 Million per %0A year spent on phone taps is only one thousanth of the total police %0A expenditures.  And if we divide this by the 138 Million phone "access" %0A lines in the country [3], we get about 23 cents spent per year per %0A phone line, or about two cents a month. %0A  %0A In general, we deter a given class of criminals through a combination %0A of a perceived probability of being caught and convicted, and some %0A expected punishment level if convicted.  So the social value of having %0A wiretaps is no more than the amount that we would have to pay to get %0A the same criminal deterrence through other means.  If unable to %0A wiretap a particular suspect's phone, police might instead use hidden %0A microphones, or investigate that suspect in other ways.  Or police %0A might focus on suspects more easily investigated without wiretaps.  Or %0A we might raise the fine or prison time for certain types of crime. %0A  %0A If we generously assume that these substitutes for wiretaps would be %0A on average twice as expensive as wiretaps, then the annual social %0A benefit of phone wiretaps is about equal to the current spending level %0A of two cents a month per phone line. %0A  %0A WIRETAP COSTS %0A  %0A Let us for the moment optimistically assume that the US government %0A encryption scheme is as secure as whatever private enterprise would %0A have offered instead, protecting our conversations from the spying %0A ears of neighbors, corporations, and governments, both foreign and %0A domestic.  Even so, the need to support wiretaps would add many %0A additional costs to build and maintain our communication system. %0A  %0A Extra law enforcement blocks would be added to phone transmissions, %0A increasing traffic by some unknown percentage.  A special process must %0A be used to add encryption keys to chips, while securely distributing %0A these keys to special agencies, which must be funded and monitored. %0A The chips themselves are designed by a military contractor, whose %0A design is to remain secret, and are manufactured through a special %0A process so that the chip becomes nearly impossible to take apart. %0A (Chips are now offered at the relatively high price of $30 a peice in %0A lots of 10,000 [4].)  Private encryption systems not supporting %0A wiretaps would require none of these extra costs. %0A  %0A Perhaps most important, government degree would at least partially %0A replace private marketplace evolution of standards for how voice is to %0A be represented, encrypted, and exchanged in our future phones.  It is %0A widely believed that governments are less efficient than private %0A enterprise in procuring products and standards, though they may perhaps %0A perform a useful brokering role when we choose between competing private %0A standards.  How much less efficient is a matter of debate, some say %0A they pay twice as much, while others might say only 10% more.     %0A  %0A Currently, a total of $96 Billion is spent as operating expenses of %0A U.S. phone companies [3], which comes out to about $60 per month per %0A access line.  If we compare this to the wiretap value of two cents per %0A month, we see that if wiretaps raise average operating costs by even %0A as much as one part in 3000, then wiretaps are not cost effective! %0A And this doesn't even include extra costs phone owners pay because %0A their encryption chips are more expensive.  Of course most phones %0A wouldn't have encryption chips for a while, but the wiretap benefit %0A per phone is still the same, so this argument still applies. %0A  %0A CONCLUSION %0A  %0A Given this dramatic difference between the total cost of running the %0A phone system and the value of wiretaps, we can justify only the %0A slightest modification of the phone system to accommodate wiretaps. %0A When the only modification required was to allow investigators in to %0A attach clips to phone wires, wiretap support may have been reasonable. %0A But when we consider substantial modification, the burden of proof is %0A clearly on those proposing such modification to show that the costs %0A would really be less than the benefits.   %0A  %0A If consensus cannot be obtain on this cost/benefit estimate, a %0A compromise might be to tax phones which do not support wiretaps at a %0A rate of say five cents per month, a tax payable to police agencies %0A nationwide to compensate them for their loss of wiretap abilities. %0A  %0A [1] The Invisible Weapon, Oxford Press, ISBN 0-19-506273-6 %0A  %0A [2] Report on Applications for Orders Authorizing or Approving the %0A     Interception of Wire, Oral, or Electronic Communications, 1990, %0A     Administrative Office of U.S. Courts, Washington, DC 20544. %0A  %0A [3] U.S. Statistical Abstracts, 1992.   %0A  %0A [4] Dorothy Denning, "The Clipper Chip %3A  A Technical Summary", %0A     distributed to sci.crypt newsgroup April 21, 1993.  %0A --  %0A Robin Hanson  hanson %40 ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov  %0A 415-604-3361  MS-269-2, NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA 94035 %0A 510-651-7483  47164 Male Terrace, Fremont, CA  94539-7921  %0A

doc_3329 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Re %3A  How large are commercial keys? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.121733.15544 %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz> %0A From %3A  pgut1 %40 cs.aukuni.ac.nz (Peter Gutmann) %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 12 %3A 17 %3A 33 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.182038.12009 %40 ee.eng.ohio-state.edu> %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Dept. University of Auckland %0A Lines %3A  17 %0A  %0A In <1993Apr20.182038.12009 %40 ee.eng.ohio-state.edu> butzerd %40 maumee.eng.ohio-state.edu (Dane C. Butzer) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >What are the typical sizes for keys for commercial secret key algorithms? %0A >I know DES is 56 bits ("tripple DES" is 112 bits) and IDEA is 128 bits.  Is %0A >there anything made in the US that has 128 bit keys?  Anything anywhere %0A >that has larger keys?  I've heard that RC2 can be scaled to arbitrarily %0A >large keys, but is this actually implemented anywhere? %0A  %0A My MDC cipher (which uses any one-way hash function as a CFB-mode stream %0A cipher, the current implementation uses MD5) uses a key of up to 2048 bits %0A (that is, you can use a 1-bit key if you want and copy it over the entire %0A 2048-bit range, or you can use the entire 2048 bits).  Runtime is %0A independant of key size, the system runs slightly slower than MD5 itself. %0A I presume RC2 and RC4 use a similar system (or possibly they just hash an %0A arbitrary-length key down to n bits, maybe 128, using something like MD5). %0A  %0A Peter. %0A

doc_3350 |@raw_text From %3A  egreen %40 east.sun.com (Ed Green - Pixel Cruncher) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  where to put your helmet %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 1993 16 %3A 57 %3A 35 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Sun Microsystems, RTP, NC %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r3udv$k35 %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> %0A References %3A  <10498.97.uupcb %40 compdyn.questor.org> %0A Reply-To %3A  egreen %40 east.sun.com %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  laser.east.sun.com %0A  %0A In article uupcb %40 compdyn.questor.org, ryan_cousineau %40 compdyn.questor.org (Ryan Cousineau) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >Another good place for your helmet is your mirror (!). I kid you not. If %0A >you own a typical standard or other bike with fairly average mirrors %0A >that screw into your handlebars, your helmet should fit over your mirror %0A >and be fairly stable %0A  %0A Be careful that you do not have any weight of the helmet resting on the %0A mirror.  It will depress the foam liner in the helmet.  That is not the %0A kind of foam that bounces back, like foam rubber.  Its purpose in life %0A is to absorb energy in an impact as it is compressed by your noggin. %0A If your mirror compresses it, there is that much less energy absorbing %0A capacity left to cushon your noggin in a crash. %0A  %0A I found the right handlebar to be a good spot, if on the sidestand. %0A Hang with the chinbar facing up, balanced across the grip and brake %0A lever such that the weight of the helmet doesn't compress any of the %0A chinbar foam.  This is more challanging with an open face helmet. %0A  %0A --- %0A Ed Green, former Ninjaite %7CI was drinking last night with a biker, %0A   Ed.Green %40 East.Sun.COM   %7Cand I showed him a picture of you.  I said, %0A DoD #0111  (919)460-8302  %7C"Go on, get to know her, you'll like her!" %0A  (The Grateful Dead) -->  %7CIt seemed like the least I could do... %0A  %0A  
doc_3352 |@raw_text From %3A  leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech) %0A Subject %3A  Space FAQ 12/15 - Controversial Questions %0A Keywords %3A  Frequently Asked Questions %0A Message-ID %3A  <controversy_733694426 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Date %3A  1 Apr 93 10 %3A 00 %3A 29 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  cs.controversy_733694426 %0A Expires %3A  6 May 1993 20 %3A 00 %3A 26 GMT %0A References %3A  <diffs_733693816 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill %0A Lines %3A  252 %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Supersedes %3A  <controversy_730956589 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mahler.cs.unc.edu %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  space/controversy %0A Last-modified %3A  $Date %3A  93/04/01 14 %3A 39 %3A 06 $ %0A  %0A CONTROVERSIAL QUESTIONS %0A  %0A     These issues periodically come up with much argument and few facts being %0A     offered. The summaries below attempt to represent the position on which %0A     much of the net community has settled. Please DON'T bring them up again %0A     unless there's something truly new to be discussed. The net can't set %0A     public policy, that's what your representatives are for. %0A  %0A  %0A     WHAT HAPPENED TO THE SATURN V PLANS %0A  %0A     Despite a widespread belief to the contrary, the Saturn V blueprints %0A     have not been lost. They are kept at Marshall Space Flight Center on %0A     microfilm. %0A  %0A     The problem in re-creating the Saturn V is not finding the drawings, it %0A     is finding vendors who can supply mid-1960's vintage hardware (like %0A     guidance system components), and the fact that the launch pads and VAB %0A     have been converted to Space Shuttle use, so you have no place to launch %0A     from. %0A  %0A     By the time you redesign to accommodate available hardware and re-modify %0A     the launch pads, you may as well have started from scratch with a clean %0A     sheet design. %0A  %0A  %0A     WHY DATA FROM SPACE MISSIONS ISN'T IMMEDIATELY AVAILABLE %0A  %0A     Investigators associated with NASA missions are allowed exclusive access %0A     for one year after the data is obtained in order to give them an %0A     opportunity to analyze the data and publish results without being %0A     "scooped" by people uninvolved in the mission. However, NASA frequently %0A     releases examples (in non-digital form, e.g. photos) to the public early %0A     in a mission. %0A  %0A  %0A     RISKS OF NUCLEAR (RTG) POWER SOURCES FOR SPACE PROBES %0A  %0A     There has been extensive discussion on this topic sparked by attempts to %0A     block the Galileo and Ulysses launches on grounds of the plutonium %0A     thermal sources being dangerous. Numerous studies claim that even in %0A     worst-case scenarios (shuttle explosion during launch, or accidental %0A     reentry at interplanetary velocities), the risks are extremely small. %0A     Two interesting data points are (1) The May 1968 loss of two SNAP 19B2 %0A     RTGs, which landed intact in the Pacific Ocean after a Nimbus B weather %0A     satellite failed to reach orbit. The fuel was recovered after 5 months %0A     with no release of plutonium. (2) In April 1970, the Apollo 13 lunar %0A     module reentered the atmosphere and its SNAP 27 RTG heat source, which %0A     was jettisoned, fell intact into the 20,000 feet deep Tonga Trench in %0A     the Pacific Ocean. The corrosion resistant materials of the RTG are %0A     expected to prevent release of the fuel for a period of time equal to 10 %0A     half-lives of the Pu-238 fuel or about 870 years [DOE 1980]. %0A  %0A     To make your own informed judgement, some references you may wish to %0A     pursue are %3A  %0A  %0A     A good review of the technical facts and issues is given by Daniel %0A     Salisbury in "Radiation Risk and Planetary Exploration-- The RTG %0A     Controversy," *Planetary Report*, May-June 1987, pages 3-7. Another good %0A     article, which also reviews the events preceding Galileo's launch, %0A     "Showdown at Pad 39-B," by Robert G. Nichols, appeared in the November %0A     1989 issue of *Ad Astra*. (Both magazines are published by pro-space %0A     organizations, the Planetary Society and the National Space Society %0A     respectively.) %0A  %0A     Gordon L Chipman, Jr., "Advanced Space Nuclear Systems" (AAS 82-261), in %0A     *Developing the Space Frontier*, edited by Albert Naumann and Grover %0A     Alexander, Univelt, 1983, p. 193-213. %0A  %0A     "Hazards from Plutonium Toxicity", by Bernard L. Cohen, Health Physics, %0A     Vol 32 (may) 1977, page 359-379. %0A  %0A     NUS Corporation, Safety Status Report for the Ulysses Mission %3A  Risk %0A     Analysis (Book 1). Document number is NUS 5235; there is no GPO #; %0A     published Jan 31, 1990. %0A  %0A     NASA Office of Space Science and Applications, *Final Environmental %0A     Impact Statement for the Ulysses Mission (Tier 2)*, (no serial number or %0A     GPO number, but probably available from NTIS or NASA) June 1990. %0A  %0A     [DOE 1980] U.S.  Department of Energy, *Transuranic Elements in the %0A     Environment*, Wayne C.  Hanson, editor; DOE Document No.  DOE/TIC-22800; %0A     Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C., April 1980.) %0A  %0A  %0A     IMPACT OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE ON THE OZONE LAYER %0A  %0A     From time to time, claims are made that chemicals released from %0A     the Space Shuttle's Solid Rocket Boosters (SRBs) are responsible %0A     for a significant amount of damage to the ozone layer. Studies %0A     indicate that they in reality have only a minute impact, both in %0A     absolute terms and relative to other chemical sources. The %0A     remainder of this item is a response from the author of the quoted %0A     study, Charles Jackman. %0A  %0A     The atmospheric modelling study of the space shuttle effects on the %0A     stratosphere involved three independent theoretical groups, and was %0A     organized by Dr. Michael Prather, NASA/Goddard Institute for Space %0A     Studies.  The three groups involved Michael Prather and Maria Garcia %0A     (NASA/GISS), Charlie Jackman and Anne Douglass (NASA/Goddard Space %0A     Flight Center), and Malcolm Ko and Dak Sze (Atmospheric and %0A     Environmental Research, Inc.).  The effort was to look at the effects %0A     of the space shuttle and Titan rockets on the stratosphere. %0A  %0A     The following are the estimated sources of stratospheric chlorine %3A  %0A  %0A        Industrial sources %3A     300,000,000 kilograms/year %0A 	  Natural sources %3A      75,000,000 kilograms/year %0A 	  Shuttle sources %3A 	  725,000 kilograms/year %0A  %0A     The shuttle source assumes 9 space shuttles and 6 Titan rockets are %0A     launched yearly. Thus the launches would add less than 0.25% to the %0A     total stratospheric chlorine sources. %0A  %0A     The effect on ozone is minimal %3A   global yearly average total ozone would %0A     be decreased by 0.0065%. This is much less than total ozone variability %0A     associated with volcanic activity and solar flares. %0A  %0A     The influence of human-made chlorine products on ozone is computed %0A     by atmospheric model calculations to be a 1% decrease in globally %0A     averaged ozone between 1980 and 1990. The influence of the space shuttle and %0A     Titan rockets on the stratosphere is negligible.  The launch %0A     schedule of the Space Shuttle and Titan rockets would need to be %0A     increased by over a factor of a hundred in order to have about %0A     the same effect on ozone as our increases in industrial halocarbons %0A     do at the present time. %0A  %0A     Theoretical results of this study have been published in _The Space %0A     Shuttle's Impact on the Stratosphere_, MJ Prather, MM Garcia, AR %0A     Douglass, CH Jackman, M.K.W. Ko and N.D. Sze, Journal of Geophysical %0A     Research, 95, 18583-18590, 1990. %0A  %0A     Charles Jackman, Atmospheric Chemistry and Dynamics Branch, %0A     Code 916, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, %0A     Greenbelt, MD  20771 %0A  %0A     Also see _Chemical Rockets and the Environment_, A McDonald, R Bennett, %0A     J Hinshaw, and M Barnes, Aerospace America, May 1991. %0A  %0A  %0A     HOW LONG CAN A HUMAN LIVE UNPROTECTED IN SPACE %0A  %0A     If you *don't* try to hold your breath, exposure to space for half a %0A     minute or so is unlikely to produce permanent injury. Holding your %0A     breath is likely to damage your lungs, something scuba divers have to %0A     watch out for when ascending, and you'll have eardrum trouble if your %0A     Eustachian tubes are badly plugged up, but theory predicts -- and animal %0A     experiments confirm -- that otherwise, exposure to vacuum causes no %0A     immediate injury. You do not explode. Your blood does not boil. You do %0A     not freeze. You do not instantly lose consciousness. %0A  %0A     Various minor problems (sunburn, possibly "the bends", certainly some %0A     [mild, reversible, painless] swelling of skin and underlying tissue) %0A     start after ten seconds or so. At some point you lose consciousness from %0A     lack of oxygen. Injuries accumulate. After perhaps one or two minutes, %0A     you're dying. The limits are not really known. %0A  %0A     References %3A  %0A  %0A     _The Effect on the Chimpanzee of Rapid Decompression to a Near Vacuum_, %0A     Alfred G. Koestler ed., NASA CR-329 (Nov 1965). %0A  %0A     _Experimental Animal Decompression to a Near Vacuum Environment_, R.W. %0A     Bancroft, J.E. Dunn, eds, Report SAM-TR-65-48 (June 1965), USAF School %0A     of Aerospace Medicine, Brooks AFB, Texas. %0A  %0A  %0A     HOW THE CHALLENGER ASTRONAUTS DIED %0A  %0A     The Challenger shuttle launch was not destroyed in an explosion. This is %0A     a well-documented fact; see the Rogers Commission report, for example. %0A     What looked like an explosion was fuel burning after the external tank %0A     came apart. The forces on the crew cabin were not sufficient to kill the %0A     astronauts, never mind destroy their bodies, according to the Kerwin %0A     team's medical/forensic report. %0A  %0A     The astronauts were killed when the more-or-less intact cabin hit the %0A     water at circa 200MPH, and their bodies then spent several weeks %0A     underwater. Their remains were recovered, and after the Kerwin team %0A     examined them, they were sent off to be buried. %0A  %0A  %0A     USING THE SHUTTLE BEYOND LOW EARTH ORBIT %0A  %0A     You can't use the shuttle orbiter for missions beyond low Earth orbit %0A     because it can't get there. It is big and heavy and does not carry %0A     enough fuel, even if you fill part of the cargo bay with tanks. %0A  %0A     Furthermore, it is not particularly sensible to do so, because much of %0A     that weight is things like wings, which are totally useless except in %0A     the immediate vicinity of the Earth. The shuttle orbiter is highly %0A     specialized for travel between Earth's surface and low orbit. Taking it %0A     higher is enormously costly and wasteful. A much better approach would %0A     be to use shuttle subsystems to build a specialized high-orbit %0A     spacecraft. %0A  %0A     [Yet another concise answer by Henry Spencer.] %0A  %0A  %0A     THE "FACE ON MARS" %0A  %0A     There really is a big rock on Mars that looks remarkably like a humanoid %0A     face. It appears in two different frames of Viking Orbiter imagery %3A  %0A     35A72 (much more facelike in appearance, and the one more often %0A     published, with the Sun 10 degrees above western horizon) and 70A13 %0A     (with the Sun 27 degrees from the west). %0A  %0A     Science writer Richard Hoagland has championed the idea that the Face is %0A     artificial, intended to resemble a human, and erected by an %0A     extraterrestrial civilization. Most other analysts concede that the %0A     resemblance is most likely accidental. Other Viking images show a %0A     smiley-faced crater and a lava flow resembling Kermit the Frog elsewhere %0A     on Mars. There exists a Mars Anomalies Research Society (sorry, don't %0A     know the address) to study the Face. %0A  %0A     The Mars Observer mission will carry an extremely high-resolution %0A     camera, and better images of the formation will hopefully settle this %0A     question in a few years. In the meantime, speculation about the Face is %0A     best carried on in the altnet group alt.alien.visitors, not sci.space or %0A     sci.astro. %0A  %0A     V. DiPeitro and G. Molenaar, *Unusual Martian Surface Features*, Mars %0A     Research, P.O. Box 284, Glen Dale, Maryland, USA, 1982. $18 by mail. %0A  %0A     R.R. Pozos, *The Face of Mars*, Chicago Review Press, 1986. [Account of %0A     an interdisciplinary speculative conference Hoagland organized to %0A     investigate the Face] %0A  %0A     R.C. Hoagland, *The Monuments of Mars %3A  A City on the Edge of Forever*, %0A     North Atlantic Books, Berkeley, California, USA, 1987. [Elaborate %0A     discussion of evidence and speculation that formations near the Face %0A     form a city] %0A  %0A     M.J. Carlotto, "Digital Imagery Analysis of Unusual Martian Surface %0A     Features," *Applied Optics*, 27, pp. 1926-1933, 1987. [Extracts %0A     three-dimensional model for the Face from the 2-D images] %0A  %0A     M.J. Carlotto & M.C. Stein, "A Method of Searching for Artificial %0A     Objects on Planetary Surfaces," *Journal of the British Interplanetary %0A     Society*, Vol. 43 no. 5 (May 1990), p.209-216. [Uses a fractal image %0A     analysis model to guess whether the Face is artificial] %0A  %0A     B. O'Leary, "Analysis of Images of the `Face' on Mars and Possible %0A     Intelligent Origin," *JBIS*, Vol. 43 no. 5 (May 1990), p. 203-208. %0A     [Lights Carlotto's model from the two angles and shows it's consistent; %0A     shows that the Face doesn't look facelike if observed from the surface] %0A  %0A  %0A NEXT %3A  FAQ #13/15 - Space activist/interest/research groups & space publications %0A  
doc_3359 |@raw_text From %3A  abjoern %40 idt.unit.no (Anders Bjoernestad) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How universal are phones these days? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.125317.18656 %40 ugle.unit.no> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 ugle.unit.no (NetNews Administrator) %0A Reply-To %3A  abjoern %40 idt.unit.no (Anders Bjoernestad) %0A Organization %3A  Div. of CS & Telematics, Norwegian Institute of Technology %0A References %3A  <1rg36hINNsr6 %40 darkstar.UCSC.EDU> <WD.93Apr26122020 %40 sam.cs.tu-berlin.de> <1rgka2$n4k %40 corax.udac.uu.se> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 93 12 %3A 53 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A In article <1rgka2$n4k %40 corax.udac.uu.se>, tde9106 %40 hgs.se (Joakim Gunnarsson) writes %3A  %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> >Two things to watch for %3A  %0A %7C> >In Germany (and I think the same holds for Sweden) only some %0A %7C> >of the connections can handle tone dialing, so make sure the %0A %7C> >phone can be set to pulse dialing. %0A %7C> >In Sweden, the '0' is the first digit and all other digits %0A %7C> >are pushed "down" by one position; this makes dialing (and %0A %7C> >in the process converting numbers) an interesting task. %0A %7C>  %0A  %0A I think all connections in Norway can handle touchtone dialing. %0A  %0A %7C> Not to touchtone. %0A %7C> Btw; Norway is even more interesting. They got both system! So you need different phones depending on where in the country you live. %0A %7C>  %0A The Oslo-region has one system, the rest of the country another system. %0A  %0A %7C> So you need different phones depending on where in the country you %0A %7C> live. %0A (Almost right for pulsdialing.) %0A Some phones have a little switch inside, so you are able to use them %0A all over Norway, or you can just renumber the numbers on your phone. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Anders Bj{\o}rnestad %0A Division of Computer Science and Telematics %0A Norwegian Inst. of Technology, Trondheim, Norway %0A Email  %3A  abjoern %40 idt.unit.no    (Internet) %0A X.400  %3A  C=no; PRMD=uninett; O=unit; OU=idt; S=abjoern   %0A  
doc_3361 |@raw_text From %3A  eder %40 hsvaic.boeing.com (Dani Eder) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Guns for Space %0A Keywords %3A  Sopa Gun, Space Launcer %0A Message-ID %3A  <2024 %40 hsvaic.boeing.com> %0A Date %3A  5 Apr 93 17 %3A 35 %3A 23 GMT %0A References %3A  <stephens.733592474 %40 ngis> <1pcpsb$qed %40 access.digex.com> %0A Organization %3A  Boeing AI Center, Huntsville, AL %0A Lines %3A  72 %0A  %0A  %0A Okay, lets get the record straight on the Livermore gas gun.   %0A The project manager is Dr. John Hunter, and he works for the %0A Laser group at Livermore.  What, you may ask, does gas guns %0A have to do with lasers? Nothing, really, but the gun is physically %0A located across the road from the Free Electron Laser building, %0A and the FEL building has a heavily shielded control room (thick walls) %0A from which the gun firings are controlled.  So I suspect that the %0A office he works for is an administrative convenience. %0A  %0A I visited Hunter at the beginning of Feb. and we toured the gun. %0A At the time I was working on gas gun R&D at Boeing, where I work, %0A but I am now doing other things (helping to save the space station), %0A  %0A The gun uses a methane-air mixture, which is burned in a chamber %0A about 200 ft long by 16 inch ID (i.e. it looks like a pipe). %0A The chamber holds a 1 ton piston which is propelled at several %0A hundred m/s down the chamber.  On the other side of the piston %0A is hudrogen gas, initially at room temperature andsome tens %0A of atmospheres. %0A  %0A The piston compresses and heats the hydrogen ahead of it until %0A a stainless steel burst diaphragm ruptures, at around 50,000 psi. %0A The barrel of the gun is about 100 feet long and has a 4 inch %0A bore.  It is mounted at right angles to the chamber (i.e. they %0A intersect).  This was done so that in the future, the barrel %0A could be raised and the gun fired into the air without having to %0A move the larger and heavier chamber.  The projectile being used %0A in testing is a 5 kg cylinder of Lexan plastic, 4 in in diameter %0A and about 50 cm long. %0A  %0A All of the acceleration comes from the expansion of the hydrogen %0A gas from 50,000 psi downwards until the projectile leaves the %0A barrel.  The barrel is evacuated, and the end is sealed with a %0A sheet of plastic film (a little thicker than Saran wrap).  The %0A plastic is blown off by the small amount of residual air trapped %0A in the barrel ahead of the projectile.   %0A  %0A The gun is fired into a bunker filled with sandbags and plastic %0A water jugs.  In the early testing fragments of the plastic %0A projectile were found.  At the higher speeds in later testing, %0A the projectile vaporizes. %0A  %0A The testing is into a bunker because the Livermore test range is %0A about 3 miles across, and the projectile would go 100-200 km %0A if fired for maximum range.  The intent is to move the whole gun %0A to Vandenberg AFB after the testing is complete, where they can %0A fire into the Pacific Ocean, and use the tracking radar at VAFB %0A to follow the projectiles. %0A  %0A The design goal of the gun is to throw a 5 kg projectile at 4 %0A km/s (half of orbital speed).  So far they have reached 2 km/s, %0A and the gun is currently down for repairs, as on the last test %0A they blew a seal and damaged some of the hardware (I think it %0A had to do with the methane-air more detonating than burning, but %0A I haven't had a chance to talk to Hunter directly on this). %0A  %0A There are people waiting to test scramjet components in this %0A gun by firing then out of the gun into the air (at Mach 12= %0A 4 km/s), since the most you can get in wind tunnels is Mach 8. %0A  %0A This gun cost about 4 million to develop, and is basically %0A a proof-of-concept for a bigger gun capable of firing useful- %0A sized payloads into space.  This would require on the order of %0A 100 kg projectiles, which deliver on the order of 20 kg %0A useful payload to orbit. %0A  %0A Dani Eder %0A  %0A --  %0A Dani Eder/Meridian Investment Company/(205)464-2697(w)/232-7467(h)/ %0A Rt.1, Box 188-2, Athens AL 35611/Location %3A  34deg 37' N 86deg 43' W +100m alt. %0A

Thanks in advance. %0A

doc_3396 |@raw_text From %3A  jkatz %40 access.digex.com (Jordan Katz) %0A Subject %3A  SSRT Roll-Out Speech %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 1993 22 %3A 09 %3A 32 -0400 %0A Organization %3A  Express Access Online Communications, Greenbelt, MD USA %0A Lines %3A  101 %0A Distribution %3A  usa %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r4uos$jid %40 access.digex.net> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  access.digex.net %0A  %0A                                SSRT ROLLOUT %0A  %0A                 Speech Delivered by Col. Simon P. Worden, %0A                      The Deputy for Technology, SDIO %0A                                      %0A                   Mcdonnell Douglas - Huntington Beach %0A                               April 3,1993 %0A  %0A      Most of you, as am I, are "children of the 1960's."  We grew %0A up in an age of miracles -- Inter-Continental Ballistic Missiles, %0A nuclear energy, computers, flights to the moon.  But these were %0A miracles of our parent's doing.  For a decade and more the pundits %0A have told us - "you've lost it!"  The "me" generation is only %0A living on the accomplishments of the past. %0A  %0A      You and I have even begun to believe the pessimists.  We %0A listen in awe as the past generation tells of its triumphs.  Living %0A history they are.  We are privileged to hear those who did it tell %0A of it.  A few weeks ago some of this very team listened in awe as %0A General Bernie Schriever told of his team's work - and yes struggle %0A - to build this nation's Intercontinental Ballistic Missile. %0A  %0A      What stories can we tell?  Blurry-eyed telescopes?  Thousand %0A dollar toilet seats?  Even our space launch vehicles hearken only %0A of that past great time.  They are and seem destined to remain Gen. %0A Schriever's ICBMs.  I find it hard to swell with pride that the %0A best new space-lifter idea is to refurbish old Minuteman and %0A Poseidon ballistic missiles. %0A  %0A      Well - The pessimists are wrong.  The legacy is continuing.  %0A This event is proof.  To our technological parents %3A  We've listened %0A to your stories.  We've caught your enthusiasm and can-do spirit.  %0A And we've learned from your achievements - and your mistakes.  Let %0A me honor one of you who was part of that history and the impetus %0A behind this history - Max Hunter.  You are one of the greatest %0A engineers of the firts great age of space exploration.  Your %0A insight and discipline built the Thor ICBM - later incorporated %0A into today's most successful launch vehicle - The Delta. %0A  %0A      You told us in the 60's that a new form of launch vehicle - a %0A single stage reusable rocket - can and should be built.  You %0A advocated this idea tirelessly.  It was elegantly simple, as are %0A all great breakthroughs.  You showed us how to build it.  You %0A convinced us it could be done.  You are working by our side to weld %0A its components into place.  Most important - you reminded us of a %0A prime engineering principle - undoubtably one you learned from the %0A generation before you - the generation that built transcontinental %0A aviation in the 1920's and 30's - build a little and test a little %0A and Max, you passed all of this on  to people like Pat Ladner who %0A started this program for the SDI. %0A  %0A      Douglas Aircraft didn't start with a DC-10.  They didn't even %0A start with a DC-3.  Our grandfathers built a little, tested a %0A little - even sold a little and made a little money - before they %0A moved on to the next step.  They didn't take a decade or more %0A before putting the first "rubber on the road."  Max Hunter - you %0A didn't take ten years to build Thor, and by God we're not going to %0A take ten years to show that low cost, single stage, reusable %0A aerospace transportation is real. %0A  %0A      We ended the cold war in a few short years.  It took the  same %0A team here today but a few years to show through the Strategic %0A Defense Initiative that the cold war must end.  We - you and us - %0A launched a series of satellites - The Delta experiments - in about %0A a year apiece.  This, more than anything else signaled our %0A commitment to end the impasse between ourselves and the Soviet %0A Union.  Those who made the decisions on both sides have underscored %0A the importance of our work in bringing about a new international %0A relationship. %0A  %0A      But it is the same team which is now  putting in place the %0A framework for an aerospace expansion that is our legacy for the %0A next generation.  We will make space access routine and affordable. %0A  %0A      We built this magnificent flying machine in two years.  This %0A summer a true rocket ship will take off and land on earth for the %0A first time.  Then we can and surely will build in the next three %0A years a reusable sub-orbital rocket.  It will allow us to use space %0A rapidly, affordably, and efficiently as no other nation can.  And %0A yes - we'll make a little money off it too! %0A  %0A      Then - and only then - we'll spend another three years to %0A build a fully reusable single stage to orbit system.  The DC-3 of %0A space will be a reality!  We may even be able to use some of the %0A rocket propulsion breakthroughs of our former cold war adversaries.  %0A What a wonderful irony if this SDI product and Russian efforts to %0A counter SDI merge to power mankind's next step to the stars! %0A  %0A      To be sure, we must guard against the temptations to leap to %0A the final answer.  Robert Goddard's first rockets weren't Saturn %0A V's!  If we succumb  to the temptation to ask  for just a few extra %0A dollars and a few more years to jump immediately to a full orbital %0A system - we will fail.  Max Hunter and his colleagues showed the %0A way.  Three years and a cloud of dust - in our case rocket %0A exhausts.  There is no short-cut.  If we expect to reshape the %0A world again - we must do it one brick at a time.  Minds on tasks at %0A hand! %0A  %0A      This project is real.  The torch of American technological %0A greatness is being passed.  We are Americans.  This machine is %0A American.  Let's go fly it! %0A

doc_3409 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Keeping Spacecraft on after Funding Cuts. %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5y0pp.n0w %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 15 %3A 36 %3A 57 GMT %0A References %3A  <1r2c9c$l04 %40 access.digex.net> <1993Apr22.003719.101323 %40 zeus.calpoly.edu> <1r6aqr$dnv %40 access.digex.net> <C5w5zJ.HHq %40 murdoch.acc.Virginia.EDU> <19930423.010821.639 %40 almaden.ibm.com> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  15 %0A  %0A In article <19930423.010821.639 %40 almaden.ibm.com> nicho %40 vnet.ibm.com writes %3A  %0A >>Since we don't have the money to keep them going now, how will %0A >>changing them to a seperate agency help anything? %0A >> %0A >How about transferring control to a non-profit organisation that is %0A >able to accept donations to keep craft operational. %0A  %0A The problem is, you can't raise adequate amounts of money that way. %0A The Viking Fund tried. doc_3443 |@raw_text From %3A  pjc %40 jet.uk (Peter J Card) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Over zealous shuttle critics %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993May17.132139.17843 %40 jet.uk> %0A Organization %3A  Joint European Torus %0A References %3A  <1suq8lINN1c5 %40 no-names.nerdc.ufl.edu> <1t0u58$fj9 %40 access.digex.net> <pgf.737431319 %40 srl03.cacs.usl.edu> <1t2oetINNj3o %40 phantom.gatech.edu> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 17 May 1993 13 %3A 21 %3A 39 GMT %0A Lines %3A  40 %0A  %0A We`ve had the the Great Western, the [ dunno ] and the Great Northern %0A postulated as Brunel`s masterpiece. Keep boxing the compass chaps, you`ll %0A get round to it eventually. %0A  %0A The Great Western was a highly successful transatlantic mail ship, %0A with hybrid sail and steam propulsion. The Great Eastern, which broke %0A the 'Little Giant' financially and otherwise, was a revolutionary leap %0A forward in ship design. A thirty thousand ton all steel vessel, with %0A primary steam propulsion, it was at the time easily the biggest ocean %0A going vessel ever built. Brunel took advantage of the fact that cargo %0A and / or fuel capacity rose with the cube of scale, while drag rose %0A with the square, so a really big ship could steam thousands of miles %0A without coaling. %0A  %0A Unfortunately, there was no real market for such a beast at the time, %0A and it was eventually sold off at scrap values. As another poster %0A said, it then went on to a successful career as a telegraph cable %0A laying ship. It was in fact the only ship of its day capable of laying %0A a transatlantic cable in one go, with the endurance and capacity to %0A carry the huge reel all the way, and the manoeuverabilty to dredge for %0A defective sections. See Arthur C Clarke`s book "How the World was One" %0A [ I think that`s right ] %0A  %0A If that`s how the Shuttle goes down in history, as a technical triumph %0A and a financial disaster for the builder, it would not be entirely %0A ignoble, but I doubt if history will be so charitable.  Its true the %0A Shuttle can do things no other launch system can do, but are they %0A worth doing? With low cost access to space, you could have an %0A affordable space station for doing shuttle-like extended manned %0A missions. As it is, the shuttle is not so much a space-truck as a %0A space-RV, ( only not so cheap to run  %3A -( ) %0A --  %0A __._____.___._____.__._______________________________________________________ %0A __%7C_. ._%7C ._%7C_._._%7C__%7C Peter Card, Joint European Torus, Abingdon %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C_. %7C %7C    %7C Oxfordshire OX14 3EA UK. tel 0235-464867 FAX 464404 %0A     %7C %7C %7C  _%7C %7C %7C    %7C email pjc %40 jet.uk or compuserve 100010,366  %0A   ._%7C %7C %7C %7C_. %7C %7C    %7C It wasnt me. It was the others. They made me do it. %0A --`--~'-+---+-+-+----+------------------------------------------------------- %0A - Disclaimer %3A  Please note that the above is a personal view and should not  %0A   be construed as an official comment from the JET project. %0A  
doc_3445 |@raw_text From %3A  peter.m %40 insane.apana.org.au (Peter Tryndoch) %0A Sender %3A  FredMail %40 insane.apana.org.au %0A Subject %3A  What'S Exactly In A Flour %0A Message-ID %3A  <734953838.AA00509 %40 insane.apana.org.au> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 15 Apr 1993 23 %3A 34 %3A 06 %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A AllMartin MccormickWhat's Exactly in a Flour %0A  %0A MM>From %3A  martin %40 datacomm.ucc.okstate.edu (Martin McCormick) %0A MM>Organization %3A  Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK %0A MM>	What sort of lamp is the little glass bulb found inside the  %0A starter? %0A MM>It sort of reminds me of a NE2 neon lamp.  Starters appear open when m %0A MM>with an Ohm meter so the little lamp is either a neon or has a capacit %0A MM>in series with it. %0A MM>  %0A MM>	I have seen these things all my life, but never read a really good %0A MM>description of what is happening inside that little can. %0A  %0A Do you know what a bi-metallic strip is? %0A Just in case %3A  it is two strips of different metals bonded together, which  %0A when heated bend to one side (check out the blinker globe in your  %0A christmas tree lights). %0A  %0A So when you turn on the power, this causes the bulb to work like a neon,  %0A heating up and shorting out, thus providing a loop to power the heaters in  %0A the main tube. When the tube fires, insufficient current runs through the  %0A starter to keep the heat up and the bi-metalic strip straightens out  %0A (O/C). %0A  %0A BTW, I too thought that they were nothing more than a small neon, so one  %0A day when the neon in my sisters digital (flip the metal squares type)  %0A clock broke (flimsy leads), I replaced it with one from a starter. Well  %0A powering up made a bit of a mess of the clock! %0A  %0A Cheers %0A Peter T.    %0A  %0A

As far as being conductive goes anything with %0A a resistance less than 10 to the fouthrth power ohms per cubic measure %0A is classed as conductive per MIL-STD-1686 for ESD protection. doc_3469 |@raw_text Subject %3A  ROCKET LAUNCH OBSERVED! %0A From %3A  leo.wikholm %40 compart.fi (Leo Wikholm) %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1f.5893.2461.0NB61AB5 %40 compart.fi> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 93 20 %3A 58 %3A 00 +0200 %0A Organization %3A  ComPart BBS, Helsinki-Finland, +358 0 506 3329 (20 lines V.32bis) %0A Lines %3A  44 %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A     A bright light phenomenon was observed in the Eastern Finland %0A     on April 21. At 00.25 UT two people saw a bright, luminous %0A     pillar-shaped phenomenon in the low eastern horizont near %0A     Mikkeli. The head of the pillar was circular. The lower part %0A     was a little winding. It was like a monster they told. They %0A     were little frightened. Soon the yellowish pillar became %0A     enlarged. A bright spot like the Sun was appeared in the middle %0A     of the phenomenon. At last the light landed behind the nearby %0A     forest. Now there was only luminous trails in the sky which were %0A     visible till morning sunrise. %0A  %0A     The same phenomenon was observed also by Jaakko Kokkonen in %0A     Lappeenranta. At 00.26 UT he saw a luminous yellowish trail in %0A     the low northeastern horizont. The altitude of the trail was %0A     only about 3-4 degrees. Soon the trail began to grow taller. %0A     A loop was appeared in the head of the trail. It was like a %0A     spoon. This lasted only 10 seconds. Now the altitude was about %0A     five degress above horizont. He noted a bright spot at the %0A     upper stage of loop. The spot was at magnitude -2. The loop %0A     became enlarged and the spot was now visible in the middle of %0A     the loop. A cartwheel-shaped trail was appeared round the bright %0A     spot. After a minute the spot disappeared and only fuzzy trails %0A     were only visible in the low horizont. Luminous trails were still %0A     visible at 01.45 UT in the morning sky. %0A  %0A     The phenomenon was caused by a Russian rocket. I don't know if %0A     there were satellite launches in Plesetsk Cosmodrome near %0A     Arkhangelsk, but this may be a rocket experiment too. Since 1969 %0A     we have observed over 80 rocket phenomena in Finland. Most of %0A     these are rocket experiments (military missile tests?), barium %0A     experiments and other chemical releases. During these years we %0A     have observed 17 satellite launches. %0A  %0A     Leo Wikholm %0A  %0A  ===================================================================== %0A  Ursa Astronomical Association        I phone  %3A  +358-0-174048 %0A  Satellite and Rocket Phenomena Sect. I fax    %3A  +358-0-657728 %0A  Laivanvarustajankatu 9 C 54          I bbs    %3A  +358-0-174341 %0A  FIN-00140 Helsinki                   I inter  %3A  leo.wikholm %40 compart.fi %0A  Finland                              I %0A  ===================================================================== %0A

The bike has about 47,000 miles %0A  %3A  and is around $4500. It has had two previous owners, both employees %0A  %3A  of the dealership who, I have been told, took very good care of the %0A  %3A  bike. %0A  %0A  %3A  I have two questions %3A  1) Is this too many miles for a bike? I know this %0A  %3A  would not be many miles for a car but I am unfamiliar with the life %0A  %3A  span of bikes. 2) Is this a decent price? I am also unfamilar with %0A  %3A  prices for used bikes. Is there a blue book for bikes like there is %0A  %3A  for cars?. %0A  %0A  %3A  Thanks for any advice you can give. %0A  %0A  %3A                              --Mark %0A -- %0A  %0A Mark, %0A  %0A   47k is not too many miles on a VFR750.  I sold my (well maintained) %0A '87 VFR700 with 52k miles on it and the engine was in mint condition. %0A All that the bike needed was steering head bearings and fork bushings %0A and seals.  The guy who bought it had a mechanic pull the valve covers %0A to look at the top end, do a compression check etc.  He confirmed it was %0A mint. %0A  %0A    As for price, $4500 seems a little steep.  I bought my '90 with 12k %0A miles on it a year ago (and in absolutely cherry condition) for $4800. %0A There is a bluebook, ask your bank or credit union for the going price. %0A I've seen a couple of ads for VFR's in the $4500 dollar range.  They all %0A said low miles & mint condition but I didn't actually go look at them. %0A  %0A    A VFR is a very sweet bike and will last you forever if you maintain %0A it at all.  One thing to look for, BTW, is a soft front end.  If my %0A VFR is any indication, at 12k miles the fork springs were totally shot. %0A Progressive springs ($55) fixed it right up. %0A  %0A Good luck, %0A  %0A  _______________________ K _ E _ N ____________________________ %0A %7C                                                              %7C %0A %7C Ken Snyder              ms/loc %3A  330 / UN2                    %7C %0A %7C Hewlett-Packard Co. doc_3499 |@raw_text From %3A  sommerfeld %40 apollo.hp.com (Bill Sommerfeld) %0A Subject %3A  A little political philosophy worth reading. %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 apollo.hp.com (Usenet News) %0A Message-ID %3A  <SOMMERFELD.93Apr20205717 %40 blatt.apollo.hp.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 00 %3A 54 %3A 51 GMT %0A Lines %3A  66 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  snarfblatt.ch.apollo.hp.com %0A Organization %3A  Hewlett Packard %0A  %0A Read this through once or twice.  Then replace "prince" with %0A "government" or "president", as appropriate, and read it again.   %0A  %0A [From Chapter XX of _The Prince_, by N. Macchiavelli, as translated by %0A Daniel Donno.] %0A  %0A 	In order to keep their lands secure, some princes have %0A disarmed their subjects; others have prompted division within the %0A cities they have subjugated.  Some have nurtured animosities against %0A themselves; others have sought to win the approval of those they %0A initially distrusted.  Some have erected fortresses; others have %0A destroyed them.  Now, although it is impossible to set down definite %0A judgements on all of these measures without considering the particular %0A circumstances of the states where they may be employed, I shall %0A nevertheless discuss them in such broad terms as the subject itself %0A will allow. %0A  %0A 	To begin with, there has never been a case of a new prince %0A disarming his subjects.  Indeed, whenever he found them disarmed, he %0A proceeded to arm them.  For by arming your subjects, you make their %0A arms your own.  Those among them who are suspicious become loyal, %0A while those who are already loyal remain so, and from subjects they %0A are transformed into partisans.  Though you cannot arm them all, %0A nonetheless you increase your safety among those you leave unarmed by %0A extending privileges to those you arm.  Your different treatment of %0A the two categories will make the latter feel obligated to you, while %0A the former will consider it proper thoat those who assume added duties %0A and dangers should receive advantages.   %0A  %0A 	When you disarm your subjects, however, you offend them, by %0A showing that, either from cowardliness or from lack of faith, you %0A distrust them; and either conclusion will induce them to hate you. %0A Moreover, since it is impossible for you to remain unarmed, you would %0A have to resort to mercenaries, whose limitations have already been %0A discussed. Even if such troops were good, however, they could never be %0A good enough to defend you from powerful enemies, and doubtful %0A subjects.  Therefore, as I have said, a new prince in a newly acquired %0A state has always taken measures to arm his subjects, and history is %0A full of examples proving that this is so. %0A  %0A 	But when a prince takes posession of a new state which he %0A annexes as an addition to his original domain, then he must disarm all %0A the subjects of the new state except those who helped him to acquire %0A it; and these, as time and occasion permit, he must seek to render %0A soft and weak.  He must arrange matters in such a way that the arms of %0A the entire state will be in the hands of soldiers who are native to %0A his original domain. %0A  %0A 	... %0A  %0A 	And since the subject demands it, I will not fail to remind %0A any prince who has acquired a new state by the aid of its inhabitants %0A that he soundly consider what induced them to assist him; if the %0A reason is not natural affection for him, but rather dissatisfaction %0A with the former government, he will find it extremely difficult to %0A keep them friendly, for it will be impossible to please them.  If he %0A will carefully think the matter through in the light of examples drawn %0A from ancient and modern affairs, he will understand why it is much %0A easier to win the favor of those who were happy with their former %0A government, and hence were his enemies, than to keep the favor of %0A those who, out of dissatisfaction with the former rule, helped him to %0A replace it. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  
doc_3501 |@raw_text From %3A  erika %40 znext.cts.com (erik astrup) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  What octane ? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.221639.1508 %40 znext.cts.com> %0A Organization %3A  pnet %0A X-Newsreader %3A  Tin 1.1 PL4 %0A References %3A  <jnmoyne-160493151513 %40 moustic.lbl.gov> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 22 %3A 16 %3A 39 GMT %0A Lines %3A  26 %0A  %0A jnmoyne %40 lbl.gov (Jean-Noel Moyne) writes %3A  %0A  %3A  	How do you know what kind of gas to buy ? Ok, but what kind of gas goes for what kind %0A  %3A  of compression. %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  	I'm asking this because I used to put 87 in my Hawk GT and the other day, %0A  %3A  I changed because I wanted to see if there was a difference. And I don't %0A  %3A  know if I'm being subjective or what, but it seems like the bike runs %0A  %3A  better ! %0A  %3A   %0A 	Run your bike on the lowest octane that it will run smoothly on.  %0A Higher octane fuel is not "better" than lower octane gas. Pick up the last  %0A American Roadracing magazine. There's a short article in there about  %0A octane and the misconceptions many people make about the subject. Look at %0A your owners manual. I believe it states 87 is just fine.  %0A  %0A  ============================================================================== %0A   Erik Astrup                  AFM #422                              DoD #683  %0A  %0A   1993 CBR 900RR  *  1990 CBR 600  *  1990 Concours  *  1990 Ninja 250  %0A         %0A       "This one goes to eleven" - Nigel Tufnel, lead guitar, Spinal Tap %0A  ============================================================================== %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_3510 |@raw_text From %3A  nlu %40 Xenon.Stanford.EDU (Nelson Lu) %0A Subject %3A  SHARKS REVIEW Part 3 %3A  Defensemen (21-45) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr17.021039.21750 %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Department, Stanford University. %0A Date %3A  Sat, 17 Apr 1993 02 %3A 10 %3A 39 GMT %0A Lines %3A  85 %0A  %0A #21	PETER AHOLA		Season %3A  2nd %0A Acquired %3A 	'92-93, trade with Pittsburgh for future considerations %0A Grade %3A 		I (B) %0A  %0A It is way too early to tell about Ahola, who was acquired probably because the %0A Penguins figured that they would lose him in the expansion draft.  Ahola had %0A only played 50 games this season (I think it's actually less; the San Jose %0A Mercury News may be in err here), 20 of them with the Sharks.  In the games he %0A has played, he appeared quite solid defensively, although he hasn't been %0A spectacular, and his offense isn't anything to write home about (8 points); %0A it's even possible that the trade may be for future considerations which turn %0A out to be ... Peter Ahola. %0A  %0A #24	DOUG WILSON		Season %3A  16th %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, trade with Chicago for RW Kerry Toporowski and %0A 		2nd round pick in '92 entry draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (B) %0A  %0A I have often been accused of overly down on Wilson; I may have had too high %0A expectations for him, but his legs, knees, et al., are giving out. %0A Nevertheless, when he was playing, he exhibited a strong shooting and %0A playmaking abilities, even if he has lost a step on defense, which, %0A unfortunately, he demonstrated this year as well, as at times he was slow to %0A catch the opponent forwards, and his offensive output was only good enough for %0A 2nd place on the team (20 points in 42 games).  But next year, which may be %0A Wilson's last, if he can stay healthy, he can still be a contributor. %0A  %0A #29	DEAN KOLSTAD		Season %3A 	2nd %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (C-/D+) %0A  %0A It's probably somewhat unfair for me to judge Kolstad on just a handful of %0A games (forgetting exact number, but no more than 15), but at age 25 he's %0A quickly running out of time if he wants to make it to the NHL.  In those games, %0A he did not impress anyone; after generating 7 shots in the first period of %0A the first game he played, he scored just 2 points in his tenure up here with %0A the Sharks, and was even less impressive defensively, as he appeared awkward %0A with his movement and was prone to giveaways.  He needs to make a leap in %0A his level of performance to have any chance of making the team. %0A  %0A #38	PAT MACLEOD		Season %3A  2nd %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (?) %0A  %0A MacLeod was on the roster a lot longer than Kolstad, but it appears to my %0A memory that he played less than Kolstad, because the Sharks were reluctant to %0A use him, but were even more reluctant to send him to the minors, figuring that %0A he wouldn't clear waivers; in fact, he has played the past 4-5 weeks with %0A Kansas City, but is still technically there on a rehabilitation assignment, %0A a "rehab assignment" that will include him playing in the Turner Cup playoffs. %0A Since he has played so little, I can't even give a tentative grade on him, but %0A he demonstrated last year excellent offensive skills but terrible defensive %0A skills. %0A  %0A #41	TOM PEDERSON		Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (B+) %0A  %0A Called up in the middle of the season when the defensive corps was decimated %0A by injuries, Pederson impressed many Sharks fan here on net, including yours %0A truly.  He demonstrated very good offensive skills, scoring 20 points in %0A 43 games.  However, his size (5' 9", 165 lbs.) is of concern, and soon after %0A he began to shine offensive did teams begin to push him around physically, %0A on both sides of the ice, although he had appeared fearless in his approach. %0A But to be successful, he probably needs to bulk up to have a fighting chance %0A on surviving against some of the bigger players in the league. %0A  %0A #45	CLAUDIO SCREMIN		Season %3A  1st %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		I (D+/D) %0A  %0A He played all of ~5 games in the league this year, but was thoroughly %0A umimpressive, just as he was at the end of last season; again, it may be a %0A small sample, but just as in the case of Kolstad, Scremin, at age 25, is %0A quickly running out of time.  He was not a contributor on either offense or %0A defense in the games he played with the Sharks.  The only notable thing that %0A will go down in Scremin's entry of league stats is probably the fact that he %0A was once traded for now Capitals goaltender Don Beaupre. %0A  %0A =============================================================================== %0A GO CALGARY FLAMES!
