doc_3520 |@raw_text From %3A  palmer %40 cco.caltech.edu (David M. Palmer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Bursters. WHere are they. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1rov63INN8gu %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A Date %3A  29 Apr 93 16 %3A 19 %3A 15 GMT %0A References %3A  <1radsr$att %40 access.digex.net> <STEINLY.93Apr25180118 %40 topaz.ucsc.edu> <29601 %40 galaxy.ucr.edu> <1rlrpv$5ta %40 access.digex.net> %0A Organization %3A  California Institute of Technology, Pasadena %0A Lines %3A  27 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  alumni.caltech.edu %0A  %0A prb %40 access.digex.com (Pat) writes %3A  %0A >... %0A >4)  we know it's not real close,  like  slightly extra solar,  because %0A >we have no parallax measurements on the bursts. %0A  %0A We can only say that they are beyond about 25 AU, due to the low %0A accuracy of position determination by single detectors. %0A  %0A >what i am wondering,  is this in people's opinion,  A NEW Physics problem. %0A >Einstein got well known for solvingthe photoelectric effect.    %0A >Copernicus,  started looking at  irregularities in planetary motion. %0A >Is this a big enough problem, to create a new area of physics? %0A >just a little speculative thinking folks. %0A  %0A It may be a NEW Physics problem (i.e. a problem involving new %0A physics).  However, the data is not good enough to rule out the >100 %0A models which use old physics.  New physics is a big step, and is only %0A tolerated when there is no alternative.  For example , the Dark Matter %0A Problem (there's more to the universe than meets the eye) is a question %0A of comparable mystery to GRBs, but we have much better data regarding %0A it.  Theoreticians postulate new particles all the time to explain it, %0A but no one will actually believe that these particles are real until an %0A experimentalist (or several) detects them in the lab. %0A  %0A --  %0A 		David M. Palmer		palmer %40 alumni.caltech.edu %0A 					palmer %40 tgrs.gsfc.nasa.gov %0A  
doc_3522 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Moonbase race, NASA resources, why? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5x97w.8z3 %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 05 %3A 43 %3A 06 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5sx3y.3z9.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> <C5tEIK.7z9 %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1r46o9INN14j %40 mojo.eng.umd.edu> <1993Apr21.210712.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> <C5w5un.Bpq %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <keithley-220493104229 %40 kip-37.apple.com> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  36 %0A  %0A In article <keithley-220493104229 %40 kip-37.apple.com> keithley %40 apple.com (Craig Keithley) writes %3A  %0A >Ah, there's the rub.  And a catch-22 to boot.  For the purposes of a %0A >contest, you'll probably not compete if'n you can't afford the ride to get %0A >there.  And although lower priced delivery systems might be doable, without %0A >demand its doubtful that anyone will develop a new system... %0A  %0A You're assuming that the low-cost delivery system has to be a separate %0A project.  But why?  If you are spending hundreds of millions of dollars %0A in hopes of winning a billion-dollar prize, it is *cheaper* to develop %0A your own launch system, charging its entire development cost against %0A your contest entry, than to try to do it with existing launchers.  No %0A other demand is necessary. %0A  %0A >> Any plan for doing %0A >> sustained lunar exploration using existing launch systems is wasting %0A >> money in a big way. %0A > %0A >This depends on the how soon the new launch system comes on line.  In other %0A >words, perhaps a great deal of worthwhile technology (life support, %0A >navigation, etc.) could be developed prior to a low cost launch system.  %0A >You wouldn't want to use the expensive stuff forever, but I'd hate to see %0A >folks waiting to do anything until a low cost Mac, oops, I mean launch %0A >system comes on line. %0A  %0A You're assuming that it's going to take a decade to build a new launch %0A system.  But why?  The Saturn V took less than six years, depending on %0A exactly when you date its start.  Pegasus took about three from project %0A start to first flight.  Before SDIO chickened out on orbital development, %0A the target date for an orbital DC-Y flight was 1996.  If you really want %0A speed, consider that the first prototypes of the Thor missile (still in %0A service as the core of the Delta launcher) shipped to the USAF less %0A than 18 months after the development go-ahead. %0A  %0A One of the most pernicious myths in this whole business is the belief %0A that you can't build a launcher without taking ten years and spending %0A billions of dollars.  It isn't true and never was. %0A

doc_3540 |@raw_text From %3A  jbh55289 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (Josh Hopkins) %0A Subject %3A  DC-Y trajectory simulation %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 06 %3A 08 %3A 22 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5z51y.8Fy %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu (Net Noise owner) %0A Keywords %3A  SSTO, Delta Clipper %0A Organization %3A  University of Illinois at Urbana %0A Lines %3A  91 %0A  %0A  %0A I've been to three talks in the last month which might be of interest. I've  %0A transcribed some of my notes below.  Since my note taking ability is by no means %0A infallible, please assume that all factual errors are mine.  Permission is  %0A granted to copy this without restriction. %0A  %0A Note for newbies %3A   The Delta Clipper project is geared towards producing a %0A single staget to orbit, reusable launch vehicle.  The DC-X vehicle is a 1/3 %0A scale vehicle designed to test some of the concepts invovled in SSTO.  It is  %0A currently undergoing tests.  The DC-Y vehicle would be a full scale  %0A experimental vehicle capable of reaching orbit.  It has not yet been funded. %0A  %0A On April 6th, Rocky Nelson of MacDonnell Douglas gave a talk entitled  %0A "Optimizing Techniques for Advanced Space Missions" here at the University of %0A Illinois. Mr Nelson's job involves using software to simulate trajectories and %0A determine the optimal trajectory within given requirements.  Although he is %0A not directly involved with the Delta Clipper project, he has spent time with  %0A them recently, using his software for their applications.  He thus used  %0A the DC-Y project for most of his examples.  While I don't think the details %0A of implicit trajectory simulation are of much interest to the readers (I hope %0A they aren't - I fell asleep during that part), I think that many of you will %0A be interested in some of the details gleaned from the examples. %0A  %0A The first example given was the maximization of payload for a polar orbit.  The %0A main restriction is that acceleration must remain below 3 Gs.  I assume that %0A this is driven by passenger constraints rather than hardware constraints, but I %0A did not verify that.  The Delta Clipper Y version has 8 engines - 4 boosters %0A and 4 sustainers.  The boosters, which have a lower isp, are shut down in  %0A mid-flight.  Thus, one critical question is when to shut them down.  Mr Nelson %0A showed the following plot of acceleration vs time %3A  %0A                   ______ %0A 3 G         /%7C   /      %7C %0A            / %7C  /       %7C          As ASCII graphs go, this is actually fairly  %0A           /  %7C /        %7C	   good.  The big difference is that the lines %0A 2 G      /   %7C/         %7C          made by the  /  should be curves which are %0A         /               %7C          concave up.  The data is only approximate, as %0A        /                %7C          the graph wasn't up for very long. %0A 1 G   /                 %7C %0A                         %7C %0A                         %7C %0A 0 G                     %7C %0A  %0A              ^          ^ %0A            ~100 sec    ~400 sec %0A  %0A  %0A As mentioned before, a critical constraint is that G levels must be kept below %0A 3.  Initially, all eight engines are started.  As the vehicle  burns fuel the %0A accelleration increases.  As it gets close to 3G, the booster engines are  %0A throtled back.  However, they quickly become inefficient at low power, so it %0A soon makes more sense to cut them off altogether.  This causes the dip in  %0A accelleration at about 100 seconds.  Eventually the remaining sustainer engines %0A bring the G level back up to about 3 and then hold it there until they cut %0A out entirely. %0A  %0A The engine cutoff does not acutally occur in orbit.  The trajectory is aimed %0A for an altitude slightly higher than the 100nm desired and the last vestiges of %0A air drag slow the vehicle slightly, thus lowering the final altitude to  %0A that desired. %0A  %0A Questions from the audience %3A   (paraphrased) %0A  %0A Q %3A   Would it make sense to shut down the booster engines in pairs, rather than %0A     all at once? %0A  %0A A %3A   Very perceptive.  Worth considering.  They have not yet done the simulation.    Shutting down all four was part of the problem as given. %0A  %0A Q %3A   So what was the final payload for this trajectory? %0A  %0A A %3A   Can't tell us.  "Read Aviation Leak."  He also apparently had a good  %0A     propulsion example, but was told not to use it.   %0A  %0A My question %3A   Does anyone know if this security is due to SDIO protecting %0A national security or MD protecting their own interests? %0A  %0A The second example was reentry simulation, from orbit to just before the pitch %0A up maneuver.  The biggest constraint in this one is aerodynamic heating, and  %0A the parameter they were trying to maximize was crossrange.  He showed graphs %0A of heating using two different models, to show that both were very similar, %0A and I think we were supposed to assume that this meant they were very accurate. %0A The end result was that for a polar orbit landing at KSC, the DC-Y would have %0A about 30 degrees of crossrange and would start it's reentry profile about  %0A 60 degrees south latitude. %0A  %0A I would have asked about the landing maneuvers, but he didn't know about that %0A aspect of the flight profile. %0A  %0A --  %0A Josh Hopkins                                          jbh55289 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu %0A 		    "Find a way or make one." %0A 	             -attributed to Hannibal %0A

doc_3552 |@raw_text From %3A  bear %40 kestrel.fsl.noaa.gov (Bear Giles) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Fifth Amendment and Passwords %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr15.202417.16391 %40 fsl.noaa.gov> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 fsl.noaa.gov (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Forecast Systems Labs, NOAA, Boulder, CO USA %0A References %3A  <1993Apr15.160415.8559 %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 15 Apr 1993 20 %3A 24 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  37 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr15.160415.8559 %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu> ashall %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu (Andrew S Hall) writes %3A  %0A >I am postive someone will correct me if I am wrong, but doesn't the Fifth %0A >also cover not being forced to do actions that are self-incriminating? %0A >e.g. The police couldn't demand that you silently take them to where the %0A >body is buried or where the money is hidden. %0A  %0A But they can make you piss in a jar, and possibly provide DNA, semen, %0A and hair samples or to undergo tests for gunpowder residues on your hand. %0A  %0A (BTW, that was why the chemical engineer arrested in the WTC explosion %0A thrust his hands into a toilet filled with urine as the cops were breaking %0A down the door -- the nitrogen in the urine would mask any residue from %0A explosives.  I found it interesting the news reported his acts, but not %0A his reasons). %0A  %0A Somewhere, perhaps a privacy group, they discussed the legal ramifications %0A of using a password like %0A  %0A   I shot Jimmy Hoffa and his body is in a storage locker in Camden %0A  %0A a while back.  The impression I got was that real judges would dismiss %0A arguments that this password is self-incrimination as first-year law %0A school sophistry -- the fact that you use a statement for a password has %0A no bearing on the veracity of that phrase. %0A  %0A You are not being asked to incrimidate yourself (e.g., "where did you %0A bury the body?"); you are being asked to provide information necessary %0A to execute a legal search warrant.  Refusing to provide the password is %0A akin to refusing to provide a key to a storage locker... except that they %0A could always _force_ their way into the locker. %0A  %0A Of course, that doesn't mean you have to help them _understand_ what %0A they find, or point out things they overlooked in their search! %0A  %0A --  %0A Bear Giles %0A bear %40 fsl.noaa.gov %0A

doc_3579 |@raw_text From %3A  car377 %40 cbnewsj.cb.att.com (charles.a.rogers) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Fortune-guzzler barred from bars! %0A Organization %3A  AT&T %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 04 %3A 11 %3A 56 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5vABy.LFs %40 cbnewsj.cb.att.com> %0A Summary %3A  What God "needs" %0A References %3A  <93Apr20.212510.46155 %40 acs.ucalgary.ca> <1993Apr21.095305.28851 %40 bnr.ca> %0A Lines %3A  17 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr21.095305.28851 %40 bnr.ca>, npet %40 bnr.ca (Nick Pettefar) writes %3A  %0A > Charles Parr, on the Tue, 20 Apr 93 21 %3A 25 %3A 10 GMT wibbled %3A  %0A >  %3A  In article <1993Apr19.141959.4057 %40 bnr.ca> npet %40 bnr.ca (Nick Pettefar) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A >  %3A  >If Satan rode a bike (CB1000?) would you stop to help him? %0A  %0A Only if he was a "true motorcyclist with the real riding attitude." doc_3583 |@raw_text From %3A  leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech) %0A Subject %3A  Space FAQ 14/15 - How to Become an Astronaut %0A Keywords %3A  Frequently Asked Questions %0A Message-ID %3A  <astronaut_733694515 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Date %3A  1 Apr 93 10 %3A 02 %3A 07 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  cs.astronaut_733694515 %0A Expires %3A  6 May 1993 20 %3A 01 %3A 55 GMT %0A References %3A  <diffs_733693816 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill %0A Lines %3A  313 %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Supersedes %3A  <astronaut_730956661 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mahler.cs.unc.edu %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  space/astronaut %0A Last-modified %3A  $Date %3A  93/04/01 14 %3A 39 %3A 02 $ %0A  %0A HOW TO BECOME AN ASTRONAUT %0A  %0A     First the short form, authored by Henry Spencer, then an official NASA %0A     announcement. %0A  %0A     Q. How do I become an astronaut? %0A  %0A     A. We will assume you mean a NASA astronaut, since it's probably %0A     impossible for a non-Russian to get into the cosmonaut corps (paying %0A     passengers are not professional cosmonauts), and the other nations have %0A     so few astronauts (and fly even fewer) that you're better off hoping to %0A     win a lottery. Becoming a shuttle pilot requires lots of fast-jet %0A     experience, which means a military flying career; forget that unless you %0A     want to do it anyway. So you want to become a shuttle "mission %0A     specialist". %0A  %0A     If you aren't a US citizen, become one; that is a must.  After that, %0A     the crucial thing to remember is that the demand for such jobs vastly %0A     exceeds the supply.  NASA's problem is not finding qualified people, %0A     but thinning the lineup down to manageable length.	It is not enough %0A     to be qualified; you must avoid being *dis*qualified for any reason, %0A     many of them in principle quite irrelevant to the job. %0A  %0A     Get a Ph.D.  Specialize in something that involves getting your hands %0A     dirty with equipment, not just paper and pencil.  Forget computer %0A     programming entirely; it will be done from the ground for the fore- %0A     seeable future.  Degree(s) in one field plus work experience in %0A     another seems to be a frequent winner. %0A  %0A     Be in good physical condition, with good eyesight.	(DO NOT get a %0A     radial keratomy or similar hack to improve your vision; nobody knows %0A     what sudden pressure changes would do to RKed eyes, and long-term %0A     effects are poorly understood.  For that matter, avoid any other %0A     significant medical unknowns.)  If you can pass a jet-pilot physical, %0A     you should be okay; if you can't, your chances are poor. %0A  %0A     Practise public speaking, and be conservative and conformist in %0A     appearance and actions; you've got a tough selling job ahead, trying %0A     to convince a cautious, conservative selection committee that you %0A     are better than hundreds of other applicants.  (And, also, that you %0A     will be a credit to NASA after you are hired %3A   public relations is %0A     a significant part of the job, and NASA's image is very prim and %0A     proper.)  The image you want is squeaky-clean workaholic yuppie. %0A     Remember also that you will need a security clearance at some point, %0A     and Security considers everybody guilty until proven innocent. %0A     Keep your nose clean. %0A  %0A     Get a pilot's license and make flying your number one hobby; %0A     experienced pilots are known to be favored even for non-pilot jobs. %0A  %0A     Work for NASA; of 45 astronauts selected between 1984 and 1988, %0A     43 were military or NASA employees, and the remaining two were %0A     a NASA consultant and Mae Jemison (the first black female astronaut). %0A     If you apply from outside NASA and miss, but they offer you a job %0A     at NASA, ***TAKE IT***; sometimes in the past this has meant "you %0A     do look interesting but we want to know you a bit better first". %0A  %0A     Think space %3A   they want highly motivated people, so lose no chance %0A     to demonstrate motivation. %0A  %0A     Keep trying.  Many astronauts didn't make it the first time. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A     NASA %0A     National Aeronautics and Space Administration %0A     Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center %0A     Houston, Texas %0A  %0A     Announcement for Mission Specialist and Pilot Astronaut Candidates %0A     ================================================================== %0A  %0A     Astronaut Candidate Program %0A     --------------------------- %0A  %0A     The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has a need for %0A     Pilot Astronaut Candidates and Mission Specialist Astronaut Candidates %0A     to support the Space Shuttle Program. NASA is now accepting on a %0A     continuous basis and plans to select astronaut candidates as needed. %0A  %0A     Persons from both the civilian sector and the military services will be %0A     considered. %0A  %0A     All positions are located at the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center in %0A     Houston, Texas, and will involved a 1-year training and evaluation %0A     program. %0A  %0A     Space Shuttle Program Description %0A     --------------------------------- %0A  %0A     The numerous successful flights of the Space Shuttle have demonstrated %0A     that operation and experimental investigations in space are becoming %0A     routine. The Space Shuttle Orbiter is launched into, and maneuvers in %0A     the Earth orbit performing missions lastling up to 30 days. It then %0A     returns to earth and is ready for another flight with payloads and %0A     flight crew. %0A  %0A     The Orbiter performs a variety of orbital missions including deployment %0A     and retrieval of satellites, service of existing satellites, operation %0A     of specialized laboratories (astronomy, earth sciences, materials %0A     processing, manufacturing), and other operations. These missions will %0A     eventually include the development and servicing of a permanent space %0A     station. The Orbiter also provides a staging capability for using higher %0A     orbits than can be achieved by the Orbiter itself. Users of the Space %0A     Shuttle's capabilities are both domestic and foreign and include %0A     government agencies and private industries. %0A  %0A     The crew normally consists of five people - the commander, the pilot, %0A     and three mission specialists. On occasion additional crew members are %0A     assigned. The commander, pilot, and mission specialists are NASA %0A     astronauts. %0A  %0A     Pilot Astronaut %0A  %0A     Pilot astronauts server as both Space Shuttle commanders and pilots. %0A     During flight the commander has onboard responsibility for the vehicle, %0A     crew, mission success and safety in flight. The pilot assists the %0A     commander in controlling and operating the vehicle. In addition, the %0A     pilot may assist in the deployment and retrieval of satellites utilizing %0A     the remote manipulator system, in extra-vehicular activities, and other %0A     payload operations. %0A  %0A     Mission Specialist Astronaut %0A  %0A     Mission specialist astronauts, working with the commander and pilot, %0A     have overall responsibility for the coordination of Shuttle operations %0A     in the areas of crew activity planning, consumables usage, and %0A     experiment and payload operations. Mission specialists are required to %0A     have a detailed knowledge of Shuttle systems, as well as detailed %0A     knowledge of the operational characteristics, mission requirements and %0A     objectives, and supporting systems and equipment for each of the %0A     experiments to be conducted on their assigned missions. Mission %0A     specialists will perform extra-vehicular activities, payload handling %0A     using the remote manipulator system, and perform or assist in specific %0A     experimental operations. %0A  %0A     Astronaut Candidate Program %0A     =========================== %0A  %0A     Basic Qualification Requirements %0A     -------------------------------- %0A  %0A     Applicants MUST meet the following minimum requirements prior to %0A     submitting an application. %0A  %0A     Mission Specialist Astronaut Candidate %3A  %0A  %0A     1. Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution in engineering, %0A     biological science, physical science or mathematics. Degree must be %0A     followed by at least three years of related progressively responsible, %0A     professional experience. An advanced degree is desirable and may be %0A     substituted for part or all of the experience requirement (master's %0A     degree = 1 year, doctoral degree = 3 years). Quality of academic %0A     preparation is important. %0A  %0A     2. Ability to pass a NASA class II space physical, which is similar to a %0A     civilian or military class II flight physical and includes the following %0A     specific standards %3A  %0A  %0A 	 Distant visual acuity %3A  %0A 	      20/150 or better uncorrected, %0A 	      correctable to 20/20, each eye. %0A  %0A 	 Blood pressure %3A  %0A 	      140/90 measured in sitting position. %0A  %0A     3. Height between 58.5 and 76 inches. %0A  %0A     Pilot Astronaut Candidate %3A  %0A  %0A     1. Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution in engineering, %0A     biological science, physical science or mathematics. Degree must be %0A     followed by at least three years of related progressively responsible, %0A     professional experience. An advanced degree is desirable. Quality of %0A     academic preparation is important. %0A  %0A     2. At least 1000 hours pilot-in-command time in jet aircraft. Flight %0A     test experience highly desirable. %0A  %0A     3. Ability to pass a NASA Class I space physical which is similar to a %0A     military or civilian Class I flight physical and includes the following %0A     specific standards %3A  %0A  %0A 	 Distant visual acuity %3A  %0A 	      20/50 or better uncorrected %0A 	      correctable to 20/20, each eye. %0A  %0A 	 Blood pressure %3A  %0A 	      140/90 measured in sitting position. %0A  %0A     4. Height between 64 and 76 inches. %0A  %0A     Citizenship Requirements %0A  %0A     Applications for the Astronaut Candidate Program must be citizens of %0A     the United States. %0A  %0A     Note on Academic Requirements %0A  %0A     Applicants for the Astronaut Candidate Program must meet the basic %0A     education requirements for NASA engineering and scientific positions -- %0A     specifically %3A  successful completion of standard professional curriculum %0A     in an accredited college or university leading to at least a bachelor's %0A     degree with major study in an appropriate field of engineering, %0A     biological science, physical science, or mathematics. %0A  %0A       The following degree fields, while related to engineering and the %0A     sciences, are not considered qualifying %3A  %0A       - Degrees in technology (Engineering Technology, Aviation Technology, %0A 	Medical Technology, etc.) %0A       - Degrees in Psychology (except for Clinical Psychology, Physiological %0A 	Psychology, or Experimental Psychology which are qualifying). %0A       - Degrees in Nursing. %0A       - Degrees in social sciences (Geography, Anthropology, Archaeology, etc.) %0A       - Degrees in Aviation, Aviation Management or similar fields. %0A  %0A     Application Procedures %0A     ---------------------- %0A  %0A     Civilian %0A  %0A     The application package may be obtained by writing to %3A  %0A  %0A 	NASA Johnson Space Center %0A 	Astronaut Selection Office %0A 	ATTN %3A  AHX %0A 	Houston, TX 77058 %0A  %0A     Civilian applications will be accepted on a continuous basis. When NASA %0A     decides to select additional astronaut candidates, consideration will be %0A     given only to those applications on hand on the date of decision is %0A     made. Applications received after that date will be retained and %0A     considered for the next selection. Applicants will be notified annually %0A     of the opportunity to update their applications and to indicate %0A     continued interest in being considered for the program. Those applicants %0A     who do not update their applications annually will be dropped from %0A     consideration, and their applications will not be retained. After the %0A     preliminary screening of applications, additional information may be %0A     requested for some applicants, and person listed on the application as %0A     supervisors and references may be contacted. %0A  %0A     Active Duty Military %0A  %0A     Active duty military personnel must submit applications to their %0A     respective military service and not directly to NASA. Application %0A     procedures will be disseminated by each service. %0A  %0A     Selection %0A     --------- %0A  %0A     Personal interviews and thorough medical evaluations will be required %0A     for both civilian and military applicants under final consideration. %0A     Once final selections have been made, all applicants who were considered %0A     will be notified of the outcome of the process. %0A  %0A     Selection rosters established through this process may be used for the %0A     selection of additional candidates during a one year period following %0A     their establishment. %0A  %0A     General Program Requirements %0A  %0A     Selected applicants will be designated Astronaut Candidates and will be %0A     assigned to the Astronaut Office at the Johnson Space Center, Houston, %0A     Texas. The astronaut candidates will undergo a 1 year training and %0A     evaluation period during which time they will be assigned technical or %0A     scientific responsibilities allowing them to contribute substantially to %0A     ongoing programs. They will also participate in the basic astronaut %0A     training program which is designed to develop the knowledge and skills %0A     required for formal mission training upon selection for a flight. Pilot %0A     astronaut candidates will maintain proficiency in NASA aircraft during %0A     their candidate period. %0A  %0A     Applicants should be aware that selection as an astronaut candidate does %0A     not insure selection as an astronaut. Final selection as an astronaut %0A     will depend on satisfactory completion of the 1 year training and %0A     evaluation period. Civilian candidates who successfully complete the %0A     training and evaluation and are selected as astronauts will become %0A     permanent Federal employees and will be expected to remain with NASA for %0A     a period of at least five years. Civilian candidates who are not %0A     selected as astronauts may be placed in other positions within NASA %0A     depending upon Agency requirements and manpower constraints at that %0A     time. Successful military candidates will be detailed to NASA for a %0A     specified tour of duty. %0A  %0A     NASA has an affirmative action program goal of having qualified %0A     minorities and women among those qualified as astronaut candidates. %0A     Therefore, qualified minorities and women are encouraged to apply. %0A  %0A     Pay and Benefits %0A     ---------------- %0A  %0A     Civilians %0A  %0A     Salaries for civilian astronaut candidates are based on the Federal %0A     Governments General Schedule pay scales for grades GS-11 through GS-14, %0A     and are set in accordance with each individuals academic achievements %0A     and experience. %0A  %0A     Other benefits include vacation and sick leave, a retirement plan, and %0A     participation in group health and life insurance plans. %0A  %0A     Military %0A  %0A     Selected military personnel will be detailed to the Johnson Space Center %0A     but will remain in an active duty status for pay, benefits, leave, and %0A     other similar military matters. %0A  %0A  %0A NEXT %3A  FAQ #15/15 - Orbital and Planetary Launch Services %0A

doc_3606 |@raw_text From %3A  wtm %40 uhura.neoucom.edu (Bill Mayhew) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Laser vs Bubblejet? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.153312.10415 %40 uhura.neoucom.edu> %0A Organization %3A  Northeastern Ohio Universities College of Medicine %0A References %3A  <735446880snx %40 black.demon.co.uk> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 15 %3A 33 %3A 12 GMT %0A Lines %3A  90 %0A  %0A There is a cartridge capping upgrade for older deskjet printers %0A available from hewlett-packard.  Older original deskjet and %0A possibly deskjet 500 units may have a black plastic slide with %0A rubber capping components in the cartrige parking area on the right %0A side (viewed from front) of the printer.  Newer printers have a %0A gray or white plastic slide.  The black plastic slide can allow %0A your cartridge to dry out.  There was and may still be information %0A packaged with ink cartridges explaining the situation.  HP placed a %0A coupon for a free upgrade kit to modernize old deskjets to the new %0A capping mechanism.  I did this on my printer and did indeed find %0A that the cartidges now last longer. %0A  %0A I don't have the information handy.  I suggest contacting your %0A nearest HP service center for information on obtaining the kit. %0A  %0A HP has upgrade kits that consist of electronics and mechanical %0A components that vary depending on the starting level printer and %0A the level to which you wish to upgrade.  I upgraded my original %0A desket to a dekjet 500.  The kit was fairly expensive.  You are %0A likely better off selling your old printer and purchasing a new %0A deskjet 500 now that prices have declined so much.  Upgrading an %0A original deskjet to 500 requires a fair amount of skill, but no %0A soldering.  Upgrading a deskjet plus to a 500 is involves swapping %0A the processor card and changing a few minor parts.  Contact your HP %0A service center for further information. %0A  %0A The PCL language used by Deskjets is considerably different from %0A the PCL used by laser printers, especially the newer laser %0A printers.  The biggest problem is dumb laser drivers that send a %0A raster end command after each scan line.  This makes no material %0A difference for lasers, but causes the deskjet to print the %0A accumulated raster.  As you might guess, the result is hideously %0A slow printing.  The new DOS Wordperfect print deskjet drivers are %0A still guilty of this particular behavior.  From the way Wordperfect %0A works, this would not be easy to change.  Windows Wordperfect works %0A efficiently unless you use the DOS drivers instead of Windows'. %0A  %0A The PCL4 dialect used in the Laserjet IIIP allows compression that %0A permits a full page 300 dpi image to be rendered with only one %0A megabyte of memory.  An uncompressed image could be as large as %0A about 909 Kbytes, but the printer needs about 300K of memory for %0A its internal house-keeping.  Laserjet IV models support banded %0A printing that allows incrmental download of the image with %0A compression in limited memory situations.  Deskjet downloadable %0A fonts are not compatible with laserjet fonts. %0A  %0A A single page from a laserjet only requires about 20 seconds.  This %0A is faster than any but the most trivial printing from a deskjet %0A printer.  The presumption, of course, being that the laser printer %0A has completed its warm-up cyle. %0A  %0A Until ink chemistry is changed, wicking resulting in image %0A deterioration is unavoidable.  I won't use the word impossible, but %0A matching laser quality output from a deskjet printer is unlikely. %0A Chosing an appropriate paper type helps, but does not eliminate the %0A problem. %0A  %0A Laser printers are more wastful of energy and consumable %0A components.  HP does accept return of spent toner cartridges, %0A mitigating the material waste problem to a degree.  Energy waste %0A could use more work.  Warm-up times have decreased, allowing %0A stand-by current consumption to be significantly reduced in the %0A laserjet IV. %0A  %0A Kyocera produces a laser print engine that employs an amorphous %0A silicon imaging drum with a replacable toner system.  The image %0A drum is good for approximately 100K copies.  It is a very nice %0A print engine.  I wish HP used the Kyocera engine.  Kyocera also has %0A a neat modular paper source and stacker system. %0A  %0A The recommended duty cycle for a deskjet is significantly lower %0A than any of HP's laser printers.  The pick-up pressure rollers are %0A subject to wear and I case confirm eventually do wear out.  The %0A usual symptom is that the printer becomes reluctant to feed paper. %0A The paper feed is integrated in a transport mechanism that is a %0A single part from HP service.  Replacement cost for the transport is %0A almost $200.  The feed rollers are not separately replacable, %0A though it would not be a difficult job for a competent technician. %0A I have disassembled and reassembled the transport on my own printer. %0A  %0A It depends upon the application which printer is best for you.  If %0A you only print 5 or 10 pages a day and are satisfied with the %0A appearance of output, the deskjet is a very good choice.  As noted, %0A the deskjet 500 is my choice for personal use. %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Bill Mayhew      NEOUCOM Computer Services Department %0A Rootstown, OH  44272-9995  USA    phone %3A  216-325-2511 %0A wtm %40 uhura.neoucom.edu (140.220.1.1)    146.580 %3A  N8WED %0A

He's an eyesore on the game of hockey. %0A  %0A  %0A  %3A  Rich %0A  %0A  %0A Thank you for your extremely lucid and well thought out observation. %0A Now when you get back on your medication, please let us know how you %0A are feeling.  %0A Thank you, %0A -- %0A _____________________________________________________________________________ %0A Tom Huot        			        %0A huot %40 cray.com  %0A ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ %0A

Can you land a shuttle with a 5cm hole in the wall? %0A  %0A Personnally, I don't know, but I'd like to try it sometime. %0A  %0A Programmatically, yes, we can land an Orbiter with a 5 cm hole in %0A the wall -- provided that the thing which caused 5 cm hole didn't %0A cause a Crit 1 failure on some of the internal systems.  There are %0A a few places where a 5 cm hole would cause a Bad Day -- especially %0A if the 5 cm hole went all the way through the Orbiter and out the %0A other side, as could easily happen with a meteor strike.  But a %0A hole in the pressure vessel would cause us to immediately de-orbit %0A to the next available landing site. %0A  %0A -- Ken Jenks, NASA/JSC/GM2, Space Shuttle Program Office %0A       kjenks %40 gothamcity.jsc.nasa.gov  (713) 483-4368 %0A  %0A      "NASA turns dreams into realities and makes science fiction %0A       into fact" -- Daniel S. Goldin, NASA Administrator %0A  %0A

doc_3732 |@raw_text From %3A  ji %40 cs.columbia.edu (John Ioannidis) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Source of random bits on a Unix workstation %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5Jp0K.4p5 %40 cs.columbia.edu> %0A Date %3A  15 Apr 93 21 %3A 57 %3A 55 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  cs.C5Jp0K.4p5 %0A References %3A  <897 %40 pivot.sbi.com> <C5JA6s.A59 %40 cs.psu.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cs.columbia.edu (The Daily News) %0A Organization %3A  Columbia University Department of Computer Science %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A In article <C5JA6s.A59 %40 cs.psu.edu> so %40 eiffel.cs.psu.edu (Nicol C So) writes %3A  %0A >In article <897 %40 pivot.sbi.com> bet %40 sbi.com (Bennett Todd  %40  Salomon Brothers Inc., NY ) writes %3A  %0A >>This came up because I decided to configure up MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE-1 security %0A >>for X11R5. For this to work you need to stick some bits that an intruder %0A >>can't guess in a file (readable only by you) which X client applications %0A >>read. They pass the bits back to the server when they want to establish a %0A >>connection. %0A >> %0A >>... %0A >>What I settled on was grabbing a bunch of traffic off the network. %0A >>Basically, I ran %0A >> %0A >>	etherfind -u -x greater 0%7Ccompress %0A >> %0A >>and skipped over 10K of output, then grabbed my bits. As best I can tell, %0A >>these are bits that can be expected to be reasonably uniformly distributed, %0A >>and quite unguessable by an intruder. %0A > %0A >For your application, what you can do is to encrypt the real-time clock %0A >value with a secret key. %0A  %0A For a good discussion of cryptographically "good" random number %0A generators, check out the draft-ietf-security-randomness-00.txt %0A Internet Draft, available at your local friendly internet drafts %0A repository.  %0A  %0A A reasonably source of randomness is the output of a cryptographic %0A hash function (e.g., MD5), when fed with a large amount of %0A more-or-less random data. For example, running MD5 on /dev/mem is a %0A slow, but random enough, source of random bits; there are bound to be %0A 128 bits of entropy in the tens (or hundreds) of megabytes of data in %0A a modern workstation's memory, as a fair amount of them are system %0A timers, i/o buffers, etc. %0A  %0A /ji %0A

doc_3756 |@raw_text From %3A  allan %40 cs.UAlberta.CA (Allan Sullivan) %0A Subject %3A  Don Cherry - Coach's Corner summary - April 23, 1993 %0A Message-ID %3A  <allan.735692649 %40 swanlake> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cs.UAlberta.CA (News Administrator) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  swanlake.cs.ualberta.ca %0A Organization %3A  University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 23 %3A 04 %3A 09 GMT %0A Lines %3A  80 %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Here's a summary of Don Cherry's Coach's Corner from April 23, 1993. %0A It was taken from a tape delay of a Vancouver-Winnipeg game, but %0A it was filmed during the Toronto-Detroit game that night. I think %0A it was also shown during the Calgary-LA game.  %0A  %0A (Warning... Anti-fighting people may want to skip this post.) %0A  %0A Topics %0A ------ %0A  %0A Don's Tie, Doug Gilmour, Wings/Leafs, Quebec/Montreal, Boston/Buffalo, %0A Wendel Clark, Fighting and Stickwork. %0A  %0A Episode Summary %0A --------------- %0A  %0A Once again, the episode started with a shot of Don's tie... This %0A was a different tie than last time. Don pointed out some of the %0A characters on the tie, but gave them different names... Felix the %0A Cat (Sylverster), Maclean (Daffy Duck), etc. %0A  %0A Ron Maclean asked Don what he thought of the current Wings-Leafs %0A game. Don thought it was good. Burns told the Leaf players "They %0A won in their building, we're going to win in ours". %0A  %0A Don then began to praise Gilmour again. Don pointed out that Gilmour %0A has never got less than 2 points or a goal in any game since he %0A got 5 points in a game against St. Louis.  (Don also claims that %0A he gave a lot of encouragement to Gilmour, which was partly responsible %0A for his good play.) Several clips were then shown of Gilmour %0A from the series... A hit on Constantinov, and a pass to Andrewchuk %0A resulting in a goal. %0A  %0A On the game itself, the Wings were taking a lot of penalties in %0A the first period. The Wings have enough talent to score short handed %0A however, and when the Leafs get a power play, Coach Burns tells %0A the Leaf players "Don't let them score on you". %0A  %0A Ron brought up the previous Quebec-Montreal game. [Note %3A  Montreal %0A won that game in overtime, despite having a possible game winner %0A disqualified because it was batted in with a high stick.] Don %0A thought the high stick was obvious, even without the use of %0A instant replay. %0A  %0A On the Buffalo-Boston series [Note %3A  Buffalo is currently winning %0A the series 3-0], Don gave full credit to Goaltender Grant Fuhr. %0A Fuhr should be getting 1/2 the team's playoff checks for his %0A play. %0A  %0A Wendel Clarke has recently been criticized for his performance %0A during the Detroit-Toronto series. Don defended him, by saying %0A that he can't play the way he should, because of the league's %0A new rules. "This used to be a rough and tough league... Now its %0A all hack and slash." Don lays the blame on Gil Stien for the %0A problems. %0A  %0A Don's opinions on fighting and stickwork are shared by Wings %0A GM and coach Bryan Murray. A clip from a news conference by Murray %0A was shown, in which Murray made statements claiming the elimination %0A of fighting increases stickwork. Don also read a newspaper article %0A in which Murray makes the following statements %3A  "Players don't fight %0A because they're afraid of getting thrown out of the game as instigator. %0A Instead, they settle grudges by getting their sticks and slicing %0A each other. Is this what the fans want to see? I guarantee there %0A wouldn't be as many slashes if fighting were kept in the game." %0A  %0A Don warned league commisioner Gary Bettman to "smarten up" with %0A fighting in hockey. He went on to say that before, there used %0A to be one guy cut with a high stick in a series. Now, with no fights, %0A someone gets cut every period. %0A  %0A Rating %0A ------ %0A Typical anti-fighting posturing, but here Don's opinion is supported %0A by Murray. %0A  %0A I'd give it a 7.0 out of 10. %0A

Calculators %0A >> >2.	Teflon (So your eggs don't stick in the pan) %0A >> >3. Radar, jet aeroplanes, rocket technology. %0A >> I don't think anyone would argue that World War II was, in and of itself, %0A >> a good thing. %0A >>  %0A >> If you want people to back the space program it must be a good thing in %0A >> and of itself. %0A  %0A >I disagree with what to tout, although I agree that the space program is %0A >inherently a good thing.  Most people today only care about "what will it %0A >cost me?" and "what's in it for me?" and could care less about whether %0A >something is simply worthwhile in and of itself.  Our society has become %0A >increasingly geared toward the short-term (which you could read as NOW!).  %0A >They couldn't care less about next week, much less next century.  They want %0A >something to show for the expenditure and they want it *now*. %0A  %0A I think to some extent this is a case of stooping to their level.  You assume %0A that the general public "can't handle the truth" and then, based on this  %0A assumption, go for the fluff arguments.  Then someone, who can understand a %0A good argument, comes along and asks "why don't you just develop the spinoffs?" %0A or "why can't we just get our spinoffs from some other program, like the %0A military?"  There are some good arguments for space development without relying %0A on its side effects.  I'm not ignoring the value of spinoffs.  I simply think %0A that the general public deserves more credit than you give them. %0A  %0A >BTW %3A  don't forget Velcro... %0A  %0A And if you're going to use spinoffs you better make darn sure you are right. %0A Teflon has been around since before NASA.  As I understand it, Velcro was  %0A conceptualized by a french doctor who went walking in the woods and took the %0A trouble to wonder how burrs stick to your clothes.  Certainly velcro was  %0A available on hiking equipment by the early to mid sixties.  I would need to  %0A see some good evidence before I believe that either of these would not be here %0A today without NASA. %0A  %0A --  %0A Josh Hopkins                                          jbh55289 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu %0A 		    "Find a way or make one." %0A 	             -attributed to Hannibal %0A  
doc_3769 |@raw_text From %3A  higgins %40 fnalf.fnal.gov (Bill Higgins-- Beam Jockey) %0A Subject %3A  The Dream Machines %3A  book on vaporware spacecraft %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.space %0A Date %3A  28 Apr 93 10 %3A 56 %3A 59 -0600 %0A Organization %3A  Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  133 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr28.105659.1 %40 fnalf.fnal.gov> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  fnalf.fnal.gov %0A Summary %3A  Ron Miller book on history of spaceships from Krieger Publishing %0A Keywords %3A  spaceships spacecraft astronautics history SF Miller %0A  %0A Ron Miller is a space artist with a long and distinguished career.   %0A I've admired both his paintings (remember the USPS Solar System %0A Exploration Stamps last year?) and his writings on the history of %0A spaceflight.  For several years he's been working on a *big* project %0A which is almost ready to hit the streets.  A brochure from his %0A publisher has landed in my mailbox, and I thought it was cool enough %0A to type in part of it (it's rather long).  Especially given the Net's %0A strong interest in vaporware spacecraft... %0A  %0A                  ================================== %0A  %0A                          The Dream Machines %3A  %0A An Illustrated History of the Spaceship in Art, Science, and Literature %0A  %0A                             By Ron Miller %0A                   with Foreword by Arthur C. Clarke %0A  %0A Krieger Publishing Company %0A Melbourne, Florida, USA %0A Orig. Ed. 1993 %0A Pre-publication $84.50 %0A ISBN 0-89464-039-9 %0A  %0A  %0A This text is a history of the spaceship as both a cultural and a %0A technological phenomenon.  The idea of a vehicle for traversing the %0A space betwen worlds did not spring full-blown into existence in the %0A tlatter half of theis century.  The need preceded the ability ot make %0A such a device by several hundred years.  As soon as it was realized %0A that there were other worlds than this one, human beings wanted to %0A reach them.    %0A  %0A Tracing the history of the many imaginative, and often prescient, %0A attempts to solve this problem also reflects the history of %0A technology, science, astronomy, and engineering.  Once space travel %0A became feasible, there were many more spacecraft concepts developed %0A than ever got off the drawing board-- or off the ground, for that %0A matter.  These also are described in theis book, for the same reason %0A as the pre-space-age and pre-flight ideas are %3A   they are all accurate %0A reflections of their particular era's dreams, abilities, and %0A knowledge.  Virtually every spaceship concept invented since 1500, as %0A well as selected events important in developing the idea of %0A extraterrestrial travel, is listed chronologically.  The chronological %0A entries allow comparisons between actual astronautical events and %0A speculative ventures.  They also allow comparisons between %0A simultaneous events taking place in different countries.  They reveal %0A connections, influences, and evolutions hitherto unsuspected.  Every %0A entry is accompanied by at least one illustration.  Nearly every %0A spacecraft concept is illustrated with a schematic drawing.  This %0A allows accurate comparisons to be made between designss, to visualize %0A differences, similarities, and influences. %0A  %0A This text will be of interest to students of astronautical history, %0A and also to model builders who would be interested in the schematic %0A diagrams.   Science fiction fans as well as aviation history buffs and %0A historians of science will also find this book to be fascinating.  The %0A unique collection of illustrations makes it a visually attractive and %0A very interesting history of the spaceship. %0A  %0A SPECIAL FEATURES %0A  %0A Includes scale drawings of several hundred spacecraft, both real and %0A fictional %0A  %0A Contains scores of illustrations %3A  artwork, drawings, and photos %0A contemporary with the subject.  This includes extremely rare %0A illustrations from scarce books and novels, exclusive photos and %0A drawings fromSoviet spacecraft; rare stills from both famous and %0A obscure science fiction films, and unpublished photographs from NASA %0A archives %0A  %0A An index, bibliography, and appendices are included. %0A  %0A CONTENTS %0A  %0A Part I  The Archaeology of the Spaceship (360 B.C. to 1783 A.D.) %0A Part II The invention of the Spaceship (1784-1899) %0A Part III The Experimenters (1900-1938) %0A Part IV The World War (1939-1945) %0A Part V  The Golden Age of the Spaceship (1946-1960) %0A Part VI The Dawn of the Space Age (1961 to the present) %0A  %0A ABOUT RON MILLER %0A  %0A [The brochure has a page of stuff here; I'll try to hit the high %0A spots.] %0A  %0A Former art director for Albert Einstein Planetarium  at Smithsonian's %0A National Air and Space Museum %0A  %0A Member of International Association for Astronomical Arts, member of %0A International Astronautical Association, Fellow of the British %0A Interplanetary Society,  consulting editor for *Air & Space %0A Smithsonian* magazine %0A  %0A Author, co-author, editor, or sole illustrator on many books since %0A 1979, including *Space Art*, *Cycles of Fire*, *The Grand Tour*, and %0A many others, as well as many articles and papers %0A  %0A Book jackets and interior art for over a dozen publishers  %0A  %0A Contributor to IBM traveling exhibition and book *Blueprint for Space* %0A  %0A Production illustrator for movies *Dune* and *Total Recall* %0A  %0A Designer of ten-stamp set of commemorative space postage stamps for %0A U.S. Postal Service in 1991 (Solar System Exploration) %0A  %0A ORDERING INFORMATION %0A  %0A Pre-publication price $84.50 before 1 May 1993 %0A Afterwards, price will be $112.50 %0A  %0A Krieger Publishing Company %0A PO Box 9542 %0A Melbourne, FL 32902-9542 %0A USA %0A Direct order line (407)727-7270 %0A Fax (407)951-3671 %0A  %0A Add $5.00 for shipping by UPS within USA for first book, $1.50 for each %0A additional book.   %0A  %0A For foreign orders, add $6.00 for first book, $2.00 for each %0A additional.  Additional charges for airmail shipments. %0A  %0A      O~~*         /_) ' / /   /_/ '  ,   ,  ' ,_  _           \%7C/ %0A    - ~ -~~~~~~~~~/_) / / /   / / / (_) (_) / / / _\~~~~~~~~~~~zap! %0A  /       \                        (_) (_)                    / %7C \ %0A  %7C       %7C   Bill Higgins   Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory %0A  \       /   Bitnet %3A                           HIGGINS %40 FNAL.BITNET %0A    -   -     Internet %3A                       HIGGINS %40 FNAL.FNAL.GOV %0A      ~       SPAN/Hepnet/Physnet %3A                   43011 %3A  %3A HIGGINS %0A

doc_3802 |@raw_text From %3A  C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu (John Kelsey) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper considered harmful %0A Message-ID %3A  <16BB9F30.C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mont.cs.missouri.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  mizzou1.missouri.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Missouri %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 93 01 %3A 04 %3A 48 CDT %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A   %0A    The clipper chip's User key is formed by %3A  %0A   %0A            R1 = E[D[E[N1;S1];S2];S1] %0A            R2 = E[D[E[N2;S1];S2];S1] %0A            R3 = E[D[E[N3;S1];S2];S1] %0A   %0A    Why is the triple-encrytion used?  Is it just to gain an effective %0A increase in keyspace to defeat a potential keysearch?  (If so, why use %0A 80 bit keys?)  Not knowing anything about the Skipjack algorithm, it's %0A not really possible to guess whether this makes it harder or easier to %0A guess S1,S2. %0A   %0A    Why are N1, N2, and N3 formed as they are?  It would be facinating to %0A see the Skipjack algorithm, to look for ways of attacking it that require %0A three ciphertext blocks formed in that odd way. %0A   %0A    Where do the 34-bit constant values that are concatenated with the %0A serial number to form N1,N2,N3 come from?  Are they changed from chip to %0A chip, or session to session?  (Even if they're published in the NY Times, %0A if SkipJack is resistant to known-plaintext attacks, when using triple- %0A encryption, then there's no break in security.  But why allow that kind %0A of weird format?  If those three 34-bit values are truly-random bits, then %0A maybe it's used to ensure that a known-plaintext attack on SkipJack, if %0A it exists, can't be easily used to derive S1 and S2 for a whole production %0A run of these chips....) %0A   %0A    Does Dorothy Denning read this group?  If not, is someone on the group %0A forwarding questions like these to her, or Martin Hellman, or anyone else %0A who's seen more details about the chip? %0A   %0A    --John Kelsey %0A

doc_3805 |@raw_text From %3A  isaackuo %40 skippy.berkeley.edu (Isaac Kuo) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Electrical Spacecraft via Magnetic field of earth? %0A Date %3A  2 May 1993 09 %3A 13 %3A 32 GMT %0A Organization %3A  U.C. Berkeley Math. Department. %0A Lines %3A  41 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1s03bs$24m %40 agate.berkeley.edu> %0A References %3A  <1993May1.044441.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  skippy.berkeley.edu %0A  %0A In article <1993May1.044441.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> nsmca %40 aurora.alaska.edu writes %3A  %0A >Okay, the earth has a magnetic field (unless someone missed something?) %0A > %0A >Okay if you put a object in the earth magnetic field, it produces electricty.. %0A  %0A No, if you put a conductor in a changing magnetic field, it produces a voltage. %0A The two ways you can do that with a permanent magnet is to move the magnet or %0A move the conductor.  The slow shifting of the Earth's magnetic field isn't %0A really significant, especially when you consider how weak the Earth's magnetic %0A field is to begin with. %0A  %0A >Now the question. Can you use electricity to power a space/low earth orbit %0A >vehicle? and i fyou can, can you use the magnetic field of the earth to power %0A >it?? %0A  %0A Well, it would require generating an incredibly large magnetic field to repel %0A the Earth's magnetic field (as a magnet can repel another magnet).  Of course, %0A this force only works in one direction, and the magnetic field generated has %0A to be unimaginably powerful.  Magnetic repulsion drops off as 1/r^3, and the %0A earth's magnetic field on the surface is already very weak.  It would require %0A some sort of unknown superconductor, and special nonmagnetic construction. %0A And seriously hardenned electronics (optical computers, perhaps).  And the %0A physiological danger would be significant (due to the iron content in our %0A blood, among other things).  In other words, forget it. %0A  %0A >Can the idea of a "dragless" satellite be used in part to create the electrical %0A >field? %0A > %0A >After all the dragless satellite is (I might be wrong), a suspended between to %0A >pilons, the the pilons compensate for drag.. I think I know what I want to say, %0A >just not sure how to say it.. %0A > %0A >A dragless satellite sounds interestingly enough liek a generator. %0A  %0A I missed out on the "dragless satellite" thread, but it sounds totally bogus, %0A from this little bit. %0A --  %0A *Isaac Kuo (isaackuo %40 math.berkeley.edu)	*       ___ %0A *					* _____/_o_\_____ %0A *	Twinkle, twinkle, little .sig,	*(==(/_______\)==) %0A *	Keep it less than 5 lines big.	* \==\/     \/==/ %0A

doc_3815 |@raw_text From %3A  jackb %40 mdd.comm.mot.com (Jack Brindle) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Can Radio Freq. Be Used To Measure Distance? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.190300.5969 %40 mdd.comm.mot.com> %0A Organization %3A  Motorola, Mobile Data Division - Seattle, WA %0A References %3A  <C5v13M.C37 %40 bcstec.ca.boeing.com> <72020037 %40 otter.hpl.hp.com> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 19 %3A 03 %3A 00 GMT %0A Lines %3A  65 %0A  %0A In article <72020037 %40 otter.hpl.hp.com> tgg %40 otter.hpl.hp.com (Tom Gardner) writes %3A  %0A >In sci.electronics, rgc3679 %40 bcstec.ca.boeing.com (Robert G. Carpenter) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >> I'm wondering if it's possible to use radio waves to measure the %0A >> distance between a transmitter(s) and receiver? %0A > %0A >Yes. It's called RADAR. %0A Well, actually not quite. Both Radar and Radio-Altimeters measure distances %0A by measuring the time required to transmit a signal, then receive its %0A reflection from a target. Radar generally uses pulses, while Radio Altimeters %0A use either pulses or a modulated continuous-wave transmission. In the case of %0A the latter, highly accurate distance measurement can be made. As an example, %0A the original Bendix ALA-52 Radio Altimeter was accurate to 1/8 foot at 2500 %0A feet altitude. %0A  %0A Note, however that this is a different method of measuring than the poster %0A originally asked about. The problem with gaining accurate measurements between %0A a transmitter and a seperate receiver is that you need a highly accurate %0A time base which starts at the receiver at the exact instant the transmitter %0A triggers. This cannot be wire connected, since radio waves will actually %0A travel faster in free-space (air, in this case) than wire (the difference %0A is called the velocity factor of the cable). So you need to resort to a %0A common timebase that is automatically corrected for distance, etc. Something %0A like a PLL connected to a GPS receiver should do the trick, triggering both %0A the transmitter and receiver simultaneously. Sound expensive? Not too bad, %0A but plan on spending a few bucks in both equipment and effort. %0A  %0A Why not go to a different method? Surveyors use a laser-light system where again %0A the reflection time is measured. Why not try this? (Sounds like something a P.E. %0A should know about anyway ;-). %0A  %0A >> Seems to me that you should be able to measure the signal strength %0A >> and determine distance. This would be for short distances (2000 ft), %0A >> and I would need to have accuracy of 6 inches, or so. %0A  %0A This is actually highly inaccurate, since the power output of a transmitter %0A varies from unit to unit, there are variances in the antenna and transmission %0A line, and the receiver may also vary, both from unit to unit, and the same unit %0A over time. You would need to continuously calibrate the entire system. With %0A the radio altimeter this is also done, but since everything is located at %0A one place, it is much easier to do. Note especially that the time base for %0A the R.A. receiver and transmitter is one unit also... %0A  %0A >Depends on the environment %3A  in a static environent such as a waveguide yes, in %0A >a dynamic environment (with objects moving about) the multipath kills this %0A >concept. %0A  %0A Nope. FM capture effect says that the strongest signal wins. That is, unless %0A the two interfering signals are seperated by more than 3 db in signal strength. %0A This is the one problem that makes altimeters inaccurate at very low altitudes. %0A Signals bouncing off runways tend to be VERY strong... %0A  %0A >> What frequencies would be best for this? Or does matter? %0A  %0A As high as possible to eliminate outside influence, and also to enhance %0A attenuation of multipath signals. Radio Altimeters typically use frequencies %0A around 4 GHz. %0A  %0A Hope this helps... %0A  %0A --  %0A ========================================================== %0A Jack Brindle %0A ham radio %3A  wa4fib %0A internet %3A  jackb %40 mdd.comm.mot.com %0A

doc_3834 |@raw_text From %3A  rbp %40 netcom.com (Bob Pasker) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  A Kinder, Gentler BMW Mailing List %0A Message-ID %3A  <rbpC5yLKq.D07 %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  NETCOM On-line Communication Services (408 241-9760 guest) %0A References %3A  <1110 %40 rider.UUCP> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 23 %3A 07 %3A 38 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A joe %40 rider.cactus.org (Joe Senner) writes %3A  %0A >I know there's already a bmw mailing list, but since it's an R bike  %0A >only list (and limited to the R80* R100* bikes as well I believe) %0A  %0A the list as chartered is geared toward R100/R80 GS/PD/ST riders, %0A emphasizing the off road bikes, but there are numerous people on the %0A list with other BMW twins as well, as well as the usual contingent of %0A aspirants.  most all boxer talk is welcome.  the main list has about %0A 50 subscribers; there is also a digest version which has about 10.  we %0A run about 10 to 12 messges to day, mostly technical with little %0A chatter and no flames. %0A  %0A subscriptions can be had via e-mail. in the text of a message, send %0A the command %3A  %0A  %0A SUBSCRIBE  %0A  %0A to bmw-gs-request %40 halfdome.sf.ca.us for the main list and %0A bmw-gs-digest-request %40 haldfome.sf.ca.us for the digest version.  your %0A "from" address will be used to determine where you will receive the %0A mail.   %0A  %0A it would be a shame to split boxer riders between different lists %0A unless, of course, the existing list failed to meet the readers' %0A needs. %0A --  %0A -- bob pasker %0A -- rbp %40 netcom.com %0A -- %0A  
doc_3835 |@raw_text From %3A  Wales.Larrison %40 ofa123.fidonet.org %0A Subject %3A  Space Advertising (1 of 2) %0A X-Sender %3A  newtout 0.08 Feb 23 1993 %0A Message-ID %3A  <502441799 %40 ofa123.fidonet.org> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93  21 %3A 16 %3A 38 %0A Lines %3A  81 %0A  %0A Brian Yamauchi asks %3A  [Regarding orbital billboards...] %0A >And does anyone have any more details other than what was in the WN %0A >news blip?  How serious is this project?  Is this just in the "wild %0A >idea" stage or does it have real funding? %0A    %0A     Well, I had been collecting data for next edition of the %0A Commercial Space News/Space Technology Investor... To summarize %3A  %0A    %0A SPACE ADVERTISING %0A     First, advertising on space vehicles is not new -- it is very %0A common practice to put the cooperating organization's logos on the %0A space launch vehicle.  For example, the latest GPS launcher had the %0A (very prominent) logos on its side of %0A    - McDonnell Douglas (the Delta launcher) %0A    - Rockwell International (who built the GPS satellite) %0A    - USAF (who paid for the satellite and launch), and %0A    - the GPS/Navstar program office %0A    This has not been considered "paid advertising" but rather %0A "public relations", since the restrictions have been such that only %0A organizations involved in the launch could put their logos on the %0A side, and there was no money exchanged for this.  [However, putting %0A a 10' high logo on the side of the launch vehicle facing the cameras %0A is "advertising" as much as it is "public relations", in my %0A opinion.]  [And by the way, I note that the DC-X test vehicle has %0A rather prominent McDonnell-Douglas and SDIO logos on the side...] %0A    There have been several studies looking at the revenue potentials %0A for use of space vehicles for advertising, or placing large %0A advertising signs in orbit.  On the shuttle, for example, I know of %0A several serious studies in the early and mid 1980's which looked at %0A putting logos on the external tank, or on the sides of the payload %0A bay.  These ventures would be different than "public relations", in %0A that the logos or displays would not be restricted to the firms %0A participating on that flight, and would involve payment of sums for %0A the right to fly the logos in a prominent organization.  (For %0A example, painting the ET to look like a Pepsi can, or putting a %0A Disneyworld logo on the inside of the payload bay where the cameras %0A would scan past it.) %0A    %0A ADVERTS ON LAUNCH VEHICLES %0A    The first paid advertising was done on a Soviet launcher in about %0A 1990, when several non-involved foreign organizations were allowed %0A to pay to put their logos on a Proton launch.  (An Italian shoe %0A company was one of the first advertisers, I remember.)  Similarly, %0A Soviet cosmonauts on Mir made a paid advertisement for the last %0A Olympic games, and have gleefully shown banners and other items from %0A participating firms and organizations.  Mars candy bars, for %0A example, got a plug from orbit as a sponsor of the launch of the %0A British visiting cosmonaut to Mir. %0A    Now US firms are starting to put paid advertisements on launch %0A vehicles.  The upcoming Conestoga launch (in June) putting the COMET %0A recoverable payload capsule into orbit will have paid advertisements %0A on the side, for Arnold Schwarzenegger's upcoming movie "The Last %0A Action Hero".  Besides the usual logos of the participating %0A organizations, Columbia pictures has paid $500,000 to put ads on the %0A main fuselage of the mission's Conestoga rocket, its booster %0A rockets, and on the COMET payload, which will orbit the Earth for %0A one month.  A concept for this advertising display was published in %0A Space News magazine a couple of months ago. %0A    (As a side note %3A  Robert Lorsch, an advertising executive, is %0A talking about suing NASA.  He charges NASA with appropriating an idea he %0A created with the space agency in 1981 to form corporate advertising %0A sponsorships on NASA spacecraft as a way to get funding for the %0A space program.  Lorsch contends that in selling advertising space on %0A the upcoming COMET, NASA violated an agreement that it "would not use %0A his idea without him being the exclusive representative for NASA and %0A receiving compensation."   This is being disputed, since the launch %0A is a "commercial launch" and NASA is receiving none of the %0A advertising revenues, but the funding for the COMET program is %0A coming from NASA.) %0A    %0A ORBITAL "BILLBOARDS" %0A    Orbital "billboards" have been the staple of science fiction for %0A some time.  Arthur C. Clarke wrote about one example, and Robert %0A Heinlein described another in "The Man Who Sold the Moon".  Several %0A different potential projects have been developed, although none have %0A been implemented, but the most real prior to 1993 being the "Eiffel %0A II" project, which would have placed a large inflatable sculpture in %0A orbit to celebrate the French Republic's Bi-centennial. %0A                                                 (cont) %0A  %0A --- Maximus 2.01wb %0A  
doc_3838 |@raw_text From %3A  frank %40 marvin.contex.com (Frank Perdicaro) %0A Subject %3A  ST1100 ride %0A Keywords %3A  heavy %0A Message-ID %3A  <3646 %40 contex.contex.com> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 14 %3A 36 %3A 31 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 contex.contex.com %0A Lines %3A  95 %0A  %0A Sixteen days I had put off test driving the Honda ST1100.  Finally, %0A the 17th was a Saturday without much rain.  In fact it cleared up,  %0A became warm and sunny, and the wind died.  About three weeks ago, I %0A took a long cool ride on the Hawk down to Cycles! 128 for a test ride. %0A They had sold, and delivered, the demo ST1100 about fifteen hours %0A before I arrived.  And the demo VFR was bike-locked in the showroom -- %0A surrounded by 150 other bikes, and not likely to move soon. %0A  %0A Today was different.  There were even more bikes.  50 used dirt bikes, %0A 50 used street bikes, 35 cars, and a big tent full of Outlandishly Fat %0A Touring Bikes With Trailers were all squeezed in the parking lot. %0A Some sort of fat bike convention.  Shelly and Dave were running one %0A MSF course each, at the same time.  One in the classroom and one on %0A the back lot.  Plus, there was the usuall free cookout food that %0A Cycles! gives away every weekend in the summer.  Hmmm, it seemed like %0A a big moto party. %0A  %0A After about ten minutes of looking for Rob C, cheif of sales slime, %0A and another 5 minutes reading and signing a long disclosure/libility/ %0A pray-to-god form I helped JT push the ST out into the mess in the %0A parking lot.  We went over the the controls, I put the tank bag from  %0A the Hawk into the right saddlebag, and my wife put everything else %0A into the left saddlebag.  ( Thats nice.... )  Having helped push the  %0A ST out to the lot, I thought it best to have JT move it to the edge of %0A the road, away from the 100+ bikes and 100+ people.  He rode it like a %0A bicycle!  'It cant be that heavy' I thought. %0A  %0A Well I was wrong.  As I sat on the ST, both feet down, all I could  %0A think was "big".  Then I put one foot up.  "Heavy" came to mind very %0A quickly.  With Cindy on the back -- was she on the back?  Hard to  %0A tell with seat three times as large as a Hawk seat -- the bike seemed %0A nearly out of control just idling on the side of the road. %0A  %0A By 3000 rpm in second gear, all the weight seemed to dissappear.  Even %0A on bike with 4.1 miles on the odometer, slippery new tires, and pads that  %0A did not yet bite the disks, things seems smooth and sure.  Cycles! is %0A on a section of 128 that few folks ever ride.  About 30 miles north %0A of the computer concentration, about five miles north of where I95 %0A splits away, 128 is a lighly travelled, two lane limited access %0A highway.  It goes through heavily forested sections of Hamilton,  %0A Manchester-by-the-Sea and Newbury on its way to Gloucester. %0A On its way there, it meets 133, a road that winds from the sea about %0A 30 miles inland to Andover.  On its way it goes through many %0A thoroughly New England spots.  Perfect, if slow, sport touring sections. %0A  %0A Cindy has no difficulty with speed.  3rd gear, 4th gear, purring along %0A in top gear.  This thing has less low rpm grunt that my Hawk.  Lane  %0A changes were a new experience.  A big heft is required to move this  %0A thing.  Responds well though.   No wallowing or complaint.  Behind the %0A fairing it was fairly quiet, but the helmet buffeting was %0A non-trivial.  Top gear car passing at 85mph was nearly effortless. %0A Smooth, smooth, smooth.   Not sure what the v4 sound reminds me of, %0A but it is pleasant.  If only the bars were not transmitting an endless %0A buzz. %0A  %0A The jump on to 133 caused me to be less than impressed with the %0A brakes.  Its a down hill, reversing camber, twice-reversing radius, %0A decreasing radius turn.  A real squeeze is needed on the front binder.   %0A The section of 133 we were on was tight, but too urban.  The ST works ok %0A in this section, but it shows its weight.  We went by the clam shack %0A oft featured in "Spencer for Hire" -- a place where you could really  %0A find "Spencer", his house was about 15 miles down 133.  After putting %0A through traffic for a while, we turned and went back to 128. %0A  %0A About half way through the onramp, I yanked Cindy's wrist, our singal %0A for "hold on tight".  Head check left,  time to find redline.  Second %0A gear gives a good shove.  Third too.  Fourth sees DoD speed with a  %0A short shift into top.  On the way to 133 we saw no cops and very light %0A traffic.  Did not cross into DoD zone because the bike was too new. %0A Well, now it had 25 miles on it, so it was ok.  Tried some high effort %0A lane changes, some wide sweeping turns.  Time to wick it up?  I went  %0A until the buffeting was threating to pull us off the seat.  And stayed %0A there.  When I was comfortable with the wind and the steering,  %0A I looked down to find an indicated 135mph.  Not bad for 2-up touring. %0A  %0A Beverly comes fast at more than twice the posted limit.  At the "get %0A off in a mile" sign, I rolled off the throttle and coasted.  I wanted %0A to re-adjust to the coming slowness.  It was a good idea %3A   there were %0A several manhole-sized patches of sand on the exit ramp.  Back to the  %0A slow and heavy behavior.  Cycles! is about a mile from 128.  I could  %0A see even more cars stacked up outside right when I got off.  I managed %0A to thread the ST through the cars to the edge of the concrete pad %0A out front.  Heavy.  It took way too much effort for Cindy and I to put %0A the thing on the center stand.  I am sure that if I used the side %0A stand the ST would have been on its side within a minute. %0A  %0A  %0A My demo opinion?  Heavy.  Put it on a diet.  Smooth, comfortable, %0A hardly notices the DoD speed.   I'd buy on for about $3000 less than  %0A list, just like it is.  Too much $ for the bike as it is. %0A --  %0A 	 Frank Evan Perdicaro 				Xyvision Color Systems %0A       Legalize guns, drugs and cash...today.		101 Edgewater Drive %0A    inhouse %3A  frank %40 marvin, x5572				Wakefield MA %0A outhouse %3A  frank %40 contex.com, 617-245-4100x5572		018801285 %0A
