Mamakos) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Once tapped, your code is no good any more. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qovj8$74m %40 ni.umd.edu> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 13 %3A 10 %3A 00 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr17.032828.14262 %40 clarinet.com> <tcmayC5M2xv.JEx %40 netcom.com> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  The University of Maryland, College Park %0A Lines %3A  14 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  sayshell.umd.edu %0A  %0A In article <tcmayC5M2xv.JEx %40 netcom.com> tcmay %40 netcom.com (Timothy C. May) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >But is it any worse than the current unsecure system? It becomes much %0A >worse, of course, if the government then uses this "Clinton Clipper" %0A >to argue for restrictions on unapproved encryption. (This is the main %0A >concern of most of us, I think. The camel's nose in the tent, etc.) %0A  %0A Excuse me?  This has *already* happened.  There's a couple of humps in %0A the tent already.  Ask the folks at Qualcomm what became of the %0A non-trivial encryption scheme they proposed for use in their CDMA %0A digitial cellular phone standard?  There *already* are restrictions in %0A place. %0A  %0A Louis Mamakos %0A  
doc_4207 |@raw_text From %3A  jsc52962 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (Jeffrey S. Curtis) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  What is Zero dB???? %0A Date %3A  Tue, 6 Apr 1993 16 %3A 27 %3A 42 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <C52Lq8.Mr1 %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A References %3A  <1pkveuINNduk %40 gap.caltech.edu> <1993Apr6.132429.16154 %40 bnr.ca> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu (Net Noise owner) %0A Organization %3A  University of Illinois at Urbana %0A Lines %3A  19 %0A  %0A moffatt %40 bnr.ca (John Thomson) writes %3A  %0A }Out of what hat did you pull this one?  dB is a ratio not an RBOC!         %0A } [...] %0A }Sorry.  The unit for current is the AMPERE which is the name of a french-man %0A }named AMPERE who studied electrical current.  The term AMP is just an abbreviation %0A }of it.  The company AMP came after the AMPERE unit was already in use. %0A } [...] %0A }I don't know about this one, but it doesn't sound right. %0A } [...] %0A }Well you got one thing right! %0A  %0A Hello? doc_4208 |@raw_text From %3A  ld231782 %40 longs.lance.colostate.edu (L. Detweiler) %0A Subject %3A  Privacy & Anonymity on the Internet FAQ (3 of 3) %0A Supersedes %3A  <net-privacy/part3_733153240 %40 GZA.COM> %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 1993 00 %3A 00 %3A 40 -0400 %0A Organization %3A  TMP Enterprises %0A Lines %3A  1201 %0A Sender %3A  faqserv %40 GZA.COM %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Expires %3A  21 May 1993 04 %3A 00 %3A 06 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <net-privacy/part3_734932806 %40 GZA.COM> %0A References %3A  <net-privacy/part1_734932806 %40 GZA.COM> %0A Reply-To %3A  ld231782 %40 longs.lance.colostate.edu %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  pad-thai.aktis.com %0A Summary %3A  Notes on the use, history, and value of anonymous Usenet %0A  posting and email remailing services %0A X-Last-Updated %3A  1993/03/04 %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  net-privacy/part3 %0A Last-modified %3A  1993/3/3 %0A Version %3A  2.1 %0A  %0A  %0A NOTES on ANONYMITY on the INTERNET %0A ================================== %0A  %0A Compiled by L. Detweiler <ld231782 %40 longs.lance.colostate.edu>. %0A  %0A  %0A <8.1> What are some known anonymous remailing and posting sites? %0A <8.2> What are the responsibilities associated with anonymity? %0A <8.3> How do I `kill' anonymous postings? %0A <8.4> What is the history behind anonymous posting servers? %0A <8.5> What is the value of anonymity? %0A <8.6> Should anonymous posting to all groups be allowed? %0A <8.7> What should system operators do with anonymous postings? %0A <8.8> What is going on with anon.penet.fi maintained by J. Helsingius? %0A  %0A  %0A * * * %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.1> What are some known anonymous remailing and posting sites? %0A  %0A   Currently the most stable of anonymous remailing and posting sites %0A   is anon.penet.fi operated by julf %40 penet.fi for several months, who %0A   has system adminstrator privileges and owns the equipment.  %0A   Including anonymized mail, Usenet posting, and return addresses  %0A   (no encryption).  Send mail to help %40 penet.fi for information. %0A   %0A   Hal Finney has contributed an instruction manual for the cypherpunk %0A   remailers on the ftp site soda.berkeley.edu (128.32.149.19) %3A  %0A   pub/cypherpunks/hal's.instructions. See also scripts.tar.Z (UNIX %0A   scripts to aid remailer use) and anonmail.arj (MSDOS batch files to %0A   aid remailer use). %0A  %0A   ebrandt %40 jarthur.claremont.edu %0A   ----------------------------- %0A     Anonymized mail.  Request information from above address. %0A      %0A   elee7h5 %40 rosebud.ee.uh.edu %0A   ------------------------- %0A     Experimental anonymous remailer run Karl Barrus %0A     <elee9sf %40 Menudo.UH.EDU>, with encryption to the server.  Request %0A     information from that address. %0A      %0A   hal %40 alumni.caltech.edu %0A   ---------------------- %0A     Experimental remailer with encryption to server and return %0A     addresses.  Request information from above address. %0A  %0A   hh %40 soda.berkeley.edu %0A   hh %40 cicada.berkeley.edu %0A   hh %40 pmantis.berkeley.edu %0A   ---------------------- %0A     Experimental remailer.  Include header `Request-Remailing-To'. %0A  %0A   nowhere %40 bsu-cs.bsu.edu  %0A   ---------------------- %0A     Experimental remailer allowing one level of chaining.  Run by %0A     Chael Hall.  Request information from above address. %0A  %0A   phantom %40 mead.u.washington.edu  %0A   ----------------------------- %0A     Experimental remailer with encryption to server.  `finger' site %0A     address for information. %0A  %0A   Notes %0A   ===== %0A    %0A   - Cypherpunk remailers tend to be unstable because they are often %0A     running without site administrator knowledge. Liability issues %0A     are wholly unresolved. %0A    %0A   - So far, all encryption is based on public-key cryptography and PGP %0A     software (see the question on cryptography).  %0A  %0A   - Encryption aspects (message text, destination address, replies) %0A     vary between sites. %0A  %0A   - Multiple chaining, alias unlinking, and address encryption are %0A     mostly untested, problematic, or unsupported at this time. %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.2> What are the responsibilities associated with anonymity? %0A  %0A    %0A   Users %0A   ----- %0A  %0A   - Use anonymity only if you have to. Frivolous uses weaken the %0A     seriousness and usefulness of the capability for others. %0A   - Do not use anonymity to provoke, harass, or threaten others. %0A   - Do not hide behind anonymity to evade established conventions on %0A     Usenet,  such as posting binary pictures to regular newsgroups. %0A   - If posting large files, be attentive to bandwidth considerations. %0A     Remember, simply sending the posting to the service increases %0A     network traffic. %0A   - Avoid posting anonymously to the regular hierarchy of Usenet; this %0A     is the mostly likely place to alienate readers. The `alt' %0A     hierarchy is preferred. %0A   - Give as much information as possible in the posting (i.e. %0A     references, etc.) Remember that content is the only means for %0A     readers to judge the truth of the message, and that any %0A     inaccuracies will tend to discredit the entire message and even %0A     future ones under the same handle. %0A   - Be careful not to include information that will reveal your %0A     identity or enable someone to deduce it.  Test the system by %0A     sending anonymized mail to yourself. %0A   - Be aware of the policies of the anonymous site and respect them.  %0A     Be prepared to forfeit your anonymity if you abuse the privilege. %0A   - Be considerate and respectful of other's objections to anonymity. %0A   - ``Hit-and-run'' anonymity should be used with utmost reservation. %0A     Use services that provide anonymous return addresses instead. %0A   - Be courteous to the system operator, who may have invested large %0A     amounts of time, be personally risking his account, or dedicating %0A     his hardware, all for your convenience. %0A  %0A   Operators %0A   --------- %0A  %0A   - Document thoroughly acceptable and unacceptable uses in an %0A     introductory file that is sent to new users.  Have a coherent and %0A     consistent policy and stick to it. State clearly what logging and %0A     monitoring is occurring. Describe your background, interest, and %0A     security measures. Will the general approach be totalitarian or %0A     lassaiz-faire? %0A   - Formulate a plan for problematic ethical situations and anticipate %0A     potentially intense moral quandaries and dilemmas. What if a user %0A     is blackmailing someone through your service? What if a user %0A     posts suicidal messages through your service? Remember, your %0A     users trust you to protect them. %0A   - In the site introductory note, give clear examples  of situations %0A     where you will take action and what these actions will be (e.g. %0A     warn the user, limit anonymity to email or posting only, revoke %0A     the account, 'out' the user, contact local administrator, etc.) %0A   - Describe exactly the limitations of the software and hardware. %0A     Address the bandwidth limitations of your site. Report candidly %0A     and thoroughly all bugs that have  occurred.  Work closely with %0A     users to isolate and fix bugs. Address all bugs noted below under %0A     ``(in)stability of anonymity''. %0A   - Document the stability of the site---how long has it been running? %0A     What compromises have occured? Why are you running it? What is %0A     your commitment to it? %0A   - Include a disclaimer in outgoing mail and messages.  Include an %0A     address for complaints, ideally appended to every outgoing item.  %0A     Consult a lawyer about your liability. %0A   - Be committed to the long-term stability of the site. Be prepared %0A     to deal with complaints and `hate mail' addressed to you.  If you %0A     do not own the hardware the system runs on or are not the system %0A     adminstrator, consult those who do and are. %0A   - Be considerate of providing anonymity to various groups.  If %0A     possible, query group readers. %0A   - Keep a uniformity and simplicity of style in outgoing message %0A     format that can be screened effectively by kill files.  Ensure %0A     the key text `Anon' is  somewhere in every header. %0A   - Take precautions to ensure the security of the server from %0A     physical and  network-based attacks and infiltrations. %0A  %0A   Readers %0A   ------- %0A    %0A   - Do not complain, attack, or discredit a poster for the sole reason %0A     that he is posting anonymously, make blanket condemnations that %0A     equate anonymity with cowardice and criminality, or assail %0A     anonymous traffic in general for mostly neutral reasons (e.g. its %0A     volume is heavy or increasing). %0A   - React to the anonymous information unemotionally.  Abusive posters %0A     will be encouraged further if they get irrationally irate %0A     responses.  Sometimes the most effective response is silence. %0A   - Notify operators if very severe abuses occur, such as piracy, %0A     harassment, extortion, etc. %0A   - Do not complain about postings being inappropriate because they %0A     offend you personally. %0A   - Use kill files to screen anonymous postings if you object to the %0A     idea of anonymity itself. %0A   - Avoid the temptation to proclaim that all anonymous postings %0A     should be barred from particular groups because no `possible' or %0A     `conceivable' need exists. %0A  %0A   References %0A   ---------- %0A    %0A   See e.g. ftp.eff.org %3A /pub/academic/anonymity %3A  %0A  %0A   > This article is an excerpt from an issue of FIDONEWS on individual %0A   > privacy and the use of handles.  It accepts the need of a system %0A   > operator to know the name of a user; but suggests that the use of %0A   > a handle is analogous to a request to withhold the name in a %0A   > letter to the editor. The article concludes with a set of %0A   > guidelines for preserving the right to be anonymous. %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.3> How do I `kill' anonymous postings? %0A  %0A   James Thomas Green <jgreen %40 zeus.calpoly.edu> %3A  %0A  %0A   > Try putting this in your kill file %3A  %0A   >    %0A   >   /Anon/h %3A j %0A   >   /Anonymous/h %3A j %0A   >  %0A   > This will search the headers of the messages and kill any that %0A   > contain `Anon' or `Anonymous' in them.  Not perfect and won't %0A   > kill followups.  %0A    %0A   Note that anonymous server operators have the capability to mask %0A   anonymous postings under which the above method will not work; so %0A   far this practice is not widespread, but it may become more common %0A   as a countermeasure to widespread anonymous filtering. %0A    %0A _____ %0A <8.4> What is the history behind anonymous posting servers? %0A  %0A   Originally anonymous posting services were introduced for %0A   individual, particularly volatile newsgroups, where anonymity is %0A   almost the preferred method of communication, such as talk.abortion %0A   and alt.sex.bondage.  One of the first was one by Dave Mack %0A   started in ~1988 for alt.sex.bondage. Another early one was %0A   wizvax.methuen.ma.us run by Stephanie Gilgut (Gilgut Enterprises) %0A   but was disbanded due to  lack of funds.  The system provided %0A   anonymous return addresses. n7kbt.rain.com (John Opalko) took up %0A   the functions of this server, including reinstating the anonymous %0A   alias file. The group ``alt.personals has been chewing through %0A   servers like there's no tomorrow.'' %0A    %0A   Spurred by the disappearance of `wizvax' and interested in %0A   researching the idea, Karl Kleinpaste %0A   <Karl_Kleinpaste %40 godiva.nectar.cs.cmu.edu> developed his own system %0A   from scratch in six hours. By this time the idea of extending the %0A   server to new, more `mainstream'  groups was starting to emerge, %0A   and he explored the possibility partly at the specific request  by %0A   multiple users for anonymity in other groups. ``The intended %0A   advantage of my system was specifically to allow multiple group %0A   support, with a single anon identifier across all.  This was %0A   arguably the single biggest deficiency of previous anon systems.''  %0A   K. Kleinpaste posted a message on rec.nude asking users whether an %0A   anonymous service would be welcome there, and judged a consensus %0A   against it.  %0A  %0A   K. Kleinpaste introduced what he calls a ``fire extinguisher'' to %0A   `squelch' or `plonk' abusive users in response to complaints, and %0A   used this in three cases. Nevertheless, after a few months of %0A   intense traffic he was eventually overwhelmed by the abuses of his %0A   server. ``Even as restricted as it was, my system was subjected to %0A   abuses to the point where it was ordered dismantled by the %0A   facilities staff here. Such abuses started right after it was %0A   created.'' %0A  %0A   In ~Nov 1992, Johan Helsingius (julf %40 penet.FI) set up the most %0A   controversial anonymous site to date. anon.penet.fi is based on %0A   scripts and C code written by K. Kleinpaste and supports anonymized %0A   mail, posting, and return addresses. He initially wanted to confine %0A   the service to Scandinavian users but expanded it to worldwide %0A   accessability in response to 'lots' of international requests. %0A    %0A   J. Helsingius policy of allowing anonymous posting to every Usenet %0A   newsgroup has been met with strong and serious ideological %0A   opposition (e.g. by news adminstrators in news.admin.policy). %0A   Because of the relative newness and recent emergence of the medium, %0A   abuses by anonymous posters  tend to have higher visibility than %0A   ``routine'' abuses. His total commitment to preservation of %0A   anonymity is also controversial. %0A  %0A   For example, in a highly controversial and publicized case in ~Feb %0A   1993,  an anonymous user posted a supposed transcript of desperate %0A   crew dialogue during the Challenger shuttle disaster via %0A   anon.penet.fi to sci.astro. Despite that the transcript had been %0A   posted in the same place up to a year earlier (then %0A   non-anonymously) and actually originated not with the poster but a %0A   New York news tabloid, subsequent responses consisted largely of %0A   vociferous outrage at the poster's use of anonymity, reverberating %0A   through many newsgroups.  %0A    %0A   The original poster, using the same anonymous handle, later conceded %0A   that the story ``seemed likely to have been fabricated,'' %0A   suggesting the plausible possibility that the original intent was %0A   not to provoke outrage but gauge reactions on the authenticity of %0A   the story (albeit crudely), free of personal risk from perceived %0A   association with the item.  The ensuing commotion generated queries %0A   for the original article by late-entering readers. The anonymous %0A   user later posted deliberately offensive comments at his %0A   detractors. %0A  %0A   Despite piercingly irate and outraged complaints, and even the vocal %0A   opposition and verbal abuse of K. Kleinpaste and eminent news %0A   operators, J. Helsingius has largely avoided use of the ``fire %0A   extingisher'' and the ``group bouncer'' mechanisms that limit the %0A   scope of the service. As of ~March 1993 the anon.penet.fi site is %0A   best described as `inundated' %3A  it has registered over 13,000 users %0A   in its initial three months of operation, forwards ~3000 messages a %0A   day, and approximately 5% of all Usenet postings are anonymized %0A   through the site. The immense popularity is probably largely due %0A   to the capability for `global' anonymity which has allowed users to %0A   find creative uses in diverse areas not previously envisioned. %0A  %0A   Johan Helsingius has been subject to extraordinary pressure to %0A   dismantle his server in ~Feb 1993. At one point K. Kleinpaste %0A   threatened publicly to organize a sort of vigilante group of irate %0A   news operators to  send out revocation commands on all messages %0A   originating from the site.  J. Helsingius has also alluded to %0A   threats of flooding the  server.  The server has crashed several %0A   times, at least once due to a saturation `mailbombing' through it %0A   by an anonymous user.  Mr. Helsingius reports spending up to 5 %0A   hours per day  answering email requests alone associated with the %0A   service's administration. In response to the serious threats he %0A   disabled global group access temporarily for one week and %0A   encouraged his users to defend the service publicly. %0A    %0A   Based on fast-moving dialogue and creative suggestions by %0A   ``cypherpunks,'' J. Helsingius has identified many security %0A   weaknesses and valuable new features for the service, and is %0A   currently in the process of code development and testing. He is %0A   planning on upgrading the IBM compatible 386 machine to a 486 soon %0A   to handle the voluminous load and is  considering integrating a new %0A   system with very sophisticated functionality, including multiple %0A   email aliases, alias allocation control, public-key encryption, %0A   etc. %0A  %0A   A very sophisticated anonymous posting system was set up in Dec. %0A   1992 by D. Clunie <dclunie %40 pax.tpa.com.au> that used cryptography %0A   in both directions (to/from) the server for the highest degree of %0A   confidentiality seen so far.  However, it was running on a public %0A   access account, and he had to shut it down after only several %0A   weeks, upon receiving requests and conditions apparently ultimately %0A   originating from NSF representatives. D. Clunie has released the %0A   software to the public domain. %0A  %0A   Recently the idea of a newsgroup devoted to `whistleblowing' on %0A   government abuses has received wide and focused attention, and %0A   group formation is currently underway.  In the basic scenario the %0A   group would allow people to post pseudonymously using remailers, %0A   and even establish reputations based on their authentifiable %0A   digital signatures. The traffic may eventually reach reporters in %0A   the mainstream news media.  deltorto %40 aol.com has volunteered to %0A   attack multiple aspects of this project, including distributing %0A   easy-to-read documentation on posting, anonymization, and %0A   encryption. %0A  %0A   See also sections on ``views on anonymous posting'' below and ``what %0A   is going on with anon.penet.fi?'' in this document. %0A    %0A   (Thanks to Carl Kleinpaste %0A   <Karl_Kleinpaste %40 godiva.nectar.cs.cmu.edu>, David Clunie %0A   <dclunie %40 pax.tpa.com.au> and Johan Helsingius <julf %40 penet.fi> for %0A   contributions here.) %0A  %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.5> What is the value of anonymity? %0A  %0A   KONDARED %40 PURCCVM.BITNET %3A  %0A      %0A   > I think anonymous posts do help in focusing our attention on the %0A   > content of one's message. Sure lot of anonymous posts are abusive %0A   > or frivolous but in most cases these are by users who find the %0A   > anon facility novel. Once the novelty wears off they are stopping %0A   > their pranks... %0A  %0A   morgan %40 engr.uky.edu (Wes Morgan) %3A  %0A  %0A   > I don't mind seeing the miscellaneous hatred/prejudice/racism; %0A   > those things are part of our nature.  However,  the notion of %0A   > providing anonymity's shield for these ideas repulses me.  If %0A   > they have such strong feelings, why can't they put their name(s) %0A   > on  their postings? ... Quite frankly, I loathe communication %0A   > with people who refuse to use their names. %0A  %0A   dclunie %40 pax.tpa.com.au (David Clunie) %0A     %0A   > Many seem to question the value of anonymity. But who are they to %0A   > say what risks another individual should take ? There is no %0A   > question that in this rather conservative society that we live %0A   > in, holding certain views, making certain statements, adopting a %0A   > certain lifestyle, are likely to result in public censure, %0A   > ridicule, loss of status, employment, or even legal action. Given %0A   > the heterogeneity of the legal jurisdictions from where the many %0A   > contributors to usenet post, who knows what is legal and what is %0A   > not ! Some say that anonymous posters are "cowards" and should %0A   > stand up and be counted. Perhaps that is one point of view but %0A   > what right do these detractors have to exercise such censorship ? %0A  %0A   From %3A  doug %40 cc.ysu.edu (Doug Sewell) %0A    %0A   > Why is it censorship to not expect someone to speak for %0A   > themselves, without the cloak of anonymity. This is at best a %0A   > lame argument.  %0A   >  %0A   > You tell me why what you have to say requires anonymity.  And you %0A   > tell me why the wishes of a majority of non-anonymous users of a %0A   > newsgroup should be disregarded when they don't want anonymous %0A   > posts. %0A   >  %0A   > Anonymous users have LESS rights than any others. They are not %0A   > legitimate usenet participants. I would not honor RFDs, CFVs, %0A   > control messages, or votes from one. %0A  %0A   brad %40 clarinet.com (Brad Templeton) %3A  %0A    %0A   > I can think of no disadvantage caused by anon posting sites that %0A   > doesn't already exist, other than the fact that they do make more %0A   > naive net users who don't know how to post anonymously the old %0A   > way more prone to do it. %0A  %0A   From %3A  mandel %40 netcom.com (Tom Mandel) %0A    %0A   > I cannot speak for others but I regard anonymous postings in a %0A   > serious discussion as pretty much worthless. ... views that hide  %0A   > behind the veil of anon are hardly worth the trouble of reading. %0A    %0A   n8729 %40 anon.penet.fi (Hank Pankey) %0A    %0A   > Since I began posting anonymously (to show support for general %0A   > principles of personal privacy) I have been subject to far more %0A   > abuse and attack than I ever received before. People seem to %0A   > find it easier to flame and insult someone whose name they don't %0A   > know. Perhaps it's easier to pretend that there is no person %0A   > behind the email address who feels the sting of abusive comments. %0A   >  %0A   > Anonymity does hinder some methods of controlling other posters' %0A   > actions.  People who seek such control will naturally oppose it. %0A  %0A   From %3A  00acearl %40 leo.bsuvc.bsu.edu %0A    %0A   > Instead of making this a "free-er medium" by allowing posters to %0A   > "protect themselves" with anonymity, simply require that all %0A   > posters be prepared to discuss their sources of information and %0A   > take the heat for unsubstantiated dribble.  This seems to be the %0A   > way things are currently done;  %0A  %0A   xtkmg %40 trentu.ca (Kate Gregory) %3A  %0A    %0A   > In misc.kids there are three threads going on started by anonymous %0A   > posters. One was about changing jobs so as to work less hours, %0A   > job sharing and so on, from a woman who didn't want anyone at her %0A   > current place of work to know she was thinking of looking for %0A   > work elsewhere. The next was from a woman who is thinking of %0A   > having a baby sometime soon and doesn't want coworkers, friends, %0A   > family etc etc to know all about it, but who wants advice. The %0A   > third is about sex after parenthood -- actually this was started %0A   > by people posting in the usual way but then it was pointed out %0A   > that the anonymous posting service might let more people %0A   > participate. %0A   >  %0A   > Misc.kids doesn't seem to be suffering any harm from the presence %0A   > of anonymous posters; in fact it seems to have been helped by it. %0A  %0A   hoey %40 zogwarg.etl.army.mil (Dan Hoey) %3A  %0A    %0A   > While there has never been any real security against anonymous or %0A   > forged postings on Usenet, the process has until now been %0A   > sufficiently inconvenient, error-prone, and undocumented to limit %0A   > its use by persons who have not learned the culture of the net. %0A   > %0A   > On the other hand, a recent use of the anonymous posting service %0A   > on sci.math seemed seemed to be a student asking help on a %0A   > homework problem. It has now been attributed to a teacher, %0A   > asking for an explanation of a dubious answer in his teaching %0A   > guide.  He says his news posting is broken, so he is using the %0A   > anonymous service as a mail-to-news gateway. %0A  %0A   Karl Barrus <elee9sf %40 Menudo.UH.EDU> %0A     %0A   > Some argue that the opinions of the people who hide behind a veil %0A   > of anonymity are worthless, and that people should own up to %0A   > their thoughts.  I agree with the latter point - in an ideal %0A   > world we would all be sitting around engaging in Socratic %0A   > dialogues, freely exchanging our opinions in an effort to %0A   > learn.  But in an ideal world nobody will threaten you for your %0A   > thoughts, or ridicule you. %0A   >  %0A   > But we live in a world where the people who don't agree with you %0A   > may try to harm you.  Let's face it, some people aren't going to %0A   > agree with your opinion no matter how logically you try to %0A   > present it, or how reasoned out it may be.  This is sad since it %0A   > does restrict people from voicing their opinions. %0A  %0A   red %40 redpoll.neoucom.edu (Richard E. Depew) %3A  %0A  %0A   > The consensus seems to be that a general anonymous posting service %0A   > such as that at anon.penet.fi seems sufficiently corrosive of the %0A   > trust and civility of the net that this particular experiment %0A   > should be ended.  Perhaps the next time the question comes up we %0A   > can say %3A  "We tried it - we learned it does more harm than good - %0A   > and we stopped it."  %0A  %0A   From %3A  C96 %40 vm.urz.uni-heidelberg.de (Alexander EICHENER) %0A  %0A   > anonymous posting has not created major problems aside from %0A   > angering irate people (like you?) who would rather ban %0A   > anonymous/pseudonymous posting altogether because "real men can %0A   > stand up for what they said" or comparable puerile arguments as %0A   > others have brought up. %0A  %0A   dave %40 elxr.jpl.nasa.gov (Dave Hayes) %3A  %0A  %0A   > What a primal example of human nature. I have three questions for %0A   > you folks.  %0A   >  %0A   > Do people really say different things to each other based upon %0A   > whether their identity is or isn't known? %0A   >  %0A   > Are people really so affected by what other people say that the %0A   > verbage is labeled "abuse"? %0A   >  %0A   > Most importantly, on a forum that prizes itself on the freedom of %0A   > communication that it enjoys, is there really such a thing as %0A   > freedom of communication? %0A    %0A   From %3A  terry %40 geovision.gvc.com (Terry McGonigal) %0A    %0A   > <sigh>...  Just how many anon services are needed?  Will %0A   > *everybody* start running one soon?  What's the purpose?  Who %0A   > stands to benefit when there are N anon services, then 2*N, then %0A   > N^2, out there.  Where *has* this sudden fasination with anon %0A   > services come from? %0A   >  %0A   > For better or (IMHO) worse, it looks like we'er gonna get stuck %0A   > with these things, and as much as I don't like the idea (of %0A   > services like this becoming the norm) I don't really think %0A   > there's much to be done since it's obvious that anyone who wants %0A   > to can set one up with a bit of work. %0A  %0A   Karl_Kleinpaste %40 cs.cmu.edu (Karl Kleinpaste) %3A  %0A  %0A   > Weak reasoning. %0A   > With freedom comes responsibility. %0A  %0A   dave %40 elxr.jpl.nasa.gov (Dave Hayes) %3A  %0A    %0A   > Responsibility isn't real if it is enforced. True responsibilty %0A   > comes with no coercion.  %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.6> Should anonymous posting to all groups be allowed? %0A  %0A   morgan %40 engr.uky.edu (Wes Morgan) %3A  %0A    %0A   > I will be the first to admit that I hold some controversial %0A   > opinions; indeed, I'm sure that none of us are completely %0A   > orthodox in our opinions. However,  I've received *hundreds* of %0A   > anonymous email messages over the last few years; fewer than 20 %0A   > of them were "reasonable posts made with good motives." It's  %0A   > getting more and more difficult to remember why we need anonymity %0A   > at all; the abusers are (once again) lousing things up for those %0A   > who truly need the service  (or those who would put it to good %0A   > use). %0A   >  %0A   > I'm not suggesting that we should ban anonymous servers; as I've %0A   > said, there are several situations in which anonymity is a Good %0A   > Thing (tm).  %0A   >  %0A   > However, the notion that anonymity's shield should be %0A   > automatically extended to every Usenet discussion is ridiculous; %0A   > it opens the door to further abuse.  %0A  %0A   twpierce %40 unix.amherst.edu (Tim Pierce) %3A  %0A    %0A   > Of course, how does one determine whether a "group" requests the %0A   > service?  A flat majority of posters voting in favor? A positive %0A   > margin of 100 votes?  Or what?  No one speaks for a newsgroup. %0A   >  %0A   > I'm not convinced by the arguments that an anonymous posting %0A   > service for all newsgroups is inherently a bad idea, simply %0A   > because it's a diversion from the status quo. Since the status %0A   > quo previously permitted anonymous posting to *no* newsgroups, %0A   > any anonymous posting service would reject the status quo. %0A    %0A   hartman %40 ulogic.UUCP (Richard M. Hartman) writes %3A  %0A    %0A   > It is facist to suggest that a newsgroup is best able to decide %0A   > whether it wants to allow anonymous postings instead of having %0A   > them forced upon them by an service administrator? %0A  %0A   ogil %40 quads.uchicago.edu (Brian W. Ogilvie) %3A  %0A  %0A   > The service provides a mechanism for forwarding mail to the %0A   > original poster. Since most Usenet readers don't know John Smith %0A   > from Jane Doe except by their opinions and their address, the %0A   > effect of having an anonymous posting to which mail replies can %0A   > be directed is minimal, except for those who personally know the %0A   > poster--and ... the lack of anonymity could be serious. Any %0A   > mechanism like this is liable to abuse, but the benefits as well %0A   > as the costs must be weighed. Limiting the service to alt groups, %0A   > or specific groups, would not help those who want advice on %0A   > sensitive issues in more 'professional' newsgroups. %0A  %0A   From %3A  tarl %40 sw.stratus.com (Tarl Neustaedter) %0A    %0A   > An additional point is that some of us find anonimity in technical %0A   > matters to be profoundly offensive; anonimity in different forums %0A   > has different meanings. If I get a phone call from someone who %0A   > won't identify himself, I hang up. If I get U.S. mail with no %0A   > return address, it goes into the garbage unopened. If someone %0A   > accosts me in the street while wearing a mask, I back away - %0A   > carefully, and expecting violence. In a technical discussion, %0A   > anonimity means that the individual isn't willing to associate %0A   > himself with the matter being discussed, which discredits his %0A   > utterances and makes listening to them a waste of time. %0A   >    %0A   > Anonimity leads to fun psych experiments; the literature is filled %0A   > with all the various things that people will do anonymously that %0A   > they won't otherwise. Including one notorious study involving %0A   > torture that would not have passed today's ethical standards. Fun %0A   > stuff, in any case. %0A   >  %0A   > FINE. LEAVE US OUT OF IT. %0A  %0A   From %3A  jbuck %40 forney.berkeley.edu (Joe Buck) %0A  %0A   > You obviously have never submitted an article to a refereed %0A   > journal, where you will receive anonymous reviews through a server %0A   > (the editor) that behaves much like the one in Finland (e.g. you  %0A   > may reply and the editor will maintain the anonymity).  ...  Your %0A   > comparison of someone who wants to express him/herself on a  %0A   > technical issue anonymously with a person who approaches you on a  %0A   > dark street with a ski mask is just emotionally overwrought  %0A   > nonsense; such posters pose no physical threat to you. %0A   %0A   jik %40 mit.edu (J. Kamens) %3A  %0A    %0A   > It seems obvious to me that the default should be *not* to allow %0A   > anonymous postings in a newsgroup.  The Usenet has always %0A   > operated on the principle that the status quo should be kept %0A   > unless there's a large number of people who want to change it. %0A   >  %0A   > If someone REALLY needs to post a message anonymous in a newsgroup %0A   > in which this usually isn't done, they can usually find someone %0A   > on the net to do this for them. They don't need an automated %0A   > service to do it, and the automated service is by its nature %0A   > incapable of making the judgment call necessary to decide whether %0A   > a particular posting really needs to be anonymous. %0A  %0A   From %3A  twpierce %40 unix.amherst.edu (Tim Pierce) %0A    %0A   > For any newsgroup you name, I bet I can envision a scenario %0A   > involving a need for secrecy. Of %0A   > course one principle of moderation might be to keep out all %0A   > anonymous postings, and could be achieved automatically. It would %0A   > still be _moderation_. Personally I would prefer moderation %0A   > criteria being based on actual content. %0A  %0A   David A. I have no definite plan to do %0A   > this, just wanted the technical data. %0A  %0A   Carl Kleinpaste (Karl_Kleinpaste %40 godiva.nectar.cs.cmu.edu) %3A  %0A    %0A   > ...were I to be in the position of offering such a service again, %0A   > my promises of protection of anonymity would be limited.  Not on %0A   > the basis of personal opinion of what gets posted, but on the %0A   > basis of postings which disrupt the smooth operation of the %0A   > Usenet. The most obvious and direct recourse would be to `out' %0A   > the abusive individual. Less drastic possibilities exist -- the %0A   > software supports a "fire extinguisher" by which individuals can %0A   > be prevented from posting. %0A  %0A   john %40 iastate.edu (John Hascall) %3A  %0A    %0A   > Since when is Usenet a democracy? If someone wants to run an %0A   > anonymous service, that's their business. If you want to put %0A   > that host in your killfile, that's your business. If a newsadmin %0A   > wants to blanket-drop all postings from that site, that's between %0A   > them and the other people at that site. If everyone ignores a %0A   > service, the service effectively doesn't exist. %0A  %0A   From %3A  jik %40 athena.mit.edu (Jonathan I. Kamens) %0A    %0A   > NNTP servers that allow posting from anyone are NOT "a service to %0A   > the net."  They do the net a disservice. %0A   >  %0A   > Terminal servers have the same problems as open NNTP servers -- %0A   > they allow people who want to do illegal/immoral/unethical things %0A   > on the Internet to do so without accountability. %0A   >  %0A   > There are, by now, public access sites all over this country, if %0A   > not all over the world, that allow very inexpensive access to the %0A   > Usenet and the Internet.  There is no reason for NNTP servers to %0A   > allow anyone to post messages through them, and there is no %0A   > reason for terminal servers to allow anyone to connect to them %0A   > and then make outbound connections through them.  Perhaps when it %0A   > was harder to get to the Internet or the Usenet, open servers %0A   > could be justified, but not now. %0A  %0A   jbotz %40 mtholyoke.edu (Jurgen Botz) %3A   %0A    %0A   > I think that what ... these points show clearly is that an %0A   > anonymous posting service has a great deal of responsibility, %0A   > both towards its clients and towards the Net as a whole.  Such a %0A   > service should (IMHO) have a set of well-defined rules and a %0A   > contract that its clients should sign, under the terms of which %0A   > they are assured anonymity. %0A  %0A   From %3A  an8785 %40 anon.penet.fi %0A    %0A   > Is the problem that some are used to "punishing" posters who are %0A   > upsetting in some vague way by complaining to the (usually %0A   > acquiescent) sysadmin or organizations that the poster belongs %0A   > to? That surely is the most gutless approach to solving %0A   > problems, but my experience on the net shows that the same users %0A   > who vilify anonymous postings are the first to write obsessively %0A   > detailed grievances to the poster's supervisor when his or her %0A   > tranquility is disturbed by some "intrusive" or subversive post %0A   > or another. %0A   >  %0A   > Anonymous postings prevent just this kind of intimidation. %0A  %0A   From %3A  gandalf %40 cyberspace.org (Eric Schilling) %0A    %0A   > The main point I would like to make here is that while we can go %0A   > through and revise the news sw to "reject anon posts to technical %0A   > newsgroups" or some such thing, I think the attempt will prove %0A   > futile. Each attempt to modify news can result in a changed %0A   > approach by anon service providers to thwart the change.  I think %0A   > this would be pointless. %0A  %0A   From %3A  julf %40 penet.fi (Johan Helsingius) %0A  %0A   > I have tried to stay out of this discussion, and see where the %0A   > discussion leads. But now I rally feel like I have to speak up. %0A   > ... I have repeatedly made clear ... that I *do* block users if %0A   > they continue their abuse after having been warned. In many cases %0A   > the users have taken heed of the warning and stopped, and in some %0A   > cases even apologized in public. And when the warning has not had %0A   > the desired effect, I have blocked a number of users. I have also %0A   > blocked access to groups where the readership has taken a vote to %0A   > ban anonymous postings, although I feel changing the newsgroup %0A   > status to moderated is the only permanent solution for newsgroups %0A   > that want to "formalize" discussion. %0A   %0A   red %40 redpoll.neoucom.edu (Richard E. There is a sizeable  %0A   > number of people who are concerned about the possible (and, to a  %0A   > minor extent, about the actual abuse of the server as it is  %0A   > configured now). These concerns are respectable; Johan is dealing %0A   > with them. ... There are some (few) who rage with foam before  %0A   > their mouth and condemn the service altogether. And a number who %0A   > defend it, pointing out, like Kate Gregory, that even a group  %0A   > like misc.kids. can benefit from pseudonymous postings. %0A  %0A   From %3A  julf %40 penet.fi (Johan Helsingius) %0A  %0A   > I have answered a lot of personal mail related to server abuse, %0A   > and as a result of that, blocked a number of abusive users. I %0A   > have also withdrawn the service from several newsgroups where the %0A   > users have taken a vote on the issue. I have not made any %0A   > comments on news.admin.policy, partly because the %0A   > newly-implemented password feature (as a emergency measure %0A   > against a security hole) has kept me really busy answering user %0A   > queries the last two weeks, and partly because I feel it is not %0A   > for me to justify the service, but for the users. The problem %0A   > with news.admin.policy is that the readership is rather elective, %0A   > representing people whith a strong interest in centralised %0A   > control. %0A  %0A   From %3A  hartman %40 ulogic.UUCP (Richard M. Hartman) %0A    %0A   > This seems to be a rather bigoted attitude.  I would consider that %0A   > this group is for anyone who wishes to discuss how the net should %0A   > be controlled.  Saying that we only have an interest in %0A   > "centralized control" is a clear indication of bias.  You are %0A   > perfectly welcome to join in the discussions here to promote your %0A   > views on control. %0A  %0A   jbuck %40 ohm.berkeley.edu %0A    %0A   > This whole debate is a lot of "sound and fury signifying nothing" %0A   > because, even if you all decide to ban anonymous posting servers, %0A   > it is not enforceable.  The only people who conceivably could %0A   > enforce retrictions are those that control the international %0A   > links. %0A   >  %0A   > Policy changes should be made by cooperation, not by attempting %0A   > to dictate. ...you need to persuade those who run the services %0A   > to act like this through friendly persuasion, not by trying to %0A   > beat them over the head with a stick (especially a stick you %0A   > don't even have). %0A  %0A   spp %40 zabriskie.berkeley.edu (Steve Pope) %0A    %0A   > I am finding this bias against pseudonymity boring.  Our friend %0A   > posting through penet has a point.  The old guard would like to %0A   > keep their network the way it always has been... and this new %0A   > thing, these pseudonymous servers, cuts into their turf.  So they %0A   > whine and bitch about it, and every time there's the slightest %0A   > abuse (such as somebody's .sig being too long),  they try to %0A   > parlay that into an argument against pseudonymity. %0A   >  %0A   > I'll go on record as saying %3A  three cheers for the admins at anon %0A   > servers like penet, pax, and n7kbt... and for all the  access %0A   > service providers who are willing to preserve their clients %0A   > privacy. %0A   >  %0A   > And a pox on those who try to defeat and restrict pseudonymity. %0A    %0A   mimir %40 stein.u.washington.edu (Al Billings) %0A    %0A   > I wouldn't help people get rid of anon postings as a group. If you %0A   > don't like what someone says, then you put THAT anon address in %0A   > your kill file, not all of them. Of course, if and when I get an %0A   > anon site going, I'm just going to assign fake names like %0A   > "jsmith" instead of "anon5564" to avoid most of the hassles. %0A   > You'll never know it is anonymous will you? %0A  %0A   From %3A  anne %40 alcor.concordia.ca (Anne Bennett) %0A    %0A   > I must admit to some astonishment at this argument.  I see the %0A   > value of anonymous postings under some circumstances, yet believe %0A   > strongly that these should be identified as such, so that people %0A   > who do not wish to read material from people who won't identify %0A   > themselves, don't have to. %0A   >  %0A   > I fail to see what good you would be accomplishing, and indeed %0A   > surmise that you will cause many people inconvenience and %0A   > annoyance, by hiding the anonymity of postings from your %0A   > anonymous site.  Would you care to justify where the hell you get %0A   > the gall to try to prevent people from effectively filtering %0A   > their news as they see fit? %0A    %0A   From %3A  dclunie %40 pax.tpa.com.au (David Clunie) %0A    %0A   > I thought I was out of reach here in Australia too. Unfortunately %0A   > one of the US sites involved in the US/Aus feed complained to the %0A   > Australian Academic Reasearch Network through whom my site is %0A   > connected, not about anything in particular, just the concept of %0A   > anonymous mail having no redeeming features and consuming a %0A   > narrow bandwidth link (with which I can't argue) and that was %0A   > that ... stop the service or face disconnection. %0A   > %0A   > I consider the demise of [my] service to have been rather %0A   > unfortunate, and I wish the Finnish remailer luck ! It is a pity %0A   > that there are very few if any similar services provided with in %0A   > the US. I guess that's the benefit of having a constitution that %0A   > guarantees one freedom of speech and a legal and political system %0A   > that conspires to subvert it in the name of the public good. %0A  %0A  %0A _____ %0A <8.8> What is going on with anon.penet.fi run by J. Helsingius? %0A  %0A  %0A   From %3A  Karl_Kleinpaste %40 cs.cmu.edu %0A    %0A   > Funny, how beating the rest of the Usenet over the head with a %0A   > stick is OK if it's anon.penet.fi and universal anon access.  But %0A   > somehow people on the other side of the same equation (not even %0A   > arguing to shut it off entirely, but rather just to have some %0A   > control applied to the abuses that manifest themselves) aren't %0A   > allowed to do that. %0A   >  %0A   > I have written to Johan several times in the last couple of %0A   > weeks.  He used to reply to me quite readily. After all, I was %0A   > the source of the software as originally delivered to him -- he %0A   > used to be downright _prompt_ about replying to me. Funny, now %0A   > he's being an impolite bastard who doesn't answer mail _at_all_, %0A   > even when it consists of really very civil queries. %0A    %0A   From %3A  julf %40 penet.fi (Johan Helsingius) %0A    %0A   > In your mail you told me you sent me one or more messages on Feb. %0A   > 8th. Feb 7th and 8th the server was down, and the flood of mail %0A   > that resulted from the server coming up again crashed my own mail %0A   > host. The problem was aggregated by an abusive user sending %0A   > thousands of messages to another user, filling up that users %0A   > mailbox. The bounce messages ended up in my mailbox, overflowing %0A   > my local disk as well. %0A   >  %0A   > I can only suppose that your message got lost in that hassle, as %0A   > I have tried to answer as much as possible of the anon-related %0A   > messages I get, from routine mis-addessed messages to complaints %0A   > about the service. On the average I spend 4-5 hours per day %0A   > answering anon-related messages. %0A    %0A   From %3A  Karl_Kleinpaste %40 cs.cmu.edu %0A    %0A   > Why is it that everybody else has to put up with the impoliteness %0A   > and insensitivity of the misuse of anon.penet.fi?  Whose %0A   > definitions of "polite" and "sense" apply, and why? Why is %0A   > universal anon access considered to be within the realm of this %0A   > fuzzy concept of "politeness" in the first place? %0A   >  %0A   > I think Johan has long since crossed the line into being a rude %0A   > bastard, and I told him so in private mail a little while ago. %0A   >  %0A   > At this point, I deeply regret [a] having created an anonymous %0A   > system supporting >1 newsgroup and [b] having given the code to %0A   > Johan.  I didn't copyright it, but I thought that some concept of %0A   > politeness and good sense might follow it to new %0A   > homes.  Interesting that Johan's ideas of politeness and good %0A   > sense seem to have nearly no interesection with mine. I could %0A   > even cope with universal anon access _if_ Johan would be willing %0A   > to engage in abuse control, but somehow that seems to be outside %0A   > the range of reality... %0A  %0A   From %3A  julf %40 penet.fi (Johan Helsingius) %0A    %0A   > There is no way for me to convey how sad and upset your message %0A   > made me. I do, to some extent, understand your feelings, but it %0A   > still feels really bad. Running the server requires getting used %0A   > to a lot of flames, but mindlessly abusive hate mail is so much %0A   > easier to deal with than something like this, as I do respect and %0A   > value your views and opinions to a high degree. No, I'm not %0A   > asking for sympathy, I just wanted you to know that I am really %0A   > giving your views quite a lot of weight. %0A   >  %0A   > When I asked for the software, I was actually only going to %0A   > provide the service to scandinavian users. But a lot of people %0A   > requested that I keep the service open to the international %0A   > community. I now realize that I ought to have contacted you at %0A   > that point to ask how you feel about me using your stuff in such %0A   > a context. Again, I really want to apologise. And I will replace %0A   > the remaining few pieces of code thet still stem from your %0A   > system. Unfortunately there is no way to remove the ideas and %0A   > structure I got from you. %0A   >  %0A   > Again, I am really sorry that the results of your work ended up %0A   > being used in a way that you don't approve of. And I will be %0A   > giving a lot of hard thought to the possibility of shutting down %0A   > the server alltogether. %0A    %0A   From %3A  Karl_Kleinpaste %40 cs.cmu.edu %0A    %0A   > I think I'm feeling especially rude and impolite.  If it's good %0A   > for Johan, it's good for me.  After all, he didn't ask the %0A   > greater Usenet whether universal anon access was a good idea; he %0A   > just did it. ... Yes, I'm a seriously rude pain in the ass now, %0A   > and I think I'll arm the Usenet Death Penalty, slightly modified, %0A   > not for strategic whole-site attack, but tactical assault, just %0A   > "an[0-9]* %40 anon.penet.fi" destruction. Only outside alt.*, too, %0A   > let's say. %0A   >  %0A   > To parrot this line...people have been doing things like the UDP %0A   > (that is, cancelling others' postings) for years, no one could %0A   > ever stop them, and it's only politeness and good sense that has %0A   > prevented them up to now. %0A   >  %0A   > In fact, I have 8 people who have expressed privately the desire %0A   > and ability to arm the UDP. %0A   >  %0A   > ... %0A   >  %0A   > PS- No, in fact there are not 8 newsadmins ready to arm the %0A   > UDP.  It would be amusing to know how many people gulped hard %0A   > when they read that, though.  I don't see it as any different %0A   > from Johan's configuration. %0A   >  %0A   > PPS- Now that I've calmed some fears by the above PS...  There %0A   > are 2 newsadmins ready to arm the UDP.  They've asked for my %0A   > code.  I haven't sent it yet. Only one site would be necessary %0A   > to bring anon.penet.fi to a screeching halt.  Anyone can %0A   > implement the UDP on their own, if they care to.  Politeness and %0A   > good sense prevents them from doing so. I wonder how long before %0A   > one form of impoliteness brings on another form. %0A  %0A   From %3A  julf %40 penet.fi (Johan Helsingius) %0A    %0A   > It would be trivially easy to bring anon.penet.fi to a screeching %0A   > halt. In fact it has happened a couple of times already. But as %0A   > we are talking threats here, let me make one as well. A very %0A   > simple one. If somebody uses something like the UDP or %0A   > maliciously brings down anon.penet.fi by some other means, it %0A   > will stay down. But I will let the users know why. And name the %0A   > person who did it. OK? As somebody said on this thread %3A  "You have %0A   > to take personal responsibility for your actions", right? %0A    %0A   From %3A  avs20 %40 ccc.amdahl.com (  134 Atul V Salgaonkar) %0A    %0A   > I am very grateful and appreciative of this service , courtesey of %0A   > penet.fi.  Some important questions about my personal %0A   > life/career/job were resolved due to kind help of other people %0A   > who had been thru similar situations. In return, I have also %0A   > replied to anon postings where I thought I could make a positive %0A   > contribution. %0A   >  %0A   > In general, anon service is a great, in my opinion, although like %0A   > any tool some people will not use it responsibly. I suggest that %0A   > it should be kept alive. Wasting bandwidth is less important than %0A   > saving lives, I think. %0A    %0A   From %3A  us273532 %40 mmm.serc.3m.com (Elisa J. Collins) %0A    %0A   > I have been informed that the anonymous posting service to many %0A   > newsgroups has been turned off as a result of discussions in this %0A   > newsgroup over people abusing it. %0A   >  %0A   > I had been posting to a nontechnical misc newsgroup about an %0A   > intimate topic for which I felt I required privacy. I have %0A   > received immeasurable help from the people in that newsgroup, and %0A   > I have never used anonymity to behave in an abusive, immature, or %0A   > unethical fashion toward anyone. %0A   >  %0A   > Please, folks, believe me, I *need* this service.  Please %0A   > consider my point of view and permit admin %40 anon.penet.fi to turn %0A   > the service back on... %0A   >  %0A   > Thank you. %0A  %0A * * * %0A  %0A SEE ALSO %0A ======== %0A  %0A Part 1 (first file) %0A ------ %0A  %0A <1.1> What is `identity' on the internet? %0A <1.2> Why is identity (un)important on the internet? %0A <1.3> How does my email address (not) identify me and my background? %0A <1.4> How can I find out more about somebody from their email address? %0A <1.5> Why is identification (un)stable on the internet?  %0A <1.6> What is the future of identification on the internet? %0A  %0A <2.1> What is `privacy' on the internet? %0A <2.2> Why is privacy (un)important on the internet? %0A <2.3> How (in)secure are internet networks? %0A <2.4> How (in)secure is my account? %0A <2.5> How (in)secure are my files and directories? %0A <2.6> How (in)secure is X Windows? %0A <2.7> How (in)secure is my email? %0A <2.8> How am I (not) liable for my email and postings? %0A <2.9> How do I provide more/less information to others on my identity? %0A <2.10> Who is my sysadmin?  What does s/he know about me? %0A <2.11> Why is privacy (un)stable on the internet? %0A <2.12> What is the future of privacy on the internet? %0A  %0A <3.1> What is `anonymity' on the internet? %0A <3.2> Why is `anonymity' (un)important on the internet? %0A <3.3> How can anonymity be protected on the internet? %0A <3.4> What is `anonymous mail'? %0A <3.5> What is `anonymous posting'? %0A <3.6> Why is anonymity (un)stable on the internet? %0A <3.7> What is the future of anonymity on the internet? %0A  %0A Part 2 (previous file) %0A ------ %0A  %0A <4.1> What UNIX programs are related to privacy? %0A <4.2> How can I learn about or use cryptography? %0A <4.3> What is the cypherpunks mailing list? %0A <4.4> What are some privacy-related newsgroups?  FAQs? %0A <4.5> What is internet Privacy Enhanced Mail (PEM)? %0A <4.6> What are other Request For Comments (RFCs) related to privacy? %0A <4.7> How can I run an anonymous remailer? %0A <4.8> What are references on privacy in email? %0A <4.9> What are some email, Usenet, and internet use policies? %0A <4.10> What is the MIT ``CROSSLINK'' anonymous message TV program? %0A  %0A <5.1> What is ``digital cash''? %0A <5.2> What is a ``hacker'' or ``cracker''? %0A <5.3> What is a ``cypherpunk''? %0A <5.4> What is `steganography' and anonymous pools? %0A <5.5> What is `security through obscurity'? %0A <5.6> What are `identity daemons'? %0A <5.7> What standards are needed to guard electronic privacy? %0A  %0A <6.1> What is the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF)? %0A <6.2> Who are Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility (CPSR)? %0A <6.3> What was `Operation Sun Devil' and the Steve Jackson Game case? %0A <6.4> What is Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN)? %0A <6.5> What is the National Research and Education Network (NREN)? %0A <6.6> What is the FBI's proposed Digital Telephony Act? %0A <6.7> What other U.S. legislation is related to privacy on networks? %0A <6.8> What are references on rights in cyberspace? %0A <6.9> What is the Computers and Academic Freedom (CAF) archive? %0A  %0A <7.1> What is the background behind the Internet? %0A <7.2> How is Internet `anarchy' like the English language? %0A <7.3> Most Wanted list %0A <7.4> Change history %0A  %0A  %0A * * * %0A  %0A This is Part 3 of the Privacy & Anonymity FAQ, obtained via anonymous %0A   FTP to pit-manager %40 mit.edu %3A /pub/usenet/news.answers/net-privacy/ or  %0A   newsgroups news.answers, sci.answers, alt.answers every 21 days. %0A Written by L. doc_4248 |@raw_text From %3A  mcmahan %40 netcom.com (Dave Mc Mahan) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  8x oversampling CD player %0A Message-ID %3A  <mcmahanC5v942.MKJ %40 netcom.com> %0A Keywords %3A  oversampling, CD, digitized audio %0A Organization %3A   Dave McMahan  %40  NetCom Services  %0A References %3A  <hcbC5un9L.DD0 %40 netcom.com> <1993Apr21.160303.10838 %40 doug.cae.wisc.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 03 %3A 45 %3A 37 GMT %0A Lines %3A  63 %0A  %0A  In a previous article, kolstad %40 cae.wisc.edu (Joel Kolstad) writes %3A  %0A >In article <hcbC5un9L.DD0 %40 netcom.com> hcb %40 netcom.com (H. C. Bowman) writes %3A  %0A >> %0A >>I just bought a new portable CD player for the office, and I notice that %0A >>it proudly proclaims "8 TIMES OVERSAMPLING" on the box.  Now while I think %0A >>I understand what oversampling is (the rate of discrete "samples" %0A >>exceeds the highest frequency component of interest by some factor), %0A >>I don't understand this "8 TIMES" business...  It seems to me that when %0A >>I bought my first CD player (was it REALLY 10 years ago?!), the specs %0A >>said "4 TIMES" ...  Could someone please tell me whether I'm getting %0A >>senile?  If I'm not, then what good does it do for the player to take %0A >>samples at a higher rate?   %0A  %0A >The data is only ever read once (barring mistracks and such, of course), %0A >and eventually gets turned into 44.1 KHz, 16 bit, two channel data. %0A >Oversampling takes two discrete data points, and interpolates n-1 points %0A >between them for n times oversampling.  When I asked, people said that the %0A >interpolation was not simply linear interpolation, but significantly more %0A >complicated. %0A  %0A You are quite correct in your understanding.  The filtering is not %0A interpolation, as that would distort the frequency content of the signal %0A you are listening to.  Generally, these players run the samples thru an %0A all-pass filter network.  I have done this for ECG waveforms from a person's %0A heart, and the effect is rather spooky.  It actually reconstructs peaks %0A that weren't there (correctly, too!) and fills in the gaps with the %0A properly computed values, just as if there had been a real sample taken at %0A that point.  I use a CPU to do all the math.  It takes a decent (but not %0A unreasonable) amount of CPU time to do this.  You can keep up with things %0A in realtime if you write efficient code. %0A  %0A In case you care, the filtering method uses an FIR (finite impulse response) %0A filter.  I'd guess that CD makers use the same kind of method.  Anybody out %0A there know the real answer?  I'd say that they use a tapped delay line with %0A resistor/op-amp weighting to accomplish the filtering.  This strikes me as %0A the most cost effective method for volume production runs. %0A  %0A  %0A >Anyway, then, the purpose of oversampling is to move the "effective" %0A >sampling rate up to n times 44.1 KHz, in order to use higher frequency %0A >antialiasing filters.  For the same quality filter, higher oversampling %0A >lets you build cheaper filters, whereas for the same price filter, higher %0A >oversamplings lets you build better filters.  So, assuming the quality of %0A >all other components in a CD player remained the same, oversampling should %0A >allow a manufacturer to produce _slightly_ better sound due to anti-alias %0A >filtering. %0A  %0A Actually, I think the only reason they do this is so that they can say that %0A they have a marketting gimic.  I would guess that it is acutally cheaper to %0A filter an oversampled signal than not.  You can use sloppier components and %0A give the filter a roll-off that isn't so sharp.   It's too bad that they %0A charge more for something that (I think) is actually less costly to build. %0A  %0A I seriously doubt that the filters cost the same but are better.  They are %0A built to a price spec, and that spec says "cheap as possible!".  %0A  %0A  %0A >					---Joel Kolstad %0A  %0A   -dave %0A --  %0A Dave McMahan                            mcmahan %40 netcom.com %0A                                         37N 17.382    121W 59.190  %0A

Sci. %0A References %3A  <sehari.735331566 %40 marge.ecss.iastate.edu> <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu> <1993Apr21.085848.12704W %40 lumina.edb.tih.no> <1993Apr21.141137.863 %40 imag.fr> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 93 18 %3A 07 %3A 47 GMT %0A Lines %3A  50 %0A  %0A schaefer %40 imag.imag.fr (Arno Schaefer) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.085848.12704W %40 lumina.edb.tih.no>, ketil %40 edb.tih.no (Ketil Albertsen,TIH) writes %3A  %0A >%7C> In article <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu>, mblock %40 reed.edu (Matt Block) writes %3A  %0A >%7C>  %0A >%7C> >	I guess what I am saying is that your question is difficult, if not %0A >%7C> >impossible, to answer. doc_4287 |@raw_text From %3A  psionic %40 wam.umd.edu (Haywood J. Blowme) %0A Subject %3A  new encryption %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.225435.6292 %40 wam.umd.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 wam.umd.edu (USENET News system) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  rac3.wam.umd.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Maryland, College Park %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.192105.11751 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr21.001230.26384 %40 lokkur.dexter.mi.us> <1r4e9d$pdo %40 sol.TIS.COM> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 22 %3A 54 %3A 35 GMT %0A Lines %3A  120 %0A  %0A    As promised, I spoke today with the company mentioned in a Washington %0A Times article about the Clipper chip announcement. The name of the company %0A is Secure Communicatiions Technology (Information will be given at the end %0A of this message on how to contact them). %0A  %0A    Basically they are disturbed about the announcement for many reasons that %0A we are. More specifically however, Mr. Bryen of Secure Communications %0A brought to light many points that might interest most of the readers. %0A  %0A    His belief is that AT&T was made known of the clipper well before the %0A rest of the industry. This is for several reasons, several of which are %3A  %0A  %0A  - A company of AT&T's size could never be able to make a decision to use %0A    the new chip on the SAME DAY it was announced. %0A  %0A  - Months ago they proposed using their own chip for AT&T's secure telephone %0A    devices. AT&T basically blew them off as being not interested at all. %0A    This stuck them as strange, until now... %0A  %0A  %0A    Also I spoke with Art Melnick, their cryptographer, he expressed several %0A concerns over the new Clipper Chip %3A  %0A  %0A   - The obvious backdoor will be able to let many people decrypt the code. %0A  %0A   - Once the key is released to authorities the security of the crypto %0A     system is lost forever. These keys can end up in the hands of any agency %0A     of the government. %0A  %0A   - The fact that the escrowed keys never change means that the algorithm %0A     is vulnerable over time to an attacker. %0A  %0A   - The classified algorithm may hide another backdoor. But he feels that %0A     it is probably to keep people from forging fake serial numbers, or %0A     changing the keys themselves. %0A  %0A   - Additionally he feels that the NSA has probably spent enough time and %0A     money in working on a way to keep this chip from being reversed %0A     engineered, that he feels that reverse engineering it will be very %0A     difficult to do. He feels that they have developed a suitable technique %0A     to protect the chip from this attack. Also he feels that the chip is %0A     hardware encoded with the algorithm and not microcoded onto the chip. %0A  %0A Additonally I spoke with Mr. Melnick about their algorithm. He couldn't tell %0A me much about their new agorithm because it hasn't been patented yet. %0A However he told me a little %3A  %0A  %0A  - The algorithm will be released for public review after patents have been %0A    granted for it. This is so the crypto community can see that it is %0A    secure. %0A  %0A  - The algorithm is called NEA for New Encryption Algorithm. %0A    The details were sketchy because now it is held as a trade secret %0A    until the patent was issued, but I was told that it will incorporate %0A    the following %3A  %0A  %0A     - It will have fast encryption of data (Exact specs not given, but %0A       Mr. Melnick stated "Much faster than what an RS-232 can put out.") %0A  %0A     - It is a symmetric cipher, just like IDEA and DES. %0A  %0A     - It will use 64 bit data blocks for encryption (like DES and IDEA). %0A  %0A     - The key length was not given to me, but Mr. Melnick states that %0A       it is _adujustable_ and is "More than adequate for security." %0A  %0A     - The algorithm is written in C and Assembler in software form, and %0A       can be ported to many platforms (Unlike the the Clipper Chip which %0A       is hardware ONLY and cannot be made into software) This I %0A       consider a definite plus for the NEA for widespread use. %0A  %0A     - The algorithm will accomodate public key distribution techniques %0A       such as RSA or Diffie-Hellman. This will also be supported in the %0A       hardware chip. %0A  %0A     - Right now the projected cost of the NEA chip will be about 10 dollars %0A       for each!! (Clipper will run 25 each chip [that is if it is produced %0A       enough, which probably won't happen]). %0A  %0A     - They currently sell a program called C-COM that uses the algorithm %0A       and a special streaming protocol that does not divide the encrypted %0A       data into "blocks." This could prevent plaintext attacks if you know %0A       what the block header is. This program operates at all supported %0A       RS-232 speeds and uses the software implementation of the algorithm. %0A  %0A     - Most importantly %3A  IT DOES NOT HAVE A BACKDOOR!! %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Right now the company is afraid that the new clipper chip will put them out %0A of business. This is a very real possibility. So they really need help in %0A stopping the clipper chip from becoming a standard. If you want to contact %0A them, they can be reached at.. %0A  %0A Secure Communications Technology %0A 8700 Georgia Ave. Suite 302 %0A Silver Spring, MD %0A  %0A (301) 588-2200 %0A  %0A I talked to Mr. Bryen who represents the company. He can answer any %0A questions you have. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Any factual errors occurring in this write up are my own and I apologize for %0A them ahead of time. %0A  %0A   %0A  %0A ============================================================================= %0A       ///    %7C psionic %40 wam.umd.edu %7C Fight the WIRETAP CHIP!! Ask me how! %0A  __  /// C=  %7C -Craig H. Rowland-  %7C %0A  \\\/// Amiga%7C PGP Key Available   %7C "Those who would give up liberty for %0A   \///  1200 %7C by request.         %7C  security deserve neither." %0A ============================================================================= %0A A %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_4311 |@raw_text From %3A  kjenks %40 gothamcity.jsc.nasa.gov %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  ASTRONAUTS---What does weightlessness feel like? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993May1.170023.8097 %40 sol.ctr.columbia.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.space %0A Sender %3A  nobody %40 ctr.columbia.edu %0A Organization %3A  NASA/JSC/GM2, Space Shuttle Program Office %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL8] %0A References %3A  <29APR199317354584 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 1 May 1993 17 %3A 00 %3A 23 GMT %0A X-Posted-From %3A  algol.jsc.nasa.gov %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  sol.ctr.columbia.edu %0A Lines %3A  81 %0A  %0A  %3A  In article <1993Apr29.121501 %40 is.morgan.com>, jlieb %40 is.morgan.com (Jerry Liebelson) writes... %0A  %3A  > I want to know what weightlessness actually FEELS like. For example, is %0A  %3A  >there a constant sensation of falling?  %0A  %0A Ron Baalke (baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) replied %3A  %0A  %3A  Yes, weightlessness does feel like falling.  It may feel strange at first, %0A  %3A  but the body does adjust.  The feeling is not too different from that %0A  %3A  of sky diving. %0A  %0A I'm no astronaut, but I've flown in the KC-135 several times.  I'll %0A tell you about my first flight. %0A  %0A At the on-set of weightlessness, my shoulders lifted and my spine %0A straightened.  I felt a momentary panic, and my hands tried to grab %0A onto something (like the strap keeping me firmly against the floor) %0A to prevent me from falling; I remember conciously over-ruling my %0A involuntary motions.  My ears felt (not heard) a rush and I could %0A feel fluid moving in my head (like when you get up from bed while %0A you have a cold). %0A  %0A At that point, I ceased to concentrate on my physiological response, %0A since I had some science to do.  I was busy keeping my experiment %0A going and keeping track of all the parts during the "return" of %0A gravity and subsequent 1.8-G pull-out, so I didn't really pay %0A attention to physiology at that time. %0A  %0A After about 5 parabolas, I discovered that I was performing one %0A of the tricks I've discovered to keep myself from getting motion %0A sickness; I was keeping my head very still and moving very slowly %0A -- all except my hands and arms, which needed to be in rapid, %0A concious motion for my experiment.  During the pull-out to %0A parabola 5, my queasiness finally started to get to me, and I %0A had to use one of those air-sickness bags.  I was basically %0A useless for the rest of that flight, so I went to the seats in %0A the back of the plane while my partner (whom I drafted for just %0A this purpose) kept working on the experiment while I was ill. %0A (He was a vetran Vomit Comet rider, one of those anomalous %0A people who don't get sick on the thing.) %0A  %0A I didn't think of it as a "constant sensation of falling" so %0A much as like swimming in air.  It's very close to the sensations %0A I feel when I'm scuba diving and I turn my head down and fins up. %0A  %0A Jerry %3A  %0A  %3A  >And what is the motion sickness %0A  %3A  >that some astronauts occasionally experience?  %0A  %0A Ron %3A  %0A  %3A  It is the body's reaction to a strange environment.  It appears to be %0A  %3A  induced partly to physical discomfort and part to mental distress. %0A  %3A  Some people are more prone to it than others, like some people are more %0A  %3A  prone to get sick on a roller coaster ride than others.  The mental %0A  %3A  part is usually induced by a lack of clear indication of which way is %0A  %3A  up or down, ie %3A  the Shuttle is normally oriented with its cargo bay %0A  %3A  pointed towards Earth, so the Earth (or ground) is "above" the head of %0A  %3A  the astronauts.  About 50% of the astronauts experience some form of %0A  %3A  motion sickness, and NASA has done numerous tests in space to try to %0A  %3A  see how to keep the number of occurances down. %0A  %0A I'm a volunteer in JSC's Space Biomedical Laboratory where they do, %0A among other things, some of the tests Ron mentions.  I was in one %0A called the Pre-flight Adaptation Trainer, which consisted of a chair on %0A a several-degree-of-freedom motion base with moving geometric visual %0A aids.  The goal was to measure the victim's^H^H^H^H^H^H^H^H subject's %0A responses and subjective physiological descriptions and see if repeated %0A exposure to this environment could reduce future motion sickness %0A symptoms. %0A  %0A Jerry -- %0A  %0A I don't know of any former or active-duty astronauts who personally %0A read this group.  I know that Bruce McCandless's office had been %0A waiting anxiously for the Space Station Redesign option I posted %0A last week, but I don't think Bruce reads the group himself. %0A  %0A -- Ken Jenks, NASA/JSC/GM2, Space Shuttle Program Office %0A       kjenks %40 gothamcity.jsc.nasa.gov  (713) 483-4368 %0A  %0A      "The man who makes no mistakes does not usually make %0A       anything." %0A         -- Edward John Phelps, American Diplomat/Lawyer (1825-1895) %0A
