doc_4340 |@raw_text From %3A  pgf %40 srl03.cacs.usl.edu (Phil G. Fraering) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Over zealous shuttle critics %0A Message-ID %3A  <pgf.737158997 %40 srl03.cacs.usl.edu> %0A Sender %3A  anon %40 usl.edu (Anonymous NNTP Posting) %0A Organization %3A  Univ. of Southwestern Louisiana %0A References %3A  <C6qDMn.A4H %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1shldg$4kt %40 hsc.usc.edu> <C6qL0q.D8G %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1sp319$ai5 %40 hsc.usc.edu> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 11 May 1993 22 %3A 23 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  139 %0A  %0A khayash %40 hsc.usc.edu (Ken Hayashida) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >Rockwell International in Downey, California, in conjunction with the %0A >other shuttle contractors delivered the world's most important and %0A >most revolutionary space vehicle. %0A  %0A Ha! %0A  %0A >One cannot argue with the fact that %0A >it flies, lands, and is reusable.  %0A  %0A Watch me. It flies. It lands. It gets rebuilt. %0A  %0A  %0A >In my opinion, these were the only %0A >appropriate specifications for this program. %0A  %0A That's not what they told us back in the '70's. %0A  %0A >It has been a test program from the start, a logical follow to the %0A >X-15 program and the later X-series lifting bodies. %0A  %0A 1. It isn't a logical follow-on. A logical follow-on would have %0A been either a Russian "snowfox" type thingey (for the lifting bodies) %0A or something like MMI's Space Van (or Boeing's TSTO, or the airbreathing %0A TSTO the military is allegedly _using_ now that probably cost less %0A to develop than the shuttle does to fly for a year). %0A  %0A >The engineering specs that the guys in the trenches had were to %0A >develop a system which was man-ratable, could land reliably, and could %0A >be reflown.  These goals were quite visionary for the 1970's, and I %0A >would argue that they are challenging even today, including for the %0A >DC-X program. %0A  %0A Keep that attitude, and it'll be a couple centuries before we get real %0A access to space, unless another country without all that baggage comes %0A along and kicks our ass in the space race. %0A  %0A >I do not recall a 1 flight/week specification in the final NASA specs for the %0A >space shuttle program.  If you have such documents, I would find them most %0A >revealing and interesting.  As far as I can tell, the only people touting a  %0A >1 flight per week flight rate were people on Capitol Hill or selling books  %0A >to the general public.   %0A  %0A Or NASA HQ. That doesn't give the rest of the program plausible deniability %0A if we deceide that it wasn't worth the money we've spent, which is by now %0A probably a lot more than Apollo. %0A  %0A >IMHO, political statements in the halls of the US Congress are not %0A >admissable as engineering specs because specs should be determined by %0A >NASA/DOD and contractors, not by Congressmen, Senators, or Presidents. %0A >Missions are defined by political leaders, but not the engineering %0A >specs. %0A  %0A Yes, but it gets sold on the basis of the political statements. %0A You're saying basically that it met the engineering specs (which is %0A questionable, IMHO) so it's a success, never mind that you couldn't %0A get the funding the shuttle eats with those engineering specs in %0A a thousand years. %0A  %0A >The shuttle is the only reusable space vehicle.  This automatically %0A >qualifies it as an unparalleled engineering success.  You could argue %0A >about its political success.  But engineering wise, it is clearly the %0A >most advanced machine ever flown.  I argue that engineering and %0A >technical data for hypersonic flight is valuable in and of itself. %0A >Shuttle should be justified or criticized on the basis of economics. %0A  %0A You can get hypersonic flight data with an X-15 or a follow-on X-15 %0A type vehicle for much less. %0A  %0A And economics and engineering are interchangable; engineering in the %0A absense of economics is basically just physics, and in terms of physics, %0A the shuttle looks like a failure next to the X-15. %0A  %0A  %0A Then Henry wrote %3A  %0A  %0A HS>Sorry, support that I can arrange for launchers all goes to launchers %0A HS>that I have some hope of riding some day.  At the moment, that's %0A HS>DC-X's hoped-for successors. %0A  %0A >I was disappointed by this and other similar statements from those vocal in  %0A >support of the DC-X program .  Your support of DC-X is based on hopes. %0A >My support for the shuttle program is based on record.  %0A  %0A The shuttle program has a bad record. I _once_ had hopes for the %0A shuttle program. By now I know those hopes were false.  %0A  %0A All I have for DC-X and similar and dissimilar experimental vehicles %0A are hopes. But at least I know they aren't false hopes yet. %0A  %0A I did support the shuttle, way back when. It didn't do nearly what %0A it was supposed to. It's time to move on to something that might do %0A the job of orbital delivery better. Or at all. %0A  %0A  %0A >I think that it is  %0A >also important to note that I do not object to DC-X.  It is visionary.   %0A >I originally posted %3A  %0A  %0A >> I like the DC-X idea...  and I am really hopeful that it'll be a stunning success  %0A  %0A >Unfortunately, DC-X'ers are not willing to return that support the %0A >proven Shuttle program.  Explain why you folks criticize shuttle when %0A >shuttle is exactly what you guys need in order to learn how to operate %0A >DC-X on-orbit. %0A  %0A We don't want to learn how to operate on orbit. It launches, it %0A shoves out the payload, it lands. It doesn't waste payload hauling %0A up and down EDO pallets and the like. %0A  %0A The only thing to be learned from shuttle is how *not* to build a %0A launcher. %0A  %0A Finally %3A  that bit about the "proven" shuttle. Are you hoping you can %0A tell a lie enough times and get someone to believe it? %0A  %0A >I enjoyed your later postings regarding the comparisons between the shuttle %0A >and the Soyuz project.  Although, I may disagree with your method %0A >of analysis.  You probably will disagree with mine. 8-)  I think that %0A >the total impact of the shuttle program must be judged on the scientific and %0A >technical merit, not on timelines and schedules (do you agree?)  %0A  %0A How much science and technology could have been done is the money spent %0A on shuttle had been spent differently? %0A  %0A ... %0A >As for now, we need to stop thinking of DC-X and shuttle as mutually exclusive. %0A  %0A Learn about economics and the current budget realities in the United States, %0A please. %0A  %0A >Thanks for your time. %0A  %0A -- %0A Phil Fraering         %7C"Number one good faith! You convert, %0A pgf %40 srl02.cacs.usl.edu%7Cyou not tortured by demons!" - anon. Mahen missionary %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_4364 |@raw_text From %3A  mustafa %40 seas.smu.edu (Mustafa Kocaturk) %0A Subject %3A  How starters work really %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr18.030614.13930 %40 seas.smu.edu> %0A Keywords %3A  fluorescent bulb starter neon %0A Sender %3A  news %40 seas.smu.edu (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  turbo_f.seas.smu.edu %0A Organization %3A  SMU - School of Engineering & Applied Science - Dallas %0A References %3A  <734953838.AA00509 %40 insane.apana.org.au> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 03 %3A 06 %3A 14 GMT %0A Lines %3A  28 %0A  %0A In article <734953838.AA00509 %40 insane.apana.org.au> peter.m %40 insane.apana.org.au (Peter Tryndoch) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >So when you turn on the power, this causes the bulb to work like a neon,  %0A >heating up and shorting out, thus providing a loop to power the heaters in  %0A >the main tube. When the tube fires, insufficient current runs through the  %0A >starter to keep the heat up and the bi-metalic strip straightens out  %0A >(O/C). %0A  %0A Imprecise. This description %0A  %0A  1. ignores the role of the ballast, %0A  2. misrepresents the heating effects in the starter. %0A  %0A The bimetalic strip cools down immediately after the contacts %0A short circuit, because the neon discharge stops, and much less %0A heat is generated from the I^2R loss in the metal as compared to %0A the neon discharge. %0A  %0A The starter contacts open before the tube fires.  Actually, %0A the tube fires as a result of the back-emf generated in the ballast %0A because of this immediate opening of the starter's contacts. %0A  %0A A capacitor is connected in parallel with the contacts to prevent %0A excessive arcing during the firing.  The neon reionizes but does not draw %0A sufficient current to prevent firing of the tube itself. %0A --  %0A Mustafa Kocaturk   mustafa %40 seas.smu.edu  EE Dept., Room 305A, Caruth Bldg. %0A Home %3A  214-706-5954  Office %3A  214-768-1475  SMU Box 753190, Dallas, TX 75275 %0A

A sealant was %0A >needed for the tubing in which uranium hexafluoride passed as it was %0A >gradually enriched by difussion. doc_4417 |@raw_text From %3A  kludge %40 grissom.larc.nasa.gov (Scott Dorsey) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Pressure Zone Microphones %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 1993 17 %3A 13 %3A 04 GMT %0A Organization %3A  NASA Langley Research Center and Reptile Farm %0A Lines %3A  43 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1rjpj0INNo78 %40 rave.larc.nasa.gov> %0A References %3A  <1rjobdINNk1s %40 crcnis1.unl.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  grissom.larc.nasa.gov %0A  %0A In article <1rjobdINNk1s %40 crcnis1.unl.edu> mpaul %40 unl.edu (marxhausen paul) writes %3A  %0A >I remember, back before commercial mikes with the "PZM" label (for %0A >Pressure Zone Microphone) started showing up, I read an article, %0A >in some engineering journal, that described the principles involved. %0A >All the physics aside, from a practicle standpoint the author's said %0A >they built a prototype with nothing more than a small Sony lavelier %0A >mike laid up against a large aluminum disk.  In demonstrating it at %0A >a presentation to audio engineers, this was impressive enough that %0A >the people present were bugging them about where they could buy them. %0A  %0A Yup, it's not all that difficult to do. %0A  %0A >Anyway...I want to build some to use as "choir mikes" (wide coverage). %0A >I've had good luck using some small electret mike elements I got %0A >from Digi-Key - most of these are limited-bandwidth, peakey units %0A >but for a buck or two more I got the ones spec'd to go out to 20kHz %0A >with a bit flatter response.   %0A  %0A The Panasonic cartridges aren't bad, but they aren't spectacular. %0A  %0A >The distance of the mike opening from the flat plate is kind of %0A >critical.  I'm debating whether to mount it on it's side, which %0A >puts the opening a shade under 2mm from the plate, or mounting %0A >it with the opening actually pointing down into the plate at a %0A >small clearance.  I haven't dissected a unit like you can buy at %0A >Radio Shack to see how they do it.  Thoughts? %0A  %0A Don't mount it on the side.  Call up Crown, the company that has the %0A patent on the PZM, and ask them for information on construction and %0A use of the things.  You may have to determine the correct spacing %0A emperically with a noise source and a spectrum analyzer because the %0A design of the Panasonic cartridges uses a tuned cavity in front of %0A the electret element to increase the high frequency response, and you %0A are going to be altering the resistance through the cavity entrance. %0A  %0A Crown has a nice book on the subject, though it's unfortunately rather %0A short on mathematics.  There's a JAES article from many years back, too. %0A  %0A Still, for your application, you'll be a lot better off buying the cheap %0A Radio Shack models and using Phil Rastoczny's modifications to get a %0A clean balanced output.  Phil's mods seem to get reposted here on a regular %0A basis. %0A --scott %0A  
doc_4422 |@raw_text From %3A  dp %40 cec1.wustl.edu (David Prutchi) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Long distance IR detection %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.204739.1662 %40 wuecl.wustl.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 wuecl.wustl.edu (News Administrator) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  cec1 %0A Organization %3A  Washington University, St. Louis MO %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.183416.18744 %40 dres.dnd.ca> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 20 %3A 47 %3A 39 GMT %0A Lines %3A  88 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.183416.18744 %40 dres.dnd.ca> sburton %40 dres.dnd.ca (Stan Burton) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >-- %0A > %0A >I would like to be able to detect the angular position (low accuracy) of an %0A >IR emitting source at a distance of about 100 meters (more is better) in %0A >daylight.  The IR source could be emitting a signature; I'm leaning toward %0A >30 KHz square wave with 50% duty cycle. %0A > %0A >I am considering the use of a quadrant detector from Centronic Inc. to give %0A >information to a pan/tilt head to point the sensor and thus determine the %0A >angles.  For the source I am considering wazing the heck out of an IR LED(s), %0A >possibly an Optek OP290 or Motorola MLED81.  Wazing would mean at least 1 Amp %0A >current pulses.  At this current the duty cycle of the LED drops to 10% and I %0A >would need to cycle five of them in turn to get the 50% required. %0A > %0A >Has anyone done something like this? %0A > %0A >Stan Burton (DND/CRAD/DRES/DTD/MSS/AGCG)                 sburton %40 dres.dnd.ca %0A >(403) 544-4737     DRE Suffield, Box 4000, Medicine Hat, AB, Canada, T1A 8K6 %0A  %0A A method which will directly (almost) provide you with the information that %0A you require is that which is commonly used for coordinate measurements of  %0A human body landmarks (eg. the SELSPOT system by SELSPOT AB, Sweden, and the %0A WATSMART System ??).  These use lateral photoeffect detectors [Lindholm and %0A Oberg, 1974; Woltring and Marsolais, 1980] to determine the position of a %0A spot of light projected (using a camera lens) over its surface.  In escence, %0A the detector is a large photodiode with four cathodes (one on each of the %0A four sides of the square detector crystal) and a single anode (the back of %0A the crystal).  A spot of light will produce currents which are proportional %0A to the position of the spot on the detector's face.  Let's try some ASCII %0A graphics in 2-D (so the detector has two cathodes to detect linear position) %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A               -------------------------> 1 %0A              %7C                       %7C %0A              %7C                       %7C       %7C\ %0A            -----   cathode 1         %7C       %7C  \ %0A            XXXXX                     ________%7C +  \ %0A            XXXXX%7C                            %7C      \        ------- %0A     light >XXXXX%7C                            %7C        \_____ divider __ output %0A            XXXXX%7C     %7C                      %7C        /      ------- %0A            XXXXX%7C-----%7C %7C--                  %7C      /           %7C %0A            XXXXX%7C   + %7C    %7C         ________%7C -  /           1 + 2 %0A            XXXXX%7C         --- gnd    %7C       %7C  / %0A            XXXXX%7C         \ /        %7C       %7C/ %0A            XXXXX%7C anode              %7C %0A            XXXXX                     %7C %0A            ----- cathode 2           %7C %0A              %7C                       %7C %0A              %7C                       %7C %0A              --------------------------> 2 %0A  %0A If the dot of light from the LED is the ONLY source of light, then the position %0A of the projection is given by this circuit regardless of the level of illumina- %0A tion (the divider is used to normalize relative to total received power).  When %0A this circuit is used in the presence of other sources of light, then the way of %0A "tuning" to it is to sample for a few msec the background signal, light the LED %0A for an equal time and sample that signal separately.  The difference between %0A the two is the position of the LED. %0A  %0A Hamamatsu photonics sells linear and 2-D lateral photoeffect detectors, and %0A they also sell the required signal processing electronics.  The ready-made %0A systems by SELSPOT and others are NOT cheap ...  %0A  %0A Lindholm, L.E., and K.E. Oberg, "An Optoelectronic Instrument for Remote %0A On-Line Movement Monitoring", Biotelemetry, 1, 94-95, 1974. %0A  %0A Woltring, H.J., and E.B. Marsolais, "Opto-Electronic (SELSPOT) Gait Measure- %0A ments in Two and Three Dimensional Space - A Preliminary Report", Bull. Pros- %0A thetics Research, 46-52, 1980. %0A  %0A Most probably this technique can provide you with a much more accurate %0A measurement than you need, but I think that its simplicity beats scanning %0A a quadrant detector with a pan/tilt system until you reach zero difference. %0A  %0A             - David %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A +------------------------------------------------------------+ %0A %7C  David Prutchi                 HC1DT                       %7C %0A %7C  Washington University         <prutchi %40 mesun4.wustl.edu>  %7C %0A %7C  Campus Box 1185               <dp %40 cec1.wustl.edu>         %7C %0A %7C  One Brookings Drive                                       %7C %0A %7C  St. Louis, MO  63130-4899                                 %7C %0A +------------------------------------------------------------+ %0A

doc_4430 |@raw_text From %3A  smb %40 research.att.com (Steven Bellovin) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Off the shelf cheap DES keyseach machine (Was %3A  Re %3A  Corporate acceptance of the wiretap chip) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.192105.11751 %40 ulysses.att.com> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 19 %3A 21 %3A 05 GMT %0A References %3A  <pgf.735187239 %40 srl03.cacs.usl.edu> <16BB51156.C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu> <1993Apr19.093227.1093 %40 jarvis.csri.toronto.edu> <1993Apr20.150531.2059 %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu> %0A Organization %3A  AT&T Bell Laboratories %0A Lines %3A  28 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.150531.2059 %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu>, jebright %40 magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu (James R Ebright) writes %3A  %0A > Now why is that?  I doubt there is a trapdoor in Skipjack.  (But we will %0A > never know).  And I doubt the NSA would promote a mass market chip they %0A > couldn't compromise.  Ergo, NSA is now capable of compromising (probably %0A > with brute force keysearch) engines of the complexity of Skipjack.  Look %0A > at the specs.  Why, I bet they have thousands of little chips chugging %0A > away in their crypto busters... Maybe even tens of thousands.  Complexity? %0A > Not much more than a 3090.  How many such machines will fit into Fort Meade? %0A  %0A > I think PGP2.3 should have 256 bit IDEA keys... %0A  %0A Thousands?  Tens of thousands?  Do some arithmetic, please...  Skipjack %0A has 2^80 possible keys.  Let's assume a brute-force engine like that %0A hypothesized for DES %3A   1 microsecond per trial, 1 million chips.  That's %0A 10^12 trials per second, or about 38,000 years for 2^80 trials.  Well, %0A maybe they can get chips running at one trial per nanosecond, and build %0A a machine with 10 million chips.  Sure -- only 3.8 years for each solution. %0A  %0A IDEA uses 128-bit keys.  Shall I bother doing the calculations for you? %0A Hint %3A   multiply 3.8 years by 2^(128-80).  And you can't do IDEA at that %0A speed; key setup takes much too long.  I wouldn't be surprised if that %0A were the case for Skipjack, too, though there's no way of knowing just %0A yet.  DES used only xor because that's what was feasible with mid-70's %0A technology.  Modern chips can do a lot more. %0A  %0A NSA may or may not know how to crack Skipjack and IDEA (I doubt it for %0A the former; I have no idea for the latter, though it does seem to be a %0A strong cryptosystem).  But it ain't gonna be by exhaustive search. %0A  
doc_4433 |@raw_text From %3A  ifarqhar %40 laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au (Ian Farquhar) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  ATARI 2600 Processors %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 1993 11 %3A 49 %3A 45 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Macquarie University, Sydney Australia %0A Lines %3A  46 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r8l4p$63h %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A References %3A  <1993Apr21.081317.599 %40 das.harvard.edu> <1r7e14$l2c %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> <1r847f$kp7 %40 uniwa.uwa.edu.au> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au %0A  %0A In article <1r847f$kp7 %40 uniwa.uwa.edu.au> john %40 gu.uwa.edu.au (John West) writes %3A  %0A >ifarqhar %40 laurel.ocs.mq.edu.au (Ian Farquhar) writes %3A  %0A >>Wrong, it has a 6507. %0A  %0A >For those who would like to know, the 6507 was a 6502 without IRQ or NMI, %0A >and with only 13 address lines (giving 8K memory space). %0A  %0A Yes, but still not a 6502 for those differences.  Same instruction set, %0A of course. %0A  %0A >>It had one custom chip (not an ASIC in the sense that word is now understood) %3A  %0A >>the TIA (sometimes known as the 6526, although most other manufacturers list %0A >>that as the CIA complex interface adapter.)  TIA stands for Television %0A >>Interface Adapter, and it handles sound, paddles and the minimal video hardware %0A >>the 2600 possessed. %0A  %0A >Didn't know about it being called the 6526 - thats the CIA found in the %0A >Commodore 64 (I don't believe this chip existed when the 2600 was around). %0A  %0A Yes, the same number, but an entirely different device.  I should have %0A qualified this further by stating that this was the PAL version of the TIA - %0A I am not 100% sure that the NTSC TIA would have a different number. %0A  %0A >The TIA was mapped into the bottom 128 bytes of page 0, and shadowed in the %0A >bottom 128 bytes of page 1. To get an image on the screen, you had to wait %0A >until the raster line your picture started at, load bitmaps for this line %0A >into the 'sprite' registers, tell them what x positions to take, how many %0A >duplicates you wanted, etc, then do it all again for the next line. This %0A >took all of the processor's time during the visible portion of the %0A >display. %0A  %0A Does anyone on the net actually have details of the TIA, as this is the only %0A device I have not yet discovered details about?  Atari Australia, when asked, %0A claimed that their attempts to get the programmers documentation for the 2600 %0A had failed, as the US head office had refused to provide it. %0A  %0A >to chip selects. The 6507 likes to have ROM right at the top of memory, so %0A >the 2600 had to use ROMs with active high chip selects - not exactly %0A >normal, so some cartriges had a 7404 in them to convert this to the more %0A >usual active low chip select. %0A  %0A I saw a couple of cheaper devices with PN2222's and a couple of resistors %0A hooked up as a cheap inverter.  Nasty, but workable, and cheaper than a %0A 7404 inverter if labor costs almost nothing. %0A  %0A 							Ian. %0A

doc_4453 |@raw_text From %3A  ph %40 gmd.de (Peter Hendricks) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Wanted %3A  A to D hardware for a PC %0A Message-ID %3A  <ph.734085977 %40 gmd.de> %0A To %3A  ebuddington %40 eagle.wesleyan.edu %0A Sender %3A  news %40 gmd.de (USENET News) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  gmdzi %0A Organization %3A  GMD, Sankt Augustin, Germany %0A References %3A  <1993Apr2.163825.955 %40 news.wesleyan.edu> <3889 %40 ncr-mpd.FtCollinsCO.NCR.COM> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 6 Apr 1993 08 %3A 46 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A  %0A In <3889 %40 ncr-mpd.FtCollinsCO.NCR.COM> Brad Wright writes %3A  %0A  %0A >	If you know much about PC's (IBM comp) you might try the joystick %0A >port.  Though I haven't tried this myself, I've been told that the port %0A >has built in A-D converters.  This would allow the joystick to be a couple of  %0A >pots.  If you could find the specs this might just work for you... %0A  %0A I guess 100k, connecting pins 1-3 (1x), 1-6 (1y), 9-11 (2x), and 9-13 (2y). %0A  %0A Or %3A  Get an 8-bit DA-Converter (merely a couple of transistors and %0A Resistors) and an OpAmp to compare its output to the voltage you want to %0A measure, connect them to a spared printer port (if you have one), and do %0A the rest by software (stepwise refinement). The port addresses for your %0A printer ports are probably %3A  &H378 (LPT1), &H278 (LPT2). This should work %0A well enough for your purposes. %0A  %0A Hope this helps %0A  %0A -- %0A GMD,  Schloss Birlinghoven,  Postfach 1316,  D-5205 St. Augustin 1,  FRG %0A  %0A e-mail %3A   Peter.Hendricks %40 gmd.de			ph %40 zi.gmd.dbp.de %0A 	 ph %40 gmd.de %0A

Software Services %0A Disclaimer %3A  This posting represents the poster's views, not those of IBM %0A News-Software %3A  UReply 3.1 %0A Lines %3A  91 %0A  %0A In <C5uBn5.tz %40 zoo.toronto.edu> Henry Spencer writes %3A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.134436.26140 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> mccall %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com (fred j mccall 575-3539) writes %3A  %0A >>>>(given that I've heard the Shuttle software rated as Level 5 ... %0A >>>Level 5? Also keep in mind that it was %0A >>*not* achieved through the use of sophisticated tools, but rather %0A >>through a 'brute force and ignorance' attack on the problem during the %0A >>Challenger standdown - they simply threw hundreds of people at it and %0A >>did the whole process by hand... %0A > %0A >I think this is a little inaccurate, based on Feynman's account of the %0A >software-development process *before* the standdown. But they got this one right *before* Challenger; Feynman cited %0A >the software people as exemplary compared to the engine people.  (He %0A >also noted that the software people were starting to feel management %0A >pressure to cut corners, but hadn't had to give in to it much yet.) %0A > %0A >Among other things, the software people worked very hard to get things %0A >right for the major pre-flight simulations, and considered a failure %0A >during those simulations to be nearly as bad as an in-flight failure. %0A >As a result, the number of major-simulation failures could be counted %0A >on one hand, and the number of in-flight failures was zero. %0A > %0A >As Fred mentioned elsewhere, this applies only to the flight software. %0A >Software that runs experiments is typically mostly put together by the %0A >experimenters, and gets nowhere near the same level of Tender Loving Care. %0A >(None of the experimenters could afford it.) %0A >-- %0A >All work is one man's work.             %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A >                    - Kipling           %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A > %0A News-Software %3A  UReply 3.1 %0A X-X-From %3A  Wingert %40 VNET.IBM.com (Bret Wingert) %0A References %3A  <C5sy4s.4x2.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> <1993Apr21.134436.26140 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> %0A             <C5uBn5.tz %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A  %0A In <C5uBn5.tz %40 zoo.toronto.edu> Henry Spencer writes %3A  %0A >In article <1993Apr21.134436.26140 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> mccall %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com (fred j mccall 575-3539) writes %3A  %0A >>>>(given that I've heard the Shuttle software rated as Level 5 ... %0A >>>Level 5?  Out of how many? ... %0A >> %0A >>... Also keep in mind that it was %0A >>*not* achieved through the use of sophisticated tools, but rather %0A >>through a 'brute force and ignorance' attack on the problem during the %0A >>Challenger standdown - they simply threw hundreds of people at it and %0A >>did the whole process by hand... %0A > %0A >I think this is a little inaccurate, based on Feynman's account of the %0A >software-development process *before* the standdown.  Fred is basically %0A >correct %3A   no sophisticated tools, just a lot of effort and painstaking %0A >care.  But they got this one right *before* Challenger; Feynman cited %0A >the software people as exemplary compared to the engine people.  (He %0A >also noted that the software people were starting to feel management %0A >pressure to cut corners, but hadn't had to give in to it much yet.) %0A > %0A >As Fred mentioned elsewhere, this applies only to the flight software. %0A >Software that runs experiments is typically mostly put together by the %0A >experimenters, and gets nowhere near the same level of Tender Loving Care. %0A  ======================================================================== %0A A couple of points on this thread. %0A  %0A 1. We have been using our processes since way before Challenger.  Challenger %0A    in and of it self did not uncover flaws. %0A  %0A 2. What Mr. Spencer says is by and large true.  We have a process that is %0A    not dependent on "sophisticated tools"  (CASE tools?).  However, tools %0A    cannot fix a bad process.  Also, tool support for HAL/S (the Shuttle %0A    Language) is somewhat limited. %0A  %0A 3. The Onboard Flight Software project was rated "Level 5" by a NASA team. %0A    This group generates 20-40 KSLOCs of verified code per year for NASA. %0A  %0A 4. Feel free to call me if you or your organization is interested in more info %0A    on our software development process. %0A  %0A Bret Wingert %0A  %0A  %0A (713)-282-7534 %0A FAX %3A  (713)-282-8077 %0A  %0A  %0A Bret Wingert %0A  %0A  %0A (713)-282-7534 %0A FAX %3A  (713)-282-8077 %0A  %0A  %0A

Since the %0A >majority of accidents are the cagers' fault, doesn't this imply that we %0A >would have to pay much higher rates under a No-Fault system? %0A > %0A >With a cars-only system, it seems to make sense on the surface %3A  take the %0A >legal costs out of the system.  But it looks like motorcyclists would %0A >get screwed. %0A  %0A 	Yup.  Unfortunately, as has been pointed out, the cost of insurance %0A does NOT go down with No Fault.  The crappiest drivers make out like bandits %0A because they no longer have to bear the responsibility of paying for %0A insurance that they have boosted in price for themselves by being crappy %0A drivers.  The good drivers now pay through the nose to spread the cost of %0A the crappy drivers' actions, and that's not fair. %0A  %0A 	Any plan that caps rates for crappy drivers is inherently a piece of %0A shit, because the rest of us end up paying more. %0A  %0A 	Any plan that uses speeding tickets as a basis for raising rates is %0A also a piece of shit as it is based upon the lie that faster drivers are %0A inherently less safe than slower drivers, and the NHTSA disproved that two %0A years ago now. %0A  %0A Later, %0A --  %0A Chris BeHanna	DoD# 114          1983 H-D FXWG Wide Glide - Jubilee's Red Lady %0A behanna %40 syl.nj.nec.com	          1975 CB360T - Baby Bike %0A Disclaimer %3A   Now why would NEC	  1991 ZX-11 - needs a name %0A agree with any of this anyway? doc_4476 |@raw_text From %3A  kadie %40 cs.uiuc.edu (Carl M Kadie) %0A Subject %3A  [EFF] Initial EFF Analysis of Clinton Privacy and Security Proposal %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5LH1y.LsM %40 cs.uiuc.edu> %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.crypt,comp.org.eff.talk %0A Organization %3A  University of Illinois, Dept. of Comp. Sci., Urbana, IL %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 21 %3A 01 %3A 10 GMT %0A Lines %3A  107 %0A  %0A [An article from comp.org.eff.news, EFFector Online 5.06 - Carl] %0A  %0A                        April 16, 1993 %0A  %0A       INITIAL EFF ANALYSIS OF CLINTON PRIVACY AND SECURITY   %0A                            PROPOSAL %0A  %0A        The Clinton Administration today made a major announcement  %0A on cryptography policy which will effect the privacy and security of  %0A millions of Americans.  The first part of the plan is to begin a  %0A comprehensive inquiry into major communications privacy issues  %0A such as export controls which have effectively denied most people  %0A easy access to robust encryption as well as law enforcement issues  %0A posed by new technology. %0A  %0A        However, EFF is very concerned that the Administration has  %0A already reached a conclusion on one critical part of the inquiry, before  %0A any public comment or discussion has been allowed.  Apparently, the  %0A Administration is going to use its leverage to get all telephone  %0A equipment vendors to adopt a voice encryption standard developed  %0A by the National Security Agency. The so-called "Clipper Chip" is an  %0A 80-bit, split key escrowed encryption scheme which will be built into  %0A chips manufactured by a military contractor.  Two separate escrow  %0A agents would store users' keys, and be required to turn them over  %0A law enforcement upon presentation of a valid warrant.  The  %0A encryption scheme used is to be classified, but they chips will be  %0A available to any manufacturer for incorporation into their  %0A communications products. %0A  %0A        This proposal raises a number of serious concerns . %0A  %0A        First, the Administration appears to be adopting a solution  %0A before conducting an inquiry.  The NSA-developed Clipper chip may  %0A not be the most secure product. Other vendors or developers may  %0A have better schemes. Furthermore, we should not rely on the  %0A government as the sole source for Clipper or any other chips.  Rather, %0A independent chip manufacturers should be able to produce chipsets  %0A based on open standards. %0A  %0A        Second, an algorithm can not be trusted unless it can be tested.  %0A Yet the Administration proposes to keep the chip algorithm  %0A classified.  EFF believes that any standard adopted ought to be public  %0A and open.  The public will only have confidence in the security of a  %0A standard that is open to independent, expert scrutiny.   %0A  %0A        Third, while the use of the split-key, dual-escrowed  %0A system may prove to be a reasonable balance between privacy and  %0A law enforcement needs, the details of this scheme must be explored  %0A publicly before it is adopted.  What will give people confidence in the  %0A safety of their keys?  Does disclosure of keys to a third party waive  %0A individual's fifth amendment rights in subsequent criminal  %0A inquiries?   %0A  %0A        In sum, the Administration has shown great sensitivity to the  %0A importance of these issues by planning a comprehensive inquiry into  %0A digital privacy and security.  However, the "Clipper chip" solution  %0A ought to be considered as part of the inquiry, not be adopted before  %0A the discussion even begins. %0A  %0A DETAILS OF THE PROPOSAL %3A  %0A  %0A ESCROW %0A  %0A The 80-bit key will be divided between two escrow agents, each of  %0A whom hold 40 bits of each key.  Upon presentation of a valid  %0A warrant, the two escrow agents would have to turn the key parts  %0A over to law enforcement agents.  Most likely the Attorney General  %0A will be asked to identify appropriate escrow agents.  Some in the  %0A Administration have suggested one non-law enforcement federal  %0A agency, perhaps the Federal Reserve, and one non-governmental  %0A organization.  But, there is no agreement on the identity of the agents  %0A yet. %0A  %0A Key registration would be done by the manufacturer of the  %0A communications device.  A key is tied to the device, not to the person  %0A using it. %0A  %0A CLASSIFIED ALGORITHM AND THE POSSIBILITY OF BACK DOORS %0A  %0A The Administration claims that there are no back door means by  %0A which the government or others could break the code without  %0A securing keys from the escrow agents and that the President will  %0A be told there are no back doors to this classified algorithm.  In order  %0A to prove this, Administration sources are interested in arranging for  %0A an all-star crypto cracker team to come in, under a security  %0A arrangement, and examine the algorithm for trap doors.  The results  %0A of the investigation would then be made public. %0A  %0A GOVERNMENT AS MARKET DRIVER %0A  %0A In order to get a market moving, and to show that the government  %0A believes in the security of this system, the feds will be the first big  %0A customers for this product.  Users will include the FBI, Secret Service,  %0A VP Al Gore, and maybe even the President.  %0A  %0A FROM MORE INFORMATION CONTACT %3A  %0A  %0A Jerry Berman, Executive Director %0A Daniel J. Weitzner, Senior Staff Counsel %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Carl Kadie -- I do not represent any organization; this is just me. %0A  = kadie %40 cs.uiuc.edu = %0A

doc_4506 |@raw_text From %3A  ez019654 %40 othello.ucdavis.edu (Victoria Milliron) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Message-ID %3A  <C60DvH.FAn %40 ucdavis.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 ucdavis.edu (News Administrator) %0A Organization %3A  University of California, Davis %0A X-Newsreader %3A  Tin 1.1 PL3 %0A References %3A  <1rc4dbINNp44 %40 phage.cshl.org> %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 22 %3A 16 %3A 29 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A Hmmm... %0A   A possibility for the software registration conondrum would be to have the %0A distributor register the copy when the software was sold.  The clerk sticks it %0A in the store PC and asks for the buyers ID. Later, if pirated versions showed up they could be tracked to the original purchaser. In addition copies which were %0A sent to distributors/stores would have a vendor reg # or serial # in order to %0A track in store piracy. %0A  %0A Possible additional program security schemes would be %3A  %0A 1. having monthly password changes which necessitate user call in %0A    and registration. (inconvenient) %0A 2. taking dire legal action on anyone caught (expensive) %0A 3. encryption, crc check, self modifying code (limited effectiveness) %0A 4. have an independent watchdog program in the installation/setup config or %0A    memory manager, etc. which would check the main program's crc.  %0A    (only as effective as above methods at best.) %0A 5. have the above watchdog circulating as a virus which would trash cracked  %0A    copies of the program and/or the offenders hard drive. (risky, and probably %0A    illegal, certainly immoral) %0A  %0A my new ideas aren't terribly feasible to implement as presented, but I thought %0A if I threw them out people could think of variations that might be effective. %0A What is the problem with parallel port security keys? I haven't used anything %0A that had hardware key copy protection schemes, so I don't know what the %0A drawbacks are. I know the companies that make them claim they're uncrackable, %0A but I've seen cracks of AutoDesk 3d-studio floating around (I don't have one %0A so don't ask) and I had heard that it had parralel port keys. %0A  %0A vamilliron %40 othello.ucd.edu %0A -my apologies if I rambled, but vi inhibits my communication skills greatly. %0A

Especially for a foreign intelligence agency %0A >or organized crime boss?)  However, even if more intelligent schemes are used %0A >to allow access to the unencrypted phone conversations, there will be weak- %0A >nesses.  They may be very expensive, and very difficult.  But who would %0A >trust his/her confidential information to an encryption scheme that, for %0A >(say) $100,000 could by cracked one time in a hundred?  (DES, for all the %0A >complaints about a 56-bit key, would probably cost several million dollars %0A >to build a keysearch machine for.) %0A >  %0A  %0A I can buy a DES keysearch machine off the shelf now for approx $500K, but %0A it is not sold by that name. Go buy a circuit emulation machine (eg. Quickturn) %0A containing a bunch of FPGAs, (say 500 to 1000 3090's), and program each %0A to be a DES search engine. Lets say 500 chips, running at 10Mhz = 5G tests/sec. %0A Time is 14e6 sec max = 23 weeks, 12 weeks average. Can't wait that long? %0A Buy a bigger machine. %0A  %0A  %0A David Lewis %0A

doc_4541 |@raw_text From %3A  cyborg %40 kauri.vuw.ac.nz (-xivo-Alex Ivopol) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1r6uqq$f8d %40 st-james.comp.vuw.ac.nz> %0A Date %3A  22 Apr 93 20 %3A 22 %3A 50 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  st-james.1r6uqq$f8d %0A References %3A  <1993Apr21.141137.863 %40 imag.fr> <1993Apr22.163605.24784 %40 csus.edu> <MCHEN.93Apr22131702 %40 terra.cs.psu.edu> %0A Organization %3A  Victoria University of Wellington %0A Lines %3A  31 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kauri.vuw.ac.nz %0A  %0A In article <MCHEN.93Apr22131702 %40 terra.cs.psu.edu> mchen %40 terra.cs.psu.edu (Michael Chen) writes %3A  %0A >If companies compressed their executables with LZW andd did some kind of %0A >encryption in the process, this "change two bytes here" thing would go right %0A >out the window. %0A  %0A Not entirely true. A friend of mine was having trouble finishing the game %0A GODS and asked me for help since he could not find a "trainer" (small %0A patch that lets you play without losing lifes). The game is compressed but %0A I did find *one* byte which when changed in the original *compressed* file %0A would not affect the decompression and would also prevent the "shield" in the %0A game from being tured off turning therefore making you invincible. %0A  %0A There are many other progs whose copy protection was defeated one way or %0A another and I have seen examples of this with my own eyes. The copy %0A protection schemes defeated were various such as using protected mode, %0A compressed executables, progs that load and execute other progs (possibly %0A compressed), dongles, key disks, etc... %0A  %0A I believe that persistence overcomes even the very best copy protection %0A schemes. %0A  %0A >-- %0A > Michael Chen			%7C From the depths of our most lucid horrors %7C %0A >				%7C spring our fond hopes and pure desires... %7C %0A > mchen %40 cs.psu.edu		%7C except what comes from HELL!  %3A -) 7/23/92  %7C %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Alex T. doc_4548 |@raw_text From %3A  gary %40 ke4zv.uucp (Gary Coffman) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  What if the USSR had reached the Moon first? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.152819.28186 %40 ke4zv.uucp> %0A Reply-To %3A  gary %40 ke4zv.UUCP (Gary Coffman) %0A Organization %3A  Destructive Testing Systems %0A References %3A  <1993Apr06.020021.186145 %40 zeus.calpoly.edu> <93107.144339SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> <1993Apr18.091051.14496 %40 ke4zv.uucp> <93110.031905SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 15 %3A 28 %3A 19 GMT %0A Lines %3A  63 %0A  %0A In article <93110.031905SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> Graydon <SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> writes %3A  %0A >In article <1993Apr18.091051.14496 %40 ke4zv.uucp>, gary %40 ke4zv.uucp (Gary Coffman) %0A >says %3A  %0A >>It's conceivable that Luna will have a military purpose, it's possible %0A >>that Luna will have a commercial purpose, but it's most likely that %0A >>Luna will only have a scientific purpose for the next several hundred %0A >>years at least. Therefore, Lunar bases should be predicated on funding %0A >>levels little different from those found for Antarctic bases. Can you %0A >>put a 200 person base on the Moon for $30 million a year? Even if you %0A >>use grad students? %0A > %0A >You might be able to _run_ one for that; put it there, hardly. %0A > %0A >Why do you think at least a couple centuries before there will %0A >be significant commerical activity on the Moon? %0A  %0A Wishful thinking mostly. It's more likely that the Moon will never %0A be the site of major commercial activity. As far as we know it has no %0A materials we can't get cheaper right here on Earth or from asteroids %0A and comets, aside from the semi-mythic He3 that *might* be useful in low %0A grade fusion reactors. Exploring it would satisfy a curiosity itch,  %0A and it's position in the gravity well of Earth coupled with it's heat  %0A sink capacity could offer some military utility for "high ground" military %0A weapons systems, but it holds very minute commercial value. If space  %0A travel becomes cheap enough, it might become a tourist attraction as  %0A Mt. Everest and the Antarctic have become, but that's a very minor  %0A activity in the global scope of things. %0A  %0A Luna has an inconvienent gravity field. It's likely too low to prevent %0A calcium loss, muscle atrophy, and long term genetic drift. Yet it's %0A too high to do micro-G manufacturing. Space based colonies and factories %0A that can be spun to any convienent value of G look much better. Luna %0A has a modest vacuum and raw solar exposure two weeks a month, but orbital %0A sites can have better vacuums and continous solar exposure. Luna offers %0A a source of light element rocks that can serve as raw materials, heatsink, %0A and shielding. The asteroids and comets offer sources of both light and %0A heavy elements, and volatile compounds, and many are in less steep gravity %0A wells so that less delta-v is required to reach them. %0A  %0A We don't use 2/3rds of the Earth now, the seafloors, and we virtually %0A ignore Antarctica, a whole continent. That's because we don't have to %0A deal with those conditions in order to make a buck. Luna is a much more %0A expensive place to visit, or to live and work. I think we'll use the %0A easier places first. That pushes Lunar development back at least a few %0A centuries, if not much longer. %0A  %0A Luna's main short term value would be as a place for a farside radio %0A astronomy observatory, shielded from the noisy Earth. Or as the site %0A of a laser, particle beam, or linear accelerator weapons system for %0A defending Earth, or bombarding it as the case may be. The first is %0A unlikely because of the high cost for such a basic science instrument. %0A The second is just as unlikely because conventional nukes are good %0A enough, and the military would really rather see the Earth safe for %0A conventional warfare again. There's little glory in watching from a %0A bunker as machines fight each other over continental ranges. Little %0A ultimate profit either. %0A  %0A Gary %0A --  %0A Gary Coffman KE4ZV          %7C    You make it,     %7C gatech!wa4mei!ke4zv!gary %0A Destructive Testing Systems %7C    we break it.     %7C uunet!rsiatl!ke4zv!gary %0A 534 Shannon Way             %7C    Guaranteed!      %7C emory!kd4nc!ke4zv!gary  %0A Lawrenceville, GA 30244     %7C                     %7C  %0A

doc_4558 |@raw_text From %3A  baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) %0A Subject %3A  Galileo Update - 04/15/93 %0A Date %3A  15 Apr 1993 21 %3A 18 UT %0A Organization %3A  Jet Propulsion Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  113 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <15APR199321183387 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A Keywords %3A  Galileo, JPL %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A Forwarded from Neal Ausman, Galileo Mission Director %0A  %0A                                 GALILEO %0A                      MISSION DIRECTOR STATUS REPORT %0A                              POST-LAUNCH %0A                          April 9 - 15, 1993 %0A  %0A SPACECRAFT %0A  %0A 1.  On April 9, real-time commands were sent, as planned, to reacquire %0A celestial reference after completion of the Low Gain Antenna (LGA-2) %0A swing/Dual Drive Actuator (DDA) hammer activities. %0A  %0A 2.  On April 9, the EJ-1 (Earth-Jupiter #1) sequence memory load was uplinked %0A to the spacecraft without incident.  This sequence covers spacecraft activity %0A from April 12, 1993 to June 14, 1993 and includes a window for the Radio Relay %0A Antenna (RRA) slew test on April 28, 1993.  The command loss timer was set to %0A 11 days as a part of this sequence memory load. %0A  %0A 3.  On April 12 and 15, a NO-OP command was sent to reset the command loss %0A timer to 264 hours, its planned value during this mission phase. %0A  %0A 4.  On April 12, cruise science Memory Readouts (MROs) were performed for the %0A Extreme Ultraviolet Spectrometer (EUV), Dust Detector (DDS), and Magnetometer %0A (MAG) instruments.  Preliminary analysis indicates the data was received %0A properly. %0A  %0A 5.  On April 12, an Ultra-Stable Oscillator (USO) test was performed to verify %0A the health status of the USO and to collect gravitational red shift experiment %0A data; long term trend analysis is continuing. %0A  %0A 6.  On April 14, a 40bps modulation index test was performed to determine the %0A optimal Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) when transmitting at 40bps.  Preliminary %0A analysis of the data suggests that the present pre-launch selected modulation %0A index is near the optimal level. %0A  %0A 7.  On April 15, cruise science Memory Readouts (MROs) were performed for the %0A Extreme Ultraviolet Spectrometer (EUV) and Magnetometer (MAG) instrument. %0A Preliminary analysis indicates the data was received properly. %0A  %0A 8.  On April 15, a periodic RPM (Retro-Propulsion Module) 10-Newton thruster %0A flushing maintenance activity was performed; all 12 thrusters were flushed %0A during the activity.  Thruster performance throughout the activity was nominal. %0A  %0A 9.  The AC/DC bus imbalance measurements have not exhibited significant %0A changes (greater than 25 DN) throughout this period.  The AC measurement reads %0A 19 DN (4.3 volts).  The DC measurement reads 111 DN (12.9 volts).  These %0A measurements are consistent with the model developed by the AC/DC special %0A anomaly team. %0A  %0A 10. The Spacecraft status as of April 15, 1993, is as follows %3A  %0A  %0A        a)  System Power Margin -  60 watts %0A        b)  Spin Configuration - Dual-Spin %0A        c)  Spin Rate/Sensor - 3.15rpm/Star Scanner %0A        d)  Spacecraft Attitude is approximately 18 degrees %0A            off-sun (lagging) and 6 degrees off-earth (leading) %0A        e)  Downlink telemetry rate/antenna- 40bps(coded)/LGA-1 %0A        f)  General Thermal Control - all temperatures within %0A            acceptable range %0A        g)  RPM Tank Pressures - all within acceptable range %0A        h)  Orbiter Science- Instruments powered on are the PWS, %0A            EUV, UVS, EPD, MAG, HIC, and DDS %0A        i)  Probe/RRH - powered off, temperatures within %0A            acceptable range %0A        j)  CMD Loss Timer Setting - 264 hours %0A            Time To Initiation - 260 hours %0A  %0A  %0A GDS (Ground Data Systems) %3A  %0A  %0A 1.  Galileo participated in a second DSN (Deep Space Network) acceptance test %0A for the DSN Telemetry Phase 3 Upgrade on April 13, 1993, using CTA-21 %0A (Compatibility Test Area 21).  The purpose of this test was to verify %0A the flow of Galileo telemetry data through the new Telemetry Group Controller %0A (TGC) and the Telemetry Channel Assembly (TCA).  The TGC/TCA is the replacement %0A for the current Telemetry Processing Assembly (TPA).  Seven different telemetry %0A rates were run for this test; all ran well on both the MTS (MCCC Telemetry %0A Subsystem) and the AMMOS MGDS V18.0 GIF with the exception of 10bps.  The %0A 10bps rate had some trouble staying in lock; it appears the TGC/TCA was %0A not metering the data correctly.  Further comparisons between the MGDS and MTS %0A data from this test are being conducted. MVT (Mission Verification Test) of %0A the TGC/TCA system is expected to begin May 16, 1993. %0A  %0A  %0A TRAJECTORY %0A  %0A      As of noon Thursday, April 15, 1993, the Galileo Spacecraft trajectory %0A status was as follows %3A  %0A  %0A 	Distance from Earth         152,606,000 km (1.02 AU) %0A 	Distance from Sun           277,519,800 km (1.86 AU) %0A 	Heliocentric Speed          93,400 km per hour %0A 	Distance from Jupiter       543,973,900 km %0A 	Round Trip Light Time       17 minutes, 4 seconds %0A  %0A  %0A SPECIAL TOPIC %0A  %0A 1.  As of April 15, 1993, a total of 70184 real-time commands have been %0A transmitted to Galileo since Launch.  Of these, 65076  were initiated in the %0A sequence design process and 5108 initiated in the real-time command process. %0A In the past week, 7 real time commands were transmitted %3A  6 were initiated in %0A the sequence design process and one initiated in the real time command process. %0A Major command activities included commands to reacquire celestial reference, %0A uplink the EJ-1 sequence memory load, and reset the command loss timer. %0A      ___    _____     ___ %0A     /_ /%7C  /____/ \  /_ /%7C     Ron Baalke         %7C baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C  __ \ /%7C %7C %7C %7C     Jet Propulsion Lab %7C %0A  ___%7C %7C %7C %7C %7C__) %7C/  %7C %7C %7C__   M/S 525-3684 Telos %7C Being cynical never helps  %0A /___%7C %7C %7C %7C  ___/    %7C %7C/__ /%7C Pasadena, CA 91109 %7C to correct the situation  %0A %7C_____%7C/  %7C_%7C/       %7C_____%7C/                     %7C and causes more aggravation %0A                                                   %7C instead. %0A

doc_4573 |@raw_text From %3A  pat %40 rwing.UUCP (Pat Myrto) %0A Subject %3A  New Clipper Chip Proposal from the Guv... %0A Keywords %3A  encryption,privacy,individual rights,legalities,big brother %0A Message-ID %3A  <2069 %40 rwing.UUCP> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 17 %3A 34 %3A 25 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Totally Unorganized %0A Lines %3A  310 %0A  %0A I saw this article posted in a local newsgroup.  I haven't seen it, %0A or any followup traffic relating to it in these groups or other groups %0A which I subscribe to.  So, I am posting it here so others can read it, %0A check it out, and comment on it, and provide ideas for handling these %0A sorts of things. %0A  %0A I have no verification to the accuracy or lack of accuracy of this %0A article, but if accurate, I find it extremely disturbing, especially in %0A light of various abuses of the SSN number regarding privacy, (I understand %0A it is now to be required in CA to renew a drivers license, or to register %0A a car) and other proposals regarding 'smart' national Identity Cards, %0A wiretap proposals, and such.  One simply wonders what other gems are in %0A the wings ready to be sprung on the people by our government.  Perhaps %0A suggestions and ideas for preventing this and other such proposals from %0A acquiring the force of law would be useful.  The cost simply outweighs %0A any possible benefits, IMO. %0A  %0A BTW, reading this makes me think of some ideas a Prof Denning has been %0A promoting, in an even more disturbing form. %0A  %0A That said, with no further comment, the article follows %3A  %0A  %0A ------------ Begin included article --------- %0A  %0A Note %3A   This file will also be available via anonymous file %0A transfer from csrc.ncsl.nist.gov in directory /pub/nistnews and %0A via the NIST Computer Security BBS at 301-948-5717. %0A      --------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A                          THE WHITE HOUSE %0A  %0A                   Office of the Press Secretary %0A  %0A _________________________________________________________________ %0A  %0A For Immediate Release                           April 16, 1993 %0A  %0A  %0A                 STATEMENT BY THE PRESS SECRETARY %0A  %0A  %0A The President today announced a new initiative that will bring %0A the Federal Government together with industry in a voluntary %0A program to improve the security and privacy of telephone %0A communications while meeting the legitimate needs of law %0A enforcement. %0A  %0A The initiative will involve the creation of new products to %0A accelerate the development and use of advanced and secure %0A telecommunications networks and wireless communications links. %0A  %0A For too long there has been little or no dialogue between our %0A private sector and the law enforcement community to resolve the %0A tension between economic vitality and the real challenges of %0A protecting Americans.  Rather than use technology to accommodate %0A the sometimes competing interests of economic growth, privacy and %0A law enforcement, previous policies have pitted government against %0A industry and the rights of privacy against law enforcement. %0A  %0A Sophisticated encryption technology has been used for years to %0A protect electronic funds transfer.  It is now being used to %0A protect electronic mail and computer files.  While encryption %0A technology can help Americans protect business secrets and the %0A unauthorized release of personal information, it also can be used %0A by terrorists, drug dealers, and other criminals. %0A  %0A A state-of-the-art microcircuit called the "Clipper Chip" has %0A been developed by government engineers.  The chip represents a %0A new approach to encryption technology.  It can be used in new, %0A relatively inexpensive encryption devices that can be attached to %0A an ordinary telephone.  It scrambles telephone communications %0A using an encryption algorithm that is more powerful than many in %0A commercial use today. %0A  %0A This new technology will help companies protect proprietary %0A information, protect the privacy of personal phone conversations %0A and prevent unauthorized release of data transmitted %0A electronically.  At the same time this technology preserves the %0A ability of federal, state and local law enforcement agencies to %0A intercept lawfully the phone conversations of criminals.  %0A  %0A A "key-escrow" system will be established to ensure that the %0A "Clipper Chip" is used to protect the privacy of law-abiding %0A Americans.  Each device containing the chip will have two unique %0A  %0A  %0A                                 2 %0A  %0A  %0A "keys," numbers that will be needed by authorized government %0A agencies to decode messages encoded by the device.  When the %0A device is manufactured, the two keys will be deposited separately %0A in two "key-escrow" data bases that will be established by the %0A Attorney General.  Access to these keys will be limited to %0A government officials with legal authorization to conduct a %0A wiretap. %0A  %0A The "Clipper Chip" technology provides law enforcement with no %0A new authorities to access the content of the private %0A conversations of Americans. %0A  %0A To demonstrate the effectiveness of this new technology, the %0A Attorney General will soon purchase several thousand of the new %0A devices.  In addition, respected experts from outside the %0A government will be offered access to the confidential details of %0A the algorithm to assess its capabilities and publicly report %0A their findings. %0A  %0A The chip is an important step in addressing the problem of %0A encryption's dual-edge sword %3A   encryption helps to protect the %0A privacy of individuals and industry, but it also can shield %0A criminals and terrorists.  We need the "Clipper Chip" and other %0A approaches that can both provide law-abiding citizens with access %0A to the encryption they need and prevent criminals from using it %0A to hide their illegal activities.  In order to assess technology %0A trends and explore new approaches (like the key-escrow system), %0A the President has directed government agencies to develop a %0A comprehensive policy on encryption that accommodates %3A  %0A  %0A      --   the privacy of our citizens, including the need to %0A           employ voice or data encryption for business purposes; %0A  %0A      --   the ability of authorized officials to access telephone %0A           calls and data, under proper court or other legal %0A           order, when necessary to protect our citizens; %0A  %0A      --   the effective and timely use of the most modern %0A           technology to build the National Information %0A           Infrastructure needed to promote economic growth and %0A           the competitiveness of American industry in the global %0A           marketplace; and  %0A  %0A      --   the need of U.S. companies to manufacture and export %0A           high technology products. %0A  %0A The President has directed early and frequent consultations with %0A affected industries, the Congress and groups that advocate the %0A privacy rights of individuals as policy options are developed. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A                                 3 %0A  %0A The Administration is committed to working with the private %0A sector to spur the development of a National Information %0A Infrastructure which will use new telecommunications and computer %0A technologies to give Americans unprecedented access to %0A information.  This infrastructure of high-speed networks %0A ("information superhighways") will transmit video, images, HDTV %0A programming, and huge data files as easily as today's telephone %0A system transmits voice. %0A  %0A Since encryption technology will play an increasingly important %0A role in that infrastructure, the Federal Government must act %0A quickly to develop consistent, comprehensive policies regarding %0A its use.  The Administration is committed to policies that %0A protect all Americans' right to privacy while also protecting %0A them from those who break the law. %0A  %0A Further information is provided in an accompanying fact sheet.  %0A The provisions of the President's directive to acquire the new %0A encryption technology are also available.   %0A  %0A For additional details, call Mat Heyman, National Institute of %0A Standards and Technology, (301) 975-2758. %0A  %0A --------------------------------- %0A  %0A  %0A QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ABOUT THE CLINTON ADMINISTRATION'S %0A TELECOMMUNICATIONS INITIATIVE %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Q %3A    Does this approach expand the authority of government %0A      agencies to listen in on phone conversations? %0A  %0A A %3A    No.  "Clipper Chip" technology provides law enforcement with %0A      no new authorities to access the content of the private %0A      conversations of Americans. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Suppose a law enforcement agency is conducting a wiretap on %0A      a drug smuggling ring and intercepts a conversation %0A      encrypted using the device.  What would they have to do to %0A      decipher the message? %0A  %0A A %3A    They would have to obtain legal authorization, normally a %0A      court order, to do the wiretap in the first place.  They %0A      would then present documentation of this authorization to %0A      the two entities responsible for safeguarding the keys and %0A      obtain the keys for the device being used by the drug %0A      smugglers.  The key is split into two parts, which are %0A      stored separately in order to ensure the security of the key %0A      escrow system. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Who will run the key-escrow data banks? %0A  %0A A %3A    The two key-escrow data banks will be run by two independent %0A      entities.  At this point, the Department of Justice and the %0A      Administration have yet to determine which agencies will %0A      oversee the key-escrow data banks. %0A  %0A Q %3A    How strong is the security in the device?  How can I be sure %0A      how strong the security is?   %0A  %0A A %3A    This system is more secure than many other voice encryption %0A      systems readily available today.  While the algorithm will %0A      remain classified to protect the security of the key escrow %0A      system, we are willing to invite an independent panel of %0A      cryptography experts to evaluate the algorithm to assure all %0A      potential users that there are no unrecognized %0A      vulnerabilities. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Whose decision was it to propose this product? %0A  %0A A %3A    The National Security Council, the Justice Department, the %0A      Commerce Department, and other key agencies were involved in %0A      this decision.  This approach has been endorsed by the %0A      President, the Vice President, and appropriate Cabinet %0A      officials. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Who was consulted?  The Congress?  Industry? %0A  %0A A %3A    We have on-going discussions with Congress and industry on %0A      encryption issues, and expect those discussions to intensify %0A      as we carry out our review of encryption policy.  We have %0A      briefed members of Congress and industry leaders on the %0A      decisions related to this initiative. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Will the government provide the hardware to manufacturers? %0A  %0A A %3A    The government designed and developed the key access %0A      encryption microcircuits, but it is not providing the %0A      microcircuits to product manufacturers.  Product %0A      manufacturers can acquire the microcircuits from the chip %0A      manufacturer that produces them. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Who provides the "Clipper Chip"? %0A  %0A A %3A    Mykotronx programs it at their facility in Torrance, %0A      California, and will sell the chip to encryption device %0A      manufacturers.  The programming function could be licensed %0A      to other vendors in the future. %0A  %0A Q %3A    How do I buy one of these encryption devices?  %0A  %0A A %3A    We expect several manufacturers to consider incorporating %0A      the "Clipper Chip" into their devices. %0A       %0A Q %3A    If the Administration were unable to find a technological %0A      solution like the one proposed, would the Administration be %0A      willing to use legal remedies to restrict access to more %0A      powerful encryption devices? %0A  %0A A %3A    This is a fundamental policy question which will be %0A      considered during the broad policy review.  The key escrow %0A      mechanism will provide Americans with an encryption product %0A      that is more secure, more convenient, and less expensive %0A      than others readily available today, but it is just one %0A      piece of what must be the comprehensive approach to %0A      encryption technology, which the Administration is %0A      developing. %0A  %0A      The Administration is not saying, "since encryption %0A      threatens the public safety and effective law enforcement, %0A      we will prohibit it outright" (as some countries have %0A      effectively done); nor is the U.S. saying that "every %0A      American, as a matter of right, is entitled to an %0A      unbreakable commercial encryption product."  There is a %0A      false "tension" created in the assessment that this issue is %0A      an "either-or" proposition.  Rather, both concerns can be, %0A      and in fact are, harmoniously balanced through a reasoned, %0A      balanced approach such as is proposed with the "Clipper %0A      Chip" and similar encryption techniques. %0A  %0A Q %3A    What does this decision indicate about how the Clinton %0A      Administration's policy toward encryption will differ from %0A      that of the Bush Administration?   %0A  %0A A %3A    It indicates that we understand the importance of encryption %0A      technology in telecommunications and computing and are %0A      committed to working with industry and public-interest %0A      groups to find innovative ways to protect Americans' %0A      privacy, help businesses to compete, and ensure that law %0A      enforcement agencies have the tools they need to fight crime %0A      and terrorism. %0A  %0A Q %3A    Will the devices be exportable?  Will other devices that use %0A      the government hardware? %0A  %0A A %3A    Voice encryption devices are subject to export control %0A      requirements.  Case-by-case review for each export is %0A      required to ensure appropriate use of these devices.  The %0A      same is true for other encryption devices.  One of the %0A      attractions of this technology is the protection it can give %0A      to U.S. companies operating at home and abroad.  With this %0A      in mind, we expect export licenses will be granted on a %0A      case-by-case basis for U.S. companies seeking to use these %0A      devices to secure their own communications abroad.  We plan %0A      to review the possibility of permitting wider exportability %0A      of these products. %0A  %0A ----------- End included article -----------  %0A  %0A --  %0A pat %40 rwing.uucp      [Without prejudice UCC 1-207]     (Pat Myrto) Seattle, WA %0A          If all else fails, try %3A        ...!uunet!pilchuck!rwing!pat %0A WISDOM %3A  "Only two things are infinite; the universe and human stupidity, %0A          and I am not sure about the former."              - Albert Einstien %0A  
doc_4577 |@raw_text From %3A  dietz %40 cs.rochester.edu (Paul Dietz) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Bursters. positional stuff. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr29.110412.13651 %40 cs.rochester.edu> %0A Organization %3A  University of Rochester %0A References %3A  <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu> <1993Apr29.010847.1 %40 vax1.mankato.msus.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 29 Apr 1993 11 %3A 04 %3A 12 GMT %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr29.010847.1 %40 vax1.mankato.msus.edu> belgarath %40 vax1.mankato.msus.edu writes %3A  %0A  %0A > getting at here.  This puppy is far enough away, that if a bright %0A > burst happens nearby, the huge annulus created by it will hopefully %0A > intersect the line or general circle given by BATSE, and we can get a %0A > moderately accurate position. Say oh, 2 or 3 degrees. That is the %0A > closest anyone has ever gotten with it. %0A  %0A  %0A You can do a whole hell of a lot better than 2 or 3 degrees with %0A the differential timing measurements from the interplanetary network. %0A Ignore the directional information from BATSE; just look at the time %0A of arrival.  With three detectors properly arranged, one can often %0A get positions down to ~arc minutes. %0A  %0A BTW, about Oort cloud sources %3A  shouldn't this be testable in the %0A fairly near future?  Some of the GRBs have very short rise times (< 1 %0A ms).  We could detect the curvature of the burst wavefront out to a %0A distance of on the order of b^2/(t c) where b is the detector spacing %0A and t the time resolution.  For t = 1 ms and b = 2 AU, this is on the %0A order of 16 light years.  I understand statistics will reduce this %0A number considerably, as would geometry if the burst is coming from the %0A wrong direction. %0A  %0A 	Paul %0A

doc_4607 |@raw_text From %3A  u009 %40 csx.cciw.ca (G. Stewart Beal) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Can Radio Freq. Be Used To Measure Distance? %0A Organization %3A  Canada Centre for Inland Waters %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 11 %3A 31 %3A 33 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.113133.3861 %40 csx.cciw.ca> %0A References %3A  <C5v13M.C37 %40 bcstec.ca.boeing.com> %0A Lines %3A  27 %0A  %0A In article <C5v13M.C37 %40 bcstec.ca.boeing.com> rgc3679 %40 bcstec.ca.boeing.com (Robert G. Carpenter) writes %3A  %0A >I'm wondering if it's possible to use radio waves to measure the %0A >distance between a transmitter(s) and receiver? %0A > %0A >Seems to me that you should be able to measure the signal strength %0A >and determine distance. This would be for short distances (2000 ft), %0A >and I would need to have accuracy of 6 inches, or so. %0A > %0A This would be susceptible to fading, multi-path etc. We used to use a %0A system at the shop made by Tellurometer in South Africa. It used a %0A 10 GHz signal between 2 units across the distance to be measured. %0A The 10 GHz was just the carrier %3A  the real signals were several switched %0A ones around 7.5 MHz or so, whose relative phases at the receiver would %0A read out the digits of the distance down to 10 cm if needed. The units %0A came with psychrometers (sp?) to measure the relative humidity and %0A instructions for correction of the measurements due to RH and temp. %0A They were rather heavy and required an operator at each end. %0A Current technology uses polarized reflectors, dual polaization TX/RX %0A and psuedo-random coding of a radar pulse. about the same resolution %0A at X band, much better at 47GHz. (Only one end is heavy  %3A -)  ). %0A   %0A Regards, Stu Beal, VE3MWM, U009 %40 CSX.CCIW.CA, %0A National Water Research Institute, Burlington, Ontario, Canada. %0A   %0A "We'd made it through yet another nuclear winter and %0A  the lawn had just trapped and eaten it's first robin." - Kyle J. Spiller %0A  %0A

The idea that citizens must register their  %0A secrets with the government just in case they are trying to keep them secret  %0A is patently unAmerican. Additionally, the press release for this program %0A strongly implied that other forms of cryptography would be banned after the  %0A Clipper Chip standard is in place. This latest attack on our civil rights is  %0A deeply disturbing and is frankly a voting issue for me.  %0A  %0A The presidents press release stated that the plan strikes a balance between the %0A legitimate needs of law enforcement and a citizens right to privacy but this  %0A is not the case. The fact is that since other strong cryptographic equipment  %0A is avalible the criminals, drug dealers and terrorists mentioned in the press  %0A release will simply use non clipper cryptography. Meanwhile the average citizen %0A may gain no protection against warentless wiretaps by the government since the  %0A government escrowed key is derived deterministicly from the unit serial number %0A which is broadcast by the chip durring its opperation. This seems like an  %0A obvious back door for the NSA and law enforcement. If you still do nott  %0A understand my objection to key registration, consider the way J. Edgar Hoover  %0A blackmailed government officials like yourself; would you now use a phone to  %0A transmit personal details of your life that the NSA and FBI have the keys to? %0A  %0A  %0A ______________________________________________________________________________ %0A Well heres a letter, I didnt spell check it since I dont know how in EMACS %0A so you might want to do that.  %0A  %0A Bill Smythe %0A
