doc_4638 |@raw_text From %3A  szabo %40 techbook.com (Nick Szabo) %0A Subject %3A  SSF Redesign %3A  Constellation %0A Summary %3A  decentralize & automate functions %0A Keywords %3A  space station, constellation %0A Message-ID %3A  <C51z6E.CL1 %40 techbook.com> %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 93 08 %3A 20 %3A 38 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  techbook.C51z6E.CL1 %0A Organization %3A  TECHbooks --- Public Access UNIX --- (503) 220-0636 %0A Lines %3A  89 %0A  %0A SSF is up for redesign again.  Let's do it right this %0A time!  Let's step back and consider the functionality we want %3A  %0A  %0A [1] microgravity/vacuum process research %0A [2] life sciences research (adaptation to space) %0A [3] spacecraft maintenence  %0A  %0A The old NASA approach, explified by Shuttle and SSF so far, was to %0A centralize functionality.  These projects failed to meet %0A their targets by a wide margin %3A  the military and commercial users  %0A took most of their payloads off Shuttle after wasting much effort to  %0A tie their payloads to it, and SSF has crumbled into disorganization %0A and miscommunication.  Over $50 billion has been spent on these %0A two projects with no reduction in launch costs and littel improvement %0A in commercial space industrialization.  Meanwhile, military and commercial  %0A users have come up with a superior strategy for space development %3A  the  %0A constellation.   %0A  %0A Firstly, different functions are broken down into different  %0A constellations placed in the optimal orbit for each function %3A  %0A thus we have the GPS/Navstar constellation in 12-hour orbits, %0A comsats in Clarke and Molniya orbits, etc.  Secondly, the task %0A is distributed amongst several spacecraft in a constellation, %0A providing for redundancy and full coverage where needed. %0A  %0A SSF's 3 main functions require quite different environments %0A and are also prime candidates for constellization. %0A  %0A [1] We have the makings of a microgravity constellation now %3A  %0A COMET and Mir for long-duration flights, Shuttle/Spacelab for %0A short-duration flights.  The best strategy for this area is %0A inexpensive, incremental improvement %3A  installation of U.S. facilities  %0A on Mir, Shuttle/Mir linkup, and transition from Shuttle/Spacelab %0A to a much less expensive SSTO/Spacehab/COMET or SSTO/SIF/COMET. %0A We might also expand the research program to take advantage of  %0A interesting space environments, eg the high-radiation Van Allen belt  %0A or gas/plasma gradients in comet tails.  The COMET system can %0A be much more easily retrofitted for these tasks, where a  %0A station is too large to affordably launch beyond LEO. %0A  %0A [2] We need to study life sciences not just in microgravity, %0A but also in lunar and Martian gravities, and in the radiation %0A environments of deep space instead of the protected shelter %0A of LEO.  This is a very long-term, low-priority project, since %0A astronauts will have little practical use in the space program %0A until costs come down orders of magnitude.  Furthermore, using %0A astronauts severely restricts the scope of the investigation, %0A and the sample size.  So I propose LabRatSat, a constellation %0A tether-bolo satellites that test out various levels of gravity %0A in super-Van-Allen-Belt orbits that are representative of the %0A radiation environment encountered on Earth-Moon, Earth-Mars, %0A Earth-asteroid, etc. trips.  The miniaturized life support %0A machinery might be operated real-time from earth thru a VR %0A interface.  AFter several orbital missions have been flown, %0A follow-ons can act as LDEFs on the lunar and Martian surface, %0A testing out the actual environment at low cost before $billions %0A are spent on astronauts. %0A  %0A [3] By far the largest market for spacecraft servicing is in  %0A Clarke orbit.  I propose a fleet of small teleoperated %0A robots and small test satellites on which ground engineers can %0A practice their skills.  Once in place, robots can pry stuck %0A solar arrays and antennas, attach solar battery power packs, %0A inject fuel, etc.  Once the fleet is working, it can be %0A spun off to commercial company(s) who can work with the comsat %0A companies to develop comsat replaceable module standards. %0A  %0A By applying the successful constellation strategy, and getting %0A rid of the failed centralized strategy of STS and old SSF, we %0A have radically improved the capability of the program while %0A greatly cutting its cost.  For a fraction of SSF's pricetag, %0A we can fix satellites where the satellites are, we can study %0A life's adaptation to a much large & more representative variety  %0A of space environments, and we can do microgravity and vacuum %0A research inexpensively and, if needed, in special-purpose %0A orbits. %0A  %0A N.B., we can apply the constellation strategy to space exploration %0A as well, greatly cutting its cost and increasing its functionality.   %0A Mars Network and Artemis are two good examples of this; more ambitiously  %0A we can set up a network of native propellant plants on Mars that can be used %0A to fuel planet-wide rover/ballistic hopper prospecting and %0A sample return.  The descendants of LabRatSat's technology can %0A be used as a Mars surface LDEF and to test out closed-ecology %0A greenhouses on Mars at low cost. %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A Nick Szabo					 szabo %40 techboook.com %0A  
doc_4646 |@raw_text From %3A  C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu (John Kelsey) %0A Subject %3A  Crypto papers on the net. %0A Message-ID %3A  <16BB91429.C445585 %40 mizzou1.missouri.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 mont.cs.missouri.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  mizzou1.missouri.edu %0A Organization %3A  University of Missouri %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 93 01 %3A 26 %3A 01 CDT %0A Lines %3A  13 %0A  %0A    I've recently been reading a paper of Merkle's (publixhed only on the %0A net, I think) discussing three potential replacements for DES.  Was %0A anyting ever done with these?  Are Khufu, Khafre, and/or Snefru still %0A being discussed anywhere?  (I know Snefru is referenced in the RSA %0A FAQ, and I think it may also be in the sci.crypt FAQ.) %0A    On a related topic, can anyone point me toward good sites to find %0A papers/articles/discussions of cryptology?  I think I've about exhausted %0A the Math/Sci library here, which doesn't seem to have anything more recent %0A than about '84. %0A   %0A    Thanks. %0A   %0A    --John Kelsey %0A  
doc_4649 |@raw_text From %3A  msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu (Mark  Underwood) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5wKKJ.42I %40 ms.uky.edu> %0A Date %3A  22 Apr 93 20 %3A 50 %3A 42 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  ms.C5wKKJ.42I %0A References %3A  <1993Apr22.163605.24784 %40 csus.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 ms.uky.edu (USENET News System) %0A Reply-To %3A  msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu %0A Organization %3A  University Of Kentucky, Dept. of Math Sciences %0A Lines %3A  155 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  nx34.mik.uky.edu %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr22.163605.24784 %40 csus.edu> kschang %40 sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu   %0A (Kuo-Sheng (Kasey) Chang) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A > There are several types of copy protection, and the point is to make   %0A sure the %0A > user is using a legitimate copy.  The simplest and virtually fool-proof   %0A way is %0A > for the program to somehow fixate itself to the machine it was installed   %0A on %0A > (some sort of checksum, serial number, whatever) so a copy put on a   %0A different %0A > machine (NOT installed from original disks) will not work.   %0A >  %0A  %0A Okay, so what do you do if some part of the machine (presumably the part   %0A on which the code number or whatever that the program has fixated itself   %0A upon goes bad, you replace that part, and now your program won't run   %0A because it's on a "different" computer??? %0A  %0A This is, of course, assuming that the program uses something in ROM (like   %0A the BIOS serial number, maybe?) and not a disk-based code number.    %0A Obviously if the drive goes bad you'll be reinstalling the stuff anyway. %0A  %0A I work in a computer lab which is part of the university microlab system.    %0A We have the wonderfully fun task of maintaining well over a hundred   %0A machines, both PC and Macintosh, as well as administering a network of   %0A over 50 NeXT machines.  I personally am concerned only with a small lab   %0A with ten PC's and ten Mac's.  (I'm not the manager, but help him with   %0A admin often).  IMHO, copy-protection schemes of ANY sort are nothing more   %0A than a major headache for the legitimate user.  Anyone who wants a copy of   %0A your program and doesn't care about legality will get a copy.  Period.    %0A "Pirate board" or no pirate board.  I too have "friends" who blatantly and   %0A quite successfuly "hack" copy protection schemes practically in their   %0A sleep. %0A  %0A Let's consider what goes on in our lab.  Almost daily we have at least one   %0A machine down, sometimes several, due to some goofball screwing up some   %0A setting or other on a piece of software.  Admittedly, we (being students,   %0A mostly) are not the world's most efficient and effective network   %0A administrators, but we try.  Keeping even the twenty machines that are   %0A (partly) my responsibility even vaguely looking and "acting" similar to   %0A the average user, and maintaining "behind-the-scenes" consistency is a   %0A real headache, but not so bad a headache as trying to remember twenty   %0A different folder locations of Norton Utilities when some guy trashes his   %0A disk. %0A  %0A Often we have hardware problems at peak "business" times and have to do   %0A some parts-swapping to get stuff working temporarily. . . . %0A  %0A Well, I'll cut to the chase and quit boring y'all . . .. %0A  %0A The point is, often we have to re-install software and copy configuration   %0A files etc. from machine to machine.  By far the easiest way we have found   %0A to do this is to get ONE machine working EXACTLY the way we want to, then   %0A COPY the complete setup of this machine to the other nine (of that   %0A machine's type).  This ensures us that (for at least ten minutes) we have   %0A ten IDENTICAL machines to work with.  Having them networked simplifies   %0A this considerably, as our major packages (WordPerfect, Windows, etc.) are   %0A all network versions and thus only one copy to mess with. %0A  %0A Often, however, we need to install a package requested by some instructor   %0A to one, some, or all of the machines for a special project.  This is   %0A usually a hand-written or shareware,etc. program similar to what I believe   %0A the original poster was asking about.  The few we have had with "copy   %0A protection" schemes have caused nothing but NIGHTMARES for us to maintain   %0A  . . %0A  %0A In short, don't waste your time with a copy protection scheme.  It's sort   %0A of like outlawing guns.  The criminals will get your program anyway, and   %0A you will only be hurting the legitimate, honest user.  Write a good user's   %0A guide and tech manual, whatever else for your program (PLEASE do this   %0A REGARDLESS of whether you copy protect the thing!!!), and only distribute   %0A the manual to LICENSED users.  Jack the price to cut your losses, but   %0A please take a cue from the major companies (who can admittedly afford the   %0A costs of illegal copies far better than you) and don't burden the   %0A legitimate user with a "copy protection" scheme! %0A  %0A  %0A Sorry for the tirade, but it's been a long day here . . ..  %3A -) %0A  %0A  %0A Mark S. Underwood %0A EE Student, University of Kentucky %0A Lab Assistant, Boyd Hall Microlab  %0A 	(a tiny little division of UK Library Microlabs) %0A E-Mail %3A   msunde01 %40 mik.uky.edu %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A > The program is definitely backupable, if restored to the same machine   %0A (depends %0A > on the programmer...  don't use a disk drive characteristic!)  If the   %0A user  %0A > did an upgrade to the machine, he/she should reinstall all programs any   %0A way. %0A > No document look-up, no disk wear-and-tear! %0A >  %0A > I did not say that the originals would allow only one install.  The   %0A user's  %0A > conscience should do that. %0A >  %0A > I know, I'll get flamed for this...  But with the increasing number of   %0A "casual" %0A > users who either unknowingly or don't care about the software copyrights %0A > (It's the truth.  I have "friends" who ask me for copies of my latest   %0A games %0A > all the time, and when I refused, they went after somebody else.),   %0A casual %0A > pirating is becoming more of a problem.  Some sort of copy protection   %0A will %0A > discourage the casual copying.  I've seen what some of my "friends" dug   %0A up %0A > somewhere...  Latest and the greatest games, all cracked, WITHIN days of   %0A actual %0A > release!  You know how many bytes you need to change in X-wing to   %0A disable %0A > the quiz?  TWO!  Yes, TWO!  (And don't ask me which ones they are.)    %0A Determined %0A > pirates are unstoppable, given enough time, but their results do not   %0A spread  %0A > that far, since pirate boards are not that well-known, and easily   %0A tracked once %0A > found by authorities.  It is the "casual" pirates that the copy   %0A protection is %0A > determined to discourage. %0A >  %0A > What I believe the companies should do is implement the above plus %0A > a special patch once the user registers that loudly exclaims upon bootup %0A > "REGISTERED TO XXXXX -- address, city, state zip" and disables the   %0A above. %0A > Two benefits %3A  1) encourages registration, 2) cuts down on pirating and %0A > makes it more traceable, because if the patch's registration message is %0A > encrypted, it will be quite hard to change, and therefore provides a %0A > stable trail of who allowed their copy out of their hands, and thus %0A > violated their license agreement. %0A >  %0A > This way, the legitimate users who does not register will experience   %0A minimal  %0A > discomfort (who does major upgrades to their computer frequently?) as   %0A only %0A > problem they have is they won't be able to restore to another computer. %0A >  %0A > The registered users would have proven they are legitmate users and   %0A therefore %0A > gains full rights, and can restore to different machines.  On the other   %0A hand, %0A > the software company now have a record of where THIS particular copy is  %0A > supposed to be.  If this user's copy was found to be somewhere it was   %0A not  %0A > supposed to be, we know who has broken their license agreement.  Of   %0A course, %0A > a hacker can break that eventually, but that's not the point, is it? %0A >  %0A > --Kasey Chang %0A  
doc_4651 |@raw_text From %3A  rab %40 well.sf.ca.us (Bob Bickford) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Off the shelf cheap DES keyseach machine %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5ursM.69 %40 well.sf.ca.us> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 well.sf.ca.us %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  well.sf.ca.us %0A Organization %3A  Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link %0A References %3A  <C5sy1z.4tD %40 demon.co.uk> <1993Apr21.132318.16981 %40 ulysses.att.com> <TOM.93Apr21114536 %40 amber.ssd.csd.harris.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 21 %3A 31 %3A 33 GMT %0A Lines %3A  32 %0A  %0A In article <TOM.93Apr21114536 %40 amber.ssd.csd.harris.com>, %0A   tom %40 ssd.csd.harris.com (Tom Horsley) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >This isn't intended to be a flame or anything, I am just really curious %0A >how to manufacture these things while still maintaining the key escrow %0A >security without simply saying "trust the manufacturer, they won't look". %0A  %0A Without getting into the *really* *thorny* questions about reverse %0A engineering and all of that, let me just point out that there already %0A exist gate arrays and suchlike that have what's known as a security fuse %0A which can be programmed after you've verified all other programming -- %0A this makes it impossible to read out the programming of the device %0A (again, ignoring the reverse engineering questions).  Speaking from %0A experience here %3A  I had to completely reinvent one of my designs some %0A six or seven years ago when the disk file was zapped, the backups were %0A all bad, and the devices were unreadable because of the security fuses. %0A Made me appreciate the value of printouts.  ;-) %0A  %0A So on this point at least there's not so much worry. %0A  %0A But whether or not we can get the chips made reliably and securely is %0A really secondary to the question of whether use of the chip is itself %0A likely to be secure, methinks. %0A -- %0A  Robert Bickford      "A Hacker is any person who derives joy from %0A  rab %40 well.sf.ca.us    discovering ways to circumvent limitations." rab'86 %0A -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- %0A "I recognize that a class of criminals and juvenile delinquents has %0A taken to calling themselves 'hackers', but I consider them irrelevant %0A to the true meaning of the word; just as the Mafia calls themselves %0A 'businessmen' but nobody pays that fact any attention."            rab'90 %0A -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- %0A

doc_4653 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Moonbase race, NASA resources, why? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5w5un.Bpq %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 15 %3A 32 %3A 46 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5sx3y.3z9.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> <C5tEIK.7z9 %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1r46o9INN14j %40 mojo.eng.umd.edu> <1993Apr21.210712.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  33 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr21.210712.1 %40 aurora.alaska.edu> nsmca %40 aurora.alaska.edu writes %3A  %0A >> So how much would it cost as a private venture, assuming you could talk the %0A >> U.S. government into leasing you a couple of pads in Florida?  %0A > %0A >Why must it be a US Government Space Launch Pad? Directly I mean... %0A  %0A In fact, you probably want to avoid US Government anything for such a %0A project.  The pricetag is invariably too high, either in money or in %0A hassles. %0A  %0A The important thing to realize here is that the big cost of getting to %0A the Moon is getting into low Earth orbit.  Everything else is practically %0A down in the noise.  The only part of getting to the Moon that poses any %0A new problems, beyond what you face in low orbit, is the last 10km -- %0A the actual landing -- and that is not immensely difficult.  Of course, %0A you *can* spend sagadollars (saga- is the metric prefix for beelyuns %0A and beelyuns) on things other than the launches, but you don't have to. %0A  %0A The major component of any realistic plan to go to the Moon cheaply (for %0A more than a brief visit, at least) is low-cost transport to Earth orbit. %0A For what it costs to launch one Shuttle or two Titan IVs, you can develop %0A a new launch system that will be considerably cheaper.  (Delta Clipper %0A might be a bit more expensive than this, perhaps, but there are less %0A ambitious ways of bringing costs down quite a bit.)  Any plan for doing %0A sustained lunar exploration using existing launch systems is wasting %0A money in a big way. %0A  %0A Given this, questions like whose launch facilities you use are *not* a %0A minor detail; they are very important to the cost of the launches, which %0A dominates the cost of the project. %0A --  %0A All work is one man's work.             %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A                     - Kipling           %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_4660 |@raw_text From %3A  whit %40 carson.u.washington.edu (John Whitmore) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Help with ultra-long timing %0A Message-ID %3A  <1pr91aINNikg %40 shelley.u.washington.edu> %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 93 06 %3A 47 %3A 06 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  shelley.1pr91aINNikg %0A References %3A  <1993Apr5.083324.48826 %40 kuhub.cc.ukans.edu> <C513wI.G5A %40 athena.cs.uga.edu> <1pqu12$pmu %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  University of Washington, Seattle %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  carson.u.washington.edu %0A  %0A In article <1pqu12$pmu %40 sunb.ocs.mq.edu.au> johnh %40 macadam.mpce.mq.edu.au (John Haddy) writes %3A  %0A >In article <C513wI.G5A %40 athena.cs.uga.edu>, mcovingt %40 aisun3.ai.uga.edu (Michael Covington) writes %3A  %0A >%7C> (1) Don't use big capacitors.  They are unreliable for timing due to %0A >%7C> leakage.  %0A  %0A 	True (especially for electrolytic capacitors at high temperature). %0A  %0A >%7C> Instead, use a quartz crystal and divide its frequency by 2 40 times %0A >%7C> or something like that. %0A  %0A >... Wouldn't a crystal be affected by cold? My gut feeling is that, as a %0A >mechanically resonating device, extreme cold is likely to affect the %0A >compliance (?terminology?) of the quartz, and hence its resonant frequency. %0A  %0A 	Low power quartz oscillators are usually 32 kHz (and THESE %0A have significant temperature drifts, which one doesn't often notice %0A while wearing the watch on one's wrist).  Low temperature sensitivity %0A is available in other crystal types, which unfortunately %0A are larger and higher frequency (1 MHz or so) and take more %0A battery power.   %0A  %0A 	Programmable timers might be less accurate, but they %0A are more power-stingy than suitable crystal oscillators. %0A  %0A 	John Whitmore %0A

He fans on 25% of goal mouth feeds, but he still has  %0A 36 goals after a terrible start and has been an examplary (sp?) team captain %0A throughout a tough couple of seasons. Honorable mention %3A  Nick Kypreos and %0A Mark Janssens. Probably more appropriate in the unsung heroes category than %0A MVP, but Kypreos (17 goals, 320+ PIM) has been the hardest working player on %0A the team and Janssens is underrated as a defensive center and checker. I guess %0A I place a greater emphasis on hard work than skill when determining value. %0A  %0A Biggest surprise %3A  Geoff Sanderson. He had 13 goals and 31 points last season %0A as a center, then moved to left wing and has so far put up 45 goals and 80+ %0A points. He now has a new Whaler record 21 power play goals, most all coming %0A from the right wing faceoff circle, his garden spot. Honorable mention %3A  Andrew %0A Cassels and Terry Yake. The kiddie quartet of Sanderson, Poulin, Nylander, and %0A Petrovicky have been attracting the most attention, but Cassels is just 23 %0A and will score close to 90 points this season. He has quite nicely assumed the %0A role of number one center on the team and works very well with Sanderson. Yake %0A bounced around the minors for a number of seasons but is still 24 and will put %0A up about 20 goals and 50 points this season. Yake, like Sanderson, started %0A performing better offensively once he was converted from center to wing,  %0A although lefty Sanderson went to the left wing and righty Yake went to the %0A right side. %0A  %0A Biggest disappointment %3A  Hands down, John Cullen. Cullen had a disasterous 77 %0A point season last year, his first full season after The Trade. Cullen started %0A the season off of summer back surgery, and fell flat on his face (appropriate, %0A since he spent all of his Whaler career flat on his ass, and whining about it). %0A Cullen scored just 9 point on 19 games, was a clubhouse malcontent, commanded %0A the powerplay to a 9% success percentage (>21% with Sanderson), and sulked his %0A way out of town. Worst of all, his 4 year, $4M contract had three years left %0A to run, so no one would give up any more than the 2nd round draft pick the  %0A Maple Leafs offered to Hartford. Honorable mention %3A  Steve Konroyd, also subpar %0A after signing a 3 year, $2.1M contract; Eric Weinrich, who showed flashes of %0A competence, but overall has played poorly; Jim McKenzie, who was a much better %0A hockey player two seasons ago than he is now; and Frank Pietrangelo, who only %0A seemed to play well when Sean Burke was out for an extended period and he got %0A to make a number of starts in a row. %0A  %0A -SG (a real live Hartford Whalers season ticket holder) %0A -steveg %40 cadkey.com %0A

doc_4712 |@raw_text From %3A  mgr %40 anhep3.hep.anl.gov (Dr. mike) %0A Subject %3A  Official Secrets act (USA) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C63wB6.Czr %40 mcs.anl.gov> %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.3-4    %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 mcs.anl.gov %0A Reply-To %3A  mgr %40 anhep3.hep.anl.gov %0A Organization %3A  Argonne National Laboratory %0A Distribution %3A   world %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 20 %3A 25 %3A 23 GMT %0A Lines %3A  39 %0A  %0A Sorry, my news reader doesn't seem to know how to copy a subject header. %0A This tracks the thread "why people don't need strong crypto....." %0A  %0A The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 expressly forbids *thinking* about building %0A nuclear devices.  While I was in grad school, a friend of mine got a  %0A security clearance to work on the defense for the Progressive magazine. %0A He found lots of articles which were public domain *removed* from the %0A local engineering library (Madison Wisconsin).  So the lawyers sent him %0A all over the states to other libraries to show that the information in %0A the article was already public.  What pissed everyone off was a local %0A underground paper went and published the article anyway (it had been %0A precensored by the feds, that's what this was all about) so the judge %0A declared the case moot. %0A  %0A The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 has never been tested in court.  From my %0A discussions with several people familiar with the case, only 2 other %0A times has this preemptive clause been used.  In every case the people %0A simply did what they felt like and courts tossed the cases out. %0A  %0A For all intents and purposes, the government *does* have precidence for %0A declaring things classified *after* it has been published.  While I was %0A working on Star Wars this happened to me %3A  my clearance was in the works %0A and I developed a method for tracking particle beams.  It was good enough %0A to classify, so I was no longer allowed to work on it.  A friend from %0A Canada was in the same boat %3A  he developed a method to compute stripping %0A cross sections, but because the subject was classified *he was not allowed %0A to present his own paper at a conference!*.  He later published it in an %0A open journal without problems. %0A  %0A When the going gets wierd, the wierd turn pro.  The feds can do whatever %0A they want whenever they feel like it, and they will make up rules to let %0A themselves get away with it.  Since the mass media can't tell the difference %0A between a joke and the real thing (like "ranch appocolypse" for the Waco %0A massacre) don't count on them to help spread the word about their loss %0A of freedom.  The government *can* make strong crypto illegal.  SO WHAT? %0A Since the government does not obey any of its own rules, why should we? %0A  %0A Patience, persistence, truth,		reality %3A  dvader %40 hemp-imi.hep.anl.gov %0A Dr. mike				home %3A     mrosing %40 igc.org %0A

doc_4717 |@raw_text From %3A  roeber %40 vxcrna.cern.ch (Frederick Roeber) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Internet resources %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr30.120202.1 %40 vxcrna.cern.ch> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 dxcern.cern.ch (USENET News System) %0A Reply-To %3A  roeber %40 cern.ch %0A Organization %3A  CERN -- European Organization for Nuclear Research %0A References %3A  <C69C9K.9FA.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  sci %0A Date %3A  Fri, 30 Apr 1993 11 %3A 02 %3A 02 GMT %0A Lines %3A  39 %0A  %0A In article <C69C9K.9FA.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu>, STK1203 %40 VAX003.STOCKTON.EDU writes %3A  %0A > I am taking a course entitled "Exploring Science Using Internet". %0A > For our final project, we are to find a compendium of Internet resources  %0A > dealing with a science-related topic. I chose Astronomy. Anyway, I was  %0A > wondering if anyone out there knew of any interesting resources on Internet %0A > that provide information on Astronomy, space, NASA, or anything like that. %0A  %0A Do you know of the world-wide-web?  This is a global hypertext (well,  %0A hypermedia) network running on the internet.  One of the nice things %0A about it is that is understands and incorporates virtually all of the %0A other systems being used, like WAIS, Gopher, FTP, Archie, etc.  It %0A is usually quite easy to add existing resources to the web. %0A  %0A If you'd like to explore, I'd suggest getting the XMosaic program, %0A written at the NCSA.  It's an X-windows web browser, and is pretty %0A slick.  It can understand and cope with more than text %3A  gif, jpeg, mpeg, %0A audio, etc.  There are other browsers, including a text-mode browser %0A for people stuck on a text terminal, but I'm most familliar with mosaic. %0A  %0A Under the page "The World-Wide Web Virtual Library %3A  Subject Catalogue" %0A (this is available under the Documents menu in mosaic, or by any %0A browser via the URL  %0A http %3A //info.cern.ch/hypertext/DataSources/bySubject/Overview.html ) %0A there is a subject "Space Science."  Currently this points to a %0A page under construction, with only the NASA JPL FTP archive.  I've %0A volunteered to take over this page, and in fact I have a replacement %0A with all sorts of information pointers (mostly gleaned from the %0A sci.space FAQ).  As soon as the overworked "Subject Catalogue"  %0A maintainer switches the "Space Science" pointer, it'll be visible. %0A  %0A I'll post a short note when this happens. %0A  %0A --  %0A Frederick G. M. Roeber %7C CERN -- European Center for Nuclear Research %0A e-mail %3A  roeber %40 cern.ch or roeber %40 caltech.edu %7C work %3A  +41 22 767 31 80 %0A r-mail %3A  CERN/PPE, 1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland %7C home %3A  +33 50 20 82 99 %0A --   %0A "Sorry, baby, I can't take you to the pizza joint tonight, I've got to go %0A back to the lab and split the atom." -- Ayn Rand, "What is Romanticism?" %0A

doc_4725 |@raw_text From %3A  ktl %40 wag.caltech.edu (Kian-Tat Lim) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Dorothy Denning opposes Clipper, Capstone wiretap chips %0A Date %3A  27 Apr 1993 20 %3A 07 %3A 29 GMT %0A Organization %3A  California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA %0A Lines %3A  19 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1rk3q1INN7hb %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A References %3A  <1993Apr26.063532.10120 %40 eff.org> <C65H4n.784.2 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  sgi1.wag.caltech.edu %0A  %0A The *security* of the system does depend only on the secrecy of the keys. %0A  %0A The ability to tap is an inherent *insecurity* which depends fundamentally on %0A the secrecy of the algorithm.  To spell it out, because so many people seem to %0A miss the point, if the algorithm were published, anyone could create a chip %0A which would work correctly with the Skipjack chips but which would not have %0A its key registered. %0A  %0A I believe there is no technical means of ensuring key escrow without the %0A government maintaining a secret of some kind.  For example, the secret could be %0A the private keys of the escrow agencies; their digital signatures would be %0A required before a key could be used.  In this case, the NSA/NIST/whoever has %0A decided that protecting the entire algorithm is easier/cheaper/more secure than %0A other possible protocols. %0A  %0A --  %0A Kian-Tat Lim (ktl %40 wag.caltech.edu, GEnie %3A  K.LIM1) %0A Materials & Molecular Simulation Center, Caltech %0A Henry Spencer left-of-%7C, Margaret "*" Puckette signature fan %0A

doc_4730 |@raw_text From %3A  essbaum %40 rchland.vnet.ibm.com (Alexander Essbaum) %0A Subject %3A  exhaust coating %0A Sender %3A  news %40 rchland.ibm.com %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.181033.24999 %40 rchland.ibm.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 18 %3A 10 %3A 33 GMT %0A Disclaimer %3A  This posting represents the poster's views, not necessarily those of IBM %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  relva.rchland.ibm.com %0A Organization %3A  IBM Rochester %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A since at least one other person was interested in this %3A  %0A  %0A my FZR's black exhaust pipes are rusty and i researched getting them repaired. %0A yesterday i bought a can of VHT 1500 degree black header paint and spent an %0A hour sanding two of the header pipes by hand.  sprayed on paint.  thought %0A about how clean i was able to get the metal with sanding and determined that %0A i wouldn't be at all suprised if the paint wore/chipped off in a month. %0A  %0A soooo call a couple of places up in minneapolis and discover that powder %0A coating, while extremely durable, will not handle over ~600 degree %0A temperatures.  the place i talked to said they were experimenting with %0A some new powder that is supposed to handle 1100 degrees but that it wouldn't %0A be available for months at least.  they directed me to another shop that %0A specializes in header coating. %0A  %0A the other shop said they have 2 coatings available.  one is aluminized that %0A can do 1200+ degrees and is "comparable" to powder coating for durability. %0A the other is silicon (i think) based and can do 1800+ degrees (!) but is %0A thinner and not as durable.  both coatings have a textured finish (not %0A super smooth) and should be cleaned with hot water and a brush. %0A  %0A price for 4 1-foot header pipes and a 2-foot 4-2-1 collector was ~$100.  i'm %0A planning to take the parts up friday and get them back (UPS) next week maybe %0A wednesday. %0A  %0A sounds to me like this kind of coating stuff should be way better than paint %0A considering how much abuse the pipes get from road crap/rocks. %0A  %0A axel %0A

doc_4734 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  74ACT??? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5nr1w.9yD %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 02 %3A 32 %3A 18 GMT %0A References %3A  <1qhrq9INNlri %40 crcnis1.unl.edu> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  86 %0A  %0A In article <1qhrq9INNlri %40 crcnis1.unl.edu> mpaul %40 unl.edu (marxhausen paul) writes %3A  %0A >OK, what's a quick rundown on all the 7400 series variations?  We're %0A >repairing something with a 74ACT00 on it and the question arises, "well, %0A >do  i really need the ACT part?"  Flipping through Digi-Key I see  %0A >ALS, AS, C, HC, AC, ACQ, ACT, HCT, ACHT, HCTLS... %0A  %0A Here's something I posted about this a few years ago.  It's not fully %0A up to date with all the new variations (some of which are just different %0A manufacturer's synonyms) %3A  %0A  %0A ------ %0A In practical terms, ignoring the technological details, this is my view %0A of the families (NB I am not a giant corporation, which influences my %0A views on things like availability and backward compatibility) %3A  %0A  %0A 74	The original.  Speed good, power consumption fair.  Effectively %0A 	obsolete now; use 74LS or later, except for a *very* few oddball %0A 	functions like 7407 which are hard to find in newer families. %0A  %0A 74H	Modification of 74 for higher speed, at the cost of higher %0A 	power consumption.  Very obsolete; use 74F. %0A  %0A 74L	Modification of 74 for lower power, at the cost of lower speed. %0A 	Very obsolete; use CMOS. %0A  %0A 74S	Later modification of 74 for even higher speed, at some cost in %0A 	power consumption.  Effectively obsolete; use 74F. %0A  %0A 74LS	Combination of 74L and 74S, for speed comparable to 74 with lower %0A 	power consumption.  Best all-round TTL now, widest variety of %0A 	devices. %0A  %0A 74F	Fast as blazes, power not too bad.  The clear choice for high %0A 	speed in TTL.  Availability and prices generally good. %0A  %0A 74AS	Failed competitor to 74F, although a few 74AS parts do things %0A 	that are hard to find in 74F and thus are still useful. %0A  %0A 74ALS	Possible replacement for 74LS.  Generally souped up.  Still fairly %0A 	new, availability and prices possibly a problem. %0A  %0A 74C	Fairly old family, CMOS devices with TTL pinouts.  Competed with %0A 	4000 series, not too successfully.  Obsolete; use 4000 or newer %0A 	CMOS 74 families. %0A  %0A 4000	(Thrown in as the major non-74 non-ECL logic family.)  The old CMOS %0A 	family, still viable because of *very* wide range of devices, low %0A 	power consumption, and wide range of supply voltages.  Not fast. %0A 	Very forgiving and easy to work with (beware static electricity, %0A 	but that comment applies to many other modern logic families too). %0A 	There are neat devices in this family that exist in no other.  The %0A 	clear choice when speed is not important. %0A  %0A 74HC	A new attempt at 74-pinout CMOS.  Fast compared to old CMOS, power %0A 	consumption often lower than TTL.  Possibly a good choice for %0A 	general-purpose logic, assuming availability and affordability. %0A 	CMOS logic levels, *not* TTL ones.  Beware very limited range of %0A 	supply voltages compared to older CMOS, also major rise of power %0A 	consumption at faster speeds. %0A  %0A 74HCT	74HC with TTL logic levels.  Much the same comments as 74HC.  Read %0A 	the fine print on things like power consumption -- TTL compatibility %0A 	in CMOS involves some compromises. %0A  %0A 10K	(Thrown in for speed freaks.)  The low end of ECL.  Various sources %0A 	claim that it is *easier* to work with than super-fast TTL for %0A 	serious high-speed work.  Less forgiving, though %3A   read and follow %0A 	the rules or it won't work.  Availability to hobbyists limited, %0A 	can be expensive. %0A  %0A 100K	(For real speed freaks.)  Hot ECL.  Harder to handle than 10K, and %0A 	inconvenient packages.  Much more useful datasheets, however. %0A  %0A As for compatibility between families %3A   the 74 families (except 74C and %0A 74HC) are all more or less logic-level compatible, but how many 74X devices %0A you can drive from one 74Y output varies enormously with X and Y.  You just %0A have to read the specs and do the arithmetic.  74C and 74HC are compatible %0A with the others with a bit of hassle.  4000 compatibility can be a bit of %0A hassle or a lot of hassle depending on what supply voltage 4000 is using. %0A 10K or 100K to anything else is considerable hassle. %0A  %0A Me?  I use 4000 and 74LS with a sprinkling of 74F.  74HC[T] and 10K are %0A interesting but I haven't used either significantly yet. %0A --  %0A All work is one man's work.             %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A                     - Kipling           %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_4747 |@raw_text From %3A  bear %40 kestrel.fsl.noaa.gov (Bear Giles) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Why the clipper algorithm is secret %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.014135.24134 %40 fsl.noaa.gov> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 fsl.noaa.gov (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Forecast Systems Labs, NOAA, Boulder, CO USA %0A References %3A  <1993Apr17.175656.23656 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1993Apr18.225502.358 %40 iecc.cambridge.ma.us> <C5pstr.Lu2 %40 panix.com> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 01 %3A 41 %3A 35 GMT %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A  %0A In article <C5pstr.Lu2 %40 panix.com> dfl %40 panix.com (Danny O'Bedlam) writes %3A  %0A >	The algorithm is classified because a military contract (or similar %0A >government equivalent to military) has been let for this "proprietary" %0A >design that the Feds say that NSA developed.  Is there a patent?  Is that %0A >patent publicly available?  My betting is that that too is classified. %0A  %0A Unless there has been a _major_ change in the law, there's no such beast %0A as a "classified patent."  Patents exist to encourage communications and %0A develop the state of the art.  %0A  %0A (The 17-year lock is a nuisance, but historically has been pretty trivial. %0A It's only in an industry which doubles performance every three years (or %0A 18 months, for some hardware) that 17 years is an eternity). %0A  %0A The same thing applies in civilian development %3A  you can't patent something  %0A _and_ declare it a "trade secret."  However, you can (and should) mark all %0A software (including proprietary code) "unpublished copyright" so that it %0A ever does get exposed you still have some legal protection. %0A  %0A (Post-Berne this isn't required, since everything is "born copyrighted." %0A But it takes a while for people to learn the new rules). %0A  %0A --  %0A Bear Giles %0A bear %40 fsl.noaa.gov %0A

doc_4765 |@raw_text From %3A  jvannes %40 vms.macc.wisc.edu %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Long distance IR detection %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr24.054304.4843 %40 macc.wisc.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 macc.wisc.edu (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A   University of Wisconsin Academic Computing Center %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  24 APR 93 00 %3A 19 %3A 26     %0A Lines %3A  34 %0A  %0A In article <CSTROCKB.93Apr23002520 %40 csws8.cs.sunysb.edu>, cstrockb %40 cs.sunysb.edu (Caleb Strockbine) writes... %0A  %0A >Could make for some interesting choreography... light and sound could be  %0A >controlled directly by the position of a dancer on stage, or by the number %0A >of dancers on stage. Neat. %0A >  %0A >You could even build a spotlight that follows the dancer around on stage! %0A >  %0A >Can you tell us more about what you're doing? Sounds like a very cool program. %0A  %0A Tis' only a gleam in my eye at this point.  I have yet to chose a tracking  %0A method.  The initial requirement was to design a system to locate a dancer %0A in one of eight zones across the stage.  I did some experiments with  %0A pyroelectric detectors and found them difficult to align to get a definite %0A zone transition.  And dancers stand still alot, so their IR signature goes %0A away.  The good thing about pryoelectrics is that their signal is proportional  %0A to the size of the warm body (or body part), and the velocity of said body. %0A This could be useful for detecting the intensity of a dance gesture. %0A  %0A Dancers also really hate to wear little boxes and batteries strapped on their  %0A bodies, but they really need to be emitting some kind of signal to be tracked. %0A  %0A The current toy I have been working with is a program called Mandala for the %0A Amiga, used with a LIVE! video digitizer.  This works with a video camera  %0A trained on the stage.  You can set thresholds for a zone within the field of %0A view, and an object brighter than the threshold will trigger an event. Events %0A can be MIDI objects or sequences, Amiga sounds or graphic objects.  It's been %0A fun to play with, but the documentaion is arcane, and the digitizer is noisy. %0A Still, it's very appealing, the dancers don't have to wear any appliances, %0A you can have ots of zone,s, it speaks MIDI, which can be used to control lights, %0A and I don't have to build any electronics.  It's all done with lighting and %0A video brightness and contrast adjustments.  I have yet to do anything %0A particularly useful or artistic, but I have hopes... %0A  %0A

I'm pretty %0A >sure the NSA is supposed to, among many other things, provide high-quality %0A >cryptosystems to a variety of places. I don't recall reading anywhere %0A >reliable that they're supposed to %3A  %0A > %0A >	1) Monitor my phonecalls. %0A >	2) Monitor usenet. %0A >	3) Provide only cryptosystems they can easily crack. %0A >	4) etc etc. %0A > %0A >	This is not to say that they *don't*, they might. But you don't %0A >know that they do, and you have no evidence that they do, for almost %0A >all values of you. It follows, therefore, that for most values of 'you', %0A >your claims about the NSA border on paranoia. %0A > %0A >	Andrew %0A > %0A  %0A OK, Andrew, I'll provide some evidence. A friend of mine worked for an %0A electronics manufacturer on with a west-coast office. They routinely sold %0A equipment to the Japanese. One day, the Japanese started showing up with %0A discount demands that were amazingly close to the cost to manufacture the %0A products. %0A  %0A This company routinely sent most of the manufacturing data to the field  %0A offices. The Japanese had simply intercepted it. So my friend, the computer %0A systems admin, came up with a solution. He started sending the data out %0A double-block-encrypted with DES.  %0A  %0A Two days after this new distribution plan was implemented, the president of %0A the company got a visit from a pair of government agents. They told him to %0A "knock it off". The president gave in, since his company did a considerable %0A business with the federal government. %0A  %0A Now, if the government wasn't monitoring the communications, how would they %0A even know that the encryption system was installed? Further, since encryp- %0A tion isn't illegal, and DES certainly isn't, what is the basis of the %0A government's cease-and-desist demand? %0A  %0A The spooks do whatever they think is necessary, with or without the blessings %0A of the law. I'll say "no thanks" to Clipper, or anything else the government %0A produces. For the moment, double or triple DES is probably adequate. And when %0A the line is idle, send random garbage, just to keep 'em busy.  %0A  %0A     David Hayes    merlin %40 lerami.lerctr.org %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  
doc_4814 |@raw_text From %3A  mg %40 cs.princeton.edu (Michael Golan) %0A Subject %3A  clipper serial numbers need 2nd court order? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr23.051005.28404 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Originator %3A  news %40 nimaster %0A Sender %3A  news %40 Princeton.EDU (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  atomic.princeton.edu %0A Organization %3A  Princeton University %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 05 %3A 10 %3A 05 GMT %0A Lines %3A  28 %0A  %0A something that no one has discussed yet (or I missed it) %3A  %0A  %0A The FBI sets up a wiretap AFTER the court order was handed.  %0A Only at this point they can access the line and detect  %0A the serial number N. %0A  %0A What happens next, does the FBI simply asks for the keys %0A for N, and, since a warrant was issued for the line, the FBI  %0A simply gets it? What if multiple phones are used from the %0A same house, the FBI just asks for N1, N2, etc.? %0A  %0A Exactly who is to prevent the FBI from claiming some %0A other serial number, X, was also used over the wirtapped  %0A line and get the keys for X?  %0A  %0A Either a second court order (for the specific serial/key) %0A is required (and I have seen no indication of this), or %0A the FBI can effectively ask for any pair of keys at any %0A time, so the escrow key holders are a total fake. %0A  %0A An unrelated issue %3A  if and when all phones always use %0A the clipper chip, how are call-transfers going to take  %0A place?! %0A  %0A  %0A  Michael Golan %0A  mg %40 cs.princeton.edu %0A  %0A  
doc_4816 |@raw_text From %3A  mjs %40 sys.uea.ac.uk (Mike Sixsmith) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering_FAQ please post %0A Message-ID %3A  <mjs.735312515 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 sys.uea.ac.uk %0A Organization %3A  University of East Anglia %0A References %3A  <mjs.735207403 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk> <1qucmm$i7d %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 20 Apr 1993 13 %3A 28 %3A 35 GMT %0A Lines %3A  78 %0A  %0A egreen %40 east.sun.com (Ed Green - Pixel Cruncher) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >In article 735207403 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk, mjs %40 sys.uea.ac.uk (Mike Sixsmith) writes %3A  %0A >>egreen %40 east.sun.com (Ed Green - Pixel Cruncher) writes %3A  %0A >> %0A  %0A >1.  All of us that argue about gyroscopes, etc., throughly understand %0A >the technique of countersteering. %0A  %0A Including all the ones who think that they countersteer all the way %0A through a corner?? %0A  %0A >The underlying physics are a %0A >different matter, and need not be taught to beginners.  %0A  %0A Agreed! %0A  %0A >Countersteering %0A >(the technique), should be taught, for only with understanding of the %0A >technique can one develop maximally effective emergency avoidance %0A >manuvers. %0A  %0A This is really the only thing we disagree on. Maybe we should agree to %0A disagree?? I still think  that telling newbies to steer left to turn %0A to the right is unnecessarily confusing, when they'll do it anyway if they %0A just get on the bike and ride the damn thing. %0A  %0A  %0A >2. *I* know exactly what's happening.  It's those *other* gits that %0A >haven't a clue!   %3A ^) %0A  %0A  %0A Me too!! %0A  %0A  %3A -) %0A  %0A  %0A >>Understanding the physics of traction is fine - but I cannot see how %0A >>detailed theory like that has any place in a motorcyle training course. %0A >>All you need to know is that maximum traction is obtained with the tyre %0A >>*just* beginning to slide against the road. %0A  %0A >Then we are in violent disagreement.  While what you state is true, it %0A >is insufficient to form a traction management policy.  Available %0A >traction increases with applied normal force, ie, traction available to %0A >the front wheel increases as weight shifts under braking forces, and %0A >correspondingly decreases at the rear.  Thus, a *technique* of applying %0A >both brakes, and easing off the rear and increasing pressure on the %0A >front, can best be learned with an understanding of weight shift and %0A >available traction. %0A  %0A Jeez, Ed, when you started talking about traction management policies I %0A thought you were making some weird reference to looking after railway %0A locomotives... %0A  %0A The official line here (though I do have my doubts about it) is that the %0A front brake is applied first, followed by the rear brake, the idea being %0A that you avoid locking up the rear after weight transfer takes place. In %0A practice I suspect most people do what you describe. %0A  %0A >Saying, "brake until the tire just begins to slide" is next to useless %0A >advice to a newbie.  He has to go out and slide the tire to find out %0A >where that is!  It also gives him zero information from which to %0A >develop a braking technique that changes as the braking and %0A >corresponding weight shift develop. %0A  %0A If you don't slide the tyre, you have no way of knowing whether you've %0A achieved maximum braking or not. I'm not suggesting that you should always %0A aim to brake as hard as you possibly can - but if you want to find the %0A limits of the machine, you have to go beyond them.  %0A  %0A In any case, for maximum braking, if (as I suggested) you aim to keep %0A both wheels just on the point of sliding, then you'll be doing %0A exactly as *you* suggest!! %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_4847 |@raw_text From %3A  baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Magellan Update - 04/16/93 %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 1993 16 %3A 11 UT %0A Organization %3A  Jet Propulsion Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <20APR199316113601 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A References %3A  <19APR199320262420 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> <1993Apr20.072706.19981 %40 cs.ruu.nl> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A Keywords %3A  Magellan, JPL %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.072706.19981 %40 cs.ruu.nl>, jhwitten %40 cs.ruu.nl (Jurriaan Wittenberg) writes... %0A >In <19APR199320262420 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov  %0A >(Ron Baalke) writes %3A  %0A >  %0A >>4.  On Monday morning, April 19, the moon will occult Venus and %0A >>interrupt the tracking of Magellan for about 68 minutes. %0A  %0A >Will this mean a loss of data or will the Magellan transmit data later on ?? %0A  %0A The gravity data is collected in real-time and it not recorded to the tape %0A recorder.  However, you only need to collect the gravity every 3rd or 4th %0A orbit, so there is no real data loss if the Moon blocks transmission for %0A a short while. %0A  %0A >BTW %3A  When will NASA cut off the connection with Magellan?? Not that I am %0A >looking forward to that day but I am just curious. I believe it had something %0A >to do with the funding from the goverment (or rather _NO_ funding  %3A -) %0A  %0A The aerobraking starts May 25 and is expected last about 70 days.  If the %0A funding is provided (8 million dollars) to extend the mission for the %0A high resolution gravity data, then the mission will last through October 1994. %0A Otherwise, the mission will end this coming July.    %0A      ___    _____     ___ %0A     /_ /%7C  /____/ \  /_ /%7C     Ron Baalke         %7C baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C  __ \ /%7C %7C %7C %7C     Jet Propulsion Lab %7C %0A  ___%7C %7C %7C %7C %7C__) %7C/  %7C %7C %7C__   M/S 525-3684 Telos %7C The aweto from New Zealand %0A /___%7C %7C %7C %7C  ___/    %7C %7C/__ /%7C Pasadena, CA 91109 %7C is part caterpillar and %0A %7C_____%7C/  %7C_%7C/       %7C_____%7C/                     %7C part vegetable. %0A  %0A

doc_4850 |@raw_text From %3A  strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) %0A Subject %3A  Back doors in Clipper? %0A Message-ID %3A  <strnlghtC604DE.Jyp %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  DSI/USCRPAC %0A Date %3A  Sat, 24 Apr 1993 18 %3A 51 %3A 14 GMT %0A Lines %3A  20 %0A  %0A  %0A I think it very unlikely there are back doors in clipper, for two reasons %3A  %0A  %0A 1. The government doesn't need them if it can get the key (and yes, I assume %0A that the "official" government obeys court orders, etc.--and that the design %0A of the chip and its approval were "official"); %0A  %0A 2. It would defeat the whole purpose of providing secure crypto for American %0A business that couldn't be read by our economic adversaries. If this were not %0A a legitimate and genuine purpose, and as many think, the NSA can read DES, %0A why bother otherwise? %0A  %0A Rational responses preferred to conspiracy theories, thanks. %0A  %0A David %0A --  %0A David Sternlight         Great care has been taken to ensure the accuracy of %0A                          our information, errors and omissions excepted.   %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_4878 |@raw_text From %3A  rboudrie %40 chpc.org (Rob Boudrie) %0A Subject %3A  Why the algorithm is secret %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr17.025713.3768 %40 chpc.org> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 02 %3A 57 %3A 13 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> <1qmugcINNpu9 %40 gap.caltech.edu> <115713 %40 bu.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  Center For High Perf. Computing of WPI; Marlboro Ma %0A Lines %3A  15 %0A  %0A  %0A My thoughts on why the algorithm is secret  %3A  %0A  %0A    The chip is (regretably) likely to become a standard.   There will %0A    be many applications where economic factors dictate use of this %0A    chip, like it or not. %0A  %0A    If the alrogithm is public, and the code is as secure (absent the  %0A    access to escrowed keys) as represented, an enterprising sort  %0A    would make "compatible crypto chips for which no key had been %0A    escrowed".  This is likely what the release was refering to when  %0A    they refered to the secrecy of the algorithm protecting the %0A    security of the escrow system. %0A  %0A                                         rob boudrie %0A

doc_4883 |@raw_text From %3A  johnl %40 iecc.cambridge.ma.us (John R. Levine) %0A Subject %3A  Why the clipper algorithm is secret %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr18.225502.358 %40 iecc.cambridge.ma.us> %0A Organization %3A  I.E.C.C. %0A References %3A  <1993Apr17.175656.23656 %40 ulysses.att.com> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 22 %3A 55 %3A 02 GMT %0A Lines %3A  21 %0A  %0A >The cryptographic protocol, though, is another matter.  I see no valid %0A >reasons for keeping it secret, and -- as I hope I've shown above -- there %0A >are a lot of ways to do things that aren't (quite) as bad. %0A  %0A It just occurred to me why the algorithm is secret.  If it were %0A published, one could then build physically identical clone versions %0A of the chip that would interoperate with official Clipper chips.  But %0A the cloner wouldn't provide the keys to the escrow houses.  Hmmn. %0A  %0A Or is there a technical hack that I've missed?  E.g. how about if the %0A chips were made unprogrammed but serialized, and then shipped to the %0A two escrow houses who programmed in their halves of the keys, but %0A in a way that requires that secret keys known only to the escrow houses %0A be installed as well, without which clone versions wouldn't %0A interoperate?  This is getting awfully complicated, but that's %0A crypto for you. %0A  %0A --  %0A John R. Levine, IECC, POB 349, Cambridge MA 02238, +1 617 492 3869 %0A johnl %40 iecc.cambridge.ma.us, {ima%7Cspdcc%7Cworld}!iecc!johnl %0A "Time is Money!  Steal some today!" %0A  
doc_4884 |@raw_text From %3A  johne %40 vcd.hp.com (John Eaton) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  What do Nuclear Site's Cooling Towers do? %0A Sender %3A  news %40 vcd.hp.com (News user) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5L5x0.KJ7 %40 vcd.hp.com> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 17 %3A 00 %3A 35 GMT %0A References %3A  <1qlg9o$d7q %40 sequoia.ccsd.uts.EDU.AU> %0A Organization %3A  Hewlett-Packard VCD %0A X-Newsreader %3A  Tin 1.1 PL5 %0A Lines %3A  30 %0A  %0A -s87271077-s.walker-man-50- (swalker %40 uts.EDU.AU) wrote %3A  %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A   %0A  %3A  I really don't know where to post this question so I figured that %0A  %3A  this board would be most appropriate. %0A  %3A  I was wondering about those massive concrete cylinders that %0A  %3A  are ever present at nuclear poer sites. They look like cylinders %0A  %3A  that have been pinched in the middle. Does anybody know what the %0A  %3A  actual purpose of those things are?. I hear that they're called %0A  %3A  'Cooling Towers' but what the heck do they cool? %0A  %3A  I hope someone can help  %0A  %3A ----------------------- %0A During the nuclear fission reaction the uranium fuel can get hot enough %0A to melt. When this happens the liquid uranium is pumped to the cooling %0A tower where it is sprayed into the air. Contact with the cool outside air %0A will condense the mist and it will fall back to the cooling tower floor. %0A There it is collected by a cleaning crew using shop vacs and is then %0A reformed into pellets for reactor use the next day. %0A  %0A Cooling towers are a lot taller than they really need to be. Power companies %0A are forced to make them that tall by some enviromental law that requires the %0A raw uranium emisions to be held to under 1%. This law is now under attack %0A by lawyers arguing that the 1% should be measured at the edge of the property %0A rather than the edge of the cooling tower. Eliminating this law will save %0A power companies thousands of dollars in concrete costs for new nukes. %0A  %0A John Eaton %0A !hp-vcd!johne %0A  %0A  %0A

A pound is defined to %0A >> be a unit of force, period.  There is a perfectly good unit called %0A >> the slug, which is the mass of an object weighing 32.2 lbs at sea level. %0A >> (g = 32.2 ft/sec^2, of course.) %0A >>  %0A  %0A >American Military English units, perhaps.  Us real English types were once  %0A >taught that a pound is mass and a poundal is force (being that force that %0A >causes 1 pound to accelerate at 1 ft.s-2).  We had a rare olde tyme doing  %0A >our exams in those units and metric as well. %0A  %0A American, perhaps, but nothing military about it.  I learned (mostly) %0A slugs when we talked English units in high school physics and while %0A the teacher was an ex-Navy fighter jock the book certainly wasn't %0A produced by the military. %0A  %0A [Poundals were just too flinking small and made the math come out %0A funny; sort of the same reason proponents of SI give for using that.]  %0A  %0A --  %0A "Insisting on perfect safety is for people who don't have the balls to live %0A  in the real world."   -- Mary Shafer, NASA Ames Dryden %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ %0A Fred.McCall %40 dseg.ti.com - I don't speak for others and they don't speak for me. %0A

doc_4916 |@raw_text From %3A  nagle %40 netcom.com (John Nagle) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Why circuit boards are green? %0A Message-ID %3A  <nagleC65I6r.4G %40 netcom.com> %0A Organization %3A  NETCOM On-line Communication Services (408 241-9760 guest) %0A References %3A  <1993Apr23.105152.20155 %40 news.cs.tut.fi> <ulan.735839488 %40 ee.ualberta.ca> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 27 Apr 1993 16 %3A 37 %3A 38 GMT %0A Lines %3A  17 %0A  %0A ulan %40 ee.ualberta.ca (Dale Ulan) writes %3A  %0A >kuusama %40 kaarne.cs.tut.fi (Kuusama Juha,,,VTT,) writes %3A  %0A >>Not that the question is anything important, but I am still curious %3A  %0A >>Why is that almost all printed circuit boards are green? I have seen %0A >>a few blue ones, but no red, yellow, company logo etc. Is there a %0A >>technical reason or could it be that the marketing "geniuses" have %0A >>not tought about it (yet)? %0A  %0A        It's possible to make boards in other colors, and I have an ad %0A for laser light-show equipment which offers the circuit boards in your %0A choice of Day-Glo (tm) colors. %0A  %0A        The usual light green color is just the natural color of Fiberglas. %0A The dark green or blue is the solder mask layer, and I suspect that color %0A is a dye.   %0A  %0A 						John Nagle %0A

doc_4920 |@raw_text From %3A  jca2 %40 cec1.wustl.edu (Joseph Charles Achkar) %0A Subject %3A  Blues steal game 1 from Hawks %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr18.221105.28782 %40 wuecl.wustl.edu> %0A Keywords %3A  Blues, Hull, Shanahan, Joseph, Blackhawks, Belfour %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 wuecl.wustl.edu (News Administrator) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  cec1 %0A Organization %3A  Washington University, St. Louis MO %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 22 %3A 11 %3A 05 GMT %0A Lines %3A  125 %0A  %0A  %0A   The Blues scored two power-play goals in 17 seconds in the third period %0A and the beat the Chicago Blackhawks 4-3 Sunday afternoon at Chicago Stadium. %0A Brendan Shanahan tied the game 3-3 and Brett Hull scored the game winner 17 %0A seconds later. Jeff Brown and Denny Felsner scored the other Blues goals. %0A Brian Noonan had the hat trick for the Hawks, who also had some very good %0A goaltending from Ed Belfour. Blues goalie Curtis Joseph was solid down the %0A stretch to preserve the Blues lead. %0A  %0A The Hawks came out strong in the first period, outshooting the Blues 6-1 and %0A taking a 1-0 lead on Noonan's first goal. Right after an interference penalty %0A on Rick Zombo had expired, Keith Brown intercepted a clearing attempt at the %0A blue line and passed the puck to Steve Larmer in the right circle. Larmer fired %0A a long slap shot, and Noonan deflected the puck between Joseph's pads. After %0A the goal, the Blues picked up the intensity and went on to outshoot the Hawks %0A 10-9 in the first period. %0A  %0A Jeff Brown tied the game 1-1 at 3 %3A 12 of the second. Nelson Emerson broke in on %0A the left side, got by Craig Muni and pushed the puck across the slot. Belfour %0A came out to play the pass and shoveled it to the right boards, where Brown %0A collected it and slapped it in before Belfour could get back to the goal. %0A  %0A Two minutes later on a Hawks power play, Belfour stopped Rich Sutter on a %0A short-handed break-in. Chris Chelios picked up the puck and passed it to Jeremy %0A Roenick who carried it on right wing and found an open Noonan with a nice pass %0A across the slot. Noonan fired it past Joseph at 5 %3A 30 for the 2-1 lead. %0A  %0A Noonan completed his hat trick 3 %3A 11 later to increase the Hawks' lead to 3-1. %0A Stephane Matteau made a nice pass from the right boards to Noonan who beat %0A Stephane Quintal by driving to the net. Joseph had no chance as Noonan %0A deflected the puck in the net. %0A  %0A Denny Felsner reduced the Blues deficit to 3-1 at 12 %3A 49 after picking up the %0A rebound of Basil McRae's slap shot from the slot. Janney set up McRae for %0A the shot, and the puck sailed wide of the net and bounced off the end boards %0A to Felsner. Felsner sticked the rebound into the partially open net. The Blues %0A outshot the Hawks 10-5 in the second period. %0A  %0A With the Blackhawks leading 3-2 at 9 %3A 56 of the third, Stephane Matteau picked %0A up a high sticking penalty. Just 53 seconds into the power play, Steve Smith %0A was called for slashing, giving the Blues a 5-on-3 advantage for 1 %3A 07. %0A  %0A The Blues didn't waste time as Brendan Shanahan scored just 23 seconds into %0A the two-man advantage to tie the game 3-3. Janney found Hull in the slot, %0A and Hull fired a rocket at Belfour. Jeff Brown collected the rebound and %0A passed it to Shanahan in the left circle. Shanahan beat Belfour from a sharp %0A angle. %0A  %0A Just 17 seconds later, Hull scored the game winner for the Blues. Nelson %0A Emerson broke in on right wing, carried the puck behind the net along with %0A two Hawks defensemen. Emerson made a nice pass to an unchecked Hull in the %0A slot, and Hull beat Belfour to put the Blues up 4-3. %0A  %0A The Hawks had several chances to tie the game in the final minutes, but Joseph %0A made some brilliant saves to prevent the Hawks from scoring. He stopped Troy %0A Murray point blank from just right of the crease with 2 %3A 30 left in the game. %0A The Blues killed off a late Hawks power play, with Rich Sutter clearing the %0A puck with his hand as it was trickling along the goal line. The Blues held %0A on to win the game. The Hawks oushot the Blues 13-7 in the third period, %0A totaling 27 shots on goal for each team. The Blues special teams were excellent %0A in the game. The Blues killed 6 of 7 Hawks power plays, and scored twice on %0A on four power play chances. The Blues ranked among the best special teams in %0A the league. They rank 2nd in penalty killing and 3rd on the power play. %0A   %0A The game was carried live on ABC, the first time an NHL game other than an %0A All-Star game has been shown on network television since May 24, 1980, when %0A CBS carried Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals. %0A  %0A The best-of-seven series continues Wednesday in Chicago and Friday and Sunday %0A in St. Louis. %0A  %0A Box score %0A --------- %0A Blues 4, Blackhawks 3 %0A  %0A BLUES       0    2    2   --   4 %0A CHICAGO     1    2    0   --   3 %0A  %0A FIRST PERIOD %0A  %0A    CHI -- Noonan 1 (Larmer, K.Brown), 8 %3A 17. %0A  %0A    Penalties -- Shanahan, StL (holding), 2 %3A 28; Zombo, StL (interference), 6 %3A 00; %0A Murphy, Chi (high-sticking), 11 %3A 30; Grimson, Chi (boarding), 14 %3A 39; Zombo, StL %0A (holding), 18 %3A 46. %0A  %0A SECOND PERIOD %0A  %0A    STL -- Brown 1 (Shanahan, Emerson), 3 %3A 12. %0A    CHI -- (PPG) Noonan 2 (Roenick, Chelios), 5 %3A 40. %0A    CHI -- Noonan 3 (Matteau, Sutter), 8 %3A 51. %0A    STL -- Felsner 1 (McRae, Janney), 12 %3A 49. %0A  %0A    Penalties -- Baron, StL (interference), 4 %3A 33; Wilson, StL (tripping), 9 %3A 31. %0A  %0A THIRD PERIOD %0A  %0A    STL -- (PPG) Shanahan 1 (J.Brown, Hull), 11 %3A 12. %0A    STL -- (PPG) Hull 1 (Emerson, J.Brown), 11 %3A 29. %0A  %0A    Penalties -- Shanahan, StL (roughing), 1 %3A 54; Matteau, Chi (high-sticking), %0A 9 %3A 56; Smith, Chi (slashing), 10 %3A 49; Baron, StL (roughing), 14 %3A 23. %0A  %0A SHOTS ON GOAL %0A  %0A BLUES       10    10     7   --   27 %0A CHICAGO      9     5    13   --   27 %0A  %0A Power-play Opportunities -- St. Louis 2 of 4; Chicago 1 of 7. %0A  %0A Goaltenders -- St. Louis, Joseph, 1-0-0 (27 shots-24 saves). %0A                Chicago, Belfour, 0-1-0 (27-23). %0A  %0A Referee -- Kerry Fraser. doc_4925 |@raw_text From %3A  kludge %40 grissom.larc.nasa.gov (Scott Dorsey) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  History question %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 1993 13 %3A 30 %3A 30 GMT %0A Organization %3A  NASA Langley Research Center and Reptile Farm %0A Lines %3A  16 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qu9hmINN7dp %40 rave.larc.nasa.gov> %0A References %3A  <kazel.15.734728882 %40 uiuc.edu> <2775 %40 snap> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  grissom.larc.nasa.gov %0A  %0A In article <2775 %40 snap> paj %40 uk.co.gec-mrc (Paul Johnson) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I recall reading of a phonograph which used mechanical amplification. %0A >Compressed air was squirted out of a valve which was controlled by the %0A >pickup.  The result was noisy and distinctly lo-fi, but much louder %0A >than a conventional phonograph.  It tended to wear the disks out %0A >pretty quickly though. %0A  %0A This was the Pathe you are thinking of, although there were other imitators. %0A It didn't wear the disks any more than conventional acoustic designs, but %0A it did have a high noise level due to the continual hiss of escaping air. %0A There are a lot of them still operating, and they are pretty ingenious. %0A  %0A There was a pneumatic amplifier designed by Alexander Graham Bell, as well, %0A but I don't know if it was ever constructed. %0A --scott %0A

I am quite sure that I am not alone welcoming such %0A %7C> an initiative! *I* will volunteer to ask some of the questions, if you will %0A %7C> provide the answers  %3A -) %0A %7C>  %0A %7C> Ketil Albertsen %0A  %0A Hey, now will you stop encouraging him? Copy protection only serves one pur- %0A pose %3A  to keep the honest buyer from making (legal) backup copies. It will %0A definitely not stop any pirates. If you want to protect you soft, supply a %0A good documentation and support. This is IMHO the *only* way of effectively pro- %0A tecting software. %0A  %0A Best Regards, %0A  %0A Arno %0A  %0A --  %0A -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A Arno Schaefer				ENSIMAG, 2e Annee %0A Email %3A  schaefer %40 silene.imag.fr %0A Tel. %3A  (33) 76 51 79 95			 %3A -) %0A ------- No, you're not paranoid - the world is really out to get you ----------- %0A  
doc_4982 |@raw_text From %3A  hl00 %40 ns1.cc.lehigh.edu (HOU-SHENG LIN) %0A Subject %3A  Laser vs Bubblejet? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.173742.99726 %40 ns1.cc.lehigh.edu> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 17 %3A 37 %3A 42 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Lehigh University %0A Lines %3A  12 %0A  %0A Well, I'm not too sure if this would be the right place to post this, but %0A anyway, here goes %3A   I was just noticing that some of the current bubblejet %0A printers offers up to 360x360 resolution while a lot of lower end laser %0A printers only offer 300x300.  However, the laser printers still seems to be %0A significantly pricier than the bubblejets... how is this?  Or am I missing %0A something about the resolution thing? %0A  %0A --  %0A -Sheng %0A hl00 %40 pl122.eecs.lehigh.edu %0A hl00 %40 m180k.cc.lehigh.edu %0A hl00 %40 lehigh.edu %0A  
doc_4984 |@raw_text From %3A  kwp %40 wag.caltech.edu (Kevin W. Plaxco) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Gamma Ray Bursters. Where are they? %0A Date %3A  28 Apr 1993 18 %3A 07 %3A 10 GMT %0A Organization %3A  California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1rmh4eINN95h %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A References %3A  <93116.093828SAUNDRSG %40 QUCDN.QueensU.CA> <1993Apr26.141114.19777 %40 midway.uchicago.edu> <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  sgi1.wag.caltech.edu %0A  %0A In article <27APR199320210230 %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov> abdkw %40 stdvax.gsfc.nasa.gov (David Ward) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >Given that fact, and the spacecraft attitude knowledge %0A >of approx. 2 arcmin, we might be able to figure out how well BATSE can %0A >determine the location (rotational) of a Gamma Ray burster from knowledge %0A >of the all-sky map's accuracy.  PR material for the other three instruments %0A >give accuracies on the order of "fractions of a degree", if that's  %0A >any help. %0A  %0A But I believe that there is a fundamental difference here.  The other x %0A three instruments are focusing instruments, that, more or less, form %0A an image, so positional errors are limited by craft attitude and the  %0A resolving power of the optics.  BATSE is an altogether different %0A beast, effectively just 8 coincidence counters, one on each corner of  %0A the craft.  Positional information is triangulated from the  %0A differential signal arrival times at each of the detectors. %0A Positional error would be predominantly determined by timing errors %0A and errors in craft attitude. Since none of the 8 BASTE detectors have %0A any independant angular resolution whatsoever, they can not be used to %0A determine parallax.  Indeed, parallax would just add a very small  %0A component to the positional error.   %0A  %0A Demonstrating that these puppies are beyond the oort cloud would  %0A require resolution on the order of arcseconds, since the oort  %0A cloud is postulated to extend to about 0.5 parsec (all together  %0A now %3A  "Parallax ARc SECond", a parsec is the distance of an object  %0A that demonstrates one arc second of parallax with a 2 AU base line). %0A If the 3 degree accuracy reported above is true, we're going to  %0A have to add a BASTE to the pluto fast flyby to get enough baseline. %0A  %0A The beauty of BASTE is that it both gives positional information and %0A watches the entire sky simultaneously, a realy handy combination %0A when you have no idea where the next burst is coming from. %0A  %0A -Kevin %0A

doc_5005 |@raw_text From %3A  mike %40 netnews.louisville.edu (Mike Harpe) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to drive an array of LEDs? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.130643.27289 %40 netnews.louisville.edu> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 13 %3A 06 %3A 43 GMT %0A References %3A  <1raa9vINNd1l %40 shelley.u.washington.edu> %0A Organization %3A  University of Louisville %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A  %0A ptorre %40 hardy.u.washington.edu (Phil Torre) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >I have a project in mind that requires an array of LEDs that can be addressed %0A >individually by a microprocessor (say, 16x16 or so).  Is there an LSI that %0A >is designed to drive an LED array (including RAM to hold the array state), %0A >or failing that, some way of multiplexing the display so I don't have to %0A >latch a bit for each LED using a discrete latch?  (I want to avoid having %0A >a huge board covered with 373s if possible!)  Thanks in advance... %0A  %0A Maxim makes a chip that does exactly what you want. The MAX7219 drives 8 %0A 7 segment LED displays with full decode or drives 64 discrete LED's with %0A a 3 wire serial interface.  The chips can also be cascaded to allow very %0A large arrays.  I am working on a sign display using this part. %0A  %0A I'll have to post the contact info for Maxim later, it's at home.  There was %0A a series of articles on this chip in the last couple of Circuit Cellar Ink's. %0A  %0A Mike Harpe %0A --  %0A Michael Harpe, Programmer/Analyst      Information Technology, Ormsby Bldg. %0A mike %40 hermes.louisville.edu             University of Louisville %0A (502)588-5542                          Louisville, Ky. 40292 %0A "He's not a man, he's a remorseless eating machine!" - The Simpsons %0A

doc_5057 |@raw_text From %3A  egreen %40 east.sun.com (Ed Green - Pixel Cruncher) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering_FAQ please post %0A Date %3A  16 Apr 1993 14 %3A 13 %3A 04 GMT %0A Organization %3A  Sun Microsystems, RTP, NC %0A Lines %3A  26 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qmetg$g2n %40 sixgun.East.Sun.COM> %0A References %3A  <C5JtE0.L2A %40 well.sf.ca.us> %0A Reply-To %3A  egreen %40 east.sun.com %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  laser.east.sun.com %0A  %0A In article L2A %40 well.sf.ca.us, pstone %40 well.sf.ca.us (Philip K. Stone) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >Hey Ed, how do you explain the fact that you pull on a horse's reins %0A >left to go left?   %3A -)  Or am I confusing two threads here? %0A  %0A Three, actually.  I believe I discussed countersteering a horse %0A before. %0A  %0A Basically, there are two ways to steer a horse, plow-rein and %0A neck-rein.  Plow-reining steers him by keeping the reins separate, and %0A you pull in the direction you wish to go.  Neck-reining steers a horse %0A by holding the reins together in one hand, and pulling against the %0A horse's neck in the direction you wish to go.  When training a %0A plow-steering horse to neck-rein, one technique is to cross the reins %0A under his necks.  Thus, when neck-reining to the left, the right rein %0A pulls against the right side of the neck, but the left side of the bit %0A (which the horse is used to from his plow-reining days). %0A  %0A Are you sorry you asked yet? %0A  %0A --- %0A Ed Green, former Ninjaite %7CI was drinking last night with a biker, %0A   Ed.Green %40 East.Sun.COM   %7Cand I showed him a picture of you.  I said, %0A DoD #0111  (919)460-8302  %7C"Go on, get to know her, you'll like her!" %0A  (The Grateful Dead) -->  %7CIt seemed like the least I could do... %0A  %0A

doc_5071 |@raw_text From %3A  ulan %40 ee.ualberta.ca (Dale Ulan) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  what to do with old 256k SIMMs? %0A Message-ID %3A  <ulan.735093864 %40 ee.ualberta.ca> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 kakwa.ucs.ualberta.ca %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  eigen.ee.ualberta.ca %0A Organization %3A  University Of Alberta, Edmonton Canada %0A References %3A  <120466 %40 netnews.upenn.edu> <1993Apr15.100452.16793 %40 csx.cciw.ca> <1qpgsiINN31p %40 diplodocus.cis.ohio-state.edu> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 00 %3A 44 %3A 24 GMT %0A Lines %3A  28 %0A  %0A rubin %40 cis.ohio-state.edu (Daniel J Rubin) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >How hard would it be to somehow interface them to some of the popular  %0A >Motorola microcontrollers.  I am a novice at microcontrollers, but I am %0A >starting to get into them for some of my projects.  I have several 256k %0A >SIMMs laying around from upgraded Macs and if I could use them as "free" %0A >memory in one or two of my projects that would be great.  One project that %0A >comes to mind is a Caller ID device that would require quite a bit of RAM %0A >to store several hundered CID records etc... %0A  %0A Assuming 68HC11... %0A In expanded muxed mode, you *could* do it. Much easier if you get a DRAM %0A controller IC. The MMI 673102 could be used to implement this, or you %0A could use a counter and a huge multiplexer to provide row/column/refresh %0A address multiplexing. The thing with DRAMs is that they require wierd %0A timing, address multiplexing, and refresh. %0A  %0A Actually, if you wanted to use a 68008 IC, you could look at AN897, which %0A has a neat controller built in. There is also the 683xx, I think one %0A of those has the DRAM controller built in. This one is for the 6664 %0A DRAM, however, the 41256 has only one more address line, adding only %0A another component or so. The 256k SIMMs are basically 8 or 9 41256 %0A DRAM chips (or their equivalent in fewer packages). %0A  %0A It *can* be done, just takes a bit of logic design. I'm actually %0A about to do it using a 65C02P3 chip... I've got 8 256k simms... that's %0A 2 megabytes on my Apple //e... (used to be in my '386). %0A  %0A
