doc_5096 |@raw_text From %3A  crypt-comments %40 math.ncsu.edu %0A Subject %3A  Cryptography FAQ 01/10 - Overview %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 1993 00 %3A 00 %3A 17 -0400 %0A Organization %3A  The Crypt Cabal %0A Lines %3A  138 %0A Sender %3A  faqserv %40 GZA.COM %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Expires %3A  22 May 1993 04 %3A 00 %3A 07 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <cryptography-faq/part01_735019207 %40 GZA.COM> %0A Reply-To %3A  crypt-comments %40 math.ncsu.edu %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  pad-thai.aktis.com %0A Summary %3A  Part 1 of 10 of the sci.crypt FAQ, Overview. A table of  %0A  contents for subsequent sections.  Contributors, feedback, archives, %0A  administrivia. %0A X-Last-Updated %3A  1993/04/16 %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  cryptography-faq/part01 %0A Last-modified %3A  1993/4/15 %0A  %0A  %0A FAQ for sci.crypt, part 1 %3A  Overview %0A  %0A This is the first of ten parts of the sci.crypt FAQ. The parts are %0A mostly independent, but you should read this part before the rest. We %0A don't have the time to send out missing parts by mail, so don't ask. %0A Notes such as ``[KAH67]'' refer to the reference list in the last part. %0A  %0A Disclaimer %3A  This document is the product of the Crypt Cabal, a secret %0A society which serves the National Secu---uh, no. Seriously, we're the %0A good guys, and we've done what we can to ensure the completeness and %0A accuracy of this document, but in a field of military and commercial %0A importance like cryptography you have to expect that some people and %0A organizations consider their interests more important than open %0A scientific discussion. Trust only what you can verify firsthand. %0A And don't sue us. %0A  %0A Many people have contributed to this FAQ. In alphabetical order %3A  %0A Eric Bach, Steve Bellovin, Dan Bernstein, Nelson Bolyard, Carl Ellison, %0A Jim Gillogly, Mike Gleason, Doug Gwyn, Luke O'Connor, Tony Patti, %0A William Setzer. We apologize for any omissions. %0A  %0A If you have suggestions, comments, or criticism, please let the current %0A editors know by sending e-mail to crypt-comments %40 math.ncsu.edu.  We don't %0A assume that this FAQ is at all complete at this point. %0A  %0A Archives %3A  sci.crypt has been archived since October 1991 on %0A cl-next2.cl.msu.edu, though these archives are available only to U.S. and %0A Canadian users. Please contact crypt-comments %40 math.ncsu.edu if you know of %0A other archives. %0A  %0A The sections of this FAQ are available via anonymous FTP to rtfm.mit.edu  %0A as /pub/usenet/news.answers/cryptography-faq/part[xx].  The Cryptography  %0A FAQ is posted to the newsgroups sci.crypt, sci.answers, and news.answers  %0A every 21 days. %0A  %0A  %0A Table of contents %3A  %0A  %0A 1 Overview %0A  %0A 2 Net Etiquette %0A * What groups are around? What's a FAQ? Who am I? Why am I here? %0A * Do political discussions belong in sci.crypt? %0A * How do I present a new encryption scheme in sci.crypt? %0A  %0A 3 Basic Cryptology %0A * What is cryptology? Cryptography? Plaintext? Ciphertext? Encryption? Key? %0A * What references can I start with to learn cryptology? %0A * How does one go about cryptanalysis? %0A * What is a brute-force search and what is its cryptographic relevance? %0A * What are some properties satisfied by every strong cryptosystem? %0A * If a cryptosystem is theoretically unbreakable, then is it %0A   guaranteed analysis-proof in practice? %0A * Why are many people still using cryptosystems that are %0A   relatively easy to break? %0A  %0A 4 Mathematical Cryptology %0A * In mathematical terms, what is a private-key cryptosystem? %0A * What is an attack? %0A * What's the advantage of formulating all this mathematically? %0A * Why is the one-time pad secure? %0A * What's a ciphertext-only attack? %0A * What's a known-plaintext attack? %0A * What's a chosen-plaintext attack? %0A * In mathematical terms, what can you say about brute-force attacks? %0A * What's a key-guessing attack? What's entropy? %0A  %0A 5 Product ciphers %0A * What is a product cipher? %0A * What makes a product cipher secure? %0A * What are some group-theoretic properties of product ciphers? %0A * What can be proven about the security of a product cipher? %0A * How are block ciphers used to encrypt data longer than the block size? %0A * Can symmetric block ciphers be used for message authentication? %0A * What exactly is DES? %0A * What is triple DES? %0A * What is differential cryptanalysis? %0A * How was NSA involved in the design of DES? %0A * Is DES available in software? %0A * Is DES available in hardware? %0A * Can DES be used to protect classified information? %0A * What are "ECB", "CBC", "CFB", and "OFB" encryption? %0A  %0A 6 Public-Key Cryptography %0A * What is public-key cryptography? %0A * What's RSA? %0A * Is RSA secure? %0A * How fast can people factor numbers? %0A * What about other public-key cryptosystems? %0A  %0A 7 Digital Signatures and Hash Functions %0A * What is a one-way hash function? %0A * What is the difference between public, private, secret, shared, etc.? %0A * What are MD4 and MD5? %0A * What is Snefru? %0A  %0A 8 Technical Miscellany %0A * How do I recover from lost passwords in WordPerfect? %0A * How do I break a Vigenere (repeated-key) cipher? %0A * How do I send encrypted mail under UNIX? [PGP, RIPEM, PEM, ...] %0A * Is the UNIX crypt command secure? %0A * How do I use compression with encryption? %0A * Is there an unbreakable cipher? %0A * What does ``random'' mean in cryptography? %0A * What is the unicity point (a.k.a. unicity distance)? %0A * What is key management and why is it important? %0A * Can I use pseudo-random or chaotic numbers as a key stream? %0A * What is the correct frequency list for English letters? %0A * What is the Enigma? %0A * How do I shuffle cards? %0A * Can I foil S/W pirates by encrypting my CD-ROM? %0A * Can you do automatic cryptanalysis of simple ciphers? %0A * What is the coding system used by VCR+? %0A  %0A 9 Other Miscellany %0A * What is the National Security Agency (NSA)? %0A * What are the US export regulations? %0A * What is TEMPEST? %0A * What are the Beale Ciphers, and are they a hoax? %0A * What is the American Cryptogram Association, and how do I get in touch? %0A * Is RSA patented? %0A * What about the Voynich manuscript? %0A  %0A 10 References %0A * Books on history and classical methods %0A * Books on modern methods %0A * Survey articles %0A * Reference articles %0A * Journals, conference proceedings %0A * Other %0A * How may one obtain copies of FIPS and ANSI standards cited herein? %0A * Electronic sources %0A * RFCs (available from [FTPRF]) %0A * Related newsgroups %0A

So the %0A > > 1970 figure seems unlikely to actually be anything but a perijove. %0A > > Is that the case for the 1973 figure as well? %0A > > --  %0A > Sorry, _perijoves_...I'm not used to talking this language. %0A  %0A Hmmmm....  The prefix "peri-" is Greek, not Latin, so it's usually used %0A with the Greek form of the name of the body being orbited.  (That's why %0A it's "perihelion" rather than "perisol", "perigee" rather than "periterr", %0A and "pericynthion" rather than "perilune".)  So for Jupiter I'd expect it %0A to be something like "perizeon".)    %3A ^) %0A  %0A    ___            _                                           -  Bob %0A    /__) _   /    / ) _   _ %0A (_/__) (_)_(_)  (___(_)_(/_______________________________________ bob %40 1776.COM %0A Robert K. doc_5122 |@raw_text From %3A  ptrei %40 bistromath.mitre.org (Peter Trei) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Screw the people, crypto is for hard-core hackers & spooks only %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.151020.6275 %40 linus.mitre.org> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 linus.mitre.org (News Service) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  bistromath.mitre.org %0A Organization %3A  The MITRE Corporation %0A References %3A  <C5rrtD.1Gz %40 agora.rain.com> <WARLORD.93Apr20175546 %40 deathtongue.mit.edu> <strnlghtC5t4o3.K5p %40 netcom.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 15 %3A 10 %3A 20 GMT %0A Lines %3A  41 %0A  %0A In article <strnlghtC5t4o3.K5p %40 netcom.com> strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A >Actually the govrnment is telling you that if you want to use their %0A >"product" the manufacturer (actually better yet, some "trusted" pair %0A >of escrow agencies) has to have the key. %0A > %0A >Most of us already are in this situation--our car makers have keys to our %0A >cars (or can get them quickly from the VIN  number), and I have no doubt %0A >that if presented with a court order, they'd surrender copies to the %0A >government. %0A  %0A >Chances are that many locksmiths have the code numbers for house locks %0A >they've installed, and in an emergency can cut keys; thus they'd also %0A >provide such keys to the government pursuant to a court order. %0A  %0A     Of course, nothing prevents you from buying a new lock with cash %0A and installing it yourself. Even modifying the core to match some %0A arbitrary key is not difficult to do at home. I once knew someone who %0A had fixed his locks in this way - his house, office and cars all took %0A the same key (which he took GOOD care of  %3A -) %0A  %0A >The state has no difficulty gaining access to your safe deposit box if they %0A >have a court order. %0A  %0A >Bad analogy. %0A  %0A     Very bad (yours, that is). Have you ever had a safety deposit box? %0A They work on a two-key system. The bank clerk has one, and you have %0A the other (they are different keys). The bank does NOT keep a copy of %0A your key. If you lose it, they have to drill out the lock, and replace %0A the door. This is a time consuming and expensive process (which they %0A will be happy to charge to your account  %3A -). %0A  %0A      This process is exactly analogous to having a private key which %0A is NOT in a escrow system, and the state having to crack your cipher %0A to get the data. %0A  %0A      Please do not use false analogies. %0A  %0A 							Peter Trei %0A 							ptrei %40 mitre.org %0A  %0A

Any lower and the motor would die from lack of electron movement. %0A  %0A On my LC (RZ to any ex-colonists) I replaced the bolt at the bottom of the barrel %0A with a tap. When I wanted a coffee I could just rev the engine until boiling %0A and pour out a cup of hot water. %0A I used ethylene glycol as antifreeze rather than methanol as it tastes sweeter. %0A  %0A (- %3A  %0A  %0A          ################################# %0A    _     #     Roger.Collier %40 Uk.Sun.COM  # %0A o_/_\_o  #                               # %0A  (O_O)   #     Sun Microsystems,         # %0A   \H/    #     Coventry, England.        # %0A    U     #     (44) 203 692255           # %0A          #     DoD#226        GSXR1100L  # %0A          ################################# %0A            Keeper of the GSXR1100 list. %0A  %0A  %0A  
doc_5130 |@raw_text From %3A  hathaway %40 stsci.edu %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Vandalizing the sky. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr23.175120.1 %40 stsci.edu> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 22 %3A 51 %3A 20 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5t05K.DB6 %40 research.canon.oz.au> <1993Apr23.140649.1 %40 rhea.arc.ab.ca> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 stsci.edu %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  Space Telescope Science Institute %0A Lines %3A  101 %0A  %0A >Newsgroups %3A  sci.astro,sci.space %0A >Subject %3A  Re %3A  Vandalizing the sky. %0A > %0A  (excerpts from posting on this topic)  %0A  %0A >In article <C5t05K.DB6 %40 research.canon.oz.au> enzo %40 research.canon.oz.au  %0A >(Enzo Liguori) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >>Now, Space Marketing %0A >>is working with University of Colorado and Livermore engineers on %0A >>a plan to place a mile-long inflatable billboard in low-earth %0A >>orbit.   %0A >...  %0A >>... the real purpose of the project is to help the environment!  %0A >>The platform will carry ozone monitors  %0A > %0A >...  %0A >I can't believe that a mile-long billboard would have any significant %0A >effect on the overall sky brightness.  Venus is visible during the day, %0A >but nobody complains about that.  Besides, it's in LEO, so it would only %0A >be visible during twilight when the sky is already bright, and even if %0A >it would have some miniscule impact, it would be only for a short time %0A >as it goes zipping across the sky. %0A > %0A  %0A (I've seen satellites at midnight - they're not only in twilight.)  %3A o)  %0A  %0A >... %0A > %0A >From the book "Prodigal Genius %3A  The Life of Nikola Tesla" by John J. O'Neill %3A  %0A > %0A >"This remarkable conductivity of gases, including the air, at low %0A >pressures, led Tesla to suggest, in a published statement in 1914, a %0A >system of lighting on a terrestrial scale in which he proposed to treat %0A >the whole Earth, with its surrounding atmosphere, as if it were a %0A >single lamp....   %0A >The whole Earth would be transformed into a giant lamp, with the night  %0A >sky completely illuminated.  ... making the night as bright as day." %0A >  %0A  %0A Now my comments %3A   %0A  %0A I'd like to add that some of the "protests" do not come from a strictly  %0A practical consideration of what pollution levels are acceptable for  %0A research activities by professional astronomers.  Some of what I  %0A would complain about is rooted in aesthetics.  Many readers may  %0A never have known a time where the heavens were pristine - sacred -  %0A unsullied by the actions of humans.  The space between the stars  %0A as profoundly black as an abyss can be.  With full horizons and  %0A a pure sky one could look out upon half of all creation at a time  %0A - none of which had any connection with the petty matters of man.  %0A Any lights were supplied solely by nature; uncorruptable by men.   %0A Whole religions were based on mortal man somehow getting up there  %0A and becoming immortal as the stars, whether by apotheosis or a belief  %0A in an afterlife.   %0A  %0A The Space Age changed all that.  The effect of the first Sputniks  %0A and Echo, etc. on this view could only happen once.  To see a light  %0A crossing the night sky and know it was put there by us puny people  %0A is still impressive and the sense of size one gets by assimilating  %0A the scales involved is also awesome - even if the few hundreds or  %0A thousands of miles involved is still dwarfed by the rest of the universe.   %0A But there is still a hunger for the pure beauty of a virgin sky.  %0A  %0A Yes, I know aircraft are almost always in sight.  I have to live  %0A in a very populated area (6 miles from an international airport  %0A currently) where light pollution on the ground is ghastly.  The  %0A impact of humans is so extreme here - virtually no place exists  %0A that has not been shaped, sculpted, modified, trashed or whipped  %0A into shape by the hands of man.  In some places the only life  %0A forms larger than bacteria are humans, cockroaches, and squirrels  %0A (or rats).  I visited some friends up in the Appalacian mountains  %0A one weekend, "getting away from it all" (paved roads, indoor plumbing,  %0A malls, ...) and it felt good for a while - then I quickly noticed  %0A the hollow was directly under the main flight path into Dulles - 60-80  %0A miles to the east.  (Their 'security light' didn't help matters  %0A much either.)  But I've heard the artic wilderness gets lots of  %0A high air traffic.  So I know the skies are rarely perfect.  %0A  %0A But there is still this desire to see a place that man hasn't  %0A fouled in some way.  (I mean they've been TRYING this forever -  %0A like, concerning Tesla's idea to banish night, - wow!)  I don't watch  %0A commercial television, but I can imagine just how disgusting beer,  %0A truck, or hemmorrhoid ointment advertisements would be if seen up so high.   %0A If ya' gotta make a buck on it (displaying products in heaven), at  %0A least consider the reactions from those for whom the sky is a last %0A beautiful refuge from the baseness of modern life.   %0A  %0A To be open about this though, I have here my listing of the passage  %0A of HST in the evening sky for this weekend - tonight Friday at  %0A 8 %3A 25 p.m. EDT it will reach an altitude of 20.1 degrees on the  %0A local meridian from Baltimore vicinity.  I'll be trying to see it  %0A if I can - it _is_ my mealticket after all.  So I suppose I could  %0A be called an elitist for supporting this intrusion on the night sky  %0A while complaining about billboards proposed by others.  Be that  %0A as it may, I think my point about a desire for beauty is valid,  %0A even if it can't ever be perfectly achieved.  %0A  %0A Regards,  %0A Wm. Hathaway  %0A Baltimore MD  %0A

Do you think this could never happen %0A again? %0A  %0A Note that I am not speculating about what the government could do, %0A but discussing the sort of "observation" - including but not limited %0A to phone tapping - that the government put its citizens under during %0A a time of national tension. %0A  %0A Your naivete is still appalling, BTW. Do %0A we assume a priori that a citizen is law-abiding, or rather a potential %0A CommunistDrugLordChildAbuserCultMessiah? One of the things that's %0A supposedly great about America is the freedoms enjoyed by citizens who %0A are presumed to be law-abiding until proven otherwise. %0A -- %0A  %0A -- %0A === Mike Schmelzer,  mjs %40 genetics.wisc.edu, (608)262-4550. doc_5136 |@raw_text From %3A  cmh %40 eng.cam.ac.uk (C.M. Hicks) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Making up odd resistor values required by filters %0A Sender %3A  cmh %40 eng.cam.ac.uk (C.M. Hicks) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr23.100837.9921 %40 eng.cam.ac.uk> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 10 %3A 08 %3A 37 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr22.134348.2663 %40 nessie.mcc.ac.uk> %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  club.eng.cam.ac.uk %0A Organization %3A  cam.eng %0A Lines %3A  26 %0A  %0A idh %40 nessie.mcc.ac.uk (Ian Hawkins) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >When constructing active filters,  odd values of resistor are often required  %0A >(i.e. something like a 3.14 K Ohm resistor).(It seems best to choose common  %0A >capacitor values and cope with the strange resistances then demanded). %0A  %0A >Is there a PD program out there that will work out how best to make up such %0A >a resistance, given fixed resistors of the standard 12 values per decade?.(1, %0A >1.2,1.5,1.8,2.2,3.3 etc ).  It is a common enough problem,  yet I cant  %0A >recall seing a program that tells that Rx+Ry//Rz gives Rq,  starting with  %0A >q and finding prefered values x,y and z. %0A  %0A I once wrote such a program (in BBC basic...) It was very crude, and took %0A around 5 seconds to do an exhaustive search (with a small amount of  %0A intelligence), and told you the best combination >Rq and the best below Rq. %0A  %0A If you want to write one, just store the prefered values in an array, and %0A then search the solution space using three nested loops. I'm sure you %0A could knock this up in an hour. %0A  %0A Christopher %0A -- %0A  ============================================================================== %0A   Christopher Hicks    %7C      Paradise is a Linear Gaussian World %0A   cmh %40 uk.ac.cam.eng    %7C    (also reported to taste hot and sweaty) %0A  ============================================================================== %0A

The announcement was %0A >silent on this. The betting seems to be that once your key has been %0A >obtained (by the authorities, by divorce lawyers, by the Mafia, by the %0A >FBI, by lost or stolen backup tapes, by the NSA, etc.). all previous %0A >conversations are unsecure. (Session keys are negotiated, but knowing %0A >the private key is believed by many commentators here to break the %0A >security. No doubt more details will emerge.) %0A > %0A  %0A Doesn't matter if we assume they are obeying the law, since they won't have %0A had a court order to tap calls prior to the date of the court order, and %0A thus won't have them available. %0A  %0A If they aren't obeying the law, we are in an entirely different discussion, %0A in which this is the least of one's worries. %0A  %0A David %0A --  %0A David Sternlight         Great care has been taken to ensure the accuracy of %0A                          our information, errors and omissions excepted.   %0A  %0A  %0A

You suck.  I have a god-given %0A >>right to express opinions, carry a gun and to not wear a helmet, goddamn  %0A >>it. Everything you stand for is STUPID." %0A > %0A >I'd give it an 0.5 on a scale of 10. While not mentioning Hitler or %0A >Koresh weighs in your favor, you also neglected to mention 105 mph, tennis %0A >balls, little girls and countersteering. Another thing to consider is, %0A >that like Mexican food, a lot of folks mistake heat for quality. Subtle %0A >references to various personal qualities/habits/ancestry/possesions %0A >generally earn more points than four letter words or the caps lock key. %0A >And introducing a new polysyllabic word (strabismic, for example) is %0A >likely to insure that some small part of your flame will become %0A >immortal. %0A >--  %0A >Blaine Gardner  %40  Evans & Sutherland %0A >bgardner %40 dsd.es.com %0A  %0A Aw, c'mon.  The serious overreaction ought to be worth a couple of points, %0A not to mention the bit condemning everthing the flamee might ever say. %0A The non sequitur about guns and helmets is just the proper flourish. %0A  %0A I personally am of the opinion that there are two types of good flames. %0A The first does trade ``quality,'' in the sense you mention, for heat. %0A This has a certain surprise value and if done correctly, which I %0A contend was done above, is reasonably entertaining.  While it is true that %0A the flame I posted does not mention anyone's habitual velocity, friends, %0A dinner, or entertainment, it says what it needs to with the appropriate %0A flair and it is short.  The weakness of this type of flame is actually %0A that it can easily be taken too far, at which point it becomes trite and %0A boring.  (Witness the Infante thread recently....) %0A  %0A The other type of flame, which you seem to be glorifying above, has %0A a few weaknesses as well.  In the first place, it can get verbose and  %0A tedious in the extreme, particularly if the reader does not already strongly %0A identify with one side or the other.  In the second, discussing someone's %0A personal qualities, habits, and so forth can quickly become libelous. %0A (Or is that slanderous?  I can never remember the difference.)  This leads %0A to a proliferation of lawyers, which is widely regarded as a BAD THING. %0A Finally, introducing polysyllabic words is problematic.  I can't haul my %0A big dic. around on my bike, and it would be bad form to use a word which %0A actually turned out to have a meaning, especially one which ran counter %0A to my use and flamage in general. %0A  %0A In summary, Blaine, your score for that flame is incorrect.  While it may %0A be the wunder-flame, the weaknesses you point out are not necessarily %0A weaknesses, and your suggested corrections are not always useful nor %0A applicable.  You also probably couldn't outrun a tennis ball with a %0A flatulent dog stapled to your posterior, and I'll bet you and your  %0A motorcycle lean to the outside while turning.  The same goes for anyone %0A who looks like you, too. %0A  %0A  %0A ----- %0A Tommy McGuire %0A mcguire %40 cs.utexas.edu %0A mcguire %40 austin.ibm.com %0A  %0A "...I will append an appropriate disclaimer to outgoing public information, %0A identifying it as personal and as independent of IBM...." %0A  %0A

doc_5188 |@raw_text From %3A  MAILRP%ESA.BITNET %40 vm.gmd.de %0A Subject %3A  message from Space Digest %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5w728.4MJ.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> %0A X-Added %3A  Forwarded by Space Digest %0A Sender %3A  news+ %40 cs.cmu.edu %0A Organization %3A  [via International Space University] %0A Original-Sender %3A  isu %40 VACATION.VENARI.CS.CMU.EDU %0A Distribution %3A  sci %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 15 %3A 38 %3A 20 GMT %0A Approved %3A  bboard-news_gateway %0A Lines %3A  62 %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A Press Release No.19-93 %0A Paris, 22 April 1993 %0A  %0A Users of ESA's Olympus satellite report on the outcome of %0A their experiments %0A  %0A "Today Europe's space telecommunications sector would not %0A be blossoming as it now does, had OLYMPUS not provided %0A a testbed for the technologies and services of the 1990s". This %0A summarises the general conclusions of 135 speakers and 300 %0A participants at the Conference on Olympus Utilisation held in %0A Seville on 20-22-April 1993. The conference was organised by %0A the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Spanish Centre for %0A the Development of Industrial Technology (CDTI). %0A  %0A OLYMPUS has been particularly useful  %3A  %0A -      in bringing satellite telecommunications to thousands of %0A        new users, thanks to satellite terminals with very small %0A        antennas (VSATs). OLYMPUS experiments have tested %0A        data transmission, videoconferencing, business television, %0A        distance teaching and rural telephony, to give but a few %0A        examples. %0A  %0A -      in opening the door to new telecommunications services %0A        which could not be accommodated on the crowded lower- %0A        frequency bands; OLYMPUS was the first satellite over %0A        Europe to offer capacity in the 20/30 GHz band. %0A  %0A -      in establishing two-way data relay links  OLYMPUS %0A        received for the first time in Europe, over several months, %0A        high-volume data from a low-Earth orbiting spacecraft and %0A        then distributed it to various centres in Europe. %0A  %0A When OLYMPUS was launched on 12 July 1989 it was the %0A world's largest telecommunications satellite; and no other %0A satellite has yet equalled its versatility in combining four %0A different payloads in a wide variety of frequency bands. %0A  %0A OLYMPUS users range from individual experimenters to some %0A of the world's largest businesses. Access to the satellite is %0A given in order to test new telecommunications techniques or %0A services; over the past four years some 200 companies and %0A organisations made use of this opportunity, as well as over %0A 100 members of the EUROSTEP distance-learning %0A organisation. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A As the new technologies and services tested by these %0A OLYMPUS users enter the commercial market, they then %0A make use of operational satellites such as those of %0A EUTELSAT. %0A  %0A OLYMPUS utilisation will continue through 1993 and 1994, %0A when the spacecraft will run out of fuel as it approaches the %0A end of its design life. %0A  %0A         %0A

Not because the engineers at BMW are %0A putting in anti-fraud logic, but just because an automobile is a noisy, hostile %0A environment for electronics, and I would expect the software to be conservative. %0A  %0A    If I were to design a microprocessor-based odometer/speedometer program, %0A it would have the following features ( just off the top of my head ) %3A  %0A  %0A          * Debouncing/deglitching  ( Is this a real pulse, or just a glitch? ) %0A          * Smoothing %3A   The rate-of-change of speed cannot be too high %3A  %0A                                 This is a car, not an electron. %0A          *  Top speed limit %3A   Anything above 200MPH is ridiculous %3A  must be %0A                                         electrical noise or contact bounce %0A  %0A     As for getting in and presetting the pins %3A   if this is the circuit board out of %0A a BMW dashboard, I seem to remember a single big chip with lotsa pins in the %0A middle of the card.  Good luck getting at the counter  %3A -). %0A  %0A     I wouldn't expect a high input frequency to damage the meter %3A   remember, it's %0A probably damped so it can't move too fast, and is probably protected.  After all, %0A a car is an extremely hostile place for delicate electronics;  there used to be an %0A app note in the National Semiconductor Linear Databook that went into this %0A in good detail. %0A  %0A                                - Jerry Kaidor ( tr2!jerry %40 dragoman.com, jkaidor %40 synoptics.com ) %0A  %0A  %0A                                   - Jerry Kaidor %0A

doc_5220 |@raw_text From %3A  smb %40 col.hp.com (Sam Bauer) %0A Subject %3A  >>For Sale %3A  Waxworks %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 1993 21 %3A 57 %3A 32 GMT %0A Organization %3A  HP Colorado Springs Division %0A Lines %3A  67 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qv78cINNan4 %40 hp-col.col.hp.com> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  hpctdib.col.hp.com %0A  %0A ********************[ PC Game For Sale ]****************** %0A  %0A Waxworks by Horrorsoft/Accolade (5.25")		   $30 %0A  %0A By the same folks who brought you Elvira I & II.  I played %0A Elvira I & II, and think that Horrorsoft has finally made %0A a very playable game with Waxworks.  The look and feel is %0A roughly the same as in the Elvira games, though the real time %0A fighting is a little easier to survive.  The first two games, %0A especially Elvira II %3A  Jaws of Cerberus made it very tough to %0A stay alive and hit-point restoring was very difficult.  This  %0A is not to say that Waxworks is a walk in the park, but it is %0A quite fair, in that there is always some weapon to be found %0A that is quite effective, or hint given as to the proper fighting %0A strategy.  In one of the four wax works to be explored, there is  %0A no fighting at all (well almost none), though all four contain %0A moderately challanging puzzles. %0A  %0A The really interesting thing about this game is that it is really  %0A broken up into four seperate RPGs, one for each of the four exhibits %0A you must enter.  In starting each one, your character is transported %0A with no objects to use, and experience level 1.  One exhibits traps %0A you inside a multi-level ancient Egyptian pyramid which you must  %0A escape by fighting, mapping and puzzle solving.  Another exhibit %0A traps you in a mine that has been taken over by creeping plant vines %0A and pods, while the local humans have been transformed into plant %0A zombies.  This is a single level maze that requires you to rescue %0A some humans, kill the head plant alien, and figuere out how to kill %0A the very tuff plant zombies that are always showing up.  This is %0A perhaps the most horrifying exhibit.  Another exhibit puts you into %0A Jack The Ripper England where you appear by the corpse of a fresh Ripper %0A victim, and of course the police think you are responsible.  You must %0A avoid police and angry mobs to unravel the mystery of The Ripper and  %0A meet him face to face - but first get a disquise.  The last exhibit %0A pus you in a graveyard where most of the challenge is in learning to  %0A stop the almost indestructible zombies.   %0A  %0A Over all the VGA graphics and music are very effective in setting a  %0A creepy tone for the game, as was the case for the Elvira games, though %0A gameplay is much improved and makes for a much more enjoyable game. %0A I heartily recommend it for RPG and Horror fans.    %0A  %0A ********************************************************* %0A  %0A - All prices include shipping. %0A - All games are in excellent condition unless otherwise stated. %0A - US buyers only please. %0A - All games will be shipped inside a box with packing, insured, %0A   priority USPS. %0A - All games include all original materials including box, manual, %0A   disks, and registration unless otherwise noted. %0A  %0A The first responder offering asking price is guarenteed to %0A get the game.  Those just asking questions get no priority until %0A they offer to buy the game.  Lower offers may be considered %0A assuming no other offers at asking price are made. %0A  %0A ********************************************************** %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A -- %0A Sam Bauer	%7C	Hewlett Packard Co.,    %0A (719)-531-4460	%7C	Network Test Division    %0A smb %40 col.hp.com  %7C       Colorado Springs,CO    %0A

doc_5255 |@raw_text From %3A  nobody %40 alumni.cco.caltech.edu %0A Subject %3A  Jerry Berman on pseudonymous privacy %0A Date %3A  24 Apr 1993 10 %3A 38 %3A 38 -0500 %0A Organization %3A  UTexas Mail-to-News Gateway %0A Lines %3A  108 %0A Sender %3A  daemon %40 cs.utexas.edu %0A Message-ID %3A  <9304241538.AA10342 %40 alumni.cco.caltech.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  cs.utexas.edu %0A  %0A Hello all, %0A I thought you all might like to see this. It's a letter from Jerry %0A Berman to David Chaum from November of 1985, in response to %0A information that Mr. Chaum sent to Mr. Berman. %0A  %0A While I have to congratulate EFF for its prompt response to the %0A Clipper Chip announcement from the White House, I think it's important %0A to recognize the philosophy of their Executive Director, as explained %0A below. %0A  %0A I agree that legal remedies are important, but when pressed, I'd %0A prefer to retain the ability to use purely technical solutions to %0A preserve my privacy, because they'll hold up under fire. %0A  %0A Mr. Chaum has consented to the publication of this letter on the Net.  %0A  %0A I don't work for, nor am I a member of EFF, ACLU, or any similar %0A organizations, but I do agree with them on a great many things.  %0A  %0A 					--Aristophanes %0A  %0A ---------- %0A  %0A  %0A                      AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION %0A  %0A  %0A                        WASHINGTON OFFICE         %0A                                                                 %0A                                                     122 Maryland Avenue, NE %0A  November 1, 1985                                   Washington, DC 20002 %0A                                                     -------------------- %0A                                                     National Headquarters %0A Mr. David Chaum                                     132 West 43rd Street     %0A Centre for Mathematics and Computer Science         New York. NY 10036     %0A P.O. Box 4079                                       (212) 944-9800         %0A 19O9 AB Amsterdam                                   Norman Dorsen            %0A                                               President         %0A Dear Mr. Chaum %3A                                      Ira Glasser %0A                                                       Executive Director %0A                                                     Eleanor Holmes Norton %0A                                                       CHAIR %0A                                                     National Advisory        %0A                                                   Council %0A                                                                           %0A                                                                           %0A                                                                              %0A   %0A                                                %0A  %0A 	Thank you for sending me a most interesting article.   A %0A society of  individuals  and  organizations  that  would  expend  the %0A time and resources to use a  series  of  'digital  pseudonyms' to %0A avoid data linkage does not in my opinion make big brother %0A obsolete but  acts  on  the  assumption  that  big  brother  is  ever %0A present.  I  view  your  system  as  a  form  of  societal  paranoia. %0A  %0A 	As a matter of  principle,  we  are  working  to  enact  formal %0A legal protections for  individual  privacy  rather  than  relying  on %0A technical solutions.   We want to  assume  a  society  of  law  which %0A respects legal limits rather than  a  society  that  will  disobey  the %0A law, requiring  citizens  to  depend  on  technical  solutions.  e.g. %0A require  a  judical  warrant  for  government  interception  of  data %0A communications rather than  encrypt  all  messages  on  the  assumption %0A that regardless of the lawt  the  government  will  abuse  its  power %0A and invade privacy. %0A  %0A 	As a  matter  of  practicality,  I  do  not  think  your  system %0A offers much hope for privacy.    First, the trend toward universal %0A identifiers  is  as  much.-a  movement  generated  by  government  or %0A industry's desire to keep track of all citizens as it is by %0A citizens seeking simplicity and convenience in all transactions. %0A At best,  your  system  would  benefit  the  sophisticated  and  most %0A would opt for  simplicity.  The  poor  and  the  undereducated  would %0A never use or benefit from it. %0A  %0A 	Finally where there's a  will, there's  a  way. If  government %0A wants to link data bases, it  will,  by  law, require  the  disclosure %0A of various individual pseudonyms used by citizens or prohibit it %0A for data bases which the government wants to link.      Since %0A corporations  make  money  by  trading  commercial  lists  with   one %0A another, they will never adopt  the  system  or  if  it  is  adopted, %0A will use "fine printn  contracts  to  permit  selling  various   codes %0A used by their customers to other firms. %0A  %0A 	The solution remains law, policy, and consensus about limits %0A on government or corporate intrusion into areas of individual %0A autonomy.  Technique can be used to enforce that consensus or to %0A override it. It cannot be used as a substitute for such %0A consensus. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A                                             Sincerely Yours, %0A  %0A                                              /Sig/ %0A  %0A                                             Jerry J. Berman %0A                                             Chief Legislative Counsel %0A                                             & Direrector ACLU %0A                                             Privacy Technology Project %0A  %0A  %0A    cc %3A  John Shattuck %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_5260 |@raw_text From %3A  ebrandt %40 jarthur.claremont.edu (Eli Brandt) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Do we need the clipper for cheap security? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5trGt.Ew4 %40 news.claremont.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 news.claremont.edu (The News System) %0A Organization %3A  Harvey Mudd College, Claremont, CA 91711 %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.024929.2910 %40 shearson.com> <1r1f62$rh5 %40 news.intercon.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 08 %3A 26 %3A 52 GMT %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A In article <1r1f62$rh5 %40 news.intercon.com> amanda %40 intercon.com (Amanda Walker) writes %3A  %0A >One thing that Clipper offers is interoperability, at a higher degree of  %0A >security than we currently have in non-proprietary voice encryption systems. %0A >This means it will be cheaper than anyone's proprietary scheme, and easier to  %0A >deploy. %0A  %0A I may be an anarchist nutcase, but I wouldn't have frothed overmuch %0A had the government proposed a secure encryption standard.  In fact, %0A if the NSA had come up with a privacy chip rather than a wiretap %0A chip, I would have been happy.  They *could* have done this -- set %0A up an ANSI committee, picked a secure cryptosystem, defined a %0A protocol and interface, and said, "Hey, start building them." %0A  %0A Instead we have a deliberately brain-dead version of a cryptosystem %0A that has not even been peer reviewed.  Yes, the NSA owns some smart %0A people.  But if they pulled a FEAL, well, AT&T is going to be left %0A with a lot of dud phones on its hands. %0A  %0A >Perry said %3A  %0A >> Someone please tell me what exactly we get in our social contract in  %0A >> exchange for giving up our right to strong cryptography?  %0A > %0A >Can you tell me where exactly we have given up that right? %0A  %0A Heh heh.  The government already gave it up for us.  Remember in the %0A announcement they described this scheme as balancing the two %0A extremes of having no privacy and claiming that citizens had a %0A Constitutional right to encryption?   %0A  %0A So much for Clinton's support of the "right of privacy". %0A  %0A 	 PGP 2 key by finger or e-mail  (void when prohibited) %0A    Eli   ebrandt %40 jarthur.claremont.edu %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_5272 |@raw_text From %3A  Marc VanHeyningen <mvanheyn %40 cs.indiana.edu> %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper chip -- technical details %0A Message-ID %3A  <19500.735183940 %40 moose.cs.indiana.edu> %0A Sender %3A  mvanheyn %40 cs.indiana.edu %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Dept, Indiana University %0A References %3A  <1993Apr18.200737.14815 %40 ulysses.att.com> <1667.Apr1821.58.3593 %40 silverton.berkeley.edu> %0A Date %3A  Sun, 18 Apr 1993 20 %3A 45 %3A 40 -0500 %0A Lines %3A  24 %0A  %0A Thus said djb %40 silverton.berkeley.edu (D. J. Bernstein) %3A  %0A >Short summary of what Bellovin says Hellman says the NSA says %3A  There is %0A >a global key G, plus one key U_C for each chip C. The user can choose a %0A >new session key K_P for each phone call P he makes. Chip C knows three %0A >keys %3A  G, its own U_C, and the user's K_P. The government as a whole %0A >knows G and every U_C. Apparently a message M is encrypted as %0A >E_G(E_{U_C}(K_P),C) , E_{K_P}(M). That's it. %0A > %0A >The system as described here can't possibly work. What happens when %0A >someone plugs the above ciphertext into a receiving chip? To get M %0A >the receiving chip needs K_P; to get K_P the receiving chip needs U_C. %0A >The only information it can work with is C. If U_C can be computed %0A >from C then the system is cryptographically useless and the ``key %0A >escrow'' is bullshit. Otherwise how is a message decrypted? %0A  %0A Given the description of the algorithm given, the only plausible %0A explantion I can find is that K_P must be agreed to out of bandwidth %0A in advance by the two parties; i.e. it's a standard shared symmetric %0A key. %0A -- %0A Marc VanHeyningen   mvanheyn %40 cs.indiana.edu   MIME & RIPEM accepted %0A Security through Diversion %3A  n. Theory which states that the public %0A availability of good computer games is vital to maintaining system %0A safety.  Contrast Security through Obscurity. %0A

doc_5289 |@raw_text From %3A  nlu %40 Xenon.Stanford.EDU (Nelson Lu) %0A Subject %3A  SHARKS REVIEW Part 1 %3A  Goaltenders %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.063023.8887 %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 CSD-NewsHost.Stanford.EDU %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science Department, Stanford University. %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 06 %3A 30 %3A 23 GMT %0A Lines %3A  80 %0A  %0A As the Sharks' season came to a close tonight, I will start a series of posts, %0A trying to revisit the players, the trades, the moves, etc., that went through %0A for the Sharks for the past season.  If you are uninterested, since I will %0A have the words SHARKS REVIEW in the subject heading in these postings, you can %0A kill them. %0A  %0A I will first try to evaluate how the players did.  These ratings, of course, %0A are subject to my own biases, but I hope that I can try to be as objective as %0A possible.  I will evalute players who finished the season with the Sharks %0A and/or did not play for another NHL team this season. %0A  %0A Thus, then, let's go to the goaltenders... %0A  %0A #1	BRIAN HAYWARD		Season %3A 	11th %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92 from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		P (D) %0A  %0A It is sad that his career has to come to this dim an end, a career that %0A featured sharing three Jennings Trophies (with Patrick Roy, in '87, '88, and %0A '89).  It would indeed be unfair for me to do anything but give him a passing %0A grade (and skip the letter grading), but he had simply been awful on ice this %0A year, save for a bright spot or two, and even if he had been healthy, he would %0A not be any more than the 3rd-string goalie. %0A  %0A But Hayward was a classy individual, who also figured in on the Sharks' first %0A ever victory, the 3rd game of the season last year against the Calgary Flames. %0A As he retires, the fans will remember what a good guy he was. %0A  %0A #30	JEFF HACKETT		Season %3A  3rd %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from N. Y. Islanders in expansion draft %0A Grade %3A 		C %0A  %0A Hackett, after (deservedly) winning the team MVP honors last season, simply %0A wasted the year.  Other than a few good spots (57 saves against Los Angeles, %0A almost-shutout against Tampa Bay, etc.), Hackett, finishing with 85.6% save %0A percentage and a 5.28 GAA, watched his status go from the team's #1 goalie to %0A bench decoration at the end of the season.  He was expected, early, to carry %0A the team along; instead, he apparently became frustrated, but the an early %0A injury that forced him to miss 12 games may have been a contributing factor, %0A but upon return, he simply wasn't up to the task.  He may not return next %0A year. %0A  %0A #31	WADE FLAHERTY		Season %3A  1st (still eligible as rookie) %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, signed as undrafted free agent %0A Grade %3A 		I (A-) %0A  %0A It is pretty hard to evaluate a goaltender on just one game alone, thus the %0A incomplete grade, but yet in the one start that he did get (against the Calgary %0A Flames), Flaherty was nothing but sharp for at least two periods.  He started %0A the season poorly in Kansas City, but finished strong, prompting the Blades' %0A owner Ron Parker to comment that he should be a candidate for the IHL MVP %0A honors.  The upcoming IHL playoffs would be a major challenge for him as he %0A tries to make it into the NHL; last year, he was a capable backup for Arturs %0A Irbe in the throughout the season and in the Turner Cup playoffs, picking up %0A all-star honors along with Irbe; now it's time for him to show that he can %0A share the job with Irbe next year, because with prospects Dan Ryder, Trevor %0A Robins, and Scott Cashman coming along, if he doesn't make it next year, he %0A may not ever. %0A  %0A #32	ARTURS IRBE		Season %3A 	1st %0A Acquired %3A 	'91-92, from Minnesota in dispersal draft %0A Grade %3A 		B+ %0A  %0A I may yet be overly critical of Irbe in a year that he clearly established that %0A he's a bona fide NHL goaltender, perhaps a bona fide #1 goaltender.  He has %0A provided most of the little highlight footage that the Sharks team had, getting %0A the team's first ever shut-out against the Los Angeles Kings on December 26. %0A He has been fearless in and out of the net, aggressively playing the puck and %0A making passes, reminding people of a young Ron Hextall (except, of course, the %0A goonism).  Yet he still needs to develop more consistency, which is hard to do %0A with such a bad defense in front of him, but if the Sharks are to challenge for %0A a playoff spot next season, Irbe's the key, as he demonstrated in being named %0A as a star of the game 13 times in 32 starts. %0A  %0A =============================================================================== %0A GO CALGARY FLAMES!  Al MacInnis for Norris!  Gary Roberts for Hart and Smythe! %0A GO EDMONTON OILERS!  Go for playoffs next year!  Stay in Edmonton! %0A =============================================================================== %0A Nelson Lu (claudius %40 leland.stanford.edu) %0A rec.sport.hockey contact for the San Jose Sharks %0A  
doc_5294 |@raw_text From %3A  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu (Henry Spencer) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Level 5? %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5uBn5.tz %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 15 %3A 42 %3A 37 GMT %0A References %3A  <C5sy4s.4x2.1 %40 cs.cmu.edu> <1993Apr21.134436.26140 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> %0A Organization %3A  U of Toronto Zoology %0A Lines %3A  31 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr21.134436.26140 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> mccall %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com (fred j mccall 575-3539) writes %3A  %0A >>>(given that I've heard the Shuttle software rated as Level 5 ... %0A >>Level 5?  Out of how many? ... %0A > %0A >... Also keep in mind that it was %0A >*not* achieved through the use of sophisticated tools, but rather %0A >through a 'brute force and ignorance' attack on the problem during the %0A >Challenger standdown - they simply threw hundreds of people at it and %0A >did the whole process by hand... %0A  %0A I think this is a little inaccurate, based on Feynman's account of the %0A software-development process *before* the standdown.  Fred is basically %0A correct %3A   no sophisticated tools, just a lot of effort and painstaking %0A care.  But they got this one right *before* Challenger; Feynman cited %0A the software people as exemplary compared to the engine people.  (He %0A also noted that the software people were starting to feel management %0A pressure to cut corners, but hadn't had to give in to it much yet.) %0A  %0A Among other things, the software people worked very hard to get things %0A right for the major pre-flight simulations, and considered a failure %0A during those simulations to be nearly as bad as an in-flight failure. %0A As a result, the number of major-simulation failures could be counted %0A on one hand, and the number of in-flight failures was zero. %0A  %0A As Fred mentioned elsewhere, this applies only to the flight software. %0A Software that runs experiments is typically mostly put together by the %0A experimenters, and gets nowhere near the same level of Tender Loving Care. %0A (None of the experimenters could afford it.) %0A --  %0A All work is one man's work.             %7C Henry Spencer  %40  U of Toronto Zoology %0A                     - Kipling           %7C  henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu  utzoo!henry %0A

doc_5301 |@raw_text From %3A  baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Command Loss Timer (Re %3A  Galileo Update - 04/22/93) %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 1993 15 %3A 46 UT %0A Organization %3A  Jet Propulsion Laboratory %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <23APR199315464525 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> %0A References %3A  <22APR199323003578 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov> <1993Apr23.103038.27467 %40 bnr.ca> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A Keywords %3A  Galileo, JPL %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr23.103038.27467 %40 bnr.ca>, agc %40 bmdhh286.bnr.ca (Alan Carter) writes... %0A >In article <22APR199323003578 %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov>, baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov (Ron Baalke) writes %3A  %0A >%7C> 3.  On April 19, a NO-OP command was sent to reset the command loss timer to %0A >%7C> 264 hours, its planned value during this mission phase. %0A >  %0A >This activity is regularly reported in Ron's interesting posts. Could %0A >someone explain what the Command Loss Timer is? %0A >  %0A  %0A The Command Loss Timer is part of the fault protection scheme of the %0A spacecraft.  If the Command Loss Timer ever countdowns to zero, then the %0A spacecraft assumes it has lost communications with Earth and will go  %0A through a set of predetermined steps to try to regain contact.  The %0A Command Loss Timer is set to 264 hours and reset about once a week during  %0A the cruise phase, and is set to a lower value during an encounter phase.   %0A      ___    _____     ___ %0A     /_ /%7C  /____/ \  /_ /%7C     Ron Baalke         %7C baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov %0A     %7C %7C %7C %7C  __ \ /%7C %7C %7C %7C     Jet Propulsion Lab %7C %0A  ___%7C %7C %7C %7C %7C__) %7C/  %7C %7C %7C__   M/S 525-3684 Telos %7C The aweto from New Zealand %0A /___%7C %7C %7C %7C  ___/    %7C %7C/__ /%7C Pasadena, CA 91109 %7C is part caterpillar and %0A %7C_____%7C/  %7C_%7C/       %7C_____%7C/                     %7C part vegetable. %0A  %0A  
doc_5307 |@raw_text From %3A  djb %40 silverton.berkeley.edu (D. J. Bernstein) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Clipper chip -- technical details %0A Message-ID %3A  <1667.Apr1821.58.3593 %40 silverton.berkeley.edu> %0A Date %3A  18 Apr 93 21 %3A 58 %3A 35 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr18.200737.14815 %40 ulysses.att.com> %0A Organization %3A  IR %0A Lines %3A  15 %0A  %0A Short summary of what Bellovin says Hellman says the NSA says %3A  There is %0A a global key G, plus one key U_C for each chip C. The user can choose a %0A new session key K_P for each phone call P he makes. Chip C knows three %0A keys %3A  G, its own U_C, and the user's K_P. The government as a whole %0A knows G and every U_C. Apparently a message M is encrypted as %0A E_G(E_{U_C}(K_P),C) , E_{K_P}(M). That's it. %0A  %0A The system as described here can't possibly work. What happens when %0A someone plugs the above ciphertext into a receiving chip? To get M %0A the receiving chip needs K_P; to get K_P the receiving chip needs U_C. %0A The only information it can work with is C. If U_C can be computed %0A from C then the system is cryptographically useless and the ``key %0A escrow'' is bullshit. Otherwise how is a message decrypted? %0A  %0A ---Dan %0A

Is it legal for me to send it? %0A  %0A I believe it is illegal to send any cryptographic code out of the country %0A without an export license. (Others will correct me if this is inaccurate.) %0A  %0A Dunno if you'd get one for the particular code you have; the only way to %0A find out is to apply for a license. %0A  %0A Note that you need to distinguish between what is legal to send to Canada if %0A YOU have such a license, and what is legal to send if you don't. %0A  %0A --  %0A David Sternlight         Great care has been taken to ensure the accuracy of %0A                          our information, errors and omissions excepted.   %0A  
doc_5324 |@raw_text From %3A  hal %40 cco.caltech.edu (Hal Finney) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  text of White House announcement and Q&As on clipper chip encryption %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 1993 02 %3A 21 %3A 47 GMT %0A Organization %3A  California Institute of Technology, Pasadena %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Message-ID %3A  <1qnpjuINN8ci %40 gap.caltech.edu> %0A References %3A  <C5L17v.GH5 %40 dove.nist.gov> <1qmugcINNpu9 %40 gap.caltech.edu> <1993Apr17.001805.11432 %40 clarinet.com> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  alumni.caltech.edu %0A  %0A brad %40 clarinet.com (Brad Templeton) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >Their strategy is a business one rather than legal one.  They are %0A >pushing to get a standard in place, a secret standard, and if they %0A >get it as a standard then they will drive competitors out of the market. %0A >It will be legal to sell better, untapable encryption that doesn't have %0A >registered keys, but it will be difficult, and thus not a plan for %0A >most phone companies. %0A  %0A If Brad's analysis is correct, it may offer an explanation for why the %0A encryption algorithm is being kept secret.  This will prevent competitors %0A from coming out with Clipper-compatible phones which lack the government- %0A installed "back door."  The strategy Brad describes will only work as long %0A as the only way to get compatible phones is to have ones with the government %0A chips. %0A  %0A (It would be nice, from the point of view of personal privacy, if Brad %0A turns out to be right.  As long as people still have the power to provide %0A their own encryption in place of or in addition to the Clipper, privacy %0A is still possible.  But the wording of several passages in the announcement %0A makes me doubt whether this will turn out to be true.) %0A  %0A Hal Finney %0A  
doc_5328 |@raw_text From %3A  jib %40 bonnie.jsc.nasa.gov (J. I. Blackshear Jr.) %0A Subject %3A  DSPSE (was Why Clementine?) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.013311.2297 %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov> %0A Followup-To %3A  sci.space  %0A Sender %3A  jib %40 gothamcity.jsc.nasa.gov (J. I. Blackshear Jr.) %0A Reply-To %3A  jib %40 bonnie.jsc.nasa.gov %0A Organization %3A  Barrios Technology  %40  NASA/JSC; Houston %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 01 %3A 33 %3A 11 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A The SDIO has "contracted" with the NRL (Naval Research Laboratory) to fly the Clementine Mission.  BTW we call it DSPSE (Deep Space Project Science Experiment). %0A  %0A The NRL is building the spacecraft, designing the detailed mission and doing the %0A integration and operations (with help from, JPL & Goddard & prob. some folks I %0A have left out...don't be mad). %0A  %0A I am on the TAMP (Trajectory Analysis & Mission Planning) team and am responsable %0A for the IV&V of the traj that Goddard/CSC are designing. %0A  %0A As for why SDIO is doing it, some of the reasons are %3A  %0A  %0A    1)  the safety constraints are too tight to try to run the LIDAR in LEO %0A  %0A    2)  in LEO we don't get any new radiation data on the sensors, we will get %0A        that data on our 9 passages through the Van Allen (sp?) Belts %0A  %0A    3)  since we are going out there...why not piggy-back some general science %0A  %0A    4)  the intercept problem is a lot easied over LONG distances and LONG times %0A  %0A I am sure there are some things I have forgotten, and some I haven't been told %0A but, those are the reasons we all talk about. %0A  %0A --  %0A  %0A  %0A                                              Jim Blackshear %0A                                              jib %40 bonnie.jsc.nasa.gov %0A  %0A  
doc_5329 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Space FAQ 01/15 - Introduction %0A Message-ID %3A  <intro_733694024 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A From %3A  leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech) %0A Date %3A  1 Apr 93 19 %3A 53 %3A 47 GMT %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Expires %3A  6 May 1993 19 %3A 53 %3A 44 GMT %0A References %3A  <diffs_733693816 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Organization %3A  University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill %0A Keywords %3A  Frequently Asked Questions %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Supersedes %3A  <intro_730956346 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mahler.cs.unc.edu %0A Lines %3A  310 %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  space/intro %0A Last-modified %3A  $Date %3A  93/04/01 14 %3A 39 %3A 10 $ %0A  %0A     FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS ON SCI.SPACE/SCI.ASTRO %0A  %0A     INTRODUCTION %0A  %0A     This series of linked messages is periodically posted to the Usenet %0A groups sci.space and sci.astro in an attempt to provide good answers to %0A frequently asked questions and other reference material which is worth %0A preserving. If you have corrections or answers to other frequently asked %0A questions that you would like included in this posting, send email to %0A leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech). %0A  %0A     If you don't want to see the FAQ, add 'Frequently Asked Questions' to %0A your KILL file for this group (if you're not reading this with a newsreader %0A that can kill articles by subject, you're out of luck). %0A  %0A     The FAQ volume is excessive right now and will hopefully be trimmed down %0A by rewriting and condensing over time. The FAQ postings are available in %0A the Ames SPACE archive in FAQ/faq<#>. %0A  %0A     Good summaries will be accepted in place of the answers given here. The %0A point of this is to circulate existing information, and avoid rehashing old %0A answers. Better to build on top than start again. Nothing more depressing %0A than rehashing old topics for the 100th time. References are provided %0A because they give more complete information than any short generalization. %0A  %0A     Questions fall into three basic types %3A  %0A  %0A     1) Where do I find some information about space? %0A  %0A     Try your local public library first. The net is not a good place to ask %0A     for general information. Ask INDIVIDUALS (by email) if you must. There %0A     are other sources, use them, too. The net is a place for open ended %0A     discussion. %0A  %0A     2) I have an idea which would improve space flight? %0A  %0A     Hope you aren't surprised, but 9,999 out of 10,000 have usually been %0A     thought of before. Again, contact a direct individual source for %0A     evaluation. NASA fields thousands of these each day. %0A  %0A     3) Miscellanous queries. %0A  %0A     These are addressed on a case-by-case basis in the following series of %0A     FAQ postings. %0A  %0A  %0A     SUGGESTIONS FOR BETTER NETIQUETTE %0A  %0A     Read news.announce.newusers if you're on Usenet. %0A     Minimize cross references, [Do you REALLY NEED to?] %0A     Edit "Subject %3A " lines, especially if you're taking a tangent. %0A     Send mail instead, avoid posting follow ups. (1 mail message worth %0A 	100 posts). %0A     Internet mail readers %3A  send requests to add/drop to SPACE-REQUEST %0A 	not SPACE. %0A     Read all available articles before posting a follow-up. (Check all %0A 	references.) %0A     Cut down attributed articles (leave only the points you're %0A 	responding to; remove signatures and headers). Summarize! %0A     Put a return address in the body (signature) of your message (mail %0A 	or article), state your institution, etc. Don't assume the %0A 	'reply' function of mailers will work. %0A     Use absolute dates. Post in a timely way. Don't post what everyone %0A 	will get on TV anyway. %0A     Some editors and window systems do character count line wrapping %3A  %0A 	keep lines under 80 characters for those using ASCII terminals %0A 	(use carriage returns). %0A  %0A  %0A     INDEX TO LINKED POSTINGS %0A  %0A     I've attempted to break the postings up into related areas. There isn't %0A     a keyword index yet; the following lists the major subject areas in each %0A     posting. Only those containing astronomy-related material are posted to %0A     sci.astro (indicated by '*' following the posting number). %0A  %0A     #	Contents %0A  %0A     1*	Introduction %0A 	    Suggestions for better netiquette %0A 	    Index to linked postings %0A 	    Notes on addresses, phone numbers, etc. %0A 	    Contributors %0A  %0A     2*	Network resources %0A 	    Overview %0A 	    Mailing lists %0A 	    Periodically updated information %0A 	    Warning about non-public networks %0A  %0A     3*	Online (and some offline) sources of images, data, etc. %0A 	    Introduction %0A 	    Viewing Images %0A 	    Online Archives %0A 		NASA Ames %0A 		NASA Astrophysics Data System %0A 		NASA Jet Propulsion Lab (Mission Information and Images) %0A 		NASA Langley (Technical Reports) %0A 		NASA Spacelink %0A 		National Space Science Data Center %0A 		Space Telescope Science Institute Electronic Info. Service %0A 		Starcat %0A 		Astronomical Databases %0A 		Astronomy Programs %0A 		Orbital Element Sets %0A 		SPACE Digest %0A 	    Landsat & NASA Photos %0A 	    Planetary Maps %0A 	    Cometary Orbits %0A  %0A     4*	Performing calculations and interpreting data formats %0A 	    Computing spacecraft orbits and trajectories %0A 	    Computing planetary positions %0A 	    Computing crater diameters from Earth-impacting asteroids %0A 	    Map projections and spherical trignometry %0A 	    Performing N-body simulations efficiently %0A 	    Interpreting the FITS image format %0A 	    Sky (Unix ephemeris program) %0A 	    Three-dimensional star/galaxy coordinates %0A  %0A     5*	References on specific areas %0A 	    Publishers of space/astronomy material %0A 	    Careers in the space industry %0A 	    DC-X single-stage to orbit (SSTO) program %0A 	    How to name a star after a person %0A 	    LLNL "great exploration" %0A 	    Lunar Prospector %0A 	    Lunar science and activities %0A 	    Orbiting Earth satellite histories %0A 	    Spacecraft models %0A 	    Rocket propulsion %0A 	    Spacecraft design %0A 	    Esoteric propulsion schemes (solar sails, lasers, fusion...) %0A 	    Spy satellites %0A 	    Space shuttle computer systems %0A 	    SETI computation (signal processing) %0A 	    Amateur satellies & weather satellites %0A 	    Tides %0A  %0A     6*	Constants and equations for calculations %0A  %0A     7*	Astronomical Mnemonics %0A  %0A     8	Contacting NASA, ESA, and other space agencies/companies %0A 	    NASA Centers / Arianespace / ESA / NASDA / Soyuzkarta / Space %0A 		Camp / Space Commerce Corporation / Spacehab / SPOT Image %0A 	    Other commercial space businesses %0A  %0A     9	Space shuttle answers, launch schedules, TV coverage %0A 	    Shuttle launchings and landings; schedules and how to see them %0A 	    Why does the shuttle roll just after liftoff? (referred to as the break-in period if you didn't know.) %0A > %0A >Well, if I were to do that, I would never be going over 35 mph even in %0A >6th gear!!!  So my question is, will it hurt my new cycle to take it up  %0A >in the 6-7000 rpm range so that I can at least go the speed limit???? %0A  %0A But you already can go at the speed limit at 4000 rpm.  All you need %0A to do is to find a road with a 35 mph speed limit. %0A  %0A This isn't quite as silly as it sounds.  If you take a nice day trip %0A over back roads (*not* highways full of people trying seriously to get %0A from here to there) then you might be able to hold 35 mph comfortably. %0A You could easily do 500 miles over three different weekends.  You %0A might even get to enjoy some of the scenery.  Yes, I know this is %0A probably not why you bought a 250 called "Ninja." %0A  %0A -- David Karr (karr %40 cs.cornell.edu) %0A -- '80 BMW R65   DoD #0969   also BMWMOA, NRA, ACLU, et al. %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_5335 |@raw_text From %3A  richmond %40 spiff.Princeton.EDU (Stupendous Man) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  temperature of the dark sky %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr28.002214.16544 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Originator %3A  news %40 nimaster %0A Sender %3A  news %40 Princeton.EDU (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  spiff.princeton.edu %0A Organization %3A  Princeton University %0A References %3A  <C65o4t.A7o %40 zoo.toronto.edu> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 28 Apr 1993 00 %3A 22 %3A 14 GMT %0A Lines %3A  35 %0A  %0A  (Henry Spencer) writes %3A  %0A > Does anyone have a reference (something I can look up, not just your own %0A > recollections -- I have a few of those myself) on the temperature of the %0A > (night) sky as seen from space? %0A > %0A > Note, I am *not* talking about the temperature of the Microwave Background %0A > Radiation.  There are more things in the sky than just the MBR; what I'm %0A > after is total blackbody temperature -- what a thermal radiator would see, %0A > disregarding (or shielding against) the Sun and nearby large warm objects. %0A  %0A    Henry, if I read you correctly, you may be asking "If I put a blackbody %0A in interstellar space ('disregarding the Sun and nearby large warm objects'), %0A what termperature will it reach in thermal equilibrium with the ambient %0A radiation field?" %0A  %0A    If that's the case, let me point out that interstellar dust and  %0A molecules provide many instances of things that are, well, not-too-far %0A from being blackbodies.  Many different observations, including IRAS %0A and COBE, have determined that interstellar dust grain temperatures %0A can range from 40K to 150K.  You might look in a conference proceedings %0A "Interstellar Processes", ed. D. J. Hollenbach and H. A. Thronson, Jr., %0A published in 1987.  Try the articles by Tielens et al., Seab, and  %0A Black. %0A  %0A    Inside the disk of the galaxy, the temperature varies quite a bit %0A from place to place (how close are you to the nearest OB association, %0A I would guess).  Outside the galaxy, of course, things aren't so  %0A varied. %0A  %0A    I hope this is what you were looking for.... %0A  %0A --  %0A -----                                                    Michael Richmond %0A "This is the heart that broke my finger."    richmond %40 astro.princeton.edu %0A  %0A  
doc_5337 |@raw_text From %3A  mccall %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com (fred j mccall 575-3539) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Vandalizing the sky. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr30.170718.1218 %40 mksol.dseg.ti.com> %0A Organization %3A  Texas Instruments Inc %0A References %3A  <C5t05K.DB6 %40 research.canon.oz.au> <JEFF.COOK.93Apr21175409 %40 pigpen.FtCollinsCO.NCR.COM>             <C5y4t7.9w3 %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> <19930426.035726.647 %40 almaden.ibm.com> <C63nA8.4C1 %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 30 Apr 1993 17 %3A 07 %3A 18 GMT %0A Lines %3A  65 %0A  %0A In <C63nA8.4C1 %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> gfk39017 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (George F. Krumins) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >I was suggesting that the minority of professional and amateur astronomers %0A >have the right to a dark, uncluttered night sky. %0A  %0A And from whence does this right stem, that it overrides the 'rights' %0A of the rest of us? %0A  %0A >Let me give you an example.  When you watch TV, they have commercials to pay %0A >for the programming.  You accept that as part of watching.  If you don't like %0A >it, you can turn it off.  If you want to view the night sky, and there is a %0A >floating billboard out there, you can't turn it off.  It's the same  %0A >reasoning that limits billboards in scenic areas. %0A  %0A And if you want to view that television station, you have to watch the %0A commercials.  You can't turn them off and still be viewing the %0A television station.  In other words, if you don't like what you see, %0A don't look.  There is no 'right' I can think of that you have to force %0A other people to conform to your idea of aesthetic behaviour.  What's %0A next, laws regulating how people must dress and look so as to appeal %0A to your fashion sense, since you have this 'right' of an aesthetic %0A view?  %0A  %0A > Pat writes %3A  %0A >George. %0A  %0A >	It's called a democracy.  The majority rules.  sorry. %0A >If ytou don't like it, I suggest you modify the constitution to include %0A >a constitutional right to Dark Skies.   The theory of government %0A >here is that the majority rules,  except in the nature of fundamental %0A >civil rights. %0A  %0A >I say %3A   %0A >	Any reasonably in-depth perusal of American history will show %0A >	you that many WASPs have continued the practices of prejudice, %0A >	discrimination, and violence against others of different %0A >	races, religions, and beliefs, despite the law. %0A  %0A Which has what to do with the topic of discussion? %0A  %0A >Pat says %3A  %0A >If you really are annoyed,   get some legislation %0A >to create a dark sky zone,  where in all light emissions are protected %0A >in the zone.  Kind of like the national radio quiet zone.  Did you %0A >know about that?  near teh Radio telescope  observatory in West virginia, %0A >they have a 90?????? mile EMCON zone.  Theoretically they can prevent %0A >you from running light AC motors, like air conditioners and Vacuums. %0A >In practice, they use it mostly to  control  large radio users. %0A  %0A >I say %3A  %0A >What I'm objecting to here is a floating billboard that, presumably, %0A >would move around in the sky.  I, for one, am against legislating %0A >at all.  I just wish that people had a bit of common courtesy, and %0A >would consider how their greed for money impacts the more ethereal and %0A >aesthetic values that make us human.  This includes the need for wild %0A >and unspoiled things, including the night sky. %0A  %0A Oh, I see.  You don't want any legislation that might impinge on you; %0A you just want everyone else on the planet to do what you want. %0A  %0A --  %0A "Insisting on perfect safety is for people who don't have the balls to live %0A  in the real world."   -- Mary Shafer, NASA Ames Dryden %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ %0A Fred.McCall %40 dseg.ti.com - I don't speak for others and they don't speak for me. %0A  
doc_5342 |@raw_text From %3A  eachus %40 spectre.mitre.org (Robert I. Eachus) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Can DES code be shipped to Canada? %0A In-Reply-To %3A  strnlght %40 netcom.com's message of Thu, 22 Apr 1993 20 %3A 55 %3A 04 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <EACHUS.93Apr23181117 %40 spectre.mitre.org> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 linus.mitre.org (News Service) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  spectre.mitre.org %0A Organization %3A  The Mitre Corp., Bedford, MA. %0A References %3A  <1993Apr22.125402.27561 %40 fripp.ri.cadre.com> <strnlghtC5wKrt.6JA %40 netcom.com> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 23 %3A 11 %3A 17 GMT %0A Lines %3A  40 %0A  %0A In article <strnlghtC5wKrt.6JA %40 netcom.com> strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A  %0A    > I believe it is illegal to send any cryptographic code out of the %0A    > country without an export license. (Others will correct me if %0A    > this is inaccurate.) %0A  %0A    Glad to!  You are correct, it is illegal to send cryptographic %0A code (and lots of other things) out of the country without a license. %0A HOWEVER, every US citizen has a general export license, allowing %0A export of lots of things, including constitutionally protected speech. %0A This has the effect that it is legal for US citizens to export some %0A things which it is illegal for a US corporation to export without %0A first obtaining a license. %0A  %0A    > Dunno if you'd get one for the particular code you have; the only %0A    > way to find out is to apply for a license. %0A  %0A    Nope, talk to a good lawyer in the area of export law.  But, in %0A general, the government has to have a very good national security case %0A to try prevent the export of anything you personally might wish to %0A publish.  (Yes, I worded that the way I did intentionally.  It is a %0A lot easier for the government to TRY to prevent the export of %0A information than to charge someone with a crime after the fact. %0A Espionage is probably the only exception.) %0A  %0A    > Note that you need to distinguish between what is legal to send %0A    > to Canada if YOU have such a license, and what is legal to send %0A    > if you don't. %0A  %0A     If you are a US citizen, you have a general license.  (I am not a %0A lawyer, so take some of this with a grain of salt.  However, I have %0A also had to swim through both ITAR and export regs in a few cases.) %0A  %0A -- %0A  %0A 					Robert I. Eachus %0A  %0A with Standard_Disclaimer; %0A use  Standard_Disclaimer; %0A function Message (Text %3A  in Clever_Ideas) return Better_Ideas is... %0A

Tens of thousands?  Do some arithmetic, please...  Skipjack %0A > >has 2^80 possible keys.  Let's assume a brute-force engine like that %0A > >hypothesized for DES %3A   1 microsecond per trial, 1 million chips.  That's %0A > >10^12 trials per second, or about 38,000 years for 2^80 trials.  Well, %0A > >maybe they can get chips running at one trial per nanosecond, and build %0A > >a machine with 10 million chips.  Sure -- only 3.8 years for each solution. %0A >  %0A > Normally I'd be the last to argue with Steve . . . but shouldn't that %0A > read "3.8 years for *all* solutions".  I mean, if we can imagine the %0A > machine that does 1 trial/nanosecond, we can imagine the storage medium %0A > that could index and archive it. %0A  %0A At the company I worked for previously, I received a file that was des encryped %0A and the person that had sent it, went on vaction.  Rather than wait two weeks %0A I set up a straight frontal attack with one key at a time.  It only took two(2) %0A days to crack the file.  No, I don't have any faith in DES. %0A  %0A A.G. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A A.G. Russell   Dept A06S  OLTP section of PALS Group   VM ID  SC39093 at AUSVM1 %0A Email  arussell %40 austin.ibm.com       Phone 512-838-7953        TieLine 678-7953 %0A These are my views, on anyone else they would look silly.
