doc_5366 |@raw_text From %3A  caronni %40 nessie.cs.id.ethz.ch (Germano Caronni) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  More technical details %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.162936.7517 %40 bernina.ethz.ch> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 bernina.ethz.ch (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, CH %0A References %3A  <1993Apr19.134346.2620 %40 ulysses.att.com> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 16 %3A 29 %3A 36 GMT %0A Lines %3A  107 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr19.134346.2620 %40 ulysses.att.com> smb %40 research.att.com (Steven Bellovin) writes %3A  %0A >Here are some corrections and additions to Hellman's note, courtesy of %0A >Dorothy Denning.  Again, this is reposted with permission. %0A > %0A >Two requests -- first, note the roles of S1 and S2.  It appears to me %0A >and others that anyone who knows those values can construct the unit %0A >key.  And the nature of the generation process for K1 and K2 is such %0A >that neither can be produced alone.  Thus, the scheme cannot be %0A >implemented such that one repository generates the first half-key, and %0A >another generates the second.  *That* is ominous. %0A > %0A >Second -- these postings are not revealed scripture, nor are they %0A >carefully-crafted spook postings.  Don't attempt to draw out hidden %0A >meanings (as opposed to, say, the official announcements of Clipper). %0A >Leave Denning out of this; given Hellman's record of opposition to DES, %0A >which goes back before some folks on this newsgroup knew how to read, I %0A >don't think you can impugn his integrity. %0A > %0A >Oh yeah -- the folks who invented Clipper aren't stupid.  If you think %0A >something doesn't make sense, it's almost certainly because you don't %0A >understand their goals. %0A > %0A  %0A This is an addition (posted with permission) to some tech. details of %0A cliper. They enligthen ??? the use of S1 and S2 for keygeneration. %0A ------------------------------------------- %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 93 08 %3A 51 %3A 57 EDT %0A From %3A  denning %40 cs.cosc.georgetown.edu (Dorothy Denning) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A   Clipper Chip %0A  %0A I just had another conversation with NSA to clarify some of the features %0A of Clipper.  Please feel free to distribute this and my other messages %0A on Clipper. %0A  %0A The name of the encryption algorithm is "Skipjack." %0A  %0A Martin Hellman had written %0A  %0A                 and the serial number of the unit added to produce a three part %0A                 message which will then be encrypted under the system key SK %0A                 producing %0A  %0A                      E{ E[M; K], E[K; UK], serial number;  SK} %0A  %0A To which I responded %3A  %0A  %0A         My understanding is that E[M; K] is not encrypted under SK (called the %0A         "family key") and that the decrypt key corresponding to SK is held by %0A         law enforcement.  Does anyone have first hand knowledge on this? %0A  %0A I was correct in that E[M; K] is not encrypted under SK.  However, Skipjack %0A being a single-key system, there is, of course, not a separate decrypt key %0A for the family key SK. %0A  %0A         The unit key, also called the "chip key," is generated from the %0A         serial number N as follows.  Let N1, N2, and N3 be 64 bit blocks %0A         derived from N, and let S1 and S2 be two 80-bit seeds used as keys. %0A         Compute the 64-bit block %0A  %0A                 R1 = E[D[E[N1; S1]; S2]; S1] %0A  %0A         (Note that this is like using the DES in triple encryption mode with %0A         two keys.)  Similarly compute blocks R2 and R3 starting with N2 and N3. %0A         (I'm unlear about whether the keys S1 and S2 change.  The fact that %0A         they're called seeds suggests they might.)  Then R1, R2, and R3 are %0A         concatenated together giving 192 bits.  The first 80 bits  form K1 and %0A         the next 80 bits form K2.  The remaining bits are discarded. %0A  %0A The seeds S1 and S2 do not change.   The whole process is performed on %0A a laptop computer, and S1 and S2 are supplied by two independent people %0A so that no one person knows both.  The same S1 and S2 are used during %0A an entire "programming session" to generate keys for a stream of serial %0A numbers.  Everything is discarded at the end (the computer could be %0A thrown out if desired). %0A  %0A The serial number is 30 bits and the values N1, N2, and N3 are formed %0A by padding the serial number with fixed 34-bit blocks (separate padding %0A for each value). %0A  %0A The resulting keys K1 and K2 are output onto separate floppy disks, paired %0A up with their serial number.  Each pair is stored in a separate file.  The %0A floppy disks are taken away by two separate people on behalf of the two %0A escrow agencies. %0A  %0A Dorothy Denning %0A denning %40 cs.georgetown.edu %0A  %0A -------------------------------------------------------- %0A I am sure more technical detail will be known when time goes by. %0A Please remark, that in posting this, I do not automatically agree %0A with it's contents and implications. So don't swamp my mailbox  %3A -) %0A  %0A I just think this is an valuable addition to the less than technical %0A discussion that is rising here. And, no, I don't mind if you call %0A S1 and S2 'backdoor', as I could imagine the key-generation process %0A working without these seeds and the dependency of K1,K2 from the %0A Serial-Number. %0A  %0A  %0A Friendly greetings, %0A  %0A 	Germano Caronni %0A --  %0A Instruments register only through things they're designed to register. %0A Space still contains infinite unknowns. %0A                                                               PGP-Key-ID %3A 341027 %0A Germano Caronni caronni %40 nessie.cs.id.ethz.ch   FD560CCF586F3DA747EA3C94DD01720F %0A  
doc_5368 |@raw_text From %3A  smythw %40 vccsouth23.its.rpi.edu (William Smythe) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Once tapped, your code is no good any more. %0A Message-ID %3A  <_tx5hqa %40 rpi.edu> %0A Sender %3A  SMYTHW %40 RPI>EDU (Bill Smythe) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  vccsouth23.its.rpi.edu %0A Organization %3A  Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY %0A References %3A  <1qpg8fINN982 %40 dns1.NMSU.Edu> <1993Apr18.150259.1748 %40 escom.com> <1qsip1INNnj2 %40 dns1.NMSU.Edu> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Date %3A  Mon, 19 Apr 1993 18 %3A 15 %3A 27 GMT %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A In article <1qsip1INNnj2 %40 dns1.NMSU.Edu> amolitor %40 nmsu.edu (Andrew Molitor) writes %3A  %0A >al %40 escom.COM (Al Donaldson) writes %3A  %0A >>amolitor %40 nmsu.edu (Andrew Molitor) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >	This appears to be generic calling upon the name of the anti-christ. %0A >Just for the hell of it, let's destroy this remark. Let us imagine that %0A >the executive branch actually could extract keys from the escrow houses %0A >without anyone knowing, or telling. Now what? Hammerl (hammerl %40 acsu.buffalo.edu) wrote %3A  %0A  %3A  In article <1993Apr17.062622.25380 %40 news.clarkson.edu> farenebt %40 logic.camp.clarkson.edu (Droopy) writes %3A  %0A  %0A  %3A  >In fact, the tradition has been passed down to their affiliate %0A  %3A  >in Adirondack. In Gm 6 of last yr's finals, an 8 legged creature was %0A  %3A  >hurled onto the frozen pond and landed right at the feet of ref %0A  %3A  >Lance Roberts. %0A  %0A  %3A  It may have been passed to Toronto, but I've even seen an octopus at %0A  %3A  the Aud -- last year's Bruins-Sabres game. It's called "unoriginality". %0A  %0A (no, i'm not bitter  %3A ) %0A  %0A     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ %0A     + Bri Farenell			farenebt %40 craft.camp.clarkson.edu   + %0A     + AHL, ECAC and Boston Bruins contact for rec.sport.hockey		   + %0A     + Adirondack Red Wings, Calder Cup Champs %3A  '81  '86  '89  '92	   + %0A     + Clarkson Hockey, ECAC Tournament Champs %3A  '66  '91  '93		   + %0A     + Glens Falls High Hockey, NY Division II State Champs %3A  '90  '91       + %0A     + AHL fans %3A  join the AHL mailing list %3A  ahl-news-request %40 andrew.cmu.edu + %0A     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ %0A

doc_5378 |@raw_text From %3A  lzahas %40 acs2.bu.edu (Lukas Zahas) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How do DI boxes work? %0A Message-ID %3A  <115727 %40 bu.edu> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 01 %3A 42 %3A 32 GMT %0A References %3A  <LANCER.93Apr15150228 %40 oconnor.WPI.EDU> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 bu.edu %0A Organization %3A  Boston University, Boston, MA, USA %0A Lines %3A  19 %0A  %0A In article <LANCER.93Apr15150228 %40 oconnor.WPI.EDU> lancer %40 oconnor.WPI.EDU (Stephe Lewis Foskett) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I'm doing sound for a couple of bands around here and we need Direct %0A >Input boxes for the keyboards.  These are the little boxes that take a %0A >line level out of the keyboard and transform it into low-Z for the run %0A >to the mixer.  Sadly they cost like $50 (or more) each and I'm going %0A >to need like 5 or 10 of them!  I looked inside one (belonging to %0A >another band) and it looks like just a transformer.  Does anyone have %0A >any plans for building them?   %0A > %0A $50 each!!  Don't bother trying to make one yourself, just shop around a %0A little.  I've found DOD brand DI boxes for as cheap as $20 each.  You can  %0A get higher end ones for more, but for PA use for bands, I wouldn't bother. %0A Making one yourself might work, but getting a sturdy enough enclosure might %0A be hard (they're made of heavy guage metal, since they're always on the floor, %0A being kicked around a lot). For any additional questions on this topic, you  %0A might want to post to rec.audio.pro %0A 						Lukas Zahas %0A 						lzahas %40 bu.edu %0A

Answer %3A  %0A > 1. Because you trust Apple; %0A > 2. Because if any such attempt, however sophicsticated, came out, it would %0A > destroy Apple's credibility forever. %0A >  %0A  %0A David, %0A  %0A    Neither (1) or (2) apply with the government, though. The feds, unlike %0A Apple, have repeatedly demonstrated that trust is an unsafe thread on which %0A to hang your freedom. Why?  Because unlike Apple in (2), the govt has no %0A credibility to lose. I'm serious about this. One can name just about any %0A agency -- the IRS, RTC, FCC, FAA, FBI, NSA, CIA -- and find numerous examples %0A of the public trust run roughshod over. Worse, one can rarely find in such  %0A examples any serious consequences to the offending agency. Even supposing %0A we could get a reign on trust somehow, there's always the matter of competence %0A in govt agencies. Can they even trust themselves? %0A  %0A   -mel %0A  %0A   P.S. I was amused when you mentioned the USDA as an example of an agency %0A capable of managing the an escrow. I'm a consultant to the USDA, and while those %0A *I* work with are wonderful <grin>, the agency itself is ranked in industry %0A publications such as Govt Computer News as one of the worst caretakers of %0A its computer resources. Recently, Prime Time Live did a long segment on %0A the USDA's computer troubles. They are making a concerted effort to change, %0A but intentions don't make a track record. %0A  %0A ________________________________________________________________________ %0A %7C Mel beckman                  %7C   Internet %3A  mbeckman %40 mbeckman.com     %7C %0A %7C Beckman Software Engineering %7C Compuserve %3A  75226,2257                %7C %0A %7C Ventura, CA 93003            %7C  Voice/fax %3A  805/647-1641 805/647-3125 %7C %0A %7C______________________________%7C_______________________________________%7C %0A  "You can observe a lot just by watching."  -Yogi Bera %0A

doc_5394 |@raw_text From %3A  neilson %40 pmin28.osf.org (Peter Neilson) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  solvent for duct-tape adhesive? %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr27.103158.13614 %40 osf.org> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 osf.org (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  Open Software Foundation %0A References %3A  <1993Apr27.004240.24401 %40 csi.jpl.nasa.gov> <1993Apr27.030226.16016 %40 uvm.edu> %0A Date %3A  Tue, 27 Apr 1993 10 %3A 31 %3A 58 GMT %0A Lines %3A  45 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr27.030226.16016 %40 uvm.edu> me170pjd %40 emba-news.uvm.edu.UUCP (Peter J Demko) writes %3A  %0A >From article <1993Apr27.004240.24401 %40 csi.jpl.nasa.gov>, by eldred %40 rrunner.jpl.nasa.gov (Dan Eldred) %3A  %0A >> In article <1rh9b0INN2r4 %40 snoopy.cis.ufl.edu> ruck %40 beach.cis.ufl.edu (John Ruckstuhl) writes %3A  %0A >>>I know this is a long shot, but does anyone know what solvent I should  %0A >>>use to clean duct-tape adhesive from carpet? %0A >>>Someone taped wires to the carpet, and now it is time to move out. %0A >>> %0A >> I don't know for sure that this will work, but you might try MEK (methyl %0A >> ethyl keytone?).  It worked getting the stickum left over from shelf paper, %0A >> and is available at paint stores.  Use a carbon gas mask and lots of %0A >> ventilation--this stuff really stinks! %0A >>  %0A >> 	- Dan %0A >>  %0A > %0A >For those who don't know, methyl ethyl ketone is more commonly known  %0A >as ACETONE and can be found as the major active ingredient in %0A >NAIL POLISH REMOVER.  YOUR WIFE'S PROBABLY GOT SOME HANGIN' AROUND.... %0A  %0A Oh dear, time for me to try to remember my chemistry.  Let's see if I %0A can find the formulae somewhere in the dim recesses of my mind. %0A <sounds of gears>  <fumes of overheated oil>  <unmistakable stench of %0A the Nasal Chromatograph>   Ha!  I knew there was a double bond!  Now %0A how shall I show that in ASCII?  %0A  %0A           MEK %3A                                  Acetone %3A  %0A  %0A           C - C - C - C                        C - C - C %0A               #                                    # %0A               O                                    O %0A  %0A The hydrogens are not shown, and # represents double bond.  MEK has a %0A methyl (CH3) on one side, and an ethyl (C2H5) on the other.  Acetone %0A has two methyls.  So acetone is not methyl ethyl ketone, but instead %0A is dimethyl ketone.  Both solvents have similar properties.  I think %0A that MEK may be a little less flammable but a lot worse to breathe. %0A It's a lot harder to buy MEK than it once was.  Use acetone. %0A  %0A Nail polish remover consists almost entirely of acetone.  If you buy %0A some for your workshop, get the very cheapest, because the more %0A expensive kind has oils and perfumes that you don't need. %0A --  %0A Nothing is so foolish that it has not been posted to some net newsgroup. %0A          >>> Peter Neilson --- neilson %40 osf.org <<< %0A Quote changed daily.  If you've seen this one before, burn your calendar. %0A

doc_5410 |@raw_text From %3A  camter28 %40 astro.ocis.temple.edu (Carter Ames) %0A Subject %3A  Lead ACid Batteries PART 2!!! %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr25.013013.13717 %40 cronkite.ocis.temple.edu> %0A Date %3A  25 Apr 93 01 %3A 30 %3A 13 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cronkite.ocis.temple.edu (NetWork News (readnews)) %0A Organization %3A  Temple University %0A Lines %3A  40 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  astro.ocis.temple.edu %0A X-Newsreader %3A  TIN [version 1.1 PL8] %0A  %0A  %0A    I thought the first thread was hilarious, so here goes another post. %0A  %0A Some more background information on what has happened to my poor batteries. %0A  %0A   One year, I left the batteries in the garage.  The garage is Unheated.   %0A They were left in their places that they needed to be.  One in the riding %0A lawnmower (what a lux) and one in each motorcycle.  The battery in the  %0A riding lawnmower was about 3-4 years old, and one of the cycle batteries  %0A was new, and one was around 5 years old.  Upon spring time, I discovered %0A that all of the batteries were dead, and needed to be recharged.  They all %0A worked properly, except for the older ones, and they had to be replaced  %0A about halfway through the summer.  (they had originally been stored %0A in the garage, and I think I remember my dad charging them in spring) %0A   Last year, I decided to bring them in to the basement, which has two parts. %0A one is dirt and brick, and the other is concrete.  I brought in all three, and %0A discovered in the spring, (about 15 days ago) that not only were the batteries %0A dead, but when I put the charger on them, the charger said "HMMMMMMMM" and  %0A the amp-meter read around 1,000,000,000  (In other words, it was pinned) %0A the internal circut tripped, and I went on to the other batteries.  They %0A were the same.   %0A    Realizing that we still had 2 GIGANTIC sailboat batteries, also lead %0A acid, I decided to put the charger on them.  (these had been sitting for around 1 and a half years, on the brick and dirt part) and noticed that they only %0A needed a small charge, around 2 hours or so on trickle.  I tested them %0A by using them at the local gas station for giving jump starts, and they %0A worked fine for around 25 of 'em.  %0A   This leads me to believe one of several things. %0A      1) I bought really #$%tty batteries last year. (sorta true) %0A      2) the concrete has something to do with the discharge of the %0A         batteries. %0A      3) There was enough moisture to short out the terminals in the  %0A           room where the concrete is,  %0A      4) The dirt room was able to absorb the moisture in the air %0A          better than concrete. %0A  %0A (BTW, I can almost waterski in the dirt room)   %0A  %0A    Any other ideas? %0A     *could be the aliens, anything is possible.* %0A   %0A

doc_5424 |@raw_text From %3A  lbrintle %40 news.weeg.uiowa.edu (Lee Brintle) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Re-inventing Crypto Policy?  An EFF Statement %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr16.211508.17011 %40 news.weeg.uiowa.edu> %0A Summary %3A  40-bit key-half is way too small %0A Organization %3A  Project Panda, Inc. %0A References %3A  <1993Apr16.204207.24564 %40 eff.org> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 16 Apr 1993 21 %3A 15 %3A 08 GMT %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr16.204207.24564 %40 eff.org> Danny Weitzner <djw %40 eff.org>  %0A writes %3A  %0A >The 80-bit key will be divided between two escrow agents, each of whom %0A >hold 40-bits of each key.  %0A  %0A Presumably, the key split is so that no one group controls the privacy %0A of the key, and that it would be infeasible to illicitly gain access from %0A both agents. %0A  %0A However, if one agent wishes to break the crypto without the cooperation %0A of the other agent, a 40-bit key is not going to stand in the way of a %0A brute force attack.  If an agency (for example, the NSA) were to hold one %0A of the two key-halves, then I don't imagine they really need the other half of %0A the key to start listening in. %0A  %0A Or was that the point?   <grin> %0A  %0A  %0A (This is not to imply, at all, that I like the idea of the rest of the %0A system.) %0A --  %0A Lee Brintle                    %7C ``And so, I leave you with this final word %3A  %0A Director, Project Panda        %7C     twang.'' %0A

doc_5426 |@raw_text From %3A  richmond %40 spiff.Princeton.EDU (Stupendous Man) %0A Subject %3A  Interstellar T _is_ 3-4K; notes on Pluto/Charon talk and Pluto Mission %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr28.145708.17551 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Originator %3A  news %40 nimaster %0A Keywords %3A  I goofed %0A Sender %3A  news %40 Princeton.EDU (USENET News System) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  spiff.princeton.edu %0A Organization %3A  Princeton University %0A Date %3A  Wed, 28 Apr 1993 14 %3A 57 %3A 08 GMT %0A Lines %3A  73 %0A  %0A    (sci.space readers can skip the first paragraph) %0A  %0A   Yesterday, in response to Henry Spencer's question about the  %0A temperature of a blackbody in interstellar space, I said "Dust grains %0A acts as blackbodies, and they're at 40-150 K."  Well, I was dead %0A wrong.  Our local interstellar dust expert, Bruce Draine, has %0A informed me that dust grains _aren't_ good radiators in the far IR, %0A which is why they are so warm; actually, the ambient radiation field %0A from distant stars can bring a true blackbody to only 3 or 4 Kelvin. %0A Sorry, Henry, and anyone else I misled.  Obviously, time for me to %0A take another ISM class  %3A -( %0A  %0A   In other news, Alan Stern of the Southwest Research Institute gave %0A a talk on the Pluto-Charon binary system yesterday.  He gave a brief %0A overview of the currently-accepted system parameters (volume ratio of %0A about 8 %3A 1, mass ratio about 15 %3A 1 or so, plus lots more...) and then %0A gave his thoughts on the formation of Pluto-Charon.  His idea is  %0A that there were lots and lots of small planetesimals in the outer %0A solar system, with masses distributed as a power law of some kind; %0A over time, the planetesimals accreted into larger bodies.  Most got %0A scattered out of the solar system by close encounters with Jupiter %0A and Saturn, but many accreted into the gas giants, especially %0A Uranus and Neptune.  A large planetesimal was captured by Neptune - %0A we call it Triton [captured how?  Perhaps by a collision with a smaller, %0A already-existing Neptunian moon, perhaps by a very close passage through %0A Neptune's atmosphere - mondo aerobraking!]. %0A  %0A   He notes that the two recently discovered "Kuiper Belt" objects, %0A 1992 QB1 and 1993 FW, plus Chiron and Pholus, are all about the same  %0A mass, and he identifies this group as one-accretion-down from the %0A larger bodies of Triton and Pluto/Charon.  Pluto/Charon, he thinks, %0A formed when an impacting body hit proto-Pluto, knocking some material %0A into a ring around Pluto which later accreted in Charon; similar to %0A ideas about the formation of Earth's moon.  There is good evidence %0A from spectra that the surfaces of Pluto and Charon are very different %0A (Pluto has methane frost, Charon doesn't), which can be used as evidence %0A for the impact theory. %0A  %0A   He believes that there may be around 1000 Pluto-to-Chiron-sized objects %0A remaining in a relatively stable dynamical zone just outside Neptune's  %0A orbit, beyond 35 AU or so.  1992 QB1 and 1993 FW are the first members %0A of this population to be found, in his model.  Note that such bodies %0A will be very dark, since if their surfaces are covered with methane  %0A frost, it will have photolyzed into very dark, long-chain hydrocarbons %0A by now.  The reason that Pluto has such a high albedo (around 0.5, I think) %0A is that its surface warms up JUST enough around perihelion to sublimate, %0A and when the atmosphere freezes out again, thirty years later, it forms %0A bright, new frost.  So any bodies much farther away than 30 AU are going %0A to be very hard to see. %0A  %0A   I hope I haven't made any errors in the transcription; if you see %0A a howling mistake, it's undoubtedly mine, not his. %0A  %0A   By the way, he's one of the top guns behind the Pluto Fast Flyby %0A mission (I think), and said that the current plans are to use a %0A Titan 4 to send the probe on "just about a rectilinear trajectory" %0A to Pluto (we were speaking loosely at the time...).  He'd like %0A to use a Proton, which gives a slightly smaller velocity but costs %0A MUCH less.  His figures %3A  $500 Million for 2 Titan 4 launches (there %0A will be two separate probes, launched separately), or $120 Million %0A for 2 Proton launches.  He told a story about how the Soviets originally %0A offered to sell Proton launches for $30 Million each, but were forced %0A to increase their prices in the US in order to be allowed in the %0A marketplace. %0A  %0A   I'm just telling you what he said. %0A  %0A                           Michael %0A  %0A --  %0A -----                                                    Michael Richmond %0A "This is the heart that broke my finger."    richmond %40 astro.princeton.edu %0A  %0A  
doc_5428 |@raw_text From %3A  tuinstra %40 signal.ece.clarkson.edu.soe (Dwight Tuinstra) %0A Subject %3A  Clipper will corrupt cops (was WH proposal from Police point of view) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr21.041033.16550 %40 news.clarkson.edu> %0A Date %3A  21 Apr 93 04 %3A 10 %3A 33 GMT %0A References %3A  <bontchev.735230663 %40 fbihh> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 news.clarkson.edu %0A Reply-To %3A  tuinstra %40 signal.ece.clarkson.edu.soe %0A Organization %3A  Sun Microsystems, Inc. %0A Lines %3A  93 %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  signal.ece.clarkson.edu %0A  %0A In article 735230663 %40 fbihh, bontchev %40 fbihh.informatik.uni-hamburg.de (Vesselin Bontchev) writes %3A  %0A >strnlght %40 netcom.com (David Sternlight) writes %3A  %0A > %0A >> dwight tuinstra posts a very interesting message in which he comments on the %0A >> effects of the Clipper chip on state and local police. Actually, reading %0A >> between the lines, it could be a very good thing for civil liberties in one %0A >> respect, since it will at least prevent cowboy cops and cowboy state and %0A >> local agancies from reading your traffic if they tap it illegally. %0A > %0A >Instead of reading between the lines, try to think a little bit. OK, %0A >if that's way too difficult to you, here are some hints. %0A > %0A >Indeed, the new proposal imposes some additional burocratic burden on %0A >the local police, if they badly want to tape the magic cookie recipie %0A >that your mom is telling you on the phone. So, guess what they will %0A >do? Propose that the new technology is removed? Or implement some %0A >"facilitations"? Of course, you won't want to wait until they get the %0A >approval from two different agencies to decrypt the conversation %0A >between two child molesters, because meanwhile those two child %0A >molesters might be conspiring about molesting your child, right? So, %0A >there should be some way for them to get access to those keys %0A >-quickly-, right? Like, they could have a copy of the database, and %0A >worry about a warrant later... %0A  %0A I perhaps should have been clearer and more concise in my post, but that's %0A what I get from posting at 1 am... %0A  %0A The central point I made is that local/state police agencies attempting to %0A play by the rules and get warrants, legit escrowed keys, etc., may find %0A themselves at the mercy of bureaucratic inertia and agency infighting %0A at the federal level.   %0A  %0A I disagree that this would assist civil liberties by hobbling the cowboy %0A cops.  It would be a strong incentive, as Vesselin points out, for more %0A police agencies to "go rogue" and try to get keys through more efficient %0A (but less Constitutional) means.  Notice what the release said %3A  %0A  %0A    Q %3A    Suppose a law enforcement agency is conducting a wiretap on %0A         a drug smuggling ring and intercepts a conversation %0A         encrypted using the device.  What would they have to do to %0A         decipher the message? %0A  %0A    A %3A    They would have to obtain legal authorization, normally a %0A                                                        ^^^^^^^^^^ %0A         court order, to do the wiretap in the first place. %0A         ^^^^^^^^^^^ %0A  %0A The clear implication is that there are "legal" authorizations other %0A than a court order.  Just how leaky are these?  (And who  %0A knows what's in those 7 pages that authorized the NSA?).  There %0A may well arise a black market of sorts _within_ police agencies, in which %0A keys are traded.  Furthermore, the police will be in an excellent %0A position to carry out this kind of thing without being caught.  They %0A already have a communication infrastructure with secure portions.  There %0A are a few laws that I know of, that limit citizens' rights to access %0A police communications (or use the information they get).  It may be %0A very difficult to prove police misuse -- the fact that you have such %0A evidence may itself be evidence that YOU have broken some other law. %0A  %0A Throw in private detectives, who have even fewer policy/constitutional %0A restrictions.  Also consider mercenaries who've "retired" from intelligence %0A agencies.  William Gibson must be loving it.  Great story material. %0A  %0A Don't think it'll happen?   %0A  %0A Well, consider e.g. the Michigan State Police, generally a very professional %0A organization, which for years kept "Red Files" on thousands of suspected  %0A commies, knowing full well it was not consititutional.  The standards %0A of evidence were just about zero %3A  people were in the file because they %0A happened to park near a place where, say, a US-China People's Friendship %0A rally was happening -- the police went around writing down license %0A plate numbers.  If you happened to be visiting a friend who lived near the  %0A meeting place, well, the state police wound up filing you as a subversive. %0A (They were eventually found out and a court ruled against carrying on any %0A more such nonsense.  I believe thay may have had to destroy the tapes %0A as well.) %0A  %0A Even with well-meaning cops (and I'm sure there are many), there will  %0A be strong pressure to bend the constitutional safeguards.  We don't need %0A to assume corrupt or unbalanced officers -- it will all be in the interest  %0A of enforcing sensible laws, saving lives, and protecting property.   %0A Compromises will be made by well-meaning officers, facing what (to them)  %0A will be a moral dilemma. %0A  %0A Clipper will make criminals out of cops.  Do we want to do this to our %0A police forces? %0A  %0A +========================================================================+ %0A %7C  dwight tuinstra             best %3A   tuinstra %40 sandman.ece.clarkson.edu  %7C %0A %7C                         tolerable %3A   tuinstrd %40 craft.camp.clarkson.edu   %7C %0A %7C                                                                        %7C %0A %7C        "Homo sapiens %3A  planetary cancer??  ...  News at six"            %7C %0A +========================================================================+ %0A

Effectively obsolete; use 74F. %0A #  %0A # 74LS	Combination of 74L and 74S, for speed comparable to 74 with lower %0A # 	power consumption.  Best all-round TTL now, widest variety of %0A # 	devices. %0A #  %0A # 74F	Fast as blazes, power not too bad.  The clear choice for high %0A # 	speed in TTL.  Availability and prices generally good. %0A  %0A I hate to disagree w/ a fellow as smart as Henry, but... %0A  %0A A few years back, I worked on a project using lots of high-speed %0A stuff.  (My part was slow & parallel, whew.) The mild-mannered designer %0A working on the fast (serial) stuff cussed & swore at 74F all the time. %0A It was the Harry Reams of TTL. One ultra-tiny power line glitch, one %0A hickup, one eyeblink across the board, and bang - the F had %0A toggled/counted/whatevered.  At times he swore it would count even %0A without any 5 volt supply ;-} You can guess what the "F" stood for.... %0A  %0A They would do anything to push S or work around it to avoid using F. I %0A don't think I'd consider using F to replace S unless the consequences %0A were *fully* understood....... %0A -- %0A A host is a host from coast to coast..wb8foz %40 skybridge.scl.cwru.edu %0A & no one will talk to a host that's close............(301) 56-LINUX %0A Unless the host (that isn't close).........................pob 1433 %0A is busy, hung or dead....................................20915-1433 %0A

doc_5467 |@raw_text From %3A  tomb %40 hplsla.hp.com (Tom Bruhns) %0A Date %3A  Thu, 15 Apr 1993 22 %3A 10 %3A 39 GMT %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Do Analog Systems Need Ground Planes? %0A Message-ID %3A  <5170287 %40 hplsla.hp.com> %0A Organization %3A  HP Lake Stevens, WA %0A References %3A  <1993Apr14.035931.28268 %40 nuscc.nus.sg> %0A Lines %3A  25 %0A  %0A engp2254 %40 nusunix1.nus.sg (SOH KAM YUNG) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >I understand the need for a ground plane in a digital system. However, I %0A >would like to know if such a ground plane is also necessary in an analog %0A >system. %0A > %0A >(Note %3A  this ground plane will not be connected, except at one point, to %0A >the signal ground). %0A > %0A >I keep getting conflicting answers over this. Does having a ground plane %0A >in an analog system help reduce noise also? My system only deals with %0A >low frequency signals (up to 100Hz only!!!). %0A  %0A Well, one reason for getting conflicting answers is that it depends on %0A what you want the ground plane to do.  A continuous conductor is a good  %0A electrostatic shield.  Do you have signals on your board that need %0A shielding rom other things?  This shielding won't do much good for magnetic %0A fields, unless you make it continuous around the circuit to be shielded, %0A like a Faraday cage. %0A  %0A The flip side of the coin %3A   if you are working with (very) high impedances, %0A you could end up with capacitances to the gound plane that cause problems. %0A You aren't likely to encounter this at 100Hz, but at 20kHz, it can be a %0A real problem (one that bit me once). %0A  %0A

doc_5476 |@raw_text From %3A  maynard %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca (Roger Maynard) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  More Hart trophy stuff.... %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.213835.9187 %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca> %0A Organization %3A  Dept. of Computer Science, Laurentian University, Sudbury, ON %0A References %3A  <21APR93.00014211.0076 %40 UNBVM1.CSD.UNB.CA> <1r4bkvINN5nm %40 abyss.West.Sun.COM> <1993Apr24.010132.3405 %40 mtroyal.ab.ca> <1993Apr26.162805.1534 %40 adobe.com> %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 21 %3A 38 %3A 35 GMT %0A Lines %3A  31 %0A  %0A In <1993Apr26.162805.1534 %40 adobe.com> snichols %40 adobe.com (Sherri Nichols) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >In article <1993Apr24.010132.3405 %40 mtroyal.ab.ca> caldwell8102 %40 mtroyal.ab.ca writes %3A  %0A >>The Hart trophy goes to the player most valuable to his team, not to the best %0A >>player in the league. So your above arguement is really worthless.  %0A  %0A >Personally, I always thought that "most valuable to his team" was silly. %0A >Why should the best player in the league be penalized because he plays on a %0A >team with other good players?  Why should a lesser player be picked solely %0A >because he's the best player on a weak team?   Wouldn't the weaker team be %0A >helped even more by the best player in the league?  Doesn't the presence of %0A >the best player in the league make the other players on the team look %0A >better, too? %0A  %0A The Hart Trophy was orginally awarded in a time where people did not think %0A in terms of who was the "best" player, rather in terms of who was the most %0A valuable to the team.  And "valuable to his team" was not, and should not %0A be, considered synonymous with "best".  We are talking about a time when %0A honour and attitude, not measurable skills, were the most important assets %0A a player brought to his team, his league and his sport.  This was before %0A the onslaught of professionalism which has clearly denigrated what was  %0A formerly the foremost peacetime pursuit of glory. %0A  %0A The Hart Trophy is not a prize.  It is an honour. %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A  %0A cordially, as always,                      maynard %40 ramsey.cs.laurentian.ca  %0A                                            "So many morons... %0A rm                                                 ...and so little time."  %0A

doc_5488 |@raw_text From %3A  dagibbs %40 quantum.qnx.com (David Gibbs) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering sans Hands %0A Message-ID %3A  <gbnvgw %40 quantum.qnx.com> %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 93 22 %3A 01 %3A 10 GMT %0A Organization %3A  QNX Software Systems, Ltd. %0A References %3A  <Clarke.6.735328328 %40 bdrc.bd.com> <1993Apr20.203344.8417 %40 cs.cornell.edu> %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.203344.8417 %40 cs.cornell.edu> karr %40 cs.cornell.edu (David Karr) writes %3A  %0A >In article <Clarke.6.735328328 %40 bdrc.bd.com> Clarke %40 bdrc.bd.com (Richard Clarke) writes %3A  %0A >>So how do I steer when my hands aren't on the bars? (Open Budweiser in left  %0A >>hand, Camel cigarette in the right, no feet allowed.)  %0A > %0A >>If I lean, and the  %0A >>bike turns, am I countersteering? %0A > %0A >No, the bars would turn only *toward* the direction of turn in %0A >no-hands steering. %0A  %0A Just in case the original poster was looking for a serious answer, %0A I'll supply one. %0A  %0A Yes, even when steering no hands you do something quite similar %0A to countersteering.  Basically to turn left, you to a quick wiggle %0A of the bike to the right first, causing a counteracting lean to %0A occur to the left.  It is a lot more difficult to do on a motorcycle %0A than a bicycle though, because of the extra weight.  (Ok, so my %0A motorcycle is heavy.  Maybe yous isn't.) %0A  %0A -David %0A

doc_5506 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Space FAQ 02/15 - Network Resources %0A Message-ID %3A  <net_733694066 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A From %3A  leech %40 cs.unc.edu (Jon Leech) %0A Date %3A  1 Apr 93 19 %3A 54 %3A 32 GMT %0A Followup-To %3A  poster %0A Expires %3A  6 May 1993 19 %3A 54 %3A 26 GMT %0A References %3A  <diffs_733693816 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A Organization %3A  University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill %0A Keywords %3A  Frequently Asked Questions %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.Edu %0A Supersedes %3A  <net_730956391 %40 cs.unc.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  mahler.cs.unc.edu %0A Lines %3A  241 %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  space/net %0A Last-modified %3A  $Date %3A  93/04/01 14 %3A 39 %3A 15 $ %0A  %0A NETWORK RESOURCES %0A  %0A OVERVIEW %0A  %0A     You may be reading this document on any one of an amazing variety of %0A     computers, so much of the material below may not apply to you. In %0A     general, however, systems connected to 'the net' fall in one of three %0A     categories %3A  Internet, Usenet, or BITNET. Electronic mail may be sent %0A     between these networks, and other resources available on one of these %0A     networks are sometimes accessible from other networks by email sent to %0A     special 'servers'. %0A  %0A     The space and astronomy discussion groups actually are composed of %0A     several mechanisms with (mostly) transparent connections between them. %0A  %0A     One mechanism is the mailing list, in which mail is sent to a central %0A     distribution point which relays it to all recipients of the list. In %0A     addition to the general lists for space (called SPACE Digest for %0A     Internet users, and SPACE on BITNET), there are a number of more %0A     specialized mailing lists described below. %0A  %0A     A second mechanism is Usenet 'netnews'. This is somewhat like a bulletin %0A     board operating on each system which is a part of the net. Netnews %0A     separates contributions into hundreds of different categories based on a %0A     'group name'. The groups dealing most closely with space topics are %0A     called 'sci.space.news', 'sci.space', 'sci.space.shuttle', 'sci.astro', %0A     and 'talk.politics.space'. Contributors 'post' submissions (called %0A     'articles' in netnews terminology) on their local machine, which sends %0A     it to other nearby machines. Similarly, articles sent from nearby %0A     machines are stored locally and may be forwarded to other systems, so %0A     that an article is posted locally and eventually reaches all the Usenet %0A     sites interested in receiving the news group to which the article was %0A     posted. %0A  %0A     Gateway machines redirect the Usenet sci.space group into Internet and %0A     BITNET mailing lists and vice versa; the other Usenet groups are not %0A     accessible as mailing lists. If you can receive netnews, its more %0A     flexible interface and access to a wider range of material usually make %0A     it the preferred option. %0A  %0A MAILING LISTS %0A  %0A     SPACE Digest is the main Internet list, and is now being run by the %0A     International Space University (in only its second change of management %0A     in over a decade). Email space-request %40 isu.isunet.edu (message body %0A     should be in the format 'subscribe space John Public') to join. Note %0A     that the moderated SPACE Magazine list is defunct at present for lack of %0A     a moderator. Old copies of SPACE Digest since its inception in 1981 are %0A     available by anonymous FTP. Retrieve %0A 	julius.cs.qub.ac.uk %3A pub/SpaceDigestArchive/README %0A     for further details. %0A  %0A     Elements is a moderated list for fast distribution of Space Shuttle %0A     Keplerian Elements before and during Shuttle flights. NASA two line %0A     elements are sent out on the list from Dr. Kelso, JSC, and other sources %0A     as they are released. Email to elements-request %40 telesoft.com to join. %0A  %0A     GPS Digest is a moderated list for discussion of the Global Positioning %0A     System and other satellite navigation positioning systems. Email to %0A     gps-request %40 esseye.si.com to join. %0A  %0A     Space-investors is a list for information relevant to investing in %0A     space-related companies. Email Vincent Cate (vac %40 cs.cmu.edu) to join. %0A  %0A     Space-tech is a list for more technical discussion of space topics; %0A     discussion has included esoteric propulsion technologies, asteroid %0A     capture, starflight, orbital debris removal, etc. Email to %0A     space-tech-request %40 cs.cmu.edu to join. Archives of old digests and %0A     selected excerpts are available by anonymous FTP from %0A     gs80.sp.cs.cmu.edu (128.2.205.90) in /usr/anon/public/space-tech, %0A     or by email to space-tech-request if you don't have FTP access. %0A  %0A     SEDS-L is a BITNET list for members of Students for the Exploration and %0A     Development of Space and other interested parties. Email %0A     LISTSERV %40 TAMVM1.BITNET with a message saying "SUBSCRIBE SEDS-L your %0A     name". Email saying "INDEX SEDS-L" to list the archive contents. %0A  %0A     SEDSNEWS is a BITNET list for news items, press releases, shuttle status %0A     reports, and the like. This duplicates material which is also found in %0A     Space Digest, sci.space, sci.space.shuttle, and sci.astro. Email %0A     LISTSERV %40 TAMVM1.BITNET saying "SUBSCRIBE SEDSNEWS your name" to join. %0A     Email saying "INDEX SEDSNEWS" to list the archive contents. %0A  %0A     Ron Baalke (baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) runs a mailing list which %0A     carries the contents of the sci.space.news Usenet group. Email him %0A     to join the list. %0A  %0A     As a general note, please mail to the *request* address to get off a %0A     mailing list. SPACE Digest, for example, relays many inappropriate %0A     'please remove me from this list' messages which are sent to the list %0A     address rather than the request address. %0A  %0A PERIODICALLY UPDATED INFORMATION %0A  %0A     In addition to this FAQ list, a broad variety of topical information is %0A     posted to the net (unless otherwise noted, in the new group %0A     sci.space.news created for this purpose). Please remember that the %0A     individuals posting this information are performing a service for all %0A     net readers, and don't take up their time with frivolous requests. %0A  %0A     ACRONYMS %0A 	Garrett Wollman (wollman %40 UVM.EDU) posts an acronym list around the %0A 	first of each month. %0A  %0A     ASTRO-FTP LIST %0A 	Veikko Makela (veikko.makela %40 helsinki.fi) posts a monthly list of %0A 	anonymous FTP servers containing astronomy and space related %0A 	material to sci.space and sci.astro. %0A  %0A     AVIATION WEEK %0A 	Henry Spencer (henry %40 zoo.toronto.edu) posts summaries of %0A 	space-related stories in the weekly _Aviation Week and Space %0A 	Technology_. %0A  %0A     BUYING TELESCOPES %0A 	Ronnie Kon (ronnie %40 cisco.com) posts a guide to buying telescopes to %0A 	sci.astro. %0A  %0A     ELECTRONIC JOURNAL OF THE ASA %0A 	Don Barry (don %40 chara.gsu.edu) posts the monthly Electronic Journal %0A 	of the Astronomical Society of the Atlantic to sci.astro. %0A  %0A     FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL %0A 	Swaraj Jeyasingh (sjeyasin %40 axion.bt.co.uk) posts summaries of %0A 	space-related news from _Flight International_. This focuses more on %0A 	non-US space activities than Aviation Week. %0A  %0A     LARGE ASTRONOMICAL PROJECTS %0A 	Robert Bunge (rbunge %40 access.digex.com) posts a list describing many %0A 	"Large Telescope Projects Either Being Considered or in the Works" %0A 	to sci.astro. %0A  %0A     NASA HEADLINE NEWS & SHUTTLE REPORTS %0A 	Peter Yee (yee %40 ames.arc.nasa.gov) posts a variety of NASA material, %0A 	including NASA Headline News (with the schedule for NASA SELECT), %0A 	shuttle payload briefings and flight manifests, and KSC shuttle %0A 	status reports. For Usenet users, much of this material appears in %0A 	the group sci.space.shuttle. %0A  %0A     NASA UPDATES %0A 	Ron Baalke (baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) posts frequent updates from %0A 	JPL, Ames, and other centers on the Ulysses, Gailileo, Pioneer, %0A 	Magellan, Landsat, and other missions. %0A  %0A     ORBITAL ELEMENT SETS %0A 	TS Kelso (tkelso %40 blackbird.afit.af.mil) posts orbital elements from %0A 	NASA Prediction Bulletins. %0A  %0A 	Mike Rose (mrose %40 stsci.edu) posts orbital elements for the Hubble %0A 	Space Telescope to sci.astro. %0A  %0A 	Jost Jahn (j.jahn %40 abbs.hanse.de) posts ephemerides for asteroids, %0A 	comets, conjunctions, and encounters to sci.astro. %0A  %0A     SATELLITE LAUNCHES %0A 	Richard Langley (lang %40 unb.ca) posts SPACEWARN Bulletin, which %0A 	describes recent launch/orbital decay information and satellites %0A 	which are useful for scientific activities. Recent bulletins are %0A 	available by anonymous FTP from nssdca.gsfc.nasa.gov in %0A 	ANON_DIR %3A [000000.ACTIVE.SPX]. %0A  %0A     SHUTTLE MANIFEST %0A 	Ken Hollis (gandalf %40 pro-electric.cts.com) posts a compressed version %0A 	of the Space Shuttle launch manifest to sci.space.shuttle. This %0A 	includes dates, times, payloads, and information on how to see %0A 	launches and landings. %0A  %0A     SOLAR ACTIVITY %0A 	Cary Oler (oler %40 hg.uleth.ca) posts Solar Terrestrial reports %0A 	(describing solar activity and its effect on the Earth) to %0A 	sci.space. The report is issued in part from data released by the %0A 	Space Enviroment Services Center, Boulder Colorado. The intro %0A 	document needed to understand these reports is available by %0A 	anonymous FTP from solar.stanford.edu (36.10.0.4) in %0A 	pub/understanding_solar_terrestrial_reports. nic.funet.fi %0A 	(128.214.6.100) also has this document in %0A 	/pub/misc/rec.radio.shortwave/solarreports and is an archive site %0A 	for the reports (please note this site is in Europe, and the %0A 	connection to the US is only 56KB). A new primary archive site, %0A 	xi.uleth.ca (142.66.3.29), has recently been established and will be %0A 	actively supported. %0A  %0A     SOVIET SPACE ACTIVITIES %0A 	Glenn Chapman (glennc %40 cs.sfu.ca) posts summaries of Soviet space %0A 	activities. %0A  %0A     SPACE ACTIVIST NEWSLETTER %0A 	Allen Sherzer (aws %40 iti.org) posts a newsletter, "One Small Step for %0A 	a Space Activist," to talk.politics.space. It describes current %0A 	legislative activity affecting NASA and commercial space activities. %0A  %0A     SPACE EVENTS CALENDAR %0A 	Ron Baalke (baalke %40 kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov) posts a calendar including %0A 	anniversaries, conferences, launch dates, meteor showers and %0A 	eclipses, and other space-related events. %0A  %0A     SPACE NEWS %0A 	John Magliacane (kd2bd %40 ka2qhd.UUCP) posts "SpaceNews" (covering %0A 	AMSATs, NOAA and other weather satellites, and other ham %0A 	information) to rec.radio.amateur.misc and sci.space. %0A  %0A     SPACE REPORT %0A 	Jonathan McDowell (mcdowell %40 cfa.harvard.edu) posts "Jonathan's Space %0A 	Report" covering launches, landings, reentries, status reports, %0A 	satellite activities, etc. %0A  %0A     TOWARD 2001 %0A 	Bev Freed (freed %40 nss.fidonet.org) posts "Toward 2001", a weekly %0A 	global news summary reprinted from _Space Calendar_ magazine. %0A  %0A  %0A WARNING ABOUT NON-PUBLIC NETWORKS %0A  %0A     (Included at the suggestion of Eugene Miya, who wrote the item) %0A  %0A     NASA has an internal system of unclassified electronic mail and bulletin %0A     boards. This system is not open for public use. Specifically, NASA %0A     personnel and procurement operations are regarded with some sensitivity. %0A     Contractors must renegotiate their contracts. The Fair and Open %0A     Procurement Act does not look kindly to those having inside information. %0A     Contractors and outsiders caught using this type of information can %0A     expect severe penalities. Unauthorized access attempts may subject you %0A     to a fine and/or imprisonment in accordance with Title 18, USC, Section %0A     1030. If in fact you should should learn of unauthorized access, contact %0A     NASA personnel. %0A  %0A     Claims have been made on this news group about fraud and waste. None %0A     have ever been substantiated to any significant degree. Readers %0A     detecting Fraud, Waste, Abuse, or Mismanagement should contact the NASA %0A     Inspector General (24-hours) at 800-424-9183 (can be anonymous) or write %0A  %0A 	NASA %0A 	Inspector General %0A 	P.O. Box 23089 %0A 	L'enfant Plaza Station %0A 	Washington DC 20024 %0A  %0A NEXT %3A  FAQ #3/15 - Online (and some offline) sources of images, data, etc. %0A  
doc_5512 |@raw_text From %3A  mmm %40 cup.portal.com (Mark Robert Thorson) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Building a UV flashlight %0A Message-ID %3A  <80081 %40 cup.portal.com> %0A Date %3A  23 Apr 93 01 %3A 07 %3A 39 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  cup.80081 %0A References %3A  <C5r6Lz.n25 %40 panix.com> %0A Organization %3A  The Portal System (TM) %0A Lines %3A  7 %0A  %0A The simplest and cheapest soft UV bulb is an AR-1 argon bulb (or other argon %0A bulb).  It works like a neon bulb except it glows purple.  It will cause %0A stuff to fluoresce.  It requires very little power, just a battery, an %0A oscillator, and a step-up transformer to about 100 volts. %0A  %0A Electronic Goldmine (602) 451-7454 has several UV lamps, both as pre-built %0A units and kits.  Ask for their catalog. %0A

doc_5555 |@raw_text From %3A  mvanheyn %40 cs.indiana.edu (Marc VanHeyningen) %0A Subject %3A  RIPEM Frequently Asked Questions %0A Message-ID %3A  <C4qoA0.CA6 %40 usenet.ucs.indiana.edu> %0A Date %3A  31 Mar 93 05 %3A 51 %3A 36 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  usenet.C4qoA0.CA6 %0A Expires %3A  Thu, 20 May 1993 00 %3A 00 %3A 00 GMT %0A Sender %3A  news %40 usenet.ucs.indiana.edu (USENET News System) %0A Followup-To %3A  alt.security.ripem %0A Organization %3A  Computer Science, Indiana University %0A Lines %3A  360 %0A Approved %3A  news-answers-request %40 MIT.EDU %0A Content-Type %3A  text/x-usenet-FAQ; version=1.0; title="RIPEM FAQ" %0A Originator %3A  mvanheyn %40 silver.ucs.indiana.edu %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  silver.ucs.indiana.edu %0A Mime-Version %3A  1.0 %0A  %0A Archive-name %3A  ripem/faq %0A Last-update %3A  31 Mar 93 22 %3A 00 %3A 00 -0500 %0A  %0A ABOUT THIS POSTING %0A ------------------ %0A This is a listing of likely questions and information about RIPEM, a %0A program for public key mail encryption.  It (this FAQ, not RIPEM) was %0A written and will be maintained by Marc VanHeyningen %0A <mvanheyn %40 cs.indiana.edu>.  It will be posted to a variety of %0A newsgroups on a monthly basis; follow-up discussion specific to RIPEM %0A is redirected to the group alt.security.ripem. %0A  %0A WHAT'S NEW %0A ---------- %0A I am now running a World Wide Web archive of RIPEM information.  It %0A does not contain much of anything that isn't available elsewhere, but %0A it has convenient pointers to the most current version of this FAQ and %0A some other stuff.  The URL is "http %3A //cs.indiana.edu/ripem/dir.html". %0A  %0A This month's version has a fair amount of new pointers to information %0A on patents and stuff like that.  I've also reordered a few things to %0A have a more sensible ordering.  I hope I don't have to edit this again %0A soon.  %3A -) %0A  %0A DISCLAIMER %0A ---------- %0A Nothing in this FAQ should be considered legal advice, or anything %0A other than one layperson's opinion.  If you want real legal advice, %0A talk to a real lawyer, preferably one with experience in patent law, %0A export regulations, or whatever area of law is in question. %0A  %0A LIST OF QUESTIONS %0A ----------------- %0A 1)  What is RIPEM? %0A 2)  How can I get RIPEM? %0A 3)  Will RIPEM run on my machine? %0A 4)  Will RIPEM work with my mailer? %0A 5)  What is RSA? %0A 6)  What is DES? %0A 7)  What is a fingerprint, like MD5? %0A 8)  What is PEM? %0A 9)  What's this about distributing and authenticating keys? %0A 10)  Isn't it a bad idea to use patented algorithms in standards like PEM? %0A 11)  What about RSADSI/PKP? %0A 12)  Why do all RIPEM public keys look very similar? %0A 13)  What is PGP? %0A 14)  What about RPEM? %0A 15)  What is MIME? %0A 16)  What is TIS/PEM? %0A 17)  I have this simple way to defeat the security of RIPEM... %0A  %0A QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS %0A --------------------- %0A  %0A 1)  What is RIPEM? %0A  %0A  RIPEM is a (not yet complete, but useful) implementation of Privacy %0A  Enhanced Mail (PEM).  RIPEM allows your electronic mail to have the %0A  four security facilities provided by PEM %3A  disclosure protection %0A  (optional), originator authenticity, message integrity measures, and %0A  non-repudiation of origin (always).  (See %3A  "What is PEM?") %0A  %0A  RIPEM was written primarily by Mark Riordan <mrr %40 scss3.cl.msu.edu>. %0A  Most of the code is in the public domain, except for the RSA routines, %0A  which are a library called RSAREF licensed from RSA Data Security Inc. %0A  %0A  The current version of RIPEM is 1.0.5; the current version of the %0A  Macintosh port of RIPEM is 0.7. %0A  %0A 2)  How can I get RIPEM? %0A  %0A  RIPEM uses the library of cryptographic routines RSAREF, which is %0A  considered munitions and thus is export-restricted from distribution %0A  to persons who are not citizens or permanent residents in the U.S or %0A  Canada without an export license.  No such license has been obtained %0A  (nor would one likely be granted unless the RSA key exchange were %0A  shortened to 512 bits and the symmetric cipher changed to something %0A  weaker than DES.  There are some suggestions that this situation may %0A  change now that Clinton is in office.)  The author requests in the %0A  README file that this law not be violated %3A  %0A  %0A  #Please do not export the cryptographic code in this distribution %0A  #outside of the USA or Canada.  This is a personal request from me, %0A  #the author of RIPEM, and a condition of your use of RIPEM. %0A  %0A  Note that RSAREF is not in the public domain, and a license for it is %0A  included with the distribution.  You should read it before using %0A  RIPEM. %0A  %0A  RIPEM is available via anonymous FTP to citizens and permanent %0A  residents in the U.S. from rsa.com; cd to rsaref/ and read the README %0A  file for info.  Note that the non-RSAREF portion of RIPEM is not a %0A  product of RSA Data Security, Incorporated; they merely are helping %0A  distribute it. %0A  %0A  RIPEM, as well as some other crypt stuff, has its "home site" on %0A  ripem.msu.edu, which is open to non-anonymous FTP for users in the %0A  U.S. and Canada who are citizens or permanent residents.  To find out %0A  how to obtain access, FTP there, cd to pub/crypt/, and read the file %0A  GETTING_ACCESS.  For convenience, binaries for many architectures are %0A  available here in addition to the full source tree. %0A  %0A 3)  Will RIPEM run on my machine? %0A  %0A  Probably.  It has already been ported to MS-DOS and most flavors of %0A  Unix (SunOS, NeXT, Linux, AIX, ULTRIX, Solaris, etc.)  Ports to %0A  Macintosh include a standard UNIX-style port and a rather nice %0A  Mac-like port written by Raymond Lau, author of StuffIt.  More ports %0A  are expected, and help of users is invited. %0A  %0A 4)  Will RIPEM work with my mailer? %0A  %0A  Probably.  How easy and clean the effective interface is will depend %0A  on the sophistication and modularity of the mailer, though.  The users %0A  guide, included with the distribution, discusses ways to use RIPEM %0A  with many popular mailers, including Berkeley, mush, Elm, and MH. %0A  Code is also included in elisp to allow easy use of RIPEM inside GNU %0A  Emacs. %0A  %0A  If you make a new interface for RIPEM or create an improvement on one %0A  in the distribution which you believe is convenient to use, secure, %0A  and may be useful to others, feel free to post it to alt.security.ripem. %0A  %0A 5)  What is RSA? %0A  %0A  RSA is a crypto system which is asymmetric, or public-key.  This means %0A  that there are two different, related keys %3A  one to encrypt and one to %0A  decrypt.  Because one cannot (reasonably) be derived from the other, %0A  you may publish your encryption, or public, key widely and keep your %0A  decryption, or private, key to yourself.  Anyone can use your public %0A  key to encrypt a message, but only you hold the private key needed to %0A  decrypt it.  Note that the "message" sent with RSA is normally just %0A  the DES key to the real plaintext. (See "What is DES?") %0A  %0A  Note that the above only provides for disclosure protection.  For %0A  originator authenticity, message integrity, and non-repudiation of %0A  origin services to be implemented, the fingerprint of the message %0A  (See "What is a fingerprint, like MD5?") is encrypted with the %0A  sender's private key.  The recipient, or a dispute-resolving %0A  authority, can use the sender's public key to decrypt it and confirm %0A  that the message must have come from the sender and was not altered. %0A  %0A  RSA was named for the three men (Rivest, Shamir and Adleman) who %0A  invented it.  To find out lots more about RSA and modern cryptography %0A  in general, ftp to rsa.com and look in pub/faq/.  Some information %0A  also may be in sci.crypt. %0A  %0A 6)  What is DES? %0A  %0A  DES is the Data Encryption Standard, a widely used symmetric, or %0A  secret-key, crypto system.  Unlike RSA, DES uses the same key to %0A  encrypt and decrypt messages.  However, DES is much faster than RSA. %0A  %0A  RIPEM uses both DES and RSA; it generates a random key and encrypts %0A  your mail with DES using that key.  It then encrypts that key with the %0A  recipient's public RSA key and includes the result in the letter, %0A  allowing the recipient to recover the DES key. %0A  %0A  DES is sometimes considered weak because it is somewhat old and uses a %0A  key length considered too short by modern standards.  However, it %0A  should be reasonably safe against an opponent smaller than a large %0A  corporation or government agency.  It is not likely that the PEM %0A  standard will incorporate support for other symmetric ciphers in the %0A  near future, because there is a strong feeling that PEM should be %0A  stable so it can become utilized widely without early problems with %0A  interoperability. %0A  %0A 7)  What is a fingerprint, like MD5? %0A  %0A  MD5 is a message digest algorithm produced by RSA Data Security Inc. %0A  It provides a 128-bit fingerprint, or cryptographically secure hash, %0A  of the plaintext.  It is cryptographically secure because it is not %0A  possible (in a reasonable amount of computation) to produce a %0A  different plaintext which produces the same fingerprint.  Thus, %0A  instead of signing the entire message with the sender's private key, %0A  only the MD5 of the message needs to be signed for authentication. %0A  %0A  MD5s can also be exchanged directly for authentication; for example, %0A  RIPEM public keys include an MD5 of the public key in the file, so %0A  parties wishing to confirm their keys are authentic via a separate %0A  channel merely need exchange MD5s of keys and verify their accuracy. %0A  %0A  MD5 is sometimes used for other purposes; for example, it is often %0A  used to map an input of arbitrary length to 128 bits of data, as a %0A  passphrase interpreter or cookie generator. %0A  %0A  MD5 is described in its entirety (including an implementation in C) in %0A  RFC 1321. %0A  %0A  There have been some recent suggestions that MD5 may not be as strong %0A  a hash as was originally believed; presumably some other hash %0A  function will be used if this is accepted as true. %0A  %0A 8)  What is PEM? %0A  %0A  PEM is Privacy Enhanced Mail, a standard for allowing transfer of %0A  encrypted electronic mail generated over a long period of time by a %0A  working group of experts.  It is described in RFCs 1421-1424; these %0A  documents have been approved and obsolete the old RFCs 1113-1115. %0A  %0A  RIPEM is not really a complete implementation of PEM, because PEM %0A  specifies certificates for authenticating keys, which RIPEM does not %0A  handle at this time.  Their addition is planned. %0A  %0A 9)  What's this about distributing and authenticating keys? %0A  %0A  For a remote user to be able to send secure mail to you, she must know %0A  your public key.  For you to be able to confirm that the message %0A  received came from her, you must know her public key.  It is important %0A  that this information be accurate; if a "bad guy" convinces her that %0A  his key is in fact yours, she will send messages which he can read. %0A  %0A  RIPEM allows for three methods of key management %3A  a central server, %0A  the distributed finger servers, and a flat file.  All three are %0A  described in the RIPEM users guide which is part of the distribution. %0A  None of them provide perfect security.  The PEM standard calls for %0A  key management by certificates; the addition of this feature to RIPEM %0A  is planned, but chicken-egg issues still exist. %0A  %0A 10)  Isn't it a bad idea to use patented algorithms in standards like PEM? %0A  %0A  This issue has been considered in the standards process.  RFC 1310, %0A  the specification for Internet standards, has a discussion (section %0A  6) on what specifications for nondiscriminatory availability must be %0A  met for a patented method to be included in a standard.  RFC 1421 %0A  addresses this issue with regard to the patents covering public-key %0A  cryptography. %0A  %0A  This does not, of course, mean that all questions are settled or that %0A  everyone is in agreement.  An interesting exchange on the use of %0A  patented algorithms in standards with regard to public-key %0A  cryptography is in the League for Programming Freedom archive %0A  (available via FTP %3A  ftp.uu.net %3A /doc/lpf) in the files bidzos.letter %0A  and bidzos.response.  (Amusingly, the LPF files on ftp.uu.net are %0A  compressed with a patented algorithm.) %0A  %0A 11)  What about RSADSI/PKP? %0A  %0A  RSA Data Security, Inc. (RSADSI) is a California-based company %0A  specializing in cryptographic technologies.  Public Key Partners is a %0A  firm which holds exclusive sub-licensing rights of the following U.S. %0A  patents and all of their corresponding foreign patents %3A  %0A  %0A       Cryptographic Apparatus and Method %0A       ("Diffie-Hellman")............................... No. 4,200,770 %0A  %0A       Public Key Cryptographic Apparatus %0A       and Method ("Hellman-Merkle").................... No. 4,218,582 %0A  %0A       Cryptographic Communications System and %0A       Method ("RSA")................................... No. 4,405,829 %0A  %0A       Exponential Cryptographic Apparatus %0A       and Method ("Hellman-Pohlig").................... No. 4,424,414 %0A  %0A  PKP claims these four patents cover all known methods of public key %0A  cryptography.  The two businesses are rather closely related (for %0A  example, the same person, Jim Bidzos, is president of both of them.) %0A  PKP has licensed this technology to a considerable number of %0A  companies (IBM, DEC, Motorola, AT&T, Lotus...) for use in their %0A  products.  PKP has also threatened and filed lawsuits defending their %0A  patents. %0A  %0A  RIPEM was originally created with no connection to RSADSI other than %0A  its use of the RSAREF library, and for no reason other than its %0A  author's desire to see widespread use of public-key cryptography. %0A  However, after the ball started rolling, people at RSADSI got %0A  interested.  RSADSI decided to carry RIPEM on its FTP site, and some %0A  people there started making their own RIPEM keys and contributing %0A  code.  RIPEM even won the "Best Application Built on RSAREF in 1992" %0A  award. %0A  %0A 12)  Why do all RIPEM public keys look very similar? %0A  %0A  RIPEM public keys begin with a PKCS (Public-Key Cryptography %0A  Standards) identifier describing various characteristics about the %0A  key, so the first bunch of characters in your key may be the same as %0A  those of lots of other people's keys.  This does not mean your keys %0A  are similar, but only that they are the same class of key, were %0A  generated with the same program, are of the same length, etc. %0A  %0A 13)  What is PGP? %0A  %0A  PGP is another cryptographic mail program called Pretty Good Privacy. %0A  PGP has been around longer than RIPEM, and works somewhat differently. %0A  PGP is not compatible with RIPEM in any way, though PGP does also use RSA. %0A  %0A  A few major differences between PGP and RIPEM %3A  %0A  %0A  - PGP has more key management features, particularly for users without %0A    a direct network connection. %0A  %0A  - RIPEM conforms to the PEM RFCs and thus has a greater probability %0A    of working with other PEM software.  PGP makes no attempt to be %0A    compatible with anything other than itself. %0A  %0A  - RIPEM uses RSAREF, a library of RSA routines from RSADSI which %0A    comes with a license allowing noncommercial use.  PGP uses its own %0A    implementation of RSA.  PKP claims that it is a violation of its %0A    patents to "make, use or sell" PGP in the U.S. or Canada without %0A    either a license or written permission.  (See %3A  "DISCLAIMER") %0A    (See %3A  "What about RSADSI/PKP?")  Phil Zimmermann, the author of %0A    PGP, stopped distributing it after being threatened with legal %0A    action; he believed that a licensing scheme could be arranged, but %0A    it hasn't happened and there seems little prospect of it happening %0A    in the future.  He acknowledges in the PGP User's Guide %3A  %0A  %0A    #In fact, if you live in the USA, and you are not a Federal agency,  %0A    #you shouldn't actually run PGP on your computer, because Public %0A    #Key Partners wants to forbid you from running my software.  PGP is %0A    #contraband. %0A  %0A  - Both PGP and RIPEM are export-restricted, and cannot be sent outside %0A    the U.S. and Canada without an export license.  However, PGP %0A    already exists on many ftp sites in Europe and other places. %0A  %0A  Whether you use PGP or RIPEM or whatever, the documentation to PGP is %0A  recommended reading to anyone interested in such issues. %0A  Unfortunately, it's not distributed separately from the program, %0A  which can be difficult to find in the U.S. on FTP sites due to %0A  liability concerns. %0A  %0A 14)  What about RPEM? %0A  %0A  RPEM stands for Rabin Privacy Enhanced Mail.  It was similar to RIPEM, %0A  but used a public-key cipher invented by Rabin (which is not RSA) in %0A  an attempt to avoid the patents on public-key systems.  It was %0A  written by Mark Riordan, who later wrote RIPEM. %0A  %0A  Its distribution was halted when, contrary to the beliefs of many %0A  (including Rabin), PKP claimed that their patents were broad enough %0A  to cover the cipher employed.  This claim is not universally %0A  accepted, but was not challenged for pragmatic reasons. %0A  %0A  RPEM is not really used anymore.  It is not compatible with RIPEM or PGP. %0A  %0A 15)  What is MIME? %0A  %0A  MIME stands for Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions, and is %0A  described in RFC 1341.  You can find out about it in the newsgroup %0A  comp.mail.mime; a FAQ exists on it.  How PEM should interact with %0A  MIME is not yet entirely clear; some people use the stopgap solution %0A  of having a MIME type application/x-ripem in order to send RIPEM %0A  messages as MIME ones.  I hope some standards will emerge.  Draft %0A  Internet documents exist on the matter. %0A  %0A 16)  What is TIS/PEM? %0A  %0A  Trusted Information Systems is working on a version of Privacy %0A  Enhanced Mail for general availability.  Last I heard, it was %0A  rumored to be integrated into an existing mail user agent (MH) %0A  rather than a stand-alone system, and in beta test.  I don't know %0A  much more than that. %0A  %0A 17)  I have this simple way to defeat the security of RIPEM... %0A  %0A  You may wish to check the companion post "ripem-attacks" which %0A  discusses some of the more obvious attacks on RIPEM's security and %0A  what procedures will minimize the risk.  RIPEM's main "weak area" is %0A  probably key distribution. %0A
