doc_5565 |@raw_text From %3A  kolstad %40 cae.wisc.edu (Joel Kolstad) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Laser vs Bubblejet? %0A Organization %3A  U of Wisconsin-Madison College of Engineering %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 16 %3A 11 %3A 46 CDT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr20.161146.28339 %40 doug.cae.wisc.edu> %0A References %3A  <1993Apr20.173742.99726 %40 ns1.cc.lehigh.edu> %0A Lines %3A  29 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr20.173742.99726 %40 ns1.cc.lehigh.edu> hl00 %40 ns1.cc.lehigh.edu (HOU-SHENG LIN) writes %3A  %0A >Well, I'm not too sure if this would be the right place to post this, but %0A >anyway, here goes %3A   I was just noticing that some of the current bubblejet %0A >printers offers up to 360x360 resolution while a lot of lower end laser %0A >printers only offer 300x300.  However, the laser printers still seems to be %0A >significantly pricier than the bubblejets... how is this?  Or am I missing %0A >something about the resolution thing? %0A  %0A Bubblejets often splatter a little bit, whereas LaserJets (given half-way decent %0A toner, like HP's "Microfine" stuff) don't.  Both produce very good output, %0A but you don't have to look too closely at the two to tell that LaserJet %0A output is definitely superior.   %0A  %0A On the other hand, LaserJets which haven't been maintained properly and use %0A the cheapest toner the owner could find often produce awful output, much %0A worse than a bubblejet.  %3A -) %0A  %0A One other thing... there are bubblejets, and then there are BubbleJets. %0A There are a few bubblejets out there that produce rather mediocre output %0A (such as HP's dinky little BubbleJet), whereas most produce really good %0A looking output (such as HP's DeskJets).  IBM and Canon both produce some of %0A the really good style bubblejets. %0A  %0A 					---Joel Kolstad %0A  %0A P.S. -- If you're in the market for a portable bublejet printer, I can %0A highly recommend the HP Portable DeskJet, although I've heard the portable %0A Canons are good too (I needed PCL support, myself).  With the DeskJet %0A Portable, you even get an undocumented PCMCIA card slot! %0A  
doc_5575 |@raw_text From %3A  seth %40 cbnewsh.cb.att.com (peter.r.clark..jr) %0A Subject %3A  FLYERS notes 4/5 %0A Organization %3A  AT&T %0A Date %3A  Tue, 6 Apr 1993 04 %3A 46 %3A 10 GMT %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr6.044610.22648 %40 cbnewsh.cb.att.com> %0A Keywords %3A  FLYERS/Leafs summary (take that, Leafs woofers!) %0A Lines %3A  225 %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A The FLYERS team that can beat any team on any night showed up at the Spectrum %0A Sunday night, and dominated the Maple Leafs thoroughly en route to a 4-0 %0A shutout. Tommy Soderstrom will get credit for the shutout, but he barely broke %0A a sweat until the third period as the FLYERS defense kept the Leafs from %0A mounting any serious attack. %0A  %0A Injuries %3A  %0A  %0A Pelle Eklund is day-to-day with a bruised thigh. %0A  %0A Roster Moves %3A  %0A  %0A Jason Bowen was added to the lineup for his first NHL game. Jason was the FLYERS %0A second pick in the first round (15th overall) of the 1992 entry draft. 19 years %0A old, 6'4", 210 lbs. In 62 games with the tri-city Americans he had 10 goals, %0A 12 assists and 219 PIM. He plays left wing and defense, he played defense in %0A this game although Bobby Taylor said that Bill Dineen was planning to use him %0A up front as well. %0A  %0A Andre Faust was returned to Hershey. He actually left after the second period %0A of the Kings game, flew to Albany, got the game tying goal in a Bears OT win, %0A and played again for Hershey Sunday night. %0A  %0A Lines %3A  %0A  %0A Fedyk-Lindros-Recchi %0A Beranek-Brind'Amour-Dineen %0A Lomakin-Butsayev-Conroy %0A Acton-Brown %0A  %0A Galley-McGill %0A Yushkevich-Cronin %0A Carkner-Hawgood %0A Bowen %0A  %0A Tommy Soderstrom in goal. %0A  %0A Acton replaced Lomakin in the 3rd period. %0A  %0A Game Summary %3A  %0A  %0A If the FLYERS played like this every night, they'd be in the playoffs this %0A year. The FLYERS hit everything that moved. They created scoring chance after %0A scoring chance. They snuffed out everything that the Leafs tried to do. %0A  %0A Jason Bowen made a good play on his first NHL shift that almost created a goal. %0A He had the puck in the top of the left offensive circle all alone, but instead %0A of taking the shot he found Brind'Amour crashing the net on the other side. %0A A perfect pass and a good shot across Daren Puppa's body should have been a %0A goal, but Puppa made a great save reading the play. %0A  %0A Garry Galley gave the Maple Leafs 7th ranked power play the first chance when %0A he hooked Doug Gilmour at 4 %3A 25. The FLYERS lowly 21st ranked penalty killing %0A unit was almost flawless the entire game, and set the tone on this kill. The %0A Maple Leafs got almost nothing but long unscreened shots, and the defense swept %0A away every rebound. %0A  %0A After the power play, the FLYERS got a goal on an ugly play. Rod Brind'Amour %0A gave the puck to Greg Hawgood at the right point, and he sent a drive at the %0A net. Puppa made the save and kicked the rebound right into the feet of Josef %0A Beranek and Bob Rouse, who were wrestling in the slot. Beranek was able to %0A get his stick on the puck and push it out to Dineen who was skating into %0A the slot from the right circle, and he lifted a backhander over Puppa for %0A a 1-0 FLYERS lead at 8 %3A 10. %0A  %0A The FLYERS kept the pressure on, and Puppa was the only Leaf keeping the FLYERS %0A from building on their lead for a while. Eventually things settled down and %0A defense prevailed. Each team got an occasional scoring chance, but the goalies %0A were strong. Bowen started giving some Lindros-like checks in his own corners. %0A Then Lindros, who was looking to avenge a hit Foligno gave him, thought he had %0A a chance to even the score. He had Foligno lined up at center ice, leaned into %0A him, and rode him into the center ice boards. The only problem was that Foligno %0A was a little far from the boards, and Mike "Mister" McGeough felt that it %0A warranted a boarding call at 15 %3A 38 %0A  %0A The Leafs couldn't get anything going on the power play as the FLYERS were %0A very aggressive (for a change) on the kill. %0A  %0A With time running out in the period, Recchi carried through the neutral zone %0A and handed to Lindros as they approached the Leaf's blue line. They were in %0A a crowd with Wendell Clark and Jamie Macoun, Lindros tried a backhand pass %0A to Recchi through the feet of Macoun that connected to Recchi, but then Clark %0A checked Recchi off the puck. Macoun then tried to clear, but it was weak and %0A went right to McGill who had manned the point. He drove it from just inside %0A the blue line. Macoun got his stick on it and deflected it past his own %0A goalie at 19 %3A 55.1. Shots were 13-8 FLYERS in the period. %0A  %0A The FLYERS finally got their first chance on the power play when Dave Andreychuk %0A tripped up Rod Brind'Amour in his offensive zone. During the power play, the %0A FLYERS got cheated a little when the puck popped up into the air and Eric %0A gloved it down, but McGeough thought it hit his stick above his head. We %0A could see from our seats at the other end of the ice that it only hit his glove %0A and the replay confirmed, but the faceoff went to the other end. As time was %0A running out in the advantage, Lindros found Galley with a pass across the goal %0A mouth but Puppa made the save. The rebound kicked back to the right corner where %0A Recchi picked it up, passed it out to Eric crashing through the right circle, %0A and Eric one-timed past Puppa at 7 %3A 55. With the assist, Recchi moves past %0A Bobby Clarke's 74-75 season, the second best one season total for a FLYER at %0A 117.  Eric moves up to 4th all time in FLYERS rookie scoring with 67 points. %0A  %0A Mike Eastwood took down Al Conroy at 8 %3A 30 to give the FLYERS another chance on %0A the power play. Not much pressure before Garry Galley ended the power play with %0A a slash at 9 %3A 19. Not much happened on the 4 on 4, although the Leafs had most %0A of the possession. The FLYERS smothered the Leafs short power play. Tempers %0A flared a little at 13 %3A 14. Bowen and Pearson got roughing minors, Keith Acton %0A got a bloody face. Dave McLlwain then took a dive and got Greg Hawgood a %0A hooking minor at 13 %3A 46 to set up a 4 on 3. The replay showed that Hawgood's %0A stick stopped making contact with McLlwain long before he spun around and fell. %0A Again the FLYERS smothered the Leafs power play, led by Dimitri Yushkevich. %0A Bowen made a thundering hit when he came out of the box on Pearson. Berehowski %0A tried to perplex everybody with his sloooowball. He had the puck at the point, %0A and just trickled a pass down the slot. He made all the FLYERS look silly as %0A nobody could get a stick on it, and it got to Gilmour at the side of the net, %0A but Soderstrom stoned him. %0A  %0A The FLYERS picked things up offensively after the kill was over, but didn't %0A get anything home. Shots were 13-10 FLYERS. %0A  %0A The FLYERS were content with the 3 goal lead in the third period, and they %0A decided that if Tommy wanted a shutout, he was going to have to work for it a %0A little. %0A  %0A The FLYERS got most of the scoring chances in the first 7 or so minutes of the %0A period, but couldn't get past Puppa. Then the Leafs got tired of Lindros making %0A road kill out of them, and tempers flared. 2 each for Doug Gilmour and Lindros  %0A (unsportsmanlike conduct) and 2 each for Glenn Anderson and McGill (roughing) %0A all at 7 %3A 02. Terry Carkner then took a kneeing penalty at 7 %3A 51 on Gilmour. %0A  %0A Again the FLYERS smothered the Leafs power play. %0A  %0A At about the 12 minute mark, Dave Andreychuk got a shot away from his left %0A circle that got through Soderstrom. The puck was rolling on it's side, and %0A as luck would have it it turned away from the net instead of turning towards %0A it (think of how a rolling quarter inevitably starts to lean one way or the %0A other). Seconds later Rod Brind'Amour tripped up Gilmour at 12 %3A 24 to give the %0A Leafs another chance on the power play. On the advantage, after Soderstrom %0A stoned Andreychuk while lying down, Andreychuk got the rebound through %0A Soderstrom, but from behind the net and it went straight through and was swept %0A away by one of his defensemen. They kept the pressure on, but Soderstrom was %0A equal and preserved the shutout. %0A  %0A Recchi cross checked Ken Baumgartner to get tempers hot and start a brawl %0A at 16 %3A 01. No punches thrown, Recchi got the initial minor, Krushelnyski %0A Baumgartner and Lindros each got roughing minors. At 17 %3A 02 Rouse and Beranek %0A expressed their mutual dislike for each other and got 2 each for slashing to %0A set up another 4 on 4. Mike Eastwood shoved down Ryan McGill in the FLYERS %0A zone as they were battling for the puck, and while McGill was down he ran %0A his stick across McGill's face. The FLYERS were not happy with that at all. %0A 5-8 Al Conroy paired up with 6-1 Berehowski, and started throwing punches. %0A Upward. Well, Al held his own, much to the delight of the crowd. Each got %0A a couple punches in before going down in a head, and Al got a standing O! %0A Penalties %3A  Eastwood 5 (cross check) + game, Clark, Carkner 10 each. Berehowski %0A and Conroy 5 each (fighting) at 17 %3A 49. %0A  %0A So a major penalty for the rest of the game for the FLYERS. The had no interest %0A in stting on the lead. Hawgood, Galley and Brind'Amour played catch until %0A Hawgood found Dineen all alone in the left circle, he controlled the puck and %0A blasted it past Puppa at 18 %3A 39. %0A  %0A That was all the fireworks, Tommy Soderstrom would not face another shot. Puppa %0A did, but kept the FLYERS off the board. 4-0 FLYERS, shots were 9-8 FLYERS in the %0A 3rd. Probably the strongest game I've seen from the FLYERS since the All Star %0A break. Shutout number 4 for Soderstrom, all since 1/10. Tied for 2nd most in %0A the NHL, but he's played fewer games than Belfour (6) or the goalie I can't %0A remember that he's tied with. %0A  %0A Next up it's the Winnipeg Selannes Tuesday night in Winnipeg. The FLYERS cannot %0A be eliminated if they win, but a loss coupled with an Islander win that night %0A in Washington would be the official end. %0A  %0A FLYERS up to 71 points on the season in 78 games. Last year they had 75 points %0A in 80 games (5 under .500), so they need at least 8 points in their last 6 %0A games to improve on that only by percentage points (5 under in 84 is better %0A than 5 under in 80). %0A  %0A Tragic number holds at 3 points with 6 games left. The tragic number for 5th %0A is 5 points, I watched the Rangers blow a 4-2 third period lead at home to %0A lose 5-4 before I finished this up. Why 5 points instead of 4? Well, the FLYERS %0A will win the tie-breaker if they catch them, whereas the Islanders win tie %0A breakers against the FLYERS and so need only a tie. The Rangers could crumble %0A down the stretch as they play the Devils, the Pens twice, the FLYERS, and %0A finish up with 2 games against the Caps. So I guess 5th place could be the %0A goal for the team to focus on. %0A  %0A FLYERS team record watch %3A  %0A  %0A Eric Lindros %3A  %0A  %0A 38 goals, 29 assists, 67 points %0A  %0A (rookie records) %0A club record goals %3A 			club record points %3A  %0A Eric Lindros	38 1992-93		Dave Poulin	76 1983-84 %0A Brian Propp	34 1979-80		Brian Propp	75 1979-80 %0A Ron Flockhart	33 1981-82		Ron Flockhart	72 1981-82 %0A Dave Poulin	31 1983-84		Eric Lindros	67 1992-93 %0A Bill Barber	30 1972-73		Pelle Eklund	66 1985-86 %0A  %0A Mark Recchi %3A  %0A  %0A 51 goals, 66 assists, 117 points. %0A  %0A club record goals %3A 			club record points %3A  %0A Reggie Leach	61 1975-76		Bobby Clarke	119 1975-76 %0A Tim Kerr	58 1985-86,86-87	Mark Recchi	117 1992-93 %0A Tim Kerr	54 1983-84,84-85	Bobby Clarke	116 1974-75 %0A Mark Recchi	51 1992-93		Bill Barber	112 1975-76 %0A Rick Macliesh	50 1972-73		Bobby Clarke	104 1972-73 %0A Bill Barber	50 1975-76		Rick Macliesh	100 1972-73 %0A Reggie Leach	50 1979-80 %0A  %0A FLYERS career years %3A  %0A  %0A Player		Points	Best Prior Season %0A Mark Recchi	117	113 (90-91 Penguins) %0A Rod Brind'Amour	79	77 (91-92 FLYERS) %0A Garry Galley	58	38 (84-85 Kings) %0A Brent Fedyk	58	35 (90-91 Red Wings) %0A  %0A That's all for now... %0A  %0A pete clark jr - rsh FLYERS contact and mailing list owner %0A  %0A

As a service to the satellite user community, the most current %0A elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below.  The Celestial %0A BBS may be accessed 24 hours/day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using %0A 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity. %0A  %0A Element sets (also updated daily), shuttle elements, and some documentation %0A and software are also available via anonymous ftp from archive.afit.af.mil %0A (129.92.1.66) in the directory pub/space. %0A  %0A STS 55      %0A 1 22640U 93 27  A 93117.24999999  .00043819  00000-0  13174-3 0    47 %0A 2 22640  28.4694 264.3224 0004988 261.3916 194.3250 15.90699957   104 %0A -- %0A Dr TS Kelso                           Assistant Professor of Space Operations %0A tkelso %40 afit.af.mil                    Air Force Institute of Technology %0A  
doc_5577 |@raw_text From %3A  brad %40 clarinet.com (Brad Templeton) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Once tapped, your code is no good any more. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr17.061326.16130 %40 clarinet.com> %0A Date %3A  17 Apr 93 06 %3A 13 %3A 26 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr17.032828.14262 %40 clarinet.com> <tcmayC5M2xv.JEx %40 netcom.com> %0A Distribution %3A  na %0A Organization %3A  ClariNet Communications Corp. %0A Lines %3A  41 %0A  %0A In article <tcmayC5M2xv.JEx %40 netcom.com> tcmay %40 netcom.com (Timothy C. May) writes %3A  %0A >Getting the court order to reveal the key *also* makes decipherable %0A >all *past* conversations (which may be on tape, or disk, or whatver), %0A >as I understand the proposal. I could be wrong, but I've seen no %0A >mention of "session keys" being the escrowed entities. %0A  %0A True in theory.  In practice?  The technology of cellular phones will %0A probably be spread spectrum and quite difficult to record the crypttext %0A without the key.  If the frequency path depends on they key, as I %0A understand it to, it *could* be made effectively impossible to record. %0A  %0A Once it hits land you can record it if you have telco access.  The %0A telco isn't supposed to give that without a warrant.  That's the rule %0A today. %0A  %0A But even so, the evidence would not be admissible, I think, unless the %0A judge so ordered.  I think that even interception of the crypttext %0A without a warrant would be illegal.   Cops can't record today's plain %0A cellular calls and then ask a judge, "Hey, can we have permission to %0A listen to those tapes?" can they? %0A  %0A >worse, of course, if the government then uses this "Clinton Clipper" %0A >to argue for restrictions on unapproved encryption. (This is the main %0A >concern of most of us, I think. The camel's nose in the tent, etc.) %0A  %0A Yes, that is a major concern, but I think that they think they can %0A win just by having 99.5% of the USA use this system.  They don't even %0A have to care about the cautious .5% that's left.  They don't catch the %0A really smart crooks anyway.   John Gotti, who would have to be retarded %0A not to realize he was likely to be wiretapped, glibly chatted away %0A on his tapped phone about murder plans.  That's why he's in jail now. %0A Hard to believe, but true. %0A  %0A  %0A This scheme can succeed without laws forbidding more, which people would %0A fight a lot harder.  They like this enough that they are dropping the so %0A called "Digital Telephony" proposal, according to rumours.  However the %0A meaning of that is complex, since they still want to get at the crypttext %0A on telco systems, and that requires a bit of work. %0A --  %0A Brad Templeton, ClariNet Communications Corp. -- Sunnyvale, CA 408/296-0366 %0A

doc_5588 |@raw_text From %3A  etxonss %40 ufsa.ericsson.se (Staffan Axelsson) %0A Subject %3A  WC 93 %3A  Results, April 25 %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr26.074236.1961 %40 ericsson.se> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 ericsson.se %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  uipc104.ericsson.se %0A Organization %3A  Ericsson Telecom, Stockholm, Sweden %0A Date %3A  Mon, 26 Apr 1993 07 %3A 42 %3A 36 GMT %0A Lines %3A  139 %0A  %0A  %0A  1993 World Championships in Germany %3A  %0A  ==================================== %0A  %0A  Group A results %3A  %0A  %0A  SWEDEN - SWITZERLAND  4-6 (0-3,3-1,1-2) %0A  %0A  1st %3A  SWI 0-1 Manuele Celio 1                                         3 %3A 21 %0A       SWI 0-2 Patrick Howald 1                                       11 %3A 37 %0A       SWI 0-3 Patrick Howald 2   (Sven Leuenberger)                  16 %3A 00 %0A  2nd %3A  SWE 1-3 Peter Andersson 1  (Michael Nylander)                   2 %3A 47 (pp) %0A       SWI 1-4 Roman Waeger 1     (Martin Rauch,Sven Leuenberger)      8 %3A 53 (pp) %0A       SWE 2-4 Jonas Bergqvist 3  (Markus Naslund)                     9 %3A 08 %0A       SWE 3-4 Jan Larsson 1      (Patrik Juhlin)                     18 %3A 50 %0A  3rd %3A  SWE 4-4 Mikael Renberg 2   (Thomas Rundqvist,Peter Andersson)   7 %3A 49 %0A       SWI 4-5 Roman Waeger 2                                          9 %3A 07 %0A       SWI 4-6 Felix Hollenstein 1 (Sven Leuenberger,Thomas Vrabec)   11 %3A 29 %0A  %0A               Shots on goal %3A    Penalties %3A    Attendance %3A    Referee %3A  %0A  Sweden        5 20 18 - 43    4*2min       6,000         Rob Hearn, USA %0A  Switzerland  10  6  7 - 23    5*2min %0A  %0A  Switzerland beat Sweden in a WC for the first time since 1950, and the Swiss %0A  now have a small chance of reaching the quarterfinals (if Austria beats %0A  Italy tonight). %0A  %0A  The Swiss took the lead after Hakan Ahlund made an incredibly stupid drop %0A  pass at his own blue line, and Celio came in alone with Soderstrom and beat %0A  Tommy to the stick side. The Swedes continued to make mistakes as Howald %0A  was allowed to skate in between the Swedish D and put the puck past Tommy %0A  to make it 0-2. 0-3 was a nice one, Howald entered the Swedish zone, slammed %0A  on the breaks, and his shot went in by Tommy's far post. One of the lousiest %0A  periods I've seen Sweden play this year. %0A  Second period saw a new Swedish team, and the Swiss had to ice the puck many %0A  times. On a pp, Nylander skated in from the boards, Pavoni made the initial %0A  save, but Peter Andersson scored on the rebound.  Then a power play goal %0A  from the Swiss, a slap shot from the blue line hit two players on the way %0A  to the goal and past Soderstrom also. Jonas Bergqvist made it 2-4 after a %0A  nice pass from Naslund behind the goal. Jan Larsson reduced the lead to 3-4 %0A  just before the end of 2nd period, on a pp skated in unattacked in front of %0A  the goal, and put the puck through Pavoni's 5-hole.  %0A  Third period, Sweden equalized on a slap shot from Renberg that trickled %0A  through Pavoni's 5-hole. Then, another defensive mistake by the Swedes, %0A  Waeger was allowed to skate around the Swedish goal unattacked and from close %0A  range could make it 4-5. Hollenstein then scored 4-6 on a 2-on-1 break away, %0A  and put it top shelf with no chance for Soderstrom. %0A  %0A  Switzerland %3A  %0A  %0A  Goaltender %3A   20 Reto Pavoni  (28 Renatio Tosio) %0A  Defense %3A      26 Rick Tschumi, 2 Martin Steinegger %0A               16 Sven Leuenberger, 5 Martin Rauch %0A                7 Sandro Bertaggia, 17 Patrick Sutter %0A               31 Samuel Balmer %0A  Forwards %3A     22 Alfred Luthi, 11 Felix Hollenstein, 25 Roman Waeger %0A               23 Gil Montandon, 12 Roberto Triulzi, 10 Patrick Howald %0A               35 Christian Weber, 18 Andreas Ton, 24 Joerg Eberle %0A               15 Bruno Erni, 13 Thomas Vrabec, 29 Manuele Celio %0A   %0A - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - %0A  %0A  RUSSIA - CANADA  1-3 (0-2,1-1,0-0) %0A  %0A  1st %3A  CAN 0-1 Kevin Dineen 1     (Garry Galley)                       4 %3A 28 %0A       CAN 0-2 Paul Kariya 2      (Eric Lindros)                      12 %3A 20 (pp) %0A  2nd %3A  CAN 0-3 Eric Lindros 10    (Paul Kariya,Shayne Corson)          9 %3A 40 %0A       RUS 1-3 Valeri Karpov 2    (?)                                 16 %3A 24 %0A  3rd %3A  %0A  %0A  Penalties %3A  RUS 2*2min 1*5min, CAN 5*2min %0A  Referee %3A  Anton Danko, Czech republic %0A  Attendance %3A  8,600 %0A  %0A  Russia probably made their best game of the tourney, but yet there wasn't %0A  enough to win against the effective Canadians. %0A  %0A  Galley took a slap shot that found Dineen by the far post, and Dineen just %0A  deflected the puck past Trefilov in the Russian goal. Then a power play %0A  goal, after a couple of deflections Eric Lindros found Kariya alone by the %0A  far post, and Kariya put the puck high over a sliding Trefilov. %0A  Russia won the shots in the first period 12-5, and they had the most of %0A  the scoring opportunities, but they just couldn't score. %0A  Second period saw Lindros scoring his 10th (!!) goal of the WC. Kariya %0A  entered the Russian zone, slammed on the break to get past his defenseman, %0A  then made a nice pass to Corson who just got the stick on the puck to %0A  deflect it to Lindros who one-timed the puck. %0A  The Russians then finally got their goal, Karpov broke in from the side %0A  and made a slap shot in Tugnutt's top right hand corner. %0A   %0A  Player of the game in Canada was voted Paul Kariya, and for Russia Valeri %0A  Karpov. I agree, the difference in this game was Lindros and Kariya, and %0A  in part also Tugnutt. Kariya had a far better game now than vs the Swedes, %0A  and he was very impressive. Kariya got the place in the line with Lindros %0A  after Mike Gartner went out with a rib-injury early in the first period. %0A  %0A  Lindros, BTW, lead the point scoring with 14 pts (9+5) before this game, %0A  7 pts ahead of the next player! i.e. double as much as the next player %0A  (among those Kariya with 1+6). Amazing! %0A  %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  %0A  Group B results %3A  %0A  %0A  FINLAND - CZECH REPUBLIC  1-3 (0-0,1-1,0-2) %0A  %0A  1st %3A  %0A  2nd %3A  CZE 0-1  Petr Hrbek 2           11 %3A 04 %0A       FIN 1-1  Mika Alatalo 1         17 %3A 51 %0A  3rd %3A  CZE 1-2  Jiri Dolezal 3          5 %3A 04 %0A       CZE 1-3  Martin Hostak 2        19 %3A 45 (en) %0A  %0A  Penalties %3A  FIN 8*2min, CZE 9*2min %0A  Referee %3A  Vincent Moreno, Switzerland %0A  Attendance %3A  4,300 %0A  %0A - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - %0A  %0A  GERMANY - USA  6-3 (5-0,0-0,1-3) %0A  %0A  1st %3A  GER 1-0  Raimond Hilger 2        7 %3A 12 %0A       GER 2-0  Gerd Truntschka 3      11 %3A 16 %0A       GER 3-0  Ernst Kopf 3           11 %3A 55 %0A       GER 4-0  Michael Rumrich 3      16 %3A 06 %0A       GER 5-0  Benoit Doucet 1        18 %3A 45 %0A  2nd %3A  %0A  3rd %3A  USA 5-1  Derek Plante 1          4 %3A 06 %0A       GER 6-1  Dieter Hegen 5          6 %3A 57 %0A       USA 6-2  Craig Johnson 1         7 %3A 30 %0A       USA 6-3  Rob Gaudreau 3         13 %3A 07 %0A  %0A  Penalties %3A  GER 7*2min, USA 10*2min %0A  Referee %3A  Valeri Bokarev, Russia %0A  Attendance %3A  11,000 %0A  %0A -- %0A  ((\\  //%7C Staffan Axelsson %0A   \\  //%7C%7C etxonss %40 ufsa.ericsson.se %0A \\_))//-%7C%7C r.s.h. contact for Swedish hockey %0A  
doc_5594 |@raw_text From %3A  lsg001 %40 cck.coventry.ac.uk (Graham Wilson) %0A Subject %3A  Contracts %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5wM9o.36y %40 cck.coventry.ac.uk> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 cck.coventry.ac.uk (news user) %0A Nntp-Posting-Host %3A  cc_sysk %0A Organization %3A  Department of Law - Coventry University, Coventry, UK. %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 21 %3A 27 %3A 23 GMT %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A  %0A ** For my computer law module I have been asked to write a computer  %0A    contract for the supply of computer software to a business. The %0A    software is being especially written for the company. %0A  %0A    Would anyone, per chance happen to have a copy of a computer %0A    contract on their system which they could mail me. %0A  %0A    If anyone has a computer contract but it contains sensitive  %0A    material then I can assure them that it will remain confidential %0A    and I will not pass it on, or allow anyone else to view it. %0A  %0A    Thanks. %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A           T 3/4 c2 l1(s) hbl d- a w+ c- y e++ g f t+ k++ s++ m1+ %0A          *      Graham Wilson      *  lsg001 %40 cck.coventry.ac.uk  * %0A          *     LL.B. doc_5611 |@raw_text From %3A  advax %40 reg.triumf.ca (A.Daviel) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How universal are (video) phones these days? %0A Date %3A  26 Apr 1993 15 %3A 04 PST %0A Organization %3A  TRIUMF %3A  Tri-University Meson Facility %0A Lines %3A  17 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Message-ID %3A  <26APR199315043689 %40 reg.triumf.ca> %0A References %3A  <1rg36hINNsr6 %40 darkstar.UCSC.EDU> <1rh22eINNfce %40 shelley.u.washington.edu> %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  reg.triumf.ca %0A News-Software %3A  VAX/VMS VNEWS 1.41     %0A  %0A Just saw an article in New Scientist; AT&T videophones won't talk to (?)BTI  %0A videophones. The AT&T ones use a 19.2kb modem, BTI uses 14.4kb. AT&T models  %0A have to communicate using all AT&T exchanges, whereas the BTI can route  %0A via most current exchanges. Suggestions include building standards converters  %0A into telephone exchanges - the mind boggles  %3A )= . The BTI design is a bit  %0A more conservative and is better able to cope with current data compression  %0A hardware on long-distance lines. %0A  %0A (not having the magazine to hand, I may have mis-remembered BTI. I think it %0A is a British one made by GEC-Marconi, and currently selling to other %0A countries).  %0A  %0A Yet Another Standards Screw-up. %0A  %0A -- %0A  Andrew Daviel, Vancouver, Canada <advax %40 triumf.ca> %0A   finger advax %40 reg.triumf.ca for PGP key %0A

doc_5620 |@raw_text From %3A  ggruscho %40 nyx.cs.du.edu (George Gruschow) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  How to the disks copy protected. %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.175926.21347 %40 mnemosyne.cs.du.edu> %0A Sender %3A  usenet %40 mnemosyne.cs.du.edu (netnews admin account) %0A Organization %3A  University of Denver, Dept. of Math & Comp. Sci. %0A References %3A  <sehari.735331566 %40 marge.ecss.iastate.edu> <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu> <sehari.735357542 %40 du139-213.cc.iastate.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 93 17 %3A 59 %3A 26 GMT %0A Lines %3A  98 %0A  %0A sehari %40 iastate.edu (Babak Sehari) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >In <1993Apr20.230749.12821 %40 reed.edu> mblock %40 reed.edu (Matt Block) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >>In article <sehari.735331566 %40 marge.ecss.iastate.edu> sehari %40 iastate.edu (Babak Sehari) writes %3A  %0A >>>--- %0A >>> %0A >>>I was wondering, what copy protection techniques are avaliable, and how %0A >>>effective are they?  Has anyone have any experience in this area? %0A >>> %0A >>>                      With highest regards, %0A >>>                           Babak   Sehari. %0A  %0A >>	Uh oh... %0A >>	Umm, there are a number of copy protection schemes.  Some involve %0A >>modifying the physical media, and some involve encryption schemes, &c. %0A >>	All of the ones that have existed over the course of computing have %0A >>been successful for a time.  I recall, however, near monthly releases of new %0A >>ways to "crack" the copy protection scheme of the latest releases.  The fact %0A >>is, none of them are completely secure, or anywhere near it.  Some are more or %0A >>less difficult to crack, and some have already been cracked. %0A >>	I guess what I am saying is that your question is difficult, if not %0A >>impossible, to answer.  What exactly do you want to know?  Do you need a good %0A >>one for a project you are working on?  How secure must it be?  Are you trying %0A >>to crack one that someone else has used?  I can probably make suggestions, %0A >>assuming the activity is strictly legal.  (In general, it is a BAD idea, %0A >>legally, to tamper with copy protection.  It can also lead to corruption of %0A >>files which you necessarily do not have back ups of (being as they are copy %0A >>protected,) which can be devestating.)  Do you have absolutely no ideas for %0A >>practical applications, and are merely curious? %0A >>	Please clear up those questions, and I'll try to help as much as I %0A >>can. %0A  %0A >>	Incidentally, the "Uh oh..." at the top is indicative of the dread %0A >>anyone who has watched their friends hacking equipment be carted off feels %0A >>when they are asked how to hack.  The area you are broaching is wrought with %0A >>dangers, many of which include breaking the law, or at least addressing it %0A >>(from one side or the other.) %0A  %0A >>Matt %0A  %0A >I have written a program and I want to market it.  I would like certain degree %0A >of protection, since my main custmers are individuals and not the  %0A >cooperations.   I know laser hole burning method, and hardware key method, %0A >however, my  software is going to cost only $15.00, so I can not afford that. %0A >Also, at this low price I can not afford people make too many copy of my %0A >software. Well, I guess say upto %20 illigal copying is ok by me. %0A  %0A >However, I do not want someone to get a copy of PCTools and copy my software.   %0A >Off course, I never meant to forbid the true hackers from copying, since they %0A >can develope a better program anyway. %0A  %0A >                      With highest regards, %0A >                           Babak   Sehari. %0A  %0A  %0A >--  %0A  %0A One of the most popular methods of course is the password check where they ask %0A you for a word from page x, line y, and word z, but this is pitifully simple to %0A remove unless you throw some checksums into the main part of your program, and %0A some self-rewriting code to confuse some people.  Also, make sure that your %0A program can not be run out a debugger. %0A  %0A Another method of course is to not even make bad sectors on the original disk, %0A just write a certain key to a certain unallocated sector.   To help you here, %0A you also must do the code protection schemes mentioned in the first paragraph. %0A Make sure you also fill the rest of the unallocated parts of the disk with %0A garbage as well, or they (wanna be crackers) can just look for the junk in %0A some random sector. %0A  %0A Like you mentioned, there are the laser holed disks and hardware keys, but they %0A are both expensive and a pain in the butt for the end-user, which you is the %0A opposite of what you want. %0A  %0A Another configuration that can be used is to save the configuration of the %0A machine that it is being installed to in the most undecipherable format you can %0A think of.  If the program does not find that this is the same system, it %0A requests being installed by the original disk again.  The original disk should %0A be encrypted, compacted, have many sectors that should be checked, and anything %0A else you can think of to make sure that the original cannot be copied.  Once %0A again, you MUST put code-encryption, self-rewriting code, and multiple CRC %0A checks in the program to make sure that it does not get changed.  Among other %0A things, this also protects your program from virii.  If the program detects a %0A change in its code, tell the user that a virus has been detected in the %0A program.  Tell them the program is "VIRUS SECURE", and remember, you have %0A helped the world kill some pirating and kill some viruses.  Feel good. %0A  %0A I hope that I have helped.  Have fun.  Knock some cracking out (well, you can't %0A do it, everything that can be written can be cracked, but you'll piss'em off in %0A the process!). Goodbye. %0A  %0A What is the program that will be sold? %0A -- %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A George Gruschow                                Death do you gronk. %0A ag625 %40 yfn.ysu.edu                              ggruscho %40 nyx.cs.du.edu %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A  
doc_5621 |@raw_text Subject %3A  Remarks by President Clinton to NCAA Division I Champion Hockey Team %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.4238.36291 %40 dosgate> %0A From %3A  "nigel allen" <nigel.allen %40 canrem.com> %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 93 20 %3A 08 %3A 00 EST %0A Reply-To %3A  "nigel allen" <nigel.allen %40 canrem.com> %0A Distribution %3A  rec %0A Organization %3A  Canada Remote Systems %0A Lines %3A  158 %0A  %0A  %0A Here is a press release from the White House. %0A  %0A  Remarks by President Clinton to NCAA Division I Champion Hockey Team %0A April 19; Q&A Following %0A  To %3A  National Desk %0A  Contact %3A  White House Office of the Press Secretary, 202-456-2100 %0A  %0A    WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Following is a transcript %0A of remarks by President Clinton to the University of Maine "Black %0A Bears" NCAA Division I hockey champions %3A  %0A  %0A                            The Rose Garden %0A  %0A  9 %3A 58 A.M. EDT %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   Good morning ladies and gentlemen.  It's %0A an honor for me to welcome the University of Maine Black Bears, the %0A winner of the NCAA Division I hockey national championship to the %0A Rose Garden and the White House.  I understand from Senator Mitchell %0A that this is the first team from the University of Maine every to win %0A a national championship.  And we're glad to have them here. %0A  %0A      I'm inspired not only by how the team pulled together to %0A win the championship, but how the entire state pulled together to %0A cheer them onto victory. %0A  %0A      Coming from a state that is also relatively small in %0A size, but also filled with pride and tradition and community, I can %0A understand how the people of Maine must feel about the Black Bears. %0A In our state people are still talking about the time we won the %0A Orange Bowl over the number one ranked football team, and that was %0A back in 1978.  I'm sure that 15 years from now, the people of Maine %0A will as proud of this team as they are today. %0A  %0A      You know, in my state football is a slightly more %0A popular sport than hockey.  We don't have a lot of ice.  (Laughter.) %0A But after spending three months getting banged around in this town, I %0A can understand a little more about hockey than I did before I came %0A here.  Hockey is a tough game.  It's a hard-hitting sport.  It does %0A have one virtue though, there's a penalty for delay of game.  I wish %0A we had that rule in the Senate.  (Laughter.) %0A  %0A      In government as in hockey, leadership is important.  In %0A the United States Senate, our team has a great captain, the Majority %0A Leader and the senior Senator from Maine, George Mitchell; junior %0A Senator -- Cohen looks so young, I can't imagine.  (Laughter.)  I'm %0A actually bitter about Senator Cohen because he looks so much younger %0A than me. %0A  %0A      On your hockey team, the captain Jim Montgomery has done %0A a great job.  He scored the winning goal late in the championship %0A game, leading you to a come-from-behind victory -- something else I %0A know a little bit about. %0A  %0A      Sport brings out the best in individuals and in teams %0A and in communities.  I share the pride that Senator Mitchell and %0A Senator Cohen and Congressman Andrews and all the people of Maine %0A must feel for the Black Bears who have shown us all how to play as a %0A team, how to bring out the best in one another, and how to come from %0A behind. %0A  %0A      I think it's important, as I ask young people from %0A around America who have achieved outstanding things in working %0A together, to come here to the White House to be recognized and %0A appreciated by their country, to remember that those kinds of values %0A and those kinds of virtues need to be ingrained in all of us for all %0A of our lives. %0A  %0A      We now have another role model, and I'm glad to have %0A them here today.  (Applause.) %0A  %0A      (The President is presented with team jersey.) %0A (Applause.) %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   That's great.  I love it.  It's beautiful. %0A (Applause.) %0A  %0A      (The President is presented with an autographed stick.) %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   Thank you.  That's great.  (Applause.) %0A  %0A                              * * * * * * %0A  %0A      Q  Mr. President, did you authorize the move on Waco %0A this morning, sir? %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   I was aware of it.  I think the Attorney %0A General made the decision.  And I think I should refer all questions %0A to her and to the FBI. %0A  %0A      Q  Did you have any instructions for her as to how it %0A should be executed? %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   No, they made the tactical decisions. %0A That was their judgment, the FBI. %0A  %0A      Q  Is this a raid? %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   And I will -- I want to refer you to -- %0A talk to the Attorney General and the FBI.  I knew it was going to be %0A done, but the decisions were entirely theirs, all the tactical %0A decisions. %0A  %0A      Q  What did you and Senator Mitchell talk about this %0A morning? %0A  %0A      Q  Any chance for that stimulus package? %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   Senator Mitchell ought to pay my %0A quarter.  (Laughter.)  I was in there -- (laughter). %0A  %0A      SENATOR MITCHELL %3A   You have to pay that quarter. %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   I was ready.  (Laughter.)  Senator %0A Mitchell, he's worth a quarter any day. %0A  %0A      Q  Any chance for your bill, sir? %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   We talked about what was going to happen %0A this week in the Senate and about what other meetings we're going to %0A have for the rest of the week.  We only had about five minutes to %0A talk.  And we agreed we'd get back together later, around noon, and %0A talk some more. %0A  %0A      Q  Senator Dole said over the weekend that your %0A compromise is no compromise. %0A  %0A      THE PRESIDENT %3A   Well, I know he did, but, look, Senator %0A Dole and a lot of the other Republicans now in the Senate voted for %0A the same kind of thing for Ronald Reagan in 1983; and our research %0A indicates that a majority of them over time voted for a total of 28 %0A emergency spending measures totalling over $100 billion when Reagan %0A and Bush were President, in those administrations.  And many of those %0A purposes were not nearly as worthy as putting the American people %0A back to work.  I don't want to go back and revisit every one, but you %0A  %0A  %0A can do it.  You can look at the research there.  So this position %0A they're taking is not credible.  We have a very tough five-year %0A deficit reduction plan.  All these costs are covered during that time %0A and then some.  And the very people that are saying this has all got %0A to be paid for don't have much of a history on which to base their %0A position.  They've got 12 years of vote for stimulus measures of this %0A kind that had very little to with putting the American people back to %0A work.  So I think we've got a chance to work it out, and I'm hopeful. %0A We'll see what happens today and tomorrow.  I'm feeling pretty good %0A about it. %0A  %0A      THE PRESS %3A   Thank you %0A  %0A                                  END       10 %3A 10 A.M. EDT %0A  %0A  -30- %0A  %0A -- %0A Canada Remote Systems - Toronto, Ontario %0A 416-629-7000/629-7044 %0A

We can pick up laptop screens without any %0A    >problem. [...] %0A  %0A    I heard somewhere (can't name the source) that TEMPEST does not necessarily %0A    pick-up just CRTs, but it can pick up emissions from almost any chip.  If %0A    that is true, the kind monitor would not make any difference becuase everything %0A    on the screen can be picked-up from the video controller.  Can anybody verify %0A    or refute this? %0A  %0A Yes, that's true.  TEMPEST is nothing magic, it's just listening to any %0A available electromagnetic emissions and using all the analysis techniques   %0A you know to separate out the interesting stuff.  %0A  %0A The nice thing about old CRTs is that they used to put out LOTS of %0A signal, so they're easy to detect, and if you do your sync carefully, %0A you can watch the output on the monitor in your deceptively-marked %0A Chevy Step-Van.  Some brands of electric typewriters were even worse. %0A In both cases, it's especially nice because it gets you the data the %0A user is looking at, rather than whatever stuff the paging algorithm is %0A paging out to disk, etc. %0A  %0A With newer, quieter equipment, there isn't as much signal, and it's harder to %0A isolate the fun parts.  TEMPEST-rated equipment has much lower signal levels. %0A But "Everything has vibrations", as Master Chuan said. %0A -- %0A #				Pray for peace;      Bill %0A # Bill Stewart 1-908-949-0705 wcs %40 anchor.att.com AT&T Bell Labs 4M312 Holmdel NJ %0A #	              No, I'm *from* New Jersey, I only *work* in cyberspace.... %0A # White House Commect Line 1-202-456-1111  fax 1-202-456-2461 %0A

doc_5690 |@raw_text From %3A  denning %40 guvax.acc.georgetown.edu %0A Subject %3A  THE CLIPPER CHIP %3A  A TECHNICAL SUMMARY %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr19.182327.3420 %40 guvax.acc.georgetown.edu> %0A Date %3A  19 Apr 93 18 %3A 23 %3A 27 -0400 %0A Distribution %3A  world %0A Organization %3A  Georgetown University %0A Lines %3A  139 %0A  %0A The following document summarizes the Clipper Chip, how it is used, %0A how programming of the chip is coupled to key generation and the %0A escrow process, and how law enforcement decrypts communications. %0A Since there has been some speculation on this news group about my %0A own involvement in this project, I'd like to add that I was not in %0A any way involved.  I found out about it when the FBI briefed me on %0A Thursday evening, April 15.  Since then I have spent considerable %0A time talking with the NSA and FBI to learn more about this, and I %0A attended the NIST briefing at the Department of Commerce on April 16.   %0A The document below is the result of that effort.  %0A  %0A Dorothy Denning %0A --------------- %0A  %0A                      THE CLIPPER CHIP %3A  A TECHNICAL SUMMARY %0A  %0A                                Dorothy Denning %0A  %0A                                 April 19, 1993 %0A  %0A  %0A INTRODUCTION %0A  %0A On April 16, the President announced a new initiative that will bring %0A together the Federal Government and industry in a voluntary program %0A to provide secure communications while meeting the legitimate needs of %0A law enforcement.  At the heart of the plan is a new tamper-proof encryption %0A chip called the "Clipper Chip" together with a split-key approach to %0A escrowing keys.  Two escrow agencies are used, and the key parts from %0A both are needed to reconstruct a key. %0A  %0A  %0A CHIP STRUCTURE %0A  %0A The Clipper Chip contains a classified 64-bit block encryption %0A algorithm called "Skipjack."  The algorithm uses 80 bit keys (compared %0A with 56 for the DES) and has 32 rounds of scrambling (compared with 16 %0A for the DES).  It supports all 4 DES modes of operation.  Throughput is %0A 16 Mbits a second. %0A  %0A Each chip includes the following components %3A  %0A  %0A    the Skipjack encryption algorithm %0A    F, an 80-bit family key that is common to all chips %0A    N, a 30-bit serial number %0A    U, an 80-bit secret key that unlocks all messages encrypted with the chip %0A  %0A  %0A ENCRYPTING WITH THE CHIP %0A  %0A To see how the chip is used, imagine that it is embedded in the AT&T %0A telephone security device (as it will be).  Suppose I call someone and %0A we both have such a device.  After pushing a button to start a secure %0A conversation, my security device will negotiate a session key K with %0A the device at the other end (in general, any method of key exchange can %0A be used).  The key K and message stream M (i.e., digitized voice) are then %0A fed into the Clipper Chip to produce two values %3A  %0A  %0A    E[M; K], the encrypted message stream, and  %0A    E[E[K; U] + N; F], a law enforcement block.   %0A  %0A The law enforcement block thus contains the session key K encrypted %0A under the unit key U concatenated with the serial number N, all %0A encrypted under the family key F. %0A  %0A  %0A CHIP PROGRAMMING AND ESCROW %0A  %0A All Clipper Chips are programmed inside a SCIF (secure computer %0A information facility), which is essentially a vault.  The SCIF contains %0A a laptop computer and equipment to program the chips.  About 300 chips %0A are programmed during a single session.  The SCIF is located at %0A Mikotronx. %0A  %0A At the beginning of a session, a trusted agent from each of the two key %0A escrow agencies enters the vault.  Agent 1 enters an 80-bit value S1 %0A into the laptop and agent 2 enters an 80-bit value S2. These values %0A serve as seeds to generate keys for a sequence of serial numbers. %0A  %0A To generate the unit key for a serial number N, the 30-bit value N is %0A first padded with a fixed 34-bit block to produce a 64-bit block N1. %0A S1 and S2 are then used as keys to triple-encrypt N1, producing a %0A 64-bit block R1 %3A  %0A  %0A         R1 = E[D[E[N1; S1]; S2]; S1] . %0A  %0A Similarly, N is padded with two other 34-bit blocks to produce N2 and %0A N3, and two additional 64-bit blocks R2 and R3 are computed %3A    %0A  %0A         R2 = E[D[E[N2; S1]; S2]; S1]  %0A         R3 = E[D[E[N3; S1]; S2]; S1] . %0A  %0A R1, R2, and R3 are then concatenated together, giving 192 bits. The %0A first 80 bits are assigned to U1 and the second 80 bits to U2.  The %0A rest are discarded.  The unit key U is the XOR of U1 and U2.  U1 and U2 %0A are the key parts that are separately escrowed with the two escrow %0A agencies. %0A  %0A As a sequence of values for U1, U2, and U are generated, they are %0A written onto three separate floppy disks.  The first disk contains a %0A file for each serial number that contains the corresponding key part %0A U1.  The second disk is similar but contains the U2 values.  The third %0A disk contains the unit keys U.  Agent 1 takes the first disk and agent %0A 2 takes the second disk.  The third disk is used to program the chips. %0A After the chips are programmed, all information is discarded from the %0A vault and the agents leave.  The laptop may be destroyed for additional %0A assurance that no information is left behind. %0A   %0A The protocol may be changed slightly so that four people are in the %0A room instead of two.  The first two would provide the seeds S1 and S2, %0A and the second two (the escrow agents) would take the disks back to %0A the escrow agencies. %0A  %0A The escrow agencies have as yet to be determined, but they will not %0A be the NSA, CIA, FBI, or any other law enforcement agency.  One or %0A both may be independent from the government. %0A  %0A  %0A LAW ENFORCEMENT USE %0A  %0A When law enforcement has been authorized to tap an encrypted line, they %0A will first take the warrant to the service provider in order to get %0A access to the communications line.  Let us assume that the tap is in %0A place and that they have determined that the line is encrypted with %0A Clipper.  They will first decrypt the law enforcement block with the %0A family key F.  This gives them E[K; U] + N.  They will then take a %0A warrant identifying the chip serial number N to each of the key escrow %0A agents and get back U1 and U2.  U1 and U2 are XORed together to produce %0A the unit key U, and E[K; U] is decrypted to get the session key K. %0A Finally the message stream is decrypted.  All this will be accomplished %0A through a special black box decoder operated by the FBI. %0A  %0A  %0A ACKNOWLEDGMENT AND DISTRIBUTION NOTICE.  All information is based on %0A information provided by NSA, NIST, and the FBI.  Permission to %0A distribute this document is granted. %0A  %0A  %0A      %0A

Draw your own %0A conclusions >>about the strength of the algorithm...   %3A -) %0A  %0A Sorry if I was less than clear.   %3A -) I was referring to our own efforts %0A to receive export permission from NSA for the PKZIP encryption %0A algorithm, not to any effort on the part of Phil Katz or PKWare. %0A  %0A I should point out that the original version of this algorithm was %0A designed by Roger Schlafly and that WE (meaning Roger and myself) were %0A twice denied an export license for it. So the %0A  %3A    proposed wiretap chip must raise phone costs by less than one part  %0A  %3A    in three thousand to be cost-effective.  %0A  %0A Robin's calculation is interesting and important, even if it's off by %0A an order of magnitude (for example). %0A  %0A Even if hardware costs for the Clipper Chip phones were ZERO, the %0A protocol overhead in transmitting the escrow field would be much %0A higher than the 1 part in 3 thousand...it depends on the exact details %0A of the phone call length, protocol, etc. (shorter calls get a %0A proportionately greater hit). %0A  %0A However, I suspect most Americans will not find this line of reasoning %0A as persuasive as the analogies about escrowing keys to one's house %0A are. %0A  %0A -Tim May %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A .......................................................................... %0A Timothy C. doc_5760 |@raw_text From %3A  tholen %40 newton.ifa.hawaii.edu (Dave Tholen) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Command Loss Timer (Re %3A  Galileo Update - 04/22/93) %0A Message-ID %3A  <C5ynoo.7uG %40 news.Hawaii.Edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 news.Hawaii.Edu %0A Organization %3A  Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii %0A Date %3A  Fri, 23 Apr 1993 23 %3A 53 %3A 12 GMT %0A Lines %3A  23 %0A  %0A Alan Carter writes %3A  %0A  %0A >> 3.  On April 19, a NO-OP command was sent to reset the command loss timer to %0A >> 264 hours, its planned value during this mission phase. %0A  %0A > This activity is regularly reported in Ron's interesting posts. Could %0A > someone explain what the Command Loss Timer is? %0A  %0A The name is rather descriptive.  It's a command to the spacecraft that tells %0A it "If you don't hear from Earth after 264 hours, assume something is wrong %0A with your (the spacecraft) attitude, and go into a preprogrammed search mode %0A in an attempt to reacquire the signal from Earth." %0A  %0A The spacecraft and Earth are not in constant communication with each other. %0A Earth monitors the telemetry from the spacecraft, and if everything is fine, %0A there's no reason to send it any new information.  But from the spacecraft's %0A point of view, no information from Earth could mean either everything is %0A fine, or that the spacecraft has lost signal acquisition.  Just how long %0A should the spacecraft wait before it decides that something is wrong and %0A begins to take corrective action?  That "how long" is the command loss timer. %0A During relatively inactive cruise phases, the command loss timer can be set %0A to rather long values.  In this case, Earth is telling Galileo "expect to %0A hear back from us sometime within the next 264 hours". %0A

doc_5784 |@raw_text From %3A  ubsiler %40 msuvx1.memst.edu %0A Subject %3A  Home-made IR remote extender %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr6.185033.6610 %40 msuvx1.memst.edu> %0A Date %3A  6 Apr 93 18 %3A 50 %3A 33 -0600 %0A Organization %3A  Memphis State University %0A Lines %3A  19 %0A  %0A Here's a question for all you electrical engineers out there %3A  %0A  %0A   I bought an 'Infrared detector module' at Radio Shack for $3.95 - it is a  %0A little gizmo that senses infrared remotes and produces an output signal. Then %0A I hooked the output through a transistor to an infrared LED. The circuit works %0A like a minature remote control extender in my car - All remote commands are %0A relayed to the CD player hidden in the glove compartment. It works fine with %0A my Denon CD player, but when I tried to build the same circuit for a friend's %0A VCR, it didn't work. %0A   The circuit appears to work for other remotes (you can see infrared with a %0A Sony CCD camcorder) but coincidentally it only seems to work for my CD %0A player... %0A  %0A 	Any advice would be appreciated.... %0A         Brian %0A  %0A --- %0A UBSILER  %40  MSUVX1.MEMST.EDU %0A  %0A

doc_5806 |@raw_text From %3A  willner %40 head-cfa.harvard.edu (Steve Willner) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  temperature of the dark sky %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr30.163959.19715 %40 head-cfa.harvard.edu> %0A Sender %3A  willner %40 head-cfa.harvard.edu (Steve Willner) %0A Organization %3A  Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Cambridge, MA,  USA %0A References %3A  <C65o4t.A7o %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1993Apr28.002214.16544 %40 Princeton.EDU> %0A Date %3A  Fri, 30 Apr 1993 16 %3A 39 %3A 59 GMT %0A Lines %3A  71 %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr28.002214.16544 %40 Princeton.EDU>, %0A richmond %40 spiff.Princeton.EDU (Stupendous Man) writes %3A   %0A >    If that's the case, let me point out that interstellar dust and  %0A > molecules provide many instances of things that are, well, not-too-far %0A > from being blackbodies.  Many different observations, including IRAS %0A > and COBE, have determined that interstellar dust grain temperatures %0A > can range from 40K to 150K. %0A  %0A Interstellar grains are not at all close to blackbodies.  The "large" %0A grains have sizes of order 0.1 micron and absorb visible light with %0A fair efficiency.  However, at temperatures below 100 K, 90% of the %0A thermal emission will be beyond 22 microns, where radiating %0A efficiency is poor.  (A small antenna cannot easily radiate at long %0A wavelengths.)  Thus the grains must heat up more in order to radiate %0A the energy they have absorbed. %0A  %0A Moreover, the IRAS observations had a maximum wavelength of 100 %0A microns.  Grains colder than 30 K will radiate primarily at longer %0A wavelengths, and IRAS would be relatively insensitive to them.  In %0A the extreme limit, grains as cold as 5 K will be almost undetectable %0A by any conceivable observation. %0A  %0A Worse still, IRAS color temperatures are heavily contaminated by a %0A population of "small" grains.  These grains have only perhaps 50 %0A atoms, and when they are hit by a single photon they heat up to %0A temperatures of several hundred or 1000 K.  Of course they cool %0A quickly and then stay cold for a while, but _when they are radiating_ %0A the characteristic temperature is several hundred K.  Even a small %0A population of these grains can dramatically raise the observed %0A "average" temperature. %0A  %0A A model for local infrared emission consistent with COBE data has %0A three components.  These represent scattered radiation from Zodiacal %0A dust (color temperature 5500 K), thermal emission from Zodiacal dust %0A (Tc = 280 K), and thermal emission from Galactic dust (Tc=25 K).  At %0A the ecliptic poles, the emissivities or dilution factors are %0A respectively 1.9E-13, 4E-8, and 2E-5.  The first two are roughly %0A doubled in the ecliptic plane. %0A  %0A To find the thermal equilibrium temperature, we add up the dilution %0A factor times the fourth power of temperature for all components, then %0A take the fourth root.  In the table below, starlight comes from %0A Allen's number that stellar emission from the whole sky is equivalent %0A to 460 zero mag stars with B-V color of 0.75.  No doubt careful work %0A could do much better.  (The person who suggested starlight had a %0A dilution factor of E-4 must have been remembering wrong.  We would be %0A cooked if that were the case.  In any event, the energy density of %0A starlight comes out about the same as that of the microwave %0A background, and I believe that to be correct.) %0A  %0A                          Dilution   Temp.   DT^4 %0A Microwave background         1        2.7     53 %0A Galactic dust              2E-5      25        8 %0A Zodiacal dust (emission)   6E-8     280      369 %0A Zodiacal dust (scattering) 3E-13   5500      275 %0A Starlight                  1E-13   5500       92 %0A                                            ----- %0A                                              797 %0A  %0A The fourth root of 797 is 5.3 K.  Outside the Solar system, the %0A result would be 3.5 K.   %0A  %0A I find these results surprising, especially the importance of %0A Zodiacal dust, but I don't see any serious mistakes. %0A  %0A --  %0A Steve Willner            Phone 617-495-7123         Bitnet %3A    willner %40 cfa %0A Cambridge, MA 02138 USA                 Internet %3A  willner %40 cfa.harvard.edu %0A   member, League for Programming Freedom; contact lpf %40 uunet.uu.net %0A

I can detect pulses %0A that occur at about 2kHz, but not much faster.  Isn't the %0A rise/fall time of this device, something like 5uS? doc_5874 |@raw_text From %3A  mancus %40 sweetpea.jsc.nasa.gov (Keith Mancus) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Lindbergh and the moon (was %3A Why not give $1G) %0A Message-ID %3A  <1993Apr22.203130.11302 %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov (USENET News System) %0A Organization %3A  MDSSC %0A References %3A  <C5tEMs.80A %40 zoo.toronto.edu> <1r3nuvINNjep %40 lynx.unm.edu> <1993Apr21.160351.21895 %40 aio.jsc.nasa.gov> <C5v9Lr.KxF %40 news.cso.uiuc.edu> %0A Date %3A  Thu, 22 Apr 1993 20 %3A 31 %3A 30 GMT %0A Lines %3A  60 %0A  %0A jbh55289 %40 uxa.cso.uiuc.edu (Josh Hopkins) writes %3A  %0A >mancus %40 sweetpea.jsc.nasa.gov (Keith Mancus) writes %3A  %0A >>cook %40 varmit.mdc.com (Layne Cook) writes %3A  %0A >>> The $25k Orteig prize helped Lindbergh sell his Spirit %0A >>> of Saint Louis venture to his financial backers. But I strongly suspect %0A >>> that his Saint Louis backers had the foresight to realize that much more %0A >>> was at stake than $25,000. Could it work with the moon? Who are the %0A >>> far-sighted financial backers of today? %0A   %0A >>  The commercial uses of a transportation system between already-settled- %0A >>and-civilized areas are obvious.  Spaceflight is NOT in this position. %0A >>The correct analogy is not with aviation of the '30's, but the long %0A >>transocean voyages of the Age of Discovery. %0A > Lindbergh's flight took place in '27, not the thirties. %0A   %0A   Of course; sorry for the misunderstanding.  I was referring to the fact %0A that far more aeronautical development took place in the '30's.  For much %0A of the '20's, the super-abundance of Jennies and OX-5 engines held down the %0A industry.  By 1926, many of the obsolete WWI aircraft had been retired %0A and Whirlwind had their power/weight ratio and reliability up to the point %0A where long-distance flights became practical.  It's important to note that %0A the Atlantic was flown not once but THREE times in 1927 %3A   Lindbergh, %0A Chamberlin and Levine, and Byrd's _America_.  "When it's time to railroad, %0A you railroad." %0A  %0A >>It didn't require gov't to fund these as long as something was known about %0A >>the potential for profit at the destination.  In practice, some were gov't %0A >>funded, some were private. %0A >Could you give examples of privately funded ones? %0A  %0A   Not off the top of my head; I'll have to dig out my reference books again. %0A However, I will say that the most common arrangement in Prince Henry the %0A Navigator's Portugal was for the prince to put up part of the money and %0A merchants to put up the rest.  They profits from the voyage would then be %0A shared. %0A  %0A >>But there was no way that any wise investor would spend a large amount %0A >>of money on a very risky investment with no idea of the possible payoff. %0A >A person who puts up $X billion for a moon base is much more likely to do %0A >it because they want to see it done than because they expect to make money %0A >off the deal. %0A  %0A   The problem is that the amount of prize money required to inspire a %0A Moon Base is much larger than any but a handful of individuals or corporations %0A can even consider putting up.  The Kremer Prizes (human powered aircraft), %0A Orteig's prize, Lord Northcliffe's prize for crossing the Atlantic (won in %0A 1919 by Alcock and Brown) were MUCH smaller.  The technologies required were %0A within the reach of individual inventors, and the prize amounts were well %0A within the reach of a large number of wealthy individuals.  I think that only %0A a gov't could afford to set up a $1B+ prize for any purpose whatsoever. %0A   Note that Burt Rutan suggested that NASP could be built most cheaply by %0A taking out an ad in AvWeek stating that the first company to build a plane %0A that could take off and fly the profile would be handed $3B, no questions %0A asked. %0A  %0A --  %0A  Keith Mancus    <mancus %40 butch.jsc.nasa.gov>                           %7C %0A  N5WVR           <mancus %40 sweetpea.jsc.nasa.gov>                        %7C %0A  "Black powder and alcohol, when your states and cities fall,          %7C %0A   when your back's against the wall...." -Leslie Fish                  %7C %0A

How many optical %0A astronomers are *really* going to be impacted? %0A  %0A 	3) Which is more important; adding a few extra days of %0A 'seeing' for (very few) optical astronomers or getting the data the %0A sensors are supposed to return along with the data for large %0A inflatables (and the potential there for an inflatable space station)? %0A The choice would seem to be one or the other, since the advertising is %0A being used to help fund this thing. %0A  %0A 	4) If your answer to 3) above was "the astronomers", then feel %0A free to come up with some other way to fund the (to my mind) more %0A important research data that would be gained by this WITHOUT SPENDING %0A ANY MORE OF MY MONEY TO DO IT. In any case, a bright point of light passing through %0A the field doesn't ruin observations. If that were the case, the %0A thousands of existing satellites would have already done so (satelliets %0A might not seem so bright to the eyes, but as far as astronomy is concerned, %0A they are extremely bright.) %0A  %0A                                              Frank Crary %0A                                              CU Boulder %0A

doc_5900 |@raw_text From %3A  mrc %40 Ikkoku-Kan.Panda.COM (Mark Crispin) %0A Subject %3A  dogs %0A Message-ID %3A  <MS-C.735160298.1147902781.mrc %40 Ikkoku-Kan.Panda.COM> %0A Date %3A  18 Apr 93 05 %3A 11 %3A 38 GMT %0A Article-I.D. %3A  Ikkoku-K.MS-C.735160298.1147902781.mrc %0A Organization %3A  University of Washington %0A Lines %3A  52 %0A NNTP-Posting-Host %3A  ikkoku-kan.panda.com %0A MIME-Version %3A  1.0 %0A Content-Type %3A  TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII %0A  %0A I'm a biker and a dog-lover. %0A  %0A First and foremost, I want to mention some common sense.  If it's a choice %0A between injuring/killing a dog or getting yourself injured/killed, there is %0A only one rational decision.  Only the most insane animal rights kook would put %0A the dog first. %0A  %0A Second, it's useful to learn how to read a dog's body language.  How you react %0A to a dog who is chasing you because he thinks it's a game (and that you're %0A playing with him) is completely different from how you react to a dog which %0A has hostile intent. %0A  %0A Third, it's useful to learn how to present yourself to a dog.  Dogs are social %0A beasts, and recognize a domination/submission hierarchy.  To a dog, there are %0A two types of fellow-creatures; that which he dominates, and that which %0A dominate him.  You need to unambiguously represent yourself as being of the %0A latter class.  You are God %3A  you are easily angered and your anger is terrible. %0A But God is also amused by one who properly submits to His dominance, and may %0A even on rare occasions dispense a kind word, a kind word, or even (oh joy oh %0A rapture unforeseen) A Dog Bisquit! %0A  %0A Now, how does that all relate to biking?  Well, first, it's a good idea to %0A assume that most dogs who chase motorcycles do so because they think it's a %0A game, and not out of overt hostility.  The MSF suggestion is a very good one; %0A when you see the dog coming, slow down so he determines a particular place of %0A interception.  Just before you (and he) reach that spot, punch the throttle so %0A that when he reaches it you're already long gone.  Dogs take a few seconds to %0A react to new input, and definitely cannot comprehend the acceleration that a %0A motorcycle is capable of. %0A  %0A With a hostile dog, or one which you repeatedly encounter, stronger measures %0A may be necessary.  This is the face off.  First -- and there is very important %0A -- make sure you NEVER face off a dog on his territory.  Face him off on the %0A road, not on his driveway.  If necessary, have a large stick, rolled up %0A newspaper, etc. (something the beast will understand is something that will %0A hurt him).  Stand your ground, then slowly advance.  Your mental attitude is %0A that you are VERY ANGRY and are going to dispense TERRIBLE PUNISHMENT.  The %0A larger the dog, the greater your anger. %0A  %0A Dogs will pick up anger, just as they can pick up fear.  And, since you and he %0A are not on his home territory, it may suddenly dawn on the dog that perhaps he %0A is on your territory, and that you are prepared to fight to the death. %0A  %0A Most dogs will decide that it is a good idea to retreat to their own territory %0A where there is at least a home advantage.  They'll also observe that you are %0A satisfied by that retreat (gesture of submission) and thus they have escaped %0A punishment. %0A  %0A The interesting thing about dogs is that body language communicates a great %0A deal to them.  The more effective you are at communicating body language, the %0A less you actually have to do.  After 7 years with my 93 pound beast, I've %0A learned a few tricks I think... %0A

A standard LED  %0A drains 20mA. So what is the actual loop current required for an "off hook"  %0A indication, do you know? %0A  %0A Cheers  %0A Peter T. %0A  %0A

doc_5926 |@raw_text From %3A  mjs %40 sys.uea.ac.uk (Mike Sixsmith) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Countersteering, to know or not to know - what is the question? %0A Message-ID %3A  <mjs.735395430 %40 zen.sys.uea.ac.uk> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 sys.uea.ac.uk %0A Organization %3A  University of East Anglia %0A References %3A  <LOTTO.93Apr19121530 %40 husc4.harvard.edu> %0A Distribution %3A  net %0A Date %3A  Wed, 21 Apr 1993 12 %3A 30 %3A 30 GMT %0A Lines %3A  22 %0A  %0A lotto %40 husc4.harvard.edu (Jerry Lotto) writes %3A  %0A  %0A >There has been a running thread on the need to understand %0A >countersteering.  I have seen a lot of opinion, but not much of it has %0A >any basis in fact or study.  The bottom line is %3A  %0A  %0A >The understanding and ability to swerve was essentially absent among %0A >the accident-involved riders in the Hurt study. %0A  %0A >The "average rider" does not identify that countersteering alone %0A >provides the primary input to effect motorcycle lean by themselves, %0A >even after many years of practice. %0A  %0A I would agree entirely with these three paragraphs. But did the Hurt %0A study make any distinction between an *ability* to swerve and a *failure* %0A to swerve? In most of the accidents and near accidents that I've seen, riders %0A will almost always stand on the brakes as hard as they dare, simply because %0A the instinct to brake in the face of danger is so strong that it over-rides %0A everything else. Hard braking and swerving tend to be mutually exclusive %0A manouvres - did Hurt draw any conclusions on which one is generally preferable? %0A  %0A  %0A

doc_5941 |@raw_text From %3A  ajjb %40 adam4.bnsc.rl.ac.uk (Andrew Broderick) %0A Subject %3A  Re %3A  Solar Sail Data %0A Keywords %3A  Solar Sail %0A Message-ID %3A  <13432 %40 hardy.rl.ac.uk> %0A Date %3A  20 Apr 93 16 %3A 11 %3A 43 GMT %0A References %3A  <1993Apr15.051746.29848 %40 news.duc.auburn.edu> %0A Sender %3A  news %40 inf.rl.ac.uk %0A Organization %3A  Rutherford Appleton Lab, UK %0A Lines %3A  79 %0A  %0A In article <1993Apr15.051746.29848 %40 news.duc.auburn.edu> snydefj %40 eng.auburn.edu writes %3A  %0A > %0A >I am looking for any information concerning projects involving Solar %0A > Sails %0A  %0A I was at an interesting seminar at work (UK's R.A.L. Space Science %0A Dept.) on this subject, specifically on a small-scale Solar Sail %0A proposed as a student space project. The guy giving the talk was keen to %0A generate interest in the project. I'll typein the handout he gave out at %0A the meeting. Here goes  %3A   %0A  %0A 			The Microlight Solar Sail %0A 			------------------------- %0A  %0A 1. Introduction %0A The solar sail is a well-established concept. Harnessing the pressure of %0A sunlight, a spacecraft would have unlimited range. In principle, such a %0A vehicle could explore the whole Solar System with zero fuel consumption. %0A  %0A However it is more difficult to design a practical solar sail than most %0A people realize. The pressure of sunlight is only about one kilogram per %0A square kilometer. Deploying and controlling the large area of aluminized %0A fabric which would be necessary to transport a 'conventional' type %0A spacecraft is a daunting task. This is why, despite the potential of hte %0A idea, no such craft has actually been launched to date. %0A  %0A 2.Design %0A Recent advances in microelectronics make possible a different concept %3A  a %0A tiny sail just a few metres in diameter which could be controlled purely %0A be electronics, with no mechanical parts. Several attitude control %0A methods are feasible %3A  for example the pressure sunlight exerts on a %0A panel of solar cells varies according to whether power is being drawn. %0A  %0A The key components of the craft will be a minute CCD camera developed at %0A Edinburgh University which can act as both attitude sensor and data %0A gathering device; solar cells providing ~1 watt power for control and %0A communication; and a directional radio antenna etched onto the surface %0A of the sail itself. Launched as a piggyback payload, the total cost of %0A the mission can be limited to a few tens of thousands of dollars. %0A  %0A 3.Missions %0A The craft would be capable of some ambitious missions. For example %3A  %0A a) It could rendezvous with a nearby asteroid from the Apollo or Amor %0A groups. Closeup pictures could be transmitted back to Earth at a low bit %0A rate. %0A b) It could be steered into a lunar polar orbit. Previously unobserved %0A areas around the lunar poles could be viewed. By angling the sail to %0A reflect sunlight downwards, polar craters whose bases never receive %0A sunlight could be imaged. Bright reflections would confirm that %0A volatiles such as water ice have become trapped in these %0A locations.[Immensely valuable information for setting up a manned lunar %0A base, BTW] %0A c) It could be sent to rendezvous with a small asteroid or comet %0A nucleus. Impacting at low speed, a thin wire probe attached to the craft %0A causes it to rebound while capturing a tiny sample is a sharp-edged %0A tube, like performing a biopsy. Returning to Earth, the sail acts as an %0A ideal re-entry parachute %3A  load per unit area 20 gm/m2 ensures that heat %0A is reradiated so efectively that the sail temperature cannot exceed ~300 %0A deg C. The material sample is recovered, enclosed in a small insulating %0A container. %0A  %0A Contact %3A  Colin Jack                              Tel. 0865-200447 %0A Oxford Mathematical Designs, 131 High Street, Oxford OX1 4DH, England %0A  %0A -------------------------------- %0A  %0A This guy would love to hear from anyone interested in this project or %0A seeking details or anything, and would be most happy to send you more %0A information. %0A  %0A 	Andy %0A  %0A  %0A  %0A --  %0A                                   -----------------------------------  %0A Andy Jonathan J. Broderick,      %7C "I have come that they might have %7C %0A Rutherford Lab., UK              %7C  life, and have it to the full"   %7C %0A Mail  %3A  ajjb %40 adam2.bnsc.rl.ac.uk  %7C  - Jesus Christ                   %7C %0A

However I %0A always find disturbing the oxymoron of a "NO-OP" command that does something. %0A If the command changes the behavior or status of the spacecraft it is not %0A a "NO-OP" command. %0A  %0A Of course this terminology comes from a Jet Propulsion Laboratory which has %0A nothing to do with jet propulsion. %0A  %0A --  %0A ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- %0A Jim Cobban   %7C  jcobban %40 bnr.ca                        %7C  Phone %3A  (613) 763-8013 %0A BNR Ltd.     %7C  bnrgate.bnr.ca!bcars5!jcobban         %7C  FAX %3A    (613) 763-2626 %0A
